DOC.HEADLINE: KMT says to push ahead with U.N. referendum plan

TEXT.P: Even if the ruling party abandons its plans for a referendum calling for U.N. membership for Taiwan, the leader of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomingtan (KMT) has said that it would stick to its own proposal for having such a vote.
KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung was quoted as saying in a closed-door party meeting Tuesday that the KMT would push ahead no matter how much pressure might be coming from the United States or China.

A source who attended the meeting said that Wu made the remarks after other senior party officials expressed support for continuing their work toward having a referendum, likely to coincide with the presidential election scheduled for next March.
Wu's remarks came a day after the KMT, as required by the Referendum Law, submitted more than 126,000 sigatures along with its proposal for a referendum to the Central Election Commission.
The panel is expected to refer the case in mid-August to an Executive Yuan committee, which will then make a decision on the merit of having the vote.

Intended as a countermeasure to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's plan, the KMT proposal involves holding a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid "under all possible designations", including the Republic of China or Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court to hand down ruling Aug. 14 on ex-mayor's corruption case

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court will hand down a ruling Aug. 14 on an embezzlement case involving former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, the presiding judge dealing with the case announced Tuesday.

The trial judge made the announcement at the end of oral argument between the prosecution and the defendant at 11 p.m. He said the two parties can furnish the court with additional documents or files by Aug. 3.
Responding to the judge's question at the end of the last court hearing on the case whether he still maintains his innocence, Ma said: "Yes, I proclaim my innocence."
Ma, who is now the main opposition Kuomintang's candidate for the 2008 presidential election, was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of corruption.

The prosecutor said in the indictment that Ma abused his position to embezzle NT$11.17 million from a "special affairs fund" reserved for his discretionary use during his mayoral term from 1998 to 2006. The offense is subject to a minimum seven-year prison term.

During Tuesday's court hearing, the prosecution employed additional legal provisions against Ma, claiming that Ma's action also involved offenses of breach of trust prescribed in Article 342 and Article 134 of Criminal Code.

Article 134 states that a public official who takes advantage of his authority, opportunity or means afforded by his position to commit intentionally an offense not provided for in this chapter shall be subject to harsher punishment than that prescribed for such offense, with the prison term increased up to one half.

The maximum punishment for an offense of breach of trust is five years of imprisonment. Now that the prosecution demands a one-half increase of the punishment, the prison term could exceed seven years.

In the Ma's embezzlement case, Yu Wen, a Taipei city government secretary, was also indicted on charges of corruption and forgery. Several individuals who worked at the city government during Ma's tenure were given suspended charges.

Speaking at the last trial session, Ma argued that he didn't tell Hou Kuan-jen, the prosecutor responsible for investigating the case, during the first round of questioning that the "special affairs fund" was "public money" purely reserved for official functions.

Ma said the prosecutor took his statement out of context by claiming in the indictment that he admitted in the first round of prosecutorial questioning that the "special affairs fund" was "public money" that should be used for official purposes only.
According to Ma, what he said during the questioning was that the "special affairs fund" was not "public money." "The prosecutor took my deposition out of context," he said at the court.

Responding to Ma's statement, Hou said he was not surprised by Ma's claim, but he insisted that his record of Ma's deposition fully complied with Ma's true meaning and contained no twists or discrepancies.

"I clearly remembered that Ma spent more than an hour reading my record during the first round of questioning. He also requested correction of many sentences. He signed his name on my record only after the record was corrected and re- printed in line with his requests," Hou said, adding that his record truthfully reflected Ma's meaning.
Hou said Ma is welcome to apply for inspection of the original text of his record or audio and visual recordings of the first round of the questioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TB-infected couple return to Taiwan

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese couple with dangerous forms of tuberculosis (TB) who flew to China despite a travel ban have already returned to Taiwan on a helicopter arranged by the Department of Health (DOH), a DOH official said Tuesday.

Chou Chih-hao, deputy director of the DOH Center for Disease Control (CDC), said the husnad, identified only by his family name of Lee, has multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), and his wife, who has active TB, were sent to the DOH run Taichung Hospital in central Taiwan for treatment in aquarantine ward immediately after they arrived back in the country.

The Lees were escorted to Kinmen Island from the coastal Chinese city of Xiamen on a direct ferry Monday night. The DOH arranged for a helicopter to carry them to the Taichung Airport Thuesday evening, Chou said.

Lee's daughter-in-law was also diagnosed with MDR-TB and is undergoing medical treatment in an isolation ward, while Lee's father, who has been diagnosed with tuberculosis, has been discharged from the hospital after received treatment.
Lee's mother and eldest son do not have TB, Chou said.

The cost of the Lees' violation of the travel ban includes NT$40,000 (US$1,215) in travel fees for an epidemic control physician who had to travel to China to arrange for the Lees' return, NT$80,000 for renting a ferry and NT$200,000 for chartering the helicopter, Chou said, adding that additional expenditure in China had not yet been calculated.

Chou reminded the public to be aware of tuberculosis as it has a long latency period. Patients with tuberculosis should take medicine regularly and people who need to take care of family members with tuberculosis must wear masks in order to lower the infection risk, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 1 million Taiwanese tourists visit Hong Kong in first 6 months
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, July 31 (CNA) 08/01/07 11:07:21 (By Mandy Wong & Raven Yah)

TEXT.P: More than 1 million Taiwanese tourists visited Hong Kong during the first six months of this year, marking a 2.5 percent year-on-year increase and making Taiwan the second largest source of tourists to Hong Kong after China, a Hong Kong Tourism Board (HKTB) spokesman said Tuesday.

According to the HKTB statistics, over 184,000 Taiwanese visitors visited Hong Kong in June, an increase of 7.1 percent over the same period last year, while approximately 1.02 million Chinese traveled to Hong Kong, recording a 6.3 percent rise over the previous year.

The spokesman remarked that around 7.1 million Chinese tourists traveled to Hong Kong during the January-June period, including 3.85 million individual travelers which marked a 22 percent growth year-on-year.
During the first half of this year, the total number of visitors to Hong Kong exceeded 13 million, an increase of 6.8 percent compared with the same period of last year, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court acquits three charged with corruption in KRTC scandal

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung District Court acquitted Tuesday three defendants accused of corruption and breach of trust for not following government procurement procedures in conducting six public bids for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) project in 2002.

The three are former members of a five-member committee in charge of the Kaohsiung MRT project. They are former Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp (KRTC) Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien, former KRTC General Manager Lai Hsien-yu, and former Kaohsiung Bureau of Rapid Transit Systems Director Chou Li-liang.
The court handed down a not guilty verdict, saying that the government procurement law is not applicable to the six bids for public construction projects.

The court ruled that there was no evidence the trio affected fair competition among the bidders and that neither was there any evidence they had disclosed the minimum bid price to benefit particular construction companies.
The court found the other two former members of the committee guilty of taking bribes.

Chung Shan-tun, former secretary-general of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, received a sentence of four years in prison and will be stripped of his civil rights for two years after the end of his sentence. The NT$3 million he took in bribes will be confiscated.

Former Kaohsiung City Bureau of Urban Development Director Wu Meng-teh was sentenced to 12 years in prison, with his civil rights deprived for six years after the end of his sentence. He was ordered to give the NT$2 million he took in bribes to the national coffers.
A middleman and two construction company executives were given reduced sentences after pleading guilty to committing bribery.

Chang Chih-jung, former chairman of the New Culture Foundation, had his sentence reduced from eight months to four, while Japanese businessman Ryoji Kikawa and Chen Chien-ting, an assistant manager of a local construction company, also had their sentences slashed by half to two-and-a-half months and seven months, respectively.

The court found that Kikawa, a deputy manager of the Japanese construction company Taisei Corp., paid NT$128 million (US$3.98 million) to Chen for helping him to bribe Wu and Chung and win the bid for the CR5 project through rigging.
Chen gave NT$32 million to Chang, who gave NT$3 million to Chung and NT$2 million to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jailed blind Chinese human rights activist wins Magsaysay award
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, July 31 (CNA) 08/01/07 11:10:04 (By Emerson T. Lim and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An imprisoned blind Chinese human rights activist and a Hong Kong citizen dedicated to curbing the spread of HIV-AIDS were among seven individuals named Tuesday to receive the prestigious Ramon Magsaysay Award for 2007, the award foundation said.

Chen Guangcheng, 35, who is serving a four-year prison term after being convicted for his role in publicizing a ruthless population control program in Shandong Province in northern China, and Chung To, 40, founder of the Hong Kong- based Chi Heng Foundation, which works to curb the spread of HIV-AIDS and erase the stigma of those infected with the virus, share the Magsaysay award for the Emergent Leadership category, the foundation said.

Despite being blind since infancy, Chen became a "barefoot lawyer" providing legal aid for the poor and disadvantaged. His role in publicizing a ruthless population control program in Shandong Province, involving coerced abortions and involuntary sterilization, led to his conviction for "disturbing public order."
Chen was named by Time Magazine in 2006 as one of the "Top 100 people who shape our world."

This year's Magsaysay award also honored Tang Xiyang, 77, one of the leaders of the environmental movement in China. He founded an environmental magazine and organized "green camps" that introduced Chinese students to the need to protect wildlife in their country.
It is rare in recent memory that three Chinese have simultaneously won the award, which is sometimes considered Asia's equivalent of the Nobel Prize.
The Ramon Magsaysay Award was established in April 1957 by the trustees of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (RBF) based in New York City.

With the concurrence of the Philippine government, the prize was created to commemorate the late Philippines President Ramon Magsaysay and to perpetuate his example of integrity in government, courageous service to the people and pragmatic idealism within a democratic society.

Every year the Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation awards prizes to Asian individuals and organizations for achieving excellence in their respective fields. The awards are given in six categories -- government service, public service, community leadership, journalism, literature and creative communication arts, peace and international understanding, and emergent leadership.

This year's winners also include an Indian journalist who highlights vital social issues, a South Korean advocate for the disabled, a Nepalese pioneer in wireless technology and a Filipino known for fighting corruption.

The sole Filipino awardee this year was Jovito Salonga, 87, a former senator known for fighting against corruption and abuse. He was briefly jailed by the late President Ferdinand Marcos when the dictator declared martial law in 1972.
Although he has retired from politics, he remains a vocal critic of incumbent President Arroyo, once even comparing her to Marcos.

Journalist Palagummi Sainath, 50, was named for reporting on vital social issues in India focusing on the plight of the rural poor, a sector ignored by much of India's press, the award foundation said.
Mahabir Pun, 52, born in the Himalayan foothills of western Nepal, won a scholarship to the University of Nebraska but returned home after 20 years to help set up a village high school.
He played a crucial role in setting up a wireless network to link local schools and villages, changing the lives of residents in these once-isolated areas, the foundation said.

Another recipient, Kim Sun-Tae, 66, was blinded by a mortar shell during the Korean War but overcame poverty and disability to found the Siloam Eye Hospital in 1986, an institution for treating blindness and training the blind.
This year's winners will be honored in a ceremony to be held in Manila Aug. 31 when they will receive a medallion, a certificate and a cash prize.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 1, or the 19th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: British chemist Sir Joseph Priestley announces that he has discovered oxygen.
1834: Robert Morrison, the first English missionary to go to China and translator of the Bible into Chinese, dies.
1894: War between China and Japan over the question of Korea breaks out. The Treaty of Shimonoseki was signed the next year, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaotung Peninsula, Taiwan, and the Pescadores to Japan.
1915: The Peking government mints its silver coin, known as "Yuantatou," bearing the likeness of Yuan Shih-kai.
1926: Kwangtung University changes its name to National Sun Yat-sen University.
1927: The Chinese communists stage the Nanchang Uprising against the Nationalist government.
1928: The Central Broadcasting System is set up in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1941: American volunteer aviators form the "Flying Tigers," with Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault as commander. They help China combat Japanese air superiority in the early stages of World War II.
1943: Lin Sen, chairman of the Nationalist government, dies at the age of 76.
1949: The Office of Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang is established in Taipei.
1958: An insurance program providing 180,000 government employees with coverage for maternity leave, illness, injury, disability and death is put into effect.
1966: The Chinese Communist Party opens a plenum meeting that declares the start of the 10-year Cultural Revolution.
1971: The Tainan Giants of the Republic of China win the Little League Asian and Pacific play-offs.
1973: The Economic Planning Council (EPC) of the Executive Yuan is inaugurated. The EPC replaces the Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development.
1973: Gen. Kao Kuei-yuan takes over from Gen. Cheng Ta-ching as the Republic of China's minister of national defense.
1976: The National Reconstruction Seminar opens in Taipei with 130 local and overseas Chinese scholars participating.
1984: ROC athlete Tsai Wen-yee wins a bronze medal in weightlifting at the 1984 Olympic Games.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a slight increase in the premium rate of laborers' occupational injury insurance. The rates for thirty-two occupations are raised.
1987: The Council of Labor Affairs is formally established under the Executive Yuan.
1989: A foreign currency call loan market designed to make the metropolis an international financial center is established in Taipei.
1992: The National Unification Council defines "one China" as "one country and two areas each ruled separately by a different political entity."
1992: The Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters, the ROC's highest security institution, is disbanded, and the Coastal Patrol General Headquarters is established under the Ministry of National Defense.
1999: The U.S. Defense Department announces the sale of two E-2T Hawkeye 2000E airborne early warning aircraft and related equipment and services to Taiwan.
2000: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh pays a visit to New Party leader Hau Lung-bin, a move Hsieh said is aimed at showing respect to the opposition.
2000: Taiwan resident Huang You-fu becomes the 10 millionth traveler to pass through Macau International Airport.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By attending to the cleanliness and purity of his person and the propriety and dignity of his dress, and in every word and act permitting nothing which is contrary to good taste and decency, that is how the ruler puts in order his personal conduct."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. position on Taiwan's U.N. bid unchanged: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, July 31 (CNA) 08/01/07 13:10:27 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States has not changed its stance concerning Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations, a U.S. State Department official said Tuesday.

The official was responding to a reporter's question on whether Washington has put more pressure on President Chen Shui-bian and warned him not to carry on with promoting the bid, in the wake of the submission of a second letter by Chen to the United Nations applying for U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan."

"I'm not aware of any particular conversations that may have been held on this, but U.S. views on these issues are consistent and remain the same, and I don't think that's a surprise to anybody, " State Department Deputy spokesman Tom Casey said during a daily press briefing.

Over the past two months, State Department officials have on a number of occasions stated that the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood, including the United Nations.

Also, the officials said the United States opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally, including a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan, " adding that such a plan would appear to run counter to Chen's repeated commitments to Washington.
Taiwan officially filed a membership application with the United Nations July 19 in a letter signed by Chen.

However, the letter was returned July 24 by the U.N. Secretariat, based on Resolution 2758, which was adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1971 recognizing the representatives of the People's Republic of China government as "the only legitimate representatives of China to the United Nations" and expelling representatives of the Republic of China on Taiwan.
Taiwan sent another letter to the United Nations July 26 to defend its right to gain membership in the organization.

According to ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang, it is unreasonable for the U.N. Secretariat to misrepresent Resolution 2758 as recognizing that "Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China."

Huang said the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" has nothing to do with changing the status quo or changing the country's official name and is instead aimed at differentiating Taiwan from the People's Republic of China.

At Tuesday's press briefing at the State Department, Casey said "there is a longstanding U.S. policy on that" when asked about President Chen's plan to make transit stops in the United States for his planned visit to Central America in late August.

Washington has repeatedly stated that it handles requests by Taiwan's leaders to stop over in the United States according to the principles of security, comfort, convenience and dignity for the travelers.
However, there has been speculation that Taiwan's plan to push for a referendum on the U.N. issue despite U.S. opposition could affect Chen's transit plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free kindergarten education for kids from low-income families begins

TEXT.P: Free one-year kindergarten education will be offered to children from low-income families beginning Wednesday, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced earlier in the day.

Five-year-olds from families with annual incomes lower than NT$300,000 (US$9,146) nationwide are now entitled to receive free kindergarten education as part of the government's efforts to address the issue of declining birth rates in the country and help reduce the financial burden of families with children, Chang said during an Executive Yuan meeting.
Meanwhile, five-year-olds from families with annual incomes ranging from NT$300,000 to NT$600,000 are entitled to attend kindergarten without having to pay tuition fees, Chang said.

A total of 81,000 kids are expected to benefit from the program, which forms the first-phase of an Executive Yuan project to financially aid children from low- income or disadvantaged families, Chang added.

As to programs in later phases of the project, Chang said he has instructed Minister Without Portfolio Lin Chin-chang to map out plans and coordinate with colleagues from other Cabinet-level agencies so as to put forth the programs within one month.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 government budget projected at NT$1.7 trillion

TEXT.P: The central government has tentatively projected its 2008 budget at NT$1.7 trillion (US$51.83 billion), with the defense budget accounting for 20 percent of the total, a senior official said Wednesday.
Hsu Jan-yau, minister of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, made the remarks a day after Premier Chang Chun-hsiung called an inter-departmental budget planning meeting.

Chang was quoted as having said at the meeting that the restriction of the government's annual expenditures at NT$1.7 trillion is aimed at maintaining the country's global credit rating competitiveness.
Noting that the government is set to achieve the goal of a balanced budget by 2011, Chang said the budget deficit should be narrowed gradually.
According to Hsu, the government's draft 2008 budget bill lists overall revenues at NT$1.6 trillion. As a result, the government will incur a budget deficit of NT$100 billion.
On the revenue side, tax revenues are projected at NT$1.18 trillion, marking a 6.9 percent year-on-year increase. Of the amount, stock transaction tax revenues are projected at NT$150 billion.

On the government expenditures, Hsu said, the defense budget will increase by about NT$40 billion from the 2007 level to reach NT$340 billion. The confidential budget for the procurement of three big-ticket weaponry systems has also been appropriated.
The budget for science and technology development is listed at NT$88 billion, up 7.5 percent from the 2007 level, Hsu said.

He further said it remains uncertain whether government employees, teachers and military personnel will get a pay raise in the coming year. If a 3 percent pay raise is to be implemented, he said, the central government must seek new funds to finance the project.
As to the national pension fund project set to be implemented next October, Hsu said that it will mainly be financed with earnings from public-interest lottery sales.
According to Hsu, the Executive Yuan has informed all agencies under its jurisdiction of their respective expenditure ceilings for 2008.

All agencies are required to draft their budget plans in line with fiscal rules and present them for discussion at the Executive Yuan's Aug. 22 weekly meeting, Hsu said, adding that the Executive Yuan is set to refer its 2008 budget bill to the Legislative Yuan at the end of this month for deliberation and approval in the next legislative session scheduled to open in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices slump on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slumped Wednesday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 395.37 points to close at 8,891.88.
The bourse opened at 9,188.6 and fluctuated between 9,265.7 and 8,891.88 during trading. A total of 8.42 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$270.64 billion (US$8.24 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 6.1 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 5.7 percent, foodstuff issues at 5.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares and paper and pulp issues both at 4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 3.7 percent, textile stocks at 3.6 percent, and construction issues at 2.3 percnet.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 283, with 87 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT terms added charges against ex-mayor 'judicial persecution'

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) claimed Wednesday that Taipei prosecutors' additional charges against former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou by employing additional legal provisions is "judicial persecution."

At the last court hearing held Tuesday on Ma's embezzlement case, the prosecutors employed additional legal provisions against Ma, deciding that his action also involved the offense of breach of trust prescribed in Article 342 and Article 134 of the Criminal Code, in addition to charges of corruption and forgery that had been brought against him previously.

Article 134 states that a public official who takes advantage of his authority, opportunity or means afforded by his position to intentionally commit an offense not provided for in this chapter shall be subject to harsher punishment than that prescribed for such offense, with the prison term increased by up to one half.
The maximum punishment for breach of trust is five years in prison. Now that the prosecution demands a one-half increase in the punishment, the prison term for Ma could exceed seven years.
The Taipei District Court is expected to hand down a ruling Aug. 14 on the case.

Condemning the prosecutors' charges, Hsu Shao-ping, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, claimed that the prosecutors' moves have underlined an accusation by President Chen Shui-bian only one day earlier that "judicial personnel might try to interfere in the 2008 presidential election."
KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said that only the rulers in office have the ability to manipulate the judiciary and called for judicial personnel not to succumb to the pressure from the ruling party.

Ma, who is now the KMT's candidate for the 2008 presidential election, has been indicted on charges of embezzling NT$11.17 million from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use while he served as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.
Prosecutors stated in their Feb. 13 indictment that the special fund was set aside by the government to reimburse the mayor for job-related spending.

They said that although the government's regulations allow the mayor to use half of the fund by simply signing a receipt instead of providing vouchers to account for his spending, the money should go toward job-related spending and that any remaining funds should be returned to the government coffers.

According to KMT Legislator Lin Teh-fu, the prosecutors' attempts to undermine Ma's presidential candidacy and sway the campaigns of the presidential candidates are "obvious" and he called for members of the judicial system to resist pressure from the government.

KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said that Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate for 2008, a former mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, has also been accused of misusing special allowance funds but has never been subpoenaed for questioning by the prosecution, which he claimed is "proof" that the prosecution is exercising double standards on mayoral usage of special allowance funds, despite affirmation by the Kaohsiung prosecutors that they are still compiling their evidence against Hsieh.

Responding to the KMT lawmakers' criticism, Wang Tuoh, the whip of the DPP legislative caucus, called for the KMT to "show some respect for the judicial system," adding that the KMT is damaging its own image every time it accuses the judiciary of "exerting political interference in cases" whenever a KMT heavyweight is indicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tariffs for seven kinds of commodities to be halved for six months

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Wednesday more measures aimed at stabilizing consumer prices, including temporarily halving the import duties for seven kinds of commodities for a period of six months.
The targeted commodities are durum wheat, wheat flour, groats and wheatmeal, corn for feed, cornflour, corn distillers grain and soy beans.
Making the announcement during a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chang instructed the Ministry of Finance to work out related details to pave the way for the measure's implementation.

According to Chang, the government has the responsibility to take steps to relieve inflation, given the sharp rise in the wholesale price index so far this year, owing to hikes in international oil, primary metal and commodity prices.

While the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) should conduct a comprehensive review of the floating oil pricing system, the MOEA and the Fair Trade Commission (FTC) should closely monitor the prices of major raw materials and consumer products to check for any abnormal fluctuations and bring to justice those responsible for manipulating prices, Chang said.
In particular, he went on, the MOEA and FTC should investigate if any irregularities are behind a 4.7 percent hike in local corn prices when international corn prices have dropped 17.1 percent.
Chang ordered the MOEA's raw material supply/demand coordination panel to examine the supply and demand of major consumer products and work out related adjustment measures.
For example, he said, the panel can adopt measures restricting the export of products experiencing significant hikes, such as steel, oil, waste paper and gravel.

Meanwhile, the premier instructed the MOEA to step up its efforts to promote energy conservation measures, enhance energy efficiency, speed up the development of renewable energy and lower the demand for crude oil-based fuel to reduce the pressure from soaring oil prices.

As part of the government's efforts to ease the impact of the soaring oil prices on businesses, the Cabinet announced last week that the state-operated petroleum company, CPC Corp. Taiwan, will provide each mass transport operator with a subsidy of NT$3 per liter of diesel fuel and each cab driver with a subsidy of NT$2 per liter of gasoline.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.061 to close at NT$32.866.
A total of US$1.06 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.755 and fluctuated between NT$32.720 and NT$32.918.

DOC.HEADLINE: Counterfeit ring busted by IPR police

TEXT.P: The intellectual property rights (IPR) police under the National Police Administration announced Wednesday that it had recently cracked down on a counterfeit ring that had produced fake big-name sports socks and marketed them online.

After securing evidence, the IPR police raided a warehouse Monday in Shulin City, Taipei County, where they discovered nearly 1,000 pairs of counterfeit Nike, Adidas, Puma and Levi's sports socks and arrested a man surnamed Lai, suspected of being the ringleader.
The police referred Lai to the Panchiao District Prosecutors Office for further questioning.

Lai is suspected of selling the counterfeit sports socks on the Internet and delivering them to online customers by mail. His products were described as being as good as the genuine versions, bearing identical labels and including the latest styles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Austronesian forum preparatory office established

TEXT.P: A preparatory office for the proposed Austronesian forum was formally established Wednesday in Taipei, with President Chen Shui-bian presiding over the ceremony.

According to the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) , representatives from eight countries, including six of Taiwan's South Pacific diplomatic allies and the Philippines, met in Taipei Tuesday for discussions on the establishment of an Austronesian forum, beginning with the setting up of the preparatory office.

The move to set up the forum, which would include Taiwan, the Philippines, Tuvalu, Nauru, Kiribati, Palau, the Marshall Islands and the Solomon Islands, is seen as part of efforts to implement President Chen Shui-bian's "Palau Declaration" that Chen signed last year with his South Pacific counterparts aimed at sharing, preserving and promoting Austronesian cultures that the eight countries have in common, as well as strengthening relations, CIP officials said.

After its establishment, the forum is also expected to boost efforts concerning the holding of academic conferences on Austronesian cultures and exchanges, increasing Austronesian participation in Asia-Pacific and international organizations, and demonstrating a commitment to indigenous development, the CIP officials said.
Meanwhile, the officials said, an Austronesian Forum secretariat is expected to be established next year in Taiwan, which will provide the majority of the funding for the forum.

The forum will also work to invite other countries, such as New Zealand, to become members and welcome the participation of government officials, academics and non-government organization workers, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three companies fined over excessive water use

TEXT.P: Three companies were recently fined by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) over excessive water use, an EPA official said Wednesday.

The three companies -- Formosa Plastics Corp., Formosa Chemicals and Fiber Corp. and Nan Chung Petrochemical Corp. -- used excessive water to the tune of 10.1 percent, 4.7 percent and 20 percent, respectively, according to a survey conducted by the EPA July 3-15, the official said.

The EPA decided to fine them due to their failure to follow stipulations on water usage described in an environmental impact assessment the EPA made to demand that companies conserve water, the official said.

Formosa Plastics Corp., the official noted, was fined NT$1 million (US$30,443.25) , followed by Formosa Chemicals and Fiber Corp., which was fined NT$850,000, and Nan Chung Petrochemical Corp., which was fined NT$650,000.
The EPA will conduct another survey before Dec. 31 to make sure that the companies are following the assessment report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drug-use most frequent recidivism after commutation: MOJ

TEXT.P: Drug-use is the most frequent recidivism of prisoners released under the sentence commutation statute enacted July 16, with 35 out of a total of 58 recidivism cases related to drug offenses, a Ministry of Justice (MOJ) official said Wednesday.

Quoting MOJ statistics, the official said 11,148 prison inmates had been released under the commutation statute as of July 27, of whom 4,840 were offenders under the Narcotic Drugs Hazard Control Act.
Some 1,872 were previously jailed for theft, and 756 were imprisoned for fraud, the second- and third-largest groups, the official said.

A commutation beneficiary in Chiayi County in central Taiwan, who was first imprisoned for offenses against the Domestic Violence Prevention Act, violated the act again after being released, the official went on.

Two released inmates in Taichung county and Yunlin county, respectively, who were previously jailed for theft, committed robbery after being released, while other recidivists included 12 commutation beneficiaries who committed theft, one who murdered a National Taiwan University associate professor, three who committed offenses against public security, two charged with interfering with public functions, one charged with causing bodily harm and one violation of the Electronic Game Arcade Business Regulation Act, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Italian iconic film-director Michelangelo Antonioni, renowned for his 1966 relese Blow-up, died at home Monday night at the age of 94. His funeral will take place in his home town of Ferrera, north-eastern Italy, on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Export of processed waste paper to be banned

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is planning to ban the export of processed waste paper from Taiwan in order to help stabilize paper prices on the domestic market, Economics Minister Steve R.L. Chen said Wednesday.

Spiraling pulp prices on the international market have pushed up the prices of related commodities, including waste paper, and the domestic paper processing industry is sustaining the impact of a shortage of paper materials as a result of brisk exports of waste paper due to higher profit gains, according to MOEA officials.
Chen said the administration is now forced to consider banning waste paper exports in the same way it imposed a temporary ban on steel exports nearly two years ago.
The ban on waste paper exports could be announced later in the day, while the date for lifting the ban will be left open, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow TimesGPutin Emphasizes Support for Abbas
President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday came out in support of Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas, as the Foreign Ministry announced that it was downgrading its ties with Hamas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan submits second membership application to United Nations

TEXT.P: Taiwan has submitted a second membership application to the United Nations after the first one was rejected by the U.N. Secretariat, a Presidential Office official said Wednesday.

The application was delivered to the United Nations July 31 through the Solomon Islands' and Swaziland's permanent representatives to the world body, said Lee Nan-yang, director of the Presidential Office's department of public affairs.

It was included in two letters dated July 27 and signed by President Chen Shui- bian, which were addressed separately to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon and Wang Guangya, rotating president of the U.N. Security Council for July and China's permanent representative to the United Nations, Lee said.

Lee noted that this marks the first time the president has written to the Security Council, in what he said is a move aimed at facilitating the discussion of cross-Taiwan Strait issues on the U.N. platform.

According to Lee, while China has repeatedly labeled Taiwan's efforts to deepen its democratic development as moves toward de jure independence, Beijing is trying to achieve de jure unification through the enactment of its Anti- Secession Law and what Taiwan claims is "misrepresentation" of U.N. Resolution 2758.

Under the circumstances, Taiwan must make sure its membership application is fully discussed on every possible occasion prior to the opening of next month's annual session of the U.N. General Assembly, to "correct international misperceptions" of Resolution 2758, Lee said.

The U.N. Secretariat rejected Taiwan's first membership application July 23 based on the resolution, which was adopted by the General Assembly in 1971 recognizing the representatives of the People's Republic of China government as "the only legitimate representatives of China to the United Nations" and expelling representatives of the Republic of China.

Responding to a question on the issue by a CNA reporter last week, Ban pointed out that U.N. membership is only granted to sovereign countries and that the position of the United Nations is that Taiwan is part of China.

In the latest letter to Ban, Chen said that Resolution 2758 neither grants China the right to represent Taiwan at the United Nations, nor states that Taiwan is either a part of China or the People's Republic of China.
Chen said that Taiwan is an independent sovereign nation and that its people have the right to participate in the United Nations.

In addition, he urged Ban to process Taiwan's application according to due procedure, because only the Security Council and the General Assembly have the authority to review and decide on membership applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan researchers reveal reasons for high SARS fatalities

TEXT.P: Virologists at National Yang-Ming University (NYMU) in Taipei have discovered the causes for the high morbidity of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) , indicating that mutations in a specific protein in the SARS virus can greatly accelerate the viral replication process, university sources reported Wednesday.

The proteins are susceptible to mutations once the SARS coronavirus gets inside humans, explained NYMU professor Chen Yi-ming, adding that the human- type SARS viruses can thus replicate themselves 60 to 100 times faster than pre- mutation ones, resulting in high mortality rates.
Chen said that if a targeted drug aimed at reducing or even inhibiting the relevant protein and related mechanisms can be created, humans might eventually have an effective SARS prevention method.
The understanding of the protein might also facilitate the study of cancer metastasis, he added.
The results have been published by the U.S.-based Journal of Infectious Diseases, first in its online version July 19 and then in print in its Aug. 1 issue.
Scientists have found the expression on the aggressiveness of SARS viruses is very different in cases of civets and humans in previous studies.

Based on those findings, Chen Chia-yen -- a member of Chen Yi- ming's team and the lead author of the research paper -- conducted a series of genetic comparisons between the SARS coronaviruses in civets and humans, leading to the discovery of the protein mutations.
Chen found that the variations not only induce apoptosis phenomena in viruses but also greatly accelerate the replication process.

During the following experiments, Chen and colleagues deployed a small interfering RNA on the mutated protein to find that the RNA can interrupt the replication process -- indicating a possibility in developing a new drug based on that effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSID to organize 1st Taiwan interior design contest

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based Chinese Society of Interior Designers (CSID) will hold the first Taiwan Interior Design Award contest this year with the aim of making Taiwan a leading nation in space design in Asia, CSID Director-General Yao Cheng-chung said Wednesday.
Yao said the contest will provide an exchange platform for space designers and will introduce the creativity of outstanding Taiwanese designers to the international community.

The CSID has invited international design giants to serve as jurors, including Konstantin Grcic, a German designer who designs products for some of Europe's leading design companies, and Claus Sendlinger, chairman and CEO of Design Hotels AG, a hotel consulting company.
The contest has no limitations on participants' nationalities, Yao said, adding that this will help promote Taiwanese designers' visibility in the world.

People who have work experience in relevant fields can apply to compete in any of the contest's four categories -- home space, work space, business space and public space -- by sending portfolio samples of work completed in the last two years.

Judging will be carried out in three stages in four criteria -- concept, worth 30 percent of the total score; innovation, also worth 30 percent; function, worth 20 percent; and environmental protection, worth 20 percent.
Enrollment will take place Aug. 15-31 and judging will be carried out Sept. 7-15, with the winners announced Sept. 21, Yao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: St. Vincent Prime Minister calls U.N. rejection `blunder'

TEXT.P: Visiting St. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves has called U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon's failure to deliver Taiwan's application to the world body to the Security Council a "blunder."
Gonsalves added that he will continue to throw his support behind Taiwan at the U.N. in September.
Gonsalves, who is visiting Taiwan, made the remarks during a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office Tuesday.
He reaffirmed St. Vincent's backing for Taiwan, saying that he will assist the country in delivering the letter containing Taiwan's U.N. membership application to the Security Council.
Gonsalves urged Taiwan's other allies to follow suit and mount pressure on the U.N. Secretariat.
Gonsalves said he has spoken for Taiwan at the world body every year for three years, adding that he will continue to do so this year.

Chen, for his part, said recent polls show that 95 percent and 75 percent of the Taiwan public support the government's bids to apply for World Health Organization (WHO) and U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan, respectively.

Saying that the U.N. should respect the voice of the Taiwan majority, Chen added that the people should not be deprived of their rights according to the principle of universal membership stated in the U.N. Charter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Openness gives learning a brand new future: Wikipedia founder

TEXT.P: A world without schools, in which children learn at home using tailor-made textbooks and educational programs was imaginatively invoked by Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales Wednesday, who predicted that such a change in education will be brought about through the "openness" and "open source" movements.

The 40-year-old American internet entrepreneur, who founded the popular multilingual web-based free content encyclopedia, attended the "Openness in the 21st Century" forum on the eve of Wikimania 2007, an international Wikimedia conference which will be held from Aug. 3 - 5.

Wikipedia, which was created in 2001 and soon grew into one of the largest reference Web sites, is a model of voluntary collaboration and global contribution, with articles that can be edited by anyone with Internet access.

"Imagine a world in which every single person on the planet is given free access to the sum of all human knowledge, " Wales said in describing the motivation behind Wikipedia in a 2004 interview with Slashdot. The project has been trying to make that vision a reality through the accumulation of basic and neutral information, cross-referencing, citation and the always on-going editing.
Its "peer-to-peer" editing process is far different from the "top down" process behind the production of traditional encyclopedias and textbooks.

Wales pointed to the example of software projects, which tend to grow more robust and perform better after becoming "open-source" and being co-developed by professional enthusiasts, while remaining free of charge.

Education might undergo the same type of evolution through the introduction of a mentality of openness, said Wales, himself a product of home-schooling who later took a Ph. D finance program at Indiana University.

The current school-based educational system is outdated and not well-suited to serving all students' needs, he claims, then predicts that textbook copyrights in the future will be freely licensed, and that social communities will become major sources of knowledge production.

Wales says he need look no further than his own family for an example of what is to come. His daughter, Kira, has received all of her education at home and now is studying third grade mathematics although still a kindergartner. Wales uses a home-learning program he found in Singapore to help Kira with the content and schedule of her schooling.
In the future, the Internet will provide children and students with various learning methods, he said, and best of all, deliver the knowledge at a low cost.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's solar output ranks 5th globally

TEXT.P: Taiwan's total solar energy output grew by leaps and bounds in 2006 and now ranks fifth in the world, Director-General of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Yeh Huei-ching said Wednesday.

Yeh said the total output value of solar energy in 2006 reached about NT$21.2 billion (US$644.2 million) , while the total output value in 2007 is expected to exceed NT$43 billion and rank fourth worldwide in terms of total output.

Seeking to facilitate exchanges of information and technology in this field, the Industrial Technology Research Institute of Taiwan established the Taiwan Photovoltaic Industry Association, the membership of which now includes a total of 102 industrial firms.
Association members include Motech Industries Inc., E-TON Solar Tech Co., Sino- American Silicon Products Inc., Green Energy Technology Inc., and TOPSOC Semiconductor Corp.

To help ensure market success, the Bureau of Energy has increased its budget to promote solar power production, and the MOEA has set up ateam to improve the production of polysilicon -- a material necessary for the next generation of thin film solar energy cells -- and made efforts to ensure legislative approval of statutes governing the development of renewable energy, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier attends inauguration of anti-domestic violence coalition

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung attended the inauguration ceremony of the Taiwan Coalition Against Domestic and Sexual Violence at Soochow University's downtown campus in Taipei City Wednesday.
The coalition's convener Kao Feng-hsien, who is also a judge, said the coalition has been operating for more than two years as an informal organization comprised of 15 civic groups.
Through its formal establishment, the organization -- now composed of 24 groups and more than 10 individuals -- aims to provide assistance to more people in need.

Chang expressed gratitude for the efforts coalition members have made to promote human rights in Taiwan before its formal establishment, including steps taken to ensure legislative approval of the Sexual Harassment Prevention Act, the Sexual Assault Prevention Act, and the Domestic Violence Prevention Act.

Chang said that he has asked the Ministry of the Interior and the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission to work on resolving problems such as the coalition's shortage of funds to cover expenditures, volunteer workers and malfunctions on the government's "113" domestic violence prevention hotline.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA bans waste paper exports

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) formally banned waste paper exports Wednesday as part of its efforts to maintain domestic price stability in the face of China's raw material buying spree.
The ban takes effect immediately, MOEA officials said, adding that the date for lifting the ban has been left open.
The export ban applies to all sorts of waste paper, including old newspapers, magazines, paper shards, unbleached kraft paper, corrugated paper and paperboard, the officials said.

Waste paper is an important material in the production of paper for industrial use. According to MOEA tallies, Taiwan needs about 4 million tons of waste paper annually. In 2006, Taiwan had to import 760,000 tons of waste paper to meet demands as only 325 tons of waste paper were recycled. Waste paper exports also reached 32,000 tons last year.

In July this year, waste paper was sold for between NT$4.2 and NT$4.6 per kilogram, an increase of more than 60 percent over the average price of NT$2.6 recorded in January. Meanwhile waste paper exports in the first half of this year topped 25,000 tons, a whopping 94 percent rise.

Given its manufacturing industrial boom, China's demand for industrial-use paper has increased substantially. As China's waste paper recycle system has not yet fully developed, it has to secure supplies from around the world, pushing up global waste paper prices, the officials said.

With a view to maintaining domestic price stability and ensuing adequate waste supplies for the production of industrial paper, the officials said the MOEA has to suspend waste paper exports for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate pledges to complete formulation of new constitution

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that if he is elected, he will be able to realize the goal of rectifying the country's name and enacting a new constitution in five years' time.
Hsieh also promised to give the country a new constitution within the same time frame, but described the two moves as "not tantamount to a change in the status quo."
Hsieh made the remarks in a TV talk show program broadcast on SANLIH Entertainment TV.
Hsieh said that he is not confident that he will be able to complete the name rectification and bring in a new constitution during his first presidential term.

However, in the fifth year following his assumption of the presidency, when Taiwan is slated to hold its eighth legislative elections, Hsieh expects that 70 percent or 80 percent of locl voters will identify with Taiwan and therefore support the two moves that are critical to the pursuit of making Taiwan a normal country.
Against such backdrop, Hsieh said, the DPP could garner three quarters of the seats in the Legislative Yuan, which will be conducive to pushing for the changes.
Hsieh said that he will communicate with the United States if it still opposes Taiwan's campaign for name rectification and enactment of new constitution at that time.

Hsieh added that with the support from the majority of Taiwan's lawmakers he will be able to convince the U.S. government by that time, although it will also be necessary to take into account the national security and the international situations.
He stressed that he will not gamble on Taiwan's national security.
Hsieh explained that the move to push for name rectification is not an attempt to change the status quo. Rather, it is a part of the government's efforts to transform Taiwan into a normal country.

Speaking on Taiwan's U.N.-membership bid, Hsieh said that the country is not likely to realize its goal in the near future, however, the recent bid to join the world body under the name of Taiwan is helpful in raising the country's international profile.

Lambasting U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon's recent rejection of President Chen Shui-bian's letter expressing Taiwan's intention to join the United Nations as a full member, Hsieh said the world body expelled the Chiang Kai-shek regime, not Taiwan, in 1971.
Now, however, the U.N. wrongly considers Taiwan to be part of the People's Republic of China, Hsieh criticized.
The late president Chiang retreated to Taiwan after losing China to the Communist Party and began 55 years of Kuomintang (KMT) rule in Taiwan.

Hsieh said that he supports holding a referendum aimed at backing the country's bid to join the U.N. under the name of Taiwan, but notes that he has promised the U.S. government that he will not hold a referendum on Taiwan's independence if elected.
He stated that Taiwan is already a sovereign, independent country, and that there is no need to organize a referendum on Taiwan's independence.
Nevertheless, Hsieh said that he does not rule out the possibility of convening a referendum on Taiwan's unification with China.
Noting that few people in the world favor the island's unification with China, Hsieh remarked that Taiwan could use such a referendum as a diplomatic bargaining chip in the future.

In addition, Hsieh said that if elected, his administration will not, in principle, recognize academic degrees issued by China out of consideration of the possible impact on employment and education system in Taiwan.
However, Hsieh said that exceptions could be made for traditional herbal medicine accreditation, which China takes lead.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st half-year turnover of Taichung park exceeds NT$110 billion

TEXT.P: The Central Taiwan Science Park's business turnover for the first six months of the year topped NT$110.8 billion (US$3.37 billion) , slightly less than half of the expected revenues for the whole year, a spokesman for the park's administration said Wednesday.

Business turnover for the second half of the year is expected to be more than the first half year's, so it is likely that the NT$240 billion target projected for the year will be realized, the spokesman said, noting that two 12-inch silicon wafer plants will start operations in the third quarter.
Those two plants belong to ProsMOS Technologies Inc. and Rexchip Electronics Corp, the spokesman said.

A total of 36 firms acquired business registration certificates and began operations in the park during the first six months. Among these, 11 are optical electronic firms, five are semiconductor industrial firms, 11 are involved in the precision machinery, while another nine firms are in the computer peripheral business.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Dow Jones Deal Gives Murdoch a Coveted Prize
Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize yesterday, gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and one of the worlds most respected news sources, for $5 billion.
Wall Street Journal:News Corp.'s Success Follows Delicate Dance Between Suitor and Target
The Bancroft family decision to sell Dow Jones & Co. capped a three-month public tango between them and Rupert Murdoch, the chairman and chief executive of News Corp.
Behind the scenes, however, the media mogul had orchestrated a deal over two years. He quietly gathered intelligence on Dow Jones's operations and consulted Wall Street figures to plot his moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to adopt 'normal country resolution'

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will adopt a "normal country resolution" at its upcoming national congress to underscore its determination to make Taiwan a normal country, a party official said Wednesday.

DPP Secretary-General Lin Jia-lung said the party's policy research unit has drafted the proposed "normal country resolution" which clearly states that Taiwan is an independent sovereign country and is by no means subjugated to China's jurisdiction.
The resolution also advocates rectifying the country's title as "Taiwan" and speeding up creation of a new constitution that is timely, viable, fitting and relevant to Taiwan, Lin said.

The draft resolution will be referred to a nine-member panel under the DPP's Central Standing Committee for a review and then be sent to the party's Central Executive Committee for a further screening before being presented to the party congress to be held in autumn for final approval.

Stressing that Taiwan's sovereignty belongs to the people of Taiwan, Lin said Taiwan must adopt a "normal country resolution" to tell the world of its action plans to attain its ultimate goal of developing Taiwan into a normal and great country. The actions will include rectifying its national designation, formulating a new constitution, joining the United Nations, beefing up its national identity and substantiating transitional justice.

TEXT.P: 2. Event: News conference on the ractopamine issue and Taiwan's hog industry Date and Time: 02:30 p.m., Thursday, Aug. 2, 2007 Place: DPP caucus office at Legislative Yuan, No. 1, Zhongshan S. DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 2, or the 20th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: William II, known as "William Rufus," king of England from 1087, is slain by an arrow while hunting in New Forest. He was succeeded by his younger brother, who became Henry I.
1798: A 14-vessel naval squadron commanded by Rear Adm. Horatio Nelson scores a brilliant tactical victory over a French fleet of 17 vessels in the Mediterranean.
1918: British, French, and U.S. troops try to smash Lenin's communist revolution by supporting the White Russian forces and seizing Archangel.
1921: Enrico Caruso, the Neapolitan with the golden voice known as the world's greatest tenor of his time, dies at the Hotel Vesuvio in Naples at the age of 48.
1922: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor of the telephone in 1876, dies at the age of 76.
1923: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, dies in office at the age of 58. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1924: The Kwangchow government sets up the Central Bank of China with T.V. Soong (Soong Tzu-wen) as governor.
1934: Paul von Hindenburg, German general, politician, and president of the Weimar Republic, dies at the age of 86. He was succeeded by Adolf Hitler who declared himself "Der Fuhrer."
1938: Chinese troops blow up a bank along a section of the upper Yangtze River in an attempt to slow a Japanese advance.
1939: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, writes to U.S. President Roosevelt urging him to start an atomic project.
1944: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., U.S. Navy pilot and elder brother of John F. Kennedy, is killed when his plane explodes over the Belgian coast.
1945: The Potsdam Conference, the final Allied summit of World War II, comes to an end.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Dahomey, Niger and Upper Volta.
1961: President John F. Kennedy and visiting ROC Vice President Chen Cheng issue a joint statement in Washington, D.C., opposing the admission of mainland China into the United Nations.
1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a retaliatory strike after a torpedo attack on the U.S. Navy ship Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin.
1980: The International Telecommunications Administration inaugurates direct dialing station-to-station telephone service between Taipei and major cities in Britain, France and West Germany.
1985: Kuo Yu-hsin, former member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, dies of illness in Washington, D.C., at the age of 77.
1986: The ROC delegation to the Aug. 4 ROC-U.S. trade talks, headed by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Vincent C. Siew, leaves for Washington, D.C.
1990: Saddam Hussein makes good on Iraq's claim to the oil-rich state of Kuwait by invading it. Thousands of heavily armed Iraqi troops quickly cut through the defenses of their tiny Gulf neighbor and gain firm control of the capital city of Kuwait City.
1996: Michel Debre, former French prime minister, dies at the age of 84. He was Charles de Gaulle's trusted aide and the architect of the Fifth Republic.
1996: Typhoon Herb roars across northern Taiwan, leaving nearly 60 people dead or missing.
1999: The ROC representative to Japan, Chuang Ming-yao, expresses his grave concern to his Japanese counterpart about a plan by a group of Japanese lawmakers to land on the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
2000: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leads a delegation of senior KMT officials to pay a courtesy call on ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh at the DPP headquarters in Taipei.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records announces two of Taiwan's record-setting fathers as part of celebrations for Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8. One of the record-breakers is Lo Tseng-wen, who has five children serving as police officers, and the other is Chang A-piao, a centenarian who is living with four generations of offspring under the same roof.
2001: The final section of the 11.307-kilometer New Kuanyin Tunnel of the North Link Railway is blasted through, making it the longest two-way railway tunnel in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By banishing all flatterers and keeping away from the society of women; holding in low estimation possession of worldly goods, but valuing moral qualities in men: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to worthy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. position on Taiwan's membership application unchanged: official
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 1 (CNA) 08/02/07 11:49:04 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United Nations' position on Taiwan's participation in the world body has not changed despite Taiwan's request for the world body to reconsider its membership application, a U.N. official said Wednesday.

After its first application was returned by the U.N. Office of Legal Affairs July 23, Taiwan submitted a second application to the United Nations July 31 in two letters signed by President Chen Shui-bian and addressed separately to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon and Wang Guangya, China's permanent representative to the United Nations who served as rotating president of the U.N. Security Council for July.

Asked about the matter during a daily press briefing, Marie Okabe, deputy spokeswoman for the secretary-general, said she could not confirm at this point whether the United Nations has made an official response to the latest move by Taiwan.
"But our position has not changed since the last time we were asked," Okabe added.
Okabe noted that the previous application was returned in keeping with U.N. Resolution 2758, which she said is the basis of the "one China" policy of the United Nations.

She was referring to the resolution adopted by the General Assembly in 1971 recognizing the representatives of the People's Republic of China government as "the only legitimate representatives of China to the United Nations" and expelling representatives of the Republic of China.

Responding to a question on the issue by a CNA reporter last week, Ban pointed out that U.N. membership is only granted to sovereign countries and that the position of the United Nations is that "Taiwan is part of China."
Meanwhile, Wang told U.N. correspondents Wednesday that he returned Chen's letter the same day that he received it.
China's state-controlled Xinhua News Agency quoted Wang as calling Taiwan's latest move "a very serious separatist act seeking independence for Taiwan."
Expressing firm opposition to the move, Wang stressed that there is only one China in the world and that Taiwan is an inseparable part of China, according to Xinhua.

In the latest letter to Ban, President Chen argued that U.N. Resolution 2758 neither grants China the right to represent Taiwan at the United Nations nor states that Taiwan is either a part of China or the People's Republic of China.
Chen asserted that Taiwan is an independent sovereign nation and that its people have the right to participate in the United Nations.

In addition, Chen urged Ban to process Taiwan's application according to due procedure, because only the Security Council and the General Assembly have the authority to review and decide on membership applications and "the U.N. Secretariat does not have the power to decide on such matters."

The Republic of China has tried without success to re-enter the United Nations since 1993. This year marks the first time it has changed tactics by bidding to join the world body under the name of "Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan airlines experience over 1,000 bird strikes in five years

TEXT.P: Aircraft belonging to Taiwan-based airlines experienced a total of 1,009 bird strikes between 2002 and 2006, according to tallies released Thursday by the Flight Safety Foundation-Taiwan.
Of these incidents, 82 cases occurred at airports of foreign countries, and 125 cases involved damage to the aircraft, meaning one plane was damaged for every eight bird strike incidents on average.
The tallies show that a total of 787, or 78 percent, of the bird strikes were recorded between the months of May and November.

Engines proved to be the most vulnerable part of the plane in the bird strike incidents, with 75.6 percent of the plane damage cases involving the aircraft's engines. Meawhile, 5.5 percent of the cases involved the wings of the aircraft, and 4.7 percent involved the plane's nose or landing lights.

Foundation officials said the incidence of bird strikes at Taiwan airports has been declining in recent years owing to the installation of various bird repellent devices. The number of bird strikes totalled 203 in 2002 and 237 in 2003, dropping to 198 in 2004 and further to 138 in 2005, although the figure increased slightly to 151 in 2006, they said.

During the 2002-2006 period, bird strikes resulted in a total of 26 abnormal situations in which the aircraft was either forced to return to the airport, give up a takeoff attempt or make an emergency landing, they said.
Other abnormal situations caused by bird strike incidents included temporary closure of runways and cancellation of subsequent flights, they said.
Meanwhile, the foundation found that most of the bird strike incidents were caused by species of small-sized birds commonly seen in Taiwan, such as skylarks, house swifts, sparrows and barn swallows.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 58.69 points to close at 8,950.57.
The bourse opened at 9,076.11 and fluctuated between 9,080.07 and 8,727.64 during trading. A total of 7.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$220.05 billion (US$6.69 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.7 percent, textile stocks at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 1 percent, construction issues at 0.9 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.8 percent.
The two other major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up 1.4 percent and plastics and chemicals shares rising 0.5 percent.
Losers numbered more than 1,000 against 444 gainers, with 137 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA still arranging president's U.S. transit plan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 2 (CNA) 08/02/07 16:27:41 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's planned transit stops in the United States during his visit to Central America later this month are still being arranged, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

According to MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh, the MOFA will file an official request with the U.S. government for the planned transit stops at the proper time, and no decision has so far been made as to which U.S. cities the president will stop over in.
Wang said the details of the plan will be made public when the the president's departure date draws closer.
Wang was responding to a United Daily News report that Washington has refused to allow Chen to stop over in the continental United States or stay overnight during the transit stops.

The daily cited unidentified sources as saying that the U.S. government has done so to show its displeasure at Taiwan's plan to push for a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan."

Asked about the matter during a daily press briefing held in Washington D.C. Wednesday, U.S. State Department Deputy Spokesman Tom Casey said he is not aware of any formal request put forward by Taiwan for Chen's transit plan.
"It would be awfully speculative of me to try and tell you what we might do or might not do in terms of any specific requests and the timing of it," Casey said.

Casey noted that Washington's policy on transit requests by Taiwan leaders is based on a standard adherence to both the U.S. obligations as written in the Taiwan Relations Act and the principles of safety, comfort and convenience of the traveler.

As to Taiwan's latest referendum plan, Casey reiterated that the United States does not want to see any unilateral changes to the status quo and hopes Taiwan and China will resolve their differences through dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: 21 ex-inmates die from drug overdose since mid July

TEXT.P: Twenty-one drug-addicted former inmates have died from overdoses since the first prisoner release July 16 under a sentence commutation program, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) reported Thursday.
Thirty others have lapsed back into their drug habit or other criminal activities over the past two weeks, MOJ officials said.
The MOJ officials called for the recently released drug addicts to take the initiative in seeking professional help or joining drug rehab programs to help them kick the habit.

They said that efforts to help drug addicts kick the habit can never be too much, adding that the MOJ will continue to strive to attain more funds from the government so that it can collaborate more closely with the Department of Health to help drug addicts released from prison fight their addiction to illegal substances.

National Cheng Kung University Hospital in Tainan City, southern Taiwan opened July 20 a round-the-clock emergency room exclusively for recently released drug- addicted prison inmates who might face difficulty kicking the habit after 10 such people died from overdoses.

A total of 9,597 prison inmates were released July 16 under the sentence commutation statute, which is expected to benefit as many as 25,670 prisoners. The statute was passed in early July to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the lifting of martial law in Taiwan.
Among the first group of released inmates, 4,256 had been sent to prison for drug-related offenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to stage U.N. bid parade Sept. 15

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will launch a series of activities to solicit support from around the world for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, including a massive parade in Kaohsiung slated for Sept. 15.

The decision was made at a DPP Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday, in which the committee also announced that it plans to seek 1.2 million endorsement signatures before Oct. 15 to underscore Taiwan's determination to enter the world body as a full member despite the U.N.'s recent rejection of President Chen Shui-bian's letters requesting U.N. membership for the country under the name of Taiwan.
U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon stressed that U.N. membership is only granted to sovereign countries and that the U.N. considers Taiwan as "a part of China."

Despite the setback, the DPP is now planning to mobilize people around the world who support Taiwan's bid to enter the world body under the name of Taiwan to express their support Sept. 15 to coincide with the DPP's large-scale parade to be held that day in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, in which some 50,000 people are expected to participate.
In addition, the DPP has invited Internet users to submit creative works, in video or audio form, to relay the Taiwan people's desire to join the U.N. as a full member to every corner of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reiterates importance of U.N. referendum

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Thursday the importance of holding a nationwide referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.
Noting that the Taiwan people are determined to choose their own way of their own free will, Chen claimed that a U.N. membership bid referendum must be held.

Speaking at a colloquium with local residents in the southernmost county of Pingtung, Chen urged voters to throw their support behind ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative candidate Su Chen-ching representing Pingtung, claiming that as many draft bills concerning the people's welfare and livelihood have been blocked by the opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan, the only way of protecting the people's rights and interests is to enable the DPP to take more than half the seats in the next legislative election slated for Jan. 12 next year.
During his whirlwind tour of Pingtung, Chen also visited Chiu Lien-hui, a former senior presidential adviser, as well as Su.
The president also lunched with some 200 Su supporters.
