DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Zoo holding exhibition on bear conservation

TEXT.P: The Taipei Zoo is holding a special exhibition to enhance public awareness about the need to conserve the ursidae family, which comprises eight species of bears.
The exhibition, titled "Bear in Mind," opened Wednesday at the zoo's Education Center and will last until the end of September.

The eight bear species in the ursidae family are brown bears, polar bears, American black bears, Asian black bears, sun bears, sloth bears, spectacled bears and the giant panda. Members of this family are distributed from the Arctic coasts to tropical jungles.
The Taipei Zoo currently has three of the eight bear species on display: brown bears, sun bears and Asian black bears, plus a subspecies of the Asian black bear -- the Formosan black bear.

The exhibition uses life-size pictures of the different kinds of bears, along with descriptions to tell visitors about their characteristics, living habits and how their habitats are being threatened.
Three documentary films are being shown at the exhibition to highlight the current conditions of polar bears, giant pandas and Formosan black bears.
There will also be hands-on workshops that allow visitors to play various bear- themed games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dairy product prices go up in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Prices for 34 kinds of dairy products went up in Taiwan Wednesday, with the country's major food manufacturing companies -- including Uni-President Enterprises Corp. (UPEC) and Wei Chuan Corp. (WCC) -- hiking their dairy product prices by between 10 percent and 15 precent.
The upward price adjustment followed a Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) decision in early July to allow dairy farmers to charge wholesalers more for their raw milk.
Major local food processors said they need to raise their dairy product prices to reflect their increased costs in procuring raw milk.
According to the COA decision, raw milk prices can be raised by NT$3.52 per liter.
The skyrocketing raw material prices in the international market is also a reason behind the domestic dairy product price adjustment, market sources said.
Meanwhile, the sources said, neither UPEC nor WCC has any plans to raise the prices of their other food products at the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County to launch waste cooking oil recycling program

TEXT.P: The Changhua county government will launch a waste cooking oil recycling program in the Central Taiwan county from September on a trial basis as part of its efforts to improve environmental protection, a county government official said Thursday.

The official of the county's Environmental Protection Bureau said the program to collect waste edible oil from households, schools and government organizations will be run first on a trial basis and will be implemented officially if the results are good.

Noting that the waste cooking oil produced by households, schools and public organizations accounts for some 20 percent to 28 percent of the country's total waste cooking oil, the official pointed out that dumping it directly into rivers or drains causes serious contamination.

The program forms part of Environmental Protection Administration's plan to reduce environmental pollution and increase the raw material supply for the production of biodiesel and other products such as soap and feed additives.

DOC.HEADLINE: President courting harm by writing to China's U.N. ambassador: KMT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is courting harm to Taiwan by asking China's U.N. Ambassador Wang Guangya, who was the rotating president of the U.N. Security Council for July, to reconsider Taiwan's bid to join the world body in a July 27 letter, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) official claimed Thursday.

Chang Rung-kung, deputy chief of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, accused Chen of seeking political gain for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party by subjecting the county to humiliation in the international community.

He described Chen as "ignorant" in his belief that his letter to Wang, and a similar July 27 letter to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, could cast the country's dispute with China into the international limelight.
He likened the president's move to "shoving the Taiwan people under the wheels of a car."
Chang made the remarks after a spokesman for Wang said in New York Wednesday that Wang returned Chen's letter July 31 before his term as Security Council chief ended.

Ban had not yet acted on Chen's letter, but his spokesman said Thursday that the U.N. Secretariat has not changed its position since it returned July 23 a similar letter from Chen in which the president asked for Taiwan U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan.

Noting that Chen's administration attempted in May to join the World Health Organization (WHO) under the name of Taiwan only to see its supporters in the WHO decline to 20 from 22 in the last year, Chang accused the president of having learned nothing from his diplomatic bungles.

DOC.HEADLINE: New construction agency head takes office

TEXT.P: Lin Chin-rong, the new head of the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , said Wednesday that he will raise the profile of national parks and focus on national land-use planning.
Speaking after assuming his new post, Lin noted that Taiwan has beautiful national parks and that the first national ocean park will soon be established on the outlying Taiwan-held island of Tungsha.
He said the agency will increase its publicizing of national parks as part of its efforts to attract more local and foreign tourists.
Stressing the importance of land resources, Lin said that much greater attention will be paid to national land-use planning in the future.

In addition, he went on, existing policies on urban redevelopment are heading in the right direction, adding that he will focus on the implementation of the policies and look for room for improvement in relevant regulations.
The 51-year-old served as director-general of the Kaohsiung city government's Urban Development Bureau prior to his new appointment.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13 members of cross-border fraud ring nabbed

TEXT.P: Thirteen people related to a cross-border fraud ring whose operations encompass Taiwan, China and South Korea, were nabbed in the central counties of Taichung and Nantou Thursday on charges of kidnapping, fraud and extortion, police in Tainan, southern Taiwan said Thursday.

Tainan police, accompanied by several Tainan City prosecutors, traveled to central Taiwan early that morning to carry out raids on several locations in Taichung and Nantou counties, arresting the ringleaders -- identified as Leen Chien-teh and Sung Ming-chung -- along with 11 accomplices. Three other ring members were reportedly still at large.
The Tainan police began to investigate the crime ring last October after several school children in Tainan City were kidnapped for ransom.

The police found that the ring members had not only kidnapped school children but had also swindled over 1,000 people in Taiwan and South Korea out of over NT$100 million (US$3.05 million) , using a variety of scams.
They also found that the ring had recruited Taiwan people with no criminal record to travel to South Korea to work as "cells" for the ring.

The ring's operations also came to the attention of the South Korea law enforcement authorities. The South Korean government announced July 18 that it had decided to cooperate with the governments of Taiwan and China in efforts to crack down on cross-border fraud.

South Korean Prime Minister Han Duck-soo said that due to increasingly rampant telephone fraud by rings operating in South Korea, Taiwan and China, the South Korean government has decided to collaborate with the Taiwanese and Chinese authorities in cracking down on the criminals.
According to South Korean government tallies, police there received 3,990 reports of telephone fraud over the past year to June 30, with the amount swindled by fraudsters exceeding US$40 million.

Han said the South Korean government therefore decided to put stricter financial and banking measures into place, including raising the minimum balance for foreign nationals wanting to open bank accounts in the country, to help stem financial irregularities, including fraud operations.

Meanwhile, according to Chao Chia-ming, an official from Taiwan's representative office in Seoul, 150 citizens of Taiwan were arrested in South Korea in the first five months of this year on charges of fraud.
South Korean police said they had swindled huge amounts of money from some 3,400 South Koreans, Chao said.

He quoted South Korean police as saying that the Taiwanese crime ring members first put ads in Taiwanese newspapers to recruit people to work in South Korea. Once they arrived in South Korea, they were trained to make telephone calls posing as South Korean officials in charge of taxation or financial regulations to swindle money from locals.
Most of the 150 Taiwanese criminals have been convicted and handed prison sentences ranging from three months to four years, Chao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President encourages indigenous townships to restore names

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has encouraged local townships to restore their indigenous names, which he said marks the significance of self-identity among aborigines in Taiwan.

Chen made the remarks Wednesday at an inauguration ceremony of the Preparatory Office of the Austronesian Forum, which is aimed at promoting Taiwan's cooperation with Austronesian countries, including the Philippines, Tuvalu, Nauru, Kiribati, Palau, the Marshall Islands and the Solomon Islands.
He expressed hope that Austronesian peoples will flourish and that the world can learn about Austronesian culture.

Austronesia, in historical terms, refers to the homeland of the people who speak Austronesian languages, to which Malay, Filipino, Indonesian, Malagasy, native Hawaiian, the Fijian language and around a thousand other languages belong. The Austronesian homeland is thought by linguists to have been prehistoric Taiwan.
The name Austronesia comes from the Latin australis "southern" plus the Greek nesos "island".

The government passed an amendment to the Constitution 13 years ago that replaced the derogatory term "mountain countrymen" with "indigenous peoples" in the Constitution, which Chen said was a historic milestone in the history of indigenous peoples' campaign to rectify their names.

Describing name rectification as a crucial part of a country's transitional justice process, Chen said he instructed the Executive Yuan to offer assistance to indigenous people a long time ago and as a result, the number of aboriginal tribes recognized by the government has increased from nine to 13.

Chen said he also ordered the Cabinet in June 2005 to designate Aug. 1 as Indigenous Peoples Day, a policy he said was slated to take effect Jan. 1, 2006 but was postponed due to the delayed passage of a relevant bill through the Legislative Yuan.
Calling for early passage of the bill, Chen said designating an Indigenous Peoples Day will help raise public awareness of Taiwan's diverse indigenous cultures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung's light rail project meets opposition in City Council

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government's plan to build a light rail system to complement its mass rapid transit railway has met strong opposition in the City Council, with most council members favoring a bus rapid transit system instead.

The Cabinet approved a plan submitted by the Kaohsiung city government in early 2004 to build a light rail system. The Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit Bureau is currently working on a 19.6 km light rail circular route budgeted at a cost of NT$11.4 billion (US$345.83 million), with 75 percent of the funds coming from central government subsidies.
City Council Speaker Chuang Chi-wang said Thursday that light rail is no longer embraced by cities in other countries as the centerpiece of their regional transportation systems.
He said the light rail system contradicts the city's goal of moving underground all electric wires and cables in the city.
Chuang suggested that Kaohsiung should adopt a "bus rapid transit" (BRT) system instead. His suggestion was supported by many city councilors.

BRT refers to a high-quality bus service that is comparable to rail transi but still enjoys the cost savings of bus transit. While the construction cost for light rail is about NT$NT$600 million per km, the cost to build a BRT system is estimated at NT$60 million per km.
Wang Kuo-tsai, director of the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit Bureau, acknowledged the convenience provided by the BRT system, but added the light rail system can coexist with the BRT system.

Huang Shu-mei, a city councilor of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said there is no reason for Kaohsiung to abandon a light rail project already approved by the central government. She added that she supports the light rail project because it is pollution free and environmentally friendly.

The federal Department of Education, after months of criticism for lax oversight of the student loan program, still has no system to detect and uncover misconduct by lenders and protect student borrowers, a new government report said yesterday.

Garo Armen froze as colleagues broke the bad news last year about a kidney- cancer vaccine he had championed for over 12 years at a cost of $300 million: The clinical trial had failed. Shares of his tiny biotechnology firm, Antigenics Inc., plunged. His ambition and patients' hopes were dashed.
Now Mr. Armen is on the move -- traveling the world on a quest to persuade regulators to approve the vaccine despite the initial results. His argument: The vaccine worked well in a subgroup of less-sick patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI presents eco-friendly cosmetic facial mask

TEXT.P: New production technology for cosmetic facial masks developed by the Hsinchu- based Industrial Technology
Research Institute (ITRI) has demonstrated the potential to replace non-woven masks with a more eco-friendly version, ITRI sources said Thursday.

The cellulose materials used for facial masks are produced from acetobacters, explained Lee Lain-Tze, a research fellow at ITRI's Biomedical Engineering Research Laboratory, explained, adding that such materials can be degraded in natural environment, in contrast to non-woven textiles that require additional recycle processes.

Lin also noted that microbial cellulose has unique features such as the high degree of purity, remarkable ability to capture moisture, and good flexibility, all which make it well-suited to use in cosmetic facial masks, as well as other products for biomedical and cosmetic purposes.
The technology has been transferred to a local manufacturer and the commercialized products have already entered mass production, according to the institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Discussion of citizen journalism kicks off Wikimania 2007 conference

TEXT.P: Using a unique discussion format, an "unconference" on the theme of citizen journalism, reflective of the "bottom-up" characteristic of Web 2.0, kicked off Wikimania 2007, an international Wikimedia conference, Thursday in Taipei.
The Citizen Journalism Unconference (CJU) was a side event of the main Wikimania 2007, to be held in Taiwan for the first time from Aug. 3 - 5 at Chien Tan Overseas Youth Activity Center.

Unlike conferences employing top-down discussions, the CJU used an Open Space technique to allow participants to manage their own agenda by first announcing the topics in which they are interested before splitting the participants into eight to 10 discussion groups focusing on various topics.

Moderated by facilitators and conducted with the "law of two feet", which means participants could join or leave the discussion at any time, about 100 participants of various nationalities started discussion groups of six to eight persons.

"I don't have any money. I want to know whether citizen journalism can be profitable, " said Singaporean blogger Preetam Rai, who was in charge of Global Voices Online South East Asia. Naturally, Rai join the discussion on citizen journalism funding and joint ventures.

Other topics raised in discussions included "Citizen Journalism vs. Professionalism," "Journalistic Passion and Enthusiasm," "Ethical Concerns Citizen Journalism Creates, " and "the Relationship Between Traditional Media and Citizen Journalism."

Well-known local bloggers, such as Schee, Eric "Ilya" Lee, and Chiao Ching, acted as facilitators in the discussions, as did staff from PeoPo.org, a citizen journalism platform initiated by Taiwan Public Television Service.

This year's Wikimania, which will be the third annual international Wikimedia conference, was co-organized by the Wikimedia Foundation and Academia Sinica's Institute of Information Science. It is both a scientific conference and a community event, bringing together bloggers and members of various Wikimedia projects.

The Wikimedia Foundation is a non-profit organization that supports nine free information project, including Wikipedia. It is a multilingual, web-based, free content encyclopedia project. It was created in 2001 and soon grew into one of the largest reference Web sites, with articles that can be edited by anyone with Internet access.

More than 50 seminars and workshops will be held during the event's three days, which is expected to attract more than 350 participants from all over the world. Registration staff said that the number of registered participants exceeded 1,000, but many of these will be unable to participate due to a variety of reasons.
"We could have had a lot more participants from overseas, but a lot of them had trouble obtaining visas," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PMC to promote robotic technology in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Precision Machinery Research and Development Center (PMC) in the central city of Taichung will promote robotic technology in Taiwan, and invites interested persons to join their design team work, a PMC official said Thursday.
PMC General Manager Chan Ping-chih made the remarks at the opening ceremony of the 2007 Taipei Computer Application Show held at Taipei World Trade Center.
At the computer application show, the exhibition of various types of robots attracted much of the attention of the audience.

At the "Gathering of Robots" pavilion, more than 20 robots developed locally or introduced from Japan demonstrated their exquisite actions, with a robot demonstrating a slow motion Chinese martial art tai chi winning the acclaim of many.

In addition to offering the audience a chance to experience personally how to manipulate a robot, the organizer also introduced the history of robotic development in the country and exhibited a variety of relevant components.

Chan said the Taiwanese people have little knowledge of robots, and that is why the PMC organized the robot exhibition at this year's computer application show. However, he added, many people do not understand that most of the chips used in robots around the world are made by Taiwanese companies.
To boost Taiwan's robot industry, the PMC will cooperate with the Ministry of Economic Affairs in forming a platform for the general public to join in the PMC's design work, Chan said.

Noting that robotics involves many other high-tech spheres, including machinery, information, electronics, and electrical engineering, Chan welcomed students to join in their work so as to establish a strong robotic industry in the country.

Citing the example of Japan, which boasts a well-established robotics industry due to its heavy dependence on robots to do the most dangerous, repetitive and boring jobs, Chan said Taiwanese society also needs more robots to help in caring for elderly people in the future given the aging of the island's population.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH approves marketing of locally-developed HPV detecting genechips

TEXT.P: Locally-developed genechips capable of detecting human papillomavirus (HPV) and speeding up HPV genotyping while maintaining a high degree of accuracy were formally approved by the Department of Health (DOH) Thursday for sale in Taiwan.
The HPV detection genechips, carrying the brand name "Easychip HPV Blot, " were developed some two years ago by a biotech company associated with King Car Food Inc.

Approval of "Easychip HPV Blot" genechips makes the King Car biotech company one of only a few firms in the world to have successfully researched, developed and brought to market genechips for HPV genotyping.

"Easychip HPV Blot" genechips are capable of identifying the genotypes of 15 of 17 high-risk types of HPV via a polymerase chain reaction-based method. Such virus types have been implicated in cervical carcinoma, which must be treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy and radical surgery, according to a corporate source.

So far, the "Easychip HPV Blot" genechips are not covered by the national health insurance, and will cost patients some NT$2,000, though they will mean a quicker and more accurate HPV genotyping enabling doctors to better decide how to treat such infections.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE to subsidize disadvantaged students

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has approved a series of measures to provide educational subsidies for disadvantaged students from low-income families, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Thursday.

The policy, which will be implemented from the new academic year -- will benefit about 658,000 people, including preschoolers and students at elementary schools, high schools, colleges and universities.

Five-year-olds from families with an annual income of less than NT$300,000 (US$9,100) will be entitled to study for free in public kindergartens. Those from families with an annual income between NT$300,000 and NT$600,000 will receive subsidies covering tuition for public kindergarten, but their families will still need to pay for other expenditures.
About 81,000 children will benefit from the measure, which will cost the government about NT$800 million per semester, the official said.

The MOE will also earmark NT$900 million annually to help each elementary and junior high school in the country to open one class providing free after-school education to disadvantaged students, which will help about 180,000 students.

High school students from families with an annual income of less than NT$300,000 will receive an educational subsidy of NT$34,000, while those from families with an annual income of between NT$300,000 and NT$600,000, will qualify for financial aid of NT$20,000. About 187,000 high school students will benefit from the policy.
Students on a five-year college course and whose annual household income is less than NT$300,000 will get an annual subsidy of NT$34,000 for the first three years, the official said.

University students from low income families will be entitled to financial aid in four categories -- a grant, emergency relief, work-study and free dormitory housing -- with the highest subsidy amount being NT$73,000 in one academic year with further reductions in tuition and miscellaneous expenditures. The measure, which will cost NT$1.6 billion per year, will benefit nearly 210,000 disadvantaged students.

DOC.HEADLINE: New education subsidy program to benefit 210,000 college students

TEXT.P: The new educational subsidy program will provide financial aid to about 210,000 disadvantaged college and university students, Deputy Minister of Education Wu Tsai-shun said Thursday.

College and university students from low-income families will be entitled to four categories of financial aid including grants, emergency relief, work-study, and free dormitory housing, together with further subsidies for tuition and miscellaneous costs and other fees.

In addition to college and university students, the new educational subsidy program approved by the Executive Yuan Wednesday will provide subsidies to preschoolers, and students in elementary schools and high schools from disadvantaged families.

College students from families with an annual household income less than NT$700,000 (US$21,225) will be eligible for annual subsidies of about NT$34,000 in grants. Applications will be rated on a five grade scale, with the most disadvantaged students receiving the greatest subsidies.
Within the work-study category, schools will provide jobs for students in financial need, allowing them to earn NT$5,000 in monthly wages to help pay for education expenses.
Schools will also provide emergency relief to students in need and will provide 1 percent of dormitory space free of charge to house disadvantaged students.

A student at a private college from a low-income family, who has to spend NT$210,000 on tuition and miscellaneous expenditures for one academic year, will be subsidized to the tune of NT$73,000 in grants and work-study subsidies, reducing the student's debt load by 34 percent.

Also under the new program, 10 percent of the subsidies previously provided to private colleges and universities will be transferred to disadvantaged students in order to help reduce their miscellaneous costs and other fees.

These subsidies would reduce a hypothetical student's loan burden from NT$500,000 to NT$368,000. With lower loan interest rates and a longer repayment schedule, future monthly payment for the student will be reduced 48 percent, from NT$6,048 to NT$3,124.
Wu said students may submit applications for subsidies until the end of October. Detailed information is available at the Ministry of Education's Website, or via the hotline: 0800-056-668.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign films box office take 63.5 times greater than Taiwanese

TEXT.P: First-run foreign movies enjoyed box office receipts 63.5 times greater than that of Taiwanese films in Taipei City in 2006, bringing in NT$2.54 billion (US$77 million) and NT$40 million (US$1.21 million) respectively.
An official of the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said the total box office take of Taipei City's first-run theaters last year was NT$2.68 billion, up 0.2 percent over 2005.
Box office receipts for films made in Hong Kong and China took in a small margin of the total at NT$100 million, though even that amount exceeded the take of Taiwanese films.
The movie industry enjoyed NT$14.4 billion in sales in 2006, an increase of 9.6 percent over 2005, with the largest sectors being theaters, at NT$6.29 billion, and distributors, at NT$5.66 billion.

The official said statistics compiled by the Government Information Office and the Ministry of Finance show that the Taiwanese film industry performed sluggishly in terms of the number of companies, number of theater visitors, and the number of awards won.

Taipei City's first-run movie theater visitors in 2006 hit the number of 11.36 million. Among them, 10.74 visitors were for foreign movies, 420,000 visitors were for Hong Kong movies and films made in China, while only 200,000 visitors were for Taiwanese movies.

There were a total of 563 companies in the movie industry in 2006, 29 fewer than 592 at the end of 2005. Among these, the number of movie distribution companies fell from 220 to 211, and the number of film theaters slid from 164 to 151.

Moreover, a total of 307 Taiwanese films were included in international film festivals last year, but the number of award nominations slid from 140 to 83, while prizes won fell from 22 to only nine, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Departing Malaysian man nabbed for carrying illicit drug

TEXT.P: A Malaysian man of Chinese ancestry was arrested Thursday at Taoyuan International Airport after law enforcement agents found 35,000 nimetazepam tablets -- a hypnotic drug -- in his luggage.

The man, identified as Lim Swee-chye, 29, was about to leave for Malaysia via Hong Kong aboard a Cathay Pacific Airways flight when Investigation Bureau agents and customs officials stopped him and asked to check all of his luggage.

A spokesman for the Bureau Taoyuan County office in Taoyuan County told the CNA that agents had kept the man under surveillance after receiving a tip-off from their colleagues in Taipei about his drug-related activities.
Lim concealed the nimetazepam tablets, weighing 9.25 kilograms in total, in eight bags in the guise of corn chip snacks, and placed the bags in his check-in luggage, according to the spokesman.

The Investigation Bureau received information that Lim stayed in a five-star hotel in Taipei at the expense of a drug trafficker in Malaysia. He probably agreed to smuggle the illicit drug because, as a failed businessman deep in debt, he needed the money badly, the spokesman said.
Nimetazepa is a highly hypnotic, benzodiazepine derived drug. It possesses anxiolytic, anticonvulsant, sedative and skeletal muscle relaxant properties.

Because the drug has been subject to abuse, especially by persons addicted to amphetamines or opiates, it is no longer sold in most Western nations, but is still subject to significant abuse in some Southeast Asian countries, including Japan and Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Keelung Harbor to set record in yearly cargo volumes

TEXT.P: Keelung Harbor is posed to set a new annual record for the total volume of cargo handled, said officials of the Keelung Harbor Bureau in northern Taiwan Thursday.

The remarks came after the bureau reported a preliminary estimate showing that July's total cargo volume amounted to 193,008 TEU. July was the fourth consecutive month in which the total cargo volume handled at the port has exceeded 190,000 TEU, breaking a 1995 record according to officials.
The harbor handled a total cargo volume of 1.27 million TEU during the January- July period, up 4.77 percent or an increase of 58,002 TEU from the previous year's level, according to officials.
Total cargo volume handled at the harbor this year is estimated to surpass 2.23 million TEU (Twenty-feet Equivalent Unit).

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County to hold street art symposium

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung County government will hold a street art symposium Aug. 31-Sept. 2, inviting street artists from France to share their experiences with their Taiwanese counterparts, officials of the county's Culture Bureau said Thursday.

The registration period for the event, co-organized by the bureau and the Preparatory Office of Wei-Wu-Ying Center for the Performing Art under the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), will run through Aug. 10, the bureau officials said.
Kaohsiung County began to be committed to developing street art performances last year, and it has issued 104 performing licenses since then, the officials said.

Street performers' direct interaction with passers-by on streets, at subway stations, and in other public facilities brings the art closer to the public and also adds humanistic touches to a city, the officials noted, adding that such performances are quite common in other countries.

Elodie Presles, CEO of France's national street art center, and two teams of French street artists will be invited to the three-day event to exchange ideas with their local counterparts, the officials said.
France organizes large street art festivals annually, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC protests PRC envoy's return of President Chen's letter

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) issued a strong protest Thursday against the return by the Chinese permanent representative to the United Nations of President Chen Shui-bian's letter asking the world body reconsider Taiwan's membership application.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun voiced the protest at an impromptu news conference on behalf of the Cabinet-level council that charts Taiwan's policy on China after Wang Guangya told U.N. correspondents Wednesday that he returned Chen's letter the same day he received it.

Claiming that Taiwan is an inseparable part of China, Wang, who served as the rotating president of the U.N. Security Council for July, called Taiwan's U.N. bid as a serious separatist act seeking independence for Taiwan.
In response, Liu said Wang's remarks reflect China's hegemonic attitude toward Taiwan, which will only result in a backlash from the people of Taiwan and drive the two sides further apart.
Liu went on to stress that Taiwan has never been a part of the People's Republic of China (PRC) as Wang claimed.

And China's refusal to recognize Taiwan's independent sovereignty and the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait do not belong to each other forms the most fundamental and greatest obstacle to cross-strait relations, Liu said.

Worse still, Liu said, China has continued employing U.N. Resolution 2758 to back up its absurd and incongruous "one China" policy and denigrate Taiwan's sovereign status in an attempt to achieve "de jure unification" of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Besides pulling out all the stops in its attempts to deny Taiwan's statehood, block Taiwan's participation in the world organizations and lure away Taiwan's diplomatic allies, Liu said China has also stepped up saber-rattling and missile deployment against Taiwan.

Liu said the international community should not ignore the perilous development in China's intensified military buildup which has endangered balance of power across the Taiwan Strait and caused anxiety among Asia-Pacific countries.

Noting that Taiwan's peaceful appeal for collective security and participation in major world bodies transcends any ideological thinking with regard to independence or unification, Liu said the pursuit reflects Taiwan's mainstream public opinion.

Stressing Taiwan has overcome many difficulties establishing a democratic political system, Liu said the international community should recognize its contribution to maintaining regional peace and promoting regional prosperity over the past decades.
Liu further said Taiwan's quest for U.N. representation is aimed at contributing to world peace and safeguarding its 23 million people's basic human rights.

After its first application was returned by the U.N. Office of Legal Affairs July 23, Taiwan submitted a second application to the United Nations July 31 in two letters signed by President Chen and addressed separately to U.N. Secretary- General Ban Ki-moon and Wang Guangya.

Asked about the matter during a daily press briefing, Marie Okabe, deputy spokeswoman for the secretary-general, said Wednesday she could not confirm at this point whether the United Nations has made an official response to the latest move by Taiwan.
"But our position has not changed since the last time we were asked," Okabe added.
Okabe noted that the previous application was returned in keeping with U.N. Resolution 2758, which she said is the basis of the "one China" policy of the United Nations.

She was referring to the resolution adopted by the General Assembly in 1971 recognizing the representatives of the People's Republic of China government as "the only legitimate representatives of China to the United Nations" and expelling representatives of the Republic of China.

In the latest letter to Ban, President Chen argued that U.N. Resolution 2758 neither grants China the right to represent Taiwan at the United Nations nor states that Taiwan is either a part of China or the People's Republic of China.
Chen asserted that Taiwan is an independent sovereign nation and that its people have the right to participate in the United Nations.

In addition, Chen urged Ban to process Taiwan's application according to due procedure, because only the Security Council and the General Assembly have the authority to review and decide on membership applications and "the U.N. Secretariat does not have the power to decide on such matters."

The Republic of China has tried without success to re-enter the United Nations since 1993. This year marks the first time it has changed tactics by bidding to join the world body under the name of "Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 3, or the 21st day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
216: An army led by Carthaginian General Hannibal defeats a huge Roman army, seizing its supply depot in the Battle of Cannae and killing some fifty thousand Roman soldiers.
1460: Scottish King James II is killed by the English during the siege of Roxburgh Castle.
1492: A flotilla of three ships, led by Christopher Columbus, sets sail from the Spanish port of Palos de la Frontera in search of a land called India.
1867: Stanley Baldwin, British Conservative prime minister three times between 1923 and 1937, is born.
1872: Haakon VII, Norwegian monarch who refused to surrender to the Germans in World War II, is born in Denmark.
1881: William George Fargo, American pioneer of long-distance express service, dies at his home in Buffalo, New York, at the age of 65.
1904: The Dalai Lama flees Lhasa as British troops invade Tibet. The Ching court on Aug. 26 orders the Pachen Lama to take over Tibetan affairs from the Dalai Lama.
1916: German troops launch a surprise attack on British forces in the Sinai in Egypt. Some 5,000 German soldiers are killed, while British loses amount to 1,100 men.
1929: Emile Berliner, German-born American inventor, dies in Washington D.C. at the age of 78. He greatly improved the telephone and invented the gramophone in 1887.
1940: Lithuania is formally incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
1958: Nautilus, the U.S. atomic submarine, becomes the first vessel to reach the North Pole under the ice.
1959: Japan Airlines formally inaugurates its Tokyo-Taipei route.
1967: The ROC Executive Yuan decides to extend the period of compulsory education from six to nine years beginning in 1968.
1969: Minister of Economic Affairs K.T. Li (Li Kuo-ting) receives the 1968 Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service.
1972: Sheng Chin-lai is appointed dean of the Engineering College at Chiaotung University.
1972: Brig. Gen. William C. Buttows, new chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command, arrives in Taipei.
1973: The Flying Tiger Line inaugurates air freight services between Kaohsiung and New York.
1974: Economics Minister Y.S. Sun and Paraguayan Minister of Industry and Commerce D. Ugarte Centurionuan sign an agreement in Taipei to boost economic cooperation between the Republic of China and Paraguay.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives eight members of the U.S. 14th Air Force Association, including Mrs. Anna Chennault, widow of the 14th Air Force's commander, Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault.
1977: A US$100 million loan agreement is signed in Taipei between the Taiwan Power Company and 17 banks from five foreign nations.
1981: President Ronald Reagan orders the firing of 12,000 striking air traffic control workers.
1986: Construction of the Synchronous Radiation Research Center under the Executive Yuan is started at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park. It is scheduled for completion within five to six years.
1988: Mathias Rust, a West German youth who landed his light air plane near Moscow's Red Square in 1987, is released from prison and expelled from the Soviet Union.
1999: Nine renowned scientists and former intelligence and military officials send a letter to all 100 U.S. senators calling for the prompt ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to prevent the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets by Communist China.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian directs the ROC Air Force to draw up a forward- looking blueprint for developing a new generation of warplanes to ensure supremacy in the skies over the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By extending the powers of their functions and allowing them discretion in the employment of their subordinates: that is how a ruler gives encouragement to the high ministers of state."

DOC.HEADLINE: Returned letter on Taiwan's U.N. membership application received
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 2 (CNA) 08/03/07 11:56:10 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Swaziland's ambassador to the United Nations has received a letter containing Taiwan's U.N. membership application which was returned by Wang Guangya, China's U.N. ambassador who served as rotating president of the U.N. Security Council for July, Taiwan officials posted in New York said Thursday.
The letter, signed by President Chen Shui-bian, was delivered July 31 to Wang through the U.N. ambassadors of Swaziland and the Solomon Islands, two of Taiwan's diplomatic allies.
Wang told the press Wednesday that he returned the letter the same day that he received it.
China's state-controlled Xinhua News Agency quoted Wang as calling Taiwan's latest move "a very serious separatist act seeking independence for Taiwan" and saying that China is firmly opposed to it.
Also on July 31, the ambassadors of Swaziland and the Solomon Islands delivered on behalf of Taiwan another letter signed by President Chen to U.N. Secretary- General Ban Ki-moon.
Ban, who is on a visit to Haiti and Barbados, has not made an official response to Chen's second letter to him. Ban returned Chen's previous letter July 23 through the U.N. Office of Legal Affairs.
U.N. officials said the letter was returned in keeping with Resolution 2758, which they pointed out is the basis of the "one China" policy of the United Nations.

The resolution was adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1971 recognizing the representatives of the People's Republic of China government as "the only legitimate representatives of China to the United Nations" and expelling representatives of the Republic of China.

The Republic of China has tried without success to re-enter the United Nations since 1993. This year marks the first time it has changed tactics by bidding to join the world body under the name of "Taiwan."
In the latest letter to Ban, President Chen asserted Taiwan's status as an independent sovereign nation that is entitled to membership in the United Nations.
Chen argued that U.N. Resolution 2758 neither grants China the right to represent Taiwan at the United Nations nor states that Taiwan is either a part of China or the People's Republic of China.

Manila Bulletin: ASEAN Forum, meetings end
Southeast Asian nations have named former Thai foreign minister Surin Pitsuwan as the next secretary- general of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), the 10-nation bloc announced yesterday.

The Detroit automakers' share of the U.S. market dropped below 50 percent in July for the first time history, according to two analysts who track industry numbers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
80% of children drink sugar-containing beverages everyday: survey

TEXT.P: Eighty percent of Taiwan kindergarten and elementary school children drink sugar-containing beverages everyday, an unhealthy habit which has caused many of the children to become overweight or underweight, according to the results of a survey released Friday.
The survey was conducted by the John Tung Foundation in April and May on more than 1,500 kindergarten children and 1,000 elementary school children around Taiwan.
The survey found that 80 percent of these children drink beverages such as soda and milk tea everyday, and most of them prefer sugar-containing beverages to plain water when asked to make a choice.

Hsu Huei-yu, director of the foundation's nutrition division, noted that while beverages with sugar usually contain a high level of calories that can lead to obesity, consuming beverages together with other food can affect children's appetite and thus cause them to become underweight.

Among the children who drink sugar-containing beverages everyday, 30 percent of boys and 20 percent of girls are overweight, and 20 percent of boys and 30 percent of girls are underweight, according to Hsu.

Pointing out that parents have a crucial influence on the dietary habits and food preferences of their children, Hsu said many of the surveyed children developed the habit of drinking sugar-containing beverages because their parents have such habit and have stocked the products at home.
She urged parents to set a good example and reject sugar-containing beverages in order to correct their children's dietary habits.

DOC.HEADLINE: Infant infected with enterovirus still struggling

TEXT.P: A 15-month-old child, confirmed to be the first severe enterovirus type 71 (E71) case this year in Taiwan, is still struggling in a pediatric intensive care unit in Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) reported Friday.

According to Chou Chih-hao, deputy director-general of the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , the infant was admitted to the Hsinchu hospital in mid- July after first developing symptoms of hand-foot-mouth disease, including high fever, vomiting, decreased energy and loss of appetite.

The infant's condition worsened after being admitted to hospital, with the infant developing fast breathing, increased heart beat and spasms, then dysfunction of the heart and lungs, before eventually falling into a coma, Chou said.
The infant currently remains in a coma, according to Chou.
Severe E71 -- the deadliest type of all enterovirus infections -- almost turned Taiwan upside down in the summer of 1998 when 405 children were infected, with 78 of the kids eventually dying.
In an outbreak of E71 in 2005, 145 children were infected, with 15 perishing, according to CDC tallies.
None of the family members of the infant, including the grandparents, parents and siblings, who all live together, have been found to be infected with E71, according to Chou.

Chou said that although the peak season for enterovirus infection is nearly over this year, people, especially children, should maintain good personal hygiene and wash their hands often in order to avoid being infected.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's demand of severing ties with Taiwan 'odious': Nicaraguan VP
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 2 (CNA) 08/03/07 15:01:35 (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Morales Carazo has termed as "odious" China's imposition of the precondition that Nicaragua sever ties with Taiwan before it can establish formal diplomatic relations with Beijing.
In an interview with the Nicaraguan daily El Neuvo Diario Wednesday, Morales described China's high-handed requirement as an act of "yellow imperialism."

China has sought to resume diplomatic relations with Nicaragua since the Sandinistas returned to power early this year. But it has demanded that Nicaragua first sever its diplomatic ties with the Republic of China on Taiwan.

Claiming that China's economic progress has been achieved at the expense of freedom, democracy and social welfare, Morales sid only 200 million of China's 1.3 billion citizens have benefited from the country's economic progress, with the remaining 1.1 billion being excluded as "non-existent."

Meanwhile, the world's leading Spanish-language news agency, EFE, reported Thursday that Morales is scheduled to visit Taiwan Aug. 12-16 to reinforce relations between the two countries. He will be the first high-ranking Nicaraguan official to visit Taiwan since the Sandinistas returned to power.
Morales told EFE that he will depart Managua Aug.10 for an official visit to Taiwan at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

In addition to lending support to Taiwan's cause, Morales said he will also take advantage of his visit to express the gratitude of the Nicaraguan government and people for Taiwan's assistance in various fields over the past years.
According to Morales, Taiwan has recently donated US$30 million for the building of a 30-megawatt thermal power plant in Nicaragua to help the country solve its electricity shortage problem.
Morales said Taiwan has also promised to invest in Nicaragua's export processing zone and other development projects, but he didn't elaborate.

When the Ortega-led Sandinista National Liberation Front was in power for the first time between 1985 and 1990, Nicaragua switched diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing. The Nicaraguan government resumed diplomatic ties with Taiwan after Violeta Chamorro took power in 1990.

Since regaining the presidency early this year, Ortega has reaffirmed on many occasions his determination to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan, even after another Central American country, Costa Rica, switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in June.
