DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Ruling Limited Spying Efforts; Move to Amend FISA Sparked by Judge's Decision
A federal intelligence court judge earlier this year secretly declared a key element of the Bush administration's wiretapping efforts illegal, according to a lawmaker and government sources, providing a previously unstated rationale for fevered efforts by congressional lawmakers this week to expand the president's spying powers. ]By Chiehyu Lin^

DOC.HEADLINE: Industrial oil prices to be kept among lowest in the world: minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs will continue its policy of maintaining low industrial fuel oil prices in order to help the domestic industrial sector maintain its global competitiveness, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen said Friday.

Speaking at a business seminar with a group of owners and executives of small- and medium-sized enterprises, Chen said that his ministry will strive to keep industrial fuel oil prices in Taiwan among the lowest in the world.

Noting that industrial fuel oil prices in Taiwan are generally lower than those in neighboring countries by about NT$1,000-2,000 per 1,000 liters, Chen said that his ministry will do its best to maintain prices at the lowest possible levels in a bid to help Taiwan manufacturers sharpen their competitiveness edge over their competitors, such as South Korea.

Chen added that in the face of spiraling international crude oil prices, the ministry has even shelved a price hike plan for industrial fuel oils proposed by CPC Corp., Taiwan which was intended to be implemented at the start of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices soar on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 107.25 points to close at 9,057.82.
The bourse opened at 9,104.34 and fluctuated between 9,134.6 and 9,025.7 during trading. A total of 5.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$172.12 billion (US$5.24 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 3.5 percent, followed by textile stocks at 2 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.5 percent, electronics shares and construction issues both at 1.2 percent, and banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent.
Paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,005 to 562, with 177 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: In a letter to supporters of the ruling center-left Union, particularly radical leftists, Italian Premier Romano Prodi appealed for support for the government's welfare reform plan which is featured in raising gradually the pension age.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 105 points to close at 8,985, with 67,768 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September rose 95 points to finish at 8,966, with 1,570 contracts traded, while December futures gained 90 points to close at 8,973, with 64 contract transactions. March futures increased 83 points to close at 8,986, with 16 contracts traded, while June futures moved up 96 points to finish at 8,973, with seven contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,880 for August, 8,871 for September, 8,883 for December, 8,903 for March and 8,877 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

August TE futures moved up 3.6 points to close at 381.6, with 3,494 contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 0.4 points to finish at 380, with 65 contract transactions. December TE futures rose 2.5 points to close at 381, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures gained 14 points to close at 1,040, with 3,726 contracts traded, while September TF futures rose 17.4 points to finish at 1,041.4, with 109 contract transactions. December TF futures moved up 15.4 points to close at 1,044.8, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should work to become 'technology innovator': president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that Taiwan should continue to work toward the goal of becoming a "technological innovator, " after the country's industrial structure has been transformed from a labor-intensive one into a knowledge-intensive one.
Chen made the remarks while addressing the opening of a science show in Taipei.

In what he said proves the excellence of Taiwan's capabilities in terms of innovation and research and development, Chen noted that Taiwan's innovative competitiveness was rated second in Asia by the U.K.-based Economist Intelligence Unit.
Meanwhile, 14 Taiwanese businesses were included on the list of the world's top 100 performers in the information technology industry released July 2 by the U.S.-based BusinessWeek, Chen pointed out.
According to Chen, although natural resources are lacking in Taiwan, talent, knowledge and innovation are precious assets possessed by the country.

Through the joint efforts of the government and private sectors over the past seven years, Taiwan has seen the production values of its semiconductor and panel industries top NT$1 trillion per year, he said.

The government is now providing various incentives to boost the development of the precision machinery, communication electronics, and bio-technology industries, with the goal of increasing their production values to NT$1 trillion per year, he said.
The president said the government will work to bringing new meaning and value to the "Made in Taiwan" logo, and equating "Taiwan" with the concepts of quality, safety, innovation and humanity.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, rising NT$0.007 to close at NT$32.871.
A total of US$689 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.805 and fluctuated between NT$32.775 and NT$32.880.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,374 kg of ractopamine seized throughout Taiwan

TEXT.P: Prosecutors from the central county of Changhua carried out raids on 10 locations throughout Taiwan Thursday, seizing 1,374 kg of the banned veterinary drug ractopamine and a smaller amount of animal antibiotic nalectin.

The Changhua prosecutors, accompanied by Changhua police, traveled to Taipei City in northern Taiwan that day to search the office of an international trading company, from where they brought company owner, surnamed Ho, to the Changhua District Prosecutor's Office for questioning, and confiscated 750 kg of ractopamine that the company has imported from China for sales to Taiwan pig or poultry farms.
The Changhua prosecutors and police then drove to the southern port city of Kaohsiung, where they searched the office of an animal feed dealer and discovered 624 kg of ractopamine.
Ractopamine is used by some foreign farmers to promote the growth of lean meat in pigs, but the drug is banned in Taiwan.

The prosecutors and police also traveled around the counties of Changhua, Tainan and Kaohsiung later that day to visit eight other pig farms and feed dealers to gain a better understanding of the situation concerning the use and distribution of ractopamine.
All pig farm owners and dealers visited admitted that they have fed the drug to the pigs they have raised, or sold the drug to hog farmers.
Also at the Taipei international trading company, prosecutors discovered 150 kg of banned animal antibiotic drug nalectin, also known as chloramphenicol.
Ho was later released on NT$100,000 bail.
Prosecutors are striving to find out whether ractopamine has also been sold to other poultry farms islandwide as a food additive.

A ractopamine scare has gripped the country recently after two shipments of U.S. pork were found to contain residue of the banned drug ractopamine. Portions of those shipments, totaling about 1,000 kg, have already entered the domestic meat markets and presumably been consumed.

The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture decided last October to ban all drugs used by farmers as food additives to boost the growth of lean meat in pigs, including ractopamine, after cases were reported abroad concerning the effect of such drugs on consumers' cardiac and neural systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Monument to be built in memory of democratic trailblazer

TEXT.P: A monument will be built at the Toucheng exit of the Hsuehshan Tunnel in the northeastern county of Yilan in memory of Chiang Wei-shui, one of Taiwan's democratic trailblazers.
A ground-breaking ceremony was held at the monument site Thursday with Premier Chang Chun-hsiung attending.

The Hsuehshan Tunnel is the centerpiece of the "Chiang Wei-shui Freeway" that links Taipei and Yilan counties. The 54.3-km freeway was named after Chiang in view of his contribution to the nation's political democratization.

Speaking at the ceremony, Chang said Chiang was a physician and forerunner of the Taiwanese nationalist movement under Japan's colonial rule. He formed the first political party in Taiwan and spared no effort in pursuing the welfare of the less privileged people. Chiang, who was born in 1891 in Yilan, was imprisoned more than 10 times during his lifetime for defying the orders of then-Japanese authorities.
Chiang's founding of the "Taiwan People's Party" laid a solid foundation for Taiwan's democratic movements, Chang stressed.

The Chiang Wei-shui Freeway, previously known as the Peiyi Freeway, begins in Taipei's Nankang district and ends in Yilan's Suao township. The most difficult part of the construction project was the 12.9-km Hsuehshan Tunnel, the longest highway tunnel in East Asia and the fifth-longest in the world.

Due to the complicated and difficult geographic structures in the tunnel, 25 workers died during the construction. Chang said the monument will also be in commemoration of engineers and workers who sacrificed their lives for tunnel construction. The tunnel significantly reduces the travel time between Taipei and Yilan.

With a price tag of NT$100 billion (US$3.04 billion) , the Hsuehshan Tunnel, considered by some foreign experts to be "impossible to build, " was opened to traffic June 16 last year after 15 years of work.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei and Chiang's 94-year-old son Chiang Sung-hui were also present at the ground-breaking ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: Family happiness named greatest achievement by most Tainan fathers

TEXT.P: Approximately 90 percent of fathers in southern Tainan city have identified family happiness as their greatest achievement, according to the results of a survey released Friday.
The survey of 851 fathers was conducted by the city's family education center from June 10-30 to mark the Aug. 8 Father's Day.

The survey found that more than 90 percent of the respondents are willing to make efforts to maintain their marriages, and nearly 80 percent said they would choose their present wives if they were allowed to reconsider their marriage partners.

However, only 42 percent of the respondents are willing to keep their wives company in doing things that their wives like, and only 47 percent will communicate peacefully with their wives to resolve their differences, the survey shows.
While 62 percent of the respondents hug their children very often, 29 percent are anxious because they have problems understanding their children.
Meanwhile, 80 percent of the fathers will miss their children when they are not together, and 70 percent will keep their children company while the kids are studying.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition lawmakers want all aged bridges in Taiwan examined

TEXT.P: Legislators of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged the government Friday to examine all aged bridges in Taiwan to prevent a mishap similar to the bridge collapse two days ago in America's Minnesota State from happening.

KMT lawmakers made the appeal at a press conference after watching horrific television footage showing a 40-year-old bridge in Minneapolis collapsing during rush hour, sending cars and trucks tumbling into the Mississippi River, killing at least four people, and leaving some 30 more missing.

Hsu Shao-ping, a KMT legislative caucus whip, pointed out that Taiwan has 942 bridges that are more than 40 years old, including 68 bridges that have been classified as "dangerous" and 10 bridges that are more than 60 years old.
There are an additional 8,000 bridges of unknown age, Hsu said, adding that more than half of these bridges are not regularly examined or maintained by central or local government agencies.
She added that last year only 11 of Taiwan's 23 cities and counties had set aside budgets for bridge maintenance.

She urge the government to attach greater importance to human lives by drawing a lesson from the U.S. collapse and taking precautionary measures to give all aged bridges in Taiwan a complete physical check-up.

DOC.HEADLINE: Skydiver team to perform at 2009 World Games opening

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has promised to arrange for Taiwan's paratroopers to demonstrate parachuting skill at the opening ceremony of the 2009 World Games to be held in southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Chen made the commitment when meeting with International World Games Association President, Froehlich Thursday, who is currently visiting Taiwan to gain a better understanding of preparations for the World Games.

During the meeting, Froehlich expressed hope that a parachuting performance can be staged at the World Games' opening ceremony. In response, Chen said the Taiwan army's airborne skydiver team will feel honored to perform at the opening ceremony.

Chen told Froehlich that the Government Information Office, the Ministry of National Defense, the Council for Cultural Affairs, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and the Executive Yuan's' counter-terrorism office will all help the Kaohsiung city government with preparations for the Games, which are highly anticipated by the Taiwanese people.

Construction projects, including the main stadium and the Kaohsiung Arena are both making good progress, Chen said, adding that the city's new traffic facilities, such as the red and orange MRT lines, are slated to begin operations at the end of this year and in mid-2008 respectively, well in time for the World Games, Chen said.

Chen also assured Froehlich that the World Games Kaohsiung Organizing Committee CEO Chi Cheng, an outstanding veteran athlete who earned the nickname "the flying antelope" for breaking records at world track and field events and who was a medal winner in Asian Games and Olympic Games, will oversee preparations for the World Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates relief fund to help quake victims in Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 3 (CNA) 08/03/07 19:16:41 (By Yang Ming-chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's deputy representative in Japan visited the government of the northwestern prefecture of Niigata Friday to express concern for those affected by an earthquake that struck the prefecture last month.

Lo Kun-tsan met with Deputy Niigata Governor Kazuo Jinbo at the latter's office to make a donation of five million Japanese yen (US$41,960) to Niigata prefecture residents in addition to offering concern from the government and people of Taiwan for the losses suffered during a July 16, magnitude-6.8 earthquake that killed 11 people.

The deadly quake injured over 1,800 people and forced some 80,000 to evacuate to safer places. With more than 14,000 houses completely or partially ruined, the quake has caused property damages to the tune of 1.5 trillion yen (about NT$370 billion or US$11.28 billion).
For his part, Jinbo expressed gratitude to Taiwan for the compassion shown to Niigata residents.

Residents of the northwestern prefecture by the Sea of Japan were bracing themselves Friday for strong winds and torrential rains as Typhoon Usagi is forecast to sweep out over the Sea of Japan after pounding Japan's southernmost main island of Kyushu, injuring 18 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former DPP chairman indicted for violating parade law

TEXT.P: Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who led a massive street protest last October aimed at forcing President Chen Shui-bian to step down over scandals was indicted for violating the Assembly and Parade Law.

Shih, the leader of a so-called "Million Voices against Corruption" campaign, led a large-scale street protest in Taipei on Oct. 10 National Day last year, calling for people around the country to join his plan to "besiege" the Presidential Office to pressure President Chen to resign over a spate of corruption scandals allegedly involving himself, his family members and close aides.
According to police, Shih didn't obtain permission before calling up tens of thousands of slogan-chanting protesters to take to the streets of Taipei.

In addition to Shih, the prosecutors also indicted 15 others who were closely linked with the unsanctioned protest, including several lawmakers from the opposition "plan-blue camp, " scholars and other political activists.

DOC.HEADLINE: 34 injured in five-car pile-up in Chungho Tunnel

TEXT.P: Thirty-four people, 30 of whom are children, were injured Friday in a five-car pile-up on a northbound section of the No. 3 Freeway in northern Taiwan.

The accident occurred at 9:25 a.m. in the Chungho Tunnel in Taipei County. Two coaches that reduced speed soon after entering the tunnel were rear-ended by two other coaches full of kindergarten children that apparently failed to keep a safe distance.

The two coaches, chartered by Kid Castle Kindergarten in the county's Sanhsia township, were in turn hit from behind by a container truck. The two coaches were carrying seven teachers and 54 children on their way to an outdoor learning session at the Taipei Zoo.

One of the coach drivers suffered a broken leg, while three other adults and 30 children received minor head and shoulder injuries. They were sent to four different hospitals in Taipei County for treatment.
The accident caused a four-km tailback and traffic did not return to normal until around noon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan torch relay to expose China's human rights abuses

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese lawmakers and human rights activists have announced that a worldwide torch relay will be launched Aug. 9 to call for world attention to human rights violations in China.

The relay will kick off in Athens and pass through over 100 cities all over the world, William C.T. Lai, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker and head of the Asian chapter of the Coalition to Investigation the Persecution of Falun Gong, said at a press conference Thursday.
The announcement came months after Taiwan rejected the 2008 Beijing Olympic torch because China was including the country as part of China's domestic relay route.

According to Beijing's proposal, the torch would have gone from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and depart to Hong Kong and Macau. However, Taiwan insisted that the torch enter and exit via a third country as part of its efforts to safeguard its national sovereignty.

Claiming that the human rights torch relay will "reveal the inside story of the bloody Olympics, " Lai said Beijing's new ban on 43 types of people it considers "hostile" from taking part in the 2008 Olympic Games and relevant activities has violated the basic spirit of the games.

The Olympic spirit is supposed to promote harmony through fair competition, Lai said. However, China has listed 43 types of people who will be banned even if they are invited by the International Olympic Committee.

The forbidden people include Falun Gong practitioners, Chinese defectors, pro- democracy activists, religious extremists and infiltrators, as well as journalists who "may jeopardize the event," according to Lai.
Twu Shiing-jer, a member of the chapter and a former head of the Department of Health (DOH), claimed that such a ban will exclude 90 percent of the Taiwan public.
On top of terrorists, China screens out the other listed people simply because it cannot tolerate those who hold different opinions, Twu said, urging the public to boycott the games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wikipedia hopes to work out issues of China blockage

TEXT.P: Wikipedia will try to communicate with China on its blockage of the popular reference Web site, as well as the intellectual property rights infringement issue, Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales said in a press conference in Taipei Friday.

Wikipedia is still being blocked -- at least partially -- in China, and China's biggest online search engine Baidu.com has been listing the Wikipedia content, which goes under the free document license, as its own copyrighted material, Wales said on the first day of the annual Wikimania 2007 which runs through Sunday.
Wales said he will visit China in September and meet with high-level government officials there to address the blockage issue, but added that "there is no formal expectation at this point."
He said the Web site will not accept self-censorship in order to be unblocked in China. In an earlier forum, he said Wikipedia will not allow censorship as Yahoo and Google have done.
Wikipedia is a wonderful, neutral educational resource and Chinese users should be allowed to access it, he said.

Unlike most intellectual property rights infringement cases, which can be talked through and resolved with simple phone calls or email exchanges, the Baidu.com case has been "something we've been aware of for a long time and is still ongoing, " said Florence Devouard, chair of the Board of Trustees of the Wikimedia Foundation.
Although Baidu is a NASDAQ-listed company in the U.S., the foundation "has no plan to do anything more aggressive" at the moment, Wales said.

The three-day Wikimania 2007, which was organized by the Wikimedia Foundation and Academia Sinica's Institute of Information Science, is both a scientific conference and a community event that brings together bloggers and members of various Wikimedia projects.
The Wikimedia Foundation is a non-profit organization that supports nine free information projects, including Wikipedia -- a multilingual, web-based, free content encyclopedia project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local Wikipedia chapter aims to promote collaborative editing

TEXT.P: The local chapter of the popular online reference Web site Wikipedia aims to promote collaborative editing, knowledge sharing and the Web site in Taiwan, the organizer of the chapter said Friday on the sidelines of an annual Wikimedia conference.

Wikimedia Taiwan was officially approved by the Wikimedia Foundation, a non- profit organization that supports nine free information projects including Wikipedia, in July as one of the foundation's 10 local charters around the world, Wikimedia Taiwan President Deng Chieh said.
Taiwanese users have been one of the most active groups in generating Chinese- language content on Wikipedia, a multilingual, Web-based, free content encyclopedia project, Deng said.

Wikimedia Taiwan plans to work with government agencies, academic institutions and schools as more and more of them have expressed interest in the new way of sharing free information, said Deng. The chapter will also be in charge of redistribution of content, organizing small group meetings to improve Chinese content, holding promotional events and trying to collect content directly from institutions such as local museums and libraries.
Wikipedia has become one of the most popular reference Web sites in Taiwan, especially among students, Deng said.
"The Web site traffic always peaks before final exams and dramatically hits bottom during summer and winter vacations, " he pointed out.
The current development of the Web site shows a lot of potential, he added, as many local companies have inquired about using the free licensed content for future development of commercial services.

The Wikimedia Foundation has been working on establishing local charters in many countries to foster better communication with locals and better content for various languages, said Florence Devouard, chair of the Board of Trustees of the Wikimedia Foundation.
Wikimedia Taiwan was established in February 2007 and has more than 40 members, Deng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Congress Backs Tighter Rules on Lobbying
The Senate gave final approval Thursday to a far-reaching package of new ethics and lobbying rules, with an overwhelming majority of Republicans and Democrats agreeing to improve policing of the relationship between lawmakers and lobbyists.
Wall Street Journal:City Is Overcrowded for Living and Dead
Hong Kong is one of the most densely populated areas in the world -- for the living and dead alike. The government says that by 2012, half of the people who die each year may not get a resting place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourist hotel occupancy rates lower, but prices higher

TEXT.P: The overall average occupancy rate of tourist hotels in Taiwan for the first six months were 65.87 percent, down 3.15 percent from the year-earlier level last year, while the average price rose 3.91 percent to NT$3,246 (US$99) per day, an official of the Tourism Bureau said Friday.

Quoting bureau statistics released Thursday, the official said the average occupancy rate of international tourist hotels was 67.03 percent, down 3.34 percent from the same period last year. Average occupancy rates of ordinary tourist hotels was 59.87 percent, down 1.39 percent.
The official said the summer peak travel season did not revive low hotel occupancy rates, and some areas' average occupancy rates for July was as much as 50 percent below last year's figures.
The average room rate for international tourist hotels was NT$3,422, an increase of NT$159, and for ordinary tourist hotels, NT$2,224, up NT$23, the official said.

Average occupancy rates for tourist hotels in the Taichung area dropped by 14.76 percent. Among these, occupancy rates at international tourist hotels decreased by 18.11 percent, while those of ordinary tourist hotels increased by 53.1 percent. Average room prices for the area's international hotels dropped by 3 percent, while those of ordinary hotels decreased by 25 percent, thereby contributing to the increase in the occupancy rate, the official said.
The Miramar Garden Taipei hotel had the highest occupancy rate in Taipei City, at 91.64 percent, followed by the city's Cosmos Hotel and Kilin Hotel.

The Monarch Plaza Hotel in Taoyuan County enjoyed the nation's highest occupancy rate at 93.73, while the Parkview Hotel in Hualien County had an occupancy rate at only 59.53 percent, the highest rate in that area.

The nation's top five hotels in terms of operating revenue for the first six months were: Grand Hyatt Taipei, NT$1.48 billion, Grand Formosa Regent Taipei, NT$1.22 billion, Sheraton Taipei Hotel, NT$1.12 billion, Far Eastern Plaza Hotel Taipei, NT$884 million, and Howard Plaza Hotel Taipei, NT$777 million. These five hotels are all in Taipei area, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan plans lawsuit against ISO over name issue

TEXT.P: The government is mulling a plan to file a lawsuit against the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) for its erroneous designation of Taiwan as a province of China, diplomatic sources said Friday.

The lawsuit plan came after U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon recently rejected President Chen Shui-bian's letter expressing Taiwan's intention to apply for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan on the ground that Taiwan is part of China.

An increasing number of international organizations and enterprises have also wrongly identified Taiwan as a province of China in recent years as they refer to the ISO's codes for the representation of names of countries and their subdivisions (ISO-3166), the sources noted.

Taiwan has long been negotiating with the ISO over the designation issue but has not received any positive response from the ISO, the sources said, adding that the government has had to consider a legal battle as the last resort.
ISO officials have pointed out that they did not coin the term but rather simply follow the policy of the United Nations when it formulated ISO-3166 in 1974.

Describing the ISO's use of "Taiwan, China" as an "infringement of Taiwan's name right, " diplomatic officials predicted that Geneva courts will accept the lawsuit, as the ISO is not an official international organization. But the officials added that it remains uncertain when a lawsuit will be formally filed.

The Geneva-based International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is an international standard-setting body composed of representatives from various national standards bodies. Founded on Feb. 23, 1947, the organization produces world-wide industrial and commercial standards.

While the ISO defines itself as a non-governmental organization (NGO) , its ability to set standards that often become law, either through treaties or national standards, makes it more powerful than most NGOs. In practice, the ISO acts as a consortium with strong links to governments. As of fall 2006, there are 158 members, each of which represents one country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan world's 4th-largest holder of foreign exchange reserves

TEXT.P: Taiwan remains the world's fourth-largest holder of foreign exchange reserves, with the total recorded at the end of July amounting to US$266.29 billion, according to statistics released Friday by Taiwan's central bank -- the Taipei- based Central Bank of China.

Bank officials pointed out that the total represents an increase of US$235 million from June, due mainly to interest accruing from existing foreign exchange reserves and foreign money remitted into Taiwan.
They noted that Taiwan has since May ranked fourth in the world in terms of foreign exchange reserves, behind China, Japan and Russia.
China's reserves stood at US$1.33 trillion at the end of June, followed by Japan's US$892.8 billion and Russia's US$298.5 billion.
Russia replaced Taiwan as the world's third-largest holder of foreign exchange reserves in May when its total reached US$284.1 billion.

Other statistics provided by the bank show that South Korea's reserves totaled US$254.4 billion at the end of July, while Singapore and Hong Kong recorded foreign exchange reserves totaling US$144.9 billion and US$130.9 billion in June, respectively.
Lin Sun-yuan, deputy director of the central bank's foreign exchange division, said Taiwan's reserves are enough to supply Taiwan's needs through imports for 15.7 months.
The amount is "appropriate, he said, adding that the world ranking means little.

DOC.HEADLINE: Brothers with rare disease to visit Statue of Liberty

TEXT.P: Two brothers who have suffered from the rare Duchenne muscular dystrophy for many years, will travel to New York to see the Statue of Liberty Aug. 5, to fulfill their dreams.

Tseng Yi-kai, the elder brother, and Tseng Yi-chi, both of whom are now in their teens, suffer from the inherited fatal disorder that is characterized by rapidly progressive muscle weakness and atrophy of muscle tissue.

They have long wished to visit the famous New York City landmark that for them symbolizes freedom -- the thing they long for the most as they are confined to wheelchairs and rely totally on other people for help instead of being able to walk freely.

Paragon Investment Managers Inc., the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, China Airlines and the New York City branch of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu- chi Foundation, worked together to help the brothers realize their dream.

The two brothers will travel to New York City to make paintings of the Statue of Liberty, accompanied by their mother and staff of the Taiwan Foundation for Rare Disorders, an organization that helps sufferers of rare diseases get treatment and rehabilitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 World Games not to be affected by lawsuit: Kaohsiung mayor

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Friday that no matter who holds the reins of the Kaohsiung city government, the 2009 World Games to be held there will not be affected by a lawsuit over the validity of her election as mayor.

Chen made the pledge to Roh Froehlich, chairman of the International World Games Association (IWGA) , who was in the southern port city at the head of a delegation to inspect the preparations for the games.
It was the second time Chen had made the assurances to Froehlich over the last few days amid growing concern over the lawsuit against her that some feel might hinder preparations for the games.

Chen filed recently an appeal against a District Court ruling that annulled her victory in last December's mayoral election on the grounds that she used election gambits against her rival Huang Chun-ying of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) that could have affected the outcome of the election.

Chen told Froehlich that she has great confidence in Chi Cheng, a Taiwanese female athlete of the 1970s who serves as chief executive officer of the Kaohsiung Organizing Committee, and her team that is organizing the games. Chen said she also welcomes any suggestions from IWGA regarding the games.

Describing Taiwan as a democratic country in which the judicial authorities will make fair rulings on lawsuits, Chen assured the IWGA officials that the outcome of her lawsuit will not affect the preparations for the games.
It is the first time Taiwan has obtained the right to host the World Games, an international multi-sports event organized by the IWGA under the patronage of the International Olympic Committee (IOC).

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Anti-corruption' movement leader, 15 others indicted

TEXT.P: The Taipei Prosecutors Office indicted the leader of an anti-corruption movement against President Chen Shui-bian Friday on charges of violations of the Assembly and Parade Law.

Shih Ming-teh, leader of the "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign that staged several massive protests to demand Chen's resignation over a spate of scandals surrounding his family members and close aides last year, along with 15 other campaign officials, were named as co-defendants.
The prosecution said Shih was not the only mastermind of the illicit assemblies and that those who issued orders to the protesters and led the mob should also be considered masterminds.

The 15 officials include Legislator Shen Chih-huei of the opposition People First Party, former legislators and leaders of civic groups Chien Hsih-chieh, Cheng Lung-shui and Lin Cheng-chieh, and former Legislator and incumbent Taipei city government cultural head Lee Yung-ping.

Rounding off the list are political science professors Emile Sheng and Yao Li- ming, Taipei Councilor Lee Hsin, former Taichung County Councilor Liu Kun-li, KMT official Kuo Shu-chun, former ruling Democratic Progressive Party politician Wang Li-ping, and Jerry Fan, who is famous for his innovative ideas in the advertisement sector, as well as critics Wei Chien-feng, Chang Fu-chung and Lo Shu-lei.
All those named served as deputy leaders and spokesmen in the campaign, according to the prosecution.
Prosecutors said in the indictment that Shih formed the "depose Chen" movement Aug. 11, 2006 and decided in late September to stage a "siege" of the Presidential Office on Double Ten National Day.

On Oct. 10, 2006, Shih and the 15 officials mobilized tens of thousands of protestors to encircle the Presidential Office and Chen's official residence in an attempt to disrupt the National Day celebration activities.

On Nov. 3, 2006, Shih and five others applied for an assembly at the square in front of the Taipei Railway Station after first lady Wu Shu-jen was indicted on charges of embezzling from a "state affairs fund" for the discretionary use of her husband.

The prosecutors said Shih and others then incited around 1,000 protestors to walk to Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office without applying for permission. Police warned the crowd several times before dispersing them.

On Nov. 22, 2006, the lawful assembly time of the "depose Chen" protestors in front of the Taipei Railway Station should have ended at 10 p.m., but Lin Cheng- Chieh and others led the crowd in front of the station to a rented house nearby that served as a provisional assembly place, although no application had been made to rally there. Lin refused to disband the protestors after warnings from the police, the prosecutors said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Anti-corruption' campaign leader saddened by indictment

TEXT.P: The organizer of an anti-corruption movement against President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he was "saddened" about being indicted.

But Shih Ming-teh, leader of the "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign that mobilized tens of thousands of people to stage several massive protests against Chen over a spate of scandals surrounding his family members and close aides last year, also said he hoped the court will give a speedy ruling and that he will not appeal.

Shih made the remarks after he and 15 others, including sitting and former legislators, a Taipei city councilor, scholars and civic group leaders, were indicted by the Taipei Prosecutors Office on charges of violating the Assembly and the Parade law.

Shih said that "a different time will give rise to a different viewpoint" and he lamented that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) did not abolish the outdated Assembly and Parade Law, but used it to indict him.

Shih, a former DPP chairman who served long jail terms for advocating democracy during Taiwan's infamous martial law era, claimed he has criticized and monitored those in power "from the perspective of the people."
He said that the presidents of the Republic of China, from Chiang Kai-shek onwards, put him behind bars.
"I thought President Chen would not do such a thing, but it seems he might," he said.
Shih, who has liver cancer, said that he hopes to "serve his due term in his remaining days."

He noted that the DPP, when it was an opposition party, had advocated the repealing of the Assembly and Parade law, and that civic groups have also worked hard to repeal the law, but the DPP, after seven years in power, still has yet to repeal the "rogue" law and even uses it to act against the public.

He also expressed disappointment toward the main opposition Kuomintang, which as the largest party in the legislature, has not promoted the repealing of the Assembly and Parade law and the formulation if other human rights bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister released after being quizzed over museum scandal

TEXT.P: Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng was released Friday after being quizzed by judicial personnel over a corruption scandal linked to the renovation of the National Palace Museum's (NPM) main exhibition hall.
Tu was questioned as a witness because the controversial renovation project was initiated and launched during his tenure as director of the suburban Taipei museum between 2000 and 2004.

Prosecutors said the project's bidding process was suspected of having violated the Government Procurement Law by allowing the winning bidder of a NT$2.5 million initial planning contract to secure a follow-up NT$13.3 million design, supervision and service contract.

"We need to determine whether Tu was aware of the bidding details because Shih Shou-chien, who was Tu's deputy and later succeeded Tu as the museum's head, claimed during a questioning session that the procurement case had been referred to Tu for a final decision, " said a prosecutor responsible for investigating the case.

Tu was first questioned by agents from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau Friday afternoon, after which he was transferred to the Shihlin Prosecutors Office for further interrogation. He was released at around 7:35 p.m.
At issue was a NT$385 million museum renovation project that got underway in July 2004 and was not fully completed until late last year.

Suspecting possible irregularities in the bidding process after repeated cost overruns, the prosecutors launched massive raids on the offices and residences of architect Luo Hsing-hua and other contractors in late May, collecting a large number of files and documents in their searches.

A number of former and incumbent museum officials and former Public Construction Commission (PCC) officials have also been arraigned over the case. The museum's deputy curator, Lin Po-ting was held incommunicado in June for further questioning. Several others, including Shih, were released on bail, with bail amount ranging between NT$400,000 and NT$1 million.

The museum and the PCC were suspected of favoring architect Lo Hsien-hua, who won part of the renovation project for the main exhibition hall. Lo was released on bail last month by Shihlin prosecutors.

In February this year, the 42-year-old museum, which houses the best of the 1,000-year-old art collection of China's emperors, celebrated the reopening of its full exhibition area after its renovation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 4, or the 22nd day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1578: The Portuguese King Sebastian and his court are killed in a failed crusade to Morocco.
1875: Hans Christian Anderson, Danish writer famous the world over for his fairy tales and stories, including "The Princess and the Pea" and "The Ugly Duckling," dies in Copenhagen at the age of 70.
1906: The Education Ministry of the Ching court promulgates a set of "regulations on education for women" governing the establishment of schools for women.
1914: World War I breaks out when German troops invade Belgium. Britain declares war on Germany as the United States declares its neutrality.
1916: Denmark sells the Danish Virgin Islands to the United States for US$25 million.
1922: Fighting breaks out in Italy between the fascists and the socialists.
1938: The Nationalist government moves its offices from Wuchang and Hankow to Chungking in order to cope with the lengthy War of Resistance Against Japan.
1940: Italian troops invade the country of British Somaliland in East Africa.
1942: David Russel Lange, New Zealand Labor politician, is born. He served as prime minister from 1984 to 1989 and was controversial for his refusal to allow nuclear-armed ships to dock in New Zealand.
1944: Anne Frank, a 14-year-old German Jewish diarist, and seven other Jews in hiding in Amsterdam, are captured by the Gestapo and sent to concentration camps.
1950: Gen. Douglas MacArthur dispatches a high-ranking aide to Taipei as a liaison officer as the United States begins providing military aid to Taiwan.
1954: The P-1 English Electronic Lightning, Britain's first supersonic fighter plane, makes its maiden flight.
1960: Chung Li-ho, a noted Taiwanese folk tale author, dies at the age of 45.
1963: The Foreign Ministry declares that the Republic of China will not recognize the border treaty signed between the Peking regime and Afghanistan.
1967: Malawian President Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1972: Ugandan President Idi Amin declares that his country will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports within three months.
1976: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang extends its "deepest sympathy" to victims of the earthquake that struck northern China.
1979: Ho Yen-sheng, former Saigon correspondent for the China Times of Taipei who had been stranded in Vietnam since 1975, arrives in Taipei from an isolated island in the South China Sea where he spent 70 days as a refugee.
1986: ROC-U.S. trade talks begin in Washington. During the five-day talks, the ROC agreed to abandon its use of duty tables as of Oct. 1, 1986.
1990: Iraq installs a nine-man puppet government in Kuwait and sets up a new "People's Army" to control the regime while 12 European Community nations ban oil imports from Iraq, impose an arms embargo on the country and suspend most trade with Iraq.
1993: Japan formally apologizes for the first time to women forced to serve as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers during World War II.
1993: The Japanese Cabinet resigns, ending 38 years of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party.
1999: British Defence Secretary George Robertson becomes the new secretary- general of NATO, succeeding Javier Solana.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Mayor Tarmile Ishoda of Majuro sign a pact of alliance in Taipei, making Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, the 44th sister city of Taiwan's capital.
2000: Government Information Office Director General Chung Chin says that the GIO is mapping out procedures for setting up exchanges across the Taiwan Strait of journalists for long-term postings.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By dealing loyally and punctually with them in all engagements which he makes with them and allowing a liberal scale of pay: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to men in the public service."

DOC.HEADLINE: Allies object to U.N. rejection of Taiwan's membership application
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 4 (CNA) 08/04/07 12:36:22 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Five of Taiwan's diplomatic allies have written to the United Nations to express their objection to the world body's refusal to process Taiwan's application for membership, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Saturday.

Signed by the U.N. permanent representatives of Palau, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, the Solomon Islands, Swaziland and El Salvador, two letters were delivered Aug. 3 to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon and Pascal Gayama, rotating president of the U.N. Security Council for August.
Also attached in the letter to Gayama was a copy of a membership application letter sent to Ban by President Chen Shui-bian but returned.

The U.N. ambassadors of the five diplomatic allies requested that Gayama distribute Chen's letter to all members of the Security Council and take "proper action" to deal with Taiwan's membership application.

They accused the U.N. Secretariat of violating rules of procedure of the United Nations and of infringing upon the authority of the Security Council by returning Chen's letter without forwarding it to the Security Council for review.

In addition, they challenged the validity of the U.N. Secretariat's rejection of Taiwan's application based on Resolution 2758, a document they claim does not deny Taiwan's eligibility for membership.

After the first letter was returned, the U.N. ambassadors of Swaziland and the Solomon Islands delivered July 31 on behalf of Taiwan another letter signed by Chen to Ban and one to Wang Guangya, China's permanent representative to the United Nations, who served as rotating president of the Security Council for July.
While Wang returned the letter soon after receiving it, Ban, who is on a visit to Haiti and Barbados, has not made an official response to Chen's second letter.
Asked about the matter Friday in New York, Farhan Haq, associate spokesman for the secretary-general, said the second letter will also be returned.

Haq said the position of the United Nations toward Taiwan's membership application remains unchanged, which he reiterated is in line with Resolution 2758 and the "one China" policy of the United Nations.

The resolution was adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1971 recognizing the representatives of the People's Republic of China government as "the only legitimate representatives of China to the United Nations" and expelling representatives of the Republic of China.

The Republic of China has tried without success to re-enter the United Nations since 1993. This year marks the first time it has changed tactics by bidding to join the world body under the name of Taiwan.
In the latest letter to Ban, Chen asserted Taiwan's status as an independent sovereign nation that is entitled to membership in the United Nations.
Chen argued that U.N. Resolution 2758 neither grants China the right to represent Taiwan at the United Nations nor states that Taiwan is either a part of China or the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government publishes information on unsafe products made in China

TEXT.P: The government has published information concerning unsafe products made in China for the reference of consumers, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday.

The Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) under the MOEA published the information on its Web site www.bsmi.gov.tw after a spate of complaints about unsafe Chinese products, ranging from food, toys with high levels of heavy metals, toxic toothpaste, tainted medicine and pet food have raised concerns around the world.
To protect domestic consumers, the BSMI abridged some of the information published by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission regarding China-made unsafe products.

The information includes the name of the product, the number of units produced, the period when the goods were sold and where, the flaws and the potential danger to consumers, courses of action for affected consumers and whether the products are sold to Taiwan.
If the China-made products have caused fatalities or serious injury, and Taiwan's overseas offices confirm that the products have entered Taiwan, the BSMI will also publish such information.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAPA protests return of Taiwan's U.N membership application
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 3 (CNA) 08/04/07 14:25:35 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A U.S.-based pro-independence Taiwanese expatriate group voiced strong protest Friday against U.N. Secretary- General Ban Ki-moon's decision not to process Taiwan's application for membership in the organization under the name of Taiwan.

In a letter addressed to Ban, Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) President C.T. Lee rejected Ban's argument that the United Nations takes the position that "Taiwan is part of China" under Resolution 2758 adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1971.
"This is contrary to the facts: If you read Resolution 2758 carefully, you will see that it does not even mention Taiwan, " Lee said.

Under the resolution, the United Nations decided to recognize the representatives of the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate representatives of China to the United Nations and "to expel forthwith the representatives of Chiang Kai-shek from the place which they unlawfully occupy at the United Nations and in all the organizations related to it."
According to Lee, the issue addressed in the resolution was "which government represented China " and it is wrong to equate the "representatives of Chiang Kai-shek" with Taiwan.
"Chiang and his representatives were not expelled in 1971 because they represented Taiwan. They were expelled because they claimed to represent China," Lee noted.
On Taiwan's status, Lee referred Ban to the San Francisco Peace Treaty of 1951-52, in which Japan formally ceded sovereignty over Taiwan.

Lee pointed out that delegates at the San Francisco conference concurred that the status of Taiwan needed to be determined "in due time, in accord with the purposes and principles as laid down in the Charter of the United Nations."

Urging Ban to reconsider his position on Taiwan's application, Lee said Taiwan is a democratic nation that fulfills all the criteria for a nation-state as defined in the 1933 Montevideo Convention: a defined territory, a permanent population and a government capable of entering into diplomatic relations with other states.

President Chen Shui-bian sent a membership application letter to Ban July 19, but the letter was returned by Ban July 23 based on Resolution 2758, which U.N. officials said is the basis of the "one China" policy of the United Nations.

Chen sent another letter to Ban July 31 urging him to reconsider his decision. Ban, who is on a visit to Haiti and Barbados, has not made an official response to Chen's second letter, although Farhan Haq, associate spokesman for the secretary-general, said Friday that the second letter will also be returned and that the U.N. position remains unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Solomon Islands thanks Taiwan for medical aid

TEXT.P: Solomon Islands Ambassador to the Republic of China Beraki Jino expressed gratitude to the Taiwan International Health Action (TaiwanIHA) for its medical aid to his country after it was rocked by a strong earthquake in April, and bestowed citations on three of the group's doctors Friday.

The ceremony was held at the Department of Health, with Minister of Health Hou Sheng-mao and Ministry of Foreign Affairs Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs Deputy Director Yu Teh-sheng also present.

The TaiwanIHA, a government-funded organization that offers international medical aid, dispatched a medical team to the Solomon Islands to provide assistance to the South Pacific island country after it was hit by the magnitude-8.1 earthquake. A tsunami triggered by the earthquake made thousands of people homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: Test results on pig innards due by end of month: DOH

TEXT.P: Amid growing concerns about a banned veterinary drug used on pigs, the Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday that local health officials have collected 40 samples of pig innards from traditional markets and that test results are due by the end of the month.

Two shipments of imported U.S. pork were recently found to contain ractopamine hydrochloride, known by the brand name paylean, prompting the Bureau of Food Safety under the DOH to instruct local health officials July 20 to collect pork samples for testing.
The DOH demanded a further 40 samples of pig innards July 31.
The Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis under the DOH completed tests on the first 43 samples and announced a day earlier that three of them contained paylean.
Cheng Huei-wen, director-general of the DOH Bureau of Food Safety, said the residual levels of paylean in the three samples were relatively small and that the public need not be alarmed.
Paylean is listed by the Council of Agriculture as a banned veterinary drug, but it is allowed in the United States and some other countries.
Cheng also said that if paylean is used during the growing period of pigs, residue of the banned drug in pig innards would be many times higher than that otherwise found in pork.
But as innards usually require more elaborate processing before testing, the results will not be known until the end of the month, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins bid to host FISU Forum 2010

TEXT.P: Taiwan has won its bid to host the 2010 forum of the International University Sports Federation (FISU) , a Sports Affairs Council (SAC) official said Saturday.

It is being considered by the Taiwanese authorities as "yet another score" in the country's "sports diplomacy, " following Taipei's success in obtaining the right to host the 2009 Summer Deaflympics and Kaohsiung's winning of the right to host the 2009 World Games.

According to SAC Vice Chairman Lee Kao-hsiang, the FISU Forum is a biennial event held alternately with the universiade, and Taiwan made a bid to host the forum in a low-profile manner in light of China's isolation of the country in the international arena.

Lee said the sports park under construction in Kaohsiung City in preparation for the 2009 World Games gave Taiwan a great advantage in competing for the right to host the 2010 FISU Forum, because the availability of the facility shows the world that Taiwan has the ability to host international sports events.

The FISU, the abbreviation of the Belgium-based Federation Internationale du Sport Universitaire, is the organizer of the Winter and the Summer Universiades in uneven years and World University Championships in even years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAN LEARN FROM JAPAN TO BRIDGE WEALTH GAP: CEPD

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic policy charting body suggested Saturday that Taiwan learn from the experience of Japan and stimulate regional industry in a bid to bridge the wealth gap between urban and rural areas.

Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said that on a scale of one to five in terms of national income, Taiwan's highest income group earns 6.04-fold that of the lowest income group on average, which it said is lower than the figures in the United States, Hong Kong and South Korea.

Figures released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that the highest income group in Singapore earns 20.91-fold the lowest income group on average, compared to 17.66-fold in Hong Kong, 9.6-fold in the United States, 7.21-fold in Great Britain and 6.84-fold in South Korea.
But Taiwan's figure is still high compared to the 4.98-fold in Japan, 4.02-fold in Sweden, 3.88-fold in Norway and 3.82-fold in Finland, the officials said.
They noted that Japan, in a bid to narrow the gap between rich and poor, has continued to promote balanced development of rural and urban areas in recent years and has achieved substantial results.
In Japan, top-notch universities, research institutes and business groups that are capable of creating new industry work together to form an emerging industry cluster, they said.

Stimulation policies initiated by Japanese local governments stress local agricultural products, business features and tourism, which are combined with local history and culture to establish regional brands, they added.
Taiwan, they went on, has promoted stepped-up efforts to promote economic development in central and southern Taiwan and to care for lower income groups.
The CEPD also hopes to develop local industry with the aim of developing one feature industry for each township under its "mega investment, mega warmth" project.
The CEPD hopes that the wealth gap can be reduced to below six-fold by 2015, the officials added.

La Repubblica: Priest accused of sexual abuse.
A 82-year-old priest who has run a drug rehabilitation center in the central Italy city of Amelia for more than 40 years was accused of sexual abuses by two addicts who had been kicked out of the center. The priest strongly denied the accusations.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Rice bomber' publishes book on life story, concern for farmers

TEXT.P: "I have been seeking, seeking a window opened by God that can lead to a promising future for farmers, and seeking a pathway that can offer a hope for disadvantaged children."
This is a passage from a book titled "Rice is Not a Bomb " written in a semi- autobiographical style by Yang Ju-men, better known locally as the "rice bomber."

The book includes more than 100 letters written by Yang to Wu Ying-ning, a freelancer based in the central county of Changhua, during his incarceration. Yang details in the letters his simple but very strong motivation behind his year-long bombing campaign that led to his imprisonment.

The book also includes two letters written by Yang to society and friends, respectively, following his release from jail with President Chen Shui-bian granting him a pardon June 21. In those two letters, Yang calls for more care for the disadvantaged, particularly farmers and children, and expressed his heartfelt gratitude for those who had repeatedly appealed for his pardon in the past few years.

Yang was sentenced in 2005 to seven-and-a-half years in prison plus a fine of NT$100,000 (US$3,030.3) for planting 17 explosive devices in public places around Taipei over a one-year period until he turned himself in Nov. 26, 2004.

Identifying himself as an opponent of the government's rice import policy, Yang always sprinkled small amounts of rice in his homemade explosives, which is where his nickname came from. Nobody was injured in his year-long bombing campaign, although he struck fear and terror into the hearts of the public.

"What kind of social structure do we have that has made elderly farmers' desires to lead a peaceful life in their rural towns in the company of their children and grandchildren become a luxury and impossible dream?" Yang asks in the book.
Growing up in a Changhua farming community, Yang said he has witnessed the decline of agriculture in rural Taiwan.

"I feel deep emotional affinity with rural elders who are living below the subsistence level after imported rice and other produce eroded the market share of locally grown crops, " Yang writes. "It is against this backdrop that I had to resort to means available to a disadvantaged individual like me to express the grievances of farmers."

Yang also writes in the new book that he once met a teenage boy selling coconuts on a street in the eastern city of Hualien with a schoolbag on his back when he was on a round-the-island cycling tour.

"I stopped cycling and asked him whether he would mind eating a meal with me. The young boy told me that he had to choose between going to school or making a living. The encounter let me see clearly the predicament of those living at the bottom of society, " Yang writes, adding that the boy later died at his home as he could not afford to see a doctor.
The episode firmed up his determination to stand up for farmers and the disadvantaged, Yang writes.

Admitting that he has little knowledge of agriculture, Yang writes that he vividly remembers whole crops of watermelons and carrots being given away because they could not fetch a reasonable price. A small truckload of cabbage was often sold for less than NT$500, he writes, adding that it was not uncommon for many grape vines to be chopped down when farmers associations or wholesale dealers stopped buying the fruit.

"What I did was purely aimed at helping farmers and children. It is my humble hope that farmers can make a living on their own land and receive due respect, while children can go to school and eat their fill without losing dignity, " Yang writes.
To him, Yang writes, the sentence handed down to him by the judiciary for his terrorist acts was tantamount to a "punishment for the disadvantaged."
"The prison sentence to me was like a penalty to the underprivileged. It seems to forbid me from speaking for the disadvantaged any more, " Yang says.
But he added that he was convinced that the longer the prison term, the better for his cause.

"As a matter of fact, I looked forward to getting the death sentence. I was not mad... For me, the sentence was a symbol of political suppression. I believe that the stronger the suppression, the stronger the backlash and the breakthrough," Yang writes.
Yang further said he originally would not appeal his case after getting a seven- and-a-half-year sentence in the first instance.

"But I changed my mind after reading the verdict, which stated that I had made the explosive devices for my own criminal purposes. Such a judgment completely denied my pursuit of justice for farmers and disadvantaged children. My motivation was to call for care for the disadvantaged and I tried my best to avoid hurting any individual in my campaign," Yang writes.
He appealed his case as a protest and his sentence was reduced to five years in prison in the second trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor in Japan to boost sisterhood ties
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 4 (CNA) 08/04/07 19:38:25 (By Yang Ming-chu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu visited a Japanese electronic firm Saturday located in the city of Hachioji, a Tokyo satellite, and was "deeply impressed" by Hachioji's high-tech development.
Chen, who arrived in Japan Friday, was there to boost relations with the city of Hachioji, which established sisterhood ties with Kaohsiung last November.
According to Yamanishi Co. Vice President Hisashi Kinoshita, the city of Hachioji has become a high-tech industrial base thanks to its good-quality water and its geographic proximity to Tokyo.
Kinoshita also noted that many of the chips in the cell phones developed by Yamanishi come from Taiwan.

Chen noted that she has been promoting an industrial upgrade in Kaohsiung to transform it from a heavy-industry metropolis in southern Taiwan that emits huge quantities of carbon dioxide to a city focused on high-tech and trade industries.
Chen hailed Hachioji's transformation from a city of contract manufacturers to one now focused on research and development, expressing hope that Kaohsiung follow suit.

Meanwhile, Kinoshita said he was quite impressed by Kaohsiung's development and considers it a city full of potential, especially after the convenience brought by Taiwan's high-speed rail system that reduces significantly the travel time between the north and the south of Taiwan. He added that a Hachioji delegation composed of small- and medium-sized enterprise representatives will visit Kaohsiung next year to gain a better understanding of the city's investment environment.

Chen, who was traveling at the head of a 39-member delegation of city government officials, noted that Kaohsiung City hopes to strengthen exchanges with the city of Hachioji -- the 23rd city to establish sisterhood ties with Kaohsiung -- in various fields, including economic, trade, cultural and municipal administration.
She is also expected to take advantage of her Japan visit to tout the 2009 World Games to be held in the southern port city.
The delegation is scheduled to leave Tokyo for home Aug. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA urges donation of second-hand computers

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) is again calling for donations of second-hand computers that can be given to children living in remote areas of Taiwan.
Cheng Chi-pu, an EPA section chief, said that to narrow the digital gap between the rural and urban areas, the administration has been running the donation program since 2005.
In the last two years, the EPA has distributed 1,500 and 3,800 computers, respectively, Cheng said, adding that this year's goal is to send out another 3,800 second-hand computers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Progress made in crackdown on corruption: MOJ

TEXT.P: The government has made remarkable headway in cracking down corruption "black gold" politics during the last seven years, indicting more than 10,000 people accused of embezzling a total of NT$31.76 billion (US$968 million) , Ministry of Justice (MOJ) officials said Saturday.

According to MOJ statistics, of the 10,221 people indicted by prosecutors during the last seven years, 573 were high-ranking civil servants, 602 were lawmakers and councilors, 1,832 were middle-level civil servants, 3,021 were low-echelon government officials and 4,193 were members of the public.

The officials noted that ever since the action plan for wiping out corruption was implemented in June 2000 soon after President Chen Shui-bian assumed the presidency, the number of indictment cases related to corruption dropped from 4,102 registered in the period 1993-2000 to 3,934 in the period 2000-2007, while the number of people indicted rose by 6.6 percent in the period 2000-2007 over the period 1993-2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA protests rejection of Taiwan's U.N. membership application

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has issued a strong protest against the rejection of President Chen Shui-bian's letter requesting Taiwan's U.N. membership by China's Permanent Representative to the United Nations Wang Guangya.

MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Friday Chen's letter applying for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan was delivered July 31 to Wang Guangya, who served as rotating president of the U.N. Security Council for July, through the U.N. representatives of Swaziland and the Solomon Islands, two of Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

However, Wang Guangya returned immediately Chen's letter the same day, arguing that Resolution 2758 adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1971 recognizes the representatives of the People's Republic of China government as the "only legitimate representatives of China to the United Nations, " and that China's representation in the U.N. "naturally" includes Taiwan.
Wang Chien-yeh said Wang Guangya's remarks are unacceptable to Taiwan as it will mislead the world community and sacrifice the basic human rights of Taiwan's 23 million people.

He added that only the U.N. Security Council and General Assembly have the right to screen and decide membership applications, which is why Chen sent Wang Guangya the letter after a letter sent to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon earlier in July was rejected, with Ban noting that U.N. membership is only granted to sovereign countries and that the U.N. considers Taiwan to be "part of China."
Wang Guangya failed to do his job by not delivering Chen's letter to the U.N. Security Council for screening, Wang Chien-yeh added.

He further noted that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been governed by separate governments for the last six decades and that Resolution 2758 does not mention Taiwan, neither does it give the People's Republic of China the right to represent the people of Taiwan in the U.N.

China has "wrongly interpreted" Resolution 2758 and has tried to create a false "one China" concept around the world, to which the Taiwan government expresses its strongest protest, Wang Chien-yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Project 'moulin' to help unconnected world with offline Wikipedia

TEXT.P: As most people are happy surfing Wikipedia, one of the most popular online reference Web sites, some people have been trying to deliver an "offline Wikipedia" to the developing countries and the "unconnected part of the world". One of them is French programmer Renaud Gaudin, who is working for the purpose under a project named "moulin."

The "moulin, " which means windmill in French, attempts to improve the access to basic information and reference material in developing countries by making it possible to access Wikipedia offline, said Gaudin Saturday in a seminar of Wikimania 2007, an annual Wikimedia conference which is being held in Taipei.

"Basically, moulin is a fully interactive, offline version of the entire Wikipedia, without pictures, on a CD, " said the French programmer who based in West African country Mali as an non-government organization volunteer.

The project is the brainchild of Gaudin and Frederic Renet, who realized that while many organizations focused on bringing computer to people in developing countries, few have paid attention to making content available for people in those places that do not have access to the Internet.

"Wikipedia has been also developing a project called 'Wikipedia on DVD', a CD collection of around 2,000 Wikipedia articles, but we want to do more than that. We wanted to have the full Wikipedia in the CD because people in Africa don't know about too many things, " said Gaudin.
The current French version moulin contains around 450,000 Wikipedia articles, he said.

Moulin started off as a side project of Geekcorps Mali, an NGO Gaudin worked for. The initial prototype of the system ran on Nokia 770, a portable internet tablet. Gaudin later rewrote the software and developed the current version of moulin which can be run off a CD before volunteering for his second tour to Mali.

Gaudin, who is now developing the software on his own with several friends volunteering in developing the software in different languages, said he talked to organizations and projects, such as OLPC (One Laptop Per Child), for collaboration.
"OLPC said it would develop a system of its own since the project targeted for children and did not need the whole Wikipedia, " he said.

The biggest problem for Gaudin right now is the lack of distribution power and funding, although it did receive funding from USAID. Without enough money, it's difficlut to distribute the French version CDs across West Africa, he said.

Gaudin, who visits Taiwan for the first time, is still optimistic, saying he plans to develop the pocket device version of moulin and set up a distribution network in Africa. He also looks forward to collaborating with people in other countries.

It's hard to spend a day in Mexico and not put money in his pocket. The 67-year- old tycoon controls more than 200 companies -- he says he's "lost count" -- in telecommunications, cigarettes, construction, mining, bicycles, soft-drinks, airlines, hotels, railways, banking and printing.
In all, his companies account for more than a third of the total value of Mexico's leading stock market index, while his fortune represents 7% of the country's annual economic output.

DOC.HEADLINE: Veterinary drugs law offenders to get harsher penalties

TEXT.P: Offenses against the veterinary drugs management act will be subject to harsher penalties after proposed amendments to the law are approved by the legislature, an animal health official said Saturday.

Yeh Ying, deputy director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) under the Council of Agriculture (COA) , made the remarks amid growing concern about a banned veterinary drug, ractopamine hydrochloride, recently found in two shipments of imported U.S. pork and some samples of locally produced pork and goose meat.

The issue has drawn even more attention after law enforcement officers seized a large amount of raw materials used for production of ractopamine hydrochloride, known by the brand name paylean, in raids around Taiwan in the past couple of days.

Yeh said even though paylean is allowed in the United States and some other countries for use as a food addictive to boost growth of lean meat in pigs, the COA has no plan to lift the ban on the drug at the moment.

Moreover, Yeh said the BAPHIQ has tightened law enforcement to deter offenses against the ban. Starting July 1, the bureau has required local livestock and poultry inspectors to conduct hair tests for residue of the banned drug.

In addition to cooperating with prosecution authorities in the recent raids on upperstream raw materials importers and paylean manufacturers, the bureau has also asked local courts to adopt a stricter attitude toward relevant offenses, including use, importing, manufacturing and marketing.
Under the current regulations, those who illegally use paylean to feed pigs or poultry will be slapped with fines ranging between NT$6,000 and NT$30,000.

According to the BAPHIQ-drafted package of amendments to the law, the fine for paylean users will be raised to a tune of NT$30,000 to NT$150,000; the prison term for importers and manufacturers of the banned drug will be raised from the current "no more than three years" to "between three years and seven years plus a fine of NT$900,000"; and the penalty for dealers or distributors will be raised from the current "a maximum of two years to a maximum of three years plus a fine of NT$900,000."
Yeh said the draft amendments will be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval during the new legislative session scheduled to open next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to name new envoy to Britain: Vice FM
DOC.DATELINE: Edinburgh, Britain, Aug. 4 (CNA) 08/04/07 23:40:33 (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will name an outstanding individual to serve as the country's new representative to Britain as Taipei-London relations are very important to Taiwan's overall well-being, a visiting diplomatic official said Saturday.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chang Siao-yue made the remarks in response to a press inquiry about the replacement of Edgar Lin who will end his stint as the Republic of China's representative to Britain in mid-August.
To the best of her understanding, Chang said President Chen is still scouting a suitable person to succeed Lin as the country's top representative in Britain.
Given the importance of relations with Britain, the president will definitely choose the best qualified talent to fill the post.
Chang arrived in Edinburgh Friday to boost the morale of the Taipei First Girls High School marching band which has been invited to perform in the annual Edinburgh Military Tattoo.
The 135-member student band is the only team from Asia to have been invited to participate in this year's event. It gave its debut performance Friday, winning resounding acclaim from the spectators.
