DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 5, or the 23rd day of the six month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: Henry I, the youngest son of William the Conqueror, is crowned king in Westminster Abbey, three days after his brother William Rufus was killed in a hunting accident in the New Forest.
1858: The laying of the world's first transatlantic telegraph cable between Ireland and Newfoundland is completed.
1792: Frederick North, British politician known as "Lord North," dies at the age of 60. He served as prime minister (1770-1782) under George III and instituted policies that led to the rebellion of the American colonies.
1861: A national income tax is introduced in the United States, initially to fund the Civil War.
1895: Friedrich Engels, German socialist theorist and writer, dies at the age of 75. He met Karl Marx in Paris in 1844 and collaborated with him on "The Communist Manifesto" in 1848.
1930: Neil Armstrong, American astronaut and the first man on the moon, is born.
1948: The Republic of China and the United States agree to organize the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, with Chiang Meng-lin, James Yen and Shen Chung-han from the ROC, and Dr. Raymond T. Moyer and Dr. John Earl Baker from the United States as commissioners.
1949: The United States issues a "White Paper" on Sino-American relations, blaming the Nationalist government for the occupation of the Chinese mainland by the communists.
1950: A Kuomintang Central Reform Committee is set up in Taipei.
1950: The U.S. 13th Air Force is stationed in Taiwan to help the ROC guard against possible mainland Chinese air attacks.
1952: The first Japanese Embassy in Taiwan officially opens on Taipei's Chungshan North Road following the exchange of diplomatic notes ratifying the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Liberia.
1958: The nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus completes a historic 2,000-mile (3,200-km) underwater journey from Point Barrow in Alaska to the Greenland Sea, passing directly under the North Pole during its five-day voyage.
1958: Vice President Chen Cheng, who was appointed on July 1 to the concurrent post of Executive Yuan president, presides over a ceremony laying the foundation for the construction of the NT$3,200 million Shihmen Dam.
1971: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with the Republic of Turkey.
1973: The Hua Hsing Junior High School baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to represent the Far East in the Senior League World Series.
1974: The Republic of China Amateur Big League baseball team leaves Taipei to participate in the 1974 Amateur Big League World Series in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla.
1976: The Executive Yuan approves the extension for two years of the Sino- Panamanian pact on technical fishery cooperation.
1984: Richard Burton, Welsh-born actor and twice husband of actress Elizabeth Taylor, dies of a stroke at his home in Switzerland.
1986: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team leaves for Moscow to compete in the 10th Women's Basketball World Championships.
1991: President Lee Teng-hui receives Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara.
1999: The 18th International Baseball Association World Amateur Big League Baseball Championship opens in Kaohsiung County with 12 teams from Cuba, Japan, South Korea, Panama, the United States and Taiwan participating.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces the list of members for his inter-party task force on cross-strait relations, which he said will be an advisory body for the ROC president and not a policy-making unit.
2001: National Defense University President Gen. Hsia Ying-tsou says that Taiwan's first state-financed military think tank, the National Center for Strategic Studies, will be inaugurated on Sept. 1.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By strictly limiting the time of their service and making all imposts as light as possible: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to the mass of the people."

MANILA, PhilippinesXResidential customers of the Manila Electric Co. will see their bills go down by 43 centavos per kilowatt-hour this month, mainly due to a reduction in generation and system loss charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Telecom workers union poised to organize new party

TEXT.P: The Chunghwa Telecom Workers' Union (CTWU) may team up with other industrial workers unions across the country to organize a new political party and field its own candidates in the next legislative election, CTWU Chairman Chang Hsu- chung said Sunday.

Chang said the CTWU board of directors held a meeting recently, during which it was resolved that he be appointed to organize a new political party representing members of all workers' unions around the country, including teachers unions, so that these group of people might be represented independently in the legislature.

Noting that the country's workers groups have been dependent on other political parties when it comes to efforts to fight for their rights and interests, Chang said that by organizing their own party, the workers will have a better means to advance their causes.

Funding to the tune of NT$10 million has already been secured, enough for the soon-to-be-organized party to field 10 of its members in the next legislative election slated for Jan. 12, 2008, Chang noted.

According to Chang, members of national federations of different industries from around the island, as well as the CTWU and the Formosa Plastics Workers' Union met July 19 for a preparatory meeting for the establishment of a Workers Solidarity Union.
Representatives of these groups of people are expected to meet again Aug. 21, when the "Workers Solidarity Union" might be formally established, according to Chang.

Once the "Workers Solidarity Union" is established, it will launch campaigns to push for a nationwide referendum on a workers' version of the annuity policy, instead of an Executive Yuan's annuity policy; a referendum on the ban on dispatch workers; and guarantees stabilizing employment opportunities, Chang said.

Chang added that it is still too early to speculate on whether the name of the political party that the workers groups are poised to form would be called the Workers Solidarity Union Party. The party could also have a name called the Third Force Reform Union or something else, he said.

In light of the fact that there are 8.6 million workers in Taiwan, political analysts said the prospective workers party could be a political force to be reckoned with if it wins their support. some around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: President kicks off 1,000-km round-the-island cycling activity

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a ceremony held in front of the Presidential Office Sunday to mark the launch of an 11-day, 1,000-km round-the- island cycling activity.

A total of 150 cyclists -- a record high number in the activity's five-year-old history -- from 13 countries and areas are taking part in the cycling activity, which will take them from Taipei City to 18 cities and counties as well as 100 townships and rural townships around the island.
The cyclists, mostly college students, are from the United States, the United Kingdom, Denmark, Ukraine, Germany, Brazil, Australia, Japan, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, Macau and the host Taiwan.

The activity is organized by the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council and sponsored by the private Farglory Business Group, which offers NT$3 million in insurance for each of the cyclists and finances a paramedic vehicle to accompany the cycling team throughout the round-the-island journey.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Gasoline is too expensive.
The Ministry of Economic Development has found that the gasoline price in Italy is four cents higher for a liter than the average of the European Union. It decided to call a meeting of refineries and distributors Aug. 10 to re-examine petroleum prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan scores two wins in 2007 Bronco League Baseball World Series
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 4 (CNA) 08/05/07 17:32:26 (By Chou Shih-hui and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: An elementary school baseball team from Taiwan has pocketed two wins in the 2007 Pony Baseball Bronco League World Series being contested among eight teams in Monterey, California.

The Taiwanese team, formed by schoolchildren aged 11-12 from Sijhih Elementary School in Taipei County, is competing in the series under the name "Chinese Taipei." The championship tournament is being played Aug. 2-7 in the Jacks Baseball Park.

On Aug. 2, the opening day of the series, the Taiwanese boys trounced the Stratford team of Connecticut -- the winning team of America's East Zone -- running up a score of 15: 3, including eight runs in the first inning. The game was terminated at the end of the fifth inning when the Taiwan team's lead exceeded 10 runs.

In its second match Saturday, the Taiwan team again brought the game to an early end in the fifth inning by defeating the Pacific Grove team from California 27:1. The Taiwanese boys had seven runs in the first inning, and scored in every inning thereafter, bringing in five runs in the second inning, four in the third, and 11 in the fifth inning.
The Taiwanese team will meet the Lafayette team from Indiana, another team in the Green Division, Aug. 5. Lafayette has also pocketed two wins, defeating Pacific Grove 6:5 and Stratford 15:14.
If the Taiwanese boys win the game against Lafayette, they will be pitted against the runner-up in the White Division and will likely earn the right to compete in the final championship game Aug. 7.

The Taiwanese schoolchildren were warmly received by the organizers and the local Chinese community. Some of the children said they were nearly moved to tears when they saw their national flag being raised during the opening ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA bans imports of meat, related products from UK

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has imposed a temporary ban on imports of meats and related products from Britain Saturday after the British government announced earlier that day an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) on a farm in southern England, a COA official said Sunday.

Sung Hua-tsung, director of the COA Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said that the COA imposed the ban on pork, mutton and beef imports from the United Kingdom soon after the British government's announcement.

Sung noted, however, that the ban would have little impact on meat supplies in the domestic market since British pork, mutton and beef products constitute only a tiny fraction of Taiwan's total meat imports.
As of Sunday noon, major countries, including the United States, Japan and Singapore, have all announced bans on imports of such products from the United Kingdom.
FMD, which can travel on the wind as well as farm equipment, causes high fevers and blisters in cloven-hoofed animals and often leads to death. It is very rarely transferred to humans.
This is the first FMD outbreak reported in the United Kingdom since 2001.

According to foreign wire news reports, British authorities have set up a 3-km radius exclusion zone and a wider 10 km surveillance area around the infected farm in the county of Surrey. Within that area is a laboratory used by the British Institute for Animal Health to test foot-and-mouth samples.

While the laboratory has not been fingered as the outbreak's source, this strain of FMD has been identified as similar to that isolated in a 1967 outbreak, and used in vaccine production and diagnostics.
Movement of all pigs, sheep and cattle in the United Kingdom has reportedly been banned as a further precautionary measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-legislator deported from China back to Taiwan under escort

TEXT.P: Former opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chang Wen-yi, who has been on the wanted list of Taiwan police since December 2004 on charges of fraud, was deported from China and escorted back to Taiwan Sunday by officials from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MOJIB).
According to the bureau, Chang, 59, was arrested in Macau Saturday soon after he flew into the former Portuguese colonial district from Shanghai earlier that day.

Chang was indicted in November 1999 on charges of fraud and insider trading in a case involving himself and Taichung Kuangsan Group Chairman Tseng Cheng-jen, in which the pair jointly embezzled all of the assets of a company that had established a major, renowned department store in Taichung.
Judges from the Taichung High Court sentenced Chang in September 2004 to a one- year jail term, only to find that Chang had fled the country Aug. 31 the same year.
The Taichung District Prosecutors' Office put him on a wanted fugitive list on Dec. 31 the same year.
Since fleeing Taiwan, Chang has reportedly done business in areas around Shanghai, investing in plastic ware and footwear manufacturing plants there.
Chang was brought to the MOJIB Taichung station for questioning immediately after he arrived in the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport around 4:30 p.m. Sunday.
He is expected to be referred to the Taichung District Prosecutors' Office later that day for further questioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical Storm Pabuk moving toward Taiwan

TEXT.P: Tropical storm Pabuk -- the fifth named storm in the Western Pacific this year -- formed northwest of Guam and is moving in a northwesterly direction toward Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said in a forecast Sunday.
The center of the storm is expected to be located at 660 km southeast of the Ryukyu Islands around 2 p.m. Monday.
CWB meteorologists said Pabuk has a 100 km-radius and is packing winds of 18 meters per second, or 65 kph, with gusts reaching 25 meters per second.
If the tropical storm maintains its present course and speed, it will make a landfall in Taiwan Aug. 8.

According to the CWB forecast, another tropical depression formed near the Spratlys and is moving slowly toward waters east of Vietnam. Because its location is close to a landmass, its strength will be limited even if it develops into a tropical storm.

The forecast also said that regions of western Taiwan will likely see thunderstorms and showers over the next two to five days, mainly due to the effects of a receding ridge of high pressure in the Pacific.
Rain brought by the southwesterly winds are expected to lower maximum daily temperatures in these areas from 37 degrees Celsius to 34-35 C.

DOC.HEADLINE: True confidence grows from understanding Taiwan: DPP candidate

TEXT.P: Taiwanese patriots should try to understand the country because true confidence emerges from a robust knowledge of its capacity and the people's vitality, the ruling party's presidential candidate said Saturday.

Frank Hsieh, the Democratic Progressive Party's standard bearer in the 2008 presidential election, made the remarks as he concluded the first stop of a nationwide campaign tour, dubbed the "New Six Stars Plan."
Hsieh started his tour in the eastern county of Hualien Thursday, with plans to stay for three days at each stop, visiting local industries and meeting grassroots supporters.
After three days of touring local communities, Hsieh said he has come to a deeper understanding of Taiwan's strength.

"Every time when I visit a local community, I see the strength and vigor of our people and come to know many heartwarming real-life stories. The tour has afforded me a valuable opportunity to understand Hualien's unique features and merits and further enhance my confidence in Taiwan's future," Hsieh said.

On the last day of his visit in Hualien, Hsieh toured the Lintienshan Culture Museum and a forest railway in addition to inspecting a railway bridge reconstruction project in the county's Yuli township.

Hsieh said the development of eastern Taiwan should not follow the mode adopted in the western part of the country because the two areas have different resources. For instance, eastern Taiwan is rich in maritime and tourist resources that deserve further exploration with eco-friendly ways.

Noting that the "New Six Stars Plan" is aimed at transforming Taiwan into a globally competitive country, Hsieh said that under the plan, Taiwan can be divided into six regions, with each region comparable to Singapore in scale and size. According to Hsieh's plan, each region should cooperate with the others and allow mutual use of their resources in order to sharpen their competitive edge.
Hsieh returned to Taipei Saturday evening to attend a campaign rally of Legislator Huang Shih-cho of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, who is seeking re- election next January.
Hsieh will continue his "New Six Stars Plan" campaign tour next week, with visits to Taitung in eastern Taiwan and the northeastern county of Yilan.

When Hsieh was premier in 2005, he also promoted a "Six Stars Plan," with the "six stars" referring to developing local businesses, improving social welfare and medical system, promoting cultural and educational development, maintaining public safety, protecting the environment and preserving natural scenery.

DOC.HEADLINE: President doesn't confirm Beijing has nixed his APEC envoy choice

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian did not confirm a local newspaper's report Sunday that Beijing has vetoed his choice of former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen as Taiwan's envoy to the informal summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, slated for September 8-9 in Sydney, Australia.

In a response to journalists questions while attending a lunch party with friends at Shezi, in Taipei City, the president said that if the report carried on Sunday's China Times is true, it only confirms his administration's claims that Beijing will spare no efforts in its attempts to isolate Taiwan.
Chen added that Beijing's interference is constant, regardless of the political affiliation or gender of Taiwanese political figures.

Without confirming that he had chosen Tsai as his envoy to the APEC Economic Leaders Meeting, the president said he will not yield to China's pressure, but continue to fight to defend the Taiwan's interests.

Meanwhile, Cho Jung-tai, acting secretary-general of the Presidential Office said the president is still searching for a proper envoy to act on his behalf at the APEC summit, and will reveal his decision before Aug. 20, adding that Beijing's opinion won't be a factor in his decision.

Although Taiwan is a member of the APEC, due to Beijing's opposition, no president has ever attended the summit since its inception in 1993. Instead, the country has sent an envoy in place of its president to the summits.
Last year the president appointed Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, as his envoy to the summit hosted by Vietnam in its capital, Hanoi.

In a front page story, the China Times cited anonymous sources as saying that Tsai has been chosen as the envoy this year by the president, but has been rejected by Beijing on the grounds that she was one of the advisors who help former President Lee Teng-hui characterize Taiwan's ties with China as "a special state-to-state relationship," in 1999.
Angered by Lee's claims, Beijing has put a halt on all dialogue with Taiwan ever since.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese Internet entrepreneur advocates 'the sharing economy'

TEXT.P: In the Internet age, the idea of a "sharing economy" will impact the traditional market economy and a group of amateurs will be able to do phenomenonal things by collaborating with one another, a Japanese internet entrepreneur said on the final day of the Wikimania 2007 international conference.

"The market economy basically tells people to make as much money as possible, but not everything evolves around making money, " Joichi Ito, a Japanese-born, American-educated activist, entrepreneur and venture capitalist, told around 400 participants of the annual Wikimedia conference.

The evolution of the Internet has changed the ways people live as well as their perspectives, he said, pointing out that the importance of "happiness, which comes from compassion of giving and receiving, " instead of money, matters more to people nowadays.

The online encyclopedia Wikipedia, a collaboration by a community of so-called amateur contributors all over the world, is a good example, he said. It provides for the needs of some, who have no current means with which to reciprocate: a characteristic of a sharing economy.
As much as everyone likes to share good things with others, it has also given rise to the piracy issue, and despite efforts to stamp it out, illegal reproduction and downloads still exist.

Commercial companies should learn to view things from a different perspective in the light of an ethic of sharing, Ito claimed. For example, he said, a video remix about politics using various television news clips should be considered a "new means of practicing free speech."
Ito, chairman of the board of Creative Commons (CC), also talked about new forms of copyright that the non-profit organization advocates.
"You give away some rights while still remaining the copyright holder, "he said.

CC is devoted to expanding the range of creative work available for others to legally build upon and share. It has released several copyright licenses known as Creative Commons licenses which, depending on the one chosen, restrict only certain rights (or none) of the work.

CC and Wikimedia are both part of the Free Culture movement, a social movement that calls for the freedom to use the Internet and other media to distribute and modify creative works, including software.

Under pressure from President Bush, the House gave final approval Saturday to changes in a terrorism surveillance program, despite serious objections from many Democrats about the scope of the executive branchs new eavesdropping power.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker says he only has party, state in mind

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Sunday that his primary concern now is how to help the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) win the legislative and presidential elections next year, not whether the party will assure him a legislator-at-large seat in the next legislature.
Wang made the remarks during a trip to Changhua County in central Taiwan to take part in a religious ceremony.

Asked by reporters to comment on news reports that he could lose his status as the legislative speaker in 2008 because the KMT might not invite him to be its No. 1 legislator-at-large, Wang said he would not pay much attention to such reports, because he only has the KMT and the state in mind.
He said his foremost concern at present is to do his utmost to help the party win the two elections next year.
The Central Election Commission has decided to hold the legislative elections on Jan. 12 next year, followed by the presidential election on March 22.
Meanwhile, KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said in Taipei that it will be a "positive thing" if Wang can continue to serve as Legislative Yuan speaker next year.

Wang declined to be Ma's running mate after Ma became the KMT's presidential nominee in early May. The two political heavyweights were bitter rivals in the 2005 KMT chairmanship election and the process to name the party's presidential candidate.
However, after Ma invited Vincent Siew, a former premier from 1997 to 2000 when the KMT was the ruling party, to be his running mate, Wang has pledged his full support for the Ma-Siew ticket.

DOC.HEADLINE: President blames Beijing for nixing his APEC envoy choice

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian blamed China Sunday for nixing his choice of a woman as Taiwan's envoy to the informal summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, slated for September 8-9 in Sydney, Australia.
He made the comments while speaking at a seminar organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan to push for the country's bid to join the United Nations.

Defending his unsuccessful effort late August to apply for U. N. membership for the country under the name of Taiwan, Chen told the seminar that Beijing's attempts to isolate Taiwan won't stop even if Taiwan leans over backward to refrain from offending China.

In order to support his claim that Beijing's interference is constant, regardless of the political affiliation or gender of Taiwan's political leaders, Chen said for the first time that Beijing has vetoed Taiwan's decision to have a woman envoy to the APEC Economic Leaders Meeting this year.

Although he didn't mention the woman envoy's name, it was the closet remarks he have ever made to a confirmation of the local newspaper China Time's story that Beijing has rejected Chen's choice of former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen as his envoy to the meeting.

In a front page story, the paper cited anonymous national security officials as saying that Beijing rejected Tsai on the grounds that she was one of the advisors who help former President Lee Teng-hui characterize Taiwan's ties with China as "a special state-to-state relationship," in 1999.
Angered by Lee's claims, Beijing has put a halt on all dialogue with Taiwan ever since.

Asking by journalists for comments, the president said in Shezi, Taipei City earlier the day that "if" the China Times' report is true, it only confirms his administration's claims that Beijing will spare no efforts in its attempts to isolate Taiwan.
Instead of admitting what would be a diplomatic setback for Taipei, the president said at that time that he will not yield to China's pressure, but continue to fight to defend the Taiwan's interests.

Meanwhile, Cho Jung-tai, acting secretary-general of the Presidential Office said the president is still searching for a proper envoy to act on his behalf at the APEC summit, and will reveal his decision before Aug. 20, adding that Beijing's opinion won't be a factor in his decision.

Although Taiwan is a member of the APEC, due to Beijing's opposition, no president has ever attended the summit since its inception in 1993. Instead, the country has sent an envoy in place of its president to the summits.
Last year the president appointed Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, as his envoy to the summit hosted by Vietnam in its capital, Hanoi.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan owes its democracy to Presbyterian Church: President Chen

TEXT.P: Taiwan owes its democracy to the Presbyterian Church in Taiwan, President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday.

In a gathering organized by the church in Taipei to mark the 30th anniversary of its issuance of a human right declaration in which it called for Taiwan's independence, Chen lauded the church leaders' courage to speak for justice and truth when the island was under the Kuomintang's authoritarian rule.
The Presbyterian Church leaders' advocacy for better human rights protection and democracy has inspired the people on the island to fight for freedom and democracy, the president said.
But for the church leaders' efforts, Taiwan wouldn't be a democracy as it is now, the president went on.

Noting that the democracy in the country still has to be solidified and improved, the president urged the church and its leaders to keep their efforts in building the country into a normal state by helping with the country's bid for U.N. membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chief to visit Philippines

TEXT.P: Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progress Party, will visit the Philippines Aug. 9-11, a Taiwanese expatriate said here Sunday.

Hsieh Shih-ying, a leader of local Taiwanese community, told CNA that Hsieh will study local market and exchange views with Taiwan businessmen working here during his tour as the DPP administration is encouraging businessmen to shift their investment away from China to southeast Asian states.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB expected to issue sea warning for Tropical Storm Pabuk

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) is likely to issue a sea warning for Tropical Storm Pabuk between Monday afternoon and Tuesday morning, forecasters said Monday.

As of Monday morning, Pabuk was centered 1,300 km southeast of Taiwan, moving northwesterly toward Taiwan at 25 kph and packing center winds of up to 85 kph, the forecasters said, adding that the tropical storm has continued to increase in intensity.
While there is a high probability that Pabuk will make landfall in Taiwan, waters surrounding the island will definitely be affected, they said.

A sea warning will be issued Monday afternoon at the earliest, the forecasters said, adding that if the storm's speed of movement decreases, a sea warning will be issued Tuesday morning at the latest.
They further said the CWB will need to continue monitoring the movement of the storm to determine to what extent the storm will affect the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Studio Classroom wins Asian publishing award

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based English-learning magazine Studio Classroom has won an Asian Publishing Management Award for its outstanding circulation program to expand its readership, magazine officials said Monday.
The winners of the first Asian Publishing Management Awards were announced during the first Asia Pacific Publishing Convention (APPC) held Aug. 2-3 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

The eight categories covered by the awards are: circulation, editorial, design and layout, advertising sales campaign, magazine franchise, best new launch of a local title, best use of multi-media by an advertiser, and innovative corporate communications in a multi-media world.

The APPC, which aims to be a learning and networking convention for print, online and mobile media in Asia, saw the participation of more than 250 senior publishing professionals from 15 countries, according to Studio Classroom officials.
The theme of this year's event was "Integrate Publishing with Digital Technology Profitably."

The conference speakers from Taiwan included Johnny Duann, editor-in-chief of Advertising Magazine; Wenny Wang, vice president and editor-in-chief of Business Weekly; and Simon Hung, general manager of Studio Classroom.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sqaud wins 3rd straight at 2007 Bronco League World Series
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 5 (CNA) 08/06/07 13:08:56 (By Josie Chou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei little league baseball team earned its third straight win Sunday at the 2007 Pony Baseball Bronco League World Series being held in Monterey, California.
The Taiwan team -- made up of students from Sijhih Elementary School in Taipei County -- trounced the Lafayette team from Indiana 16-1 to win the Green Division.

With the victory, the Chinese Taipei little leaguers won the Green Division and qualified for the semi-finals. They will take on the runner-up in the White Division Monday afternoon for the right to compete in the championship game slated for Tuesday.

On the opening day of the eight-team tournament Thursday, the Taiwan squad beat the Stratford team from Connecticut by a score of 15-3 before going on to trounce the Pacific Grove team from California 27-1 on Saturday.
The team manager, Chang Yao-teng, said that despite their three consecutive wins, the boys will have to step it up a notch if they want to win their next two games to take the championship.

The Taiwanese little leaguers have been warmly received by the organizers of the tournament and the local Chinese community. During Sunday's game, the organizers even played three Taiwanese songs to entertain the spectators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei consumer price index up in July

TEXT.P: Taipei City's consumer price index (CPI) for July increased 0.17 percent over the level posted in June, according to tallies released Monday by the Taipei City Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DBAS).
The July CPI figure represented an increase of 0.19 percent over the level for the same month last year, DBAS officials said.
DBAS officials attributed the rise mainly to soaring international oil prices and increases in the cost of travel overseas.

Prices in the service sector increased by an average of 0.82 percent over the June level and by 1.36 percentyear-on-year, while prices of commercial goods declined by 0.54 percent from the June level and by 1.06 percent year-on-year, Taipei City officials said.
By category, prices for traveling overseas jumped by an average of 2.37 percent over the June level, while plane ticket prices rose 1.14 percent, both as a result of spiraling oil prices.
Meanwhile, prices of miscellaneous items increased by an average of 0.25 percent, while medical and health prices rose 0.06 percent from the June level.
Clothing and footwear prices, however, declined by a whopping 6.22 percent over the June level, largely because of summer sales at most of the city's department stores, the officials said.
Vegetable and fruit prices also declined, dropping 0.31 percent from the June level, they said.

Comparing with the same month last year, prices of education and entertainment, including overseas travel, increased by an average of 2.58 percent, while clothing prices soared 3.25 percent and medication and health food prices jumped 3.16 percent, they said.
Food prices declined 3.75 percent year-on-year in July, the officials added.

For the first seven months of this year, Taipei's CPI increased 0.72 percent year-on-year, with clothing prices rising 2.18 percent; prices of miscellaneous items moving up 2.13 percent; education and entertainment prices up 1.95 percent; medical and health prices up 1.8 percent; transportation prices up 1.38 percent; housing prices up 0.62 percent; and food prices declining 1.11 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: President touts Taiwan tailoring industry's contribution

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian touted Monday the contribution of Taiwan's tailoring industry to boosting the country's profile in the international arena.

Making the remarks while addressing the opening of the 32nd World Congress of Master Tailors being held Aug. 5-10 in Taipei, Chen noted that master tailors from Taiwan have won various awards in international competitions since they joined the World Federation of Master Tailors in 2003.

For example, during the 31st World Congress of Master Tailors in Berlin, Germany, delegates from Taiwan won the gold medal for dressmakers and second prize for tailors in the Golden Needle and Golden Thread Awards, Chen pointed out.

Through the joint efforts of the Association of Taiwan Master Tailors, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and Taiwan's representative office in Germany, Taiwan won the right to host the 32nd congress, he said.

According to Chen, while the holding of the congress in Taiwan shows the world that Taiwan's tailoring skills are comparable with those of Western countries, the event also lets people see how Taiwan tailors "use their needles and threads to sew a new ground for the country's foreign relations."

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 40% of Taiwan women fail to undergo cervical cancer screening

TEXT.P: More than 40 percent of Taiwan women do not undergo a Pap smear test at least once a year, even though free cervical cancer screening has been offered by the government since 1995, a doctor at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) Hospital said Monday.

Cheng Ya-ming, a doctor in the hospital's Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, noted that an estimated 500,000 women around the world die from cervical cancer each year, while in Taiwan, this type of cancer also poses as a major health threat to women, with the number of new cases per year reaching 6,000.
With some 1,000 women in Taiwan dying from cervical cancer each year, it has become the leading cause of death among women in the country.

Cheng expressed regret that although the government has since 1995 offered a free Pap smear screening a year for woman over the age of 30, it still seems difficult to get some women to receive the tests. He said women aged 30-50 years old form the bulk of those undergoing annual screening, with few women who have reached menopause requesting such tests.
To encourage more women to undergo Pap smear screening, NCKU Hospital will hold a lucky draw each week for those who do so, with the prize being a 30-percent- discount health check coupon.

As to alternatives, Cheng said that an anti-cervical cancer vaccine developed last year may reduce women's anxiety over the cancer. However, the vaccine is not covered by the national health insurance program. According to Cheng, each dose of vaccine costs NT$4,000 (US$122), with the amount recommended by doctors being three doses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 116.09 points to close at 8,941.73.
The bourse opened at 8,865.58 and fluctuated between 8,960.75 and 8,856.91 during trading. A total of 4.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$124.8 billion (US$3.8 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by electronics and construction issues both at 1.6 percent, financial stocks at 1.4 percent, paper and pulp shares at 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.9 percent, and plastics and chemical shares as well as cement stocks both at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,300 to 358, with 101 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Row over gasoline prices between Minister Bersani and petroleum business sector.
A row over gasoline prices between Minister of Economic Development Pierluigi Bersani and the petroleum business sector erupted following the denouncement of over-pricing of gasoline in Italy by Bersani's ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down 125 points to close at 8,860, with 52,686 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September dropped 116 points to finish at 8,850, with 1,577 contracts traded, while December futures lost 86 points to close at 8,887, with 58 contract transactions. March futures decreased 118 points to close at 8,868, with 14 contracts traded, while June futures moved down 106 points to finish at 8,867, with four contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 8,985 for August, 8,966 for September, 8,973 for December, 8,986 for March and 8,973 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

August TE futures moved down 4.2 points to close at 377.4, with 2,936 contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 4.4 points to finish at 375.6, with 132 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded other months.

August TF futures dropped 5.8 points to close at 1,034.2, with 3,010 contracts traded, while September TF futures moved down 4.6 points to finish at 1,036.8, with 96 contract transactions. December TF futures lost 14 points to close at 1,030, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Excessive intake of 'healthy' beverages might undermine health

TEXT.P: Excessive intake of "healthy" beverages, such as sports drinks, high fiber drinks or "fat-cutting" soft drinks might backfire and undermine the drinkers' health, the John Tung Foundation claimed Monday.

At a news conference to announce the findings of a recent survey conducted by the foundation on the relationship between bottled beverages and health, Hsu Hui-yu, a John Tung Foundation official in charge of nutrition, said that swallowing a 350 cc bottle of sports drink is equal to taking 5.4 cubes of sugar.

Hsu quoted the results of the survey conducted between February and March this year among some 1,000 elementary schoolchildren islandwide as showing that 67 percent of the children and 65 percent of their parents thought sports drinks are healthy beverages and believed that the more the children drink, the healthier they will become.
Nevertheless, Hsu pointed out, a 350cc bottle of sports drink contains 110 big calories, as well as electrolytes that can increase the burden on the heart, blood vessels and kidneys.

The current fad for beverages containing "high fiber" or "algae" -- claimed by the manufacturers as being able to cut weight -- will not help lose weight, but rather might cause nutritious imbalance, said Chiang Chun-ping, a pediatrician at Mackay Memorial Hospital in Taipei.

Chiang said the best drink for people, particularly elementary schoolchildren, is boiled water and that "fiber drinks" can never replace vegetables when it comes to taking natural fiber to help with digestion and seeking balanced nutrition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan illustrator sues Chinese phone seller for copyright violations

TEXT.P: A popular Taiwanese illustrator and author who uses the pen-name Jimmy has sued an online Chinese mobile phone seller for infringing upon his copyright, a Chinese court news Web site reported Monday.
The case is being handled by the Chaoyang District Court in Beijing, according to www.chinacourt.org sponsored by the Supreme People's Court of China.

In his petition filed with the court, Jimmy accused the seller, which operates through the Web site www.18900.com, of allowing its customers to download his illustrations as mobile phone themes without his authorization, the report said.

They include illustrations from some of his popular illustrated books, such as Turn Left Turn Right, Moon Forget, Sound of Colors, The Moments, Singing in the Forest, Love in the Cards and Missing My Cat, the report said.

In addition to requiring the seller to stop the unauthorized download service, Jimmy is demanding that the seller pay him 300,000 Chinese yuan (US$39,651) in compensation, post an apology statement on its Web site and pay for his lawyer fees and travel costs spent on the case, which total 25,000 Chinese yuan, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chunghwa Telecom to replace pay phones from this month

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest telecommunication company, Chunghwa Telecom, will replace the existing public pay phones around the country with new ones that accept both coins and cards, starting this month, company officials said Monday.

Three kinds of public phones are currently in use -- those that accept only coins, those that accept only optical cards and those that accept only IC cards, the officials noted, adding that the situation has caused great inconvenience to the public.

Although the demand for public phones is declining owing to the popularity of mobile phones, it is necessary for the company to integrate the functions of public phones to provide convenient, basic telecommunication services to the public, the officials said.
Chunghwa Telecom will install 1,000 coin/card pay phones starting this month, before installing another 2,500 at the end of this year, they said.

In addition to accepting both coins and cards, the new phones will also have other new functions that allow users to adjust the phone volume and to make a second call without having to hang up, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.017 to close at NT$32.888.
A total of US$724 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.770 and hit a high of NT$32.920.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPI for first seven months up 0.47 % year-on-year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index for the first seven months rose 0.47 percent over the same period of last year, according to a report released Monday by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
For July, the CPI was 105.01, down by 0.24 percent over the figure for the previous month and a drop of 0.34 percent over the same month of last year.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's wholesale price index (WPI) for the January-July period soared 6.65 percent over the level of a year before.
The WPI for July reached 124.46, a gain of 0.1 percent from the WPI of June, and a surge of 4.02 percent over the same month of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Thai woman arrested for carrying fake passport

TEXT.P: A Thai woman was arrested Sunday at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport for trying to leave Taiwan on a bogus passport, National Immigration Agency officers said Monday.

The 45-year Thai woman, identified as Parawee Vichaivong, admitted that she obtained the false passport for NT$30,000 (US$915) from a human smuggling group. The woman was detained while preparing to board a flight to Bangkok.
Vichaivong entered Taiwan last year and began working in a massage parlor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese brothers with rare disease arrive in New York
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 5 (CNA) 08/06/07 18:20:44 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese brothers with the rare Duchenne muscular dystrophy have arrived in New York City to realize their dream of visiting the Statue of Liberty, with help of enterprises and charity organizations.

Tseng Yi-kai, the elder brother, and Tseng Yi-chi, both of whom are now in their teens, have suffered from the inherited fatal disorder that is characterized by rapidly progressive muscle weakness and atrophy for many years.

The brothers are being accompanied by their mother Lin Chin-lien, Hsu Chi- hsiang, an ENT doctor from Taipei Medical University Hospital and Taiwan Foundation for Rare Disorders Secretary Chang Yen-ling.

Hsu, who volunteered to offer medical care for the two brothers on the trip, said it has been the most difficult task he has had this year, as each of the brothers needs 20 pillows to keep a proper sitting position due to their very serious curvature of the spine and because every change of position takes about 20 minutes to accomplish.

Paragon Investment Managers Inc. paid the travel fees of more than NT$300,000 (US$9,100) for them, and China Airlines upgraded their tickets to business class in order to give them a more comfortable flight.

They received a warm welcome from the New York branch of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu-chi Foundation upon their arrival and the branch arranged volunteer workers and doctors to accompany them during their stay in New York, branch Chairman Chang Chi-tuo said.

During their eight-day visit, they will make paintings of the Statue of Liberty, which symbolizes freedom -- the thing they long for the most as they are confined to wheelchairs. They will also visit Yankee Stadium to cheer for Taiwan-born pitcher Chien-ming Wang. They might also go to the Empire State Building, Central Park, and the American Museum of Natural History if their health allows, Chang said.
The branch has also arranged to hold a blessing party Aug. 10 for the two brothers, Chang went on.
Their mother, who has taken care of them alone for many years with subsidies from the government, expressed deep gratitude to those who helped the brothers realize their dream.

DOC.HEADLINE: Convenience stores in Taipei to join first aid network

TEXT.P: The Taipei health authorities are working on a plan to make the city's 2,000 convenience stores part of Taipei's first aid network, officials of the city government's Department of Health said Monday.

The officials said the plan will see convenience store employees offered the opportunity to go on training programs so that they can be issued with first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) certification.

The convenience stores, found in every community and operating on a 24-hour basis, are closely entwined with the daily lives of Taipei residents, the officials said, adding that with appropriate training, these stores can supplement the emergency medical services provided by hospital emergency rooms and the city's Fire Department.

Kao Wei-chun, a city government section chief in charge of medical services administration, said the city government hopes at least 70 percent of the 2,000 convenience stores can obtain CPR and first aid certification by the end of this year.
She said convenience store employees will also be invited to join the city's suicide prevention services in the near future.
Taipei's convenience stores belong to five chains: 7-Eleven, FamilyMart, Hi- Life, OK and Nikomart.
Kuo Shih-wei, a manager of the 7-Eleven chain, said the some 300 7-Eleven stores owned directly by President Chain Store Corp. have already obtained CPR and first aid certification.
He added that 7-Eleven will ask its franchise stores to do the same to provide customers with better services.
7-Eleven has announced on it Web site that its stores not only will be good neighbors aiming to improve the quality of life, but will also serve as community service centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Driving age set to rise to cut youth death toll
The minimum legal driving age is expected to rise to 18 as part of reforms to cut the number of deaths caused on Britains roads by novice drivers. Ministers are to propose a 12-month training period for new drivers, in effect preventing 17-year-olds from holding a full licence, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: President spared embarrassing encounter with Chinese flag

TEXT.P: Thanks to a bit of arranging by the organizers, President Chen Shui-bian was spared an embarrassing encounter with the Chinese flag while presiding over the opening of an international conference in Taipei Monday.

Chen had arrived at the Taipei International Convention Center to give a keynote speech at the opening of the 32nd Congress of Master Tailors, where the organizers -- the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and the Association of Taiwan Master Tailors -- removed the Chinese flag from the venue just before his arrival.
According to the organizers, they removed Chinese flag on the grounds that the Chinese delegates to the congress were not present at the opening ceremony as they were on a tour of central Taiwan.
Another Chinese flag hung along with the flags of other member states over an escalator leading to the venue was not removed because the president did not take the escalator.
The president has raised the hackles of Beijing with his outspoken criticism of China and his push for Taiwan independence.
It is the first time Taiwan has played host to the World Congress of Master Tailors, which has brought together 300 tailors and cloth designers from 16 countries and will run through Aug. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers withdraw from proposed U.S.trip

TEXT.P: Two opposition Kuomintang lawmakers said Monday that they will turn down a Ministry of National Defense (MND) invitation to visit the United States, in a bid to avoid "endorsing" the ministry's plans to procure U.S. weaponry systems.

KMT Legislator Su Chi said he will boycott the proposed U.S.trip on the grounds that the MND altered the itinerary unilaterally by adding a visit to a shipyard that builds Aegis-equipped warships and that Vice Defense Minister Ko Cheng-heng and his aides will join the legislators on the trip without notifying the legislators before the invitations were issued.

Su complained that agreeing to visit the Aegis producer would be tantamount to endorsing a possible procurement of the Aegis combat system-equipped Arleigh Burke-class destroyers and that the number of MND officials would surpass the number of legislators expected to go on the tour if Ko and his aides accompany the lawmakers.

Likening the MND to "a magician who produces rabbits and doves from his top hat without notice, " Su said he wonders what else the ministry will do once the legislators, from across the political spectrum, are off to the United States.
KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-min said Taiwan does not need any Aegis-equipped warships, adding that the Republic of China Navy cannot afford the ships and lacks the ability to maintain them.
Moreover, Shuai said, Aegis warships are designed to execute long-range anti- missile missions over distances of 500 nautical miles, far larger than Taiwan's territorial water limits.
There have been twists and turns since the MND announced its plans in early July to organize the U.S.trip for legislators.

Two legislators traded barbs July 11 over the proposed visit, with one accusing the MND of organizing the trip at taxpayers' expense and the other lambasting the accuser as playing to the gallery by smearing his colleagues.

The dispute stems from an accusation made by KMT Legislator Lin Yu-fang, who claimed that the ministry was trying to "buy" lawmakers' support for its plan to acquire eight U.S.-built submarines by offering them free trips to the United States.

According to Lin, the so-called fact-finding trip had already attracted 24 lawmakers from across the political spectrum and will cost the MND more than NT$10 million, to be financed by a NT$200 million (US$6.09 million) budget passed by the legislature June 15 to assess the feasibility of acquiring the submarines.

Lin claimed that many of the lawmakers in the proposed delegation do not even sit on the legislature's Committee for Defense Affairs, and that the organizers altered the itinerary to accommodate some lawmakers' requests for private trips during the visit.
He urged the lawmakers to withdraw from the trip to "save their integrity."
However, Lin's claims irritated Legislator Fu Kun-chi of the opposition People First Party (PFP), who is one of the 24 lawmakers planning to take advantage of the free trip offer.
Fu said his party is one of the firm opponents of the billion arms acquirement project and claimed that PFP officials asked party lawmakers in the delegation to pay their own fares.
He accused Lin of trying to smear his colleagues for personal political gain.

According to an original itinerary revealed by the United Daily News in mid- July, the trip, slated from Aug.14-26, will take the lawmakers to Washington, D.C., Boston, Los Angeles and Hawaii, and will include visits to defense contractors General Electric Co., Northrop Grumman Crop., Raytheon Corp.and Lockheed Martin Corp.
The MND has wanted the submarines since 2004, but a budget bill for the deal has been bogged down in the opposition-controlled legislature ever since.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vegetable/fruit price drops contribute to July CPI fall

TEXT.P: Thanks to significant drops in fruit and vegetable prices, Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) for July was 105.01, declined 0.34 percent over the same month of last year, an official of the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Monday.

Prices of vegetables and fruit for July were lower than the same month of last year due to a good harvest, with vegetable prices moving down 29.07 percent and fruit prices dropping 12.68 percent, said Wu Chao-ming, a DGBAS section chief.
According to Wu, last year's prices were comparatively higher as farmers suffered losses of about NT$300 million (US$9.1 million) because of damage caused by two typhoons.
As the vegetable and fruit price drops offset price hikes for cooking oil, eggs and milk in July, Wu said the month's CPI registered a negative growth as compared with the year-earlier level.

If prices drops for vegetables and fruit were excluded, the annual growth rate of the CPI for July this year reached 1.44 percent, which was the highest in the last five months, Wu said, adding that vegetables and fruit account for a large weight in the CPI calculation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water officials have mixed feelings about looming storm

TEXT.P: Water officials at the Ministry of Economic Affairs have mixed feelings about tropical storm Pabuk, currently approaching Taiwan.

With the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) poised to issue a sea warning for Pabuk late Monday night or Tuesday morning, officials with the Water Resources Agency said Monday that while they fervently hope Pabuk will bring timely rains to relieve Taiwan's water-thirsty areas, they also fear that the tropical storm will leave damage in its wake.

Chen Shen-hsien, director of the Water Resources Agency, said his agency has taken precautionary measures by asking River Management offices in southern Taiwan to move their 12-inch mobile water pumps to strategic points in central and northern Taiwan to prevent flooding.

Noting that Taitung County in eastern Taiwan has been hit hard by the most serious drought in 30 years, Chen said he hopes that the rain brought by Pabuk will allow farmers there to salvage some of their crops.

Taitung county's Chihshang township, one of Taiwan's main centers for producing organic rice, has recorded total rainfall of only 258 mm so far this year -- less than one third of the normal amount. Farmers have waited in vain for rain to begin their second-stage rice planting.
Chen added that some of the areas in northern Taiwan, including Keelung, Sijihe and Juifang, also need rain badly to replenish their reservoirs and soothe the parched land.

According to a CWB weather report, Pabuk, located about 1,000 km southeast of Taiwan, was moving northwesterly at 28 kph. If it maintains its present course, the storm's center is expected to make landfall in Taiwan early Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Power Co. to lay undersea electric cable to Penghu

TEXT.P: The state-owned Taiwan Power Co. announced Monday a plan to construct a 60-km undersea electric cable linking Taiwan proper and its outlying island of Penghu as part of the company's efforts to secure supplies of wind-powered electricity between the two places.

The NT$14.68 billion (US$445 million) plan is currently undergoing an environmental impact assessment, a company spokesman said, who estimated that the entire project would be finished in November 2012 if the assessment is completed by the end of this year.
Once the cable is completed, wind-powered electricity on Penghu could be produced on a massive scale, the spokesman noted.
The undersea electric cable will serve as a backup system, but one which the spokesman said must be put in place in advance.
Without a backup system, if the wind becomes unstable, the outlying island's power system will be compromised, leading to the possibility of a comprehensive shutdown, the spokesman added.
Globally, the Penghu area is one of the best suitable places for wind power generation, with annual wind speed averaging over eight meters per second, the spokesman said.

If the use of Penghu's wind power could be increased, the country's demand for expensive diesel-powered electricity will be reduced, and emissions of carbon dioxide will also decrease, the spokesman went on.
The company began turning Penghu's wind into an alternative energy source in the late 1990s, and has continued to increase investments ever since, the spokesman remarked.
The company is still negotiating with local residents on the outlying island in the hope of reaching an early consensus on the specifics of the project, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. has not yet responded to president's transit plan: minister

TEXT.P: The U.S. government has not yet responded to President Chen Shui-bian's planned transit stops in the United States en route to his Central American visit late this month, Minister of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) James Huang said Monday.

Huang made the remarks during a swearing-in ceremony for new chiefs of Taiwan's representative offices abroad. At that time, Huang stressed that many recent reports of local media regarding Chen's transit stop in U.S. were for the most part speculative.

Huang was responding to local reports that Washington has refused Chen's request for a transit stop in the continental United States to make known its displeasure over Chen's proposal to push for a referendum on whether the island should apply U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan". The U.S. sees such a referendum as an attempt to unilaterally change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

Concerning recent remarks by Tom Casey, deputy spokesman of the U.S. State Department, on the transit policy of the United Sates, which saw Casey skip over the "dignity" of treatment the U.S. government usually accords Taiwanese leaders when they make a transit stop in the U.S., mentioning instead only the principles of safety, comfort and convenience for the traveler, Huang said Washington has assured him that U.S. transit policy remains unchanged.

Asked about whether China has protested former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen's serving as Chen's special envoy to attend a summit of Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Australia in early September, Huang said the government has not yet presented its envoy proposal to Australia, and most of the reports are merely speculative.

As to the return of Chen's letter requesting U.N. membership for Taiwan under the name "Taiwan" by China's Permanent Representative to the United Nations Wang Guangya in late July, Huang said Wang failed to do his job properly as the rotating president of the U.N. Security Council for July by not delivering the letter to the U.N. Security Council for screening.
Wang's behavior reflected China's long-term arbitrary repression and bullying of Taiwan in the world community, and Taiwan will fight for its rights, Huang stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Bush Signs Law to Widen Legal Reach for Wiretapping
President Bush signed into law on Sunday legislation that broadly expanded the governments authority to eavesdrop on the international telephone calls and e-mail messages of American citizens without warrants.
Congressional aides and others familiar with the details of the law said that its impact went far beyond the small fixes that administration officials had said were needed to gather information about foreign terrorists.
Wall Street Journal:How Bear Stearns Mess Cost Executive His Job
On Wednesday James Cayne, the 73-year-old chief executive of Bear Stearns Cos., summoned his top lieutenant to his smoky, dimly lit office in midtown Manhattan.
The big securities firm Mr. Cayne had led as CEO for 14 years was under attack. Two of its mortgage-related hedge funds had blown up, costing investors more than $1 billion, and its stock was under siege, down 27% this year alone.
Bear's co-president quit, becoming Wall Street's highest-profile casualty in the subprime -lending fiasco. As Wall Street banks face the risk of a broad bond- market unwind, many longer- term holders believe recovery could stretch into this fall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing's torch relay scheme an attempt to belittle Taiwan: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday that China is attempting to use the torch relay route issue to belittle Taiwan.

Lu made the remarks during a meeting with foreign correspondents stationed in Taiwan after Jiang Xiaoyu, the Beijing Organizing Committee for the Olympic games executive vice-president, said earlier that day that Beijing hopes Taiwan can return to a consensus reached earlier this year so as to facilitate the torch's travel through Taiwan.
Noting that the Olympic Games is a major sports event, Lu said Taiwan should have the same right as other countries to take part in the games.

She lamented that Beijing has maneuvered to politically exploit the situation, referring to its plan to have the torch travel from South Korea to Vietnam and then to Taiwan before proceeding to Hong Kong, Macau, and other Chinese cities until it reaches at the host city, Beijing.
The relay route shows clearly Beijing's intention to claim sovereignty over Taiwan, Lu said.
Beijing even attempted to change the name of the Taiwan delegation from its official name of "Chinese Taipei" to "China Taipei," she continued.
"Such political maneuvering is a violation of the spirit of Olympic Games," she said.

Taiwan still hopes that the torch can travel from South Korea to Taiwan and then proceed on to Vietnam and continue to Hong Kong and Macau, Lu said, adding that Taiwan is still working toward the " third country in, third country out" goal.
Jiang criticized Taiwan in April for "breach of agreement" after it turned down a Beijing offer to be included in the Olympic torch relay.

Jiang even produced a copy of the minutes of a February meeting between Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee Chairman Thomas W. Tsai and Beijing Olympic organizers, during which a four-point consensus was reached on the torch relay route.

In response, Tsai said in Taipei that conference minutes did not qualify as a formal agreement. "We have never been formally committed to accepting Beijing's proposals regarding Taiwan's role or place in the torch relay," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate to embark on 'long stay' campaign in south

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate for the 2008 presidential election, said Monday that he will begin the second phase of his "long stay" campaign targeting southern Taiwan Tuesday as part of his efforts to solicit grassroots support.
Ma made the remarks during an interview with the Central News Agency.
Allaying fears that he might encounter strong opposition from locals, Ma said that he will do his utmost to make people aware of his sincerity, describing himself as an "easy-going person."
Residents in southern Taiwan are traditionally regarded as staunch supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , KMT's rival.
Ma said that his previous 10-day bike tour of 19 cities and counties around the country generated satisfactory results because locals came to realize that he attaches great importance to them.

During the first phase of his "long stay" campaign in Taichung, Changhua and Nantou in central Taiwan, Ma said that he stayed overnight in locals' homes during one third of the 18-day trip in the three central counties.
Ma added that he will do the same throughout the second phase of his campaign in the three southern counties of Yulin, Chiayi, and Tainan.

Noting that with a population of over 3.4 million, the three counties produce most of the country's domestic rice, but has serious land-sinking problem, Ma said that he will learn more about the region during the trip, hoping that the locals can also come to a better understanding of him.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPI gauges general price changes: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The consumer price index (CPI) reflects the general condition of product prices in Taiwan, an official of the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) explained Monday amid public doubts of the newly released CPI figures.

Wu Chao-ming, a section chief of the DGBAS, said the CPI works by showing average price changes including ups and downs during a period of time, instead of reflecting price changes of particular products, therefore, the CPI result will be more moderate than specific products' price changes.
According to a report released by the DGBAS, the CPI for July was 105.01, down by 0.34 over the same month last year, which was the biggest drop since last November.

Quoting the results of the report, Wu said the five goods that showed the biggest price hikes were: Chinese herbal medicine, 62.6 percent, yellow croaker, 21.65 percent, cooking oil, 16.65, gas, 14.8, and group travel fees, 14.33 percent.
Meanwhile, the five articles showing the biggest price drops are onion, 68.76, papaya, 39.49, balsam pear, 37.64, watermelon, 34.62, and cell phone, 22.92 percent, Wu said.
Wu pointed out that price drops in vegetables and fruit offset price hikes for other categories, as fruits and vegetables are heavily weighted in the CPI calculation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young woman of Taiwan wins two gold medals in world judo tourneys

TEXT.P: A young woman from Taitung County has won two gold medals in two world judo championship tournaments held during the past week, a female judo coach of the Chihpen Elementary School said Monday.

Huang Li-feng said that faculty and students of Chihpen Elementary School are proud that Chien Tzu-hui, an alumna who was formerly a member of the school's judo team, had won a gold medal in women's under-48 kg class in the 2007 Pacific Rim Judo Championships, held July 27-29 in Macau, and the 2007 Taipei Open Judo, held Aug. 4-5 at the Taipei Gymnasium.

Chien, 18, is a 2007 graduate from the National Taitung University Affiliated Physical Education Senior High School. Her achievements have earned her the nickname, "Honorable Black Pearl," partly because of her dark skin.
More than 200 judoists from 22 countries contended in the 2007 Pacific Rim Judo Championships. Four of Chien's teammates also won medals in the competition.

Pan Chang-yu captured a silver medal in the men's under-66 kg class, while Li Chieh-heng and Wang Liang-min each won bronze in the men's under 60-kg class and under-70 kg class respectively. Another female judoist from Taiwan, Lin Hui-min, also earned a bronze medal in the under-48 kg class.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate terms status quo as 'one Taiwan, separate definitions'

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) presidential candidate described Taiwan's status quo Monday as "one Taiwan, separate definitions, " but claimed that the ruling and opposition parties' definitions are partially overlapping, with the "Republic of China" title being the greatest common denominator for all sides.
Ma Ying-jeou made the remarks in an interview with the Central News Agency. It also marked the first time that Ma has coined such a term to explain Taiwan's present political situation.
According to Ma, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) argues that Taiwan is already an independent country, even though its official title remains as the Republic of China.
In contrast, Ma said, the KMT has consistently maintained that the Republic of China is an independent sovereign country.
As to China's attitude, Ma claimed that Beijing leaders are more tolerant of the "Republic of China" title than they are of "Taiwan independence."

Ma also challenged the Mainland Affairs Council's inference that as the ratio of local people considering themselves "Taiwanese" has surpassed those who consider themselves to be "Chinese" or both "Taiwanese and Chinese, " the national consciousness of the people of Taiwan has undergone a fundamental change.

Ma, a Harvard-trained politician, said Taiwan consciousness is not tantamount to "Taiwan independence consciousness." While many people consider themselves to be Taiwanese, Ma claimed that the number of people who explicitly support Taiwan independence remains a minority and that maintaining the present status quo enjoys the support of mainstream public opinion.

While China is the most vocal opponent of Taiwanese independence, Ma claimed that the Beijing leadership focuses its target mainly on "de jure" Taiwan independence, namely writing a new constitution and rectifying the country's name.

As Taiwan's people can now elect their own president and lawmakers and manage their own affairs, Ma said Taiwan now enjoys de facto independence. Despite that reality, war has not erupted across the Taiwan Strait. Against this backdrop, Ma said the current status quo has become "one Taiwan, separate definitions, " with the KMT asserting that the Republic of China continues to exist, and the DPP asserting that Taiwan is already an independent country with the Republic China as its official designation.
Ma further claimed that China originally would not accept the "Republic of China" and regard it as a "C-type Taiwan independence."

With the development of cross-strait relations, Ma claimed that the Chinese mainland has adjusted its "one country, two systems" unification stance into one that places more emphasis on preventing independence than on promoting unification.

"Beijing leaders have come to understand that advocacting the Republic of China's continued existence is a lesser evil in comparison to advocating Taiwan independence. And this is our present status quo, " Ma said, adding that the Republic of China is the greatest common denominator acceptable to all parties concerned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Embezzlement case a major test: KMT presidential candidate

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the ongoing embezzlement case is a major test for him.
Ma also said that drawing on his own personal experience, he plans to submit judicial reform policies after the Taipei District Court hands down a ruling on his case Aug. 14.
He noted that even during the last court hearing on the case July 31, the prosecution failed to produce substantial incriminating evidence against him.

The prosecution indicted him mainly because they believed that during his term as Taipei mayor 1998-2006, he "cheated" the staff of the Taipei city government every month to claim the "special allowance fund" put for his discrecional use, according to Ma.
"I'm sure a lot of people wouldn't put up with such an allegation, "Ma said.
On the upcoming court ruling, Ma said that "I have confidence in my innocence, and I expect a just ruling from the court."
Ma said that he has "braced for every outcome" although it will not affect his determination to run in the 2008 presidential election.
He said that in the West, judges will rule the defendant not guilty if there is insufficient evidence to prove the charges beyond a reasonable doubt.
As a defendant, Ma say he has learned first-hand about the investigative and the litigation process, which he said will be valuable for him in working out judicial reform policies.
He cited, as an example, that a prosecutor's deposition can vary from the statement of a witness, something that he couldn't possibly have known even though he once served as justice minister.

Ma was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of corruption. Prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen said in the indictment that Ma received NT$10.23 million in special allowances during his first term from December 1998 to December 2003.
However, the expenditure records of Ma's bank accounts show that he spent only NT$3.49 million of that amount, but did not return the unspent portion -- NT$6.74 million -- to the national coffers.
From January 2004 to July 2006, Ma used NT$630,000 of the NT$5.06 million fund and kept the remaining NT$4.43 million in his account.
Hou contends that the unspent money during his two terms, totaling NT$11.17 million, should be considered "gains from embezzlement."
Hou rejected an interpretation by the Ministry of Justice last November that special allowance funds for executives of government departments are actually meant as salary subsidies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT adopts 'pragmatic' means to promote U.N. bid: candidate

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the KMT has adopted a "pragmatic" means of promoting a referendum on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.

Ma made the remarks in an interview with the CNA when he compared the KMT's approach with that of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , noting that President Chen Shui-bian has promoted a referendum on joining the U.N. under the name of Taiwan.
Ma said that the KMT's way is to authorize the administrative branch to find the best name, or a name that is most beneficial and dignified to the island, to join the United Nations.

He noted that "joining or re-entering international organizations is not something that can be decided by us, " noting that "even if Taiwan passes the referendum on its U.N. bid, the United Nations still will not admit the island."

"The key lies in the kind of organizations, and entering them under what name, " Ma said, noting that Taiwan joined the International Olympic Committee under the name of "Chinese Taipei, " and joining the World Trade Organization under the name of "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu."
Ma said further that Taiwan has not succeeded in joining any international organizations under the name "Taiwan" over the past 20 or 30 years.
Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization has been repeatedly thwarted and its chances of joining the United Nations under that name should be clear, Ma said.
He noted that President Chen Shui-bian twice wrote to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-boon on the island's bid to join the world body recently, but his letters were returned both times.

He said that the KMT, during its five decades of rule, had promoted unconventional diplomacy and accumulated valuable experience, and so will adopt a "pragmatic" approach in joining international organizations.

He termed the DPP's advocacy of its United Nations bid under the name of Taiwan a "strategic error," as the party's aim is not to join the United Nations, but to create divisions with the aim of proving its gallantry, although the action "will do Taiwan no good."

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB issues sea warning against tropical storm Pabuk

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning against tropical storm Pabuk late Monday as the storm was swirling toward waters off Taiwan's eastern coast.

The eye of Pabuk, the sixth typhoon in the West Pacific this year, was 711 kilometers east-southeast of the eastern county of Hualien at 11 p.m., CWB meteorologists said, adding that the light typhoon was moving west-northwest at 20 kilometers per hour.

Waters northeast and southeast of Taiwan will come under the influence of the storm, the meteorologists said, adding that ships operating in those areas should maintain vigilance. People should also refrain from visiting costal regions in eastern Taiwan as there will be high waves there.

The storm has gained strength moderately in the past three hours, with sustained winds of 90 kilometers, the meteorologists noted, adding that if the storm maintains its current course, the bureau is scheduled to issue a land warning early Tuesday.
Pabuk is the name of a large fresh water fish in Laos, according to the Hong Kong Observatory, which lists names in use for western Pacific typhoons.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young woman of Taiwan wins two gold medals in world judo tourneys

TEXT.P: A young woman from Taitung County has won two gold medals in two world judo championship tournaments held during the past week, a female judo coach of the Chihpen Elementary School said Monday.

Huang Li-feng said that faculty and students of Chihpen Elementary School are proud that Chien Tzu-hui, an alumna who was formerly a member of the school's judo team, had won a gold medal in women's under-48 kg class in the 2007 Pacific Rim Judo Championships, held July 27-29 in Macau, and the 2007 Taipei Open Judo, held Aug. 4-5 at the Taipei Gymnasium.

Chien, 18, is a 2007 graduate from the National Taitung University Affiliated Physical Education Senior High School. Her achievements have earned her the nickname, "Honorable Black Pearl," partly because of her dark skin.
More than 200 judoists from 22 countries contended in the 2007 Pacific Rim Judo Championships. Four of Chien's teammates also won medals in the competition.

Pan Chang-yu captured a silver medal in the men's under-66 kg class, while Li Chieh-heng and Wang Liang-min each won bronze in the men's under 60-kg class and under-70 kg class respectively. Another female judoist from Taiwan, Lin Hui-min, also earned a bronze medal in the under-48 kg class.
