DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 7, or the 25th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of the Dominion of Canada.
1903: Louis Leakey, British anthropologist, is born. He uncovered crucial evidence of man's early evolution, including a 1,750,000-year-old skull.
1904: Ralph Johnson Bunche, American diplomat, is born. He helped found the United Nations and won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the 1949 Arab- Israeli truce.
1912: Japan and Russia sign an agreement determining their spheres of influence in Manchuria and Mongolia.
1913: Samuel Cody, American aviator, becomes Britain's first air fatality when his plane crashes at Famborough.
1942: U.S. marines land on Guadalcanal in the Pacific during World War II.
1945: The Soviet Union declares war on Japan seven days before the Japanese surrender in World War II.
1948: The Yangtze River overflows its banks, forcing three million people into homelessness.
1952: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the designation of July 1, instead of January 1, as the beginning of the fiscal year.
1957: The ROC Navy sinks four Communist Chinese warships south of Kinmen.
1957: Oliver Hardy, the husky one in the Laurel and Hardy comic-duo who made more than 100 films from 1926 until 1950, dies of a stroke at the age of 65.
1959: The worst floods in more than 60 years hit central and southern Taiwan, killing 1,075 people, injuring 852, and causing more than NT$3.4 billion in property damage.
1974: Pingtung's Mei Ho Senior Little League baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to participate in the 1974 Little League World Series.
1974: Paul Hogberg, president of the International Handball Federation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Vice Foreign Minister H.K. Yang meets with President Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay.
1976: Kin Aziwa, newly-appointed deputy chief of the Japanese Interchange Association, Taipei Office, arrives to assume his post.
1983: Communist Chinese air force pilot Sun Tien-chin flies his MiG-21 jetfighter to South Korea to seek political asylum. He arrived in Taipei on Aug. 24.
1987: The leaders of Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Costa Rica sign a 14-page peace plan in Guatemala City aiming to settle a 10-year-old conflict in the region.
1990: President George Bush orders U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraq.
1992: Beijing signs an agreement with Washington promising to probe any allegations that goods produced by prison labor are being shipped to U.S. markets.
1998: Bombs explode almost at the same time outside the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing more than 80 people and injuring over one thousand others.
1999: The Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew ends a five-day visit to Macedonia after a meeting with his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng says the KMT is happy that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to hold a multiparty roundtable meeting to discuss major national issues with the heads of the opposition parties.
2001: The third cross-strait symposium about sports terms opens in Taipei, with sports representatives from Taiwan and mainland China sitting down to discuss the "unification" of various sports terms between the two sides.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB issues land warning for Tropical Storm Pabuk

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for Tropical Storm Pabuk Tuesday morning as the storm approached Taiwan's east coast.

The eye of Pabuk, the sixth tropical storm in the West Pacific this year, was located 350 kilometers east of the eastern county of Taitung as of 10 a.m., with the storm moving west-northwest at 21 kilometers per hour, CWB meteorologists said.
The rim of the storm had reached waters southeast of Taiwan as of Tuesday morning, they said, adding that it is expected to make landfall in the afternoon.

Waters north and southeast of Taiwan are already under the influence of the storm, the meteorologists said, urging ships operating in those areas to stay alert. They also warned people against visiting coastal areas in eastern Taiwan as expected high waves there will pose a potential danger.
The storm has gained in strength moderately over the past several hours, with maximum sustained winds reaching 101 kph and gusts of up to 126 kph, the meteorolgists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Immigration officer detained on corruption charges

TEXT.P: An immigration officer in the southern city of Chiayi has been arrested and taken into custody on charges of corruption and leaking of official secrets, prosecution authorities said Tuesday.

The Chiayi District Court approved prosecutors' application for the detention of Lin Shun-tang, a squadron chief of the National Immigration Agency's (NIA's) Chiayi branch, late Monday after he was questioned by judicial personnel for several hours about his suspected criminal offenses.
Lin is accused of having leaked information to manpower brokers before spot checks by law enforcement officers on illegal migrant workers for which he received entertainment in return.
He is also suspected of having colluded with those brokers to secure monetary rewards set up by the government to encourage law enforcement officers to seize illegal immigrants.

According to prosecutors, the manpower brokers allegedly would first "dump" at designated locations disobedient, unqualified or incompetent illegal foreign workers and those who were willing to return home voluntarily and then would tip Lin off so that he could arrest them and claim the prize money from the immigration agency.
As both alleged crimes committed by Lin are felonies which carry a minimum prison sentence of five years, prosecutors said he should be held incommunicado pending further investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down 93 points to close at 8,767, with 58,867 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September decreased 82 points to finish at 8,768, with 1,421 contracts traded, while December futures lost 97 points to close at 8,790, with 59 contract transactions. March futures moved down 87 points to close at 8,781, with five contracts traded, while June futures dropped 85 points to end at 8,782, with four contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,860 for August, 8,850 for September, 8,887 for December, 8,868 for March and 8,867 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

August TE futures moved down 7.2 points to close at 370.2, with 4,146 contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 6.6 points to finish at 369, with 76 contract transactions. December TE futures decreased 7.2 points to end at 370, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures lost 20.2 points to close at 1,014, with 3,648 contracts traded, while September TF futures decreased 24.8 points to finish at 1,012, with 180 contract transactions. December TF futures moved up 17.4 points to close at 1,047.4, with three contracts traded, while March TF decreased 44.2 points to end at 1,030, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commonwealth Publishing Group wins three Asian publishing awards

TEXT.P: Two magazines belonging to the Taiwan-based Commonwealth Publishing Group (CPG) garnered a total of three wins in the first Asian Publishing Management Awards (APMA) presented recently in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, CPG officials said Tuesday.

Two of the awards went to Global Views Monthly. One of them was in the editorial category, for a feature report on problems facing elementary schools in outlying areas that was published in the September 2006 issue of the magazine; the other one was in the category of innovative corporate communications in a multi-media world, for the second Corporate Social Responsibility Awards organized by the magazine, according to the officials.

Meanwhile, the traditional Chinese version of Harvard Business Review, launched by the CPG in September, was awarded an APMA in the category of magazine franchise in recognition of its successful launch.
The winners of the first APMA were announced during the first Asia Pacific Publishing Convention (APPC) held Aug. 2-3 in the Malaysian capital.

In addition to Global Views Monthly and the traditional Chinese version of Harvard Business Review, another Taiwan-based English-learning magazine, Studio Classroom, also won an APMA for its outstanding circulation program to expand its readership.

The eight categories covered by the awards are: circulation, editorial, design and layout, advertising sales campaign, magazine franchise, best new launch of a local title, best use of multi-media by an advertiser, and innovative corporate communications in a multi-media world.
The APPC, which aims to be a learning and networking convention for print, online and mobile media in Asia, saw the participation of more than 250 senior publishing professionals from 15 countries.
The theme of this year's event was "Integrate Publishing with Digital Technology Profitably."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Normal country' resolution key to DPP in elections: chairman

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that he is poised to continue promoting the "normal country" resolution as it is vital to help boost the party's chances in coming elections.
Yu made the remarks during a meeting with representatives of various pro-Taiwan independence groups at the DPP's headquarters.

According to Yu, the DPP core supporters' pro-Taiwan independence stance must be made clear in a party resolution so as to solidify a consensus and encourage party candidates to score a victory in the Jan. 12 legislative election and the March 22, 2008 presidential poll.
"How could DPP candidates compete other parties' opponents in the coming elections if the party fails to provide the public with a clear vision regarding the country's future?" he argued.

The resolution, designed to turn Taiwan into what Yu called a normal country, was approved by the DPP's Central Standing Committee, and President Chen Shui- bian displayed his support for the resolution during a meeting last week attended by ranking officials from the party, the Executive Yuan and the Presidential Office, he said.
Nor did Frank Hsieh, the DPP's presidential candidate who also took part in the meeting, voice objections to the resolution, he noted.

Brushing aside allegations from some party members that the "normal country" resolution would take a toll on the DPP in the upcoming two elections, Yu said that he is willing to take full responsibility for its negative impact, although it was agreed upon by the Central Standing Committee.

"If the DPP lacks a consensus on Taiwan's future and fails to come up with such a resolution, it would dampen the hopes of the party's supporters and ruin its chances in future elections," he contended.
The DPP must craft an electoral strategy to distinguish itself from other parties with the "normal country" resolution that will benefit this country in the short, middle and long terms, he claimed.

Taiwan's eventual unification with China, broached by the main opposition Kuomintang, is tantamount to a suicide for Taiwan, while the idea of maintaining the status quo across the Taiwan Strait is the equivalent to the gradual suicide of the country, he claimed, insisting that neither is beneficial to Taiwan.

For their parts, representatives from the various pro-Taiwan independence groups urged Yu to put forward a more clear-cut and radical resolution to advance Taiwan independence, as the "normal country" resolution, initiated by Yu himself early this year, fails to shrug off the "one China" concept contained in the current Republic of China Constitution.
They suggested Yu discard the existing political framework of the ROC and replace the "normal country" resolution with one that calls for the establishment of a "Taiwan republic."

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB expands land warning for Tropical Storm Pabuk

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) expanded the scope of its land warning for Tropical Storm Pabuk afternoon as the storm reached the waters off Taiwan's southeast coast Tuesday.

The outlying island of Kinmen was added to the list of areas expected to be affected by the storm within the next 24 hours. Already included in the list were Hualien, Taitung, Green Island, Orchid Island, Ilan, Nantou, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Penghu, CWB forecasters said.
The forecasters also urged ships operating in waters off Taiwan's northeast and southeast coasts, the Taiwan Strait, the Bashih Channel and waters near the Pratas Islands to remain alert.

As of 4 p.m., the storm was centered 170 km east-northeast of the eastern county of Taitung, moving westerly at 21-24 kph toward Taiwan and packing maximum sustained winds of 101 kph, according to the CWB.

The outer edge of Pabuk is expected to reach the southeastern part of Taiwan Tuesday evening, with the eye of the storm projected to land in the area between Hengchun and Taitung around midnight, forecasters said, adding that the storm will have completely passed over Taiwan around noon Wednesday.
The forecasters said Pabuk will bring strong winds to the Hualien and Taitung areas and rainfall of at least 200 mm to most areas around Taiwan.

Accumulated rainfall is expected to reach up to 300 mm in the northern region, 400 mm in the northeastern region, 350 mm in the Hualien and Taitung areas, and 250 mm in the central and southern regions, they said.

Meanwhile, CWB observatory data shows that a tropical low pressure system forming southeast of Pabuk Tuesday morning is likely to increase in intensity over the next few days to become a tropical storm by the weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to spend NT$7.96 billion rebuilding old bridges

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese government will earmark NT$7.96 billion (US$241 million) to rebuild 121 old bridges and repair 1,000 others in order to better safeguard people's traffic safety, an official of the Executive Yuan's Public Construction Commission said Tuesday.
The bridge repair program was passed last year, and is scheduled to be finished within the three years from 2007-2009, the official said.
Quoting statistics compiled by the commission, the official said Taiwan has a total of 26,000 bridges, with an average age of 20 years, but 952 of the bridges are more than 40 years old.

The public became more concerned about the nation's bridge safety issue after a bridge over the Mississippi river in the U.S. state of Minnesota collapsed Aug. 1, killing at least four and leaving 30 missing.

According to the official, the government has collected and integrated data and information about the nation's bridges from the Directorate General of Highways, the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau, the Taiwan Railway Administration, and local governments since 2001, which will be used to provide references on maintenance and repairs.
The official said Taiwan's highway and water resource units will meet to coordinate their actions and ensure smooth progress on repairs.

The commission also asked authorities at all levels to implement bridge maintenance and evaluation, to carry out inspections regularly, and record inspection results in order to provide and ensure greater traffic safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan bracing for onslaught from tropical storm Pabuk

TEXT.P: Taiwan is preparing for an onslaught by tropical storm Pabuk, the sixth named storm in the western Pacific this year.
The central government said Tuesday that it had activated its disaster response center at the Ministry of the Interior's National Fire Agency.

Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang, who serves as head of the center, urged people in 13 most vulnerable cities and counties to store enough food and drinking water to last from three to seven days.

Marked for heightened alert are the eight cities of Hualien, Taitung, Pingtung, Yilan, Nantou, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan and Kaohsiung, together with the counties of Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Penghu.
Lee said he had ordered additional water pumps to be moved to flood-prone areas in Yilan, Hualien and Taitung.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin also set up an emergency response center manned with senior officials from different city government departments. He urged residents to guard against flooding and falling billboards while the tropical storm is passing through Taiwan.

At least eight cities and counties have formed emergency response centers. While the Cabinet-level Department of Health has placed medical teams and helicopters on standby, the Ministry of National Defense has also ordered military units to be ready to join disaster relief operations.
On Orchid Island off the eastern coast of Taiwan, some 2,000 holidaymakers cut short their stays and were ferried back to Taitung in eight boats early Tuesday.

As winds and rain on Orchid island intensified, the Taitung county government decided to suspend school classes and office work there from 2 p.m. It also announced that all schools and public organizations in Taitung County will remain closed Wednesday.

According to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB), Pabuk's center was located 140 km southeast of Taitung at 6 p.m. Tuesday. With a 150-km radius, the tropical storm was moving west at 26 kph and was expected to slow down to 22 kph.

Packing center winds of 28 meters per second and gusts of up to 35 meters per second, or 126 kph, Pabuk was expected to make landfall in Taiwan at around 11 p.m. Tuesday, with its center leaving the Hengchun peninsula at about 1 a.m. Wednesday.
CWB forecasts said Taiwan's eastern, central and southern areas might see at least 200 mm of rainfall brought by the storm, with eastern Taiwan getting more rain than other areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records first imported case of severe enterovirus infection

TEXT.P: A two-year-old Taiwanese girl developed serious complications triggered by enterovirus type 71 (E71) soon after returning from a China visit late last month, making her the country's first imported case of severe enterovirus infection, a Center for Disease Control (CDC) official said Tuesday.

The girl traveled to Shenzhen in China's Guangdong province together with her parents and four-year-old brother last month, only returning to Taiwan July 26, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao.

While the boy displayed hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome, a condition indicative of a mild enterovirus infection, July 27, the girl came down with high fever, muscle twitching, a rapid heart beat and sleepiness the following day, Chou said.
The case was reported to health authorities as a severe case of enterovirus infection, and tests confirmed the diagnosis, Chou said.
Noting that the incubation period of enterovirus infection usually runs between three and five days, Chou said the two children were probably infected while in Shenzhen.
He said both the girl and her brother are recovering well and that the girl has been transferred from an intensive care unit to an ordinary ward.
CDC tallies show that three severe cases of enterovirus infection have been recorded in Taiwan so far this year, two of which were caused by E71, including this latest one.
The other case, which resulted in death, was caused by echovirus type 6, another member of the enterovirus family, according to the CDC.
Taiwan experienced a severe outbreak of E71 -- the deadliest type of all enteroviruses -- in 1988 when 405 children were infected, 78 of whom died.
In another E71 outbreak in 2005, 145 children were infected, with 15 killed.
Enterovirus are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis and can cause serious disease especially in infants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tariff cuts for seven staple commodities valid until Feb. 5

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has approved an application by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Council of Agriculture to lower customs duties on seven major commodities for six months, effective immediately, MOEA officials said Tuesday.

According to officials at the MOEA's Department of Customs Administration, the six-month period kicked off Aug. 6 and will run through Feb. 5, 2008 as part of the government's efforts to help stanch growing inflation pressure on the domestic market, a result of soaring prices of raw materials on the international marketplace.

The government's decision to slash the customs tariffs on the seven major farm products, including wheat and corn, will cost the national coffers some NT$121 million (NT$3.7 million) in tax revenues, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan International Folklore & Game Festival wraps up for good

TEXT.P: The curtain fell on the Yilan International Folklore and Game Festival for good Tuesday.

Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua announced the county government's decision to bring an end to the annual festival in a press conference at county hall at the end of this year's festival, citing the heavy losses incurred over the last two years.

He attributed the festival's failure to competition from similar water theme parks around the island, the rising price of general goods, and the baseless criticisms leveled against the activity by certain media outlets.
Lu said the two-month festival has created a financial burden of about NT$50 million for the county government during each of the last two years despite efforts to curb costs.

The decision to end the cultural activity was a difficult one as the event had earned an international reputation for the eastern Taiwan county, and helped enhance its profile and boosted local tourism, but the county simply can't bear the financial burden without central government aid, Lu said.

Citing the proverb that the finish line of one race is the starting line of another, Lu said the county government will start planning a new activity for the next summer to continue promoting Yilan as a tourist attraction.

The festival, organized by the Cultural Bureau of the county government every summer at the county's Dungshan River Park, was a hit when it started in 1997. It featured performances by many foreign dance troupes and has attracted many tourists from Taiwan and abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: 199 smuggled Asian softshell turtles seized

TEXT.P: Customs officials discovered 31 cases containing 199 smuggled Asiatic softshell turtles, which are an endangered species under international protection, last week at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan.
The discovery came after the officials received a tip-off that a man surnamed Huang planned to smuggle the turtles from Thailand into Taiwan, where he intended to sell them to local restaurants.
As well as being endangered, the turtles could damage Taiwan's ecosystem if they escape and can carry viruses harmful to humans, the officials pointed out.
The case will also damage the country's international image as the animals are listed in the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, the officials went on.
The turtles will be checked for viruses prior to being taken to the Taipei City Zoo, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County to organize festival in mid-August

TEXT.P: The Changhua county government will organize a festival Aug. 11-19 at a fishing port in the central county, featuring a total of 16 activities, a spokesman said Tuesday.
The spokesman made the announcement at a press conference, attended by County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan, Deputy Magistrate Chang Jui-pin, among other central and local government officials.
Welcoming public participation in the event, the spokesman said that sunset at the Wangkung fishing port, the venue of the event, is one of the eight best scenes in the county.
The public can also sample oyster dishes at the port, which is at the center of the county's major oyster-producing area, the spokesman went on.
The nine-day festival will include folk activities, food fairs, tours of local areas, and a concert, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Modern fathers bear heavier burden in house purchases: survey

TEXT.P: Nearly 90 percent of young fathers in Taiwan feel their financial burdens are heavier than those of the older generations in terms of house purchases, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by a local real estate broker.
The survey was conducted by www.yungching.com, a Web site operated by the Yungching real estate group, to mark Father's Day.

A total of 58.85 percent of the fathers who responded to the survey mentioned that repayments on mortgages account for the largest share of their monthly family expenditure, compared with 31.77 percent who said they spend most on tuition fees or babysitting expenses every month.
Despite the heavy financial burden of mortgage repayment, fewer than 10 percent of the respondents said they have no plans to buy houses and will continue to rent.

Among those who plan to buy houses, 40 percent said they will buy a small one first before selling it for a larger one in the future; 35.38 percent said they will buy the house of their dreams no matter what; and 15.9 percent said they will buy a cheaper one in the suburbs first and will only consider moving to a downtown area in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Better legal environment key for Taiwan's IT competitiveness
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 7 (CNA) 08/07/07 20:51:06 (66.5), Taiwan (65.8), Sweden (65.4), Denmark (64.9), Canada (64.6) (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A better legal environment and government support will be the keys for the development of Taiwan's already robust information technology (IT) competitiveness if it wants to overtake Asia Pacific leaders Japan and South Korea, an IT consultant said Tuesday.

Taiwan's IT industry competitiveness ranks sixth globally and fourth in the Asia Pacific region, according to the "IT industry competitiveness index" released by the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) in July.

With Taiwan's buildup on IT infrastructure and research and development, along with a better legal environment and support from the government, Taiwan has the potential to overtake Japan and South Korea, said Goh Seow Hiong, director of Asia software policy of Business Software Alliance.

The EIU has conducted a global survey for the first time to compare countries' IT competitiveness by gauging their performance in six areas -- overall business environment, IT infrastructure, human capital, legal environment, R&D environment and support for IT industry development -- with 100 representing the highest score.

Collaboration between the government and private sector has been very successful, helping Taiwan establish a robust R&D environment that ranks third in the world, according to Goh, who added that the best example is the success of the Industrial Technology Research Institute in Hsinchu.
Taiwan's overall business environment, which ranked seventh globally, will enter a phase where a lot of mergers occur in the future, he predicted.

The government was encouraged to open the market for competition in order to improve the IT infrastructure, which ranked a fair 18th out of 64 countries in the survey. With the Institute for Information Industry leading the way, government support is adequate, although a 19th place ranking shows there is a lot of room of improvement, Goh pointed out.
Creating a better legal environment is also vital, said Goh, who pointed out that Taiwan ranked only 32nd in that category.

In terms of government priorities, key findings in the survey are that the government should ensure the flow of talent and support competition and innovation without stifling them, and ensure better intellectual property rights protection, he said.

According to the survey, the top 10 countries with the strongest IT industry competitiveness are the United States (77.4) , Japan (72.7) , South Korea (67.2) , the United Kingdom (67.1), Australia and Switzerland (63.5).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Bridge Collapse Revives Issue of Road Spending
In the past two years, Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota twice vetoed legislation to raise the states gas tax to pay for transportation needs.
Now, with at least five people dead in the collapse of the Interstate 35W bridge here, Mr. Pawlenty, a Republican, appears to have had a change of heart.
Despite historic highs in transportation spending, the political muscle of lawmakers, rather than dire need, has typically driven where much of the money goes.
Wall Street Journal:New Kingmaker:Vegas's Mr. Kihuen Will See You Now
Nevada state assemblyman Ruben Kihuen, a 27- year-old Mexican immigrant, is barely known outside his Las Vegas district. But he is being hotly pursued by Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and the other contenders for the Democratic presidential nomination.
Mr. Obama summoned him for a tete-a-tete in his hotel suite at Caesars Palace. Christopher Dodd asked him to play a round of golf. Bill Richardson and John Edwards have sought his endorsement, too. Mrs. Clinton's campaign invited Mr. Kihuen to fly on her private jet to Los Angeles so she could personally court him.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indonesian students call for help in saving rainforest

TEXT.P: A group of Indonesian students in Taiwan held a press conference Tuesday to call for local awareness and assistance in saving the Indonesian rainforest, which is being rapidly destroyed.

Indonesia, which has the second-largest rainforest in the world, is facing a severe environmental crisis that even the people of Taiwan cannot overlook, said group leader Denni, a junior at the Transworld Institute of Technology (TIT) in Yunlin County.
Denni was one of five Indonesian exchange students at TIT's Department of Environmental Resources Management who made the appeal. They all came from the Indonesian island of Sumantra.

Indonesia's rainforest is vanishing at frightening speed because of illegal logging, corruption and global warming he said, adding that the destruction has led to the deaths of more than 1,000 orangutans, 33 Sumatran tigers and numerous other endangered species every year.

"People may think that Taiwan has nothing to do with the status of the Indonesian rainforest. But most people don't realize that Taiwan has been hurting the Earth more than other countries. That is why we should offer our help more than anyone else, " said Chang Tzu-chien, a professor at TIT, who also noted that the average greenhouse gas emission per person of Taiwan ranks third- highest globally.

The group of Indonesian students have been engaging in an international exchange project, titled "Sustainable Sumatra, " a collaboration of TIT's Department of Environmental Resources Management and Bodhicitta Mandala Conservation, an Indonesian non-government organization (NGO) that focuses on environmental conservation.

"Well-known NGOs such as the World Wildlife Foundation and Conservation International have been trying to save the rainforest but the rate of destruction has not slowed, largely as a result of poverty," Chang said.
He said the exchange project aims to work with local organizations to improve the local economy, public health, provide clean water and environmental protection.
"We feel obligated to so something for our home country. Hopefully, what we do today can raise the awareness of Taiwanese people on the issue, " said Hendra, a sophomore from Medan.

DOC.HEADLINE: New tropical depression might develop into typhoon: CWB

TEXT.P: Another tropical depression has taken shape in the western Pacific and is likely to develop into a typhoon between Aug. 9 and Aug. 11, Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecasters said Tuesday.

CWB meteorologists said the active low pressure, which has not yet been named, comes on the heels of Tropical Storm Pabuk, which was expected to make landfall in Taiwan shortly before midnight Tuesday.

The center of the low pressure system was pinpointed at about 540 km east of Luzon, the largest island in the Philippine archipelago. If it is upgraded to a tropical storm or typhoon, it will take the name Wutif, contributed by Macau.

It is not unusual for Taiwan to see two typhoons in a row. On Aug. 8 last year, the CWB issued a land warning for Tropical Storm Bopha, followed by another land warning a day later for Typhoon Saomai, while a third storm, Typhoon Maria, was heading toward Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei girls school's marching band receives wide acclaim in U.K.
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 6 (CNA) 08/07/07 21:59:10 (By Jennifer Huang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei First Girls' High School marching band is receiving wide acclaim at the Edinburgh International Festival being held in the United Kingdom Aug. 3-25, helping to increase Taiwan's profile on the world stage.

Tong Dai-lin, one of the captains of the 135-member marching corps, said during an interview with the Central News Agency Monday that she feels honored to represent Taiwan at the Edinburgh Military Tattoo, an internationally renowned event featuring military bands and other performing groups now in its 58th year.
Tong, also the conductor of the band, said she is always deeply moved when tens of thousands of people in audiences from various countries applaud the corps members as they march.

Asked how she has overcome homesickness during her first overseas tour, Tong said she stopped missing her family after telling herself that she is making a contribution to her country's international profile.
Compared with other performing groups, the band is quite large and catches the public's much attention, Tong said.

During their month-long stay in the Scottish capital, the band members are constantly practicing in order to perfect their performance, while also taking time to work on their studies in the middle of the night, Tong stated.
Noting that her fellow students are gradually used to the "fast pace of life in Edinburgh, " Tong said she believes they will perform even better in the remaining days of the event.
She described the overseas performance as a precious opportunity, which she said has expanded her horizons and changed her attitudes towards her life and future plans.
Yeh Wen-chin, another band captain, said that the corps members have also made new friends among their counterparts, and that they are also teaching Chinese to a group of U.K. bikers.
Citing as an example Aug. 5 festival opening parade in Edinburgh, Yeh said they were greatly touched by Taiwanese expatriates who cheered alongside the band, waving the country's national flag.

Huang Li-wen, also a member of the corps, said the band and the other participating groups are performing at a high level, and she described the experience as "one of the most unforgettable memories of my life."

DOC.HEADLINE: Hushan reservoir project in Yunlin to be completed by 2014

TEXT.P: Approximately 25 percent of the Hushan reservoir in the southern county of Yunlin had been completed as of July, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Tuesday, estimating that the entire project will be finished by 2014.
The NT$20.5 billion (US$621 million) project is part of the government's efforts to resolve a land sinkage problem in the county, the officials noted.
The majority of the county's land is sinking, a problem resulting from local residents pumping too much ground water for irrigation and aquaculture, the officials said.

Over 100 million tonnes of ground water is pumped out annually in the southern county, the officials said, warning that water in some areas of the county has also been found to be contaminated by toxic chemicals including arsenic and nitrate nitrogen.

The county's land sinking problem also needs to be curbed as it poses a safety threat to the Yunlin station on the country's high speed railway, the officials went on. The station is still under construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical Storm Pabuk brings relief to drought-stricken Taitung

TEXT.P: Farmers in the eastern Taiwan county of Taitung were overjoyed Tuesday as rain brought by Tropical Storm Pabuk began to fall on their drought-parched land.

The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea and land warning early Tuesday when Pabuk was about 400 km southeast of Taitung, but hours later, shortly before noon, long-awaited rain finally came -- first as fine drizzle, followed by a two hour downpour.

Elated farmers rushed to their land to check their irrigation systems to ensure smooth flow of water. The step was necessary to make sure clogged water channels did not cause overflows that could break the levees and ruin the whole field.
The rice farmers, especially those in Chihshang township, one of Taiwan's main centers for producing organic rice, have waited too long for rain to begin their second rice planting this year.

Water also began to flow in Taitung County's streams, which had run dry since late June. The water level in the Hsinwulu river, the habitat of the Taiwan ku fish, not only returned to normal but kept rising.
For tea growers in the county, however, the rain came too late to salvage their crops, with more than 60 percent of their plants already withered under the scorching sun.

Water resources officials at both the central and local government levels expressed mixed feelings about Pabuk. Although they were delighted about the rain it has brought, they also feared the tropical storm would leave a trail of damage in its wake.
Taitung County has been hit hard by the most serious drought in 30 years, with only 258 mm of rain recorded for the first seven months of this year -- less than one-third of the normal amount.

Pabuk was expected to make landfall in Taiwan at around 11 p.m. Tuesday, with its center leaving the Hengchung peninsula at about 1 a.m. Wednesday. According to the CWB, most areas in Taiwan will see at least 200 mm of rain from Pabuk, with eastern Taiwan receiving more than other areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet supports impartial probes into corruption cases: spokesman

TEXT.P: The executive branch supports impartial judicial probes into any corruption cases involving government officials, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Tuesday.

Shieh made the remarks after investigators searched the office of Vice Economic Affairs Minister Hou Ho-shong earlier in the day as part of a probe into alleged corruption that might implicate dozens of other government officials.

Led by prosecutors, nearly 200 staff members from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau searched Hou's office and several agencies under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) in its probe into suspected forgery and influence peddling involving certain river and reservoir dredging and cleanup projects.

More than 30 officials from the MOEA's water resources bureaus and river management offices are suspected of having given favors to specific contractors employed to handle river and reservoir dredging and cleanup, according to prosecution authorities.

Shieh said the Executive Yuan fully supports prosecutorial probes into those cases in an impartial manner. "Our hope is that there will be no false prosecution and no tolerance of official wrongdoing, " he added.

Moreover, Shieh said the MOEA will review its procurement bidding procedures and check whether there is any gaps or holes in its supervisory mechanism. The MOEA will also investigate whether any individuals should be held accountable for any irregularities, Shieh said.

"Investigative results will be the basis in the MOEA's decision of its next step. If judicial probes find any official is guilty of any offense, the MOEA will deal with the case in accordance with legal provisions. And if those who are subject to investigations are found to have not committed any wrongdoing, they will clear their names, " Shieh said, adding that the administration will not tolerate any corrupt act and will honor its promise to establish clean politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lifting ban on ractopamine requires DOH-COA approval: official

TEXT.P: Removal of a ban on the use of the veterinary drug ractopamine in local hog and cow farming and setting permissible residue levels will require a joint decision and action of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Council of Agriculture (COA), a food sanitation official said Tuesday.

Cheng Hui-wen, director-general of the DOH's FBureau of Food Sanitation, made the remarks in response to a protest earlier the same day by local pig raisers who accused the government of seeking to remove the ban on the drug by seeking endorsement from academics as a result of foreign pressure.
Brushing aside hog raisers' allegations that the government is to lift the ban on ractopamine, Cheng said the DOH will not do so "in a rush or in a reckless manner."

Cheng said the DOH will first ask experts to make a broad assessment on the feasibility of permitting a maximum 10ppb residue of the substance in locally produced pork or beef, as is the case in Japan.

Japan was a major market for Taiwanese pork exports before the country was listed as a foot-and-mouth disease affected area, and Japan allowed limited ractopamine residue of under 10ppb, he explained.
Cheng said the DOH will not remove the ban unless relevant government agencies, including the COA, have made concerted moves and agree to the use of the currently banned drug.

He also said it is wrong to mislead the public into believing that large amounts of U.S. pork containing ractopamine residue has entered Taiwan because foreign imports only account for 1 percent of local consumption and pork imported from the United States, where use of the drug is permitted, only makes up of 0.7 percent of the total foreign imports.
Two shipments of U. S. pork and some locally farmed pork were recently detected to contain the drug, provoking "grave concern" among local consumers.

A group of pig farmers, led by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Ko Chun-hsiung, accused the DOH earlier that same day in a news conference of seeking to ease its stance on the use of ractopamine as a result of foreign pressure.

Ko and Pan Lien-chou, a local hog-raising association chairman, made the accusation after it was reported that the DOH might yield to pressure from foreign countries and allow the use of the drug that can promote growth of lean meat in pigs and poultry.
Pan claimed that an estimated 1,000 metric tons of imported pork containing ractopamine are currently waiting to enter Taiwan at Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan.

Pan said he strongly suspects that the DOH will relax its ban on ractopamine and claimed that allowing the use of the substance for local pig and cow farmers will pose great risks to the public's health.
Yin Ling-yin, a lawmaker of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, also asked the DOH to stick firm to its ban on ractopamine "for the sake of Taiwan consumers' health."
Yin demanded Cheng step down from his post to take responsibility if the U.S. pork in Kaohsiung is allowed to enter Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet supports impartial probes into corruption cases: spokesman

TEXT.P: The executive branch supports impartial judicial probes into any corruption cases involving government officials, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Tuesday.

Shieh made the remarks after investigators searched the office of Vice Economic Affairs Minister Hou Ho-shong earlier in the day as part of a probe into alleged corruption that might implicate dozens of other government officials.

Led by prosecutors, nearly 200 staff members from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau searched Hou's office and several agencies under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) in its probe into suspected forgery and influence peddling involving certain river and reservoir dredging and cleanup projects.

More than 30 officials from the MOEA's water resources bureaus and river management offices are suspected of having given favors to specific contractors employed to handle river and reservoir dredging and cleanup, according to prosecution authorities.

Shieh said the Executive Yuan fully supports prosecutorial probes into those cases in an impartial manner. "Our hope is that there will be no false prosecution and no tolerance of official wrongdoing, " he added.

Moreover, Shieh said the MOEA will review its procurement bidding procedures and check whether there is any gaps or holes in its supervisory mechanism. The MOEA will also investigate whether any individuals should be held accountable for any irregularities, Shieh said.

"Investigative results will be the basis in the MOEA's decision of its next step. If judicial probes find any official is guilty of any offense, the MOEA will deal with the case in accordance with legal provisions. And if those who are subject to investigations are found to have not committed any wrongdoing, they will clear their names, " Shieh said, adding that the administration will not tolerate any corrupt act and will honor its promise to establish clean politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lifting ban on ractopamine requires DOH-COA approval: official

TEXT.P: Removal of a ban on the use of the veterinary drug ractopamine in local hog and cow farming and setting permissible residue levels will require a joint decision and action of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Council of Agriculture (COA), a food sanitation official said Tuesday.

Cheng Hui-wen, director-general of the DOH's FBureau of Food Sanitation, made the remarks in response to a protest earlier the same day by local pig raisers who accused the government of seeking to remove the ban on the drug by seeking endorsement from academics as a result of foreign pressure.
Brushing aside hog raisers' allegations that the government is to lift the ban on ractopamine, Cheng said the DOH will not do so "in a rush or in a reckless manner."

Cheng said the DOH will first ask experts to make a broad assessment on the feasibility of permitting a maximum 10ppb residue of the substance in locally produced pork or beef, as is the case in Japan.

Japan was a major market for Taiwanese pork exports before the country was listed as a foot-and-mouth disease affected area, and Japan allowed limited ractopamine residue of under 10ppb, he explained.
Cheng said the DOH will not remove the ban unless relevant government agencies, including the COA, have made concerted moves and agree to the use of the currently banned drug.

He also said it is wrong to mislead the public into believing that large amounts of U.S. pork containing ractopamine residue has entered Taiwan because foreign imports only account for 1 percent of local consumption and pork imported from the United States, where use of the drug is permitted, only makes up of 0.7 percent of the total foreign imports.
Two shipments of U. S. pork and some locally farmed pork were recently detected to contain the drug, provoking "grave concern" among local consumers.

A group of pig farmers, led by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Ko Chun-hsiung, accused the DOH earlier that same day in a news conference of seeking to ease its stance on the use of ractopamine as a result of foreign pressure.

Ko and Pan Lien-chou, a local hog-raising association chairman, made the accusation after it was reported that the DOH might yield to pressure from foreign countries and allow the use of the drug that can promote growth of lean meat in pigs and poultry.
Pan claimed that an estimated 1,000 metric tons of imported pork containing ractopamine are currently waiting to enter Taiwan at Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan.

Pan said he strongly suspects that the DOH will relax its ban on ractopamine and claimed that allowing the use of the substance for local pig and cow farmers will pose great risks to the public's health.
Yin Ling-yin, a lawmaker of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, also asked the DOH to stick firm to its ban on ractopamine "for the sake of Taiwan consumers' health."
Yin demanded Cheng step down from his post to take responsibility if the U.S. pork in Kaohsiung is allowed to enter Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 8, or the 26th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1549: France declares war on England.
1588: The Spanish Armada is defeated by the British.
1900: The first Davis Cup tennis tournament, named after Dwight Filley Davis, begins in Brookline, Massachusetts.
1901: Ernest Lawrence, the American physicist who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1939, is born. He invented the first subatomic particle accelerator and the color television tube.
1918: The Battle of Amiens begins when Allied forces advance against 20 German divisions and take 16,000 prisoners in two hours.
1919: A peace conference between India and Afghanistan results in the signing of the Treaty of Rawalpindi.
1923: Esther Williams, the American actress and former champion swimmer, is born. She became best-known for her appearance in "Bathing Beauty."
1944: Adolf Hitler has four of his top men hanged with piano wire for attempting to assassinate him.
1945: The United States drops its second atomic bomb, "Fat Man," on the Japanese city of Nagasaki, days after devastating Hiroshima with "Little Boy," the first such device ever used.
1957: General Chow Chih-jou is appointed governor of Taiwan, succeeding C.K. Yen.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1961: Mei Lan-fang, noted Beijing opera actor, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 67.
1963: In one of the most audacious holdups of all time, robbers involved in "The Great Train Robbery" net an estimated 2.5 million pounds (US$4.6 million) in unused bank notes from a night mail train traveling between Glasgow and London.
1963: The United States, Britain and the USSR sign the nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the Kremlin.
1967: The "Bangkok Declaration" is signed by the foreign ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. The declaration led to the formation of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
1974: Richard Nixon makes history as the first U.S. president to resign from office.
1977: The Interior Ministry reports that at the end of June, the population of Taiwan reached 16,655,140 and that of Taipei hit 2,113,030.
1983: A military coup led by Defense Minister General Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores overthrows President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala.
1988: ROC swimmer Wang Han and a six-man team swim across the English Channel in relays in 14 hours and 31 minutes.
1988: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa announces the decision to build a new highway linking Ilan and Nankang in Taipei County.
1990: National Defense Minister Chen Li-an announces that the Red Cross Society of the ROC will handle the repatriation of illegal mainland entrants in the future.
1994: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait sign and make public a joint announcement confirming the results of the second round of talks between Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei.
1999: The Fifth Asia Children's Literature Convention opens in Taipei with 300 authors of children's literature from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia and the ROC attending.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records names 109 -year-old Hu Chin-yao as Taiwan's oldest father.
2001: Officials from Taiwan and Australia gathers in Taipei to participate in a two-day conference on mineral and energy resources.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If those in authority have not the confidence of those under them, government of the people is an impossibility."

DOC.HEADLINE: Pabuk likely to bring downpours to eastern, northern Taiwan: CWB

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) warned residents in northern and eastern Taiwan Wednesday to prepare for possible downpours triggered by Tropical Storm Pabuk, which is moving rapidly away from Taiwan.
The storm made landfall on the Hengchun Peninsula at the southernmost of Taiwan at 1 a.m. Wednesday.

As of 8 a.m., Pabuk was centered 140 km south-southwest of the outlying island group of Penghu, moving westerly at 25 kph toward China, forecasters said, adding that the CWB is expected to lift its land warning for Pabuk at around noon.

Although the tropical storm's influence on Taiwan's weather is diminishing, it is likely to bring downpours to the eastern and northern parts of Taiwan as its outer edge passes over the area, forecasters said.

Between early Tuesday morning and 8 a.m. Wednesday, accumulated rainfall registered 392 mm in Hualien City, 298 mm in Huayuan, Taitung County, 221 mm in Kenting, and 208 mm in Pihu, Taipei County, according to CWB tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to continue seeking repatriation of fugitive tycoon: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday the government will continue working to have fugitive Rebar Group founder Wang You-theng repatriated back to Taiwan through legal means, in the wake of Wang's release from a holding center in the United States.
Chang said the concerned Taiwan authorities have had U.S. legal experts study what actions Taiwan can take to achieve the goal.
"We won't be discouraged and will do whatever we can on the matter, regardless of what problems we face," Chang said.

Meanwhile, Bureau of Investigation officials said that they have not received any official notification from U.S. authorities concerning Wang's release and that they will monitor his whereabouts as soon as they obtain related information.
According to local media reports, Wang was released Tuesday from an immigration holding center in San Pedro, California, where he had been held since Feb. 2.

Wang was detained by U.S. immigration authorities when he tried to return to Los Angeles with both his Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports canceled, following a failed attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore.

Wang is suspected of having embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds from the group before fleeing with his wife, Wang Chin She-ying, to China late last year and then to the United States in January this year.
Taiwan authorities placed the couple on the country's most-wanted list Jan. 15 and have been seeking U.S. assistance to have them repatriated back to Taiwan to face charges.

In March, Taiwanese prosecutors indicted Wang and 106 others involved in the Rebar Group scandal on a long list of charges, including fraud, money laundering and insider trading, and are seeking a prison sentence of 30 years and an unprecedented fine of NT$1.71 billion (US$52.13 million) for Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate to visit Singapore

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Frank Hsieh is scheduled to depart for Singapore this weekend for a three-day visit, Hsieh's campaign aides said Wednesday.
The major purpose of Hsieh's trip will be to exchange views with Singaporean officials on a development project that he has proposed as part of his campaign platform, they said.

Hsieh's proposal, which is aimed at facilitating resources sharing and enhancing the country's competitiveness, concerns the division of Taiwan into six major regions, with each region having the scale of one Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: Metal band promotes Taiwan on U.S. tour
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 7 (CNA) 08/08/07 13:29:47 (By Josie Chou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese symphonic black metal band ChthoniC has successfully promoted Taiwan, particularly Taiwan's bid to join the international community, during its current tour in the United States, the U.S. Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) reported Aug. 2.

In an exclusive interview on the PBS program Pacifictime, ChthoniC lead vocalist Freddy Lin said that the band has spoken loudly for Taiwan's causes, mainly its difficulties in joining international organizations due to Beijing's obstruction, during the Ozzfest 2007.

According to Lin, ChthoniC gave 20 performances at Ozzfest 2007, at the invitation of Ozzy Osbourne, the lead singer of the pioneering heavy metal band Black Sabbath, held in Santa Ana in Los Angeles and San Francisco last month.

Lin said that ChthoniC has performed songs in both Mandarin and Taiwanese for thousands of American fans and that he is not worried that these songs might not be accepted by American fans, noting that heavy metal audiences pay more attention to music rather lyrics.

He emphasized, however, that the song "Unlimited Taiwan, " demonstrating the unlimited potential of the island and its people, was performed in English in order to better present the band's support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.
He said he spoke out in English at every concert, asking fans to support Taiwan as their music was inspired in and by the nation.

Lin said he is not worried about the band being associated with politics. On the contrary, he said the opportunity to raise Taiwan's profile in the international community would be a brand-new experience for Taiwan's music world.

During the seven-minute interview, Lin said that the Ozzfest concert was just part of the beginning of the group's "Unlimited World Tour" 2007, which will involve more than 80 concerts around the world, including Germany's Wacken Open Air festival -- the world's largest exclusively metal music festival -- as well as a number of concerts around Asia.
More than 1 million fans will be listening to ChthoniC's music and words on Taiwan issues, Lin noted.
During the Unlimited World Tour, Lin said, the group will promote Taiwan culture and the country's concerns by distributing paper dolls, T-shirts and CDs, in addition to playing music.

The PBS interview is expected to be re-broadcast by 15 other PBS stations across America over the following months, Lin said, adding that fans in Hong Kong and southern China will also be able to catch the interview on channel Radio 3. The interview can also be found online at www.kqed.org/pacifictime.

The name "Chthonic" (pronounced THON-ick) is Greek for "of the Underworld." The group's music focuses in part on the history of the Taiwanese people. Though the band's image is reminiscent of the black metal legends of Scandinavia, ChthoniC's use of corpse paint is inspired by the history of their own culture. In Taiwanese folklore, deities known as the "Eight Generals" wear corpse paint to become empowered with Taoist spirits that give them the power to judge good and evil. It is this spirit that the band conveys on stage.

ChthoniC has been pushing the boundaries throughout their career, and having singlehandedly launched an extreme metal scene in their home country, the group now sets their sights squarely on the rest of the world, according to a U.S. critic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Tainan County councilor seriously injured in railway crossing accident

TEXT.P: A Tainan County councilor is in critical condition at the Chi Mei Medical Center in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, after being seriously injured in a railway accident Tuesday night.

Chan Lung-chou, as well as his assistant Wu Cheng-che, were badly injured when the sedan they were in was hit on the side by an express train at a level crossing in the southern county, according to hospital sources.

The county fire department was informed of the accident at about 11 p.m. and immediately rushed personnel to the scene, where they found both Chang and Cheng in a coma. The two injured men were then rushed to the hospital.
According to the local police's preliminary investigation, Wu, who was driving the vehicle at the time of the accident, had allegedly attempted to run the railway crossing.
As a result of the accident, the train was delayed by 30 minutes.
Further investigations into the accident are currently underway, according to local police.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rebar founder's status in U.S. yet to be finally resolved: AIT

TEXT.P: The status of Wang You-theng, founder of Rebar Asia Pacific Group who was released Tuesday from an immigration holding center in the United States, has yet to be finally resolved, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) spokesman said Wednesday.

"U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement is now determining the next appropriate steps in the case of Wang You-theng. His status in the United States has yet to be finally resolved, " AIT spokeman Thomas Hodges said.
"Further questions about Mr. Wang's case should be directed to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, " he said.
Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed in a press conference Wednesday morning that Wang has been released from the immigration holding center in San Pedro, California.

Wang had been detained by U.S. immigration authorities since Feb. 2, when he tried to return to Los Angeles with both his Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports canceled, following a failed attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore.

Wang is suspected of having embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds from the group before fleeing with his wife, Wang Chin She-ying, to China late last year and then to the United States in January this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather bureau issues sea, land warning for new storm

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) lifted its land warning for Tropical Storm Pabuk at 11: 30 a.m. Wednesday while issuing a sea and land warning for an ensuing storm at the same time.
The new storm, named Wutip, was centered 430 km east-southeast of Taiwan as of 11 a.m., moving north-northwesterly at a speed of 22 kph toward Taiwan, CWB meteorologists said.

Wutip -- which is the seventh tropical storm reported in the West Pacific area this year -- is expected to affect the eastern counties of Yilan, Hualian and Taitung, as well as Green Island, Orchid Island, the Bashi Channel area and waters off eastern Taiwan, the forecasters said.
They added that although Wutip is coming closely on the heels of Pabuk, it is not expected to lead to a Fujiwara Effect, or Twin Typhoon Effect, because both storm systems are not strong enough.

The CWB meteorologists, however, still called for residents in eastern and southern Taiwan to be on alert as the two storms are expected to trigger torrential rainfall in these areas over the next several days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 311 points to close at 9,078, with 52,580 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September rose 282 points to finish at 9,050, with 2,474 contracts traded, while December futures gained 290 points to close at 9,080, with 70 contract transactions. March futures moved up 274 points to close at 9,055, with eight contracts traded, while June futures increased 295 points to end at 9,077, with four contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,767 for August, 8,768 for September, 8,790 for December, 8,781 for March and 8,782 for June.

Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher. August TE futures moved up 12.3 points to close at 382.5, with 3,495 contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 12.6 points to finish at 381.6, with 141 contract transactions. December TE futures increased 7.2 points to end at 379, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures increased 33.2 points to close at 1,047.2, with 3,387 contracts traded, while September TF futures rose 35 points to finish at 1,047, with 191 contract transactions. December TF futures gained 4.6 points to end at 1,049.4, with two contracts traded, while March TF futures moved up 12 points to end at 1,042, with one contract transaction. No contracts were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government allocates funds for digital content industry development

TEXT.P: The government has decided to invest a total of NT$4.12 billion (US$125 million) in efforts to develop the country's digital content industry over the next five years, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Wednesday.

In addition, the Executive Yuan will also activate its NT$20 billion National Development Fund to help push for local and international investment in the industry, Chang said, noting that the measures were formed in the hopes of boosting the emerging sector's production value to NT$600 billion by 2011.

Chang made the announcement at the Executive Yuan after listening to a report from the Ministry of Economic Affairs on the latter's plans to reinforce the government's efforts to assist local businesses in the development of computer animation technologies and digital games.
The report outlined plans for helping Taiwan to become one of the world's most advanced countries in the areas of entertainment business and multi-media innovation and applications.
Also at the Executive Yuan meeting, a draft of statutes governing the digital content industry's development was passed. The draft bill will now be sent to the Legislative Yuan for screening.

On the government's planned investment, Chang said NT$1.36 billion will be allocated for subsidizing 60 local animated film and digital game development and production projects in an effort to cultivate local talent in these areas.

With the investment, Chang said he hopes Taiwan will eventually break into international markets with locally-produced animated films carrying the image of Taiwan, while at the same time creating thousands of job opportunities in the country over the next thre years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exports, imports for July hit single-month highs

TEXT.P: Export and import values for July reached US$21.18 billion and US$20.73 billion, respectively, both setting single-month records, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Wednesday.
Export value marked an 8.2 percent year-on-year rise while imports rose 16.7 percent from the year-earlier level.
With imports growing faster than exports, the country's trade surplus dropped 75 percent from the year-earlier level to a mere US$450 million for July, the lowest since March 2006.

Lee Li-hsue, director-general of the MOF's Statistics Department, said exports of consumer products to Hong Kong, China and Europe all had annual growth rates of more than 12 percent, which contributed to the high export value for the month.

The high import value was achieved thanks to increases of imports from the Middle East, Europe, Hong Kong, China and America, at 36.2 percent, 27.2 percent, 17.5 percent, and 11.2 percent, respectively, Lee said, adding that a large amount of naphtha imports also contributed to the total figure.

Total export value from January to July hit US$135.12 billion, up 7.6 percent over the same period of last year, owing to an increase of 7.8 percent in exports to Asian countries and a 13 percent increase in exports to Europe.

The total import value for the same period reached US$124.13 billion, an increase of 7 percent year-on-year, giving Taiwan a trade surplus of US$10.99 billion for the first seven months, up 14.9 percent over the same period of last year.
