DOC.HEADLINE: President wants to communicate with U.S. on U.N. issue

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he wants to further communicate with the United States to resolve their differences on Taiwan's efforts to push for a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.

Stressing that his "four noes" commitment to the United States will remain in place in the remaining nine months of his term, Chen reiterated that unlike the U.S., he does not think the referendum plan violates this commitment.
Chen made the remarks while receiving Randall Schriver, a former deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, who is visiting Taiwan.

During the meeting, Chen claimed not to know what Washington finds wrong with the referendum plan -- whether it is with the U.N. participation, with the use of the name Taiwan or with the country's attempt to address the issue through a referendum.
Claiming that U.N. membership for Taiwan is the aspiration of the majority of Taiwan's people, Chen told Schriver that 77 percent of the people support the country's bid to join the United Nations.

As to the use of the name Taiwan, Chen said not even the largest opposition party -- the Kuomintang (KMT) -- has "dared" to openly oppose the move and that the KMT-initiated referendum plan does not rule out using the name to join the United Nations, either.

According to Chen, using the name Taiwan does not mean changing the country's official name, and the country has made the choice since the official title of Republic of China is not accepted in the international arena.

Compared with other names, such as Chinese Taipei and the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, which the country has used to join international organizations, Taiwan is the most familiar, powerful and beautiful name preferred by the majority of the country's population, Chen said.

Despite the high thresholds that referendums are required to pass, various political parties have put forth several referendum initiatives designed to be held alongside next year's legislative elections or presidential election, Chen said, calling the development atestimony to Taiwan's democracy.

Challenging the fairness of the U.S. policy of not supporting Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is required, based on its "one China" policy, Chen asked if any of the three U.S.-China communiques mentions that "Taiwan is a province of the People's Republic of China" or "recognizes" Taiwan as part of China.

Chen said the issue is not addressed in Resolution 2758 adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1971 either, although the world body has cited the resolution as the basis of its rejection of Taiwan's membership application.

Over the past few months, U.S. State Department officials have on a number of occasions stated that the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood, including the United Nations.

Also, the officials have noted that the U.S. opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally, including the referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, adding that such a plan would appear to run counter to Chen's repeated commitments to Washington.

Chen pledged during his 2000 and 2004 inaugural addresses that if China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" concept on cross-strait relations in the Constitution and will not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Venezuelan foot-dragging over baseball visas 'unacceptable': GIO

TEXT.P: Venezuela's procrastination in issuing visas to Taiwan youth baseballers to enable them to compete in the 13th World Youth Championship beginning Aug. 14 is "unacceptable, " Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday.

The Chinese Taipei youth baseballers are scheduled to enter the competition Aug. 14 to pave the way for the kickoff of the 13th World Youth Championship Aug. 17, but the players have not yet received visas from the Venezuelan authorities.
The Chinese Taipei Amateur Baseball Association has been worked on the visa issue for the past four months but has still not received any positive answer from the Venezuelan government.

Local media reported Wednesday that the top official of Venezuela's national baseball association had admitted to the International Baseball Federation (IBAF) recently that "there were some `political problems.'"

According to Shieh, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has lodged protests to Venezuela as well as the IBAF over the visa boycott "in real time, " adding that their efforts will not stop until the baseball players reach the venue.
Shieh accused China of persistently suppressing the sporting spirit around the world in order to obstruct Taiwan's participation in competitions.
He added that Beijing's unworthy gesture is definitely detrimental to the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Meanwhile, Wang Tuoh, a whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus, called a news conference at the Legislative Yuan Wednesday to express the ruling party's indignation over the visa issue.

Noting that Beijing has "put its political hand into the international sports arena" and accusing Venezuela of turning a blind eye to global justice, Wang said the DPP lodges its strongest anger and protest to Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus also hosted a similar news conference that same day in which Chou Shou-hsun, a deputy whip of the caucus, called for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Sports Affairs Council to pull out all the stops to enable the Chinese Taipei youth baseball players to go to Venezuela to compete in the world series.

DOC.HEADLINE: New method to extract key ingredient for cancer drugs developed

TEXT.P: Local agricultural researchers have developed a new and efficient technique to extract a key ingredient of cancer drugs from a plant endemic only to Orchid Island and Green Island, sources at the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday.

Ho Cheng-kuen, a researcher at the COA's Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, said the plant -- nothapodytes nimmoniana -- was first discovered by Japanese scientists more than two decades ago to contain a substance named camptothecin that has proved effective against colon cancer.
Since then, nothapodytes nimmoniana has been utilized in colon cancer drug production, Ho added.

Ho noted that however, the patents for a camptothecin-related drug -- Campto -- have been held exclusively by Japanese pharmaceutical companies, so that even though the plant is endemic to Taiwan and local researchers have known the effects of camptothecin, no further experiments could be done before the patent rights expired.

Ho explained that since the patent rights finally expire this year, the institute has initiated several projects to improve the extraction and production process that will help Taiwan biomedical manufacturers gain some edge over the drug production.

According to the institute, the new technique for camptothecin extraction is to insert a specific kind of bacteria -- agrobacterium rhizogenes -- into the seeds to double the growth rate of the plant's roots. The roots, containing 552 ppm to 1,555 ppm of camptothecin, are then cultivated in vitro and the camptothecin released into the culture solution, giving 9.8 milligrams of camptothecin to every liter of culture solution.
The institute will adapt the technique to mass production and apply for Taiwan patents for the related techniques, Ho noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices skyrocket on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange skyrocketed Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 237.15 points to close at 9,099.46.
The bourse opened at 8,961.12 and fluctuated between 9,099.46 and 8,938.54 during trading. A total of 4.87 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$143.69 billion (US$4.37 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 4.8 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 4 percent, textile stocks at 3.7 percent, cement stocks at 3.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 3.1 percnet, plastics and chemicals shares at 3 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2.6 percent, and construction issues at 2 percent.
Gainers numbered more than 1,000 againt 305 losers, with 155 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice economics minister detained over alleged corruption

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Hou Ho-shong was detained Wednesday following an investigation into his alleged role in corruption surrounding several water resources engineering projects.

Hou's detention came one day after he was questioned by Nantou prosecutors who suspected the vice minister of using his influence to help his cronies win bids and receive contracts for several public works projects related to water resources, river and reservoir dredging and cleanups in the central county.

Over 200 prosecutors and investigation agents also searched 33 locations, including offices of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, related agencies and various construction companies, in search of evidence.
Economic Affairs Minister Steve R. L. Chen said earlier the same day following a weekly Executive Yuan meeting that Hou will be suspended from his duties if he is detained.

According to an initial investigation, Hou might have been involved in the bidding procedures or have engaged in influence peddling to assign contracts to his cronies in several public water resources and river management projects, Chen said.

He added that the Ministry of Economic Affairs will fully respect the investigation and prosecution authorities' rights to probe the cases implicating Hou and that his ministry will do its best to cooperate.
Huang Yen-tung, a construction company executive, was also detained along with Hou after being interrogated by prosecutors and judges.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15-year-old becomes youngest varsity freshman this year

TEXT.P: A 15-year-old child prodigy was admitted into the Department of Electrical Engineering of the prestigious National Taiwan University Wednesday, making her the youngest freshman in Taiwan this year.

Tsai Pei-chen, a graduate from the Taipei First Girls' High School, will not turn 16 until Aug. 16. She has skipped grades twice since the age of 10, according to her father, Tsai Yen-hsin, an assistant professor at the Technology and Science Institute of Northern Taiwan.
Tsai said Pei-chen has been interested in math, nature and physics since she was very young. In addition, he went on, she has a photographic memory.

According to Tsai, Pei-chen was excused from math classes because she was so far ahead of her classmates, giving her additional spare time to spend in the library reading books or taking online classes provided by NTU.

DOC.HEADLINE: Storm leaves no serious damage in Taitung County

TEXT.P: Taitung County escaped relatively unharmed Wednesday, although the county bore the brunt of Tropical Storm Pabuk's onslaught overnight.
Not only did the eastern Taiwan county emerge unscathed, its two-month-long drought -- the most serious in 30 years -- was effectively relieved by the nearly 300 mm of rainfall brought by Pabuk.

According to the Taitung Disaster Response Center, no serious damage in the county was reported as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, except for some 1,600 households in Taimali township that were left without electricity.
By noon, both air and land transport had resumed normal operations, but marine traffic still remained suspended.

The 3,000 residents of Lanyu, an outlying island under the jurisdiction of Taitung County, spent a night in total darkness after gusty winds caused a power outage late Tuesday. Taiwan Power Co. restored power to half of the households Wednesday morning, with the other half -- about 600 households -- still without electricity.

Lanyu, also known as Orchid Island, experienced gusty winds of up to 56 meters per second, or 202 kph -- stronger than a super typhoon -- at around 8: 30 p.m. Tuesday, but fortunately the winds did not cause serious damage, according to officials at the disaster response center.

DOC.HEADLINE: No pay raises for civil servants, military personnel next year

TEXT.P: There will be no pay raises for civil servants, military personnel or public school teachers next year, government sources said Wednesday.

According to the sources, President Chen Shui-bian agreed to the Executive Yuan's decision not to adjust public functionaries' salaries for the coming year after listening to a briefing by Premier Chang chun-hsiung on the government's 2008 budget plans earlier in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tibetan human rights advocates protest over China

TEXT.P: Tibetan human rights advocates protested Wednesday over China's continuing oppression of the autonomous zone, saying that the totalitarian state is not qualified to host the Olympics, as China launched its one-year countdown to the 2008 Beijing Summer Olympics.

"China has never stopped its social, political and religious oppression in Tibet. Awarding China the 2008 Olympics is like handing it a license to kill in the same way Nazi Germany was given the right to host the 1936 Berlin Olympics, " according to Chou Mei-li, chairwoman of the Taiwan Friends of Tibet.

On the same day that China launched its one-year countdown to the Olympics, Taiwan wants and needs to be a part of a global coalition that supports Tibetan human rights and condemns the Chinese regime, she said.

"For the Chinese government, this is a symbolic moment to promote its Olympics propaganda and to show an outer layer in fancy pictures of China and occupied Tibet to the outside world. For Tibet and our worldwide supporters, Aug. 8, 2007 marks the beginning of a massive International Day of Action for Tibet, " said Rinzin Tsering, chairman of the Taiwan Tibetan Welfare Association.
Wednesday marked the 32nd day since 14 Tibetans began a hunger strike in the Indian city of New Delhi July 8 in an effort to put pressure on China, said Tsering.

Yang urged Taiwanese corporations to reconsider their plans to sponsor the Olympics and said Taiwan should not rule out the possibility of boycotting them if China fails to improve its human rights record.

A 16-year-old Buddhist nun was killed by People's Liberation Army soldiers on the Tibet-Nepal border last year and the Chinese government announced that it would control regulations on reincarnation of Tibet's "Living Lamas." China has also increased its military deployment in Lhasa, closed the China-Nepal border and criticized India for allowing the hunger strike to take place, said Khedroob Thondup, a member of the Tibetan government-in-exile.
"Thus shows that China has no intention of improving the human rights situation in Tibet at all, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier asks government functionaries to be alert for new typhoon

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung asked government functionaries at all levels Wednesday to be alert to the movement of a new tropical storm named Wutip that was heading toward Taiwan, as well as the possibility of continuing downpours caused by Tropical Storm Pabuk, which passed over Taiwan the previous night.

The Central Weather Bureau lifted a land warning for Pabuk at 11: 30 a.m. Wednesday but at the same time issued a sea and land warning for Wutip, which is the seventh tropical storm reported in the western Pacific this year.

Chang ordered the National Disaster Prevention and Protection Commission to supervise local authorities' disaster prevention and response measures, including keeping an eye on river level changes, water gate and pumping station safety check-ups, maintaining normal drinking water supplies and watching for landslides and floods.
Chang also ordered local governments to prohibit activities such as mountain climbing, swimming and ocean watching during the typhoon.
He also expressed gratitude to government staff who prepared for Pabuk and minimized the damage risk.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung's household sewer connection rate to exceed 50 percent

TEXT.P: The household sewer connection rate in Kaohsiung has reached 47.7 percent and is expected to surpass the 50 percent mark by the end of this year, city government officials in charge of sewer construction projects said Wednesday.
The officials at the Sewerage Systems Office under the city government's Public Works Bureau acknowledged that it is an expensive job to connect households to the city's sewer systems.
They estimated that it will cost NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) to raise the connection rate by 1 percent, allowing 3,700 households to discharge their wastewater to the sewage systems.
The Sewerage Systems Office will award 11 construction bids in the next few months to have an additional 44,600 households connected to the sewer systems, according to the officials.
They added that by the end of this year, 9,840 more households will be linked to the city's sewer systems, further increasing the connection rate to 50.7 percent.
The officials said the increasing prevalence rate of household sewer connection will help improve the environmental quality of Kaohsiung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, decreasing NT$0.001 to close at NT$32.895.
A total of US$597 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.865 and closed at the day's high of NT$32.915.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Private lab denies it to blame for outbreak
The vaccine company suspected of being at a centre of the foot-and-mouth disease outbreak in Surrey said today that it had found no evidence to suggest that its staff carried the virus out of its laboratory.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Anti-Drug Aid Would Target Mexican Cartels Deal to Include Training, Gear
The Bush administration is close to sealing a major, multiyear aid deal to combat drug cartels in Mexico that would be the biggest U.S. anti-narcotics effort abroad since a seven-year, $5 billion program in Colombia, according to U.S. lawmakers, congressional aides and Mexican authorities. ]By Chiehyu Lin^

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO plans to open international broadcasting channel

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) is working with scholars, experts and media representatives on a plan to open an international broadcasting channel to speak for Taiwan, GIO Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday.
Shieh explained that Taiwan has never had its own international broadcasting channel like Japan's NHK, or the Arabic Al-Jazeera television network headquartered in Doha, Qatar.

If Taiwan had its own broadcasting network, Shieh said, it could at once convey to the international community accurate information about Taiwan-related issues the government thinks would be seen as important by the international community, such as the one concerning Taiwan's move to push for a referendum on its bid for U.N. membership.
In the initial plan, Shieh said, the channel will be launched in a non- government form to broadcast in Mandarin and English about events in Taiwan, Taiwan-relevant events in China and Asian events.
Shieh said the planned facility could be established in eight months to a year at a cost of around NT$2 billion (US$60.62 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ throws tight dragnet for election bribery

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has enhanced its anti-bribery mechanism to better combat vote-buying in the seventh legislative election slated for January 2008, MOJ Department of Prosecutorial Affairs Director-General Chiang Huei-min announced Tuesday.

Chiang said bribery is likely to occur soon, as the election is expected to be even more fiercely contested than usual due to the adoption of asingle-member constituency, two-vote electoral system that will see the number of legislative seats halved.

Chiang said bribery might appear in the form of banquet meetings, free tours and gift giving instead of money giving and receiving. He urged the public to collect evidence of bribery using their cell phone cameras and added that the MOJ will ask people who are possible bribery targets to report any irregularities.

Anti-bribery and anti-violence teams of the Supreme Prosecutors Office and all district prosecutors offices were inaugurated July 3 in order to begin inspections to combat bribery early, Chiang said, adding that police and prosecutors have already started investigating reported cases.

Reward money for information on election bribery will be at least NT$500,000 (US$15,152) and will be taxed separately from income tax, Chiang said, adding that the government gave away more than NT$350 million in reward money for election bribery last year.

Chiang called on all candidates to run fairly and not to violate the law. Bribers will receive prison sentences of at least three years and will have no chance of having their indictments suspended, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPU's second assembly to open Aug. 14 in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) will hold its second assembly in Taipei Aug. 14-15, according to Vice President Annette Lu.

Hailing the event as a major achievement in Taiwan's difficult diplomatic situation, Lu told a news conference held at the Presidential Office Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian will deliver a keynote speech at the opening ceremony for the assembly, which will be attended by nearly 100 foreign guests from 33 nations, including Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Morales Carazo and his predecessor,
Founded in 2005, the DPU, an international body initiated and currently chaired by Lu, aims at promoting "democracy, peace, and prosperity" in the Asian Pacific region and the world.
The DPU will also hold the second Pacific Congressional Caucus (PCC) meeting, with over 40 parliamentary members expected to join the event, Lu said.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Lu went on, will preside over the meeting to discuss how to use digital technology to carry out congressional reforms.

Furthermore, Lu stressed that the DPU will form an alliance involving 15 domestic universities and 26 foreign ones, adding that presidents and vice presidents of these 41 schools will exchange ideas on constructing a platform for young students.

The second assembly discussions will focus on three issues -- the new situation in the Pacific Ocean after the 2008 Beijing Olympics Games, how to formulate green policies in the era of global warming, and how to apply Taiwan's information technology to the digitalization of all DPU member countries.
Calling for wider local media coverage of the event, Lu said the assembly is a important diplomatic event in the midst of Taiwan's difficult situation in the international arena.

Asked how the DPU will be funded after she leaves office next year, Lu responded that part of the union's funding currently comes from the union's 100 members from the business sector, each of which donates NT$200,000 (US$6,060) per year.
The DPU will also organize activities to raise funds every year, with the next year's goal targeting at NT$10 million, Lu said.

Lu added that as vice president, she cannot travel overseas freely, but if she is elected as the chairwoman of the DPU again this year, Lu said that she will organize more activities in other countries. Lu's vice presidential term will end May 20, 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: President endorses 'normal country' resolution: DPP head

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian fully supports promoting a "normal country" resolution and believes that doing so will help boost the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) chances in the coming legislative and presidential elections, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.

Both Chen and Frank Hsieh, the DPP's presidential candidate, endorse crafting a resolution on the party's commitment to "make Taiwan anormal country, "Yu told reporters following the party's weekly Central Standing Committee meeting.

Brushing aside a local media report that Chen and Hsieh had reservations about promoting such a resolution, Yu said that the president fully backed such a move after hearing his report Tuesday about a plan to put forward the statement for party approval at its national congress slated for Sept. 30.
Yu quoted Chen as complaining that the media presented twisted reports claiming that he was reserved about promoting a "normal county" resolution.
According to Yu, the president has expressed support for the draft resolution every time that they have met in recent months since he began drafting the motion early this year.

In a meeting attended last week by ranking officials from the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the DPP, no one, neither Chen nor Hsieh, voiced objections to such a resolution to underscore Taiwan's sovereignty and statehood independent of China, Yu said, pointing out that "many reports in this regard are inaccurate."

The draft resolution must be approved by a nine-member panel in the DPP's Central Standing Committee, the DPP Central Executive Committee and the party's national congress to take effect, Yu said, noting that the draft resolution, including its title, has yet to be fixed as currently there are two different versions.
The draft resolution actually serves as a means to pool wisdom and invite a wide spectrum of valuable opinions to make a future, formal resolution more sound and visionary, he said.

The DPP chairman said Tuesday that he is poised to continue promoting the "normal country" resolution as it is vital to help boost the party's chances in next year's Jan. 12 legislative election and March 22 presidential poll.

According to Yu, the "normal country" resolution will serve as an electoral strategy and a means to solidify a consensus within the DPP to help encourage party candidates to score a victory in the coming two key elections.
DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung said that the nine-member panel is slated to hold a meeting next week to discuss the wording of the draft resolution for the second time.
The party's central also plans to hold seminars in northern, central and southern regions to solicit and consolidate public opinion, according to Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice economics minister suspended from duties: minister

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Hou Ho-shong has been suspended from his duties, Economic Affairs Minister Steve R. L. Chen announced Wednesday after Hou was detained earlier that day over his alleged role in corruption scandals.

Chen said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs has also ordered job reassignments for two other suspects -- Yang Shui-yuan, deputy manager of the Taiwan Water Corp., and Chang Yi-min, head of the Second River Management Office of Water Resource Agency -- both of whom have been released on bail.

Hou's detention came one day after he was questioned by prosecutors in the central county of Nantou over allegations that he had used his influence to favor certain bidders in several public water resources and river management projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fish fries to be smuggled to China seized

TEXT.P: Hsinchu County's Coast Guard brigade intercepted in seas off the outlying island of Penghu a fishing boat attempting to smuggle more than 400,000 king grouper fish fries to China, an officer of the Coast Guard Administration said Wednesday.
The boat, called "Feng Chuan Li, " also tried to smuggle two tons of frozen threadfin perch together with king grouper fish fries, with a total market value of over NT$10 million (US$303,000).
King grouper, or Epinephelus lanceolatus, is a high-end restaurant dish due to its delicate and firm flesh. Taiwan's breeding technology is far ahead of China's.

According to the Coast Guard authorities, China might have been able to develop its artificial cultivation technology at a low cost if the fish fries had been smuggled there, and later sold the mature fish back to Taiwan at a very low price, causing a huge impact on the local market, the officer said.
In order to prevent Taiwan's king grouper breeding know-how from being stolen by China, the prosecutors have confiscated the smuggled fish fries and are investigating their source.

DOC.HEADLINE: Venezuela urged to issue visas to Taiwanese teenage baseballers

TEXT.P: A major Taiwanese baseball association called on the Venezuelan government Wednesday to issue the country's teenage baseball players visas by Aug. 10 to enable them to attend this year's World Youth Championship (WYC) slated to open Aug. 16 in the South American nation.

Richard Lin, executive secretary of the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association (CTBA), said the Chinese Taipei baseball team is training in the central city of Taichung prior to competing in the 13th WYC.
However, foot-dragging by the Venezuelan authorities on visa issuance is making it uncertain whether the team can attend the games, Lin added.

As the two countries have no diplomatic ties, the host country has not accepted visa applications from Taiwan since April, Lin noted, adding that the CTBA commissioned travel agencies to handle visa applications for the players in mid- April and has asked for assistance from officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Department of Central and South American Affairs and staff of Taiwan's representative office in Caracas to help expedite the application procedures.

Meanwhile, the CTBA has also several times requested the International Baseball Federation (IBF), which runs the YUC, and the Venezuelan Association of Baseball, to help with the visa problems, but has not received any answer, Lin said.
Lin voiced hope that the players will get their visas before Aug. 10 so that they can make the trip.

He attributed Venezuela's delay to political factors, adding that it is the first time in nearly 10 years that a Taiwanese baseball team has been unable to go abroad to compete due to political factors.

Lin said the CTBA will demand an apology from the Venezuelan baseball association and will lodge a protest with the IBF to request a formal explanation if the Taiwanese team fails to attend the games.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Government Set for a Crackdown on Illegal Hiring
In a new effort to crack down on illegal immigrants, federal authorities are expected to announce tough rules this week that would require employers to fire workers who use false Social Security numbers.
Officials said the rules would be backed up by stepped-up raids on workplaces across the country that employ illegal immigrants.
Wall Street Journal:How Courting Sheiks Slowed Violence in Iraq
To understand how the U.S. managed to bring relative calm to Iraq's unruly Anbar province, it helps to pay a visit to Sheik Hamid Heiss's private compound.
On a recent morning, a 25-year-old Marine Corps lieutenant from Ohio stacked $97,259 in cash in neat piles on Sheik Heiss's gilded tea table. The money paid for food for the sheik's tribe and for two school renovation projects on which the sheik himself is the lead contractor. Even the marble- floored meeting hall where the cash was handed over reflects recent U.S. largesse: The Marines paid Sheik Heiss and his family $127,175 to build it on his private compound.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP allowed to begin second phase of U.N. referendum campaign

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has passed the first phase of its campaign to hold a referendum on applying for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan, Central Election Commission officials said Wednesday, adding that the DPP can start the second phase now.

The officials made the remarks after the commission confirmed that the signatures collected by the DPP for the first phase of the referendum proposal have exceeded the required minimum level of 82,536.
The second phase requires 825,359 signatures, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ban on ractopamine remains in place: COA officials

TEXT.P: Responding to local hog farmers' protests that the government might lift a ban on ractopamine, a veterinary drug used in hog and cattle farming to boost growth of lean meat, government officials said Wednesday that the government presently has no plans to lift the ban.

Cheng Hui-wen, director-general of the Bureau of Food Sanitation under the Department of Health (DOH), and Cheng Chun-pin, a deputy section chief at the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine of the Council of Agriculture (COA), made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan news conference called by opposition People First Party (DPP) Legislator Tsai Sheng-chia amid ripples arising from the issue.

The use of the drug has become an issue of public concern since two shipments of U.S. pork imports and some of pork farmed in southern Taiwan were recently found to contain ractopamine residue, provoking concerns among local consumers.
Although a minimum use of the veterinary drug is permitted in some countries, such as the United States and Japan, it is banned in Taiwan.

Tsai said he suspected that the DOH intends to lift the ban as a result of pressure from their political superiors, and threatened to lead hog farmers to stage a protest in front of the DOH if it turns a blind eye to a threat posed to their livelihoods by insisting on lifting the ban to facilitate foreign imports.
Cheng Hui-wen denied widespread speculation that superiors have pressed the DOH to lift the ban and promised that the ban would only be eased when complementary measures are put in place.

Cheng Hui-wen said Tuesday that the DOH will not unilaterally decide to lift the ban unless relevant government agencies, including the COA, also agrees to a relaxation of the ban. He admitted that the DOH has commissioned academics to thoroughly investigate the use of the drug, which is lawful in some 22 countries.
According to Cheng Chun-pin, ractopamine remains banned in Taiwan and the government has no plan for the time being to soften its stance on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor reserved about baseball team's trip to Venezuela

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Wednesday the city's youth baseball team should think seriously about whether they still want to compete in the International Baseball Federation (IBAF) World Youth Championships in Barquisimeto, Venezuela, Aug. 17-26, even if the host country grants them visas for the event.
Hu condemned the Venezuela government for procrastinating in issuing visas to the Taichung baseball players.
Noting that Venezuela is an unsafe place, Hu said several other countries, including Australia and the Netherlands, have decided not to compete in the championships there.

The mayor added that for the sake of their own safety, the Taichung baseball players, who obtained the right to represent the Asia-Pacific area in the world championships, should consider carefully whether they want to go to Venezuela even if they are granted visas.
Venezuela is notorious for having the highest murder rate in the world, according to a United Nations study in 2006.

The Taichung baseball team, which is to compete under the name Chinese Taipei, was scheduled to arrive in Venezuela before Aug. 14, but probably due to political considerations, the Venezuelan authorities have withheld their visas.

News media in Taipei reported Wednesday that the top official of Venezuela's national baseball association had admitted to the IBAF recently that "there were some 'political problems,'" denoting that pressure from Beijing had influenced its decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: Schedules for next legislative, presidential elections unveiled

TEXT.P: Candidacy registration for the next legislative election to be held Jan. 12, 2008 will start Nov. 16 and run until Nov. 20, a spokesman for the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Wednesday.

Qualified candidates will draw lots Dec. 19 to determine the sequence in which their names will appear on the ballots, the spokesman said, adding that the official campaign period will run from Jan. 2 through Jan. 11.

The next legislative election will mark the first time that a "single-member constituency, two ballots" electoral system will be implemented as part of the country's legislative reforms. The election will also see the number of legislative seats to be up for grabs halved to 113 from the current 225.

The CEC also decided Wednesday that candidacy registration for the next presidential election scheduled for March 22, 2008 will take place from Jan. 26-Jan. 30, with a lot drawing being held Feb. 25 to determine the order in which candidate's names will appear on the ballots. The official campaign period will run from Feb. 23 through March 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate to start Southeast Asian tour Aug. 11

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh will set out on a Southeast Asian campaign tour this weekend that will take him to Singapore and other countries in the region, Hsieh's campaign aides said Wednesday.
The itinerary of Hsieh's Southeast Asian tour will be unveiled Thursday, said Chao Tien-lin, a spokesman for Hsieh's campaign office.

In addition to meeting with Taiwanese expatriates in major Southeast Asian countries to court their support for his presidential bid, Chao said Hsieh will also take advantage of the trip to meet with as many officials of host countries as possible to boost mutual understanding and convey Taiwan people's common aspirations.

Noting that Taiwan, as an Asia-Pacific country, must play a peacemaker's role in the international arena, Chao said Hsieh will make use of the trip to improve communications with neighboring Asian countries.

During his Aug. 11-13 visit to Singapore, Hsieh is expected to meet with Singaporean officials. Chao refrained from revealing the ranks of Singaporean officials with whom Hsieh will meet, saying instead that Hsieh will be able to meet with everyone he should.

According to Hsieh's other campaign aides, Hsieh will leave Singapore Aug. 13 to continue his Southeast Asian tour. The aides' remarks were tantamount to a denial of a media report that Hsieh will meet with former Premier Su Tseng-chang in Singapore Aug. 14.
Su is believed to be some DPP politicians' favorite choice to serve as Hsieh's running mate. Nevertheless, Hsieh reportedly would like to pick former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan as his running mate.
Hsieh is scheduled to announce his running mate by Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairman set to depart for Philippines visit Thursday

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun is set to depart for Manila Thursday for a brief visit aimed to drumming up support for the party's candidates for two upcoming critical elections, party officials said Wednesday.

During his three-day visit, Yu will meet with executives of the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in the Philippines and deliver a speech at an evening party to be organized by major Taiwanese expatriate associations in that country, DPP officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug.9, 2007

TEXT.P: 2. Event: News conference on a fashion show featuring creations by Taiwanese designers as part of 32nd World Congress of Master Tailors activities Date and Time: 02:00 p.m., Thursday, Aug. 9, 2007 Place: Taipei International Convention Center, No. 1, Xinyi Road, Sec. 5, Taipei City Press Contact: Tel.:2723-2589 Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

The CEC also decided Wednesday that candidacy registration for the next presidential election scheduled for March 22, 2008 will take place from Jan. 26-Jan. 30, with a lot drawing being held Feb. 25 to determine the order in which candidate's names will appear on the ballots. The official campaign period will run from Feb. 23 through March 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate to start Southeast Asian tour Aug. 11

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh will set out on a Southeast Asian campaign tour this weekend that will take him to Singapore and other countries in the region, Hsieh's campaign aides said Wednesday.
The itinerary of Hsieh's Southeast Asian tour will be unveiled Thursday, said Chao Tien-lin, a spokesman for Hsieh's campaign office.

In addition to meeting with Taiwanese expatriates in major Southeast Asian countries to court their support for his presidential bid, Chao said Hsieh will also take advantage of the trip to meet with as many officials of host countries as possible to boost mutual understanding and convey Taiwan people's common aspirations.

Noting that Taiwan, as an Asia-Pacific country, must play a peacemaker's role in the international arena, Chao said Hsieh will make use of the trip to improve communications with neighboring Asian countries.

During his Aug. 11-13 visit to Singapore, Hsieh is expected to meet with Singaporean officials. Chao refrained from revealing the ranks of Singaporean officials with whom Hsieh will meet, saying instead that Hsieh will be able to meet with everyone he should.

According to Hsieh's other campaign aides, Hsieh will leave Singapore Aug. 13 to continue his Southeast Asian tour. The aides' remarks were tantamount to a denial of a media report that Hsieh will meet with former Premier Su Tseng-chang in Singapore Aug. 14.
Su is believed to be some DPP politicians' favorite choice to serve as Hsieh's running mate. Nevertheless, Hsieh reportedly would like to pick former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan as his running mate.
Hsieh is scheduled to announce his running mate by Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 9, or the 27th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1794: General Napoleon Bonaparte is arrested in France on suspicions of Robespierrism.
1814: Under the terms of the Treaty of Fort Jackson signed between the U.S. government and the native Creek tribe, the Creeks lose 9.3 million hectares of land -- over half of Alabama and part of southern Georgia -- to the United States.
1842: The United States signs the Webster-Ashburton Treaty with Britain, establishing the boundary between the U.S. and Canada from Maine to the Great Lakes.
1867: John Harrison Surratt is arrested for being an alleged conspirator in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln.
1902: Edward VII, 64, is crowned King of Great Britain and Ireland after a six- week delay due to an emergency appendectomy.
1903: Giuseppe Sarto becomes Pope Pius X following the death of Pope Leo XIII.
1919: India concludes a secret pact with Britain, recognizing Britain as India's protector after Britain promised India a major role in its own government.
1928: Italian divers find precious diamonds in the wreckage of "Elizabethville," a Belgian ship sunk during World War I.
1937: Japanese troops clash with Chinese forces at Hungchiao airport in Shanghai.
1938: Rod Laver, Australian tennis star, is born. He won the singles title at Wimbledon four times.
1942: Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress, is arrested in Britain for his "Quit India" campaign, which demands that the British should withdraw from India.
1945: Soviet troops enter Manchuria after the Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1946: Henry Pu Yi, who was enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists on Mar. 1, 1934, arrives in Tokyo to testify before an international court against Japanese war crimes committed during the invasion of China.
1954: The Republic of China Navy sinks 12 Communist Chinese ships at Tungshan seaport, Dongshan Island, near Fukien province.
1965: Singapore is separated from Malaysia and becomes an independent state within the Commonwealth of Nations.
1973: Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves for Washington to attend a WACL Executive Committee meeting.
1974: Gerald R. Ford is sworn in as the 38th president of the United States after the resignation of Richard Nixon.
1979: Councilors in the English seaside town of Brighton cause a furor by agreeing to allow naturalists to bare all on "Cliff Beach," one of the less popular beaches in the district.
1990: Communist China's first airship, with a length of 40 meters, makes its maiden flight over Hupei province.
1994: The U.S. government announces trade sanctions against the ROC under the Pelly Amendment, placing a ban on imports of Taiwan wildlife products effective from August 19, 1994.
1999: The China External Trade Development Council signs a memorandum of understanding on technological cooperation with the Agency for International Development of Technology and Trade under the Trade and Industry Ministry of France.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui says the main reason he voiced the "special state- to-state relations" statement regarding cross-Taiwan Strait ties the previous month was to elucidate the fact that the Republic of China exists in the world.
2000: The Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association is established to promote Taiwan's trade and cooperation with the international community.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to gain confidence for one's authority. If a man is not trusted by one's friends, he will not gain the confidence for his authority."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
U.S. Harpoon sales to beef up Taiwan's deterrence force: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 8 (CNA) 08/09/07 14:29:20 (By Chiehyu Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Continued sales of U.S. Harpoon missiles will help beef up Taiwan's deterrence force, a Republic of China official stationed in Washington, D.C. said Wednesday.

The official made the remarks after the Defense Security and Cooperation Agency (DSCA) under the U.S. Department of Defense said earlier the same day that it has notified the Congress of the possible sale of 60 Harpoon Block II anti-ship cruise missiles to Taiwan.
According to the official, the sale is a subsequent deal following Taiwan's procurement of F-16 jet fighters in the 1990s.

The proposed deal, valued at an estimated US$125 million, will include 60 ABM- 84L missiles, 30 lugs for air-launched missiles and 50 kits to upgrade the AGM- 84G version of the missile to the AGM-84L, the DSCA said in a press release.
The press statement further said the proposed sale will help improve the security of the recipient and assist in maintaining political stability, military balance and economic security in the region.
The Harpoon can be launched from fighter aircraft, surface ships or submarines to attack targets on land as well as at sea.

"The 500-pound blast warhead delivers lethal firepower against a wide variety of land-based targets, including coastal defense sites, surface-to-air missile sites, exposed aircraft, port industrial facilities, ships in port," a Boeing fact sheet said.
The Pentagon statement noted that Taiwan has bought both air- and surface- launched Harpoon missiles before.
It said the sale was in keeping with the Taiwan Relations Act, which commits the United States to providing Taiwan with "arms of a defensive character."

The Japan Times: Koreans announce landmark summit
North and South Korea announced their first simmit in seven years Wednesday, but critics said it was mostly domestic politicking and doubted it would help the push to make Pyongyang abandon nuclear arms.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Vietnam Prime Minister here today
Vietnam Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung arrives today for a two-day official visit in Manila, which includes meetings with President Arroyo and congressional leaders. Dung, accompanied by his wife Madame Tran Thanh Kiem and several government officials, will arrive at 3 p.m. today at terminal 1 of the Ninoy Aquino International Airport and proceed immediately to Malacanang.
The Philippine Daily InquirerG How cheating is done?
MANILA, Philippines -- Looking well-rested, Lintang Bedol began to enjoy a new, albeit temporary, lease on liberty Wednesday afternoon after posting bail of P15,000 even as he told the Philippine Daily Inquirer he was willing to talk about how cheating is done in elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Valentino Rossi being investigated over alleged tax evasion.
Italian motorcycling hero Valentino Rossi was being investigated by the tax office over possible undeclared earnings of 60 million euros for the period between the year 2000 and 2004. The investigation was linked to the seven-time world champion's decision to take up the British residency in the year 2000, tax officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No casino opening until consensus reached: GIO

TEXT.P: Before a high degree consensus is reached among the public, the administration will not allow the establishment of legal casinos anywhere in the country, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Thursday.

Discounting a news report that the government is planning to grant three licenses for casinos to be built in the offshore county of Penghu and the southern counties of Chiayi and Pingtung, Shieh said the government's plans for opening casinos are still on the drawing board and are not expected to be implemented anytime soon.

According to a United Daily News report that same day, the government's plans to establish casinos around the country will become clearer in October at the earliest, when the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development will have completed a draft bill governing the establishment and operations of casinos.
According to the report, the government will initially issue licenses to enable three casinos to be established on Penghu island and in Chiayi and Pingtung counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 83.14 points to close at 9,182.6.
The bourse opened at 9,213.47 and fluctuated between 9,219.02 and 9,140.47 during trading. A total of 5.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$178.43 billion (US$5.43 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 1.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent, construction issues at 0.5 percent, and textile stocks at 0.2 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 994 to 587, with 202 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: July stock transaction taxes hit new high: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock transaction taxes for July set a record of NT$19.1 billion (US$578 million) , surpassing the previous record of NT$19 billion for February 1990, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Thursday.

Quoting statistics released by the MOF, Lee Li-hsue, director-general of the MOF's Department of Statistics, said July's figure showed an increase of NT$13.4 billion over the same month of last year, up 232 percent. Lee attributed the result to foreign investment inflow and a brisk stock market.

Given the lower present transaction tax rate of 0.3 percent compared to the 0.6 percent of February 1990, and the higher amount of transaction taxes, July 's stock market was extremely brisk, Lee said.
The total transaction value for 22 trading days in July hit NT$4.95 trillion, with average daily transaction value reaching NT$22.5 billion, both of which are record figures.
The over-the-counter transaction value for July topped NT$1.49 trillion, with average daily transaction value amounting to NT$67.75 billion.
Total stock transaction tax revenues for the first seven months hit NT$73.03 billion, an increase of NT$19.6 billion or up 36.7 percent from the year-earlier level, Lee said.

The expected stock transaction tax revenue for the whole year is projected at NT$85.12 billion and the achievement rate has already reached 85.8 percent from January to July, Lee said, adding that the goal is likely to be achieved by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 58 points to close at 9,136, with 53,202 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September rose 74 points to finish at 9,124, with 3,456 contracts traded, while December futures gained 75 points to close at 9,155, with 62 contract transactions. March futures moved up 56 points to close at 9,139, with 14 contracts traded, while March futures increased 56 points to finish at 9,139, with 14 contract transactions. June futures gained 60 points to close at 9,137, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 9,078 for August, 9,050 for September, 9,080 for December, 9,083 for March and 9,077 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

August TE futures moved up 4.5 points to close at 387, with 3,685 contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 5.4 points to finish at 387, with 215 contract transactions. December TE futures increased 6.05 points to close at 385.65, with seven contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures dropped 2.2 points to close at 1,045, with 3,234 contracts traded, while September TF futures moved down 1.4 points to finish at 1,045.6, with 482 contract transactions. December TF futures lost 6.4 points to close at 1,046.8, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.
