DOC.HEADLINE: Blind athletes shine at IBSA World Championships
DOC.DATELINE: Sao Paulo, Brazil, Aug. 8 (CNA) 08/09/07 17:06:55 (By Tan Ya-lin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese athletes clinched one gold medal, one silver and two bronzes at the just-concluded Third International Blind Sports Federation (IBSA) World Championships and Games in Sao Paulo, Brazil.
The games, which are exclusively for visually impaired athletes, are organized every four years by the IBSA. The last IBSA World Games took place in Quebec, Canada in 2003.
Ten Taiwanese athletes joined nearly 1,600 other visually impaired counterparts from 57 countries to compete in the July 28-Aug. 6 competition in the Brazilian capital.

Track and field athlete Chiang Chi-chung scored the best among the local athletes, winning gold in the javelin event, silver in the discus and bronze in the shot put, while Hu Hsin-chung took bronze in 200-meter freestlye swimming.

Chiang also took gold in the javelin at the Sydney Paralympics in 2000 and a javelin silver in the 2nd IBSA event, while Hu, a winner of the China Youth Corps' outstanding youth award, has also won medals in international swimming competitions over the past few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislator insists Yilan children's folkgame festival continues

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) threatened Thursday to attempt to recall Yilan County Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua if he insists on replacing the popular children's folkgame festival with a new activity.

Chen Chin-de from the northeastern county said the annual International Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival, one of the most popular summer tourist attractions in Yilan since it started in 1996, should continue. He further insisted that there be no change in the designation of the event.

Chen made the statement after Lu announced a day earlier that his office will unveil a plan for new summer activities for next year at the end of September, which he guaranteed will not be smaller than the existing festival.
Lu also said the phrase "children's folkgames" has restricted the event's development and that there will be no new planned activities under that banner.

In response, Chen claimed that the "children's folkgame festival" is widely regarded as a "city brandname" that the county is proud of. The event should not be closed for good "just because the magistrate is not willing to organize such a big festival," Chen said.

According to Chen, since Lu announced an end to the annual summer festival, there have been increasing protests against the move from the industrial and cultural sectors, as well as on the Internet. Many Internet users have even joined in an online campaign to depose Lu, he claimed.

According to Chen, 127 art and music troupes from 67 countries around the world have performed in the festival since its 1996 inception. So far, it has been visited by over 5 million people and has generated countless business benefits.
The colorful and festive event is of profound significance in the fields of city diplomacy, economic benefit and cultural arts, Chen claimed.
Lu explained, however, that heavy losses incurred by the annual festival over the past two years have made it necessary to bring down the curtain on the event for good.
Lu said the two-month festival has created a financial burden of around NT$50 million for the county government during each of the last two years, despite efforts to curb costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5.7 magnitude earthquake rocks southeastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A strong earthquake registering 5.7 on the Richter Scale shook southeastern Taiwan Thursday but there were no immediate reports of injuries.
According to the Central Weather Bureau's Seismology Center, the quake occurred at 8:55 a.m. and lasted about five seconds.

The quake's epicenter was located near Peinan township in Taitung County at a depth of five kilometers. It was caused by energy released from a collision between the Euro-Asia Plate and the Philippine Sea Plate, CWB seismologists said.
The temblor could be felt at intensities ranging from 4 to 1 in cities in eastern, southern and central Taiwan.
On April 1 last year, a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck Taitung County, injuring 37 people. That quake was also centered near Peinan, at a depth of 10 kilometers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan excels in information technology rating

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed pleasure Thursday that Taiwan has excelled in global information technology ratings recently, including an e-government survey conducted by Brown University in the United States.

In his latest electronic letter, Chen praised Taiwanese students' good performance in a Web competition titled "Doors to Diplomacy" sponsored by the U.S. Department of State and the International Schools CyberFair.
In addition, Chen added, Taiwan ranked second in an e-government survey conducted by Brown University in 2006. Taiwan led the list in both 2004 and 2005.

Among other achievements, Taiwan's preparedness in becoming an information society ranked third in a 2005 survey conducted by the World Economic Forum (WEF), and its rating ranked seventh last year, behind only Singapore in Asia, Chen said.

He noted that an official document would take almost two months to "travel" from the central government to local government agencies 10 years ago. However, the process has been significantly streamlined in the Internet era, he said.
Under the country's e-government campaign, the public can save time by paying taxes via computer and can look at tourist spots via government webcams.
The government will also present an "e-housekeeper" program in which citizens can receive information from government agencies, including various kinds of tax-paying information.

The government is now working on "single-window" Web services through which the government can pass information to entrepreneurs more efficiently, while private enterprises can bid on government purchase projects or pay taxes, Chen added.

In the Internet era, information technology represents the competitiveness of a country and integrating information for the public has become a responsibility that the government cannot shirk, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.01 to close at NT$32.885.
A total of US$708 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.865 and fluctuated between NT$32.815 and NT$32.915.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stem cells can transform into heart cells: research

TEXT.P: Cardiologists from Taiwan and the United States have proved that mammalian myocardia can be regenerated from stem cells or precursor cells, breaking a longstanding hypothesis denying the possibility of such a cardiomyocyte renewal, one of the researchers at Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) said Thursday.

However, the regeneration process is most perceivable only after heart injuries such as myocardial infarction or pressure overload, and is much less helpful in replenishing attrition by natural aging, Patrick C.H. Hsieh of NCKU's Institute of Clinical Medicine explained.

The research report -- authored by Hsieh and members of Harvard Medical School and Cincinnati Children's Hospital -- has been published online by the U.S. science journal Nature Medicine, which will also publish the results in print in its next issue.

According to the paper, researchers first raised double- transgenic mice whose cardiomyocytes carried green fluorescent proteins. Following that, they created two scenarios for the subjects -- some of them stayed in the normal aging process for one year, while the others were given deliberate heart injuries.

In the first group, the percentage of green-tainted cardiomyocytes remained unchanged after the period, indicating that stem or precursor cells did not replace uninjured cardiomyocytes at a significant rate. For the second group, however, the ratio of marked cells decreased by 6.2 percent to 15.3 percent after injury, implying that stem or precursor cells had taken those positions.
Even though the experiments prove that myocardia can be regenerated in mammals, Hsieh estimated that it would take at least five to 10 years to adapt such results to human testing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier puts paid to civil servants' hopes for pay rise

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has approved an Executive Yuan proposal not to raise civil servants' pay in the next year, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday.

In response to journalists' questions while presiding over the opening of the Taiwan Culinary Exhibition in Taipei, Chang confirmed reports earlier that day that a pay rise for the country's 1 million- odd civil servants, teachers and military personnel in the next year is out of the question.
Chang said those sectors had raises in 2001 and 2005 with a combined hike of 6 percent, which is enough to counter the 5.6 percent inflation registered in the last six years.

Noting that a 3 percent raise would increase the government's annual outlay by NT$20 billion (US$607.81 million), the premier said it will further strain the government's financial resources, as his administration is lowering taxes and at the same time increasing social welfare spending.
Furthermore, the premier said, a pay raise for civil servants at this time could put pressure on private employers to follow suit by raising salaries for their employees, stoking inflation.
The United Daily News said that day that Chang's administration has to curb inflation in the run-up to the legislative and presidential elections early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recipient of Chinese stem cells recovering well

TEXT.P: A teenage Taiwanese girl who received a transplant of peripheral blood stem cells donated by a donor from China last month is doing well after passing two critical weeks at the Taipei Veterans General Hospital, medical sources said Thursday.

The girl has not rejected the transplant, there is no inflammation and the cancer cells that were in her blood before the transplant are all gone, said Chiu Tsung-chieh, a doctor at Taipei Veteran General Hospital's Blood and Tumor Department.

Chiu noted that although the peripheral blood stem cell transplant was successful and that the patient can be discharged Aug. 11, they will need to wait for some three months to see whether a severe rejection will occur.
In addition to a possible severe rejection, recipients of peripheral blood stem cell transplants need to be observed for one to two years to see whether chronic rejection develops, Chiu added.

The 15-year-old Taipei girl, who suffers from inherited anemia, was one of two Taiwanese recipients of peripheral blood stem cells donated by two Chinese women last month, thanks to the efforts of the Dao Pei Hospital in Beijing and Taiwan's Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Center.
The other recipient, who received a similar transplant at Hualien Tzu Chi Hospital in eastern Taiwan, was also reportedly doing fine after the operation.
It marked the first case in which two Chinese citizens had donated peripheral blood stem cells for two Taiwanese recipients.
Several Taiwanese citizens have donated bone marrow to Chinese recipients over the past several years under arrangements made by the Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Center.

The Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Center -- the largest of its kind in Asia -- has built up a databank of nearly 300,000 bone marrow samples since its inception in 1993 and has helped more than 300 victims of blood diseases to find donors.
The center now has access to data on more than 10 million donors worldwide after linking up with two bone marrow data banks in the United States and Germany late last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu's human history could trace back to late Tang Dynasty
DOC.DATELINE: Matsu, Aug. 9 (CNA) 08/09/07 19:04:38 (By Yu Hao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Pottery shards unearthed recently from a prehistoric archaeological site in a village in southern Matsu prove that history involving human activity in the Taiwan-held island could date back to the late Tang Dynasty, Matsu officials in charge of cultural affairs said Thursday.

An archaeological team headed by Professor Chen Chung-yu of Academia Sinica's Institute of History and Philology and sponsored by the Matsu County Bureau of Cultural Affairs embarked on an archaeological mission throughout the five Matsu islets June 12 and decided to begin excavations in Fucheng village on Tungchu islet June 22.

In a pile of discarded seashells that the team members excavated in the village, they discovered tons of seashells, fish bones and pottery shards. Of these items, they discovered a pottery eaves tile that was a product of the Southern Sung period, between 420-479 A.D., according to the Matsu officials.

Using carbon dating, the team members found that some of the pottery shards unearthed from the Fucheng site could be shards of pots or bowls used by people living in the Matsu area some 1,270 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public in favor of floating oil pricing system: MOEA

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen said Thursday that the public supports the government's floating oil pricing mechanism, even though it has stirred up debate in society due to rising international oil prices.
Chen made the remarks while answering questions during a public hearing called by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker Wang Tu-fa at the Legislative Yuan.

Chen said that the conclusion was reached after his ministry thoroughly assessed public opinion regarding the issue and added that most of the people surveyed still back the floating oil pricing system despite the fact that further adjustments may be needed to perfect it.

Ascribing the increases in domestic consumer product prices to soaring international crude oil prices and a "global bad crop" resulting from drastic climate changes, he denied public misconceptions that the recent wave of product price hikes was driven by the floating oil pricing system, implemented early this year.

Speaking on the same occasion, state-run CPC Corp. Taiwan Chairman Pan Wen-yen contended that the floating oil pricing system more accurately reflects the company's procurement costs. Taiwan relies completely on imported oil to meet local energy demand.
The company's expenditures for the whole of last year hit NT$800 billion (US$24.2 billion), NT$500 billion of which was spent on crude oil procurement, Pan reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial proof for foreign spouse to get ID card necessary: minister

TEXT.P: Financial proof for foreign spouses who intend to apply for Taiwanese citizenship is indispensable, as it ensures their financial ability, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said Thursday.

Lee made the remarks in response to a protest by the Coalition Against Financial Requirement for Immigrants that demanded the Executive Yuan lift regulations requiring foreign spouses to provide proof of finances in order to get Taiwanese identification card, as stipulated in both the Nationality Act and Immigration Law.

Other requirements include passing a medical check-up, staying in Taiwan for a certain period of time, renouncing original nationality and passing a Chinese proficiency exam, while the financial proof is considered the most difficult as it requires the spouses family to submit financial proof of assets of about NT$400,000 (US$12,120).

The coalition comprises various civic groups, including the Labor Rights Association and the Taiwan Association for Human Rights. It claims that the regulations constitute class discrimination as it is an almost unreachable standard for such families, in which the foreign spouses come mainly from Southeast Asian countries and China.
Lee expressed hope that the public will not "misunderstand" the purpose of the regulation and said that the financial proof will ensure a family's financial stability.

Lee added that financial proof of assets is not the only choice as the families can also submit proof that they have a household income that is double the minimum wage set forth in the Labor Standards Law.
He went on that a family without a household income of two minimum wages will confront financial difficulties and will burden the society's social welfare system.
Countries like Vietnam and South Korea also have similar regulations on providing financial proof, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairman leaves for the Philippines on election campaign

TEXT.P: The chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) flew to the Philippines Thursday for a visit aimed at seeking the support of overseas Taiwanese voters in the upcoming presidential and legislative elections.
Ahead of his departure, Yu Shyi-kun said he will also inspect the operations of DPP branch offices in that country during the trip and visit Philippine politicians.

Asked about disputes between the DPP and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , over the nomination of candidates to run in the 2008 legislative election slated for Jan. 12, Yu said he will do his utmost to cooperate with the TSU in an effort to push for a "pan-green camp" electoral victory.
The "pan-greens" referring to DPP and TSU members, must unite to win in the upcoming battle, Yu underlined.

On the Yilan county government's recent decision to close for good the annual International Children's Folklore and Game Festival, Yu, who created the festival in 1996 while serving as magistrate of the northeastern county, said he feels regret and very sorry over the end of the event to which he gave birth.

Yu described the annual event as a successful diplomatic strategy since it not only attracted tourists and generated great economic benefits at home, but also as a hit with the international community given its distinct cultural features.
Calling on the local government to preserve the annual activity, Yu said the event is not simply an entertaining activity, but also an activity with educational and cultural functions.

The festival, organized by the Yilan county government's Cultural Bureau every summer at the Dungshan River Park, featured performances by many foreign dance and music troupes. Since it started in 1996, it attracted more than 120 performing groups from 67 countries, and visited by over 5 million people, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Body of drowned Chinese tourist recovered in harbor

TEXT.P: The body of a drowned Chinese tourist who fell into the sea Wednesday off the Yehliu Geological Park in northern Taiwan was recovered in an adjacent fishing harbor Thursday.
Liao Xin, a 28-year-old art teacher, was trying to take a photo on the edge of a rock in the scenic park shortly after noon Wednesday when a big wave knocked him into the sea.
Liao was with a 40-member group from Chongqing No. 18 Middle School in Sichuan province that arrived in Taiwan Aug. 6 for a sightseeing tour.

A search team consisting of firemen from Taipei County and staff of the Coast Guard Administration combed the sea all afternoon to no avail. Their search operations were made extremely difficult by strong winds and big waves brought by Tropical Storm Wutip.

Residents of Wanli township spotted Liao's body Thursday morning in Tung-Ao fishing harbor, located several hundred meters to the south of the Yehliu Geological Park. Local police confirmed his identity through papers he was carrying.

The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , Taiwan's semi-official organization for handling exchanges with China, indicated that it has notified Liao's parents about their son's death and will help them get visas to enter Taiwan.
The principal of Chonqing No. 18 Middle School and a senior school official will stay in Taiwan to help Liao's parents handle the aftermath of his death, according to SEF officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP members call for early settlement of Hsieh-Yeh ticket

TEXT.P: Although ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh has repeatedly said that he will announce his running mate by Aug. 15, two DPP members called Thursday for an early formation of a ticket between Hsieh and former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan.

Lee Wen-chung, a well-known lawmaker who quit the DPP last year due to dissatisfaction with a series of corruption scandals linked to President Chen Shui-bian's family, said that a Hsieh-Yeh ticket should be put in place as quickly as possible to solidify party unity in preparation for next year's March 22 presidential election.

Speaking to reporters at the Legislative Yuan, Lee said it is urgent that the Hsieh-Yeh ticket be announced now that the other possible running mate, former Premier Su Tseng-chang, has consistently showed no willingness to pair up with Hsieh.
Continued rehashing of the issue would only serve to further embarrass Su and Yeh and erode Hsieh's chances in the coming presidential poll, Lee suggested.

DPP lawmaker Kao Chien-chih, a protege of Hsieh, also voiced his full backing for a Hsieh-Yeh ticket. Whoever Hsieh's running mate ends up being, all party members should do their utmost in the campaign, Kao said.
Hsieh's aides said that he is scheduled to make public his choice of running mate on the evening of Aug. 15 after he returns from a trip to Singapore and Indonesia.

Meanwhile, Yeh, who is currently visiting Singapore, criticized the main opposition Kuomintang's presidential ticket formed by former party Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and former Premier Vincent Siew during an interview Tuesday with the Singaporean daily Lianhe Zaobao.

According to Yeh, the national economic development blueprint put forward by the Ma-Siew ticket will not benefit the country, which is clear because the "cross- Taiwan Strait common market" promoted by Siew lacks a "Taiwan-centric" notion.

It is vital that anyone seeking to become the nation's leader, including Ma and Siew, realize that their top priority after coming to power is to fully protect Taiwan's independent sovereignty, she said.
Without full statehood, Taiwan would sink to the same lowly status of Hong Kong, which Yeh argued is not improved merely because the former British colony enjoys brisk economic expansion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan urged to support Taiwan's U.N. bid
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 8 (CNA) 08/09/07 20:24:29 (By Mike Chang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top representative to Japan called on the Japanese government Wednesday to recognize Taiwan's statehood and to throw its support behind the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.
Ko Se-kai, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, made the call during an address in Tokyo on Taiwan's U.N. bid to nearly 200 Taiwanese expatriates.
Hsu said the Taiwan government followed mainstream public opinion and launched this year's U.N. bid under the name of Taiwan instead of the country's national title -- the Republic of China.
According to recent opinion polls, Hsu went on, 77 percent of Taiwan people favor the use of the name Taiwan in the country's U.N. membership application.

Hsu said that U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon overstepped his authority and "overinterpreted" U.N. Resolution 2758 in his recent rejection of President Chen Shui-bian's two letters expressing Taiwan's intention to apply for membership of the world body.

Hsu said the resolution only stipulates that the People's Republic of China (PRC) is the only legitimate representative government of China but does not say that the PRC represents the people of Taiwan in the United Nations.
Quoting the results of a poll conducted by Japanese media two years ago, Hsu noted that more than 80 percent of the Japanese public backed Taiwan's U.N. membership.

Hsu slammed the spokesman of Japan's Foreign Ministry, who recently said Japan does not recognize Taiwan as a country and opposes Taiwan's bid to join the U.N., saying that such remarks are in conflict with Japanese public opinion.

Describing Taiwan's latest U.N. application as a "practical move, " Hsu urged the Japanese government to take into account its national interests and recognize Taiwan as a country, as well as to support Taiwan's U.N. membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC planning compulsory helmet wearing for cyclists

TEXT.P: In light of rising traffic fatalities involving bicycles, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is planning to amend a road law to stipulate that cyclists must wear safety helmets while riding or face fines.

In a MOTC meeting presided over by Minister Tsai Duei, officials from the MOTC Road Safety Supervisory Committee said that fatalities resulting from traffic accidents involving bicycles and cyclists have been high in recent years, and of the people killed in these accidents, most have died from head injuries.
This fact has prompted researchers from the MOTC Institute of Transportation to propose an amendment to the road safety law to make safety helmets compulsory while cycling, the officials said.

In addition, the amendment will also require that left turns be conducted in two steps by cyclists on the road, that cyclists ride within one meter of the side of the road, and that bicycle makers be required to install lights and reflecting panels on new bicycles, the officials noted.

MOTC officials quoted tallies compiled by the National Police Administration as indicating that between 2003-2006, traffic accidents involving bicycles resulted in 664 deaths and 7,131 injuries. Of the 664 deceased, 483 or 72 percent, died after being hit by a vehicle and falling.
In 2006 alone, 183 cyclists died in traffic accidents, with 118 of the deceased sustaining head injuries, the officials added.

Researchers from the MOTC Institute of Transportation are expected to come up with a draft amendment to the current road safety law by the end of this year to pave the way for implementation of stricter regulations for cyclists riding the roads.
Meanwhile, MOTC officials said, beginning Sept. 1, cyclists in Taipei City who run a red light or ride in the fast lanes reserved for automobiles will be issued tickets.

DOC.HEADLINE: President should be allowed U.S. transit: Ex-U.S. official

TEXT.P: The Republic of China president should be allowed to make transit stops in the United States and the transit issue should not be linked to other issues, a former U.S. government official said in Taipei Thursday.

"Taiwan is a friendly government and a democracy, its leadership should be received with respect and dignity. My personal opinion would be that Taiwan's president should be allowed to be in the U.S. for transit and should be received with all the respect he is due, " said Randall Schriver, a former deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs.
However, Schriver admitted that there is a tendency in Washington, D.C. to use the transit issue as leverage in dealing with Taiwan-U.S. relations, adding that "it's not healthy. But it does exist."

Schriver described Taiwan-U.S. relations has more of a "troubleshooting" relationship and encouraged the U.S. government to show more support for Taiwan's democracy even though both sides have disagreed with each other on some issues.

Acknowledging that there is frustration in Taiwan over the U.S. attitude and responses to Taiwan's U.N. referendum plan and transit issues, among others, Schriver said the U.S. should not be only critical of Taiwan.

However, as a former U.S. official, Schriver said he can understand the difficulties in managing trilateral relations among the United States, China and Taiwan, as it requires "great attention and complexity of communication." Most of the attention of senior U.S. officials has been shifted to the Middle East and the war of terror in recent years, he pointed out.

To some extent, the worst case scenario of Taiwan-U.S. relations will be that either inattention or lack of interest among U.S. officials on the Taiwan issue will make the U.S. unable or unwilling to support democracy in Taiwan, he said.

In terms of the U.N. referendum, Schriver said the U.S. government opposes the content of the referendum rather than the referendum itself. The basic thinking of the U.S. is that the referendum is unnecessary because "in the U.S., a topic that is so popular and has the support of over 70 percent of the people does not go to referendum."
One of the keys, Schriver pointed out, will be how Taiwan's newly elected president will deal with the result of the referendum, since it will be held on the same day as the presidential election.

Schriver works for Armitage International, a leading bipartisan study group that plans to publish a report on Taiwan-U.S. relations in early 2008 to provide references for the next U.S. administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pigs from Changhua farm tested positive for ractopamine

TEXT.P: A test for the veterinary drug ractopamine in the blood serum and hair of pigs from a ranch in Changhua County came back positive Thursday, animal health officials in the central county said.

This second round of tests on pigs from the farm, owned by Wu Tzai-wang in Changhua County, followed confirmation by health officials last month that some pork produced at Wu's farm and sold in traditional markets around the country was found to contain ractopamine.

Kuo Chou-che, director of the Changhua county government's Animal Disease Control Center, said Wu was prohibited from selling any of his more than 200 pigs in his ranch until next tests results came back negative.
Kuo said some local farmers have taken to using ractopamine after being convinced by animal feed additive traders that the ractopamine can boost growth of lean meat in pigs.
Currently, ractopamine is a legal additive in animal feed in more than 20 countries, but is banned in Taiwan.

The issue caused a panic among consumers, with Department of Health (DOH) officials having to assure the public that the government ban on the use of ractopamine in pigs remains in place, and imports of pork containing residue of the drug are still prohibited.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heavy rain warning issued for all areas of Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) lifted the sea and land warnings for Tropical Storm Wutip Thursday, but issued a heavy rain warning for all areas of Taiwan for the next four days.
The CWB lifted the sea and land warnings for Wutip at 11:30 a.m., as the loosely-structured storm was downgraded to a low pressure system.

However, meteorologists said that although Wutip was not much of a storm in terms of wind strength, the southwest air current drawn into the low pressure system, covering 2,000 km, could bring heavy or torrential rains to all parts of Taiwan from now until Aug. 13.

People in southern, southeastern and central Taiwan are warned to be prepared for excessively heavy rains Friday, and those living in mountainous areas should guard against flash floods, falling rocks, landslides and mudflows.

According to weather experts, Wutip, which comes on the heels of Tropical Storm Pabuk, continues to move northwest despite its structure having broken up while passing over Taiwan's Central Mountain Range.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chair not guilty in '228 Incident culprit' slander case: court

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court ruled Thursday that ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun is not guilty of defamation for portraying the late president Chiang Kai-shek as the prime culprit behind the 228 Incident of 1947, an uprising against the then-corrupt Kuomintang (KMT) government.
While describing Yu's remark as a bit "sensational, " the court ruling said Yu was within his rights to make the comment at a public event.
The ruling came months after KMT Legislator John Chiang, a grandson of the late president, brought a criminal defamation lawsuit against Yu.
The ruling indicated that Yu neither fabricated his accusation, nor slandered others with ill-intent.
Yu based his comment on a research report on responsibility for the 228 Incident, compiled by Academia Historica President Chang Yen-hsien and other academics, the ruling said.

According to the ruling, Yu also defended himself by citing recent remarks made by Demos Chiang, a 31-year-old great-grandson of Chiang during an interview with a local magazine, who stated: "My family once suppressed the people of Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: VP calls for caution against radical 'normal country' resolution

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu Thursday called for caution in drafting a more radical "normal country" resolution in response to calls for further action by some pro- independence groups, saying that any rash moves in this regard will put the security of Taiwan people at risk.

Lu made the remarks during an informal meeting with local electronic media executives after she read through a "normal country resolution" drafted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) central after being initiated by DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun.

Although several pro-independence organizations opined that the the DPP's version broaching a new national title and a new constitution for Taiwan is "not radical enough" and have called for bolder moves, she said that any daring advance toward Taiwan independence must be built on a national consensus due to the country's delicate situation in international society.

Before a national consensus concerning the point has been forged, it is extremely important that the nation's leaders and key public office holders refrain from precipitous acts that could put Taiwan's security under threat, she said.

However, the vice president is reluctant to comment on the DPP's draft resolution designed to reaffirm the party's determination to develop Taiwan into what the independence-leaning party calls a "normal country, "saying that in her opinion, dealing with the country's present designation, the Republic of China, is necessary, to allow Taiwan to shed its links to the People's Republic of China -- Beijing's official title.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police authorities plans to increase penalties for drunken driving

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) proposed Thursday that existing punishments for drunken driving be raised to a higher level that would be more effective in curbing offenses, a NPA officer said.

Ho Kuo-jung, head of the NPA traffic division, said that the agency has proposed at a Ministry of Transportation and Communications meeting on traffic safety that the criterion in determining an offense of drunken driving be changed and the threshold limit of breath alcohol concentration be lowered from 0.25 mg/L to 0.15 mg/L.

The fine for an offense with a breath alcohol concentration of 0.25-0.55 mg/L would be doubled to NT$30,000-NT$90,000, while the fine for an offense with a breath alcohol concentration of between 0.15 mg/L and 0.25 mg/L be adjusted to NT$3,000-NT$9,000, according to the NPA suggestions.

Under the current statute governing road traffic management and punishment, a motorist caught driving with a breath alcohol concentration of 0.25 mg/L or higher faces a fine ranging between NT$15,000 and NT$60,000.

Driving while intoxicated was the top culprit for deadly road traffic accidents in Taiwan in the first six months of the year, responsible for one of every five road traffic deaths during the period, according to NPA statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pork produced in Nantou County free of ractopamine: officials

TEXT.P: Nantou county government health officials assured the public Thursday that the pork produced in the county is free of ractopamine, a veterinary drug banned in Taiwan.
Officials of Nantou county government's Health Bureau issued the assurance after tests for ractopamine residue in several pork samples from the ranches in the county came back negative.

The use of ractopamine in pigs came to light in July, when two shipments of pork imports from the United States and some samples of locally produced pork were found to contain ractopamine, an animal feed additive that is legal in more than 20 countries to boost growth of lean meat in pigs.

Amid growing consumer concerns and calls from many hog farmers for the government to maintain its ban on the use of ractopamine in hogs and pork imports containing residue of the drug, the officials of Department of Health have repeatedly assured the public that the ban remains in place.

Health officials in Nantou County said they will continue regular check on local pigs to strengthen the food safety for consumers, and urged the public at the same time to buy products from companies of good repute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu to hold International Art Beach Festival

TEXT.P: The 2007 Penghu Island International Art Beach Festival will take place Aug. 18-26 on the renowned Lintou golden sand beach, the Penghu County government announced Thursday.

County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa and County Council Speaker Chen Chao-ling told a press conference that the festival will present a variety of beach activities everyday from 5 p.m. for eight consecutive days.
They said that the county government has invited famous foreign musical bands as well as local ensembles to entertain participants with different kinds of music throughout the festival.

The final competition of a beauty pageant will take place on the four-km golden beach and select a winner from among 15 finalists to help the county promote tourism, they said, adding that a fun cooking contest will be held, using locally produced marine and farm products to create gourmet dishes.
An exhibition at the site of the festival will display and sell Penghu's agricultural produce and fishery products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Annual tax revenues expected to exceed target for 2007: MOF

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) officially forecast that annual tax revenues will exceed projected targets for 2007 after reporting Thursday that the net tax revenues during the first seven months reached NT$1.696 trillion (US$51.4 billion) , up 7.8 percent from the year-earlier level.
Nevertheless, the complete fiscal year's tax revenue is not likely to be as good as last year's, the official added.

During the January-July period of this year, income tax revenues were up 14 percent, or an increase of NT$56.8 billion, securities transaction tax revenues were up 36.7 percent (an increase of NT$19.6 billion), land value-added tax revenues were up 10.4 percent (up NT$4.4 billion), and business tax revenues were up 1.3 percent (upNT$2.1 billion), compared with the same period last year.

Meanwhile, the official also reported a decline of NT$8.6 billion in commodity tax revenues. Inheritance and gift tax revenues were down by 11.5 percent (a decrease of NT$1.9 billion), and customs duties revenues decreased by NT$500 million or falling 1 percent.
The net tax revenues in July posted a year-on-year rise of NT$16 billion, or up 17.1 percent, to NT$109.5 billion, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate to announce running mate Aug. 15

TEXT.P: The dust over the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential ticket will settle Aug. 15 when the party's presidential candidate Frank Hsieh will finally announce his running mate, DPP sources siad Thursday.

Hsieh will set off on a Southeast Asian campaign tour Aug. 11 and is scheduled to return Aug. 15 in time to attend a carnival-style evening rally at 228 Peace Park in down Taipei, during which he will formally announce who his running mate will be, the sources said.

The Aug. 15 rally will be the first large-scale campaign forum sicne Hsieh wins the party's candidacy for the 2008 presidential election, the sources said, adding that all DPP bigwigs, including Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, will be present at the occasion to lend their support behind Hsieh's presidential bid and underscore internal party unity.

Speculation about Hsieh's running mate has been rife. While some party members prefer to see Hsieh team up with his presidential primary rival -- former Premier Su Tseng-chang, Hsieh himself reportedly would like to pick former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan as his running mate.
According to party sources, Hsieh's capaign staff will encompass key figures from all factions and groups within the party to facilitate internal coordination and harmony.
Hsieh's Southeast Asian tour will take him to Singapore and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 10, or the 28th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1821: Missouri is admitted as the 24th state of the United States.
1846: The Smithsonian Institute is established in Washington as a center for scientific research with a bequest from English scientist James Smithson.
1874: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, is born. His belief in individual freedom led him to reject federal relief for unemployment during the Depression and lost him the 1932 election to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
1894: Varahagiri Venkata Giri, president of India from 1969 to 1974, is born. He was prominent in India's labor movement.
1904: During the Russo-Japanese War, the Russian fleet suffers heavy loses when the Japanese fleet blocks it from escaping from Port Arthur in the Battle of the Yellow Sea.
1913: The Treaty of Bucharest is signed, ending the second Balkan War and partitioning Macedonia among Serbia, Greece, Romania and Bulgaria.
1926: Northwest Airlines is established in Chicago.
1944: Yicheng County in Hupei Province changes its name to Chihchung County in memory of the bravery of Gen. Chang Chih-chung who died in action during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1944: American forces recapture Guam from the Japanese after three weeks of fighting in which only 500 of the 18,000 defending Japanese troops survived and surrendered.
1945: Robert H. Goddard, American pioneer of rocket science, dies at the age of 63. He conducted the first successful launch of a liquid-propellant rocket in 1926. The rocket climbed 184 feet (56 meters) into the air at a speed of about 60 miles (97 kilometers) per hour.
1946: Gen. George C. Marshall, a special envoy of U.S. President Harry Truman to China on a mission to mediate the civil war between the Nationalists and the Chinese communists, issues a statement declaring that his efforts have failed.
1950: U.S. State Department official Karl L. Rankin arrives in Taipei as charge d'affaires of the U.S. Embassy.
1961: Britain applies to join the European Economic Community.
1966: Orbiter I, the first American moon satellite, is launched from Cape Kennedy.
1975: Flight service between the Republic of China and Japan resumes after the ROC government announced on April 20, 1974 the termination of the Taiwan-Japan flights of China Airlines and Japan Airlines.
1979: The newly completed Keelung-Suao Highway is opened to traffic.
1981: The joint meeting of the Second Asian Conference of the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology and the First Asian Conference of the International Council of Psychologists opens in Taipei.
1990: The ROC government declares its support of a United Nations call for world sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.
1993: The New KMT Alliance breaks with the ruling Kuomintang and forms the New Party.
1993: Shih Yueh-po, a Chinese passenger, hijacks a mainland Chinese Boeing 767 passenger plane to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
1998: Some 2,000 people die in floods in China.
1998: Prince Al-Muhtadee Billah, eldest son of Sultan Hassan Bolkiah of Brunei, is proclaimed heir to the throne.
1999: The Republic of China inaugurates Asia's first flight recorder laboratory, allowing local personnel to analyze aircraft flight recorder (black box) data rather than having to send such data to a third country for analysis.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian accuses Beijing of hypocrisy in terms of its definition of "one China," and reiterates Taiwan's rejection of Beijing's demand that it embrace "one China" on Beijing's terms.
2001: After being on death row for almost 10 years, mainland Chinese hijackers Cho Chang-jen and Chiang Hung-chun are executed at the Taipei Prison for kidnap and murder.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to be trusted by one's friends. If a man does not command the obedience of the members of his family, he will not be trusted by his friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan organizations win four 2007 eAsia Awards
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Aug. 10 (CNA) 08/10/07 12:25:28 (By Wu Shye-chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: E-projects initiated by Taiwan organizations garnered a total of four awards at the 2007 eAsia Awards announced Thursday in Bangkok, Thailand, making the country the biggest winner at this year's event.

The 2007 eAsia Awards, administrated by the Asia Pacific Council for Trade Facilitation and Electronic Business (AFACT) , honors projects in four major categories: trade facilitation, electronic business in the public sector, electronic business in the private sector and bridging the digital divide.
Six of the 12 semi-finalists for awards were from Taiwan, with four of them winning one of the 10 awards up for grabs.

The winners from Taiwan included the "Maritime and Harbor Information Overall Development" project organized by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, which took the top award in the trade facilitation category, and the "Taiwan e-Culture Construction Plan" project organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs, which took the top award in the bridging the digital divide category.

The other two winners were the "G2B2C Government Official Document Interchange System" project organized by the Institute for Information Industry, which was awarded the innovation prize in the electronic business in the public sector category; and the "Bridging the Digital Divide of the SME Project/Taiwan SME Digitalization Task Force Plan" organized by Chunghwa Telecom Co., which received the excellence award in the bridging the digital divide category.
The winners of the awards were announced in conjunction with the annual AFACT meetings being held Aug. 6-10 in the Thai capital.
