ZAMBOANGA CITY V Nine soldiers were killed when an Abu Sayyaf band waylaid them on their way to market to buy food in Sulu yesterday.
The Manila TimesG 9 troops killed in Sulu
NINE soldiers were killed and two others were wounded after their truck was ambushed by suspected Abu Sayyaf militants in a remote village in Sulu Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Prices slump on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slumped Friday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 251.29 points to close at 8,931.31.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 8,870.27 and peaked at 8,969.31 during trading. A total of 5.53 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$166.49 billion (US$5.05 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 4.1 percent, followed by textile stocks at 3.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 3.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2.8 percent, construction issues at 2.5 percent, cement stocks and plsatics and chemicals shares both at 2 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 1.7 percent.
Losers numbered more than 1,000 against 287 gainers, and 89 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August dropped 336 points to close at 8,800, with 64,613 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved down 348 points to finish at 8,776, with 6,642 contracts traded, while December futures lost 334 points to close at 8,821, with 85 contract transactions. March futures dropped 289 points to close at 8,850, with 14 contracts traded, while June futures decreased 332 points to finish at 8,805, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 9,136 for August, 9,124 for September, 9,155 for December, 9,139 for March and 9,137 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

August TE futures moved down 14.95 points to close at 372.05, with 3,641 contracts traded, while September TE futures dropped 16 points to finish at 371, with 393 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 10.65 points to close at 374, with six contracts traded, while March TE futures decreased 12.55 points to finish at 374.2, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

August TF futures dropped 55 points to close at 990, with 3,899 contracts traded, while September TF futures moved down 57.6 points to finish at 988, with 859 contract transactions. December TF futures lost 36.8 points to close at 1,010, with three contracts traded, while March TF futures decreased 62.6 points to finish at 1,010, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's planned U.S. stopovers 'simply for transit': MOFA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's plan to stop over in the United States during his Central America visit later this month is being arranged for the simple purpose of transit only, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Friday.

Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said the major purpose of the president's Central America trip is to take part in the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its Central American allies, to be held in Honduras, and he urged the media not to "focus all their attention on the transit plan."
According to Huang, the heads of state of most of the invited allies will attend the event in person.

Meanwhile, a high-ranking MOFA official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, admitted that Taiwan's decision to push for a referendum on the U.N. issue despite U.S. opposition has led Washington to adopt a less flexible attitude toward Chen's request to stop over in the United States this time.

Unlike in the past when the president always took part in some other private activities during his transit stops in the United States, the president will try to keep the transit stops simple this time and has not considered other possible countries for transit stops, the official said.

On Washington's disapproval of Taiwan's referendum plan, the government has explained to U.S. officials that the plan is not based on Chen's personal preferences but on the desire of the majority of the Taiwan people, he said.

Also, the government has told U.S. officials that the referendum will allow the international community to understand the strong determination of the Taiwan people to join the United Nations, he added.

There have been reports that Washington has refused to allow Chen to stop over in the continental United States or stay overnight during the transit stops as a way of showing its displeasure at Taiwan's plan to push for a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan."

The Taiwan-based China Times said Friday that the president would consider giving up his plan to stop over in the United States and instead make a transit stop in another country if the U.S. government were to decide not to allow him to set foot in the continental United States.

According to the report, Chen's plane might fly over Africa and Europe, instead of North America, on his way back to Taiwan, a plan which could involve a stopover on the Dutch-held island of Curacao, located in the southern part of the Caribbean Sea off the west coast of Venezuela.

Commenting on the report, Cho Jung-tai, acting secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said the United States remains the president's first transit choice in terms of its geographical location, and he dismissed the report as mere speculation.
Also, Cho said he was not able to respond to many of the "hypothetical questions" such as what if the U.S. government refuses to allow the president to stop over in the continental United States.

Cho said that President Chen is firm on protecting Taiwan's sovereignty and dignity in negotiating with the United States on his transit plan and that he believes this position will obtain the support of the United States and other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Congress helps upgrade Taiwan fashion industry's profile

TEXT.P: The smooth conclusion of the 32nd World Congress of Master Tailors held in Taipei has helped upgrade local fashion industry's international profile and visibility, organizers said Friday.

The congress, held Aug. 6-9 at the Taipei International Convention Center, brought together 206 experienced tailors from 15 countries around the world to show off their tailoring skills and fashion designs as well as exchange professional knowledge, organizers said.

Ho Liang-hung, chairman of the organizing committee of this year's committee, said Taiwan won the bid to host the biennial conference after vigorous competition from many countries, including Austria, America, and Thailand, during the previous conference held in Berlin, Germany in 2005. The first congress was held in Brussels, Belgium in 1910.
The four-day event included a series of activities, such as Western suit tailoring competitions and fashion shows, to provide an exchange platform for the world's outstanding tailors, Ho said.

Taiwan joined the federation in 2003 and was the third Asian country to host the event after Japan, which held the event in Tokyo in 1964, and South Korea, which hosted the event in Seoul in 1991, Ho said, adding that the event was a big chance to bring Taiwan to the world stage.
The organizing committee also invited many domestic designers to put on fashion show to present Taiwan's vitality and creativity in the tailoring industry Thursday, the last day of the event.

Lin Kuo-chi, one of the participating domestic designers, said Taiwan's world- class tailoring techniques to produce Western suits has been recognized around the world, and that more exchanges with fashion design brands favored by young people will help create more business opportunities with sectors of the industry requiring high-standard craftsmanship.
Classic brands such as Prada, YSL, and Burberry have successfully positioned themselves at peak of fashion with product designs that better suit younger generations' preferences, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Real estate transaction prices database to be established in one year

TEXT.P: The government is expected to establish within one year a national real estate transaction price database to facilitate public access to relevant information, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Friday.

The database, to be administered by the Ministry of the Interior, will integrate data on real estate transaction price currently held by various government agencies and private real estate brokers, CEPD officials said.

According to officials, the lack of such a database has caused difficulties for consumers, businesses, banking institutions and even government agencies trying to obtain transaction price information.

After completion of the price database, the government will further integrate the information on land administration, building administration and taxpayer ID with the goal of building a comprehensive, stable, transparent and open real estate database, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Stock markets in Europe suffered heavy losses Thursday due to worries over financial institutions' exposure to bad credit in the U.S. sub-prime mortgage market. In Italy, the Milan share index was down 1.45 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, rising NT$0.08 to close at NT$32.965.
A total of US$828 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.790 and fluctuated between NT$32.785 and NT$32.971.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA helping small and medium-sized companies upgrade technology

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has allocated NT$150 million (US$4.57 million) to help small and medium-sized enterprises upgrade their technology, MOEA officials said Friday.

Officials from the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said they are hoping that within the next year, the program will help more than 650 small and medium-sized companies upgrade their technology with the benefits in terms of increased productivity reaching NT$2 billion.
According to the officials, a total of 685 companies have shown interest in participating in the program, with two-thirds of them located in central and southern Taiwan.

The program forms part of the government's efforts to better serve the central and southern regions of the country, the middle and lower classes of society, and small and medium-sized enterprises, the officials said.
Currently, there are more than 1.2 million small and medium-sized companies around Taiwan, accounting for 98 percent of all businesses in the country.

According to IDB officials, manufacturing plants with capital of less than NT$80 million or fewer than 200 workers, as well as service companies with annual turnover of less than NT$100 million or fewer than 50 employees can apply for the short-term technological assistance offered by the MOEA's 16 R&D organizations, including the Industrial Technology Research Institute.
The officials said that the companies that have applied to join the technological assistance program are mainly from the textile, machinery, plastics and metal industries.
If the program works well, the MOEA is expected to double the technological assistance budget to NT$300 million next year, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President nominates next chief auditor

TEXT.P: Vice Auditor-General Lin Ching-lung has been nominated by President Chen Shui- bian to succeed Su Chen-ping as head of the Ministry of Audit, an aide to the president said Friday.
The anonymous aide made the disclosure hours after Chen said he had named a candidate to succeed Su whose six-year term will come to a close Oct. 1.

According to the Republic of China Constitution, the auditor-general, who heads the Ministry of Audit under the Control Yuan, should be nominated by the president and be approved by the Legislative Yuan.

Su, who has served in his current post since 1989, was cast into the limelight in late 2006 when he ordered a probe into allegations that President Chen Shui- bian had misused funds set aside for discretionary use on important state affairs.

The probe led to a judicial investigation into the allegations and resulted in the indictment of first lady Wu Shu-chen and several confidential aides to the president on charges of forgery and corruption.
The 80-year-old Su took the president's announcement in stride Friday, saying the president is authorized to act on this matter and he respected his decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education ministry to tighten quality control on universities

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) is studying new measures to further strengthen its control on the quality of local universities, a ministry official said Friday.

Ho Chou-fei, head of the ministry's Department of Higher Education, made the remarks amid widespread concerns, including harsh remarks made by Vice President Annette Lu earlier this week, regarding the low threshold for entering local universities this year.
Under current regulations, Ho said that if any domestic university fails to pass a ministry review, then the number of students to be recruited by the school and its tuition will be cut.
The ministry will also cut subsidies for the school, Ho noted.
In addition, such universities will not be allowed to recruit any students in the following year if it fails the second review, Ho stressed.
At present, the ministry is reviewing the regulations and hoping to further tighten the quality control measures on universities, which Ho said will help eliminate under-performing schools.

Meanwhile, Ho said that he does not believe that the quality of today's university students is lower than that in the past, describing Taiwanese students' performances as "more creative" in the Academic Olympia contests in recent years.
Also, Ho said that decades ago, many senior high school students entered the job market upon graduation because few of them were able to enter colleges.
Today, with hugely increased number of college students, the four more years of learning and training should improve their workplace performance, Ho went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public urged not to take bribes in upcoming elections

TEXT.P: Officials of the Central Election Commission (CEC) are urging the public not to take bribes in the upcoming legislative and presidential elections, as more severe punishments will be imposed on such violations.
The officials made the call with the approach of the next legislative and presidential elections.

As vote-buying and bribe-taking have been rampant in Taiwan's elections, an amendment to the Public Official Election and Recall Law approved in 2005 stipulates harsher punishment for violators, the officials said.

According to the officials, a man surnamed Wu was sentenced to three years and a half in prison and deprived of his civil rights for three years for delivering bribe to a voter before last year's Taipei city councilor elections.
The officials said law-enforcement authorities will step up their efforts in the fight against vote-buying and bribe-taking, and urged the public not to become involved in such crimes.
The next legislative election is slated for Jan. 12, 2008, while the presidential poll will take place March 22, 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for public support of Taiwan's U.N. bid

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the people of Taiwan Friday to throw their support behind the country's applications to join the United Nations and the World Health Organizations (WHO) under the name of Taiwan.
Chen made the appeal while delivering a keynote speech at a meeting of Rotary International District 3520 in Taipei.

Chen said that the government decided to use the name "Taiwan" to launch the bids because the country can neither change its official title -- the Republic of China -- nor use it in its bid to join the world organizations.

Citing the results of recent polls, Chen noted that 95 percent of Taiwan's people favor joining the U.N., while 77 percent back the country's bid to apply for the U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan.
In addition, Chen said that he insists on pursuing his mission of developing Taiwanese identity, while safeguarding Taiwan from being downgraded as merely a part of China or as a Chinese province.

The people of Taiwan, Chen went on, can now resort to a referendum to express themselves, which he claims will lead Beijing to better respect the choice of the Taiwanese public on the future of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) have launched campaigns to initiate a referendum on the country's bid to enter the U.N., which Chen described as a "rare consensus" and "a solid foundation for unity at home."
Chen said that the government will soon launch new applications to become the members of the two world bodies, and called on locals to actively respond and support the applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan students entered final stage of Asian comic contest

TEXT.P: Comic creations by six Taiwanese students have entered the final selection stage of the 1st Asian Animation and Comics Contest (AACC) being held in Guiyang City in the southwestern Chinese province of Guizhou, a comic association spokesman said Friday.
Huang Chih-yung, director-general of Taiwan's Asia Manga Cultural Association, said the six students' creations have defeated 3,000 other submissions from more than 10 countries.

The six students are Chih Hsue-ni, a college graduate; Hsieh Chih-huei, Cheng Shih-hua, both college students; Chang Yun-jung, a senior high student; Yen Yu- chun, a junior high student; and Huang Chia-yu, an elementary student, Huang said.

The six students' creations were among works preliminarily selected from the applications of a national comic contest for students, which aims at identifying the next generation of outstanding comic artists, Huang said.

Huang pointed out that within the culture industry, comics are the sector with the lowest cost threshold, but also one able to create the highest value. Comic creators must be equipped with good playwriting ability, directorial proficiency and excellent drawing skills.

Winners of the AACC final contest will be announced Sept. 7 and be recognized at an awards ceremony the same day at the Guiyang Grand Theater in China's Guizhou province. Winning creations will be exhibited at the Guiyang Art Museum Sept. 7-9.

The organizers will also host a forum on the development of the comic industry Sept. 7-8. World renown comic masters including Mikkel Egelund Lee, animation director of the Walt Disney Co., Jerry Robinson, creator of American "Batman" strip, Mikhail M. Zlatkovsky, Russian comics master, and Massoud Shojai Tabatabai, director of Iranian House of Cartoon were invited to hold seminars with participants, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition held in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition is taking place at the Taipei World Trade Center Aug. 9-12, with more than 30,000 people visiting the fair on opening Thursday.
The annual exhibition, held by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, changed its name this year from the previous Taipei Chinese Food Festival.

The exhibition, now in its 18th year, features this year the theme of "healthy organic food, " with 10 sub-themes, including "mysterious Sichuan food, " "renowned dishes, " "cooking classes" and "food from Sun Moon Lake."
Organizers invited 12 of Taiwan's most famous restaurants, including some in Taipei's five-star hotels, to demonstrate their cooking skills at the exhibition.
Twelve tourist farms have been invited to display their produce and show the public how to use the materials they produce to make various delicious dishes.
Eight teams form Taiwan and abroad are competing in the exhibition's biennial World Culinary Contest. The foreign teams are from the United States, Japan, Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong and China.

In the preliminary rounds, the eight teams will compete in pairs. They are required to cook seven Chinese dishes in three hours. The two teams that excel in the semi-finals Aug. 11 will vie for the championship Aug. 12.
A group of 75 royal cuisine researchers from South Korea demonstrated their cooking skills in a "royal feast" Friday.

The organizers have also invited several well-known chefs from China's Sichuan Province to engage in exchanges with their Taiwanese counterparts and demonstrate their skills in preparing hot, spicy Sichuan dishes.
Entry to the exhibition costs NT$250 per head for adults and NT$150 for children, with NT$50 discount coupons available from http://coupon.travelrich.com/2007food.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Foreign doctors face competence inquiry
Britains medical regulator has launched a major inquiry into the competence of foreign doctors after it emerged that they are now twice as likely to face disciplinary hearings as UK medical graduates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to launch product fairs to help local industries

TEXT.P: The government is planning to launch a product fair project in October that will set up sales platforms in major cities and counties to promote products and industries with local characteristics, a labor affairs official said Friday.

Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Lu Tien-lin made the announcement during a tour of Taichung, Changhua and Nantou counties in central Taiwan to gain a better understanding of the difficulties in the implementation of a CLA- sponsored employment promotion program.

Lu said he found that a major problem for many industries is a lack of sales and distribution channels and added that without proper outlets, many high-quality products developed under the program fail to reach consumers.

He noted that the government will integrate special industries that will receive guidance from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, the CLA, the Council for Cultural Affairs, the Council for Hakka Affairs and the Council of Indigenous Peoples to take part in the fairs.

He said that once the sales platforms are launched, they will not only help special industries sell and distribute products and facilitate sustainable development, but will also provide more purchase options for consumers and create more jobs.
He noted that the project is likely to kick off in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hog raisers protest against possible easing of ban on animal drug

TEXT.P: Groups of hog producers from across the country staged a protest Friday in front of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) as they suspected that a ban on ractopamine -- an animal drug that promotes the growth of lean meat in pigs and cattle -- may soon be lifted.

Hog farmers from across Taiwan demanded that the DOH not yield to pressure from the United States and lift the ban on the veterinary drug so as to allow U.S. pork containing the substance to enter Taiwan.

The use of ractopamine has provoked local consumers' concern after two shipments of imported pork from the United States and some locally raised pork from central Taiwan were discovered last month to contain the drug, which is lawful in the United States but banned in Taiwan.
According to hog farmers, over 1,000 metric tons of imported U.S. pork are awaiting entry to Taiwan in local ports -- entry conditional on the government lifting the ban on ractopamine.

Arguing that less than 1 percent of domestic farmers would use ractopamine in raising their pigs, representatives of the local hog-raising industry demanded the government not bow to U.S. pressure and criticized local pork importers as "diffident, " evidenced by their fear of declaring the meat to customs authorities.

Yang Her-pei, deputy chairman of the nation's hog-raisers association, accused the DOH of turning a deaf ear to a request made some six months ago by local farmers that foreign pork imports be examined to see whether they contain ractopamine residue.

He blamed the DOH for failing to invite local industry representatives to a seminar it recently sponsored and questioned whether academics who spoke in favor of the drug's use on the occasion represented vested interests.

According to Changhua County pig-raising association chairman Yang Kuan-chang, 52 containers of U.S. pork, collectively worth more than US$50 million in market value have been waiting since July 2 for the ban on ractopamine to be lifted so as to receive clearance.
Young Ju-men, an activist committed to bettering local farmers' livelihoods, who was released from jail last month through a presidential pardon, also took part in the protest.
Shipments of U.S. pork detected to be ractopamine-tainted last month were allegedly going to be sold to a "famous fast-food chain, " he said, expressing his objections to an easing of the ban.
Young was imprisoned for planting explosive devices in Taipei to arouse public attention to the plight of local farmers after the opening of Taiwan's market to foreign farm produce.

Hsieh Ting-hung, deputy director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, confirmed that the DOH has for more than one month not received any customs clearance report of imported pork. But he clarified that the Council of Agriculture (COA) is the authority in charge of deciding whether to remove the ban.
The DOH will not apply two different standards to examinations of locally and foreign produced pork, he said.
DOH officials have repeatedly said that the DOH has no authority to unilaterally lift the ban because such a move must be approved by the COA, which listed ractopamine as a banned drug.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP cancels Thailand trip over visa snub
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 10 (CNA) 08/10/07 20:45:45 (By Wu Shieh-chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, who is visiting Manila, has been forced to cancel his plan to visit Thailand after the Thai government denied him a visa, a spokesman of DPP's Southeast Asian chapter in Bangkok said Friday.
Yu was scheduled to proceed to Thailand Saturday after finishing his visit to the Philippines, the spokesman said.
According to the spokesman, the Thai government's refusal to grant Yu a visa was due to pressure from Beijing. He condemned China for its "arbitrary and relentless" repression of Taiwan.

Yu was originally planning to meet Taiwanese expatriates living in Thailand but was forced to cancel his trip after receiving abrupt notice from Thailand's Ministry of Foreign Affairs two days before his planned arrival that it would not grant him a visa.
The DPP spokesman said China imposed the pressure on Thailand on the grounds that Yu is an advocate of Taiwan independence.

Yu has been promoting ways to make Taiwan a "normal country, " including a resolution within the party that will push for changing the country's official title to "Taiwan" and formulating a new constitution more suitable for the nation.
The spokesman said that although Yu could have applied for a landing visa to enter Thailand, he refused to do so, deeming such a move "too demeaning" for him.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators indicted for disrupting 2006 National Day celebrations

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung and opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chen Chao-jung were indicted Friday for disrupting last year's Double Ten National Day celebrations.

According to the indictment, Liu and Chen illegally interfered with a National Day rally Oct. 10, 2006 in front of the Presidential Office by striding across processions of guards of honor deliberately.

Liu and Chen continued their disruptive behavior despite warnings from National Security Bureau agents and military policemen at the ceremony, the indictment said, adding that the two lawmakers were indicted for violations of Article 31 of the Assembly and Parade Act.

The two lawmakers' disruptive behavior came at the height of a so-called "Million Voices Agaist Corruption" campaign to force President Chen Shui-bian to step down over a spate of corruption scandals allegedly involving members of his family and aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children are nation's future: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that children are the country's future energy resources rather than burdens, using three new films to demonstrate his point and describe the devotion of parents.
Chen made the remarks during his participation in a parents-kids day activity at the Presidential Office.

Describing parents as more powerful than the robots in the movie "Transformers, " Chen said parents need to be equipped with perseverance, endurance and physical strength to take care of their children.
Meanwhile, as with the film "Spiderman, " parents need to rush to their children's rescue when they are in difficulty or sick, Chen said.
In addition, he continued, parents have to possess wonderful cooking skills, "as demonstrated by the rat in the movie 'Ratatouille,'" so that their children can eat healthily and happily.
Portraying parenthood as "the most difficult and greatest job in the world, " Chen said that it is also an occupation' that brings still greater joy in return.
Chen urged local parents to treasure their children, who he described as "gifts from god, " adding that children can teach adults about the true meaning of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3,000 suspected pirated video game discs seized at airport

TEXT.P: The Taipei Customs Office seized 2,990 video game discs from an import warehouse this week and is trying to establish whether they are pirated goods, officials from the office disclosed Friday.
The officials said they chanced upon the suspicious goods, comprising 2,170 discs of Nintendo Wii games and 820 discs of Sony PlayStation 2 (PS2) games.
They said the goods belong to an import company but did not name the company.
According to the officials, the 2,990 discs, with an estimated retail value of NT$4.3 million, would seriously disturb the market and affect the rights of lawful dealers.
They said the customs office has asked the Criminal Investigation Division of the Aviation Police Bureau to pursue the case.

This is the third major find of suspected pirated video game discs in three months. In July, the Taipei Customs Office seized 1,865 discs of Wii and PS2 video games. Aviation police later certified that the discs were counterfeit.
In June, the Taipei Customs Office requested the help of a Nintendo representative who confirmed that 400 Wii discs worth NT$600,000 that were seized at Taiwanese ports of entry were pirated.
Nintendo's Wii and Sony's PS2 are popular video games in Taiwan, with the number of console owners surpassing 200,000 and 250,000, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pan-blue lawmakers want amendments to assembly law

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), in the "pan-blue alliance" will cooperate to seek amendments to the law governing street assembly and demonstrations in the next legislative session, PFP legislative caucus chief Fu Kun-chi announced Friday.

Speaking at a news conference, Fu said that the two parties reached an agreement to collaborate in pushing amendments to the Assembly and Parade Act after Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT lawmaker and director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, contacted him the previous night to seek the PFP's cooperation.

Although the KMT's legislative caucus has repeatedly called for amendments to the assembly law and the PFP's caucus has proposed that it be scrapped altogether, Fu said that the two parties share the same idea of "doing something" to the "evil law" in order to fully guarantee the assembly and demonstration rights enshrined in the Constitution.
He added that the two parties will also launch concerted moves to list the amendment proposal as a priority issue on the agenda of the next legislative session.

According to Fu, the indictment by Taipei prosecutors of 16 prime organizers -- including former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh -- of a series of anti-corruption protests held last autumn in front of the Presidential Office and the Taipei Train Station was the main reason driving the two parties to collaborate.
Fu expressed hope that the KMT and the PFP can iron out amendments to the law and make it more fully meet the people's needs.

In a related development, PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung and KMT lawmaker Chen Chao-jung were indicted that same day by the Taipei Prosecutors Office on charge of disrupting last year's Oct. 10 National Day celebrations.

Both Liu and Chen, who had both been invited to take part in the celebration activities, were indicted over deliberately disrupting the performance of the honor guards and marching bands. The two accused claimed after the celebrations that they were only "taking a walk" in an open area.

DOC.HEADLINE: III to lead biotech delegation to Saudi Arabia

TEXT.P: The non-profit Institute for Information Industry (III) is scheduled to lead a delegation of biotech pharmaceutical manufacturers on a visit to Saudi Arabia in September.

The visit will be part of efforts by the III in recent years to tap business opportunities in petrodollar nations in the Middle East, III officials said, noting that the III set up an office in Qatar as a one-stop window joint service center last month.
III officials noted that Saudi Arabia is hoping to improve its health insurance system and that Taiwan's health insurance is one that could be suitable for the country.

They added that the III sent officials to brief the Saudi Arabian government on Taiwan's health insurance system in May. Saudi health officials then came to Taiwan to attend a six-week seminar on the system that began in July.
Saudi Health Minister Fahad Bin Jalawi, who heads the delegation of health officials, said Saudi Arabia has also sent officials to Japan, Germany and France to inspect their health insurance systems.
He said that Taiwan has taken only 15 years to establish what he described as a "sound system."
He noted that the health insurance system has been computerized and praised its sound infrastructure.
He also invited Taiwanese manufacturers in charge of establishing the information data of Taiwan's health insurance system to visit Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to increase subsidies for bunker oil

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian announced Friday that subsidies for bunker oil for fishing boats will be raised by NT$871 per kiloliter, retrospective from July 1.

The president made the announcement at the Presidential Office when he received heads of local fishermen's associations to listen to their views on subsidies for fishing boats, insurance and foreign fishery workers management, as well as the development of the fishing industry.
Chen noted that the government wants to help fishermen solve the difficulties they face due to soaring oil prices.

He said that based on the declared price of bunker oil July 1, which was set at NT$18,093 (US$550) per kiloliter, it will raise the subsidy level to 14 percent, or NT$2,533 per kiloliter, making it NT$871 more than the existing subsidy of NT$1,662.

In addition, the president said the Council of Agriculture will also raise the subsidy level for insurance premiums for fishing boats as a way to encourage them to join insurance programs, with the subsidy level raised to equal that provided by the Kaohsiung city government to fishing boats under its jurisdiction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County residents oppose nuclear waste storage

TEXT.P: Several hundred Taipei County residents, led by Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, staged a protest Friday as the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council was holding a hearing on a plan to store nuclear waste at two nuclear power plants in the county.

The protesters included members of the county council and environmental protection activists. They demonstrated outside the Taipei International Convention Center and shouted slogans to express their opposition to the plan.
Most of the protesters were residents of Wanli, Shihmen, Chinshan and Sanchih townships, all of which will be affected by the plan.

Taiwan Power Co. has floated the proposal to build dry-storage facilities at Nuclear Power Plant No. 1 in Shihmen township and at Nuclear Power Plant No. 2 in Wanli township to keep spent nuclear fuel rods.

Chou said the plan will pose a hazard to the health of the residents of Taipei County, while the township heads said it is unfair to residents of Taipei County because three of Taiwan's four nuclear power plants are located in their county, with the No. 4 plant -- still under construction -- in the county's Kungliao township.

Taiwan Environmental Protection Union Chairwoman Gloria Hsu demanded that the Atomic Energy Council immediately shelve its plan because an evaluation committee of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration rejected it April 23.
She said that in holding the hearing, the council was acting against the law.
Spent nuclear fuel rods -- a byproduct of the fission of uranium in commercial nuclear plants -- are highly radioactive.

Currently, spent nuclear fuel rods are stored in deep pools of water at most nuclear power plants. However, by designing facilities for dry storage, the need for maintaining high-cost pools can be eliminated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecution dealing with illegal entry of Chinese dissident: MAC

TEXT.P: The Yilan Prosecutors Office is dealing with the case involving the illegal entry of a Chinese dissident, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan said Friday.
Tung was referring to Cai Lujun, who arrived in Taiwan Aug. 5 by disguising himself as a fishery worker and using his younger brother's name.

Cai expressed his intention to seek political asylum through a local human rights promotion association after arriving in a Chinese fishery workers reception center in Nanfangao in Yilan County, northeastern Taiwan, Tung said.
Through coordination, Tung said, the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture and the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) handled the case in accordance with the regulations.
As Tsai violated the National Security Law and committed forgery, the CGA transferred the case to the Yilan Prosecutors Office for further investigation, Tung said.
Noting that relevant agencies are checking Cai's background, Tung said that if Cai's identity and testimony are verified, the prosecution authorities are not expected to indict him.

After the conclusion of the judicial process, Tung said, the MAC customarily calls a meeting of officials from all relevant government agencies, including the Ministry of the Interior, to screen the case, ascertain Cai's true aspirations and assist in arranging for him to travel to a third country and help with his application for international refugee status with the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees.
During his stay in Taiwan, Tung went on, the government will give him proper care.

According to Tung, no Chinese dissidents who enter Taiwan via illegal channels can obtain legal residency in Taiwan. At present, he said, the government is arranging for four other Chinese dissidents who entered Taiwan illegally to settle in a third country.

As for Chinese dissidents who come to Taiwan through legal channels, Tung continued, the government usually helps them secure permanent residency in Taiwan so long as they meet the Interior Ministry's requirements.
Tung said Taiwan does not have a comprehensive legal mechanism to handle refugee issues and that the Interior Ministry has referred a draft refugee bill to the Executive Yuan for approval.
"Once the bill passes the legislature, we will have a more efficient mechanism to deal with the issue," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan willing to negotiate Olympic torch relay with Beijing: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to negotiate on the issue of the 2008 Olympic torch relay route with Beijing if it shows sincerity and goodwill, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan made the remarks at a news conference in response to a request by Beijing Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games (BOCOG) Executive Vice President Jian Xiaoyu.
Jian had expressed hope that Taiwan will return to a previous consensus reached by two sides of the Taiwan Strait in order to let the flame's relay route include Taiwan.

Taiwan rejected a torch relay route offered by China in April that would have included Taiwan as China's first "domestic" stop and would have had the flame arriving in Taiwan from Vietnam and going on to China-controlled Hong Kong and Macau. The arrangement was considered by Taiwan as an intentional move to downgrade Taiwan's sovereign status.

Tung said that Taiwan rejected China's proposal because it violated a formal agreement reached by both sides in 1989 that ensures Taiwan has equal sporting status to China by referring to Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei." China has often referred to Taiwan as "Taipei, China."

He went on that the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC), as a member of the International Olympic Committee (IOC), has the right to participate in IOC international sporting events on equal terms with other members.

The 2008 Olympic torch relay is highly anticipated by the Taiwanese people and the CTOC will contact Beijing on the issue in order to have a final decision on the route made before the September deadline, Tung said.

Taiwan has several basic requirements for the negotiation, including that both sides follow IOC regulations, that Beijing shall not downgrade Taiwan's sovereignty and that the negotiation will benefit future interaction between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to visit Latin America via Alaska

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will travel via Alaska on his way to Latin America and on his way home, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Friday.
The officials said that after negotiating with the U.S. authorities, they decided Chen's plane will make short refueling stops in Anchorage, Alaska on its way to and from Latin America.
The officials said the main purpose of Chen's visit is to take part in the sixth leadershp summit between Taiwan and its Central American allies, to be held in Honduras later this month.

Since the visit is to cement relations with the nation's allies in the region in the wake of the severing of diplomatic ties with Costa Rica in June, they said that using Alaska as a refueling point is the easiest method of making the journey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese woman suspected of killing her three children in Finland

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Helsinki said Friday that he will continue to request a visit with a Taiwanese woman being held incommunicado on suspicion of killing her three children in suburban Helsinki.
Sheng Pei-huang said that because the woman has Finnish nationality, police declined his request to visit.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has traced her original residence in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan but has been unable to get in touch with her family there.
Sheng said major media outlets in Finland have reported heavily on the tragic killing since Sunday, although the media and Finnish police have not revealed a motive or other details.
He said the woman, identified only by her maiden name of Fu, married her Finnish husband more than 10 years ago.

Fu later divorced her husband, who had custody of their eight-year-old twin daughters, while she had custody of a one-year-old son. The twin daughters were probably visiting the mother during their summer vacation.
Sheng said Fu came with her children to Taiwanese expatriate activities during this year's Dragon Boat Festival, which fell on June 19 this year.

He said there are around 60 Taiwanese expatriates in Finland, most of them Taiwanese women married to Finnish men and who usually have frequent exchanges with each other. None of the other Taiwanese women questioned said they had sensed anything abnormal about Fu recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawyers protest court ruling of no need to subpoena president

TEXT.P: A Taipei District Court decision not to subpoena President Chen Shui-bian in the trial of an embezzlement and forgery case involving first lady Wu Shu-jen and the president's former and present aides is unconstitutional and absurd, the defendants' lawyers said Friday.

The group of lawyers representing Ma Yung-cheng, a former head of Chen's office, and his successor Lin Teh-hsun, asked the judges to subpoena Chen during a court hearing July 27 to facilitate the investigations and protect the rights of the two defendants.
The panel of judges dealing with the case ruled Friday that as the points to be verified in the trial of Ma and Lin on their roles in the case are clear, there is no need to subpoena Chen.

The judges also said court proceedings regarding the case will continue, ignoring the defense lawyers' claim that the trial is illegal and unconstitutional according to a constitutionality interpretation given by the Council of Grand Justices in June.

Ma and Lin are charged with forgery in the case involving alleged misappropriation of a "special affairs fund" set aside for the president's discretionary use, which includes funding confidential diplomatic missions.
Their lawyers said Chen himself is the core figure in the case, as Ma and Lin did not act according to their personal wills or independent legal status while executing missions given by Chen.
Against this backdrop, the lawyers said only Chen himself can clarify certain conflicting points and uncover the truth.
As Chen enjoys constitutional immunity from prosecution, he has not been indicted. However, the defense lawyers said the "bona fide" defendant in the current trial is Chen himself.

However, the panel of judges said the prosecutors didn't question the existence of secret diplomatic missions. The trial of the case involving Ma and Lin only touches on whether they had used other people's proofs of spending to claim reinbursements from the "special affairs funds. As a result, the judges said they see no need to subpoena the president.

As to the defense lawyers' criticism that the judges have failed to respond to Chen's request for return of a collection of files that prosecutors have seized from his office in the process of investigations, the judges said the lawyers' statement is unrelated with the lawsuit itself and will therefore not affect the proceeding and judgment of the case.

The defense lawyers slammed the judges for ignoring the grand justices' June 15 ruling that states that no criminal investigation, prosecution and trial with the president as target is legally permissible.
"The judges' insistence on going ahead with the trail is unconsitutional and outrageous," said a defense lawyer.
In their Friday ruling, the panel of judges said as whether or not the files taken from the Presidential Office will be returned to Chen will not affect court proceeding, the trial will continue.

The judges still failed in their Friday ruling to respond to Chen's June 28 request for the court to return a collection of files taken away by prosecutors from the Presidential Office for investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 11, or the 29th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Christiaan Eijkman, the Dutch physician who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B, is born.
1863: The French, who occupy southern Vietnam, make Cambodia a protectorate.
1919: Scottish-born American industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie dies at the age of 84. He amassed a fortune in the steel industry and donated millions of dollars for the benefit of the public.
1921: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, formally invites China, Japan, Britain, France and Italy to join a disarmament meeting in Washington, D.C. to cope with an increasingly dangerous international situation after World War I.
1930: Britain goes broke. The United States and France each lend it US$46 million, while American bankers extend another US$111 million.
1932: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, says it is time to scrap Prohibition. He lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt later that same year.
1936: Nationalist Chinese forces of Chiang Kai-shek enter Canton after foiling a rebellion led by Chen Chi-tang in the city in southern China.
1945: The Allies inform Japan that its surrender offer is acceptable.
1945: Communist "Yenan General Headquarters" orders Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the Republic of China government.
1950: The U.N. Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out in protest.
1960: Chad gains independence from France.
1960: The ROC recognizes the Ivory Coast and Chad.
1966: A peace treaty is signed in Jakarta, ending three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia.
1972: President Richard M. Nixon completes his "Vietnamization" of the Vietnam War by pulling out the last 92 American soldiers from the Southeast Asian country.
1973: The Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens its three-day 19th Conference in Taipei.
1975: The first meeting of the Asian and Pacific Congress on Health, Physical Education and Recreation opens in Taipei with 250 experts from 17 nations and areas attending.
1976: The industrial and commercial panel of the National Reconstruction Seminar opens a three-day meeting to make recommendations to the government.
1986: Sixteen people are killed and 87 others injured in an accidental explosion aboard the tanker SS Canari which is waiting to be scrapped in a shipwrecking yard in Kaohsiung Harbor.
1992: The United States, Canada and Mexico reach an agreement to set up a North American free-trade zone that would rank as the world's largest single trading bloc.
1993: The ROC Cable Television Law goes into effect.
1997: An international meeting called to shore up the shaky Thai economy offers loans of US$16 billion to the financial crisis-hit country.
1999: Taiwan's China Airlines signs an agreement with Boeing Co. of the United States to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion.
2000: A "Tzu Chi Village" in South Africa built by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, a charity organization, is formally inaugurated. Meanwhile, the Tzu Chi Medical Center announces the 99th and 100th overseas cases in which it has supplied bone marrow for transplant operations.
2001: The Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the Finance Ministry and the Central Deposits Insurance Corp. take the initiative to put 36 faltering local financial institutions under supervision, the first phase of a "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" action to consolidate the operations of local banks and farmers as well as fishermen's cooperatives.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to command the obedience of the members of one's family. If a man looking into his own heart is not true to himself, he will not command the obedience of the members of his family."
