DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-U.S. communication continues over fugitive tycoon case
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 10 (CNA) 08/11/07 13:20:55 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to communicate with the U.S. government over the possibility of having fugitive Taiwanese tycoon Wang You-theng repatriated back to Taiwan for trial, a Taiwan official said Friday.

According to Stanley Kao, Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States, U.S. authorities had notified Taiwan before Wang, founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, was released on bail from an immigration holding center in San Pedro, Calif. early this week.

Taiwan was also informed that legal proceedings in Wang's case have yet to be concluded, which is the reason why he is required to wear an electronic monitoring device after being released from the holding center, Kao said.
However, Kao said the reason for Wang's release remains unclear to Taiwan, adding that Taiwan officials will continue to seek an explanation from the U.S. side.

Wang had been detained by U.S. immigration authorities since Feb. 2 when he tried to return to Los Angeles with both his Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports canceled, following a failed attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore.

Wang is suspected of having embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds from the group before fleeing with his wife, Wang Chin She-ying, to China late last year and then to the United States in January this year.
Taiwan authorities placed the couple on the country's most-wanted list Jan. 15 and have been seeking U.S. assistance to have them repatriated back to Taiwan to face charges.

In March, Taiwanese prosecutors indicted Wang and 106 others involved in the Rebar Group scandal on a long list of charges, including fraud, money laundering and insider trading. They are seeking a prison sentence of 30 years and an unprecedented fine of NT$1.71 billion (US$52.13 million) for Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Saudis visit to learn about Taiwan's health insurance system

TEXT.P: Saudi Arabian officials completed a six-week training program in Taiwan that gave them an opportunity to learn from Taiwan's expertise and experience in its renowned National Health Insurance program, which Saudi Arabia intends to introduce in the future.

"Saudi Arabia selected Taiwan over Sweden and Germany as the place to send its delegation because Taiwan boasts one of the best national insurance systems in the world and because its population is about the same as that of Saudi Arabia, " said Fahad Jalwi Lzahr, Saudi Arabia's director general of health insurance.

Jalwi Lzahr led a 13-member delegation, including 12 health insurance officials from provinces in Saudi Arabia, to attend the "Health Insurance Professional Development Program for the Ministry of Health, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, " co- organized by Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry (III) , Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Department of Health, and Bureau of National Health Insurance.

The program, which concluded Aug. 9, aimed to introduce Taiwan's expertise and technologies to familiarize Saudi delegates with policies, administration and operational issues that are essential to the proposed implementation of the Cooperative Health Insurance in Saudi Arabia.

"Taiwan's publicly funded health insurance program is similar to what we would like to establish in Saudi Arabia, while the German program is more of an outsourcing program that involves a lot of private companies, " Jalwi Lzahr said.

The program included lectures and discussions, as well as on-site visits to organizations related to the topics covered. The lecture topics included historical background, basic framework, health insurance economics, health insurance operations, and hospital operations.

The on-site visits were arranged to give members of the delegation an enhanced understanding of the theories, administration, operations and implementation of a publicly-funded national health insurance program.

Jalwi Lzahr said he was happy with the program in general. Speaking about the on-site visits, he said he was especially impressed with the success of Taipei Municipal Wang Fan Hospital. He added that by the end of the program, the delegates had already been contacted by several Taiwan pharmaceutical companies which expressed an interest in doing business in Saudi Arabia.

According to Jalwi Lzahr, Saudi Arabia and the III will launch a series of cooperation projects between the two countries. Possible projects include a training program on health care and insurance information systems, on-the-job training related to health insurance system operations, and graduate studies in the health care and health insurance fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heavy-duty motorcycles to be allowed on expressways from Nov. 1

TEXT.P: Motorcycles with 550 cc engines or larger will be allowed to use expressways around the country from Nov. 1, a Directorate General of Highways (DGH) spokesman said Saturday.
DGH Deputy Director General Chen Chun-hsuing made the announcement in Taipei at a gathering of motorcycle riders, who have for long complained about not being allowed to use expressways.

On the new policy, Ho Kuo-jung, head of the National Police Agency's traffic division, said that most expressways will be open to heavy-duty motorcycles, excluding the Pakuashan Tunnel on the Tai roadway No.76 which connects Changhua and Nantou counties in central Taiwan, and road sections where local governments prohibit motorbikes.
However, motorcycles will still be prohibited from using freeways, Ho noted.

Starting Nov. 1, motorcycles with 550 cc engines or larger will be treated as four-wheel cars which can use expressways and make direct left turns on roads, Ho said, adding that such motorcycles should carry a red license plate with white numbers on the front side of the vehicle to facilitate identification.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan exports expected to post double-digit growth for 2007

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export volume is expected to post double-digit growth for 2007 despite the slowdown in growth momentum in the first half of the year, Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) officials said Saturday.
The officials made the forecast based on the fact that the second half of each year is usually the brisk season for Taiwan exports, especially consumer electronic products.

Ministry of Finance tallies show that the country's export volume rose 7.6 percent year-on-year to stand at US$135.12 billion for the first seven months of this year, while import volume increased 7 percent year-on-year to US$1124.13 billion.
This translates into a trade surplus of US$10.99 billion, up 14.9 percent compared with the same period last year, according to the tallies.
BOFT officials said Taiwan's exports did not perform as well as expected in the first half of this year mainly because of the impact of the sluggish international business climate.

While growth in Taiwan's electronic, information and communication exports slipped in the first half of this year owing to inventory adjustments by their clients, demand was also declining in Taiwan's major export markets, including the United States and Japan, the officials said.
Due to the sluggishness of the contract chip-making industry, Taiwan's semiconductor exports only increased 6 percent for the first half of this year, they pointed out.

Although the value of export orders received by Taiwan rose 12.8 percent for the first half of this year, exports increased only 7.5 percent because 46 percent of the orders were for products manufactured in overseas production lines, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office dismisses reports about Judicial Yuan head

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office dismissed reports Saturday that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to nominate incumbent grand justice Lai In-jaw as the head of the Judicial Yuan.

Officials said the reports are "not true, " adding that the president is still working on recruiting qualified people to fill vacant seats on the Council of Grand Justices as well as the posts of Judicial Yuan president and vice president.

According to Saturday's Liberty Times, a local newspaper, Lai will be nominated as the president of the Judicial Yuan, while Yang Jen-shou, head of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries, will serve as Lai's deputy.

Among the 15 seats on the Council of Grand Justices for which President Chen nominated candidates in 2003, eight of them, including the post of president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, are for four-year terms, while the remainder are for eight-year terms.

However, as former Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo resigned and Yang left to serve as the head of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries, there are currently only 13 grand justices.

Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, who concurrently serves as a grand justice, as well as five other grand justices, namely Lin Yung-mo, Wang He- hsiung, Yu Hsueh-ming, Tseng You-tien and Liao Yi-nan, will see their terms expire this September.
This is why the president has to put forward a list of eight grand justice nominees to fill the vacancies.
Other incumbent grand justices, including Lai, Hsu Pi-hu, Peng Feng-chih, Lin Tze-yi, Hsu Tsung-li, Hsieh Tsai-chuan and Hsu Yu-hsiu, will see their terms expire in September 2011.
Meanwhile, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that it would not comment on reports about Lai serving as the Judicial Yuan president.
Tseng Yuan-chuan, executive director of the KMT Policy Committee, said that President Chen has yet to send his list of grand justice nominees to the Legislature Yuan for approval.
Tseng said that reports about possible candidates are an attempt to sound out the response of the public, and the KMT would "refrain from commenting on such reports now."
However, the People First Party (PFP) , an ally of the KMT, responded positively to the idea of Lai serving as the Judicial Yuan president.

Daniel Huang, executive director of the PFP's Policy Committee, noted that Lai served as PFP Chairman James Soong's deputy during the latter's term as governor of the now marginalized Taiwan Provincial Government.
"If Lai is nominated by the president, the PFP will exercise the right of confirmation after screening his qualification," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins 1st gold at 2007 Universiade in Bangkok
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 11 (CNA) 08/11/07 15:22:05 (By Wu Shye-chang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan earned its first gold medal at the 2007 World University Games, also known as Universiade, in Bangkok, Thailand Friday, with Lin An-ni winning the women's 67-kg taekwondo event on the second day of competition.
Lin, a student at the National College of Physical Education and Sports, won the gold by defeating her Turkish rival in the final match.

Meanwhile, Hung Chun-an won a bronze medal in the men's under 78 kg taekwondo event and Chen Yen-ju took bronze in the women's under 72 kg event, giving Taiwan a total of three medals and 12th place standing in the overall medal count as of Friday.
Meanwhile, Taiwan athletes performed well in the tennis event, with players in the singles and doubles competitions making it to the third-round.
On the same day, Taiwan athletes competing in the men's and women's table tennis, badminton and shooting events performed well, keeping themselves in the hunt for gold.

Also on Friday, the Taiwan women's basketball team defeated Serbia 59-52 to earn a spot in the quarterfinals. The Taiwan squad earned a fifth-place finish in the previous Universiade held in 2005 in Izmir, Turkey.
The biennial international sports event will last until Aug. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan higher education fair opens in Kuala Lumpur

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taiwan Higher Education Fair in Malaysia opened Saturday in Kuala Lumpur in a drive to attract more students of Chinese descent to study in Taiwan, according to the Ministry of Education (MOE).

The fair has been organized by a 102-member delegation headed by Chang Chin-fu, president of Nantou County-based National Chi Nan University. The group is made up of presidents and executive officials of 38 Taiwanese universities and colleges, including the prestigious National Taiwan University and National Taiwan Normal University.
The exhibition will be held in the Malaysian capital for two days before moving to the southern town of Muar, where it will be held Aug. 14-15.

Nearly 1,000 youths living in Malaysia apply for admission to universities or colleges in Taiwan every year, MOE officials said, adding that according to their observation, most of those students perform as well as their local counterparts academically in Taiwan, particularly in the field of medicine.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: European stock markets suffered heavy losses Friday for the second consecutive day as credit fears were spreading. Shares' market value was lowered by more than 268 billion euros. In Italy the Milan share index was down 2.48 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of people with Alzheimer's in Taiwan tops 140,000

TEXT.P: Taiwan had about 140,000 people with Alzheimer's disease as of the end of 2006, and the figure could double in the next 20 years, a Taiwan Alzheimer's Disease Association (TADA) official said Saturday.
Tang Li-yu, secretary-general of the TADA, made the prediction at a forum on the Alzheimer's prevention and care.

Alzheimer's is a neurodegenerative disease that, in its most common form, is found in people over the age of 65. Clinical signs of the disease are characterized by progressive cognitive deterioration, together with declining physical activity, as well as neuropsychiatric symptoms or behavioral changes. It is the most common type of dementia.

To cope with the rapid increase in the number of people with Alzheimer's, Tang called for efforts to facilitate early detection and treatment of the disease in patients as well as concerted efforts by the government and private sectors in caring for Alzheimer's patients.
Although there is no cure for Alzheimer's, she said, there are steps that people can take to minimize their chances of becoming victims of the disease.

She noted that people with high blood pressure and diabetes are at higher risk for Alzheimer's, adding that these people have to make greater efforts at controlling their diets and exercising their body and mind more.
In addition, she urged the government to spend more on raising awareness of Alzheimer's, noting that many people with the disease have yet to diagnosed as such.
The association will hold an Alzheimer's awareness campaign on Sept. 15, ahead of World Alzheimer's Day, which falls on Sept. 21, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Output of Taiwan's RFID industry to reach NT$10 billion by 2009

TEXT.P: The annual production value of Taiwan's radio frequency identification (RFID) industry is expected to expand 12.5-fold over the next three years to amount to NT$10 billion (US$303.95 million) by 2009, according to a report released Saturday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
This will increase Taiwan's RFID production value to 4 percent of the world's total, the report said.

It pointed out that the RFID technology, an automatic identification method that relies on storing and remotely retrieving data using devices called RFID tags, is considered one of the 10 most important technologies of this century, with more than 6,000 patent applications having been filed over the past 10 years for RFID-related products.

According to a report released by the U.S.-based ABI Research for the first quarter of 2007, the global RFID market was valued at US$1.41 billion in 2006, with the value expected to increase to US$5.1 billion in 2007, US$6.39 billion in 2008 and further to US$11.5 billion in 2011.

To promote the applications of RFID technology, the South Korean government implemented six large-scale pilot RFID projects in the public sector in 2004 and 2005 and is set to funnel US$30 million per year during the 2005-2010 period to boost the development of the RFID industry.

As the development of Taiwan's RFID industry has seen a late start compared with other countries, it is necessary for the government to work out a policy to enhance the industry, according to the CEPD.

A report published by the Institute for Information Industry last year shows that there were 149 manufacturers of RFID products in Taiwan in 2006, with the number of workers totalling 578 and combined production value amounting to NT$814 million.

While the electronic seal system used by Taiwan harbors is one of the most innovative applications of RFID technology, a number of Taiwan businesses, including Foxconn Technology Group, Mosel Vitelic Inc., Yuen Foong Yu Group, Cheng Loong Corp. and Asia Smart Tag, are also developing RFID related products, according to the CEPD.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNFI members in favor of Taiwan-U.S. FTA: survey

TEXT.P: Over 98 percent of members of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) have expressed the wish for Taiwan to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with the Unites States, one of Taiwan's largest trade partners, as soon as possible, a CNFI spokesman said Saturday, citing a recent survey.
The results of the poll on CNFI members also showed that most respondents expressed the hope that the United States will remove or lower tariffs on a wide range of products exported from Taiwan.
Chen Mei-lan, a senior commissioner of the CNFI trade development committee, said tariff reduction has been the major concern and key issue in trade talks between Taiwan and the United States.

However, the survey also showed that several local industrial businesses, such as automobile and electric cable manufacturers, seem opposed to a Taiwan-U.S. FTA out of concerns that tariff cuts would lead to an inflow of competitive imports.
A total of 162 valid samples were collected in the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung politicians lobby for bigger share of government budget

TEXT.P: Public functionaries from Kaohsiung geared up to lobby for a bigger share of the central government budget for the southern port city while accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on a community outreach tour Saturday.
Braving heavy rains, President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu visited the Taoist Pao-An Temple in downtown Kaohsiung at around noon where they received a warm welcome from local residents.
After praying for the god's blessing for the country and people's well-being, Chen and Lu held a colloquium with local politicians from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

All of the elected officials and civil servants present at the meeting, including two DPP legislators, Kuan Bi-ling and Lee Kun-tze, took the opportunity to voice their opposition to the Executive Yuan's plan to have Taipei County share the 43 percent of the government's tax revenues originally set aside for Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities from 2008.

The Executive Yuan came up with the plan after the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Law on Local Government Systems May 5 that makes Taipei County eligible for special municipality status, giving it access to far greater budget resources.

Lee said the proposal, if implemented, would result in a NT$11.1 billion cut into the Kaohsiung City's budget allocation. Even though the Executive Yuan has proposed appropriating an additional NT$7 billion for the city, Lee said the amount is not enough to help the city government make ends meet.

The outspoken lawmaker urged the central government to conduct a thorough review of the existing budget allocation system and work out more plausible and reasonable measures to resolve the controversy.

If the central government fails to deal with the budget allocation issue properly, Lee said he is afraid that the DPP could lose the support of Kaohsiung City residents and even those in other cities and counties in southern Taiwan which has traditionally been the DPP's stronghold.

Also present at the gathering were Kaohsiung City Councilors Kang Yu-cheng and Huang Shu-mei, Kaohsiung City Government Secretary-General Hau Chien-sheng and Bureau of Civil Affairs Director Su Li-chiun, as well as former Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao, who has announced his bid to run for a legislative seat in Kaohsiung City in the next legislative elections slated for Jan. 12, 2008.
With a view to promoting balanced regional development, Yao urged President Chen to see to it that the proposed new international television channel be headquartered in Kaohsiung City.
Incumbent GIO Minister Shieh Jhy-wey announced earlier this week that the government plans to open an international TV outlet to help boost foreign understanding of Taiwan.

Stressing that he fully supports the proposal, Yao said the new broadcasting station should choose Kaohsiung as its home to help enhance the visibility of southern Taiwan. For years, Taiwan's major news media have been concentrated in northern Taiwan, particularly in Taipei City.

Later in the day, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu met with President Chen at a lunch gathering organized by a civic group, during which Chen Chu told the president that the current budget allocation system should be completely overhauled, instead of simply giving Taipei County a share of the tax revenues originally designated for Taipei and Kaohsiung.

"If Kaohsiung City's budget is abruptly cut by NT$11 billion, the city government will have a hard time continuing its development projects and welfare services for the disadvantaged, " Chen Chu was quoted as having told the president.
She even said that if the central government goes ahead with its allocation plan, it would be a tall order for her to stump for DPP candidates in the 2008 legislative and presidential elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-speed train delayed for over 60 minutes

TEXT.P: A north-bound high-speed train was delayed for more than 60 minutes Saturday, with the suspected cause being abnormalities with the brake system, Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) officials said.

The No. 502 train, which departed from Taichung at 7 a.m., was scheduled to arrive in Taipei at 8 a.m. However, it arrived at 9: 30 a.m., with the arrival times at each of the stations north of Hsinchu being at least 60 minutes later than scheduled, the officials said.

As a result of the delay, the THSRC was forced to cancel the train's south-bound trip from Taipei scheduled for 8 a.m., the officials said. Among the more than 800 passengers who bought tickets for the scheduled 8 a.m. south-bound train, some 200 managed to change to the No. 451 train that departed at 8:06 a.m., they said.

For the other passengers who were forced to take a train departing after 8: 30 a.m., those who arrived at their destinations between 30-60 minutes late received half refunds, while those who arrived at their destinations more than an hour late received full refunds.
Passengers who canceled their trip were also given full refunds, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA studying feasibility of building another runway at Hengchun airport

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) is studying the feasibility of building another runway at the Wuliting Airport in Hengchun in the southernmost Pingtung County, CAA Director General Billy K.C. Chang said Saturday.
Chang noted that during the winter, there are always strong winds in Hengchun, creating uncertainty factors for the landing and taking off of airplanes.
That is why the CAA is studying the feasibility of building another runway perpendicular to the original one to help airplanes overcome the strong wind problem.
He said that the airport cost around NT$539 million (US$16.33 million) to build and that initial estimates put the price tag for constructing another runway at NT$1 billion (US$30.3 million).
The money will be chiefly spent on the purchase of peripheral land and on coordinating with the state-owned Taiwan Power Co. to shift a high-pressure electric line underground, Chang said.
CAA officials said that the Hengchun airport was inaugurated in January 2004 to help relieve traffic congestion at the nearby Kengting Park during holiday periods.

Three airlines -- UNI Airways Corp., Trans Asia Airways and Mandarin Airlines -- originally offered flight services between Hengchun and Taipei and between Taichung and Taitung daily, but because the air passenger occupancy rate averaged less than 40 percent during the past two years, the number of flights has gradually been cut.
The CAA then coordinated to have Mandarin Airlines and Trans Asia Airways withdraw from the Taipei-Hengchun route. From Aug. 10, only UNI Airways will ply the route..
UNI AIrways Chairman Su Hung-yi said that Hengchun Peninsula attracts 5 million tourists every year, including many from Japan and Hong Kong.
The airline is preparing to cooperate with operators of leisure activities to promote travel to Hengchun on UNI airline, Su added.

DOC.HEADLINE: St. Lucia acting prime minister to visit Taiwan in September

TEXT.P: St. Lucian acting Prime Minister Stephenson King will visit Taiwan in September for the first time at the invitation of Taiwan's government, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Saturday.
King assumed the post of acting prime minister in May after 82-year-old Prime Minister John Compton was hospitalized in April.

The Caribbean island nation resumed formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan on May 1. It first established diplomatic ties with Taiwan in 1984, before switching diplomatic recognition to China in 1997.

The official said the MOFA had originally planned for President Chen Shui-bian to make a stopover in St. Lucia en route to Honduras to attend the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its Central American allies to be held later this month.

The plan was canceled because of a lack of preparation time as St. Lucia has to deal with its own political turmoil stemming from its prime minsters's health problems, the official said, adding that Taiwan's ambassador to St. Lucia, Tom Chou, only recently assumed his post and therefore would likely not have sufficient time to arrange a proper reception for the president.

According to the official, St. Lucia's ruling party is likely to hold a vote to choose a new party chairman and Compton is likely to be elected party chairman again. The focus will be who the first vice chairman will be as he could be Compton's successor.
As an alternative to the stopover plan, Taiwan's government invited King to visit Taiwan to better cement bilateral relations, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New immigrant families pose multilayer meanings to Taiwan society

TEXT.P: The increasing number of new immigrant families pose multilayer meanings to Taiwan society as it represents a challenge, a must-do task to learn from different cultures, and an opportunity for a brand new future, participants to a seminar on new immigrant issues said Saturday.

"The biggest challenge for any foreign spouse coming from Southeast Asia is the language barrier. However, observations showed they picked up language quickly. And, contrary to the conventional thinking, their children, being in a multi- culture and multi-lingual family, are at an advantage, " said Tang Jing-lan, chief executive officer of the Good Shepherd Sisters Taiwan, in a seminar focused on international marriages.

As of June 2007, the number of marriage migrants to Taiwan has surpassed 390,000, including 136,115 coming from Southeast Asian countries and 256,590 from China, according to a Ministry of Interior (MOI) statistics.

There are still many stigmas to be eliminated in Taiwan about new immigrants, for instance that most children with "foreign mothers" have learning difficulties and growth retardation -- both false concepts that have been proven incorrect by numerous surveys, said Edwin Yang, a professor at the College of International Studies and Education for Overseas Chinese, National Taiwan Normal University.

In fact, Taiwan and Vietnam, where most foreign spouses came from, are both countries with diverse cultures, which is why shouldn't be difficult for Taiwanese to accept and learn from a different culture, Yang said.

"We're now at a time of a global village and our generation will be citizens of a global community who have to be always learning something new. I'm glad that my children and I have the opportunity to learn from the Vietnamese culture, " said Lin Jian-chung, who was married to a Vietnamese 10 years ago and have three children. Lin is now a volunteer for Eden Social Welfare Foundation (ESWF).
However, Lin said, the husbands and family members should also learn to help their wives to adjust to a new environment, culture and language.

The future of Taiwan will be at least slightly different because of new immigrants, said Chien Ya-huei, who works for ESWF. The latest statistics showed that 11.69% of babies born in Taiwan in 2006 were born into new immigrant families.
"It's possible that we will have legislators whose mothers are Vietnamese. And our national policy will have to take care of people who came from new immigrant families, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dispersing homeless at train station won't solve problem: official

TEXT.P: Dispersing the homeless people who gather at the Taipei Railway Station will not help solve the problem as they will surely return, a Taipei City Government official said Saturday.
Shih Yi-ling, head of the Department of Social Welfare, also said that homeless hanging out around the railway station and other transportation depots is a common phenomenon around the world.

The relevant authorities have the duty to maintain order by taking action, she said, adding that her department will respect the decisions that they make in carrying out their duties. However, she added that she is opposed to forceful dispersal or imposition of a loitering ban as such measures would "create human rights disputes."

She made the remarks one day after the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) decided to take action against the homeless at the Taipei Railway Station so as to maintain the station's image of being clean and orderly.

TRA officials noted that the basement parking lots at the Taipei Railway Stations are occupied by homeless people all year round, with some of the homeless also using the restrooms in the station to do their laundry or bathe, which they said has frightened some passengers.
They added that there have been incidents of fire breaking out in the winter time when the homeless build fires and huddle around them to keep warm.

The TRA officials said Friday that Taipei station officials will disperse the homeless at 7 a.m. and 5 p.m. daily and that after the last train departs at 12: 20 a.m. each night, there will be another clearing operation.
Shih said that the department has coordinated with the TRA concerning the homeless problem and has made its stance clear.
"Dispersing the homeless is only a temporary solution as they are bound to return as the experience of other countries has shown, " she said.

She denied that the department has not been active in seeking a solution, saying that it has sought cooperation with the TRA and has offered the homeless job opportunities or provisional housing rent subsidies.

She said that Taipei Railway Station is usually the place where people from central and southern Taiwan looking for job opportunities in Taipei City first arrive, adding that many of those who cannot find jobs immediately seek temporary shelter at the station. She further said that with government assistance, this group of homeless will be easier to handle.

However, she admitted that some homeless don't expect the government to interfere in their lives and that they have no intention of working or staying in accommodations provided by the government, adding that this group of homeless people is the most difficult to deal with.

DOC.HEADLINE: Philippines visit fruitful: DPP chairman
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 11 (CNA) 08/11/07 20:50:47 (By Emerson Lim & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun flew back to Taiwan Saturday after concluding a three-day visit in the Philippines.

Describing the trip as "fruitful, " Yu told CNA ahead of his departure for home that he visited several influential Philippine politic leaders, met with DPP supporters and Taiwanese expatriates living in the country, and inspected the DPP branch chapter's operations here during the trip.

In talks with representatives of Taiwanese expatriate groups and DPP supporters, Yu said they all displayed determination in promoting Taiwan's efforts to become a "normal country." He said they also promised to vote for the DPP and the party's presidential candidate, Frank Hsieh, in the major elections slated to be held in 2008.

On party diplomacy, Yu said he visited the Philippine congress and the Liberal Party headquarters in Manila. During the visits, he exchanged views with influential Philippine politicians on a wide range of issues, including those concerning bilateral Taiwan-Philippine trade and economic relations, regional security, trilateral United States-Japan-China ties, and Taiwan's controversial plan to hold a referendum on its bid for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan.

Most of the Philippine political heavyweights expressed concerns on issues concerning the democratic movement and human rights in China, as well as on the roles that the United States and Japan play in the Asia-Pacific region, according to Yu.

Yu was originally scheduled to proceed to Thailand Saturday after concluding his visit in Manila. According to the DPP branch chapter in Manila, Yu had planned to meet with Taiwanese expatriates in Thailand but was forced to cancel the journey after receiving an abrupt notice from Thailand's Ministry of Foreign Affairs two days before his planned arrival that it would not grant him a visa.
The DPP chapter claimed that China pressured Thailand not to issue Yu a visa on the grounds that he is an advocate of Taiwan independence.
Speaking on Thailand's decision not to grant him a visa, Yu said he feels regret over the decision. He also condemned China for its suppression of Taiwan in the international arena.

Yu has been promoting ways to make Taiwan a "normal country, " including a resolution within the party that will push for changing the country's official title from "Republic of China" to "Taiwan" and formulating a new constitution more suitable for the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate meets with Singaporean leaders

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , met with top Singaporean leaders Saturday for wide-ranging talks at the start of his campaign tour of Southeast Asian nations.
Hsieh and his campaign aides were whisked to Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's official residence for a luncheon upon their arrival at Changi Airport.
Later in the day, Hsieh reportedly met with Singapore's Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew, who is also Lee Hsien Loong's father.

Hsieh would not confirm whether he did in fact meet with the two most influential Singporean political figures, saying that he must respect the wishes of his hosts who prefer to keep their meetings confidential. However, Hsieh's campaign aides later confirmed that Hsieh had indeed met with both men.
During an informal evening meeting with Taiwan journalists covering his current Southeast Asian tour, Hsieh said he had "met with certain important old friends" on his first day in Singapore.
"I have not been here for 10 years. I'm delighted to meet with my old Singaporean friends," Hsieh said, adding that he exchanged views with them on a wide range of topics of mutual interest.

According to Hsieh, their talks touched on Taiwan's elections, the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's policy toward cross-strait ties, Singapore's role in the international arena, exploration of business opportunities in the Middle East, Singapore's experience in waste water treatment, and the city-state's opening to tourism-centered casino operations.

On cross-strait relations, Hsieh said international friends tend to advocate maintaining the current peaceful status quo. Noting that the key point in this regard lies in the definition of the status quo, Hsieh said that the DPP defines Taiwan's present status quo as an independent sovereign state and will strive to safeguard this independent status quo.

In contrast, Hsieh said Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) just advocates maintaining the status quo and leaves open the question of Taiwan's future. It is dangerous if the KMT's advocacy prevails. The KMT lacks a definite direction and such a deficiency will hinder Taiwan's development and even spell a disaster for Taiwan, he cautioned.

Noting that Taiwan needs to have a clear-cut national goal and definite development direction as well as an awareness of its current place. "Our strategy must comply with our direction and contribute to our goal, " Hsieh said, adding that Taiwan must seek strategic security.

If he is elected the next president, Hsieh said he relentlessly seek dialogue and communications with China so that the international community, the Asia- Pacific region and Taiwan society will feel ease without misgivings about the possibility of a cross-strait conflict.

"If elected, I'll also adopt a policy that favors openness toward cross-strait trade and economic exchanges. Nevertheless, I will not compromise our national sovereignty and dignity under any circumstances, " Hsieh said, adding that he opposes the KMT's cross-strait common market overture.
Hsieh said he has also briefed Singaporean political bigwigs on his "Six Stars" plan which concerns the division of Taiwan into six major regions, with each region having the scale of one Singapore.
"The plan is mainly aimed at facilitating resources sharing and enhancing our country's competitiveness," Hsieh explained.

Hsieh also met with Singaporean Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong to exchange views on matters of mutual concern. In the evening, he visited Singapore's most famous tourist spot -- the Santosa Island which will be developed into a recreational, sightseeing, convention and gambling center.

Hsieh's current campaign journey will also take him to Indonesia where he will meet with Taiwanese expatriates to court their support for his presidential bid as well as meet with Indonesian political heavyweights.

Prior to his departure for Singapore, Hsieh said he is scheduled to return to Taipei Aug. 15 in time to attend a carnival-style evening rally at 228 Peace Park in down Taipei, during which he will formally announce who his running mate will be.

The Aug. 15 rally will be the first large-scale campaign forum since Hsieh wins the party's candidacy for the 2008 presidential election. All DPP bigwigs, including Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, will be present at the occasion to lend their support behind Hsieh's presidential bid and underscore internal party unity.

Speculation about Hsieh's running mate has been rife. While some party members prefer to see Hsieh team up with his presidential primary rival -- former Premier Su Tseng-chang, Hsieh himself reportedly would like to pick former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan as his running mate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indonesians in Kaohsiung celebrate Independence Day

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 Indonesian spouses of Taiwan nationals celebrated the upcoming Indonesian Independence Day with music, dance and Indonesian delicacies at an immigrant services center in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Saturday.

Indonesian Independence Day, which falls on Aug. 17, commemorates the end of Japan's occupation of the country between 1942-45 during the final years of World War II. Before the Japanese occupation, Indonesia was under Dutch colonial rule for three-and-a-half centuries.

Statistics compiled by the municipal government's Social Affairs Bureau show that there are more than 2,000 Indonesian spouses of Taiwanese citizens in the southern port city, with many living in the city's Chichin, Hsiaokang and Chienchen districts.

An Indonesian spouse taking part in the celebration said Indonesian Independence Day is as important to Indonesians as Lunar New Year's Day is to the people of Taiwan. She said that patriotic celebrations begin weeks before Aug. 17 and that the national flag can be seen everywhere in the country during this period.

She said that many of the Indonesian spouses living in Kaohsiung miss their home country and the Independence Day activities and therefore decided to hold the celebration to feel less homesick and have a good time.

Wu Chiou-o, chairwoman of a club for Indonesian spouses, expressed the hope that these kinds of activities would also allow Taiwan nationals to gain a better understanding of the cultures of many of Taiwan's new immigrants.
In the celebration, participants also conveyed their affection for Taiwan by reading loving declarations and expressing the hope of assimilating into local society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Family members to travel to Finland to help murder suspect

TEXT.P: Three family members of a Taiwanese woman being held incommunicado on suspicion of killing her three children in suburban Helsinki will travel to Finland Monday to assist in legal proceedings and other affairs, family sources said Saturday.

The woman's father, uncle and younger brother will fly to Finland to help with handling of the aftermath, the sources said, adding that they will retain lawyers to defend the woman, identified only by her maiden name of Fu.
Fu's father said he was shocked by the tragedy, saying he couldn't believe that his daughter who had pursued advanced study in Britain had committed the alleged crime.
According to her family, Fu worked at a Finnish postal office and maintained close contact with her family in Kaohsiung City's Autzuti district in southern Taiwan.

Her father said Fu often chatted with him over phone. Nevertheless, he said Fu had never told any family member that she had frequently fallen victim to domestic violence and was subject to protection and observation of a Finnish social counseling agency.

"My daughter was a brave and strong-willed woman. She never mentioned any woeful things in her daily life. We didn't know her distressing plight until a Finnish pastor contacted us after the tragic incident," said the senior Fu.

He recalled that Fu divorced her husband in March 2006. While Fu secured the custody of their 1-year-old son, the guardianship of their 8-year-old twin daughters went to their father. Fu could only get together with her twin daughters on weekends.
Fu's divorced husband reportedly had often banned the twin daughters from visiting their mother and had taken away the passports of Fu and their three young children.
Sheng Pei-huang, Taiwan's representative to Helsinki, said Friday that Finnish police have rejected his repeated request to visit Fu because she has Finnish nationality.

According to Sheng, major Finnish media outlets have given prominent coverage of the tragic killing since last Sunday, although the media and Finnish police have not revealed the motivation or other details.

To the best of his understanding, Sheng said Fu married her Finnish husband more than 10 years ago and that she came with her children to Taiwanese expatriate activities during this year's Dragon Boat Festival, which fell on June 19 this year.
There are around 60 Taiwanese expatriates in Finland, most of whom are Taiwanese women married to Finnish men and who usually have frequent exchanges with each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug.12, 2007

The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet mulling ways to resolve budget allocation controversy

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will unveil various plausible options in the coming few days in an effort to resolve the controversy surrounding budget allocations among municipality governments, Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Saturday.

Shieh made the remarks after the China Times, a local daily, reported earlier the same day that Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu will refuse to stump for ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates in the next legislative and presidential elections scheduled for early next year in protest against a Cabinet proposal to have Taipei County share 43 percent of the government's tax revenues originally set aside for Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities.

An Executive Yuan panel came up with the proposal earlier this week after the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Law on Local Government Systems May 5 that makes Taipei County eligible for special municipality status, giving it access to far greater budget resources.

According to the newspaper report, the Kaohsiung city government will see an NT$11 billion cut into its 2008 budget if the proposal is indeed implemented, causing Chen to worry about the city's finances.

After talking with Chen's aides, Shieh said the mayor was not intending to use her refusal to campaign for DPP candidates as a leverage to pressure the Executive Yuan not to cut the southern port city's budget allocation.
"What the mayor said was that the planned budget cut would make it difficult for her to woo Kaohsiung residents' support for DPP candidates," Shieh said.

As a matter of fact, he went on, it remains uncertain whether the proposal for Taipei County to share 43 percent of the government's tax revenues originally designated for the country's two special municipalities.

"Relevant government agencies are still mulling feasible measures based on each administrative district's practical demand or special needs, "Shieh said, adding that in the long run, the current law governing allocation of tax revenues among local governments will be amended to meet the new national situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 12, or the 30th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1099: The Crusaders defeat the Egyptians at Ascalon on the Palestine coast in the First Crusade.
1813: Austria declares war against Napoleon.
1848: George Stephenson, the British railway pioneer who built the first passenger railway in 1825, dies at the age of 67. He also developed the first practical steam locomotive, the "Rocket."
1877: A group of people witness a public demonstration of a new device, a phonograph that records the human voice, at Thomas Edison's "invention factory" at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1881: Cecil B. De Mille, the American film director, is born. He is legendary for his large-scale Biblical and historical epics such as "The Ten Commandments," "Samson and Delilah" and "Cleopatra."
1898: The United States and Spain sign a protocol ending the Spanish-American War, with Spain relinquishing Cuba and ceding Puerto Rico to the United States. In addition, the Hawaiian Islands are formally annexed by the United States.
1908: The Ford Motor Co. introduces its Model T car, a sturdy, black, four- cylinder number that comes in two versions: tourer and roadster. Both retail at incredibly low prices: the roadster at US$825 and the tourer for just US$25 more.
1912: William Booth, a Methodist minister who founded the Salvation Army in London in 1865, dies of illness in London at the age of 83. The Salvation Army works to foster a love of God and to provide for the needy. It offers its services to people of any race, creed, sex or age.
1914: Britain declares war on Austria-Hungary.
1946: The stolen body of dictator Benito Mussolini is found in northern Italy.
1948: The United States recognizes South Korea.
1954: The last batch of United Nations forces in the Korean War pulls out of Korea.
1961: Chen Chia-keng, an overseas Chinese from Singapore and founder of Amoy University, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 88.
1970: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and West Germany sign a non- aggression pact in Moscow.
1970: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane of the Republic of China crashes into a mountain on its way from Hualien in eastern Taiwan to Taipei, killing or injuring 31 people.
1978: Taiwan's fastest electrified train, the Tzu Chiang Express, makes a test run between Taipei and Taichung.
1978: Mainland China and Japan sign a treaty of peace and friendship in Beijing.
1985: A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 Jumbo jet crashes into Mount Osutaka on its way from Tokyo to Osaka, killing all but four of the 524 people aboard.
1990: Beijing's attempt to restore its tarnished image after the slaughter in Tiananmen Square receives a severe setback. Official documentation of the disturbances now reveals that more than 450 were killed, the majority by bullets, while 750 were injured and 3,000 were detained.
1991: Two mainland journalists arrive in Taipei, marking the first-ever visit to the ROC by the mainland Chinese press.
1995: The United States government decides to stop all nuclear testing.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for the Dominican Republic to attend the Aug. 16 inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez.
1999: CAL signs an agreement with Airbus Industrie of Europe for a US$1.8 billion order for seven A340-300 passenger jets, with an option for one more A340-300 and four A330-300s.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh urges mainland China to produce a president through popular elections so as to bridge the gap between the political systems and public opinion on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political party formed by some of former President Lee Teng-hui's followers is formally inaugurated, with a written congratulatory message from President Chen Shui-bian read out at the ceremony.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way for a man to be true to himself. If he does not know what is good, a man cannot be true to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Space shuttle heat shield damaged during liftoff
NASA said it has detected ab apparent gouge on the space shuttle Endeavor's heat shield during a routine inspection Friday, after the orbiter docked with the International Space Station (ISS).

DOC.HEADLINE: Family members to travel to Finland to help murder suspect

TEXT.P: Three family members of a Taiwanese woman being held incommunicado on suspicion of killing her three children in suburban Helsinki will travel to Finland Monday to assist in legal proceedings and other affairs, family sources said Saturday.

The woman's father, uncle and younger brother will fly to Finland to help with handling of the aftermath, the sources said, adding that they will retain lawyers to defend the woman, identified only by her maiden name of Fu.
Fu's father said he was shocked by the tragedy, saying he couldn't believe that his daughter who had pursued advanced study in Britain had committed the alleged crime.
According to her family, Fu worked at a Finnish postal office and maintained close contact with her family in Kaohsiung City's Autzuti district in southern Taiwan.

Her father said Fu often chatted with him over phone. Nevertheless, he said Fu had never told any family member that she had frequently fallen victim to domestic violence and was subject to protection and observation of a Finnish social counseling agency.

"My daughter was a brave and strong-willed woman. She never mentioned any woeful things in her daily life. We didn't know her distressing plight until a Finnish pastor contacted us after the tragic incident," said the senior Fu.

He recalled that Fu divorced her husband in March 2006. While Fu secured the custody of their 1-year-old son, the guardianship of their 8-year-old twin daughters went to their father. Fu could only get together with her twin daughters on weekends.
Fu's divorced husband reportedly had often banned the twin daughters from visiting their mother and had taken away the passports of Fu and their three young children.
Sheng Pei-huang, Taiwan's representative to Helsinki, said Friday that Finnish police have rejected his repeated request to visit Fu because she has Finnish nationality.

According to Sheng, major Finnish media outlets have given prominent coverage of the tragic killing since last Sunday, although the media and Finnish police have not revealed the motivation or other details.

To the best of his understanding, Sheng said Fu married her Finnish husband more than 10 years ago and that she came with her children to Taiwanese expatriate activities during this year's Dragon Boat Festival, which fell on June 19 this year.
There are around 60 Taiwanese expatriates in Finland, most of whom are Taiwanese women married to Finnish men and who usually have frequent exchanges with each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to visit Central America via Alaska
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 11 (CNA) 08/12/07 15:38:16 (By Michelle Tsai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will travel via Alaska on his way to Central America, and again on his way home later this month, Taiwan's deputy representative in the United States confirmed Saturday.

It has been decided in principle by U.S. and Taiwan officials that President Chen's plane will make short refueling stops in Anchorage, Alaska on its way to and from Central America, although details of the transit plans will still be arranged by officials from the two sides next week, Huang Wei-feng said.

The main purpose of Chen's upcoming visit to Central America -- beginning Aug. 20 -- would be taking part in the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its Central American allies, to be held in Honduras.

As President Chen and Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials value the bilateral ties between Taiwan and the United States and hope that the ties will not be affected by any transit stop by Taiwan's leaders, they have agreed that Chen's transit plans will be kept as simple as possible, according to Huang.
Chen is expected to use his visit to cement relations with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America in the wake of the severing of formal ties with Costa Rica in June, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd Democratic Pacific Union assembly to open in Taipei Tuesday

TEXT.P: The second assembly of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , an international body aimed at promoting "democracy, peace, and prosperity" in the Asian Pacific region and the world, is scheduled to take place in Taipei Aug. 14-15.

Vice President Annette Lu, founder and chairwoman of the DPU, said that a DPU board meeting will be held Monday, when a new chairman or chairwoman of the union is expected to be elected to lead DPU operations and activities for the next two years.

President Chen Shui-bian is expected to deliver a keynote speech at the opening ceremony Tuesday for the assembly, which will be attended by nearly 100 foreign guests from 33 nations, including Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Morales Carazo.

Meanwhile, the DPU will also convene the second Pacific Congressional Caucus meeting Monday, with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng presiding over the meeting to discuss how to use digital technology to carry out congressional reforms.

Furthermore, Lu said, another meeting is also slated for Monday on the DPU's forming an alliance, involving 15 domestic universities and 26 foreign ones, to serve as a platform for faculty and students from these 41 varsities to swap ideas and strengthen academic exchanges.

Discussions of the second DPU assembly are expected to focus on three issues -- the new situation in the Pacific Ocean area after the 2008 Beijing Olympics Games; how to formulate green energy policies in the era of global warming; and how to apply Taiwan's information technology to the digitization of all DPU member countries.
Calling for wider local media coverage of the event, Lu said the assembly is an important diplomatic event at a time when Taiwan is facing a difficult situation in the international arena.
Lu added that if she is elected as the chairwoman of the DPU again this year, she will organize more activities in other countries.

Lu had played an instrumental role in bringing about the establishment of the DPU -- a non-governmental organization designed to serve as a platform for exchanges among the Pacific Rim countries in the promotion of democracy, peace and prosperity, and other common values -- in Taipei on Aug. 14, 2005, with 26 countries and areas taking part as permanent members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Water Corp. trying to relieve Penghu's water shortage

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Water Corp. is working on emergency plans to relieve the imminent water shortage facing residents of the outlying Penghu island group.
Penghu's demand for fresh water has increased in recent years as a result of booming tourism.

The two tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- that passed over Taiwan last week have effectively ended the drought in eastern Taiwan and replenished reservoirs in most parts of Taiwan proper, but have failed to alleviate the water shortage in Penghu.
Penghu's three reservoirs currently have only 64,000 metric tons of water left. With water being pumped out at a rate of 5,000 tons a day, that amount could last barely two weeks.
The Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs has instructed Taiwan Water Corp. to work out emergency plans to ensure that water supply to Penghu will not be disrupted.

Taiwan Water Corp. has indicated it is working on a plan to ship 6,000 metric tons of water from Taiwan to Penghu twice every three days from Aug. 15. The company will try to find a company willing to undertake the job for a fee through a second tender after its first tender failed to attract interested bidders last week.

If the second tender again fails to find a successful bidder, Taiwan Water Corp. will resort to a backup plan to pump underground water from selected wells that have not yet been salinized, senior officials of the company said.
Penghu now has three sea water desalination plants and five well water desalination plants, with a total water output of 17,980 metric tons, which can meet about half of Penghu's normal water needs.

The government is building two additional sea water desalination plants in Makung and Hsiyu, and when completed by the end of this year, they will produce 5,500 tons and 750 tons of fresh water daily respectively.

La Repubblica: House fire kills four kids.
Four children were killed in a house fire in Livorno, central Italy on Friday night. The victims' parents were arrested for leaving their kids of the minor age at home alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate awaits former premier's word on joining ballot
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 12 (CNA) 08/12/07 17:31:45 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh reiterated Sunday that if former Premier Su Tseng-chang agrees, he is positive that the DPP will field a Hsieh-Su ticket for Taiwan's hotly-contested 2008 presidential race.

Hsieh, who is currently visiting Singapore and is scheduled to return to Taipei Aug. 15 to announce his choice of running mate, said that he recently extended an invitation to Su to serve as his running mate and has also visited Su's family, but until Sunday, he said, he has not heard an answer from Su.
Hsieh will be returning to Taipei Wednesday, in time to attend a carnival-style evening rally at 228 Peace Park in down Taipei, during which he will formally announce his choice of running mate.

Speculation about Hsieh's choice of running mate has been rife. While some DPP party members prefer to see Hsieh team up with Su, Hsieh himself reportedly would like to pick former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, a woman who is devotedly supported by the country's Hakka people.
Also on Sunday, a DPP lawmaker urged Hsieh from Taipei to act "in all sincerity" if he is determined to choose Su his running mate for the 2008 race.

DPP Legislator Wu Ping-jui said that if a Hsieh-Su ticket is to be formed, Hsieh should demonstrate the greatest possible sincerity because Su is a statesman who would consent to decisions taken to best serve the DPP's and the country's interests and would not insist on his own stance.

A cable television channel reported Sunday that Su, currently in the United States on a private visit, will probably decide whether or not to prepare to return to Taiwan these two days as Hsieh is expected to announce Aug. 15 whether he will pick Yeh or Su -- his presidential primary rival -- as his running mate.
Su's aides in his Taipei office, however, denied the TV report, saying that they have not been informed of anything of the sort.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foster families in Kaohsiung cited by city government

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government cited nearly 100 foster families Sunday for their love and devotion in caring for orphaned and less privileged children.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu presided over a ceremony at the Dream Mall shopping center's conference room in honor of the foster families.

Among the foster parents were Chang Chu-hua and his wife Wu Hsiu-chen, who have reared 20 foster children, and Wang Chung-yi and his wife Hsu Mei-jung, who have raised 16 foster children in addition to their own three children.

They received a happy surprise when officials of the city government's Social Affairs Bureau arranged a meeting between them and "secret guests" who turned out to be some of the now grown children they brought up but have not seen for many years.
The reunion was a moving occasion, with the foster parents and the children they have helped hugging each other and weeping with joy.

The Kaohsiung mayor pointed out that Kaohsiung's foster family program has entered the 25th year and allowed more than 1,000 less fortunate children to grow up with the loving care of foster families.
She said she was very grateful that so many kind, loving foster parents have helped to make the program a success.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cheng Kung University to sponsor seminar on emerging technology
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 11 (CNA) 08/12/07 17:46:45 (By Lillian Lin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan, Taiwan will host the 2008 Emerging Information and Technology Conference (EITC) in the southern city, NCKU President Michael Ming-Chiao Lai announced Saturday in the U.S. state of New Jersey.
Lai made the announcement after the conclusion of this year's EITC, which was held at Princeton University Aug. 9-10 and brought together more than 100 Taiwan-born scholars and experts.

The first ever EITC was launched in 2000 with the aim of providing a platform for Taiwan academics and professionals residing in the United States to exchange views on technology developments and innovations.

During the initial period, topics discussed at the EITC were mainly drawn from the field of information technology, whereas this year, the symposium explored a wide variety of subjects, ranging from topics related to biotechnology, nanotechnology, and green energy technology and the development of emerging financial services.

Several members of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, were also invited to deliver keynote speeches at this year's forum, including Gregory Chow, a professor of Economics at Princeton University; Way Kuo, professor and dean of Engineering at University of Tennessee; Ma Tso-ping, professor and chairman of Electrical Engineering at Yale University and NCKU President Lai.

Feng Da-hsuan, NCKU Executive Vice President for Research Affairs, said as the EITC will for the first time to be held in southern Taiwan next year that the NCKU would do its utmost to assemble as many as outstanding and legendary scholars to take part in the conference. He added experts expected to participate will come from many Asian countries in addition to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should learn from Singapore's success: DPP candidate
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 12 (CNA) 08/12/07 17:49:24 (By Hsieh Chia-chen, Charles Kang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Taiwan should learn from Singapore's achievements in expanding diplomatic relations with the Middle East and Arab countries and in financial globalization, while touring a resort destination in the city state Saturday.

Earlier the same day, Hsieh reportedly met with Singaporean Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong, who is in charge of Middle East affairs, but Hsieh refused to confirm it during an evening meeting with Taiwan journalists covering his current Southeast Asian campaign tour in the Sentosa resort spot.
Hsieh said he cannot reveal with whom he met, but admitted he had indeed met with old Singaporean friends and exchanged views with them on a wide range of issues of mutual concerns.
He added Singapore has a lot of experience that Taiwan can learn from, while Taiwan also has something valuable to share.
However, Hsieh noted Taiwan's financial laws should be reformed and updated in order to raise its global competitiveness and keep abreast of the rest of the world.

According to Hsieh, as Singapore has provided US$3.03 billion to operate resort centers, including casinos, in a bid to develop tourism, he will visit Singapore casinos and gambling facilities during his current tour of the country.

He said that during his tenure as premier he favored having foreign investors form joint ventures in setting up resort casinos on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Penghu under the premise that local ecology and residents' lives would not be compromised.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins two gold at 2007 Universiade in Bangkok
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 11 (CNA) 08/12/07 18:02:51 (By Wu Shye-chang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has won two gold, one silver and five bronze medals as of Saturday at the 2007 World University Games, in Bangkok, Thailand, helping Taiwan secure 12th in terms of number of medals won.

Taiwanese athletes performed particularly well in the taekwondo event, snatching one gold, one silver, and one bronze Saturday, the third day of the games, after Lin An-ni earned the first gold for Taiwan the previous day.

Doha Asian Games gold medalist Su Li-wen took one gold in the women's 63-kilogram category after defeating Croatian Josipa Kusanic 1to -1, while Tseng Ching-hsiang lost to Iran's Mohammad Bagheri Motamed in the men's under 67-kilogram class to take silver, Hsiao Wan-tien lost 7-3 to South Korea's Lin Su Jeong in the women's under 59- kilogram class to take bronze.
In addition, Taiwan took bronze in the badminton team event after losing to the host country Thailand 3-0 in the semifinal.

As for the tennis event, Taiwanese player Chan Chin-wei advanced past the women's third round of play after defeating her French rival 6-0 and 6-2, while Chen Ti and Chuang Chia-jung also advanced in mixed doubles.

In the archery category, Taiwan's women's squad secured fourth place, while Chen Shih-wei has gained second place in the men's individual double trap shooting. Taiwan currently stands in second place in the men's double trap shooting team tournament and has an excellent opportunity to take further medals for the country.
Meanwhile, Chinese Taipei women's softball team overpowered South Africa 18-2 in their first event of the games to reach the next round.

DOC.HEADLINE: New tropical depression may become typhoon and head toward Taiwan

TEXT.P: A new tropical depression located east of the Philippines is likely to develop into a tropical storm or typhoon and head toward Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) announced in a forecast Sunday.
Wu Teh-jung, director of the CWB's Weather Forecast Center, said the low pressure system has a better structure than the two tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- that swept across Taiwan last week.

Wu added that as of Sunday afternoon the center of the low pressure system was located about 1,600 km east-southeast of Taiwan and appeared stagnant, and that the CWB will keep a close eye on its future development.

If the tropical depression is upgraded to a tropical storm or typhoon, it will take the name "Sepat," contributed by Malaysia, and be the eighth named storm in the western Pacific this year. Sepat is the name of a freshwater fish found in Malaysia's rivers and swamps.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education minister's son quits job with Kaohsiung city government

TEXT.P: The son of Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng quit his job with the Kaohsiung city government Sunday after he was reportedly involved in a scuffle in Tainan the previous day.

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said she had approved Tu Min-yi's resignation after consulting her aides out of concern that the junior Tu's reckless behavior might tarnish the image of Chen's administration.

Tu min-yi submitted his resignation after a man claimed that he was roughed up by Tu outside a KTV parlor, or Karaoke box, in Tainan City early Saturday after he talked pleasantly with afemale friend who accompanied Tu to the KTV.

The man reported the incident to police later Saturday claiming that Tu ripped off his necklace and tore his clothes during the incident. The man stopped short of filing a charge against Tu, according to the police.
Tu refused to comment on the incident Sunday but city officials quoted him as claiming that the media reports about it were incorrect.

Tu also made headlines June 11 when employed as a commissioner at the Kaohsiung Organizing Committee for the 2009 World Games under the Kaohsiung City Government and worked in an office with the mayor's close aides in the city hall.
The mayor denied critics claims at that time that Tu's father was pulling strings to get his son the job in Kaohsiung.

The junior Tu is not a stranger to controversy. He made headlines while serving his compulsory military service for staging dancing party at his father's official resident in Taipei and enjoying in a drinking binge with hostesses at a pub.

DOC.HEADLINE: Washington urging U.N. to correct statement about Taiwan

TEXT.P: Washington is urging the U. N. Secretariat to correct its statement that Taiwan is part of the territory of the People's Republic of China (PROC) , a Republic of China (ROC) diplomat posted to Washington said Saturday.

Huang Wei-feng, ROC deputy representative to the United States told a group of Taiwanese living in the United States that Washington will keep prodding the U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon to correct his statement made in March in a letter denying Taiwan's request to join the U.N. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
In that letter to Nauru's U.N. ambassador who relayed Taiwan's above request, Ban said Taiwan is part of PROC's territory, citing the resolution 2758 of the U.N. General Assembly in 1971.
Huang rebutted the U.N. chief's statement, saying that the resolution 2758 simply acknowledged the PROC as the sole legitimate government of China and gave it China's seat in the United Nations.
He said that Ban had made a great mistake by thinking that resolution having accepted China's claim over Taiwan.
This misunderstanding, if left uncorrected in U.N. official correspondence, will hinder Taiwan's efforts to join international organizations as a state with sovereignty, Huang said.

The United States which only acknowledges China's claim that Taiwan is part of its territory didn't see eye to eye with Ban on this issue and was pushing the U.N. chief to correct his statement, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to push for Taiwan's U.N. membership

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung vowed Sunday to push for Taiwan's U.N. membership, force the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to give up its ill-gotten assets, and keep Taiwan's indigenous regime survive.

In a rally organized in this port city by the Presbyian Church in Taiwan to mark the 30th anniversary of its issuance of a human right declaration, the premier said changing the country's name from the Republic of China to Taiwan and formulating a brand-new constitution are also instrumental in fulfilling the goals unveiled in the declaration.

Noting that his administration is pushing for the transitional justice, the premier said, this would be impossible unless the country's indigenous regime could survive in the upcoming presidential elections.

The Rev. Kao Chun-ming who was chief of the Taiwan Presbyian Church when it issued the declaration under the KMT's iron-fist rule, said at the rally that he was worried about the consequences of revealing the declaration which called for Taiwan independence, but he believed a good Christian would also be a good citizen who should struggle to make the state a better place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 13, or the first day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, located at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish- American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho" and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander in chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Zedong names Beijing as Communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1974: Mort Young, deputy editor-in-chief of Hearst Newspapers in the United States, arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit.
1975: An eight-member Taiwan dance troupe leaves for La Paz to perform at celebrations marking Bolivia's independence day.
1976: Over 140 youths from 20 nations join in the opening ceremony of the International Youth Recreation Tour to the Republic of China sponsored by the China Youth Corps.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves extension of the Sino-Uruguayan Agreement on Agricultural Cooperation for two years.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seekers freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Communist Chinese Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria, to Seoul, South Korea, on May 5, 1983.
1989: Two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of the balloons plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1993: A hotel collapses in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
1999: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan estimates that the ROC's economic growth rate will reach 5.5 percent for the year.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and his 200-member entourage leave Taipei, beginning a 13-day visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa.
2001: Academia Sinica member George C. Tiao becomes the first scholar and the first ethnic Chinese to receive both the prestigious Wilks Memorial Award and the Julius Shiskin Award in statistics in the same year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Trust is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."
