DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical Storm Sepat could hit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Tropical Storm Sepat, forming in waters east of the Philippines early Monday, is likely to move toward Taiwan over the coming week, forecasters at the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.

The forecasters said they are closely monitoring the movement of the tropical storm, which was centered 1,530 km east-northeast of Manila at 2 a.m. and was moving slowly west-southwesterly before turning westerly.

Although the storm is still 1,600 km from Taiwan and is expected to maintain its slow movement over the next couple of days, it is likely to continue to gain momentum and approach the island, they said.
Also Monday, the CWB again warned residents in central, southern and southeastern parts of Taiwan to prepare for heavy rains triggered by a strong southwest air current.

In the mountainous areas of southern Taiwan, residents should be on guard against possible landslides and mudflows brought about by excessively heavy rains, while those living in downstream sections of rivers should watch out for possible floods, the forecasters said.

From midnight until 6: 50 a.m. Monday, accumulated rainfall registered 216 mm in Wanluan, Pingtung County, 200 mm in Kaohsiung County's Taoyuan and Sanmin areas, and 182 mm in Taitung County's Tajen township, according to CWB tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
President reiterates need for new constitution

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Monday the necessity for Taiwan to tailor- make a new constitution that is viable and up to date to enhance the country's competitiveness.

Addressing the issue during a conference on the challenges faced by new democracies held by the Taiwan Thinktank, Chen identified what he called the stiff, outdated and illusory "greater China ideology" as the major enemy and culprit that has been hampering, delaying and impairing the development of Taiwan's constitutional democracy.

In order to sustain such an ideology, the past authoritarian rulers of Taiwan turned the position of president into that of a monarch, while the legislature, which had originally been designed to be elected via regular elections, was made into "a virtually eternal body," Chen noted.

"Furthermore, a constitution that was never approved by the Taiwanese people was imposed on us, and no revision or changes have so far been allowed to be made to the original text of the constitution," Chen said.

Although Taiwan has now become a truly democratic and free country, the country's democratic system is far from being complete, Chen said, adding that there are five steps that the nation can take to improve the situation.

First of all, the country should strengthen the Taiwan-centric consciousness to protect Taiwan's status as a sovereign country and uphold its right to participate in the international community, including becoming a full member of the World Health Organization and the United Nations, according to Chen.
Secondly, the president continued, the country should deepen its democracy by amending the highly restrictive Referendum Law to facilitate the enactment of the new constitution, he said.

Thirdly, the country should create an environment favorable for fair competition between political parties, he said, stressing that a normal democratic country should not tolerate the existence of a party with "ill-gotten assets" worth tens of billions of New Taiwan dollars and that the government should reclaim the Kuomintang's "ill-gotten assets" to realize transitional justice.
Fourthly, Taiwan media should establish a self-discipline mechanism to enhance their credibility, he said.
Fifthly, the president said, the country should raise public awareness on participating in public affairs and public discussion.
According to Chen, in addition to the "split national identity," the military threat posed by China is another unique challenge facing Taiwan's democratic development.

Noting that China has always stigmatized Taiwan's efforts to pursue freedom and democracy as moves toward "de jure independence, " Chen said he believes Taiwan is the only country in the world that has to endure such heavy pressure in order to protect its democracy.
Despite the threat by Beijing, Chen asserted, Taiwan is a sovereign country, and only its 23 million people have the right to determine the country's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to visit Nicaragua after Taiwan-Central America summit

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that he will visit Nicaragua for a meeting with his counterpart Daniel Ortega following a visit to Honduras in late August, where he will attend a presidential summit meeting between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean.

Chen made the announcement during a meeting with visiting Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Rene Morales Carazo at the Presidential Office. He described the plan for him to make a state visit to Nicaragua as a perfect arrangement after Morales was appointed to attend the summit on behalf of Ortega.
At the meeting, Chen extended a warm welcome to Morales and offered his congratulations on Ortega and Morales' electoral victory.

Chen said he was honored to be invited to take part in the ceremony marking their inauguration held Jan. 10 in Managua. At that time he met with Ortega at the Sandinistas' headquarters and the new president promised to maintain diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Nicaragua, for which Taiwan was very moved and grateful.

When the Ortega-led Sandinista National Liberation Front was in power for the first time between 1985 and 1990, Nicaragua switched diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing. The Nicaraguan government resumed diplomatic ties with Taiwan after Violeta Chamorro took power in 1990.

Since regaining the presidency early this year, Ortega has reaffirmed on many occasions his determination to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan, even after Costa Rica switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in June.

Morales arrived in Taiwan Sunday for the second assembly of the Democratic Pacific Union, an international body founded by Vice President Annette Lu to promote democracy, peace and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region and the world. The two-day event opened in Taipei Monday.
This is Morales' second visit to Taiwan. His first was in July 2001.

Chen is scheduled to head for Honduras Aug. 20 to take part in the Taiwan- Central America summit. According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, invitations have been extended to the heads of state of Guatemala, Honduras, Belize, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Panama and the Dominican Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP head firm on seeking U.N. seat to maintain Taiwan's statehood

TEXT.P: Taiwan must strive to rectify its name, write a new constitution and join the United Nations in order to survive as an independent sovereign state in international society, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Monday.

Yu made the remarks in a news conference while answering questions about a U.S. media report that Beijing is planning to counteract Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations by seeking to propose a vote in the coming U. N. General Assembly on its claim that "Taiwan forms part of the People's Republic of China."
Although Yu called the report speculation that has yet to be confirmed, he urged Beijing to reassess such action and said that "Taiwan will respond if China takes the action."

According to Yu, the Taiwan public are divided over three different approaches regarding the country's future -- seeking Taiwan's eventual unification with China, maintaining the status quo between the two sides and seeking to make Taiwan a normal country through joining the United Nations, writing a new constitution and rectifying its name.

Yu claimed that eventual unification with China would be the equivalent of immediate suicide to Taiwan and that maintaining the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo would be gradual suicide. He added that only turning Taiwan into a normal country will provide the country with a lifeline amid China's aggressive pressure to squeeze it on the world stage.

DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Rail firms legal threat to silence passenger watchdog Britains worst- performing train company tried to silence the official passenger watchdog by threatening to sue it for libel for making a complaint about its poor performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Profuse rain eases water shortage in Penghu

TEXT.P: A water shortage crisis on the outlying Penghu island group has eased considerably since more than 200 mm of rain has fallen in the area in the past five days, government officials in charge of water affairs said Monday.

Officials from the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said they had decided to put on hold a plan that would ask the state-run Taiwan Water Corp. to ship fresh water from southern Taiwan from Aug. 16 to relieve the Penghu shortage.

According to the officials, although two recent tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- that swept across Taiwan brought very little rainfall to Penghu, the southwesterly air currents following the two storms gave local residents their much-needed rain.

Water levels in Penghu's three reservoirs have continued to rise steadily and according to a forecast by the Central Weather Bureau, the wet weather will continue for at least two more days, which should end Penghu's drought completely.

Penghu's demand for fresh water has increased in recent years as a result of booming tourism. Its three major reservoirs can supply more than 5,000 metric tons of water per day, while three sea water desalination plants and five well water desalination plants have a total water output of 17,980 metric tons.

The government is building two additional sea water desalination plants in Makung and Hsiyu, which, when completed by the end of this year, will produce 5,500 tons and 750 tons of fresh water daily, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose slightly Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 7.65 points to close at 8,938.96.
The bourse opened at 9,030.82 and fluctuated between 9,030.93 and 8,913 during trading. A total of 5.06 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$145.49 billion (US$4.36 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 3.8 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.1 percent and plastics and chemicals issues, as well as banking and financial shares, at 0.3 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.2 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers numbered more than 1000, against 604 gainers, and 196 stocks remained unchanged.

A total of US$668 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.935 and hit a high of NT$32.983.

DOC.HEADLINE: 84% of office workers keen on starting own businesses: survey

TEXT.P: Eighty-four percent of office workers polled in Taiwan are enthusiastic about starting their own businesses, mainly because of dissatisfaction with low pay, according to the results of a survey released Monday by an online employment service provider.
The survey was conducted by 1111 Job Bank between July 27 and Aug. 10 among 1,174 workers. It had a margin of error of 2.9 percent.
While 56.56 percent of the respondents expressed their desire to open their own businesses, 27.77 percent were actually doing so, the survey shows.

The results are consistent with that of another survey carried out in July among a group of newcomers to the job market, in which 75.48 percent of the respondents either had the desire or were making the move to start their own businesses.

Similar to the results of a survey conducted last year, the latest survey indicates that low salaries offered by their present jobs remain the top reason motivating office workers to open their own businesses, with 52.53 percent of respondents mentioning this reason.
A total of 45.25 percent of respondents said becoming their own boss is part of their career plan, while 39.6 percent said they want to do jobs that fit their interests or expertise.

On the fields that potential business starters aim to enter, 37.98 percent intend to open an ice dessert and beverage store, 21.82 percent want to open a restaurant and 15.35 percent plan to open a convenience store.

Opening an ice dessert and beverage store was also the top choice of potential business starters surveyed last year. The result also corresponds to tallies showing that franchises in this category account for nearly 50 percent of the total number of franchises in the country.

However, the online auction industry, which was the second-most popular choice among potential business starters last year, has been squeezed out of the top 10 list this year, after Yahoo! Taiwan started collecting transaction fees from sellers.
The survey found that prospective business starters spend 7.71 months and NT$800,000 on average preparing to open their businesses.
On the sources of their startup capital, 79.09 percent rely on savings, 47.58 percent rely on bank financing and 33.23 percent rely on loans from friends or relatives, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 125 points to close at 8,925, with 47,528 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September rose 112 points to finish at 8,888, with 14,139 contracts traded, while December futures gained 81 points to close at 8,902, with 117 contract transactions. March futures increased 87 points to close at 8,919, with seven contracts traded, while June futures moved up 83 points to finish at 8,888, with one contract transaction.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 8,800 for August, 8,776 for September, 8,821 for December, 8,832 for March and 8,805 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

August TE futures moved up 5.25 points to close at 377.3, with 4,733 contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 2.1 points to finish at 373.1, with 3,261 contract transactions. December TE futures rose 0.1 points to close at 371.7, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures gained 17.6 points to close at 1,007.6, with 3,134 contracts traded, while September TF futures rose 14 points to finish at 1,002, with 1,834 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan, San Jose celebrate sisterhood anniversary
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, California, Aug. 12 (CNA) 08/13/07 18:41:43 (By Chou Shih-huei and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair attended acelebration Sunday at San Jose City Hall in California to mark the 30th anniversary of the formation of Tainan-San Jose sisterhood ties.

Hsu arrived in the United States earlier in the day for a visit scheduled to run through Aug. 17. During the celebration, Hsu introduced his city, which he said has been certified by the World Health Organization as a "healthy city" in the West Pacific region and is one of four major high-technology cities in Taiwan.
Tainan and San Jose, located in Silicon Valley, forged sisterhood ties in 1977.

In his address, San Jose Mayor Chuck Reek expressed his gratitude for Taiwan's contribution to high-tech development in Silicon Valley, and his admiration toward Taiwan's achievements in pursuing democracy and freedom.

Reek also mentioned that there are around 10,000 Taiwanese living in San Jose. According to statistics released by the San Francisco Chronicle in 2004, about 50,000 Taiwanese expatriates lived in the San Francisco Bay Area that year. San Jose is located at the south end of the Bay Area.

The sisterhood anniversary celebration was attended by Santa Clara County Supervisor Pete McHugh, nine San Jose city councilors and many other city officials, as well as Taiwanese expatriates from Tainan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chief of Media group indicted along with others for embezzlement

TEXT.P: Gary Wang, president of the Eastern Multimedia Group, was indicted along with 31 others Monday on charges of embezzling group funds, with the probe's lead prosecutor seeking a 28-year imprisonment for Wang.
The prosecutor accuses Gary Wang of colluding with his father Wang You-theng, who founded the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, to loot NT$37.9 billion (US$1.14 billion) from the group.

The senior Wang fled to the United States long before a prosecutor indicted him, along with 106 others, for embezzling funds from the Rebar group in separate case on March 8. The prosecutor in that case has requested a 30-year jail term.
The prosecutor in charge of the Eastern Multimedia Group probe also accuses Gary Wang of embezzling NT$3.3 billion from the Eastern group.
His wife Tsai Hsueh-ching, who went into hiding in the United States after her husband was investigated, was indicted as an accomplice, for whom the prosecutor is seeking a jail term of 10 years.

Five others members of Wang's family have also been indicted in the case, including Gary's brother Wang Ling-yi, his sister-in-law Kuo Chi-ling, his uncle Wang Shih-chang, his father Wang You-theng, and Wang You-theng's wife Wang Chin Shyh-ying who is staying with her husband in a suburban mansion in Los Angeles.

Notable among the accused are Chang Shu-sen, general manager of the Eastern TV, for whom the prosecutor asking for an one-year jail term, and Tung Chia-ching, financial chief of the Eastern group, for whom the prosecutor is seeking a 16-year jail term.
The case came to light on Dec. 30, 2006 when Wang You-theng and Wang Chin Shyh- ying flew to the United States one day after the Rebar group applied for bankruptcy protection.
That prompted a rush on the Chinese Bank, which was owned by the Wang's family.

Although Gary Wang argued that his business group was financially independent of the Rebar group of his father, investigators searched the Eastern group on June 14 anyway, and placed him in custody June 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: International conference discusses choice of constitutional systems

TEXT.P: A two-day international conference hosted by the Taiwan Thinktank opened Monday to discuss a theme titled "After the Third Wave -- Problems And Challenges for New Democracies, " with more than 40 scholars from Argentina, Canada, Ireland, South Korea, Italy, Australia, the U.K., the U.S. and Taiwan participating.

A study by Robert Elgie, a professor at Dublin City University, shows that the semi-presidential system has had a poor record in advancing democratization. Elgie also concluded that president-parliamentary forms, which Taiwan uses, perform worse than premier-presidential forms in which the prime minister is responsible only to the legislature.

He also found that "cohabitation, " which means the president and the prime minister come from different political parties, and a divided minority government, do not result in failures of democratic transition.

The eventual abandoning of the semi-presidential system and the single nontransferable vote, which is regarded as the secret of one-party dominance, and the switch to a single-member simple plurality system in Taiwan, Japan and South Korea could be explained as a political reform and formation of a new order, while the old regime is collapsing, said Lin Jih-wen, a research fellow at Taiwan's Academia Sinica.

In another session, Benjamin Reilly, a professor from Australian National University, argued that recent political reform across Asia, including that of Taiwan, has seen the emergence of a more genuine "Asian model" of democracy that is moving closer to the Anglo-American system of "majoritarism, " electoral competition and two-party politics.
Guillermo O'Donnell, a professor of politics from the University of Notre Dame, delivered a keynote speech at the conference on democratic theories after the Third Wave.
The Third Wave of Democratization is a term coined by Samuel Huntington to describe the global trend that over 60 countries experienced democratic transition since 1974.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT bicker prior to court ruling on KMT presidential candidate

TEXT.P: The secretary-general of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) speculated Monday that the court will hand down a not guilty verdict on Ma Ying-jeou, the party's presidential candidate who was indicted on corruption charges over alleged misuse of special municipal allowance when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

Wu Den-yih made the remarks to reporters a day before the Taipei District Court is to hand down its ruling on the case. Ma was indicted in Feb. 13 after a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers filed a lawsuit alleging him of embezzling some NT$11.17 million in public funds.
Ma was accused of remitting the money to his wife's bank account -- half of the total special municipal monthly allowance designated for his discretionary use during his two mayoral terms.

According to the law, half of the mayoral special allowance requires proof of spending in the form of receipts before the money can be reimbursed, while the other half of the funds can be used "freely" by the mayor for "public duties."

Ma was charged with "knowingly embezzling" the funds that do not need receipts or invoices, but he maintained his innocence on the grounds that half of the special allowance was earmarked for his "free" use, as is also the case for more than 6,500 ranking government officials and over 40,000 retired local government and state agency chiefs.
According to Wu, Ma did not have any intention of embezzling the money and thus did not commit any crime. He expressed his hope that the court will deliver a "fair judgment" and clear Ma's name.

Speaking in a Legislative Yuan news conference the same day, DPP legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming called on the judges to pass an impartial verdict on Ma, as their ruling will have a far-reaching impact on Taiwan's politics.

As Ma was accused of using public funds to pay for his family's daily expenses, Ker urged the public to vigorously examine his integrity -- a key element that he claimed is critical to an aspirant vying for the presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city, county heads protest tax revenue allocation

TEXT.P: The Taipei mayor and the Taipei County magistrate walked out of a meeting Monday in protest over the central government's plans for allocation of tax revenues among Taipei, Kaohsiung and Taipei County.
The allocation of funds became an issue of contention after Taipei County joined the rank of Taipei and Kaohsiung as an administrative area under the direct jurisdiction of the Cabinet in early May.

During the Monday meeting, a special committee of the Cabinet continued to discuss fund allocation, using NT$150 billion (US$4.54 billion) as the basis, although finance officials had acknowledged earlier that the centrally allotted tax revenues for 2008 would amount to NT$250 billion.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin deplored the committee's refusal to use the 2008 figures as the basis for discussions on the grounds that the Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures first needs to be amended.
Hau said the Cabinet should have asked the legislature to amend the law during its extraordinary session July 10-20 to pave the way for the planned allocation of tax revenue next year.
He strongly disagreed with the Cabinet's plan to cut NT$20 billion from Taipei's budget and NT$10.5 billion from Kaohsiung's budget and give the money to Taipei County.

Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei pointed out that the county will see increased activity and operations after being placed under the direct control of the Cabinet, and that the county needs at least an extra NT$62.9 billion in 2008 to balance its budget.
Chou complained that the Cabinet would only allocate an extra NT$30.5 billion, leaving the county to face a shortfall of NT$30 billion.
He threatened to resolve the issue through legal action or even encourage Taipei County residents to take to the streets to fight for a fair share of the budget.

According to the Distribution Regulations for Centrally-Allotted Tax Revenues, the special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung currently are entitled to 43 percent of the centrally allotted tax revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma to respond to court ruling on embezzlement charges

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) presidential candidate, will call a news conference Tuesday after the court hands down a ruling on his embezzlement case related to a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006, KMT officials said Monday.
KMT officials made the remarks as the Taipei District Court is scheduled to hand down a verdict at 10 a. m. the next day.

Ma was indicted by Taipei prosecutors on Feb. 13 after a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers sued him over his alleged misuse of the public funds amounting to NT$11.17 million.

According to an internal KMT assessment, Ma is likely to receive a slap on the wrist or be acquitted, party officials said, adding that whatever the verdict, Ma will explain his standing concerning related issues during the news conference.

Commenting on possible public response if Ma is convicted, party officials said that Ma is not in favor of resorting to violent means to deal with the situation but added that the party will still fully back Ma should he be found guilty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to launch pioneering biobank plan in November

TEXT.P: A pioneering project to establish the planned Taiwan Biobank will be activated in November, with its executor, Academia Sinica, beginning to collect blood samples from local people in hope that the blood will provide clues to the top 10 causes of death as well as to the causes of top 20 diseases in Taiwan, a spokesman for the academic institution said Monday.

Dr. Chen Yuan-tsong, director of the Academia Sinica Institute of Biomedical Sciences (IBS), said that during the initial stage of the project, researchers will try to collect at least 15,000 blood samples with financial support of the Department of Health.

The operation will also be overseen by ethical experts and scholars in order to prevent disputes over privacy and human rights violations -- a measure included after some human rights groups accused the Institute in 2006 of such violations after it gathered blood samples from indigenous people of the country before ethic disputes surrounding the move were settled, Chen noted.

According to Chen, the approximate cost for the establishment of the 15,000-people biobank has been assessed at NT$400 million. Their long-term goal is to expand the biobank to include blood samples from 200,000 people, Chen said.

So far, the IBS has not yet decided on how the databank will be managed, Chen pointed out, noting it can be a non-profit corporation, or the IBS to be commissioned to run the Taiwan Biobank, and that they have two years' time to discuss the issue.

Beginning in November, the project's personnel will begin to collect blood samples of volunteers in the Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Hualien and Taitung areas. No ethnic groups are specifically targeted for blood collection, according to the IBS, which also revealed that the blood samples of those who have concerns about their blood donations to the Biobank will be destroyed to respect their wishes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA hopes APEC envoy issue can be settled prior to president's trip

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday that it hopes Taiwan's envoy to the 2007 informal leadership meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum can be settled prior to President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming Latin American visit.
MOFA officials said that Australia, the host country of this year's informal summit slated to be held in Sydney Sept. 8-9, will soon send an official to Taiwan to present the invitation.
It is hoped that Taiwan can reach an agreement with Australia on the identity of the APEC envoy prior to Chen's departure for the diplomatic tours Aug. 21, the officials said.

They said President Chen is currently considering four or five possible candidates, adding that all of them "currently hold no official posts, " and that all will "underscore Taiwan-centric consciousness as well as upgrade Taiwan's image."

They said that the prospective candidates have a financial or economic background, or they have served as APEC envoys before, although Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. will not be included in the short list.
Chang served as President Chen's envoy to attend the summit hosted by Vietnam in its capital, Hanoi last year.

Although Taiwan is a member of the APEC, due to Beijing's opposition, none of its presidents has ever attended the summit since its inception in 1993. Instead, the country has sent envoys in place of its president to the summits.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese swimmers arrive for 'swim across strait" activity

TEXT.P: Eight Chinese swimmers arrived at Taipei Monday for the "swim across the Taiwan Strait" activity to be held later this week.
Long distance Taiwan swimmer Wang Han, who initiated the activity, greeted the Chinese swimmers at the Taoyuan International Airport.
Wang said that 28 swimmers -- including 16 from Taiwan, eight from China and four from South Africa -- will be divided into 14 teams with two members in each team for the journey.
Each team will swim for 60 minutes before another team takes over for the round the clock journey, he added.

The swimmers plan to dive into water at the Fishermen's Wharf in Tamsui, Taipei County, at 3 p.m. Thursday and hope to arrive at Fuao Wharf on the Taiwan-held outlying island of Matsu in four or five days if weather and sea conditions permit.

Wang, who has swum across the Strait of Gibraltar alone and crossed the English Channel in a tag team effort, said that he had originally planned to start his cross-Taiwan Strait journey from either Taoyuan County or Hsinchu County to reach Pingtan, Fujian province in southeastern China.
But he said that the route was cut short "due to limited time for organization, " and expressed hope that the swimmers might accomplish that feat next year.

The straight-line distance across the Taiwan Strait is 170 kilometers, but the actual swimming distance, when taking into account detours to avoid sharks and adverse ocean currents, should be 250 kilometers, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government activates emergency response center amid heavy rains

TEXT.P: A supra-ministerial emergency response center came into operation Monday afternoon after parts of the country were hit by extremely heavy rains.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) made the announcement after torrential rains, brought by southwesterly air currents resulting from Tropical Storm Wutip, claimed one life in central Taiwan, disrupted trains in southern Taiwan, and left over 1,000 passengers stranded on Green Island off the southeastern Taiwan coast.

The center is staffed with officials from the National Fire Agency, the Council of Agriculture, the National Science and Technology Center for Disaster Reduction, the Central Weather Bureau, the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior, the MOEA's Water Resources Agency, and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
Officials said they will closely monitor the situation from the center.
Water Resources Agency officials said that the center of heavy rains began to move northward from Pingtung and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan to Taichung in central Taiwan early Monday morning.
Officials also noted that in those places the volume of daily precipitation has surpassed 200 mm.

Noting that the rains have begun to subside in most areas of Taiwan, the officials said that Neipu Township and Majia Township in the southern county of Pingtung are still reporting rainfall in the afternoon.
Meanwhile, police in the central county of Nantou reported that a 54-year-old woman showed no signs of life after being pulled out from a rain-triggered landslide.
In addition, two elderly people and a child were reported to be trapped on a sand bar in the central county of Taichung due to a rapid surge in water levels.
Southbound trains operating on the South Link Railway were halted at noon, said a railway official in the southern county of Pingtung where transportation links to many flooded areas were cut.
The official noted that shuttle buses have been provided to accommodate passengers who need to travel between the north and south.
Meanwhile, more than 1,700 tourists were reported stranded on the outlying island of Green Island after heavy thunderstorms forced the cancellation of plane service to Taiwan proper.
A spokesman for the Taiwan Water Corp. said that the water quality in southern city and county of Kaohsiung has worsened as a result of heavy rainfalls.
Water supplies, however, remain at normal levels, the spokesman continued, while still urging the locals to store water for emergency use.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate advocates 'two countries, one system' in Indonesia

TEXT.P: Relations across the Taiwan Strait should develop in a "two countries, one system" direction, the presidential candidate of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said in Jakarta Monday at the start of his visit in Indonesia.
Frank Hsieh broached the idea in an interview with Suara Karya, an Indonesian newspaper, shortly after his arrival in the Indonesian capital from Singapore where he just concluded a three-day visit.

Questioning the wisdom of Beijing's "one country, two systems" overture for cross-strait unification, Hsieh said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be characterized as two countries and both of them should uphold the same political system, namely "one democracy system."
In his view, Hsieh said only the "two countries, one system" formula will contribute to both sides' popular well-being and regional stability.
Noting that China's military budget has grown past what it needs to counter Taiwan, Hsieh said such a development should be a common concern to Asia-Pacific regional security.

While everybody hopes to see China rise peacefully, Hsieh said its attitude toward Taiwan could be a litmus test. If China cannot tolerate Taiwan or cannot resolve the cross-strait issue with peaceful means, he said, it would not be just a problem to Taiwan but would concern regional security and even the stability of entire world.
Touching on the purpose of his current visit, Hsieh said he looks forward to expanding his global vision through the visit as he is running for Taiwan's next presidency.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Indonesia, Hsieh said the two countries have maintained close interaction in various fields. It is hoped that his visit will contribute to mutual understanding and friendship between the two countries, he added.

On the prospect of his presidential bid, Hsieh said he is confident that he will emerge as the final winner in next year's presidential election in which Ma Ying-jeou, the main opposition Kuomintang's standard bearer, will be his main rival.
Hsieh received VIP treatment upon his arrival at the Jakarta international airport. Many Taiwanese expatriates greeted him at the hotel where he is staying during his visit.

Hsieh met with Indonesia Vice President Jusuf Kalla Monday evening. On Tuesday, he will attend seminars with Indonesian business executives and legal scholars and experts as well as take part in a charitable activity to be hosted by the wife of the Indonesian vice president.

Hsieh will also meet with the Indonesian industry minister Tuesday and receive an interview with an Indonesian television station. In the evening, he will attend a dinner to be given by the Taiwanese expatriates association in his honor and afterwards, he will hold talks with Indonesian officials and lawmakers. He is scheduled to wrap up his Indonesia visit and return to Taiwan Wednesday when he will formally announce who his running mate will be.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH urges vigilance while touring Bali

TEXT.P: Taiwanese people traveling to Bali, Indonesia should be on guard after Indonesian government confirmed the first human death due to avian influenza on the resort island, an official of the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

Chou Chih-hao, deputy director of DOH's Centers for Disease Control, urged Taiwan tourists not to have contact with fowl, not to eat raw fowl products, and to wash hands and change clothes immediately in case they happen to touch bird droppings.
If they don't feel well within 10 days of their return, they should seek medical treatment immediately, Chou said.

But he noted that the death in this case took place in a remote region about 100 km outside Denpasar, the capital of Bali, and the DOH will not advise Taiwan tourist against going there, although they are advised to be on guard about their own health.

Avian influenza virus usually refers to Influenza A viruses found chiefly in birds, but infections can occur in humans. The risk is generally low for most people, because the viruses do not usually infect humans. However, confirmed cases of human infection have been reported since 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet works out new allocation of tax revenues (update)

TEXT.P: The central government worked out new measures Monday for allocating centrally dispensed tax revenues to Taipei, Kaohsiung and Taipei County, although the Taipei mayor and the Taipei County magistrate walked out of a meeting earlier in protest.

A special committee of the Cabinet called the meeting because the allocation of funds required review after Taipei County joined the rank of Taipei and Kaohsiung as an administrative area under the direct jurisdiction of the Cabinet in early May.

The committee insisted on letting the three administrative areas share 43 percent of the centrally allotted tax, using the 2007 total of NT$150 billion (US$4.54 billion) as the basis. The new measures will increase Taipei County's share from NT$9.8 billion to NT$30.5 billion.
However, Taipei City will see its share of tax revenue decrease from NT$58.2 billion to NT$38.2 billion, while Kaohsiung City's NT$21.9 billion is being slashed to NT$11.4 billion.

The committee decided to compensate most of the two special municipalities for loses with subsidies, with Taipei receiving NT$15.5 billion and Kaohsiung getting NT$10 billion. This means Taipei still faces a shortfall of NT$4.5 billion, while Kaohsiung will suffer a loss of NT$500 million.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei withdrew from the meeting in protest, saying that the Cabinet should not have used NT$150 billion as the basis for drawing up the budget.

They contended that finance officials had acknowledged earlier that the centrally allotted tax revenues for 2008 would amount to NT$250 billion, and that this figure should have been the basis for discussions.

Hau strongly disagreed with the Cabinet's plan to cut NT$20 billion from Taipei's budget and NT$10.5 billion from Kaohsiung's budget and give the money to Taipei County, although the losses of Taipei and Kaohsiung will be partially compensated through subsidies.

Chou pointed out that the county will need NT$62.9 billion in 2008 to balance its budget. He contended that by allocating NT$30.5 billion to Taipei County, the Cabinet will leaving the county to face a shortfall of NT$30 billion.
He threatened to seek to resolve the issue through legal action or even encourage Taipei County residents to take to the streets to fight for a fair share of the budget.

According to the Distribution Regulations for Centrally-Allotted Tax Revenues, the special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung are currently entitled to 43 percent of the centrally allotted tax revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum on U.N. bid Taiwan people's common aspiration: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that holding a referendum on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan is the common aspiration of a majority of the people of Taiwan, rather than his personal preference.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with Eni Falemavaega, chairman of the Subcommittee on Asia, the Pacific and the Global Environment under the U.S. House Committee on Foreign Affairs, who is currently on a visit in Taiwan.

Referring to U.S. opposition to the Chen administration's plan to hold a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid under the name Taiwan, Chen said it seems to him that the United States has downgraded the issue to his "personal business."

Chen said Taiwan and the United States have shared views and interests in many fields, particularly in maintaining peace and security in the Asia-Pacific. He further said he treasures the longstanding Taiwan-U.S. friendship and appreciates the contribution the U.S. government and people have made to Taiwan's democratization and treasures.

Noting that he doesn't like to see mistrust between the two sides simply because of misunderstanding or insufficient communications over the U.N. membership issue, Chen said he hopes the two sides can strengthen dialogue on relevant topics.

Stressing that an overwhelming majority of Taiwan people have a strong desire to see their country obtain representation in the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, Chen said it is necessary for his administration to push for a national referendum to let the world hear the Taiwan people's voice and pay heed to their common aspiration.
Holding such a referendum has nothing to do with a change to the country's official title, Chen added.

Meanwhile, Chen said he earnestly hopes that the U.S. administration can attach importance to a resolution passed by the House of Representative recently calling for a removal of restrictions on senior Taiwan officials' visit to the United States because the resolution reflects a common voice of the Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM: U.S. would react to biased interpretation of U.N. resolution

TEXT.P: The U.N. chief's "expanded interpretation" of U.N. Resolution 2758 is not in the interest of the United States and Washington would take actions as a result, Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang said Monday.
U.N.Secretary- General Ban Ki-moon's statement has caused "serious concerns" in Washington, Hwang said Monday in an interview with the CNA. He did not give any details.
The minister admitted that, in the short term, it would be difficult for Washington to adjust to the change in Taiwan's strategy in trying to rejoin the United Nations.
"After bilateral discussion, however, the United States should be able to understand that its interests would only be served by supporting (there being a separate) Taiwan identity," he noted.
In the interview, Huang also warned against any attempt by Beijing to push for a vote in the United Nations on China's claim on Taiwan.
"Would such a move be a step on the red-line of the Taiwan people? ...In everything they do, Beijing would need to take into account the feeling of the Taiwan people," he said.
Huang's remarks came after unconfirmed reports that Beijing might consider giving more bite to the U.N. secretary-general's comments about Taiwan being part of China.
Answering questions in July, Ban said that the United Nations' position has been that Taiwan is part of China after the U.N. General Assembly adopted the resolution in October, 1971.
The comments caused some angry reaction in Taipei, with the Taiwan government saying the resolution did nothing more than giving China seat to Beijing at the expense of Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative mission to visit U.S. over arms procurement deal

TEXT.P: A legislative delegation will set off on an 11-day visit to the United States Tuesday to facilitate its assessment of a plan to purchase eight U.S.-built diesel-electric submarines, Legislative Yuan Defense Committee sources said Monday.

The delegation, composed of legislators from across the party spectrum, will visit Washington, D.C. and Boston and make a transit stop in Los Angeles while canceling its original plan to tour U.S. military base in Hawaii, the sources said.

Because of media criticism and partisan disputes over the trip, the sources said, Vice Defense Minister Ko Cheng-heng has canceled his plan to join the group and the duration and itinerary of the trip have both shortened.

According to an Aug. 7 meeting between legislative and military staff, the sources said the delegation will be composed of nine lawmakers, including Liao Wan-ju and Shui Hua-ming from the main opposition Kuomintang, Shen Fa-hui and Chang Hua-kuan from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Ho Ming-hao of the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
The number of Ministry of National Defense (MND) staff members to accompany the lawmakers on the visit will also be reduced, the sources said.

In response to media criticism that the trip could be a waste of taxpayers' money, the sources said legislators will have to foot part of the travel bills out of their own pockets. The remaining fees will be paid by the MND and the Legislative Yuan, the sources said, adding that none of the expenditures will come from the NT$200 million budget set aside for assessing feasibility of the submarine deal.
Besides visiting the U.S. Pentagon, the sources said, the delegation will also call at the U.S. Navy headquarters and some shipyards on the U.S. East Coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court acquits former Taipei mayor of corruption

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou was acquitted of corruption charges Tuesday.
The Taipei District Court said in its judgment that Ma was not guilty of embezzlement.

Ma was charged on Feb. 13 for inappropriately lining his own pocket with NT$11.17 million in public funds between Dec. 1998 and July 2006 during of his term as Taipei's mayor. The funds in question had been set aside to cover the mayor's job-related expenses.

The prosecutor in charge of the case claimed in the indictment that Ma transferred half of those public funds to his personal bank account every month, keeping that portion which was not used as his personal income, with the knowledge that they were public funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 14, or the second day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: The British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy -- march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The Republic of China Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
1949: Konrad Adenauer becomes the first chancellor of West Germany.
1951: Randolph W. Hearst, the newspaper publisher known as the king of America's "yellow press," dies at the age of 88. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire comprising 28 major newspapers.
1951: Seamen aboard the Ta Han, a 2,000-ton mainland Chinese freighter, defect to Taiwan, sailing their ship to the port of Kaohsiung.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down three Communist Chinese MiG-17s over Matsu.
1958: The United States decides to maintain an embargo on trade with Communist China, North Korea and North Vietnam, despite NATO's announcement of a relaxation of trade restrictions with the Soviet bloc and Communist China.
1971: Ground for the construction of Taiwan's north-south freeway is broken near Linkou.
1973: Over 300 Chinese and foreign computer scientists meet at the Academia Sinica for the First International Symposium on Computers.
1974: The Taipei Century Symphony Orchestra leaves for the United States on a three-week goodwill tour.
1977: The ROC Air Force celebrates the 40th anniversary of its victory over the Japanese at Hangchow, with Gen. Szetu Fu presiding.
1979: Wang Yun-wu, senior advisor to the president of the Republic of China, dies of heart failure at Veterans General Hospital at the age of 92.
1980: More than 360 scholars from home and abroad take part in the International Conference on Sinology at the Academia Sinica.
1985: The ROC Executive Yuan issues a report on the investigation of official administrative responsibilities regarding the 10th Credit Cooperative scandal. Fifteen financial officials are reprimanded, given demerits or dismissed.
1988: Major racial conflict breaks out in the African country of Burundi, with more than 24,000 people being killed in the conflict.
1999: The United States defeats Chinese-Taipei 10-9 to win the 18th International Baseball Association Big League Championship in Kaohsiung.
2000: Premier Tang Fei instructs the Ministry of Justice to review and revise relevant laws and regulations so as to enable the government to effectively crack down on the types of crimes that are increasingly harming Taiwan society.
2001: Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, a 1987 Nobel Peace Prize winner, says in Kinmen that Taiwan and mainland China should engage in dialogue to ease the tension across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who intuitively apprehends truth is one who, without effort, hits what is right, and without thinking understands what he wants to know; whose life is easily and naturally in harmony with the moral law. Such a one is what we call a saint or a man of divine nature."

DOC.HEADLINE: Expat group to try to persuade fugitive tycoon to return to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/14/07 12:11:20 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Leaders of a Taiwanese expatriate group in the United States are expected to meet with fugitive Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng and his wife later this week to persuade the couple to return to Taiwan to face criminal charges, an official said Monday.

According to Lee Ping-hsin, chief of the Los Angeles chapter of the Taiwanese Benevolent Association of America (TBAA) , the couple have drawn much attention in the Taiwanese expatriate community since they fled to the United States more than six months ago, and the association will try to arrange a meeting with the couple in the next few days to talk face-to-face with them.

TBAA President Lo Su-o, who is scheduled to arrive in Los Angeles Wednesday to prepare for the association's 30th annual meeting, will visit the Wangs at their residence located in South Pasadena and invite them out for dinner, Lee said.
Lee further said that in addition to Lo and himself, chiefs of the TBAA's Las Vegas and Orange County chapters will also join the persuasion effort.
Wang, who had been held at an immigration holding center in San Pedro, Calif. since Feb. 2, was released on bail Aug. 7.
Wang was detained when he tried to return to Los Angeles with both his Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports canceled, following a failed attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore.

Wang is suspected of having embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds from the group before fleeing with his wife, Wang Chin She-ying, to China late last year and then to the United States in January this year.
Taiwan authorities placed the couple on the country's most-wanted list Jan. 15 and have been seeking U.S. assistance to have them repatriated back to Taiwan to face charges.

In March, Taiwanese prosecutors indicted Wang and 106 others involved in the Rebar Group scandal on a long list of charges, including fraud, money laundering and insider trading. They are seeking a prison sentence of 30 years and an unprecedented fine of NT$1.71 billion (US$52.13 million) for Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Sepat intensifies to become typhoon

TEXT.P: Tropical Storm Sepat, which increased in intensity to become a typhoon Tuesday morning, maintains a high probability of making a landfall in Taiwan, forecasters at the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Tuesday.

As of 10 a.m. Tuesday, Typhoon Sepat was centered 1,150 km east-northeast of Manila, or 1,300 km east-southeast of Oluanpi at Taiwan's southernmost tip, moving west-northwesterly at 12 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of 130 kph, according to the CWB.

The typhoon will continue its slow movement over the next couple of days during which it is not expected to affect the island, the forecasters said, adding that they will further assess to what extent the storm will affect the island when the typhoon draws closer.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen mum on KMT presidential candidate's acquittal

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian refrained from making any comments Tuesday on the acquittal of former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on corruption charges, saying the case is still pending.
Chen made the remarks after the Taipei District Court cleared Ma, who is now the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) presidential candidate, of all corruption charges earlier in the day.

Ma was indicted Feb. 13 on suspicion of diverting NT$11.17 million in government funds into his personal account during his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006. The "not guilty" verdict removed a dark shadow over Ma's presidential bid, even though the prosecution may still appeal the case.
Chen was asked about his view on Ma's acquittal while visiting a stationery ware manufacturing company in Taipei County's Panchiao City as part of his community outreach tour.
Noting that the case has not yet been closed, Chen said it's inappropriate for him to make any comment at the moment.

Asked whether Ma's acquittal will have any impact on the outcome of the 2008 presidential election, Chen didn't give a direct response, saying instead that the most important thing for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is to streamline its ranks.

"We shouldn't just try to cash in on other people's mistakes. We shouldn't only factor in outside elements. The most important thing is to work to move people and win their support with our visions, policy initiatives and internal unity," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 27.97 points to close at 8,910.99.
The bourse opened at 8,952.54 and fluctuated between 9,023.26 and 8,840.26 during trading. A total of 4.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$142.72 billion (US$4.33 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.6 percent, followed by foodstuff issues and construction issues both at 0.5 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 0.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues both at 0.4 percent, and textile stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 945 to 647, with 225 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Gap-year students told to forget aid projects
One of Britains leading charities has warned students not to take part in gap- year aid projects overseas which cost thousands of pounds and do nothing to help developing countries.

DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Hamas thanks Prodi, Israel worried.
Italian Premier Romano Prodi's recent proposal to open dialogue for the Middle East peace to the Palestinian hardline faction Hamas worried Israel, while Hamas expressed its appreciation to Prodi.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hopes local administrators will not act egotistically

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged leaders of local governments to refrain from self-serving actions and called for their consideration of the central government's difficulties given falling tax income and rising spending.

Chang made the call in response to media inquiries relating to the dispute over the distribution of centrally allocated tax revenues after the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung, and the Taipei County magistrate voiced protests Monday against the Executive Yuan's decision to let the three administrative areas share 43 percent of the centrally allotted tax revenues.

The decision has resulted in significant drops in the share of revenue allocated for Taipei and Kaohsiung. At the same time, while Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei acknowledges that funding for his county will rise significantly as a result of joining Taipei and Kaohsiung under the direct jurisdiction of the Cabinet, the money the county receives from the central government will still be insufficient to help Taiwan's largest county balance its budget in 2008.

Chou argued that the Cabinet should not have used the tax revenue of 2007 -- totalling NT$150 billion (US$4.54 billion) -- as the basis for drawing up the 2008 budget given that finance officials have acknowledged that the centrally allotted tax revenues for next year would amount to NT$250 billion.

Chang attributed the disputes to the Legislative Yuan's amendment in May to the Act on Local Government Systems, allowing Taipei County to become a "quasi- special municipality." However, he said the legislature failed to revise the law governing the allocation of government revenues and expenditures at the same time to re-arrange the tax revenue distribution.

Under the existing law, the special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung are entitled to 43 percent of the centrally allotted tax revenues. That ratio was not changed despite the inclusion of Taipei County following the passage of the law revision that makes the county eligible for special municipality status.

Chang also stated that following Taipei County's upgrade to municipality status, other counties and cities, including Taichung and Tainan, have also displayed a strong desire to upgrade their status and obtain a larger share of centrally- allotted tax revenues.
Noting that the country's governmental system must be upheld, Chang said none of individual people or administrative districts should try to "take more than their fair share."

DOC.HEADLINE: Court determines former mayor did not intend to embezzle funds

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court determined Tuesday that former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying- jeou had no intention to embezzle from a special mayoral fund as it acquitted him on corruption charges.
The court rejected the prosecution's charge that Ma obtained the money through "fraudulent means" and ruled in favor of Ma's claim that he used the fund in the same manner as his predecessors.

Ma was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of embezzling NT$11.17 million from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use while he served as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006. The funds in question were set aside to cover the mayor's job-related expenses.

The prosecutor in charge of the case claimed that Ma transferred half of those public funds to his personal bank account every month, keeping that portion which was not used as his personal income, with the knowledge that they were public funds.

The prosecutor claimed that although the government's regulations allow the mayor to use half of the fund by simply signing a receipt instead of providing vouchers to account for his spending, the money should go towards job-related spending and that any remaining funds should be returned to the government's coffers.

However, the verdict issued by the Taipei District Court said that half of the special allowance funds paid to executives holding public office without proof of spending are meant as salary subsidies and that as soon as the payment is made, the receivers are authorized to spend the money at their discretion.
The practice is established by the Cabinet and should not be considered "fraudulent," according to the verdict.

On the prosecutor's claim that Ma confessed during a Sept. 12, 2006 questioning that he was "aware that the special funds were public funds, " the verdict said the claim was invalid because it was made based on a misinterpretation of Ma's testimony.

In addition, the court rejected written testimony prepared by the prosecutor based on questioning Jan. 25, 2007 of a cashier at the Taipei City Government's Secretariat, Wu Li-ju, after determining that the written testimony was inaccurately recorded.

Wu complained during a July 10 hearing that the written testimony did not record her statement accurately, and the court later approved a request by Ma's lawyers that the judge review the optical disc on which the entire process of the questioning was recorded to check if there are any discrepancies between her verbal statement and the written testimony.

Meanwhile, one of Ma's aides, Yu Wen, was convicted of using others' invoices to help Ma to claim reimbursement from the special allowance fund, and sentenced to two years and four months for forgery. That sentence was commuted to one year and two months according to a commutation statute implemented on July 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president reserved about Ma's initial acquittal verdict

TEXT.P: Despite Ma Ying-jeou's acquittal of corruption charges by the Taipei District Court, Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that Ma, the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) presidential candidate, will have really proved his innocence only if the Supreme Court issues the same ruling.
Lu made the remarks while answering reporters' questions after the Taipei District Court handed down a not guilty verdict in Ma's case earlier the same day.

Ma was indicted by Taipei prosecutors on embezzlement charges Feb. 13 after some lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) sued him over an alleged mishandling of special municipal allowance earmarked for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei during the 1998-2006 period.
Lu said that she is unaware of the judges' reasons for issuing the not guilty verdict, but she urged the public to respect the ruling.

Asked whether Ma's acquittal would slash the DPP's chances in the March 22, 2008 presidential election, Lu said that the question should be directed to Frank Hsieh, the ruling party's presidential candidate, who will return to Taiwan Wednesday from a visit to Indonesia and Singapore.
Hsieh, who is currently visiting Jakarta, declined to comment on Ma's acquittal, saying that "he won't talk about Taiwan's domestic affairs while on an overseas visit."
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung also said that he had no comment on the latest development involving Ma's embezzlement charges as prosecutors still can appeal the case.
"We fully respect the court's ruling and we won't make any comments regarding a judicial case that has not yet finalized," he said.
Meanwhile, Taipei Prosecutors Office spokesman Lin Chin-tsun said that prosecutors would assess whether to appeal the case after reading through the judgment.
According to the judgment, Ma was acquitted because he did not act dishonestly nor induce anyone to commit a crime when seeking reimbursement of funds from the special mayoral allowance.

The supreme administrative court has made it clear that such special allowances for ranking government officials and local government chiefs may be viewed as "substantial subsides," the court verdict said, adding that "Ma drew on the special mayoral funds in a way consistent with the practices of his predecessors."

Ker Chien-ming, the DPP's legislative caucus whip, said in a Legislative Yuan news conference that the result is "no surprise" at all and voiced the caucus' full support for prosecutors to appeal the case.
"Although Ma can escape legal punishment for the time being," Ker said, "Ma has actually been given a political death penalty as his credibility is totally bankrupt."
Ker accused Ma of repeatedly lying to prosecutors during the probe and urged the public to scrutinize his words and deeds.

DPP Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni, one of the lawmakers who brought the case against Ma, called the day one of the darkest in the history of Taiwan's judiciary and questioned how the judges could face other public servants imprisoned for corruption.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August dropped 40 points to close at 8,885, with 55,688 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved down 48 points to finish at 8,840, with 33,229 contracts traded, while December futures lost 86 points to close at 8,816, with 79 contract transactions. March futures dropped 95 points to close at 8,830, with 31 contracts traded, while June futures decreased 53 points to finish at 8,822, with 19 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,925 for August, 8,888 for September, 8,902 for December, 8,925 for March and 8,875 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

August TE futures moved down 2.1 points to close at 375.2, with 3,861 contracts traded, while September TE futures dropped 1.2 points to finish at 371.9, with 3,370 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 5.45 points to close at 370, with eight contracts traded, while March TE futures decreased six points to finish at 372.5, with one contract traded. June TE futures dropped 4.4 points to close at 371.5, with three contracts traded.

August TF futures gained 3.4 points to close at 1,011, with 6,517 contracts traded, while September TF futures moved down four points to finish at 998, with 5,208 contract transactions. December TF futures lost 12.2 points to close at 1,009.8, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.003 to close at NT$32.968.
A total of US$565 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.935 and hit a high of NT$32.980.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA chief inspects foreign laborers' workplaces

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Lu Tien-lin inspected conditions of foreign laborers' workplaces in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan to acquire a firsthand understanding of their working conditions.

Lu visited the Fulltide Enterprise Co. in Tayuan township and the Catholic Hope Workers Center in Chungli City. He listened to briefs from both the enterprise and the center, and also viewed laborers' working and living environments, which he found satisfying.
Lu invited opinions from three foreign laborers on services their employers provide, and living and working environments, and received positive evaluations from them.
Responding to questions about foreign labor policy making, Lu said he will listen to opinions from different perspectives in order to make decisions that will benefit both local and foreign laborers.
He also expressed hope that employers will always actively improve living and working conditions to ensure that foreign laborers have a safe and comfortable environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Christian media voices support for S. Korean hostages

TEXT.P: Christian media GOOD TV broadcast a discussion program Tuesday calling for support for South Korean Christian aid workers who are being held hostage by Afghanistan's Taliban insurgent group.

Afghanistan's Taliban captured 23 South Korean Christian aid workers July 19, offering to return them in exchange for Taliban prisoners held in Afghan jails. Two of the hostages have been shot dead, two females freed, while another 19 remain captive.

Those volunteer aid workers' misadventure has aroused both positive and negative opinions. The televised discussion aimed to provide a Christian point of view on this event in defense of the group and invited Christians to pray for them.

Chang Kuei-yue, a senior reporter who served in the Balkans for seven years and visited South Korea two weeks ago, said it is no easy task for missionaries to go to war-torn and poverty-struck areas such as Afghanistan to preach religion. Only people who understand the real value of life would place themselves in such dangerous places, she added.

Hsin-tien Covenant Church Rev. Chang Mao-song said it is admirable for Christian missionaries to go to foreign countries to preach religion while providing medical or educational services. He also said that those South Korean Christian workers deserved the public's encouragement given their dedication.

Chung Yuan Christian University professor Lin Chih-ping, who also participated in the discussion, said sending missionaries abroad for missionary work is a time-honored activity and has yield positive results around the world. South Korea has nearly 16,000 missionaries preaching religion abroad, which is only second to America's number. Taiwan also has a number of missionaries to do much the same thing, Lin went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fuel prices to be cut by NT$0.7 Wednesday

TEXT.P: Domestic gasoline prices will be lowered by NT$0.7 per liter beginning Wednesday and held constant until September, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Tuesday.

The MOEA froze a floating fuel pricing mechanism July 31 to begin an overall review into the system in light of a rising public outcry against the floating fuel price, with consumers complaining of surging gasoline prices.

The MOEA activated the floating fuel pricing mechanism Sept. 14, 2006 to reflect reasonable crude oil costs. Under the system, gasoline prices are adjusted weekly based on the price of the West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen announced Tuesday that in the near future pricing adjustments will be conducted once a month, rather than each week, in an attempt to address public complaints.
The revised pricing mechanism will be implemented from Sept. 1. Until it is implemented, fuel prices will not undergo further adjustments following Wednesday's cut, Chen noted.

On the price cut, Yu Kai-hsiung, secretary general of the non-profit Consumers' Foundation, said the foundation insists that the domestic gasoline prices be slashed by NT$2.5 per liter, arguing the state-run petroleum company, CPC Corp., Taiwan, adopted higher retail fuel prices last September when it began to carry out the floating pricing mechanism.

On last Sept. 14, the WTI price, taken as the benchmark in setting the price, were at the same level as those in February. However, Yu said, the CPC's retail price for a liter of 95 octane unleaded gasoline was recorded at a level NT$2.5 higher than the February price.
In this regard, in fairness, gasoline prices should be lowered by a further NT$2.5 following the upcoming NT$0.7-cut, Yu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan develops world's fastest 3C decoder

TEXT.P: Researchers at I-Shou University have developed the world's fastest 3C decoding program, with a maximum calculating capacity 100 times faster than that of the existing ones, the Kaohsiung County-based university announced Tuesday.

The program is a collaborative creation between Professor Chang Yao-tsu and two candidates for doctoral degrees at the university's Institute of Information Engineering, according to university officials.

The team has already integrated the programs into computer chips that can be utilized in products in areas of satellite communications, mobile communications, digital audio-visual playing, and digital storage.
Chang noted that thanks to an innovative error correcting theory developed by the team, the calculating speed of the programs has been greatly enhanced in the research and development process.

Chang explained that almost all technologies and products related to digital content require error correcting mechanisms to ensure the accuracy of data transmission and storage, and that a decoder with a faster calculating potency such as theirs not only improves service quality but also reduces the size of the products.
According to the university, the next step will involve seeking opportunities to transfer the results to local manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eastern Multimedia Group loses right to manage Taipei Arena

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Tuesday the city government's decision to terminate its nine-year contract with the Eastern Multimedia Group to manage the Taipei Arena, the city's first multifunctional indoor stadium.

Hau made the announcement after public prosecutors indicted Eastern Multimedia Chairman Gary Wang a day earlier on charges of committing a series of financial crimes, including using collusive bidding to obtain the right to manage the facility.
Hau said the city government will set up a task force to take over the arena's management, with Deputy Mayor Samuel Wu as its convener.

Noting that at least seven shows will be staged in the arena from now until the end of this year, Hau said the city government will do everything it can to make sure the performances proceed unaffected.
He also said he was satisfied that no Taipei city government officials were involved in the bidding collusion.

Asked how the city government will get the latest installment of concession fees totaling some NT$129 million from the Eastern Multimedia Group, Hau said the city government has a NT$150 million security deposit from Eastern Multimedia and that the contract allows the city government to withhold money owed by the group from that amount.
Eastern Multimedia won the right to manage the Taipei Arena for nine years with a bid of NT$1.58 billion in 2005 when Ma Ying-jeou was Taipei mayor.

Taipei prosecutors have unearthed evidence that Wang and Hsieh Yin-lung, deputy manager of an Eastern Multimedia subsidiary company formed specifically to manage the arena, engaged in bidding collusion to allow Wang to obtain the concession right.

According to the prosecutors, Wang and Hsieh each formed a new company specifically for the bidding, but Wang later paid Hsieh NT$24.78 million in return for his promise that his bid would not go higher than Wang's -- an act in violation of the Government Procurement Law.
Wang and 31 of his associates were indicted Monday for their alleged involvement in several embezzlement scandals. Prosecutors requested a 28-year sentence for Wang, plus a fine of NT$1 billion.

: The Washington Post: Rove's Plans for Lasting GOP Majority Fall Short
The Washington Times: Bush adviser Rove resigns

The New York Times: Rove to Resign as Bush Aide at End of Month
