DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers embark on low-profile arms procurement trip to U.S.

TEXT.P: Seven lawmakers from across the party spectrum set off on an 11-day visit to the United States Tuesday as part of a feasibility study for a submarine procurement deal aimed at beefing up the country's defense capabilities.
The lawmakers kept a low profile as they departed, declining to reveal any details about their itinerary or even the number of people in the delegation.

The members of the group are Shui Hua-ming, Su Chi and Liao Wan-ju of the main opposition Kuomintang, Fu Kun-chi of the opposition People First Party, Ho Ming-hao of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union and Chang Hua-kuan and Shen Fa-hui of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. Two lawmakers -- Ko Chun- hsiung and Lin Kuo-ching -- who were originally on the delegate list -- did not show up.

Because of media criticism and partisan disputes over the trip, Vice Defense Minister Ko Cheng-heng canceled a plan to join the group and the duration and itinerary of the journey have both been curtailed.
The number of Ministry of National Defense (MND) staff members accompanying the lawmakers on the visit has also been reduced, Legislative Yuan Defense Committee sources said.

In response to media criticism that the trip is a waste of taxpayers' money, the sources said the legislators will have to foot part of their travel expenses out of their own pockets. The remaining fees will be paid by the MND and the Legislative Yuan, the sources said, adding that none of the expenditures will come from the NT$200 million budget set aside for assessing feasibility of the submarine deal as well as the type that most fits Taiwan's needs.

Besides visiting the Pentagon, the sources said, the delegation will also visit U.S. Navy headquarters and some shipyards on the U.S. East Coast. While the group will make a transit stop in Los Angeles, it has canceled a plan to tour U.S. naval bases on the West Coast and in Hawaii, the sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government raises budget for marketing local firms globally

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has increased its budget to help local firms develop international marketing strategies to NT$5.5 billion (US$166.57 million) in an effort to receive more export orders, a spokesman for the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Tuesday.

According to the spokesman, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has drafted international marketing strategies for local firms based on the perspectives of market, industry and general economic situation. The project is estimated to benefit about 65,000 local companies.

TAITRA will work with the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) in organizing four seminars around the nation to explain the government's services to enterprise owners, with the first seminar to be held in Kaohsiung City Aug. 16, the spokesman said.

BOFT Director-General Huang Chih-peng will explain the government's beneficial policies and measures to participants at the first seminar, which will be attended by more than 150 local firms in a variety of industries.

The organizers will provide counseling services at the seminars on exhibition marketing opportunities, brand consulting, package design and Internet marketing, the spokesman said, adding that the one-to-one counseling services are free to participants and that people can sign up for the seminars via the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses hit US$3.9 million as vegetable prices surge

TEXT.P: Extremely heavy rain in Taiwan's central and southern counties and cities over the past week has resulted in huge agricultural losses assessed at over NT$130 million (US$3.9 million), according to statistics released Tuesday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

Pingtung County was recorded as suffering the heaviest agricultural losses of NT$57.11 million, while Yunlin County registered losses of NT$61.95 million, and Kaohsiung County was hit for NT$30.99 million, the tallies show.
Since Aug. 9, Taiwan has been under the influence of a powerful southwesterly airflow that has brought torrential rain to central and southern areas.
The COA assessed that crop losses have amounted to NT$12.78 million around Taiwan, with a total of 3,845 hectares, or 19 percent, of fields damaged by the rain.
Watermelons, melons and leafy vegetables sustained the greatest damage, COA officials said.

Meanwhile, Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co. data shows that declines in vegetable and fruit supplies have resulted in price surges in Taipei's markets, with the price of melons recording the largest rise at NT$175 per kilogram.

DOC.HEADLINE: Illegal Vietnamese workers seized

TEXT.P: Police have seized 15 illegal Vietnamese workers and their employer in Taoyuan County's Yangmei township in northern Taiwan, Chiayi County's Shueishang Police Precinct Director Sun Ping-yi said Tuesday.

The arrested employer, identified only by his surname Chiou, and the illegal workers, were being investigated for violations of the Employment Services Act. The workers were sent to the National Immigration Agency's branch Chiayi County in southern Taiwan, Sun said.
The police started their investigation after receiving a report Aug. 4 on the workers, who were said to be hiding and working in the township.

Sun said illegal labor brokers and human smuggling rings use a variety of channels to bring illegal foreign workers into Taiwan and claimed that the phenomenon results in "many different social problems."

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president calls attention to rise of Chinese nationalism

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called for greater attention to the rise of Chinese nationalism, which she said is likely to reach its peak during the 2008 Olympic Games to be held in Beijing Aug. 8-24.
Lu made the remarks while addressing the second assembly of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , which took place Aug. 13-14 in Taipei.

Lu said the Communist Party of China has been promoting Chinese nationalism. Noting that China's rise could be a factor affecting the security and development of the Pacific region, Lu said China saw an economic growth rate of 11.5 percent during the first half of this year and expects to overtake Germany to become the world's third-largest economy.

China is increasing its influence in the Pacific region in the aspects of diplomacy, politics and the military, Lu said, adding that China is now eyeing Central and South America amid its growing significance in Central Asia and Southeast Asia.

Lu said that against this backdrop, the United States is developing a wide range of cooperation with Japan, Australia and India as part of its efforts to consolidate its influence in Asia, particularly on the Korean peninsula and in the Taiwan Strait.
As a result, the U.S. acts as a counterforce against any rise of undemocratic power in Asia, according to Lu.
Past security mechanisms were confined to military power, Lu went on, adding that there is a need for a security mechanism that should be open to all countries.
Lu claimed that only an open organization is able to change the international situation, deter rogue regimes and combat terrorism. She said the DPU can shoulder such responsibilities.
Lu also predicted that China will replace the U.S. as the greatest producer of greenhouse gas emissions in the next year, and she urged the world not to fight over limited petroleum resources.

Rather, she continued, the world should develop renewable energy in the Pacific region and integrate the research results of many countries to turn the crisis of global warming into an opportunity for sustainable development.

Lu also announced that the DPU will form five associations within the next two years in an effort to make greater contributions to the world and promote democracy, peace, prosperity, sustainable development and digitalization.

During her address at a party welcoming nearly 100 foreign guests from 33 nations a day earlier, Lu said that in face of the threat of 1,000 Chinese missiles, Taiwan insists on maintaining cross-strait peace, which she described as a determining factor in the stability of the Pacific region.

She said Taiwan hopes to join the international community and expects the world to support the country's applications to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization under the name of Taiwan.

Taiwan, as an oceanic nation rather than an isolated island off China's coast, has demonstrated its "soft power" and has made advanced progress in human rights, democracy, peace, love for the world and high technology, she continued.
Lauding the country's economic success and democratic achievements, Lu said Taiwan's global competitiveness ranks 13th worldwide and 26th in terms of economic freedom.
Approximately 60 percent of the world's information technology products come from Taiwan, she noted.
Following the peaceful transfer of political power in 2000, Freedom House in the U.S. places Taiwan among the highly democratic Western countries, Lu said.

She added that Taiwan is not self-complacent and is willing to share its achievements and experiences with the international community, urging the participants to back the country's U.N. and WHO bids.

Lu is the founder and chairwoman of the DPU, a non-governmental organization that aims to serve as a platform for exchanges among the Pacific Rim countries in the promotion of democracy, peace and prosperity, and other common values.
Founded in Taipei Aug. 14, 2005, the DPU has 26 countries and areas as permanent members.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19 Taiwanese criminals repatriated from China

TEXT.P: Four fugitives wanted in Taiwan and 15 suspected criminals were repatriated by Chinese police authorities to Taiwan under the Kinmen Accord via the outlying island of Matsu Tuesday.
The Red Cross societies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait signed the accord in September 1990 as a guideline for the repatriation of cross-strait illegal immigrants.

Chinese police escorted the 19 Taiwanese nationals aboard a boat from China to Matsu and then handed them over to Criminal Investigation Bureau officials and local police. Among the four wanted fugitives were Hsu Han-ting, a 46-year-old man wanted for fraud, and Ku Chun-nan, 35, who was wanted for committing the offense of abandonment.
The other two fugitives were Kao Chi-chuan, wanted for manslaughter and forgery, and Chiu Cheng-kang, wanted for committing an offense against personal liberty.
Although the 15 others repatriated were not on the wanted list, Chinese police said they had been arrested for entering China illegally and for being members of fraud rings.
Police took all 19 suspects to Taiwan by helicopter later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Nicaragua ties stable, lasting: Nicaraguan vice president

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Morales Carazo said Tuesday that relations between Taiwan and Nicaragua are stable, lasting and will not be affected by outside pressure.

Morales made the remarks at the opening ceremony of the second assembly of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , a non-governmental organization founded by Vice President Annette Lu in 2005 that is aimed at boosting democracy, peace and prosperity for Pacific Rim democracies.

Morales said that although Taiwan and Nicaragua are geographically far apart, they are closely linked by common values and convictions and the distance has been significantly reduced through close cooperation over the years.

Nicaragua welcomes President Chen Shui-bian's participation in the leadership summit between Taiwan and its Central American allies to be held in Honduras later this month, and his later visit to Nicaragua, Morales said.

Sharing the aspirations of democracy, peace and progress promoted by the DPU, Nicaragua hopes to boost its ties with all countries around the world despite political and ideological differences, Morales said.
He hailed Lu as a dynamic promoter of the DPU, which gathered together representatives of 33 countries around the Pacific Rim at the event.
According to Morales, Nicaragua has begun a process of national reconciliation, giving priority to the problems of poverty, unemployment and education.

To attain the goal, the most important thing is domestic and foreign private investment, Morales said, adding that Nicaragua welcomes any investment that will lead to social, employment and environmental improvement in his country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-U.S. official urges U.S. to restore diplomatic ties with ROC

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Representative to the United Nations John Bolton said Tuesday that the United States should "expand or restore" its diplomatic relations with Taiwan and suggested Taiwan to try to seek the repeal or modification of U.N. Resolution 2758.

Bolton also expressed his disappointment at what he described as U.N. Secretary- General Ban Ki-moon's "massive error" in rejecting Taiwan 's application for U.N. membership without submitting it to the member governments.

"The U.S. needs to take a decisive step -- the restoration of full diplomatic relations with Taiwan -- to avoid the situation becoming riskier and more dangerous for the U.S. as well as the PRC and the ROC, " Bolton said in a speech titled "U.S. Global Democracy Strategy and Cooperation with Taiwan."
What former U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. George H.W. Bush proposed in 1971 as "dual representation" should "make sense now" as "dual recognition, " he said.
"Recognizing Taiwan in fact is simply recognizing reality, which is always the best grounding for any foreign policy, " he said.
By recognizing Taiwan, the ambiguity will be eliminated, he said, offering his opinion that ambiguity is a negative for the U.S. rather than a plus.

The ambiguity encourages China to believe it might actually conquer Taiwan without waging a war, he explained. Recognition would bring stability and certainty as well as strengthen the U.S. hand in the region by signalling to others the U.S. commitment to Taiwan, he said.
As for China's response to dual recognition, Bolton said there is "no way" China would break its relations with the U.S. nor impose economic costs.
"They will not be happy... But Beijing will not take any substantial steps, " he speculated.

Bolton went on to suggest that in terms of U.N. status, the real answer for Taiwan is to seek the repeal of U.N. Resolution 2758 because "applying for regular membership will produce a PRC veto if it gets that far."
"If the U.N. General Assembly can pass Resolution 2758, it can repeal it or modify it, " he pointed out, adding that prior UNGA resolutions have been repealed or modified.

Ban Ki-moon has rejected both Taiwan's U.N. membership applications and its effort to accede to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women treaty, which constitutes a huge mistake by Ban, according to Bolton.
As Ban was elected U.N. Secretary-General with the help of China and the U.S., the U.S. is observing which direction will Ban take if there is a dispute between China and the U.S., Bolton said.
"He went to the direction of China in his first test, " he said.

For the U.N. application name issue and referendum, Bolton said the name is for the people of Taiwan to decide. While the referendum is a mechanism to reflect popular choice, it is anomalous for the U.S. to object to people voting in a referendum after all the pressure to make Taiwan a democracy, he said.

Looking ahead to the presidential elections in Taiwan and the U.S., Bolton said the U.S. presidential candidates should publicly commit to "no deals over Taiwan without the consent of the people" while Taiwanese candidates should make sure they "get the best deal possible" for the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mixed reactions to Ma's acquittal

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun urged prosecutors Tuesday to appeal the case of Ma Ying-jeou, the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) presidential candidate, after Ma was acquitted of corruption charges by the Taipei District Court.
Yu issued the call at a news conference with key party officials after the Taipei District Court handed down a not guilty verdict on Ma earlier that same day.

Claiming that the ruling is biased and does not serve justice or convince the public, given evidence "clearly showing" Ma's wrongdoing, Yu called on the prosecution to seek an overturn of Ma's acquittal as quickly as possible so as to close the case at an early date.

Echoing the DPP chief's call, Yin Ling-ying, a legislative caucus whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP in the "pan-green camp," said the caucus fully supports an appeal by Prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen who indicted Ma Feb. 13 over corruption charges.
Yin accused the judiciary of "wallowing in degeneration" and claimed that the Taiwan people will not accept such a ruling.

Speaking at a news conference at the KMT headquarters, KMT Chairman Wu Poh- hsiung expressed happiness with Ma's acquittal on embezzlement charges and said it will help inject momentum to Ma's election campaign.

Wu Poh-hsiung said he strongly believes in Ma's clean reputation and added that prosecutors' indictment accusing Ma of using his position to rack up personal monetary advantages sent a shockwave through society.

For his part, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih urged prosecutors to apply the same criteria by launching probes into similar cases involving four DPP heavyweights -- Vice President Annette Lu, former Premier Frank Hsieh who now is the DPP's presidential candidate, and former Premier Su Tseng-chang.

Ma was indicted by prosecutors Feb. 13 after ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers sued him over his alleged mishandling of public funds related to the reimbursement of a special mayoral allowance earmarked for his discretionary use when he was mayor of Taipei during the 1998-2006 period.
Meanwhile, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu of the DPP said Ma's acquittal is proof that the ruling party cannot and did not manipulate the judiciary.
Chen expressed her hope that same standard can be applied to deal with similar cases in the future, regardless of political affiliation of the accused.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin of the KMT hailed the judges' ruling as fair and said he is happy Ma's name has been cleared.

Speaking at a news conference following a municipal meeting, Hau said the verdict did not fail to meet the public's expectations and that Ma's acquittal will help clear barriers on his way to the presidency.

The Taipei District Court's ruling, although it might be overturned by the High Court and the Supreme Court, had a major impact on Taiwanese politics, because only a few months are left before the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential election, analysts said.

If prosecutors decide to appeal, the High Court has to come up with a verdict within six months -- right when the presidential poll is to be held, which will cast a shadow over Taiwan's political stability at an extremely sensitive time, the analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. helicopter company looks to expand to Taiwan market

TEXT.P: A U.K. helicopter company is looking to expand its business to Taiwan, as the country has slowly opened up its domestic civil and corporate aviation market.

AgustaWestland, which specializes in helicopters and related training, has a tender for the National Airborne Service Corps' (NASC's) procurement of 12 helicopters to be used for search and rescue, disaster relief and emergency medical services.
The company sees Taiwan as a future market with tremendous potential although the expansion will be slow and steady, said Andrew Symonds, vice general manager of sales in North Asia.

Symonds said the company's AW-139 and EH-101 models are suited for Taiwan's mountainous areas and the high winds often experienced in rescue and relief missions and added that the company is happy to collaborate with Taiwanese government agencies.
The main focus will be on civil services, later expanding to corporate services and air taxi operations, Symonds said.

AgustaWestland is a subsidiary of Finmeccanica, which is the ninth-largest aerospace, defense and security company globally and the second-largest in Europe. The company has its primary operations in Italy, the U.K. and the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Torrential rain causes huge agricultural losses in Pingtung County

TEXT.P: Pingtung County, Taiwan's southernmost county, has suffered the heaviest agricultural losses in the country as a result of torrential rain over the past few days, county government officials said Tuesday.
According to the county government's estimate, as of late Tuesday, agricultural losses due to the rain had increased to a total of more than NT$100 million (US$3.03 million).
Among the crops that suffered the greatest damage were bananas, melons and leafy vegetables.
The aquaculture sector recorded a loss of NT$2 million, with many fish ponds completely inundated and having lost all their fish.
The flooding had also drowned 290,000 chickens, washed away 40,000 ducks and killed 800 hogs, with losses amounting to NT$17 million.
The rain was brought to Taiwan by southwesterly air currents that came in the wake of two tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- which swept across Taiwan last week.
Machia township in Pingtung County saw record rainfall of more than 1,000 mm within 24 hours Monday, while other townships recorded between 500 mm and 700 mm of rain in a 24-hour period.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate may name running mate upon his return to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate said in Jakarta Tuesday that he is likely to announce his running mate upon his return to Taiwan if he gets a positive response from his target choice.
Frank Hsieh told Taiwanese reporters covering his Southeast Asian tour that he talked with former Premier Su Tseng-chang on the phone a day earlier.

"During our conversation, Su said he will give a goodwill response to my invitation to serve as my running mate out of his desire to do what's best for the country, " Hsieh said, adding: "Even though our talks did not come to a conclusion, I'm convinced that the outcome will be a good one."
Hsieh said in Singapore Sunday that he had invited Su to run for the vice presidency in 2008.
The lawyer-turned-politician was scheduled to conclude his Indonesia visit Wednesday, which is also the date he has promised to announce his running mate.

Hsieh said he will not make a formal announcement aboard his return flight. "But if I secure a definite reply, I'm very likely to announce the formation of a Hsieh-Su ticket upon my arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport," he added.

Hsieh was originally scheduled to announce his running mate at a rally to be held at 228 Peace Park in downtown Taipei Wednesday evening. As recent torrential rains have wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan -- the DPP's traditional stronghold, Hsieh said the rally will be postponed indefinitely. "The time and venue for the replacement rally will be decided later, " he said, adding that despite the postponement, he will announce his running mate as scheduled.

Hsieh arrived in Jakarta Monday after concluding a three-day visit to Singapore during which he met with Singapore's top leaders, including Prime Minister Lee Hsieh Loong and Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew.

Hsieh met with Indonesia Vice President Jusuf Kalla Monday evening. On Tuesday, he attended seminars with Indonesian business executives and legal scholars and experts as well as took part in a charitable activity hosted by the wife of Indonesian vice president.

Hsieh held talks with Indonesian Industry Minister Fahmi Idris at noon. Hsieh assured Idris that if he wins the presidency, he will work for expanded Taiwan- Indinesian ties. Hsieh also met with Indonesian parliamentarians in the afternoon. In the evening, he attended a dinner given by the Taiwanese expatriates association in his honor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two hijackers repatriated to China via Matsu

TEXT.P: Two Chinese citizens convicted of attempting to commandeer a passenger plane by holding hostage a Taiwanese official and injuring him in 1999 were repatriated to China via the Taiwan-held outlying island of Matsu Tuesday after serving out their prison terms.

Yang Mingde and Lin Wenqiang were escorted to Matsu aboard a police helicopter early in the morning, from where they were taken back to China on a Chinese boat, escorted by Chinese public security personnel.
In exchange, the Chinese security personnel handed over 11 wanted Taiwanese fugitives to officials from Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Burea.
Yang and Lin were among 18 Chinese citizens imprisoned in Taiwan for hijacking passenger planes from China during a spate of hijackings between 1993 and 1998.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said Tuesday that only one convicted hijacker, Wang Zhihua, remains imprisoned in Taiwan, as 15 others were repatriated previously.

Yang and Lin were to have been repatriated in 1999 via another Taiwan-held outlying island -- Kinmen -- but the pair tried to commandeer the plane taking them to Kinmen in a last-ditch attempt to avoid being returned. The duo and two others had hidden sharpened pieces of metal in their clothes and planned to demand the plane be flown to the United States.

Their attempt was thwarted and they were returned to Taiwan to face new charges. In their action, Jan Jyh-horng, then-deputy secretary-general of the quasi- official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , were held hostage at one point and injured in the incident. Jan is now MAC chief secretary.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCTU develops ties with Latin American counterparts

TEXT.P: Higher education has entered the era of global learning, featuring international exchanges and cooperation, a local university president has said, citing the recent academic links between National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) and higher education institutes in Latin America as an example.

NCTU President Wu Chung-yu made the remarks Monday while hosting a discussion on the development of higher education in connection with the second annual conference of the Democratic Pacific Union, which opened earlier the same day.

Wu said that through the research exchange program, students from Latin American countries will be able to receive technical and vocational training with the country's two world-famous contract chip makers, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.(TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC).

Wu indicated that over the past years, higher education has had a profound and far-reaching influence on the development of Taiwan's wafer and IC technology, and that given the tendency toward globalization, high education needs to further develop and upgrade through the integrated efforts of international research professionals to facilitate national development.

Kim Shin Bok, vice president of Seoul National University, also said that higher education institutes should establish a world-recognized and object-oriented evaluation system for the assessment of educational achievements in order to provide quality certificates for the reference of parents, students, enterprises and government.
Kim stressed such a system will help boost competitiveness and stimulate quality improvement among higher education institutes.

The Korean university vice president noted that a lot of international organizations have set up their own evaluation systems, including the U.S.-based Council of Higher Education Accreditation, the National Institute for Academic Degrees and University Evaluation in Japan and the Australian University Quality Agency.
Kim further suggested that the World Bank provide technical and financial support for Asia-Pacific countries to set up their own accreditation systems or establish an international system.
The discussion included representatives from universities in Japan, Indonesia and various schools around Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President looks forward to 2nd Taiwan-Pacific allies summit

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that he looks forward to the 2nd Taiwan- Pacific Allies summit slated to take place in Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, in October.
Chen made the remarks while receiving Palau Vice President Elias Camsek Chin, Marshall Islands First Lady Mary N. Note and Tuvalu parliamentary speaker Kamuta Latasi at the Presidential Office.

Chen warmly welcomed the visiting dignities to the country, who have come to attend the second assembly of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) -- a non- governmental organization inaugurated in August 2005 to boost democracy, peace, prosperity in Pacific Rim democracies. The DPU is a brainchild of Vice President Annette Lu.

Palau, the Marshall Islands, and Tuvalu are three of Taiwan's best diplomatic allies, Chen said, noting that the three dignitaries' coming to Taiwan for the DPU assembly indicates that the three countries highly value the DPU.

Chen expressed hope that the 2nd Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit would help flesh out the "Palau Declaration" signed by Chen and his counterparts from the Republic of China's six South Pacific allies in Palau Sept. 4, 2006 at the conclusion of the first-ever leadership summit between Taiwan and its six South Pacific allies -- Palau, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, the Solomon Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu.

The declaration recognizes Taiwan's achievements in political democratization and economic development, and pledges that all of Taiwan's Pacific allies will fully support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other major international organizations and activities.

With their shared values of democracy and human rights, all of the signatories agreed to strengthen cooperation in three major fields -- manpower cultivation, economic development and social culture promotion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 15, or the third day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1057: Macbeth, King of Scotland who ascended to the throne after killing his cousin King Duncan in battle in 1040, is killed by Duncan's son Malcolm at Lumphanan, near Aberdeen. The legend of his rise to power and his reign are the basis of Shakespeare's tragedy "Macbeth."
1769: Napoleon Bonaparte, military leader and the emperor of France from 1804 to 1815, is born in Ajaccio, Corsica.
1900: The Kuang Hsu Emperor and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, flee to northwestern China from Beijing as the capital is captured by the forces of eight foreign powers during the Boxer Uprising.
1914: The 82-km-long Panama Canal, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, is opened after 35 years of construction.
1945: The Republic of China Legislative Yuan unanimously approves the United Nations Charter.
1947: India gains independence from Britain with Jawaharlal Nehru as the first prime minister.
1948: President Syngman Rhee formally proclaims South Korea as the Republic of Korea.
1949: A Southeast China Governor's Office is established in Taipei with Gen. Chen Cheng as governor.
1959: The ROC Army receives Nike-Hercules surface-to-air missiles from the United States under a military aid program.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan rules that, according to Article 77 of the ROC Constitution, courts of all levels shall be placed under the jurisdiction of the Judicial Yuan.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Congo (Brazzaville) Republic.
1962: The Netherlands signs a treaty agreeing to Indonesian rule of Irian Jaya (Netherlands New Guinea).
1967: Kung Hsiang-hsi, former ROC premier and finance minister, dies in the United States at the age of 88.
1974: South Korean President Park Chung Hee's wife is shot dead by an assassin in an attempt on Park's life.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo urges college students to contribute their wisdom and energy to the country as he presides over the closing ceremony of the summer vacation military training program of college students at the Cheng-kung base in Taichung.
1979: Direct dialing service to the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore is initiated by the Taiwan Telecommunications Administration.
1980: The wreckage of the Titanic, the British luxury liner which sank after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York on April 14, 1912, is found laying on the ocean floor 3,657 meters below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.
1981: The First ROC-Indian Cultural and Economic Seminar on India's 34th Independence Day is held in Taipei.
1981: The Republic of China and Saint Vincent establish formal diplomatic relations.
1985: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa accepts the resignation of Finance Minister Loh Jen- kong.
1986: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa, in an interview with Saudi Arabian journalists from the Okaz Daily and Al-Bilad Daily, points out that the achievements of the ROC over the past thirty-odd years has won the nation international recognition and made it an indispensable force against communist expansion in the Asia-Pacific region.
1990: President Mikhail Gorbachev restores Soviet citizenship to Nobel Prize- winning author Alexander Solshenitsyn, who was exiled to the West in 1974 for his novels attacking Stalinism.
1995: The Chinese mainland begins eleven days of tactical guided missile exercises by firing live artillery shells into the sea 136 kilometers north of Taiwan.
1999: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Commission, donates US$100,000 and 20 computers to the Chinese Benevolent Federation in San Francisco.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture announces that beef imports from Argentina and Paraguay will be temporarily banned due to an outbreak of foot- and-mouth disease in the two South American countries.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party formally establishes the Taiwan-Japan Goodwill Association to further bolster bilateral ties between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who acquires truth is one who finds out what is good and holds fast to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH planning to permit low levels of ractopamine residue in pork

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) unveiled Tuesday its plan to relax a ban on ractopamine in livestock to permit low residue levels of the veterinary drug in pigs and cattle.

According to a proposed revision to the DOH's standards for veterinary drug residues, the maximum allowable level of ractopamine residue in pigs and cattle would be 10 ppb in muscle and fat tissue, 40 ppb in the liver, and 90 ppb in the kidneys.
If the proposal meets no objection by Aug. 21, the new standards can be implemented at the end of the month at the earliest, DOH officials said.

Cheng Hui-wen, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Safety, said the DOH is planning to adopt the standards recommended by the Codex Alimenterius Commission, a body established by the Food and Agriculture Organization and the World Health Organization, after reviewing the ractopamine residue criteria of international organizations and 24 countries where the use of ractopamine is permitted, including the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand.
Even after the ban is relaxed, the standards to be adopted by Taiwan would remain the strictest among those countries, Cheng said.

Ractopamine, marketed under the brand name Paylean, is a phenolethanolamine s-adrenoceptor agonist that is used for the improvement of weight gain, carcass leanness and feed efficiency in animals, DOH officials noted.

Studies have shown that the drug can be processed rapidly by animals and humans and that the chances of long-term consumption of residue of the drug in meat having toxicological effects are extremely slim, they said.
The issue has received much public attention in the country since the DOH rejected last month two shipments of U.S.-exported pork which was found to contain ractopamine residue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pingtung villagers standed by floods airlifted to safety

TEXT.P: A total of 150 residents stranded by floods and mudslides in the mountain village of Haocha in Pingtung County over the past two days were airlifted off the mountain to safety Wednesday.

The village saw record rainfall of more than 1,000 mm within 24 hours Monday in the wake of two tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- which swept across Taiwan last week, causing floods and mudslides which in turn buried 30 homes, stranded at least 150 people, obstructed main roads and knocked out all communications.
The stranded Haocha villagers agreed to be evacuated after learning that a new typhoon, named Sepat, was heading toward Taiwan.
They were airlifted in groups Wednesday morning to Neipu rural township down the mountain to be sheltered temporarily at a farmers' and workers' activity center.
As of late Tuesday, agricultural losses in Pingtung County due to torrential rainfall had reached NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) , according to county government estimates.
Meanwhile, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung is scheduled to arrive in Tungkang coastal township later Wednesday to inspect flood damage caused by the two storms.
