DOC.HEADLINE: Excess savings total NT$5.46 trillion for past decade: CBC governor

TEXT.P: Taiwan's total excess savings amounted to NT$5.46 trillion (US$165 billion) for the last 10 years, Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai- nan said Monday, adding that the problem will not go away and that it is necessary to promote domestic investment.
Perng made the remarks while delivering a report on the functions of the central bank at a monthly Presidential Office meeting.
Describing excess savings as one of the two major challenges facing the country, Perng said that savings have been providing sufficient capital for the local banking system over the years.

According to Perng, the CBC has repeatedly been employing monetary policies and tools -- including open-market operations and financial institutions' transfer deposits -- to maintain currency growth at a moderate level to stabilize consumer prices.
While admitting that the central bank's measures will not resolve the problem of excess savings, Perng suggested the promotion of domestic investment as a possible solution.
Speaking on the other challenge, Perng said it is difficult for the central bank to strike a balance among stable exchange rates, free flows of capital, and monetary policy autonomy.
Globalization has led to a close integration of the world's financial markets, Perng said, adding that total foreign exchange trade on the world market amounted to US$1.9 trillion per day.
"In the age of financial globalization, if one country's market is adversely affected, the impact will immediately spread to the rest of the world," Perng said.

Against this backdrop, Perng said the CBC is forced to follow in the steps of its major foreign counterparts by adjusting interest rates as part of its efforts to stabilize exchange rates and avoid massive international capital movement due to a wide gap in interest rates in Taiwan and in other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sea warning for new typhoon likely to be issued Thursday: CWB

TEXT.P: A sea warning for Typhoon Sepat is expected to be issued Thursday at the earliest as the typhoon has continued to increase in intensity and move toward Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Thursday.
As of 10 a.m. Wednesday, Sepat was centered 1,100 km southeast of Taiwan, moving west-northwesterly at 11 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of 175 kph, CWB meteorologists said.
The meteorologists forecast that Sepat, the eighth tropical storm reported in the West Pacific area this year, may continue to gain strength to become a strong typhoon over the next two days.

The weather bureau urged residents around the island to be on high alert against the new typhoon, which is very likely to make landfall in Taiwan based on its current course, adding that mountainous areas are now extremely vulnerable to landslides due to the fact that the soil in these areas is saturated with water in the wake of two tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- which swept across Taiwan last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: List of proposed nuclear waste sites to be made public by year's end

TEXT.P: The government has decided to make public a list of proposed sites for storage of nuclear waste by the end of this year, a senior economic planner said Tuesday in Taitung, southeastern Taiwan.

Ho Mei-yueh, minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks in a regular biannual meeting held with representatives of Orchid Island residents as well as relevant scholars and experts to discuss relocation of the radioactive waste storage site on the Orchid Island, operated by the state-run Taiwan Power Co.

Ho said that since the storage site on the island has been used for more than two decades, the government will launch a comprehensive safety check of the current nuclear waste stock, which amounts to around 90,000 barrels.

Each barrel will be checked to make sure that the outer metal clothing has not rusted and that the inner concrete seal has not loosened or degraded, Ho said, noting that the safety check process is scheduled to be completed by 2010.

In response to Orchid Island residents' demand for relocation of the nuclear waste site away from their island, the minister underlined that the government will make public a list of suggested sites by the end of the year.

Local referendums will then be organized in each of the cities and counties where the proposed sites are located, adding that none of the proposed sites will be chosen without the approval of the local residents in such a vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to continue to push forward with U.N. bid: foreign minister
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 15 (CNA) 08/15/07 13:43:42 (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang told a major Japanese newspaper that the nation will continue to push forward with its bid to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" when the world body convenes a general assembly this September.
Huang made the remarks when he was interviewed by Yomiuri Shimbun, which ran the interview Wednesday.
Huang said that Taiwan will promote its U.N. bid via its diplomatic allies in Central and South America.

Despite the fact that the U.S. and Japanese governments do not support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, Huang said he believes that a lot of people in the two countries support Taiwan's bid, and he expressed the hope that the two nations can understand Taiwan's stance and lend their support.
Huang also criticized U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon for twice returning President Chen Shui-bian's letters to apply to join the United Nations.
Huang stressed that Ban has no right to reject Taiwan's application, noting that only the U.N. Security Council and General Assembly can discuss applications for U.N. membership.
On Ban's citing Resolution 2758 adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1971 as the reason for rejecting Taiwan's bid, Huang said that Ban's interpretation of the resolution was wrong.
Huang said that the resolution gave the China seat in the United Nations to the People's Republic of China at Taiwan's expense but did not mention that Taiwan is a part of the PRC.

DOC.HEADLINE: 74% of child daycare centers fail to meet safety requirements

TEXT.P: Just over 74 percent of child daycare centers inspected recently by the Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) failed to meet the country's established safety requirements, officials said Wednesday.
The inspection was carried out jointly by the CPC and the Ministry of the Interior's Children Bureau between May and June among 172 child daycare institutions around the country.

According to consumer protection official Wang Teh-ming, a total of 128 of the inspected institutions did not pass the evaluation, including 64 that failed in the area of building safety and management, 64 that failed in the area of firefighting safety and management, 72 that failed in the area of sanitary safety and management, and 97 that failed in the area of administrative, teaching and caregiving management.
After these institutions were ordered to make improvements within a required period of time, a second inspection found that 57 had failed to do so, Wang said.

Among the institutions failing in the category of firefighting safety and management, 36 had defects in their emergency escape facilities, Wang said, adding that food contamination was discovered in 21 institutions failing in the category of sanitary safety and management.
Chen Kun-huang, chief secretary of the Children's Bureau, noted that more than 284,000 children require daycare services and that there are more than 4,200 child daycare institutions in the country.

Chen said the results of the government's annual evaluation of these institutions are available on the bureau's official Web site, urging parents to check the results before sending their children to any of these institutions.

While selecting a daycare institution, parents should check whether the institution is licensed and whether it is over-enrolled, he said, noting that daycare institutions are required to provide one caregiver for every 15 children.

In addition, he called parents' attention to the fact that daycare institutions are not allowed to hire foreign teachers and that many institutions that tout their language programs provided by foreign teachers are illegal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices slump on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slumped Wednesday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 317.95 points to close at 8,593.04.
The bourse opened at 8,782.05 and fluctuated between 8,808.59 and 8,561.02 during trading. A total of 5.64 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$163.46 billion (US$4.95 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 4.7 percent, followed by textile stocks and paper and pulp issues both at 4.3 percent, construction issues at 4 percent, machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares both at 3.7 percent, foodstuff issues at 3.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 2.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 90, with 44 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Planned law lets you pick guardians in case of mental illness.
A new law is being planned to give Singaporeans a say over who will look after them if they lose their mind to dementia, illnesses or accidents.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Health Singaporeans can appoint people to take care their affairs after they lose their mind.
Under the proposed Mental Capacity Bill by the Ministry of Community Development, Youth and Sports (MCYS), individuals will be allowed to appoint friends or families they trust to look after their financial or personal welfare while they are still mentally capable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expands efforts to boost academic exchanges with Europe

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has expanded the operations of its Taiwan-Germen Academic Exchange Executing Commission to cover exchanges of the kind with other European countries, including Austria, France and Belgium, MOE officials said Wednesday.

Therefore, the name of the organization has been changed to the Taiwan-European Academic Exchange Executing Commission, under which two task forces have been formed to manage Taiwan's exchanges with Germany and Austria, the officials noted.

The Taiwan-German academic exchange commission was organized in 2006 as a way to carry out the Taiwan-German Academic Links Agreement signed in March 2005 by three Taiwan associations of universities and colleges and Germany's union of universities and colleges -- the Hochschulrektorenkonferenz (HRK) -- to boost bilateral educational cooperation and student exchanges.

Last year, the commission provided scholarships to 15 Taiwanese students to study at German universities. The number of scholarships will be increased to 40 this year, with 35 for students planning to study in Germany and five for those who apply to study at art schools in Austria, according to the MOE.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP legislative caucus whip expresses support for 'Hsieh-Su' ticket

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming expressed support Wednesday for the notion of DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh teaming up with former Premier Su Tseng-chang to form a ticket for the 2008 election.

Ker said that if Hsieh teams up with Su, the ticket "will be invincible, " adding that such a ticket will also represent a victory for all the people of Taiwan and meet the expectations of Taiwan society.
Hsieh, who has visited Singapore and Indonesia over the past several days, is expected to announce his running mate upon his return to Taiwan Wednesday evening.

According to Ker, a resolution submitted by all the DPP Central Standing Committee members calling for the formation of a Hsieh-Su presidential ticket is expected to be passed by the party Wednesday afternoon.

Ker said that both Hsieh and Su had served as premier and that both have the personality traits of a trailblazing leader, adding that unlike the opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, and his running mate, Vincent Siew -- a ticket which the DPP legislative whip claimed is considered "dull and inconsequential" -- the Hsieh-Su ticket will be greater than the sum of its parts.

Ker added that all the members of the DPP legislative caucus as well as hundreds of party members will meet Hsieh at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to welcome him home and express their support for the formation of a Hsieh-Su ticket.
Su, who was Hsieh's presidential primary rival, is currently in the United States on a private visit. He is expected to return to Taiwan later this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$81.7 billion to be invested in care, service for seniors

TEXT.P: The government will invest up to NT$81.7 billion over the next 10 years in establishing a comprehensive care and service network for disabled elderly people, an official with the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

According to the official, Taiwan currently has an estimated 210,000 people aged 65 or over with physical limitations, and the number of people in this group is expected to increase to 301,000 by 2015.
As physically challenged seniors often have difficulty taking care of themselves, they present a heavy burden to their families and on the government's financial resources as well, the official said.

The Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has foreseen a steep upward trend in expenditures on long-term care for seniors with disabilities in all countries around the world, the official said.
According to an OECD study, the ratio of such spending to a country's annual gross domestic product (GDP) could surge from 1.1 percent in 2005 to 2.3 percent in 2050.

With Taiwan's population aging fast, the demand for long-term care has increased steadily, the official said, adding that the government has drawn up a 10-year plan to develop an inclusive service mechanism to offer better care for disabled senior citizens.
The beneficiaries of the service network will also include indigenous people aged 55 or over as well as mentally or physically challenged individuals over 50 years of age, the official said.

Under the current national health insurance program, elderly people who rely on life-support systems but live at home are eligible for two free home visits by medical personnel per month. Once the 10-year service system is launched, the number of such visits will increase to four, the official said.

Meanwhile, the official said the government will invest in improving living environments and introducing up-to-date technologies and devices to lower incidence of chronic diseases and enable senior citizens to live independently for a longer period of time.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Mattel recalls 18 million toys.
U.S. toymaker Mattel has recalled more than 18 million toys around the world over safety fears. The recalled products were made in China and contained either unauthoritzed paint or small magnet that can come loose.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August dropped 315 points to close at 8,570, with 28,708 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved down 392 points to finish at 8,448, with 46,247 contracts traded, while December futures lost 359 points to close at 8,457, with 130 contract transactions. March futures dropped 369 points to close at 8,461, with 40 contracts traded, while June futures decreased 378 points to finish at 8,444, with six contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,885 for August, 8,840 for September, 8,816 for December, 8,830 for March and 8,822 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

August TE futures moved down 12.2 points to close at 363, with 3,082 contracts traded, while September TE futures dropped 17.9 points to finish at 354, with 4,492 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 17.35 points to close at 353.2, with 14 contracts traded, while March TE futures decreased 17.2 points to finish at 356, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

August TF futures dropped 37 points to close at 974, with 3,005 contracts traded, while September TF futures moved down 40 points to finish at 958, with 3,886 contract transactions. December TF futures fell 60 points to close at 960, with seven contracts traded, while March TF futures decreased 44 points to finish at 987, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM instructs agencies to brace for heavy rain

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung instructed government agencies Wednesday to brace for heavy rain caused by recent tropical storms and amid the threat of a typhoon that might hit the island soon.

Chang issued the instructions at an Executive Yuan meeting in which he listened to a report on the responses made by government agencies on damages caused by heavy rain that has inundated southern Taiwan over the last few days.
Chang asked the military to extend rescue assistance to the worst-affected areas and the Council of Agriculture (COA) to coordinate efforts to ensure a sufficient supply of vegetables and fruit.
The premier also asked the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission to strengthen checks on commodity prices to prevent profiteering by traders.
According to Cabinet officials, Chang was to proceed to Kaohsiung and Pingtung in southern Taiwan to inspect flood-control work in these areas, immediately after finishing the meeting.

In addition to pushing the central government agencies to help local governments in post-disaster rescue and reconstruction work, Chang told reporters that several banks will offer low-interest loans for families affected by the rain, some of whom will be eligible for tax reductions or exemptions.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges U.S. not to dictate Taiwan's democracy

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the United States should not draw a line in the sand with regard to Taiwan's democracy.

The president made the remarks to U.S. Rep. Virginia Foxx, a Republican from North Carolina, in reference to U.S. opposition to his plan to hold a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations alongside the 2008 presidential election.

"The United States opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally. This would include a referendum on whether to apply to the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, " a U.S. State Department spokesman said recently when asked to comment on the issue.

According to Chen, holding a referendum is the "gist of democracy, " noting that in the United States, there are all sorts of referendums being held alongside national or local elections. In Taiwan, a national referendum took place for the first time in 2004.
The president said the United States should not draw a line in the sand on Taiwan's democracy, otherwise, the people of Taiwan will be unable to enjoy complete democracy.

He said that "if the line is there, we'll do everything possible to avoid treading on it. But while we act gingerly, if someone moves the line so that we inadvertently step on it, it will not be fair to the people of Taiwan."

The president said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has entered the second-stage name collection on holding a referendum on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, hoping that the bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan will gain the support of the majority.
He noted that U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice recently said the United States will support independence for Kosovo even if the United Nations Security Council vetos the idea.
He said this clear and unequivocal stance of the U.S. on Kosovo contrasted sharply with Washington's opposition to his promotion of a U.N. referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, rising NT$0.042 to close at NT$33.010.
A total of US$946 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.928 and fluctuated between NT$32.865 and NT$33.075.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan cyclists to take part in 1,200-km French randonneur

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan extreme endurance cyclists were scheduled to depart for France late Wednesday to take part in the 1,200-km Paris-Brest-Paris randonneur -- a grueling test of endurance and cycling ability and an event that has a history of 116 years.

Jack Ruan, 42, and Cheng Wen-chang, 57, will be the first two men from Taiwan to take part in the randonneur slated for Aug. 20-24. It is the oldest non- competitive bicycling event in the world still run on a regular basis on the open road.
First run in 1891, the 1,200-km Paris-Brest-Paris, or PBP as it is commonly called, is organized every four years by the Audax Club Parisien.

In the last PBP held in 2003, a record number of 4,069 cyclists took part, 3,457 of whom succeeded in the challenge while 612 failed. Japan was the only Asian country to take part in the event that year, fielding 20 cyclists of whom 12 completed the course.
Beginning on the southern side of the French capital, it travels west 600 km to the port city of Brest on the Atlantic Ocean and returns along the same route.

Although today's randonneur cyclists no longer ride the primitive machines used 100 years ago over dirt roads or cobblestones, they still have to face rough weather, endless hills and pedalling around the clock.

A 90-hour time limit ensures that only the hardiest randonneurs earn the prestigious PBP finisher's medal and have their names entered into the event's "Great Book" along with every other finisher going back to the very first PBP.
Ruan, currently financial controller and spokesman for an international cargo express company in Taipei, is an amateur marathon runner who has taken part in the 226-km Kenting Triathlon.
Cheng, who retired as a teacher in 2005, founded the Kenting Triathlon last year and continues to run marathons and do extreme endurance cycling, despite his age.
To qualify as the first Taiwanese riders to tackle the PBP and break the 90 hour cut-off mark, Ruan and Cheng recently completed three races in Japan of 200 km, 300 km and 600 km brevets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will not seek China's representation in U.N.: FM

TEXT.P: As an independent and sovereign state, Taiwan has no interest in vying for China's representation in the United Nations against the People's Republic of China (PRC), Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Wednesday.

Huang made the remarks at a news conference at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to explain Taiwan's efforts in seeking to join the United Nations, in response to a proposal by John Bolton, a former U. S. ambassador to the world body, that Taipei consider suggesting that the United Nations amend or repeal Resolution 2758.

According to Huang, 15 of Taiwan's diplomatic partners have signed an endorsement proposing that the U.N. Security Council deal with Taiwan's membership application in its coming 62nd General Assembly, slated to open Sept. 18.

The U.N. General Committee is expected to discuss Sept. 19 whether to list the proposal for Taiwan's U.N. membership on the General Assembly 's agenda, he said, and expressed his appreciation for the allies' support for Taiwan's U.N. cause.

President Chen Shui-bian wrote last month to U.N. Secretary- General Ban Ki- moon, and put forward the country's application to enter the United Nations as Taiwan instead of the Republic of China (ROC). But the application was turned down by Ban, citing Resolution 2758 adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1971, which recognized the PRC as the sole legitimate government of China."

Asked to comment on the suggestion by Bolton in Taipei Tuesday that Taiwan demands the United Nations revise or scrap Resolution 2758, Huang replied that Taiwan has no intention of joining the United Nations as the ROC and challenging the PRC to vie for China's representation in the international organization.

Taiwan is an independent and sovereign state and it is fully entitled to take part in the United Nations, according to the U. N. charter, Huang said, adding that the country is determined to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan so as to make it clear to the rest of the world that "Taiwan does not form part of the PRC."

Taiwan hopes to shed the historic and legal disputes of the past and enter the United Nations as a new member, Huang said. He also questioned how the international community will heed Taiwan's U.N. bid if the country itself fails to assert its national sovereignty and statehood.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-Korea FTA to have impact on Changhua textile industry

TEXT.P: The signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between the United States and South Korea might have a serious impact on the textile industry of Changhua County in southern Taiwan, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said Wednesday.

The two countries signed an FTA June 30 that will help increase South Korea exports to the United States in a variety of industries such as textiles and will thus affect Changhua County's textile industry, said Cho.
The county has 975 registered textile firms and is a stronghold of Taiwan's textile business.

The county's textile industry had been in decline for the past decade because of competition from China's low-priced products, Cho said, adding that the industry has seen some improvement in export orders since the United States set limitations on import quotas for Chinese textile products this year.
However, he added, the impact of the FTA between the United States and South Korea might become evident from the end of this year, with more and more orders being transferred to South Korea.

Cho said the county government has the obligation to give advice and warnings in this regard to local textile firms, and that the Changhua County Industrial Development and Investment Promotion Committee and the county government's Department of Economic Development have started gathering information for reference by local business people.

Department chief Huang Cho-chung said the two units have consulted the Taiwan Textile Federation for useful information and are making an evaluation on the possible impact of the U.S.-Korea FTA. They will also have meetings with textile firm owners to provide counseling and listen to their opinions, in an effort to propose measures to reduce the impact to the minimum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Women's group continues fight for compensation for comfort women

TEXT.P: The non-profit Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF) launched a series of movements Wednesday in its continuing efforts to assist Taiwanese women forced to served as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers during World War II in fighting for their rights and benefits.

On the day marking the 62nd anniversary of Japan's defeat in World War II, the TWRF gathered young Taiwanese people for a parade to the Taipei Office of the Interchange Association, Japan's liaison office in Taiwan, to demand an apology and compensation for the victims from the Japanese government.

The TWRF will never stop its assistance for the comfort women in claiming Japanese compensation for their victimization, even though they lost a lawsuit against the Japanese government two years ago in the Tokyo High Court, TWRF executives said during the parade.

The issue concerning comfort women has become a high-profile human rights issue in the international community after the U.S. Congress passed a resolution in early August urging Japan to make a full apology to wartime comfort women.

In addition to the parade, the TWRF also launched a "one person, one letter" campaign, calling for people to write to Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, demanding that he lead his country in facing its wartime crimes. The foundation is also on the way of a movement aimed at raising funds to build a virtual- reality museum on comfort women.

DOC.HEADLINE: National-level financial holding firm to be established by year-end

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Wednesday a government plan to establish a national-level financial holding company by the end of this year to enhance the overall competitiveness of Taiwan's financial sector.

The new institution, named Taiwan Financial Holding, will comprise the three completely state-owned financial institutions -- Bank of Taiwan, Land Bank of Taiwan and Export-Import Bank of the Republic of China.

Chang said that although many financial institutions have reorganized to set up holding companies over the past few years to improve efficiency and competitiveness, they are facing intense challenges from international financial holding groups that enjoy advantages such as a high international profile, strong abilities in research, development and innovation, and a huge global distribution footprint.
After its establishment, the market share of Taiwan Financial Holding is expected to exceed 10 percent in the country, with its asset value ranking 18th in Asia and 89th in the world, Chang said.

According to Deputy Minister of Finance Liu Teng-cheng, the ministry will complete a merger of the three state-owned financial institutions within three years after the financial holding company is established.
In the first phase of the plan, a securities subsidiary and a life insurance subsidiary will be set up under the financial holding company when it is established by the end of this year, Liu said.

In the second phase, which is aimed to be completed in 12-18 months, the Export- Import Bank will be merged with Bank of Taiwan and an insurance company will be set up to take over the insurance business currently operated by the Export- Import Bank, Liu said.

In the third phase, which will be completed in two to three years, the Land Bank of Taiwan will be merged with Bank of Taiwan and the real estate worth over NT$100 billion owned by the two banks might be sold or taken over by a new subsidiary, the minister said, adding that another subsidiary might also be set up to take over the government procurement business that has in turn been taken over by Bank of Taiwan from Central Trust of China.
He estimated that the asset value of Taiwan Financial Holding will reach US$158.8 billion.

As for other financial institutions in which the government has a dominant stake, the ministry will continue to encourage them to merge with other institutions or sell their government-owned stock to private investors, including foreign investors, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top 50 Taiwan firms must cope with global market changes: ratings co.

TEXT.P: The credit quality of Taiwan's top 50 corporations is good and expected to be boosted despite few sign of a global economic revival, but the leading enterprises must seek new ways to tackle today's volatile global markets, a credit ratings company said in a report released Tuesday.
Standard and Poor's Ratings Services (S&P) and its subsidiary Taiwan Ratings Co. (TRC) published the report on the rating outlook for Taiwan's top-tier enterprises.

The high-tech sector comprises the largest ratio of the nation's top 50 firms, accounting for 58 percent of the total, followed by the plastic, steel, telecommunications, aerospace, petroleum, shipping and transportation, retail and electric power industries, the study shows.

The top three high-tech firms continued to play dominant roles in the market, taking advantage of their technical edges, good relations with clients and low cost structures, while coping with competition by seeking technology upgrades and increasing capital expenditure, according to the report.

The credit quality of the top 50 shows continued improvement, with financial conditions growing stronger, including the ratio of cash-flow to debt, the TRC said, predicting that top-tier companies will maintain their stable credit quality this year, or even achieve slightly better performance.

With the growing importance of economy of scale, large-scale companies will particularly be able to better maintain their credit profiles as their operating performances will not easily be affected by domestic economic developments, according to the TRC report.
Improving financial structure, taking measures to respond to economic cycles and making meticulous financial plans and investments are key to maintaining corporate credit quality, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan lawmakers arrive in U.S. to visit submarine manufacturers
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 15 (CNA) 08/15/07 18:55:10 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Seven lawmakers from across the party spectrum arrived at the United States Tuesday to conduct a feasibility study for a submarine procurement deal.

Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Liao Wan-ju said the purpose of the visit is to learn about the production capacity of U.S. submarine manufacturers and the attitude of the U.S. government toward the deal.
The group hopes to "obtain the best submarines for Taiwan at the most reasonable price," according to Liao.

Members of the group also include KMT legislators Shuai Hua-ming and Su Chi, Fu Kun-chi of the opposition People First Party, Ho Ming-hao of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union and Chang Hua-kuan and Shen Fa-hui of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

On speculation that the group could also make a feasibility study on E-2 aircraft and other arms procurement deals, Liao said the group wants to keep the mission simple and will not include other feasibly studies "in principle."
Ho also said they have tight schedule and that it will be a "mission-oriented and professional" visit.
In addition to visiting the Pentagon and other related U.S. government agencies, they will also visit four submarine manufacturers.

Due to the media criticism prior to the group's departure that the trip is a waste of taxpayers' money, the legislators have to foot part of their travel expenses out of their own pockets. The remaining fees will be paid by the Ministry of National Defense and the Legislative Yuan, None of the expenditure will come from the NT$200 million (US$6.06 million) budget set aside for assessing the feasibility of the submarine deal or the most suitable type of vessel for Taiwan's needs.

The group traveled to Washington Wednesday and will also visit Boston as well as four arms manufacturers -- Lockheed Martin, Raytheon, Northrop Grumman and General Dynamics -- before returning to Taiwan August 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: Torrential rain causes massive agricultural losses in Pingtung

TEXT.P: The southernmost county of Pingtung has suffered the biggest agricultural losses in the country due to torrential rain over the past few days, officials of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday.
According to a COA estimate, as of late Tuesday afternoon, agricultural losses as a result of the rain had amounted to NT$227.62 million (US$6.89 million).
Among the crops that suffered the heaviest damage are bananas, melons and leafy vegetables, the officials said.
The aquaculture sector recorded losses of NT$2.72 million, with scores of fishponds completely inundated and having incurred the loss of all their fish, according to the officials.
The flooding, the officials added, had also drowned 271,000 chickens, 33,000 ducks and 14,000 geese, with losses adding up to NT$16.29 million.
The rain was brought to Taiwan by southwesterly air currents that came in the wake of two tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- which churned across Taiwan last week.
Machia township in Pingtung County saw record rainfall of more than 1,000 mm within 24 hours Monday, while other townships recorded between 500 mm and 700 mm of rain in a 24-hour period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eden Foundation fund drive to help 500 disabled children

TEXT.P: An 80-member team from the Eden Social Welfare Foundation and the Nan Shan Life Charity Foundation will depart from Taipei Aug. 18 on a trip around Taiwan to raise funds to buy wheelchairs for disabled children.

Wang Kai-chiang, chairman of the Eden Foundation, told a press conference Wednesday that the 80 volunteer workers will travel on bicycles during the 14-day journey and that they will be led by Hsieh Ching-kuei, a disabled man who will ride with them in an electric wheelchair.

According to Wang, the team will take the No. 1 Provincial Highway and stop in 15 cities and townships, including Hsinchu, Taichung, Nantou, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Hualien, Yilan and Keelung. They will be joined by other cyclists along the way, including local government officials, employees of Nan Shan Life Insurance Co. and other supporters.
The goal of the team is to muster enough funds to buy 500 wheelchairs for disabled children.

The bike tour is part of the Eden Foundation's fund-raising campaign launched last month to purchase wheelchairs for the disabled and canes for the blind. The fund-raising campaign is a continuation of the foundation's "Love Without Borders" project initiated in 1996 to help people with disabilities around the world.
Under this project, the foundation has given away nearly 10,000 wheelchairs worth NT$80 million to disabled people in 20 countries.
The foundation will hold three fund-raising dinners -- one each in Taichung, Kaohsiung and Tainan -- on Aug. 24, 25, and 26, respectively, at NT$2,000 per plate.
It has set a target of mustering NT$12 million (US$362,406) ) to buy 500 wheelchairs for disabled adults and 1,250 white canes for visually impaired people.

The Eden Foundation was founded in 1982 by the late Liu Hsia, a female wheelchair-bound writer who suffered from rheumatic arthritis, with a small office and only two employees. It has evolved into an institution employing 1,200 people, with 65 service centers in 20 cities and counties around Taiwan and branch offices in Malaysia and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: Works by Lukang woodcarving masters on display in Yilan County

TEXT.P: Scores of works by woodcarving masters from Lukang township in Changhua County are on display at Yilan County's National Center for Traditional Arts along with other exhibits at the Taiwan Woodcraft Exhibition.
A spokesman for the center urged the public Wednesday not to miss the opportunity to see these woodcarving masterpieces, saying that the exhibition will last until Sept. 23.

Among others, five of Lukang's nationally renowned woodcarving masters have put their works on display at the exhibition: Shih Cheng-yang, Huang Ma-ching, Huang Huan-wen, Huang Sha-jung and Chen Mien-mo. Their works cover nearly all aspects of life in Taiwan, the spokesman said.
The Taiwan Woodcraft Exhibition, which opened July 1, is displaying some 250 works by dozens of Taiwan's most accomplished woodcarvers.
The exhibits in the main pavilion of the center include traditional and modern works of art, as well as works by mountain aborigines.
Four other pavilions are devoted separately to toys, tools, furniture and musical instruments -- all made of wood.
Conspicuous among other exhibits are works by Chen Cheng-hsiung, a 65-year-old woodcarving master from Tainan in southern Taiwan who has devoted himself to woodcarving since the age of 14.
Chen has created only about 100 works in his 50-year career, with each work taking five to 10 years to complete. Most of his works have already been bought by collectors.
Some of the collectors agreed to lend their works to the exhibition, including a few items priced at more than NT$8 million (US$243,080).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan thanks allies for helping with its U.N. bid

TEXT.P: Taiwan made public Wednesday its gratitude to 15 diplomatic allies for their assistance in the country's latest bid to join the United Nations, after they jointly endorsed a proposal requesting that Taiwan's application for U.N. membership be treated impartially.

In a news release, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) stated that the proposal, delivered to the U.N. General Assembly Tuesday, requested that the assembly press the Security Council to "equitably handle Taiwan's application for membership in accordance with the Rules of Procedure."
The U.N. General Assembly is scheduled to start its 62nd session Sept. 18 in New York. The 15 allies will request that the proposal be listed as a supplementary item on the General Assembly's agenda.
It is expected that the matter will be discussed at the General Committee meeting to be held Sept. 19, according to MOFA.

This year President Chen Shui-bian for the first time submitted the membership application to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon . However, the U.N. Secretariat flatly denied the application, citing U.N. Resolution 2758 as the reason.
Taiwan issued a strong protest at the action and asked the U.N. Secretariat to "correct" its stance, the MOFA said in the news release.
The MOFA also reiterated its interpretation that Resolution 2758 neither mentions anything about Taiwan nor provides China the right to represent the people of Taiwan in the U.N.

The proposal on Taiwan's U.N. bid, raised by the country's allies, aims to urge U.N. members to look at Taiwan's right and need to join the international organization, while demonstrating determination to promote the bid, the news release said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pitches world environmental organization

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said he is willing to promote the establishment of a world environmental organization with people of insight from the rest of the world, especially member countries of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU).
Chen made the remarks Tuesday while attending the second assembly of DPU, attended by nearly 100 foreign guests from 33 nations, in Taipei City.

Founded in 2005, the DPU, an international body initiated and currently chaired by Vice President Annette Lu, aims at promoting "democracy, peace, and prosperity" in the Asian Pacific region and the world.
Chen spoke of his hope of helping to initiate a world environmental organization integrating international powers to deal with environmental changes, challenges, and protection.

Taiwan has made regular contributions to the world in many respects, Chen said, adding that the nation is willing to share its development experience with other countries and make further contributions.

Chen mentioned that the rise of China involves an imbalance of economic growth, high levels of environmental pollution, the oppression of democratic movements and human rights, and continuous military expansion, all of which threaten regional and world peace.
It is the indispensable duty of the DPU to ensure that the economic development of China is accompanied by an "awakening in peace" and "development of democracy," Chen added.

One of the assembly's participants, Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Morales Carazo showed support for Taiwan, calling on the United Nations to re-examine the 2758 resolution that excludes Taiwan from participating in the international body.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pig farmers to protest use of animal drug

TEXT.P: Local hog farmers will demonstrate Aug. 21 in front of the Department of Health (DOH) and the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) to protest a DOH decision to ease a ban on ractopamine -- an animal drug that promotes growth of lean meat in pigs or cattle-- under the U.S. pressure, one of their leaders said Wednesday.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan called by lawmakers, Yang Her-pei, vice chairman of the Republic of China Swine Association, said that pig farmers are set to stage the demonstration or even vote in the coming legislative and presidential elections against the political parties that disregard the health of Taiwan's people and farmers' livelihoods, if the DOH fails to rescind its decision to remove the ban in the coming days.

The DOH announced Tuesday evening that it will ease its ban to allow a limited use of the animal drug, which was listed last year by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) as a banned drug, despite repeated assurances that it would not do so after two shipments of U.S. pork were found last month to contain ractopamine.
Yang suspected that the DOH's decision to relax the ban was a result of pressure from the United States to clear barriers to its pork imports.
"Local hog farmers cannot accept this decision which will allow the United States to dump pork containing an illegal substance in Taiwan," he said.
Cheng Hui-wen, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Sanitation, denied allegation that the DOH's decision to remove the ban on ractompaine was due to U.S. concerns.
Cheng cited the latest scientific evaluation as explaining that some kinds of ractopamine are not harmful to human health and thus raise no food safety concerns for consumers.

Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmakers Yin Ling-ying and Liao Pen-yen,, and main opposition Kuomintang lawmaker Ker Chun-hsiung, threatened to freeze next year's budgets allocated for the DOH and asked Cheng to step down from his post after hearing his explanation.

Yu Kai-hsiung, secretary-general of the Consumers' Foundation, accused Cheng of failing to provide solid evidence to back his rhetoric and said that his foundation will launch a campaign urging local consumers to boycott U.S. pork.

Yu accused the DOH of kow-towing to the United States and described its decision to lift the ban on ractopamine as a "sinister deal" that lacks substantial approval by experts and that will put consumers' health and farmers' livelihoods at great risk.
According to Yu, the Consumers' Foundation will lend its support for pig farmers' demonstration next week to protest the government's softening of its stance regarding the veterinary drug.
Later the same day, an AIT spokesman denied allegation that the institute has pressured Taiwan's authorities to remove the ban.
The AIT is responsible for U.S. dealings with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan city top in barrier-free facilities for pedestrians: survey

TEXT.P: Tainan City was top while Keelung City was bottom in a nationwide assessment of barrier-free facilities for pedestrians, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said Wednesday.

Lee said the ministry commissioned an educational foundation to assess the barrier-free facilities on roads and in parks in the 25 cities and counties, and 139 cities and townships with populations of over 50,000.
The foundation based its assessment on the criteria of "safety, comfort and accessibility," Lee said.
In the urban group, Tainan is followed by Kaohsiung and Chiayi cities, while Keelung and Hsinchu cities are ranked bottom and second from the bottom.
In the rural group, Yunlin, Taichung and Miaoli counties are the best, while Hsinchu, Nantou and Pingtung counties need to be improved.
In the group encompassing remote regions and outlying islands, Taitung and Penghu counties rank first and second, with Matsu at the bottom.

Lee said the ministry will cut subsidies for the cities and counties that ranked bottom in each group by 20 percent, using the money to encourage those on top in each group so that city and county governments will be willing to invest more in creating better environments for pedestrians.

DOC.HEADLINE: Forum to boost Taiwan's competitiveness formed

TEXT.P: A forum organized by academics with the purpose to boost Taiwan's competitiveness was formed Wednesday in Taipei, according to the organizers.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, former Premier Tang Fei, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Hung Chi-chang and several business and industrial leaders attended the inauguration ceremony held in the legislature.

Lin Chien-fu, convener of the forum organized by some 50 professors specialized in economics and public policies, said at the press conference that Taiwan urgently needs to elevate its competitiveness whether it moves toward unification with China, independence or maintaining the status quo, which is why he and his professor friends set up the forum to allow the participants to pounder constructive public policies for the country.

According to Lin, the professors are neither supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) nor of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" and are fed up with the political bickering among the different political parties.

Tang, who organized recently a political group aimed at "saving" Taiwan's future, noted that some 4 million people cast deliberately spoiled ballots or chose not to vote at all in the 2004 presidential election, which in Tang's view represented people's disgust with Taiwan politics. Tang said something has to be done to revive people's confidence in Taiwan.

Winston Wang, son of business tycoon Wang Yung-ching and president of Grace T.H.W. Group, was also present at the press conference. He urged both the ruling and opposition parties to cooperate on pivotal issues involving the people's welfare, which he claimed is "quite normal" in a democratic country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Election of Kaohsiung County township head annulled by court

TEXT.P: A township head of Kaohsiung County, elected in December 2005, will be relieved of his position after the Kaohsiung branch of the Taiwan High Court annulled his election Wednesday on grounds of vote buying.
Lin June-tsung, head of Niaosung township, said he deplores the court ruling on the civil lawsuit but can only accept his fate as the ruling by the high court is final.

The township head assumed office March 1, 2006. The Kaohsiung District Court found Lin guilty of vote buying in a criminal suit in June last year, but the ruling was overturned by the high court in May this year.
Lin, a member of the opposition Kuomintang, said he was puzzled as to which court ruling he should comply with.

In the civil suit, Lin contended that the 27 votes suspected of being bought by his camp was immaterial to the electoral result, as he defeated his opponent, Chen Wan-ting of the Democratic Progressive Party, by 3,034 votes.
The high court, however, rejected that argument and ruled that his election was invalid according to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law.

The Bureau of Civil Affairs of the Kaohsiung County government indicated that Lin will be relieved of his position as soon as the county government receives the court ruling, and that a by-election will take place within three months to fill the vacancy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ruling DPP presidential candidate announces his running mate

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh announced Wednesday that former Premier Su Tseng-chang will serve as his running mate for the presidential election in 2008.
Flanked by a group of DPP legislators and hundreds of supporters, Hsieh made the announcement at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport upon his return to Taiwan from visiting Singapore and Indonesia.

Hsieh said he called Su, who is currently visiting the United States, Tuesday night and the latter said that "in response to public expectation, he is willing to shoulder historical responsibility to serve as my running mate."

A Hsieh-Su ticket is generally considered to have a better chance in winning the presidential election than a ticket featuring Hsieh and former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, although Hsieh was reported to prefer to team up with Yeh at the early stage of his election campaign.

Meanwhile, an evening rally scheduled to take place at the 228 Peace Memorial Park to drum up support for Hsieh-Su ticket has been postponed due to heavy rains that hit central and southern Taiwan in recent days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teenage boy survives heavy flood-tide in Taoyuan

TEXT.P: A teenage boy who was washed away Tuesday by a heavy flood-tide on the Tahan River, in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan, returned home Wednesday after hiding in a cave near the river for more than 10 hours.
The boy, surnamed Liu, was washed away by the rising tide Tuesday afternoon while swimming in the river with three other schoolmates.
Liu's companions called for the police after searching for the boy by themselves for nearly two hours.

The police did not find the boy after mobilizing more than 30 fire fighters, and even resorted to having the water agency stop releasing water from reservoirs on the upstream of the river to facilitate the search.
Waiting to receive information about Liu, the boy's family was despairing and praying for a miracle.
Fortunately, their prayers came true.

A temple guardian near Yuemei Mountain in Taoyuan was surprised to find a frightened boy stood outside the temple Wednesday afternoon. After learning that Liu was the boy for whom the police were searching, the temple guardian called police to take Liu back home.

Liu told police that he was washed away by the rising tide and ended up stuck in a small cave on the riverbed. The boy said he hollered for help when he heard fire fighters passing by, but his voice was drowned out by flood waters.
The boy was scared but remained alert throughout the night in the cave, managing to climb out when the flood waters subsided Wednesday morning.
The police said Liu was lucky to survive the flood waters, while the boy told his family that he would never again dare to swim in the river.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eliminating ambiguity benefits all: ex-U.S. official

TEXT.P: Eliminating ambiguity in the United States' policy on cross-Taiwan Strait relations would benefit trilateral relations between Taiwan, the U.S. and China, and restoration of full diplomatic relations between the U.S. and Taiwan would be the best way of achieving the objective, said an ex-U.S. official Thursday.

Former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations John Bolton, who is in the middle of his first trip to Taiwan in seven years, reiterated in a press meeting that U.S. recognition of Taiwan would bring stability and certainty, and keep China from misreading the situation.

U.S. President George Bush made a clear commitment that the U.S. would defend Taiwan early in his first term before returning to an ambiguous stance on the status of that commitment, which is "more dangerous" for U.S. national interests, Bolton said.

Bolton admitted, however, that the U.S. State Department will not support the idea of restoring diplomatic relations with Taiwan as "the attitude of the Formosa Problem has never left the State Department" since 1949, when the State Department misjudged the situation in Taiwan, predicting that Taiwan's fall to the Communists was inevitable and urging the Americans to leave the island.

He said that he didn't understand how China has successfully portrayed Taiwan as a troublemaker and Taiwan's U.N. referendum as provocative, given that Taiwan poses neither a military nor economic threat to China.

"But some people in the State Department are buying China's argument, " he said, adding that the best time to change the situation will come at the beginning of a new administration and pointing to the opportunity posed by next year's U.S. presidential election.
"I wish to hear someone [in the State Department] say that allowing people to vote in the referendum is provocative, " Bolton said.
The U.S. had been pressing Taiwan's government for over a decade to be democratic, and the State Department is telling Taiwan "not to be so democratic" at this moment, he said.

Bolton also commented on other issues, including Taiwan's U.N. bid. He suggested that Taiwan should focus on repealing U.N. Resolution 2758 as the objective is to "go back to 1971", when former U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. George H.W. Bush proposed "dual representation."

Addressing U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon's mishandling of Taiwan's U.N. membership application, Bolton said that Ban has made a huge mistake, which will help Taiwan in some ways because it will generate interest in America and bring attention to the case.
He also expects that the U.S. Congress "will react very negatively" to Ban during the September session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei welcomes cancellation of baseball tournament in Venezuela

TEXT.P: Taiwan has welcomed the International Baseball Federation's (IBAF's) decision to cancel the 13th Senior League Baseball, which was supposed to open Aug. 17 in Caracas, Venezuela, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Wednesday.
Wang Chien-yeh said the federation's decision would send a message to the world that any country playing host to an international sporting event should not mix sport and politics.

He made the comments after an official of IBAF in Lausanne, Switzerland said the federation decided Tuesday to cancel the tournament in Caracas, partly due to Venezuela's refusal to grant visas to the Taiwanese team.
Taiwan thereby had no chance to compete in the tournament despite four months of fruitless efforts to obtain entry visas to Venezuela.

The IBAF official also cited the inappropriate preparation work of the host country and the threat posed by rampant insurgents in neighboring Columbia, which combined to make many states hesitant about sending teams to the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: Army leader explains delayed flood relief to Kaohsiung Magistrate

TEXT.P: Commander of the Eighth Army Corps in southern Taiwan Chen Liang-chun offered an explanation to Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing Wednesday for delays affecting military rescue forces responding to a flood disaster in the county's Meinung township Monday.
The county suffered floods caused by heavy rains Monday, leaving many houses and vehicles damaged. Several main roads were closed, and more than 100 people were stranded in areas flooded that day.
The county government's Water Resources Bureau officials pointed out that the bureau applied for aid from the military rescue force at 3 p.m. Monday, but had to wait until 7 p.m. for relief.

Chen explained that the corps immediately undertook rescue operations after receiving the order, but the troupe was not able to enter the township as its three connecting roads were all flooded. The troupe began its work early Tuesday morning when the floods started to recede.
Officials said that waiting for authorization from the Ministry of National Defense (MND) was largely responsible for the rescue delay.

Meinung township head Lo Chien-to also explained that he suggested the corps delay rescue operations out of consideration for the safety of the troops and the fact that rescue forces from the county's Fire Bureau had already proceeded with their own relief work in flood areas.

Yang said the current procedure for applying for military assistance in rescue operations is "ridiculous" in terms of emergency response time. The current procedure requires that local governments needing aid submit an application to the Executive Yuan's disaster prevention and relief center.
Yang claimed that military units in local areas should have the right to proceed with disaster relief without authorization from the MND.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer's founder to be Taiwan's envoy to APEC summit in Sydney

TEXT.P: Acer computer group's founder Stan Shih has been appointed by President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday as his envoy to the informal summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, slated for Sept. 8-9 in Sydney, Australia.
Chen made the announcement in a statement issued through his office in which he lauded the Taiwan-educated business tycoon's contribution to the development of the country's hi-tech industry.
The president was reportedly to have named former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen as his envoy to the summit earlier this month but was denied by the host county because of China's opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 16, or the fourth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Americans led by Gen. John Stark defeat the British at the Battle of Bennington during the American Revolution.
1825: Bolivia declares its independence from Spain.
1909: Japanese Chutaro Kido discovers an iron mine in Anshan, Liaoning Province, located in Manchuria, where Japan has extensive economic privileges. The Southern Manchuria Railway later sets up a steel plant in Anshan.
1913: Menachem Begin, Israeli prime minister from 1977 to 1983, is born in Russia. He shared the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize with Anwar Sadat of Egypt.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who had participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty, organizes a revolt in Tahu, Hsinchu County, against Japanese rule of Taiwan in the so-called Miaoli Incident. He was executed after the uprising failed.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1990, is born.
1923: Shimon Peres, Israeli prime minister from 1984 to 1986, is born in Poland.
1937: The Supreme National Defense Council decides at a meeting that the Nationalist government should authorize Chiang Kai-shek as generalisimo to lead the Republic of China armed forces in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: George Herman Ruth, known as "Babe" Ruth, the most famous baseball player of all time, dies in New York City at the age of 53. He broke the Major League home run record in three consecutive seasons (1919-21), and then again in 1927 with a staggering 60 home runs.
1949: Margaret Mitchell, the author of "Gone with the Wind," dies after being hit by a car two days earlier. She was 49.
1950: Taiwan, formerly comprising eight counties and nine cities, is re-divided into 16 counties and five cities.
1960: The new republic of Cyprus comes into being, with Archbishop Makarios as its first president.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Gabon.
1968: The first Poseidon missile is launched.
1974: Wu Kuan-hsiung, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, and Ahmad Sowaidi, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of Qatar, sign a trade cooperation memorandum.
1975: The Republic of China and Nauru sign a civil aviation agreement.
1977: Elvis Presley, the king of rock and roll, dies of heart failure at the age of 42 after collapsing in his mansion in Memphis, Tenn.
1978: Cardinal Yu Pin dies of a heart attack in Rome at the age of 77.
1979: John G. Diefenbaker, Canadian politician who served as prime minister from 1957 to 1963, dies at the age of 84. The Progressive Conservative government he headed lost the 1963 general elections because of opposition to his proposals to build nuclear weapons in Canada.
1990: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warns U.S. President George Bush that thousands of the troops he has sent to the Gulf will return home in coffins.
1996: Leonel Fernandez becomes the 100th president of the Dominican Republic.
1999: Two Republic of China warships, the Hui Yang and the Han Yang, are decommissioned after almost 30 years of service, bringing to 10 the total number of naval vessels decommissioned by the ROC.
2000: Visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation take part in the inauguration of Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia held at the Parliament Building.
2000: ROC Premier Tang Fei unveils a proposal to transform Taiwan into a knowledge-based economy that is on par with those of the world's most advanced nations within ten years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In order to acquire truth, it is necessary to obtain a wide and extensive knowledge of what has been said and done in the world; to critically inquire into it; to carefully ponder over it; to clearly sift it; and to earnestly carry it out."

DOC.HEADLINE: Sea warning issued for Typhoon Sepat

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau issued a sea warning for Typhoon Sepat Thursday as the storm continued to approach Taiwan.
At 8 a.m., the typhoon was centered 830 km southeast of Taitung in eastern Taiwan, moving northwesterly at 17-20 kph toward the island and packing maximum sustained winds of 184 kph.
Forecasters said Sepat is posing a threat to waters southeast of Taiwan and the Bashih Channel, urging ships operating in these areas to be extra careful.
Lu Kuo-chen, a section chief at the bureau's Weather Forecast Center, said a land warning for the typhoon is expected to be issued Thursday afternoon or night.
According to Lu, the eye of Sepat can be clearly seen on satellite pictures, which indicates that the storm is well-structured and can be very destructive.
With a radius of 250 km, the typhoon covers an area larger than the size of Taiwan, Lu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expat group stages rally to urge fugitive tycoon to return to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 15 (CNA) 08/16/07 13:01:26 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Representatives of a U.S.-based Taiwanese expatriate organization staged a demonstration outside the Los Angeles residence of fugitive Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng Wednesday to urge him to return to Taiwan to face criminal charges.
Members of the Taiwanese Benevolent Association of America, led by president Lo Su-o, made the move after their request to meet with Wang and his wife, Wang Chin She-ying, was rejected.

Not getting the opportunity to talk to the Wangs face-to-face, the members displayed posters condemning the couple as "lacking morality and conscience" for leaving behind huge debts in Taiwan and fleeing to the United States, and urging the couple to return to Taiwan to face justice.
Lo said her association had originally intended to politely try to persuade the Wangs to return to Taiwan and had written to the couple to express their desire to meet with them.
However, the association was informed by Wang's lawyer Tuesday of Wang's decision to turn down the request, Lo said.
Lo said her association will continue following and watching the pair wherever they go because "they have cheated the Taiwan people out of a lot of money."

Wang was released on bail Aug. 7 from an immigration holding center in San Pedro, Calif., where he had been held since Feb. 2 after trying to return to Los Angeles with both his Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports canceled, following a failed attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore.

Wang is suspected of having embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds from the Rebar Group before fleeing with his wife to China late last year and then to the United States in January this year.
Taiwan authorities placed the couple on the country's most-wanted list Jan. 15 and have been seeking U.S. assistance to have them repatriated back to Taiwan to face charges.

In March, Taiwanese prosecutors indicted Wang and 106 others involved in the Rebar Group scandal on a long list of charges, including fraud, money laundering and insider trading. They are seeking a prison sentence of 30 years and an unprecedented fine of NT$1.71 billion (US$52.13 million) for Wang.
