DOC.HEADLINE: Motion on Taiwan's membership bid submitted to United Nations
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 15 (CNA) 08/16/07 15:00:22 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Fifteen of Taiwan's diplomatic allies have put forward a motion at the United Nations pressing the world body to deal with Taiwan's membership application according to established procedures, Taiwan officials posted in New York said Wednesday.

The motion, which the allies said they hope can be included on the agenda of the upcoming annual gathering of the U.N. General Assembly, was submitted to the General Assembly Tuesday by the ambassadors to the U.N. from The Gambia, Swaziland and Tuvalu, three of the motion's sponsors. The other sponsors were Belize, Burkina Faso, Honduras, Kiribati, Malawi, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Palau, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Sao Tome and Principe, and the Solomon Islands.

The 62nd regular session of the General Assembly is scheduled to open Sept. 18 at the United Nations Headquarters in New York. The General Committee is expect to meet Sept. 19 to finalize the agenda of the session.

The Republic of China has tried without success to re-enter the United Nations since 1993. This year marks the first time it has changed tactics by bidding to join the world body under the name of Taiwan.

President Chen Shui-bian sent a membership application letter on behalf of Taiwan to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon July 19, but the letter was returned by Ban based on U.N. Resolution 2758, which U.N. officials said is the basis of the "one China" policy of the United Nations.

On July 31, Chen sent a second letter to Ban urging him to reconsider his decision and one to Wang Guangya, China's permanent representative to the United Nations, who served as rotating president of the Security Council for July. Both letters wer also returned.

Taiwan has strongly protested Ban's move, claiming that only the Security Council and the General Assembly have the authority to review and decide on membership applications and that the U.N. Secretariat does not have the power to decide on such matters.
Also, Taiwan argued that Resolution 2758 neither grants China the right to represent Taiwan at the United Nations nor states that Taiwan is either a part of China or the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices nosedive on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange plummeted Thursday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 391.67 points to close at 8,201.37.
The bourse opened at 8,397.24 and fluctuated between 8,438.08 and 8,166.08 during trading. A total of 5.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$180.26 billion (US$5.44 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 7.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 6.61 percent, textile stocks at 6.42 percent, construction issues at 5.82 percent, paper and pulp issues at 5.31 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 4.73 percent, banking and financial shares at 3.97 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 3.89 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,656 to 87, with 78 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September dropped 294 points to close at 8,154, with 86,225 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved down 436 points to finish at 8,158, with 608 contracts traded, while December futures lost 301 points to close at 8,156, with 190 contract transactions. March futures dropped 311 points to close at 8,150, with 36 contracts traded, while June futures decreased 325 points to finish at 8,119, with 15 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 8,448 for August, 8,594 for October, 8,457 for December, 8,461 for March and 8,444 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

September TE futures moved down 12.6 points to close at 341.4, with 6,437 contracts traded, while October TE futures dropped 23.1 points to finish at 339.1, with 63 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 13.8 points to close at 339.4, with 10 contracts traded, while March TE futures decreased 19.65 points to finish at 335, with two contracts traded. June TE futures fell 21.15 points to close at 338.25, with one contract traded.

September TF futures dropped 27.4 points to close at 930.6, with 4,024 contracts traded, while October TF futures moved down 52.6 points to finish at 925.4, with 61 contract transactions. December TF futures fell 23.4 points to close at 936.6, with 13 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan driver's licenses eligible for use in Japan from Sept. 19
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/07 15:54:33 (By Yang Ming-chu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Japanese Cabinet approved Wednesday an amendment to its traffic laws that recognizes Taiwan driver's licenses.
Under the amendment, holders of Taiwan driver's licenses will be able to drive on roads in Japan from Sept. 19, a Taiwan official stationed in Tokyo said Thursday.
The goodwill measure adopted by the Japanese government follows its granting of 90-day visa-free treatment to Taiwan tourists in September 2005.
According to the official, Taiwan's government will recognize Japanese driver's licenses in the near future as a reciprocal gesture.
Under the Japanese regulations, a translated certificate should be attached to the driver's licenses.

According to reports, travel service operators in the Japanese Prefecture of Hokkaido had made great efforts to persuade the Japanese government to recognize Taiwan driver's licenses as Taiwan is one of the main sources of foreign tourists to the prefecture.

According to official Japanese statistics, some 300,000 Taiwan tourists visit Hokkaido annually. Taiwan tourists made a total of more than 1.3 million visits to Japan last year, ranking behind only South Korean tourists, who made a total of 2.1 million visits.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taxi driver arrested for alleged murder of Chinese woman

TEXT.P: A taxi driver was arrested Thursday on suspicion of having murdered a Chinese woman, whose mutilated body was found dumped in a public graveyard in Pali on the outskirts of Taipei a day earlier.
The suspected murderer, identified by his surname of Chuei, was described by police as "Taiwan's Jack the Ripper" because he cut open the woman's body from the heart down to the lower belly.

The police arrested Chuei early Thursday after human blood was detected in his taxi. The police brought him to the location of the body in the Pali graveyard, where he admitted that he killed the woman, identified as Liu Liqing, at a motel Tuesday out of anger as a result of a financial dispute and then cleaned the body before dumping it in the graveyard.
The police had also brought in two ex-husbands of Liu's for questioning Wednesday, but both of them were cleared and released the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: President inspects flooded areas in Pingtung

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Thursday that the government will end the long- term flooding problem in the southern county of Pingtung, adding that resolve is the key to success.
Chen made the remarks during an inspection tour of the southern county's Tungkang township, which was heavily flooded by recent torrential rain.
The township is always flooded when the daily precipitation exceeds 400 mm due to its location at the convergence of three rivers, Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung told Chen at a briefing.
Nevertheless, a flood diversion project and two pumping stations could prevent the flooding from occurring again, Tsao said, calling for central government subsidies.
Chen promised to offer subsidies to facilitate an early start of the flood- fighting projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, rising NT$0.118 to close at NT$33.128.
A total of US$1.25 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.963 and hit a high of NT$33.170.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung city seeks right to host world baseball tournament

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday that his city wants to seek the right to host the 13th Youth World Baseball Championship (YWBC) after the entire championship was canceled because the Taiwan team was refused visas to enter Venezuela, the host country.

The Switzerland-based International Baseball Federation (IBAF) canceled the Caracas tournament Tuesday after the host country succumbed to pressure from China to refuse the visas for Taiwanese baseballers. The tournament was originally scheduled to open Aug. 17.

Hu pointed out that canceling an international game on the eve of its opening is a serious matter and that such situation has never happened to the YWBC since its first tournament held in Japan in 1989.
The shambles in Venezuela reflects the universal principle that "politics should not affect sports, " Hu said, expressing his appreciation for the IBAF's just handling of the situation.

Speaking about the central city's desire to host the 13th YWBC, which will be postponed for 12 months while the IBAF finds another venue for the tournament, Hu said Taichung is on the IBAF's priority list of possible YWBC host cities, after his city hosted the IBAF Intercontinental Cup tournament last year.
Besides Taichung, Japan and South Korea have both expressed their willingness to host the international event.
Hu said August is not a good month to hold the tournament in Taiwan because of the hot weather and he suggested that the IBAF hold the competition in the winter.

The mayor also advised the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to grant visas to the Venezuelan team should it be invited to attend games held in Taiwan, reiterating his call for no political interference in sports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most students have 1st contact with pornography at age 13-15: poll

TEXT.P: More than 65 percent of students responding to a recent survey have had experience using pornography, with most first-time contacts with pornography taking place between the ages of 13 and 15, officials of the Bureau of Health Promotion said Thursday.

The survey was conducted online by the Mercy Memorial Foundation for the bureau from June 15-30 among 3,614 undergraduates and students studying in senior high schools, junior high schools and senior years of elementary schools. The respondents comprised 1,733 boys and 1,881 girls.

According to the results of the survey, 15.3 percent of students in senior years of elementary schools, 38 percent of junior high students, 69.3 percent of senior high students and 79.4 percent of undergraduates admitted to having used pornography.
Fifty percent of junior high students, 51.9 percent of senior high students and 35 percent of undergraduates said they had their first contact with pornography between the ages of 13 and 15.

The figures compare with 27.8 percent of students in senior years of elementary school, 16.4 percent of junior high students and 14.8 percent of senior high students who said they had used pornography before the age of 10.
Among the boys who have used pornography, 72 percent have seen erotic films, 65.5 percent have looked at erotic pictures and 58.5 percent have visited erotic Web sites.
Among the girls, 53.4 percent have seen erotic comics, 46.3 percent have read erotic fiction and 40.7 percent have seen erotic films.

Noting that the age of first contact with pornography is getting younger, foundation CEO Yen Han-wen urged parents to provide the "correct" sex knowledge to their children to prevent them from imitating pornography, which he claimed presents undesirable information such as violence, sadism and incest.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: More rains expected until Sunday
The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) yesterday warned communities in western sections of Luzon and the Visayas to brace for heavy rains today and tomorrow as Typhoon Egay further intensifies and continues to enhance the southwest monsoon.
The Philippine Daily InquirerG Arroyo gets stuck in flood
MANILA, Philippines -- As the country's weather swung from one extreme to another, pounding rains from Typhoon "Egay" (international codename: Sepat) Wednesday turned Metro Manila streets into rivers, paralyzing a wide area of the metropolis and bringing misery to millions. No less than President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo had a taste of what it was like to get stuck in floods and traffic when her convoy was caught in one of the day's monstrous traffic jams, forcing her to swing around so she could reach her appointments on Wednesday morning.
The Philippine StarG Rains bring MM to a standstill
Metro Manila residents yesterday woke up to torrential rains which flooded the metropolis, disrupting classes and businesses and leaving thousands stranded on streets that turned into rivers and virtual parking lots.
The Manila TimesG Floods grip Metro; more rains ahead
Heavy rains lashed Metro Manila Wednesday, flooding streets and causing major disruptions to businesses and schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Councils told to stop clamping cars for profit
Parking wardens will be banned from clamping cars for single offences as part of the biggest overhaul of parking rules in more than a decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-Taiwan FTA long overdue: U.S. scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 15 (CNA) 08/16/07 18:35:55 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Heritage Foundation scholar said Wednesday in a report that U.S. businesses generally support the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between the United States and Taiwan and that such an agreement is long overdue.

For the benefit of the United States, the U.S. should sign an FTA with Taiwan the sooner the better, John J. Tkacik, a senior research fellow in China, Taiwan and Mongolia Policy in the Asian Studies Center of the Heritage Foundation wrote in an article that was published on-line Wednesday titled Free Trade with Taiwan is Long Overdue.

A U.S.-Taiwan FTA has a lot to offer for everyone and promises to be more beneficial to U.S. exports than to Taiwan's exports, Tkacik said, adding that a U.S.-Taiwan FTA has the potential to boost American jobs in key manufacturing industries, with autos and business equipment topping the list.

U.S. manufacturers of other machinery and equipment, especially office equipment, engines, turbines, communications equipment, appliances and an array of industrial control computers would enjoy similar increases in exports if a U.S.-Taiwan FTA were signed, he said.

Meanwhile, he went on, Taiwan is an important global power in its own right. Taiwan is now the world's 16th-largest economy, the 10th-largest trading power and the "third-largest holder of foreign exchange reserves after China and Japan."

He said Taiwan has a larger population than Australia and a larger gross domestic product than any member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) . For the past two decades, he said, Taiwan has consistently ranked as one of America's top 10 export markets and it already gives fairly free access to imported U.S. goods and services, which totaled $23 billion in 2006.
Among other things, a U.S.-Taiwan FTA would increase U.S. rice, poultry and livestock exports and open a significant new market for new research medicines, he added.
American pharmaceutical companies would also gain, given Taiwan officials' openness in discussing National Health Insurance (NHI) pharmaceutical reimbursements, he continued.

Tkacik said that automobiles, machinery and agriculture are some of the main trade concerns on Capitol Hill and noted that annual U.S. exports in these sectors would surge under an FTA with Taiwan. Furthermore, he said, Taiwan has a developed economy on par with Europe, with labor and environmental standards that are world-class and intellectual property protection that has earned the praise of U.S. businesses.

He said that while many members of the U.S. Congress oppose free trade agreements and are reluctant to authorize full trade promotion authority, there "should be room" for a broad bipartisan consensus on an FTA with Taiwan.

For its part, he said, Taiwan seems willing both to meet the high bar of the U.S. Trade Representative's "gold standard" FTA template on trade and investment issues and to address Congress's concern about labor and environmental issues. Congress should seriously consider a country-specific mandate to begin FTA negotiations with Taiwan along with instructions on how to structure the FTA.

Beijing would, of course, complain about a U.S.-Taiwan FTA and would undoubtedly say that a free trade agreement that must be approved by Congress is qualitatively different from previous executive agreements, Tkacik admitted.

But Washington could tell Beijing that it intends to "maintain cultural, commercial and other unofficial relations with the people of Taiwan under the stipulations of the Taiwan Relations Act," he said.
Moreover, he added, it is a diplomatic imperative that the United States not allow China to dictate either the form or substance of U.S. trade relations with Taiwan.
The article was authored by Tkacik and Daniella Markheim, who is a Jay Van Andel senior trade policy analyst at the Center for International Trade and Economics at the Heritage Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei aerospace, defense technology exhibition opens

TEXT.P: The Taipei Aerospace and Defense Technology Exhibition opened Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with 63 international businesses taking part in the four-day event.

A total of 602 booths were set up at the venue by aviation, naval and land defense technology contractors and manufacturers, including world leaders such as Dassault, Lockheed Martin, Raytheon, Pratt and Whitney and L-3 Communications.

The scale of the 2007 show, the ninth of its kind, is some 50 percent larger than the previous one that was held in 2005, according to the organizers -- the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and the Singapore-based Reed Exhibitions, one of the world's leading events organizers.

It has been assessed that orders for military-use products will reach NT$18 billion (US$541.7 million) in the biennial exhibition, which is the only professional aerospace and national defense weapons and equipment show in Taiwan, the TAITRA said.

TAITRA Deputy Secretary-General Yeh Ming-shuei said many newly developed products are being displayed at the show, including multi-function displays (MFDs) for jet fighters and computer devices with flat screens and anti-shock protection.
The exhibition is expected to attract over 40,000 visitors, including buyers from the United States, Germany, Britain, Australia, India, Thailand, Singapore and Japan, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier encourages Taiwan delegation for world disabled games

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung encouraged the Taiwan delegation for the 2007 World Wheelchair and Amputee Games to achieve great victory with the true spirit of sportsmanship during a flag-presentation ceremony Thursday.
Chang expressed his admiration for physically challenged athletes as they require much more efforts to excel in the sports arena.
The event is scheduled to be held Sept. 9-19 in Taipei City and will be attended by 576 physically challenged players from 44 countries and areas.

The participants will compete in eight sports -- archery, track and field, badminton, fencing, power lifting, shooting, swimming and table tennis -- seven of which will be qualifying matches for the Beijing 2008 Paralympic Games.

Defeating four serious contenders -- the United States, South Korea, Israel and South Africa, Taiwan won the bid to host the 2007 World Wheelchair and Amputee Games at the previous games, the first of their kind, in Brazil in 2005, said Chen Lee-chou, chairwoman of the Chinese Taipei Paralympic Committee.
The Taiwan delegation won three gold medals, seven silvers and five bronzes at the previous Games, Chen said.
In an attempt to get better results in this year's Games, Taiwan is fielding 62 men and 22 women, which is the biggest team in the Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't aid to SMEs to increase by nearly 50%: economics minister

TEXT.P: The government will increase its financial aid by 50 percent this year to help the country's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) develop, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen said Thursday.

Speaking at a colloquium held in the southern county of Tainan with several hundreds of SME owners and executives, Chen said that about 98 percent of Taiwan's private companies are SME operations, and their flexibility and durability have made them a driving force behind Taiwan's economic growth.

As part of a new policy touted by President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to offer better care for the country's less-advantaged groups and low-income families, those living in central and southern Taiwan, as well as the SMEs, Chen said the administration has decided to increase its financial aid by 50 percent this year to benefit the development of small- and medium-sized enterprises.

Meanwhile, Chen added, the Ministry of Economic Affairs will see to it that funds to a tune of NT$1.6 trillion (US$48.48 billion) are made available as loans for SME operations over the next three years.
The ministry also plans on investing some NT$10 billion to help new business owners start up joint ventures, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elementary school in Changhua to make cultural exchanges with Perth

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Nanguo Elementary School in Changhua County, central Taiwan, will set off on a visit to Perth, Australia, Aug. 19 to strengthen cultural exchanges with the Australian city, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said Thursday.

It will be the second time the elementary school has represented Changhua County in cultural exchanges with a foreign country, Cho said. Last year, the school made a cultural visit to a New Zealand elementary school.
Cho presented a flag Thursday to the delegation and wished them a happy and successful eight-day visit to Australia.
According to Cho, Perth's mayor will receive the students during their stay there and the students will present musical performances and traditional dance.
Cho said the Aug. 19-26 visit is aimed at elevating the students' global vision and allowing the world to better understand Changhua County, home to many of Taiwan's agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: R&D on 'green' steel-structure prefab houses launched

TEXT.P: A new development project on eco-friendly prefabricated housing has been initiated by a research group at Chaoyang University of Technology (CYUT) in Taichung County, university sources said Thursday.
They explained that these steel-structure prefab houses integrate ideas to both cut energy consumption and reduce environmental impact.

Wang Min-chao, Dean of CYUT's College of Enterprise Innovation, said that through a combination of wall cavities, double skin, and wave-plate roofing, temperatures inside the prefabs can be moderated naturally to reduce the use of air-conditioning or heating systems.
Wang noted that the team expects to finish the project in one year, and that, hopefully, mass production will begin shortly afterwards.

Even though the cost per unit is currently about NT$2 million (approximately US$60,300), Wang said the price could be reduced after all components have been modulized and standardized in commercial production.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Society of Quantum Technology launched at NCKU

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Society of Quantum Technology, the first of its kind, has been established at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan City, to promote research in quantum sciences, nano technology and biomedical studies, academic sources reported Thursday.
The first major event to be organized by the society will be the 2007 Seminar on Quantum- and Nano-Technology at end of this year, said Hwang Chi-chuan, chairman of the new society.
The members of the society come mainly from local academia, with 12 of them forming the board of directors, added Hwang, who is also a professor at NCKU's Department of Engineering Science.

According to a statement issued by the society, the objectives of the society include: to gather information on the latest developments in related areas; to promote local research and applications in these areas; and to facilitate exchanges among academia, the public sector and the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Land warning to be issued for typhoon Sepat

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) is set to issue a land warning at 8: 30 p.m. Thursday for Typhoon Sepat for the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung, as well as the Hengchun Peninsula on the southernmost tip of Taiwan, after earlier releasing a sea warning.
At 5 p.m. the typhoon was centered 690 km southeast of Taitung in eastern Taiwan, and moving northwesterly at 17-20 km/h toward the island and packing maximum sustained winds of 191 km/h.
Forecasters said Sepat poses a threat in waters southeast of Taiwan and the Bashih Channel, and urged ships operating in these areas to take additional precautions.
The typhoon is forecast to hit Taiwan Friday afternoon, with the greatest impact being seen Saturday.
According to CWB data, Typhoon Sepat, a potentially destructive strong typhoon, is moving toward Taiwan on a course similar to those of typhoons Tim in 1994, and Bilis in 2000.

Those two typhoons caused heavy human casualties and property damage in Taiwan, the data shows. Due to Tim's devastation, 17 people died and other 70 were injured as strong winds and torrential rains following Tim paralyzed road, railway and air traffic in eastern Taiwan.
Tim formed on the seas off eastern Luzon of the Philippines, July 10, then moved northwesterly before striking Taiwan in the area of the mouth of the Siouguluan River in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.

Typhoon Bilis took shape Aug. 22 over the seas off of the eastern Philippines before heading northwesterly toward Taiwan. After landing near Taitung, southeastern Taiwan, it destroyed 434 houses and washed out many roads. Eleven people died due to Bilis' devastation, which was attributed to agricultural losses valued at NT$4.74 billion, the CWB data showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's new U.N. bid ad calls for end to political apartheid

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exclusion from the United Nations over the past 36 years has been likened to a form of political apartheid and should be brought to an end, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Thursday in a press conference to announce Taiwan's U.N. bid advertisement for this year.

Shieh unveiled a poster featuring the image of a hunch-backed figure in a fish bowl, symbolic of Taiwan's limited international space, as well as the slogans "A vital life should not be limited, a democratic nation not isolated" and "End political apartheid."
"To some extent, the U.N.'s exclusion of Taiwan is similar to South Africa's ethnic separation from 1948 - 1994. It has been a form of political apartheid, " said Shieh.

The 36 years of exclusion from the U.N. have been unfair to Taiwan, which had also suffered under 50 years of Japanese colonial rule and 38 years of martial law under the Kuomintang (KMT), Shieh said.

The GIO will start placing the advertisement in major U.S. newspapers and magazines, such as the New York Times and Time Magazine, as well as newsstands and bus stops in New York City from late August to promote Taiwan's brand new U.N. bid this year, which for the first time will see the country apply for a full U.N. membership under the name Taiwan.
Promotional films in various languages will also be aired in a number of countries before the annual meeting of the U.N. General Assembly being held in New York City in September, Shieh said.
The promotion project is being conducted with a budget of a little more than NT$10 million, he said.

"U.N.'s exclusion of Taiwan is not in line with the global trend towards democracy. U.N. Resolution 2758 was passed in 1971 against the background of a Chinese civil war between two dictators -- Mao Zedong and Chiang Kai-shek -- but it has continued to limit the international space of a democratic Taiwan for almost three decades since, " Shieh said.

"We know this [Taiwan's U.N. bid] is going to be difficult, but we have to do it, " he said, also jokingly adding that the GIO renounced the copyrights of the advertisements and everyone is welcome to reproduce and distribute them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Day care centers banned from employing foreign teachers: officials

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reiterated Thursday that day care centers around the country are all banned from employing foreigners to give foreign language lessons.
Under the Employment Service Act, violators against the law will face fines ranging from NT$150,000 to NT$750,000, CLA said in a news release.

Explaining the reason that no day care centers are allowed to hire foreign teachers, CLA said the measure is part of the country's general educational policy. The government believes the children in day care are in a key period in the formation of language capacity, therefore their learning should center on the mother tongue language, the CLA news release said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police detain six gangsters in fifth round of crackdown: NPA

TEXT.P: Police detained six gang leaders Thursday at the first day of the fifth round of crackdown on organized crime of this year, according to National Police Agency (NPA) officers.

The six gangsters, including one woman, were already blacklisted by the Chihping Anti-Gangster Program -- a large-scale crackdown on organized crime -- for their alleged connections to local criminal rings. Their crimes range from blackmail and violent loan sharking to manipulating the betel nut market.

With the approach of legislative and presidential elections to be held early next year, the police have redoubled their surveillance of gangsters to prevent them from using violence to affect the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: No twists in Taiwan-China ties in run-up to elections: MAC

TEXT.P: No major twists in cross-Taiwan Strait ties will take place in the run-up to two key elections in Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Thursday.

Chen made the comments in a seminar held jointly by the MAC and the semi- official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan to explain the government's trade and economic policy toward China and explore public opinions in this regard.

Stating that the government will maintain its current policy toward China based on the "Taiwan-centric" notion of seeking economic benefits while safeguarding national security and sovereignty, Chen gave assurances that "drastic surprises" in Taiwan-China links are unlikely prior to next year's Jan. 12 legislative election and March 22 presidential election.

As the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has been soliciting public endorsement to hold a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid alongside the presidential poll, many people are concerned whether cross-strait ties would be affected by this matter, according to Chen.
Nonetheless, Chen promised that the government is poised to maintain its present China policy to keep peace in the strait and allow Taiwanese companies to continue expanding.

The government fully realizes that cross-strait relations are critical to Taiwan's development and are of a great importance to the continued growth of Taiwan's businesses, he said, repeating that the government will seek to improve bilateral ties, manage a stable relationship between the two sides and build peace in the region.

Citing government statistics, Chen reported that cross-strait trade totaled over US$88.1 billion last year, while Taiwan's people made more than 4.4 million visits to China during the same year -- figures indicating that cross-strait economic and trade activities form an extremely essential part of Taiwan's economic expansion.

Speaking on the same occasion, SEF Chairman Hung Chi-chang said that now is the time that China-based Taiwan businessmen consider shifting their operations to Taiwan in view of rising production costs in China.
The government and the SEF are more than willing to help Taiwan businessmen hoping to operate in the home market, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Association condemns rude behavior toward journalists

TEXT.P: The Association of Taiwan Journalists condemned Thursday a security guard for President Chen Shui-bian's daughter Chen Hsing-yu and Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng for what they claimed was "rude behavior" toward photo journalists.
The association issued the condemnation in a press statement after the security guard and Tu pushed two camera journalists on different occasions a day earlier.
The association called for apologies to the reporters and respect for journalists' "rights."

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer founder looks forward to APEC mission

TEXT.P: Acer Group founder Stan Shih said Thursday he will use his influence within the information technology (IT) industry worldwide to promote the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum Digital Opportunity Center (ADOC) project when he participates in an APEC leadership meeting on behalf of President Chen Shui- bian.
The tycoon made the pledge a day after Chen announced that he had named Shih as his special envoy to the 2007 APEC summit, slated for Sept. 8-9 in Sydney, Australia.

Shih said he feels great responsibility about the job and expressed hope that through the summit he can share his longstanding IT experience and resources with other member states in order to contribute to Taiwan and the international community.

As what will be his main mission, Shih said concrete plans will be unveiled after he exchanges views with Chen, although he said he will be proactive on issues related to the digital divide and will seek to forge economic and trade relations with other member states.

He also noted that Taiwan's edge in hardware production has been instrumental in the implementation of the ADOC project, adding that Taiwan needs to further integrate the efforts and resources of the United States, Japan and South Korea.
Shih is recognized for having built his company into one of Taiwan's internationally recognized computer brand names.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former vice premier to be 'Hsieh-Su' ticket's top campaign manager

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, who was previously reported as being favored by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh to join him on DPP's presidential ticket, confirmed Thursday that she has accepted Hsieh's invitation to be his top campaign manager.

Yeh, a woman who is devotedly supported by many of the country's Hakka people, said that she will do her utmost to drum up support for Hsieh and his running mate -- former Premier Su Tseng-chang, Hsieh's presidential primary rival who nodded his agreement only a day earlier to be Hsieh's running mate -- as the ticket's top campaign officer until the DPP finally wins the 2008 race.
Yeh also appealed to her Hakka supporters for their understanding that she is not teaming up with Hsieh as they previously anticipated and urged them to support the Hsieh-Su ticket.
She said she would be grateful if the Hakka supporters throw their staunch support behind her so they can jointly stump for the Hsieh-Su ticket and keep the DPP in office for another term.
Hsieh, also formerly a premier, announced Wednesday that former Premier Su will serve as his running mate in the 2008 presidential election.

A Hsieh-Su ticket is generally considered to have a better chance at winning the presidential election than a ticket featuring Hsieh and Yeh, although Hsieh reportedly preferred teaming up with Yeh at an earlier stage of his election campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative Yuan on its own over Control Yuan member consent: speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that the legislature acts on its own and makes its own decisions when it comes to exercising its right to confirming new Control Yuan members.

Wang quoted Item 632 of the explanations of the Council of Grand Justice as stipulating that the President has the right to nominate Control Yuan members while the Legislative Yuan has the right to screen and confirm the nominations.

Wang made the remarks after the Presidential Office said earlier in the day that President Chen Shui-bian would draw up a new list of Control Yuan member nominees if the Legislative Yuan agrees to screen the nominations.
The speaker said that so long as the list is referred to the Legislative Yuan, the legislature will naturally do its job.

The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, has been left vacant since the terms of the previous Control Yuan members expired in January 2005 as the opposition-dominated legislature has refused to screen the list proposed by President Chen over dissatisfaction with some of the nominees, especially the nominee to serve as Control Yuan president: Clement C.P. Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's financial structure healthy: CBC governor

TEXT.P: Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan said Thursday that Taiwan's financial structure is quite healthy, despite the Taipei stock market's serious slide that day.

Jolted by a credit crisis caused by sub-prime loan problems in the United States, Taipei stock markets dropped 391 points Thursday, with the New Taiwan dollar losing ground against the U.S. dollar three days in a row.
Perng refused to comment on Taipei stock market's tumble, but said that in a globalized economy, it is unlikely that Taiwan's stock market will be unaffected by the global financial situation.
However, Perng reaffirmed that Taiwan's financial structure is "healthy, " and the CBC will adopt adequate measures to stabilize local monetary market.
The New Taiwan dollar dropped significantly Thursday, losing NT$0.118 against the U.S. dollar to close at NT$33.128.

It is reported that foreign investors remitted out some US$500 million or US$600 million from Taiwan Thursday. However, Perng did not want to comment on that as he said the amount was merely speculative.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pig farmers' opinions on animal drug will be heeded: gov't official

TEXT.P: In response to next week's planned demonstration by pig farmers in Taipei against a government plan to allow the use of a veterinary drug, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Thursday that the government will fully take farmers' opinions into account before lifting the ban.

According to Shieh, the government has heard the voices of hog farmers and the Council of Agriculture (COA) will step up communications with them to ensure that they gain a better understanding of a safe use of the animal drug which promotes the growth of lean meat in livestock.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) decided to lift the ban on ractopamine by the end of this month at the earliest, after having studied the drug's use in the United States and Japan, Shieh said.

The DOH is set to permit regulated amounts of ractopamine residues in different organs of pigs and cattle and their meat after Aug. 21 if no one voices opposition, he said, and denied that the decision was made due to strong pressure exerted by the United States, he said.
Later the same day, the Consumers' Foundation issued a statement expressing its objections to the government's plan to legalize the use of the banned drug.

The foundation urged the DOH and COA not to give way to foreign pressure and allow the drug use, which they say will pose great risks to consumers' health, especially to patients with liver and heart problems.

Over 10,000 people from across Taiwan are set to demonstrate next Tuesday in front of relevant agencies and the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) against a government decision to lift the ban on ractopamine due to pressure from the United States, a representative from the local pig-raising industry said the same day.

Wang Feng-ming, chairman of the Republic of China hog-raising association, said that in addition to some 7,000 pig farmers from central and southern region, thousands of consumers and environmental protection and female rights activists will also take part in the demonstration in front of the DOH.

From the DOH, demonstrators will proceed to the AIT and the Council of Agriculture (COA) , where they will also stage protests against the easing of the ban, Wang said, adding that pig farmers are prepared to stage a series of demonstrations over the long term if the government fails to repeal its ban decision by Aug. 21.

Despite repeated assurances, the DOH and COA announced Tuesday that they will lift the ban on ractopamine and denied allegations that the decision was made as a result of U.S. concerns after two shipments of U.S. pork imports were found to contain the unlawful substance.

Wang accused the government of turning a blind eye to local hog producers' livelihoods and consumers' health concern, questioning the meaning of the government's efforts over the past decade in guiding farmers not to use the drug, which promotes the growth of lean meat in livestock.

Earlier the same day, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker Yin Ling-ying demanded the government give a reasonable explanation of its lifting of the ban on ractopamine and asked relevant agency chiefs to resign from their posts to assume responsibility for what she called a mistaken policy.

Speaking at a news conference held in Yunlin county in southern Taiwan that was also attended by representatives from the local pig- raising association, Yin urged the DOH and the COA to provide the public with a sensible explanation of their decision to allow the use of ractopamine.
Yin also urged relevant DOH and COA officials to step down from their posts and assume responsibility.
The two agencies announced Tuesday that they would lift the ban on the animal drug which was banned by the COA last year.

Although government officials said that limited use of ractopamine is lawful in 24 countries, including the United States and Japan, she asked why they did not also point out that the animal drug is banned in more than 160 other countries.
She threatened to take pig farmers to the streets if the government fails to respond to their calls.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF to help 'taishang' solve business difficulties

TEXT.P: The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will help Taiwanese business people operating in China, known locally as "taishang, " to solve problems that arise in the course of business operations, SEF Chairman Hong Chi- chang said Thursday.
Hong made the remarks at a seminar held in Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung, which was attended by 230 Taiwanese business persons operating in China.

Hong said taishang previously sought investment opportunities in China owing to its low labor costs, lax regulations on labor affairs and environmental protection, and easy acquisition of land to set up manufacturing plants.

However, he said that the situation is changing, and that now the situation is characterized by insufficient labor and higher wage demands in southern and eastern areas of China. Taiwanese business people in China have thus come to a fork in the road and have to decide whether to move their businesses to China's mid-west, to Vietnam, which is further south than China, or return to Taiwan, Hong said.

Noting that taishang are Taiwan's invisible assets as they represent an extension of the economic influence of domestic business and national power of Taiwan to China, Hong said the SEF has made efforts to integrate domestic resources and provide useful information and assistance to help them deal with business difficulties.
The government will also make greater efforts to improve Taiwan' sinvestment environment in order to ensure Taiwan's economic prosperity, Hong went on.

Chairman of the Cabinet's Mainland Affairs Council Chen Ming-tong, also, said at the seminar that Taiwan's trade and economic policies aim to strike a balance between cross-Taiwan Strait business development and global market expansion. He added that the government is working on industrial upgrades and transformation to seek a better future for the nation.
Chen encouraged Taiwanese business people in China to return to home and invest here after making a profit in China.

SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General You Ying-lung said the SEF has positioned itself as a well-intentioned, humanistic, attentive organization, keen to provide aid to Taiwanese business people operating in China as difficulties in cross-Taiwan Strait interactions remain.

DOC.HEADLINE: Little to worry about in Taiwan's economy: AIT Taipei Office head

TEXT.P: Taiwanese have little to worry about their national economy and Taiwan-U.S. bilateral trade is on track for another record year, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office Director Stephen Young said Thursday.

Young took note of the food safety issue, and encouraged Taiwan to "review accepted international standards and adopt a science-based approach that ensures consumer safety while avoiding unnecessary trade disruptions, " in his remarks at a Leader Forum organized by the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI).

Young's elaboration on the issue came on the heels of the Department of Health's (DOH's) announcement Tuesday that it would relax a ban on ractopamine in livestock to permit low residue levels of the veterinary drug in pigs and cattle. The issue has received much public attention since the DOH rejected last month two shipments of U.S.-exported pork which were found to contain ractopamine residue.

In the first half of the year, a 19 percent increase in U.S. exports to Taiwan outpaced overall bilateral trade growth at 7 percent, Young said, noting that the U.S.-Taiwan economic relationship has never been stronger.

"Many of my Taiwanese friends seem preoccupied by doubts over Taiwan's economic competitiveness and future. Given your many strengths, I think you have little reason for worry, " he told CNFI members.
The AIT also noted that economic issues were emerging as a major topic of the coming presidential election and welcomed that debate, he said.

Young said that the U.S.-Taiwan Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) is the primary vehicle for deepening bilateral trade relationship and the process has seen renewed vigor, most recently with July's successful round of talks in Washington.
The top U.S. representative in Taiwan also once again urged Taiwan to expand economic ties across the Taiwan Strait to enhance its global competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deputy speaker to be Control Yuan deputy chief

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker Chung Jung-chi, a member of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , is likely to be named as the new vice president of the Control Yuan, a legislative source said Thursday.
The high-level source, who preferred anonymity, further said the PFP could recommend three candidates for the Control Yuan seats in proportion to the number of its seats in the legislature.
According to the source, the PFP previously recommended two of its incumbent legislators for Control Yuan seats -- Feng Ting-kuo and Liu Wen-hsiung.

The source said he had passed on to PFP Chairman James Soong a message about President Chen Shui-bian's plan to refer a new list of Control Yuan nominations to the legislature for approval. Soong clearly told the source that the PFP, which controls 21 seats in the legislature, will absolutely not send any recommendation list to the president with regard to the Control Yuan nomination.

PFP Legislator Feng Ting-kuo said he is not aware of any information about the Control Yuan nomination, stressing that he is busy with his bid for re-election in the Taichung County's third constituency in central Taiwan.

Anonymous PFP sources said as Hakka people command a strong influence in the PFP, the PFP could face strong pressure if it chooses to boycott President Chen's new nomination list and Chung, a Hakka bigwig, is indeed nominated to be the next Control Yuan vice president.

A Presidential Office spokesman said earlier in the day that if the opposition- controlled legislature is willing to deal with the Control Yuan nomination issue during its new session, scheduled to open next month, President Chen will refer a new list for lawmakers to screen.

The country's supreme watchdog body has remain moribund since the tenure of the previous Control Yuan members expired Jan. 31, 2005 due to a boycott by the PFP and its "pan-blue" ally -- the main opposition Kuomintang. The "pan-blues" declined to review the president-proposed nomination list because they felt some of the nominees failed to live up to public expectations.
The issue was again spotlighted after the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) ruled Wednesday that the legislature's refusal to review the list is unconstitutional.

In response to a request by lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for an interpretation of the constitutionality of the opposition-controlled legislative Procedure Committee to persistently refuse to place the Control Yuan nomination list on the legislative agenda, the CGJ said such a move violates the spirit and provisions of the Constitution.

Noting that the Control Yuan is one of the nation's most significant government body, the CGJ ruling said the Legislative Yuan is obligated to screen the Control Yuan nomination list proposed by the president in line with the constitutional provisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public functionaries disciplinary chief said to head Judicial Yuan

TEXT.P: The head of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries (CDSF) has been tapped to be the new Judicial Yuan chief, a senior legislative source said Thursday.

According to the source, President Chen Shui-bian is set to nominate CDSF Chief Commissioner Yang Jen-shou to replace Weng Yueh-sheng as new Judicial Yuan president. Weng's tenure will expire in September.
The source, who preferred anonymity, further said Chen will name an incumbent grand justice to serve as Judicial Yuan vice president.

As to the Control Yuan lineup, the source said, Chen will nominate an independent acceptable to the opposition "pan-blue" alliance to serve as the new Control Yuan president. The source further said incumbent Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker Chung Jung-chi, amember of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , will be named as the new Control Yuan deputy chief.

The country's supreme watchdog body has remain moribund since the tenure of the previous Control Yuan members expired Jan. 31, 2005 due to a boycott by the PFP and its "pan-blue" ally -- the main opposition Kuomintang.
The "pan-blues" declined to review the president-proposed nomination list because they felt some of the nominees failed to live up to public expectations.
The issue was again spotlighted after the Council of Grand Justices ruled Wednesday that the legislature's refusal to review the list is unconstitutional.

According to the Legislative Yuan source, the KMT and the PFP are not likely to recommend lists of Control Yuan candidates as requested by the president. Nevertheless, the source said, President Chen will respect opposition opinions in drawing up a new list. For instance, those on an unpublicized KMT-drafted recommendation list, such as Wang Hsin-ching, better known by his pen name Nan Fang-shou, will be high on the Chen-proposed list.
The president will also refer to the leslature soon a list of nominations for Judicial Yuan president and vice president as well as eight seats on the Council of Grand Justices for approval.

Among the 15 seats on the Council of Grand Justices for which President Chen nominated candidates in 2003, eight of them, including the post of president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, are for four-year terms, while the remainder are for eight-year terms. However, as former Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo resigned and Yang Jen-shou left to serve as the head of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries, there are currently only 13 grand justices.

Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, who concurrently serves as a grand justice, as well as five other grand justices, namely Lin Yung-mo, Wang He- hsiung, Yu Hsueh-ming, Tseng You-tien and Liao Yi-nan, will see their terms expire this September.
This is why the president has to put forward a list of eight grand justice nominees to fill the vacancies.
Other incumbent grand justices, including Lai, Hsu Pi-hu, Peng Feng-chih, Lin Tze-yi, Hsu Tsung-li, Hsieh Tsai-chuan and Hsu Yu-hsiu, will see their terms expire in September 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB issues land warning for Typhoon Sepat

TEXT.P: Typhoon Sepat drew closer to waters off Taiwan's southeastern coast late Thursday, with the northeastern county of Yilan falling into the land warning areas, meteorologists with the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.
After releasing a sea warning earlier in the day, the bureau issued a land warning at 8: 30 p.m. Thursday for Sepat, the eighth tropic storm reported in the West Pacific area this year.

The land warning areas cover the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung, Yilan in northeastern Taiwan as well as Green Island, Orchid Island and the Hengchun Peninsula on the southernmost tip of Taiwan.
If Sepat, which means freshwater fish in Malay, maintains its current course, CWB forecasters said all areas of Taiwan must be on guard against the storm.
The typhoon was centered 580 km southeast of Taitung in eastern Taiwan at 11: 30 p.m. It was moving northwesterly toward Taiwan at 20 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of 191 kph.
Weathermen said Sepat poses a threat in waters southeast and northeast of Taiwan and the Bashih Channel, and urged ships operating in these areas to take additional precautions.
With the potentially destructive storm approaching, Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. announced Thursday evening that Maokong Gondola will suspend operations Friday.

Some airlines have announced cancellation of certain domestic and international flights or decided to advance departure times for some flights. Passengers are advised to contact air companies for further information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 17, or the fifth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: The English defeat the Scots and the French at the Battle of Verneuil during the Hundred Years' War.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a U.S. representative from Tennessee who joined with Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico. He died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West, American comedy actress and international sex symbol known for her sultry stage persona during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage productions and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold field at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England, by a car traveling at just 6.4 kilometers per hour.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon premiers in Paris.
1943: U.S. forces under Gen. George S. Patton liberate Messina, Italy, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After the end of Japanese occupation, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist Yenan General Headquarters issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch a full- scale war against the Nationalists.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator is formally inaugurated in Geneva, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan, following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the United States and mainland China. The ministry also asks the United States to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the previous 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when his camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, faster than the previous record by one hour and 20 minutes.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy for the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing his KMT membership, which he has held for 42 years.
2000: Chen Yi-song, leader of the Agriculture Technical Mission to the Republic of the Gambia, says that ROC agriculture technologists have transformed the Gambia River basin, which used to yield nothing but peanuts, into the "rice bowl of West Africa" over a period of five years.
2001: Taiwan's two major paper makers -- Yuen Foong Yu Paper and Chung Hwa Pulp -- sign a merger agreement and promise that there will be no layoffs in the new company.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learning a thing, you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan braces for Typhoon Sepat

TEXT.P: Taiwan is bracing for the largest storm to hit so far this year, as Typhoon Sepat, for which the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning at 8: 30 p.m. Thursday, continues to approach Taiwan Friday.

CWB meteorologists forecast that Sepat will begin to pound Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rain from Friday afternoon and that its onslaught is expected to cover the entire island with a radius of 250 km.
The typhoon was centered 390 km southeast of Taitung in eastern Taiwan as of 9 a.m., moving northwesterly at 18-21 kph toward the island and packing maximum sustained winds of 184 kph.

CWB chief meteorologist Lu Kuo-chen said strong winds and heavy rains are expected to begin to hit Taiwan later Friday, with the typhoon's influence on the island expected to peak between Friday night and Saturday morning.

Flash floods are expected to pound eastern and southern Taiwan again throughout Saturday and Sunday in the wake of two tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- which swept across Taiwan last week and caused landslides and flash floods in those areas, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President set to refer Judicial Yuan nomination list to legislature

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is set to refer a list of nominations for the Judicial Yuan presidency and vice presidency as well as eight seats on the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) to the Legislative Yuan Friday for approval, according to Presidential Office sources.

Besides nominating Yang Jen-shou, chief commissioner of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries (CDSF) as the new Judicial Yuan president, Chen has nominated Hsieh Tsai-chuan, a senior grand justice, as Yang's deputy, the sources said.

Yang will replace Weng Yueh-sheng, whose tenure is set to expire at the end of September, while Hsieh will fill the post left vacant by Cheng Chung-mo, who resigned in April 2006 amid allegations that he had lodged in a motel with a young woman.

Yang, 65, graduated from the Department of Law of National Taiwan University (NTU) . He has a master's degree from Chinese Culture University on Yangmingshan. Yang has worked his way up the judicial ladder. He has been the Kaohsiung and Taipei district court president and the Taiwan High Court president as well as Judicial Yuan secretary-general.

He served as a grand justice between 2003 and 2006 and was then transferred to his current post as the chief commissioner of the body responsible for handing down disciplinary measures for public functionaries found to be derelict in their duty.

Hsieh, 63, is also a graduate of the NTU's Department of Law and has a master's degree in law from Southern Methodist University in Dallas, Texas. He has served in the past as the Taichung District Court president, director of the civil affairs department of the Judicial Yuan, and director of the Training Institute for Judges and Prosecutors. He has been a grand justice since 2003.

Among the 15 seats on the Council of Grand Justices for which President Chen nominated candidates in 2003, eight of them, including the post of president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, are for four-year terms, while the remainder are for eight-year terms. However, as former Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo resigned and Yang Jen-shou left to serve as the head of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries, there are currently only 13 grand justices.

Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, who concurrently serves as a grand justice, as well as five other grand justices, namely Lin Yung-mo, Wang He- hsiung, Yu Hsueh-ming, Tseng You-tien and Liao Yi-nan, will see their terms expire this September.
This is why the president has to put forward a list of eight grand justice nominees to fill the vacancies.
Other incumbent grand justices, including Lai, Hsu Pi-hu, Peng Feng-chih, Lin Tze-yi, Hsu Tsung-li, Hsieh Tsai-chuan and Hsu Yu-hsiu, will see their terms expire in September 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: 742 areas at risk of mudslides marked to warn public

TEXT.P: Hundreds of locations at risk of mudslides have been marked around the country in preparation for Typhoon Sepat, which is beginning to sweep across Taiwan, officials from the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau under the Council of Agriculture announced Friday.
The bureau issued "yellow alert" Friday against potential rock and mudslides in 742 areas demarcated in 67 rural townships and 302 villages and boroughs in eight counties around the island.

Bureau officials urged the public to be on high alert against the possibility of rock and mudslides, and to prepare for evacuation as Typhoon Sepat is expected to bring torrential rains to the entire island, particularly eastern and southern Taiwan.
The 742 potentially risky areas are scattered throughout the eastern counties of Yilan, Hualien and Taitung, the central Nantou County and the southern counties of Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung.

Officials warned that mountainous areas are now extremely vulnerable to landslides because the soil in these areas is water saturated in the wake of the two tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- which swept across southern Taiwan last week.

They said that a "red alert" will be issued in these areas if landslides or mudslides indeed occur. Evacuation procedures will be implemented immediately upon the issuance of a "red alert, " they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP vice presidential candidate departs U.S. for home
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/17/07 14:18:03 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) vice presidential candidate, Su Tseng-chang, departed New York for home late Thursday.

Su, who stepped down from the premiership shortly after losing the DPP presidential primary to Frank Hsieh in May, agreed to serve as Hsieh's running mate just a day before the Aug. 15 deadline set by Hsieh for announcing his running mate.

Su kept a low profile since arriving in the United States in late July for a private visit in the company of his wife and two daughters. He first visited Los Angeles and later traveled to Philadelphia and other cities on the U.S East Coast.

The DPP chapter on the U.S. East Coast and major Taiwanese expatriate associations in the greater New York area organized groups to see Su and his wife off, the sources said, adding that the couple are scheduled to arrive at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Saturday morning.

Despite differences in their personal styles, Hsieh and Su have many things in common. Both have served as lawyers, lawmakers and DPP chairmen. Both worked as defense lawyers in court cases concerning the Kaohsiung Incident, also known as the Formosa Incident, which is recognized as a watershed event in Taiwan's recent transition to democracy.

Hsieh had been mayor of Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second largest city, before serving as premier between 2005 and early 2006. Su had been magistrate of the southernmost county of Pingtung and the country's most populous county of Taipei before succeeding Hsieh as premier on Jan. 25, 2006. He served as premier until May of this year.
Hsieh and Su used to belong to the now defunct Welfare State faction within the DPP, but their relationship underwent a severe test during the bitterly contested DPP presidential primary.

While announcing Su's assent to his invitation to team up for the 2008 election, Hsieh said that although there had been conflict within the DPP during the presidential primary, the party is now cooperating smoothly.
Noting that he advocates reform as well as reconciliation and co-existence, Hsieh said the promotion of co-existence should start within the DPP ranks.

"After I win the presidential election, I will also cooperate with main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou to safeguard Taiwan, " Hsieh said, adding that he is convinced that it is impossible for Taiwan to make breakthroughs in the international arena without solidarity at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reportedly set to name former vice premier as chief of staff

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is set to name former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan as his chief of staff, Presidential Office sources said Friday.
If the president does name Yeh to the post, she will become the first woman ever to serve as Presidential Office secretary-general.

The post has been left vacant for nearly three months since Tan Sun Chen was transferred from the position to serve as secretary-general of the National Security Council in an administration reshuffle that followed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) May 6 presidential primary.

Yeh, a Hakka politician who was previously reported as being favored by the DPP's presidential candidate, Frank Hsieh, to serve as his running mate for the 2008 election, just confirmed Thursday that she has accepted Hsieh's invitation to be his top campaign manager.
It remains unclear whether Yeh will continue her leading role in the Hsieh campaign after taking up the Presidential Office post.

While announcing his decision earlier this week to team up with former Premier Su Tseng-chang, Hsieh also expressed his gratitude for Yeh, praising her selflessness and loyalty to the DPP during his search for a running mate.

Hsieh further said he will entrust her with an important position so as to live up to the expectations of the Hakka supporters. Hakkas form the second largest ethnic group in Taiwan, after Holo Taiwanese.

During a campaign trip to the northern county of Taoyuan Thursday, Hsieh said Yeh will help him and his running mate Su draw up their campaign platform and spearhead efforts to woo votes from women and Hakka people.
"Yeh has promised not to be absent from the election, " Hsieh said, adding that the formation of the Hsieh-Su-Yeh golden triangle will unite to fight for final victory in the 2008 election.

For her part, Yeh said she will pull out all the stops to stump for the Hsieh-Su ticket. "The DPP must win for the sake of Taiwan, and I believe that the Hakka people will stand by my side, " she added.
Even though some Hakka groups have expressed disappointment at her failure to make it onto the DPP presidential ticket, Yeh said her support for Hsieh will not waiver.

Yeh, who entered politics after her husband, a dissident during Taiwan's infamous martial law era, chose to commit suicide rather than be arrested in 1989 over freedom of press issues, has held many important posts, including minister of transportation and communications and head of the Council for Hakka Affairs. She also once served as lawmaker and acting mayor of Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second largest city.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sustains no U.S. pressure over ractopamine ban lifting: MOFA

TEXT.P: The government did not receive any pressure from the United States to lift its ban on the veterinary drug ractopamine ahead of its decision to relax the ban, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.

MOFA deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei-pi said that the government decided to relax the ban to permit low levels of ractopamine residue in pigs and cattle after conducting a thorough assessment of the impact of the drug on public health and food safety.
Yeh denied allegations that the Department of Health (DOH) made the decision, which was announced Aug. 14, due to pressure from the United States.
The relaxing of the ban also has nothing to do with President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming transit stop on U.S. soil as alleged by some media outlets, Yeh reiterated.

According to a proposed revision to the DOH's standards for veterinary drug residues, the maximum allowable level of ractopamine residue in pigs and cattle would be 10 ppb in muscle and fat tissue, 40 ppb in the liver, and 90 ppb in the kidneys.
If the proposal meets no objection by Aug. 21, the new standards can be implemented at the end of the month at the earliest, DOH officials said.

Ractopamine, marketed under the brand name Paylean, is a phenolethanolamine s-adrenoceptor agonist that is used for the improvement of weight gain, carcass leanness and feed efficiency in animals, DOH officials noted.

Studies have shown that the drug can be processed rapidly by animals and humans and that the chances of long-term consumption of residue of the drug in meat having toxicological effects are extremely slim, they said.

The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture decided last October to ban all drugs used by farmers as food additives to boost the growth of lean meat in pigs, including ractopamine, after cases were reported abroad concerning the effect of such drugs on consumers' cardiac and neural systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to put forth 'green' proposal at APEC meeting
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/07 16:32:01 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will put forth a proposal during the upcoming Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting to make known the country's efforts to tackle global warming and climate change issues, the head of Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Thursday.

EPA Minister Chen Chung-hsin said that under the proposal, Taiwan will make efforts to address global warming and climate change issues in five areas, namely environmental protection in industry; consumption patterns; clean production; pollution control; and greenhouse gas reduction.

During the next APEC meeting, slated for Sept. 8-9 in Sydney, Australia, Taiwan delegates will inform the APEC member countries that Taiwan is able to make a solid contribution to efforts to control greenhouse gas emissions, Chen said.

Chen, who had recently attended an international meeting on environmental protection in Hawaii, arrived in Washington, D.C. earlier this week for a short visit. He met with several officials in charge of environmental protection affairs from the Bush administration Thursday morning for talks on Taiwan's environmental protection policy and current situation.

The EPA head then delivered a speech at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars think tank in the afternoon. He briefed his audience on Taiwan's efforts in pushing for legislation of a greenhouse gas reduction act and recapped the EPA's efforts to protect water resources, promote garbage separation and push for waste recycling.
He said that in the face of global warming and climate change, Taiwan proposes that a World Environment Organization be formed.
He condemned China for its senseless obstruction of Taiwan's participation in global environmental protection meetings and activities.
The EPA head also said that excessive mercury pollution created by Chinese industries has already affected the quality of air and the environment in East Asia.

In response to a question on whether Taiwan will build new nuclear power plants in an effort to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions, Chen said that the government is determined to provide the Taiwan people with a "nuclear-free" environment.

He further said that the government should restrict the operations of thermal power plants, which use coal as fuel, and invest more in developing environmentally-friendly hydraulic and wind power plants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September dropped 269 points to close at 7,885, with 79,117 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved down 308 points to finish at 7,850, with 386 contracts traded, while December futures lost 224 points to close at 7,932, with 130 contract transactions. March futures dropped 224 points to close at 7,951, with eight contracts traded, while June futures decreased 270 points to finish at 7,911, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,154 for August, 8,158 for October, 8,156 for December, 8,175 for March and 8,181 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

September TE futures moved down 11.35 points to close at 330.05, with 5,014 contracts traded, while October TE futures dropped 2.65 points to finish at 336.45, with 54 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 8.2 points to close at 331.2, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures dropped 33.4 points to close at 897.2, with 4,137 contracts traded, while October TF futures moved down 26.6 points to finish at 899.6, with 20 contract transactions. December TF futures fell 18.6 points to close at 920.8, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Small groups now a large threat in U.S.
After more than a decade of warning that the greatest threat of homegrown terrorism for the United States came from individual lone-wolf radicals, the FBI and other law enforcement agencies have begun focusing on what they say is a greater threat--small, anonymous groups of disaffected men who radicalize one another and turn to violence. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from torrential rains exceeds NT$420 million

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses due to torrential rains caused by Tropical Storms Pabuk and Wutip have exceeded NT$420.69 million (US$12.75 million) as of Thursday, with damaged assets increasing by NT$100 million per day, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Friday.

Among those losses, farm land produce had seen losses of NT$279.53 million, with 20 percent of 6,971 hectares of farm land damaged, and watermelons, melons, loofahs, and leafy vegetable crops sustaining the greatest damage, the official said.

According to the official, markets and farmer associations' large-scale freezers around Taiwan have a total of 4,586 tonnes of vegetables in storage, including 2,693 tonnes of rootstock and 1,518 tonnes of leafy vegetables.
The COA has requested that owners of these freezers make available a total of 200-250 tonnes of vegetables per day through a variety of market channels to cover consumers' needs.

Meanwhile, data of the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co. shows that supplies of fruits and vegetables increased from Wednesday's 1,065 tonnes to 1,114 tonnes, and despite the poor quality of produce, wholesale prices still surged to NT$28.11 per kg.
Leafy vegetables showed the most obvious price surge, while prices of rootstock vegetables remained roughly stable, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Black day, stock markets on brink of collapse.
From Asia to America, there was a panic in stock markets around the world which were at the brink of collapse Thursday. In Europe, the losses amounted to 304 billion euros.
