DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Stock market rout as blue chips lose G60bn
Nearly G60 billion was wiped off the value of Britains bluechip companies yesterday after mounting fears of a global credit crunch sent shares plunging as world stock markets endured a deepening rout.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.197 to close at NT$32.931.
A total of US$1.05 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.095 and fluctuated between NT$32.931 and NT$33.121.

DOC.HEADLINE: Australian envoy delivers APEC invitation to president

TEXT.P: An Australian envoy visited President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office Friday to deliver an invitation for Taiwan to participate in the informal summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Sydney Sept. 8-9.
During the visit, President Chen told David Spencer, Australia's Ambassador to APEC, that he has appointed Stan Shih, a prominent entrepreneur, to attend the summit on his behalf.

Chen told Spencer that Shih is a Taiwan-educated business tycoon who founded the Acer group, which has not only sold computer products around the world but has also boosted Taiwan's image in the international arena.

According to one of Chen's aides, Shih was named by Time magazine last year in its list of "60 Years of Asian Heroes, " as the influential magazine paid tribute to the remarkable men and women who have shaped the times over the last six decades in Asia.
Shih was also given the title of "Star of Asia" in 2004 by Business Week, a U.S.-based commercial weekly journal, after he was praised by CNN as an entrepreneur with vision.
Shih is the best spokesman for Taiwan in the international community due to his contribution in putting Taiwan on the world's high-tech map, according to the aid.

DOC.TEXT:

Moscow Region -- The MAKS air show kicks off next week and, beyond the daily displays of aerial acrobatics and military hardware, all aerospace industry eyes will be on the performance of Russian producers. [by Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
FTC activates disaster response mechanism to prevent profiteering

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission (FTC) has activated a natural disaster response mechanism in a drive to prevent possible profiteering in countrywide vegetable and fruit markets amid the approach of Typhoon Sepat -- the largest storm to hit so far this year, a spokesman for the FTC said Friday.

Under the emergency response mechanism, price fluctuations in terms of agricultural products will be closely monitored, the spokesman said, reiterating that violators against the Fair Trade Law will face severe punishment.

According to the FTC, data released by agricultural product trading centers around the country showed that the average wholesale price of vegetables was NT$25.5 per kg Friday, while that of fruits was NT$21.9 per kg.

To prevent vegetable price hikes as a result of anticipated losses, the FTC has asked for the cooperation of the Council of Agriculture in asking farmers' groups to boost supplies to major wholesale markets around the country, FTC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education ministry to improve school facility use

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will earmark approximately NT$700 million (US$21 million) over the next three years to promote a program aimed at helping 1,000 local schools make better use of their facilities, according to MOE Minister Tu Cheng-sheng.
Tu made the announcement Thursday at a national meeting with education bureau chiefs in the northeastern county of Yilan.
Under the program, the ministry will help schools establish community lifelong learning centers, improve the use of school facilities, and increase sports facilities, Tu said.
The ministry will also encourage sustainable energy use, develop the schools with distinctive features, and set up more digital opportunity centers in remote areas, among local schools, Tu went on.
The ministry will soon make public the details of the program and start accepting applications, Tu said, adding that the ministry will begin the program this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most rail, air transportation to be suspended as typhoon approaches

TEXT.P: Railway transportation service will be partially suspended beginning late Friday and all domestic flights will be grounded Saturday, given the approach of Typhoon Sepat -- the largest storm to hit Taiwan so far this year.

The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) announced earlier that on the Western Line, express trains from Pingtung in southern Taiwan to Sijhih of Taipei County in the north will all be suspended from 10:50 p.m., with those from Chidu in Keelung, northern Taiwan, to Pingtung to be suspended from 10:22 p.m.

On the Yilan and North Link Lines in the east, all trains setting off from Hualien toward Shulin in Taipei County will be suspended from 8:30 p.m, while those from Shulin to Hualien will stop operating at 7:48 p.m.
On the Hualien-Taitung Line, all trains running from Taitung to Hualien will be suspended from 7:30 p.m. while trains from Hualien to Kaohsiung are to be suspended at 7:11 p.m.
On the South Link Line, all trains from Taitung to Kaohsiung will be suspended from 7: 10 p.m. while those from Kaohsiung to Taitung to be suspended beginning at 6:50 p.m.
The TRA will make public Saturday's schedule at 9: 30 p.m., a spokesman for the administration.

Meanwhile, Saturday's domestic flights have all been canceled as the island on the alert for a potentially devastating typhoon, while several international flights taking off tomorrow for regional cities like Ho Chi Minh City and Macao have also been canceled.
Travelers are recommended to check their flight information before heading to the airport Saturday.

As to the Kinmen-Xiamen ferry line, Kinmen officials responsible for port affairs said the transportation link between Kinmen to Xiamen and Chuanchou in southeastern China has been closed since 1:30 p.m., and the closure will continue throughout Saturday.

Central Weather Bureau (CWB) meteorologists forecast that Sepat will begin to pound Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains Friday afternoon. The onslaught is expected to cover the entire island as the storm has a radius of 250 km.
As of 4: 00 p.m., the CWB reported that the typhoon was centered 270 km southeast of Taitung, moving northwesterly at 18-21 km/h toward the island and packing maximum sustained winds of 184 km/h.

CWB chief meteorologist Lu Kuo-chen said strong winds and heavy rains are expected to begin to hit Taiwan later Friday, and that the typhoon's influence on the island is expected to peak between Friday night and Saturday morning.

Flash floods are expected in eastern and southern Taiwan again throughout Saturday and Sunday given soil saturation in the wake of two tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- which swept across Taiwan last week causing landslides and flash floods in those same areas, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices slump on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slumped Friday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 111.08 points to close at 8,090.29.
The bourse opened at 8,209.91 and fluctuated between 8,307.37 and 7,987.61 during trading. A total of 5.98 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$178.43 billion (US$5.4 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 5.3 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 4.2 percent, construction issues at 3.5 percent, textile stocks at 3.4 percent, cement stocks at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both at 1.4 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 1 percent.
Losers numbered more than 1,000 against 450 losers and 169 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The Straits Times: China vows to get tough over unsafe products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Emergency center activated with the approach of Typhoon Sepat

TEXT.P: Representatives of 15 Cabinet-level agencies met Friday morning to discuss disaster prevention countermeasures with the approach of Typhoon Sepat.

Officials of the Central Emergency Operation Center organized by National Fire Agency said Typhoon Sepat, with its solid structure, is expected to bring strong winds and heavy rains, as well as cause mudslides and flooding.
The center has listed several places around the country as potentially dangerous areas due to the threats posed by the typhoon, including 292 rivers, 131 mountainous areas and 66 coastal areas.

Regarding mountain climbers, officers of National Police Agency (NPA) said there are not many climbers left on the mountains given that two other tropical storms -- Pabuk and Wutip -- passed over Taiwan during the last week.

According to NPA statistics, 426 mountain climbers from 86 groups have already left the mountains as of Friday noon, while eight climbers who were already on various mountains chose to cease their journey and seek shelter from the storm's winds.
As for the Chinese fishing boats that ran ashore Taiwan's coasts to avoid the strong winds, officials of Coast Guard Administration have arranged temporary accommodations for the fishermen.
Meanwhile, the only woman in the mountainous village of Haocha in Pingtung County to have refused evacuation to safer ground was forcibly airlifted off the mountain Friday morning by the military.
The village, which suffered floods and landslides in the last two tropical storms, has had all its lines of communication cut.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosa Plastic Group donates pneumococcus vaccines to government

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastic Group pledged Friday that it will donate 578,000 pneumococcus vaccines, worth NY$460 million (US$13.92 million), to the government over the next three years.

Susan Wang, deputy chief executive officer of Formosa Plastic and a daughter of group founder Wang Yung-ching, announced the gift to the government during a ceremony at the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH).

Accepting the gift on behalf of the government, DOH head Hou Sheng-mou thanked Formosa Plastics for its generous charity work. He said Formosa Plastic is the first enterprise in Taiwan to donate vaccines to help the needy and urged other businesses to follow its example.

DOH officials said that because the number of vaccines is limited, they will begin the free vaccination program this year with elderly people in the counties of Yunlin and Chiayi who are 75 years old or over.

Susan Wang said that her 90-year-old father had developed pneumonia after catching a cold several years ago, and that after he was cured, he accepted a doctor's suggestion that he take a pneumococcus vaccine, with very satisfactory results.

She added that her father felt that elderly people aged 75 or over should all be vaccinated against the pneumococcus bacteria, and that was why Formosa Plastics decided to donate the vaccines to the government.

Pneumococcus is a leading cause of pneumonia and other infections, including middle ear infection and meningitis. According to statistics compiled by the DOH, pneumonia ranks fifth among the 10 leading causes of death in Taiwan, with children aged 5 or under and people who are 65 or over being the high-risk groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former vice premier to become top presidential aide

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan has agreed to serve as President Chen Shui- bian's chief of staff and will assume the post Aug. 20, a Presidential Office official said Friday.
Yeh's decision came in the wake of President Chen's repeated invitations, said Chen Chi-mai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.
Yeh, a Hakka politician, is set to become the first female Presidential Office secretary-general, Chen Chi-mai noted.
Yeh was previously reported as a likely running mate of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate, Frank Hsieh, in the 2008 election.
Yeh confirmed a day earlier that she has accepted Hsieh's invitation to serve as his top campaign manager.
Yeh has held many important posts, including minister of transportation and communications and head of the Council for Hakka Affairs.
She also once served as a lawmaker and acting mayor of Kaohsiung, the second largest city in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free flu vaccines for primary school students to begin in October

TEXT.P: Free flu vaccines for local first-year and second-year primary school students will begin in October, an official of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced Friday.
Presently, the government offers free flu shots to those aged between six months and two years as well as persons over 65 years of age, CDC Deputy Director Chou Chih-hao said.
Studies show that first-year and second-year primary school students are also a high-risk group because they often bring flu home from schools and infect their families, Chou went on.

In addition, the CDC will replace the tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine with the tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis (Tdap) vaccine free-of-charge for local first graders from next September, Chou said.

Noting that the CDC must earmark an additional NT$40 million (US$1.2 million) too provide the free Tdap vaccines each year, Chou said that the new vaccine can greatly boost school children's immunity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait charter service in sight: MAC chief

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China have nearly wrapped up bilateral technical talks on setting up direct charter service and opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists, and will continue to engage on the remaining issues, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Friday.
Chen made the remarks while delivering a keynote speech at a seminar sponsored by the National Association of Industry and Commerce.

As most of the technical details regarding the two matters have been settled, the two sides are currently seeking breakthroughs in remaining unsolved issues so as to materialize cross-strait charter flights and allow the entry of Chinese tourists to Taiwan as soon as possible, Chen said.

Brushing aside allegations that the MAC has always stood in the way of cross- strait exchanges since the Democratic Progressive Party came to power in 2000, he said that over the past seven years the government has been consistent in its China policy, focusing on boosting two-way trade and economic activities amid increased regional integration and growing globalization.

Citing Chinese government statistics, Chen reported that as of the end of June, Taiwan's investment in China had snowballed to US$58.6 billion. Unofficial figures might amount to between US$100 billion and US$200 billion, he added.

But the MAC chief failed to unveil a timetable for charter flight services to kick start and the arrival of the first wave of regular Chinese tourists, and called on China to cast aside political concerns and step up the pace of negotiations in order to make a genuine breakthrough.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sends medical team to Peru

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Health Action

(Taiwan IHA) has decided to send a medical mission to Peru to help with post- disaster relief after the country was devastated by a magnitude-8 earthquake earlier this week, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said Friday.
The government also donated US$100,000 to the South American country, the official said, adding that the medical team is set to depart 10:50 p.m. Friday via a China Airlines flight.

The Taiwan IHA is an ad hoc inter-agency body established by the Executive Yuan's Department of Health and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to offer emergency or humanitarian medical aid to countries in need.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM visits emergency center amid the approach of Typhoon Sepat

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung instructed the various government agencies to adopt countermeasures against Typhoon Sepat Friday during an inspection tour of a national emergency and disaster response center.

With its solid structure, meteorologists have warned that Typhoon Sepat might bring strong winds and heavy rain, as well as cause mudslides and flooding. According to the Central Weather Bureau, Taiwan will receive the brunt of the onslaught from late Friday night to Saturday morning.

Chang reminded the government agencies to remember the damage caused by Typhoon Bilis that hit Taiwan in 2000, killing 11 people and causing tremendous economic losses, and he urged related agencies to beef up their preparedness.

Meanwhile, the premier told the Water Resources Agency to heed the water quality in reservoirs and reminded the public to stockpile water in advance in case of high turbidity of water in the reservoirs caused by mudslides.
The center has listed several places around the country as potentially danger areas due to the threat posed by the typhoon, including 292 rivers, 131 mountainous areas and 66 coastal areas.

The Taipei city government announced Friday evening all schools and government offices would be closed from Friday night till Saturday, while most of the counties and cities around Taiwan announced a day off for students and civil servants on Saturday.

Part of the island's rail systems and trips via the "mini three links" between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, and Xiamen and Fuzhou harbors in China's Fujian Province will also be canceled Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's national identity unstable: researcher

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national identity is in an unstable state, with differences existing between its two major groups of people -- mainlanders and native Taiwanese, an Academia Sinica researcher said Friday.

Wu Nai-teh of the Academia Sinica Institute of Sociology made the remarks in a report on Taiwanese people's national identity to a forum held by the preparatory office of the planned National Center for Research and Protection of Cultural Properties in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

In Taiwan, the term mainlanders refers to Chinese immigrants who arrived after 1949 with the relocation of the Republic of China government, and native Taiwanese is the term used for those who moved to Taiwan from China in the several hundered years prior to 1949.

Citing the results of a survey, Wu said 63 percent of the respondents would support Taiwan independence if there was no threat of war with China. Should China ever become democratic, nearly 50 percent of those polled said they would support the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The results show that Taiwan's national identity is unstable, Wu concluded, noting however that even with the different opinions, the two groups of Taiwanese people share a common consensus on Taiwan's future, which is that "only Taiwanese people have the right to decide Taiwan's future."

The trend among mainlanders, despite having what he described as "a strong complex about China, " is to accept the Taiwan independence movement even though they are still not willing to give up their wish for unification.

The "de-sinicization" movement -- a reference to the government's move over the past year to change state-run companies' designations that carry the word "China, " has harmed mainlanders' feelings, making them to feel they are not respected in the country, according to Wu.

At the same forum, Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said it is "not necessary for people sharing a common culture to form a single country, " referring to Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations despite the opposition of Beijing, which regards Taiwan as part of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Increasing defense budget shows Taiwan's self-defense resolve

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that Taiwan's 2008 defense budget will for the first time account for 3 percent of its GDP, reflecting the country's determination to maintain its self-defense capacity.
Chen made the remarks at the opening ceremony of the National Defense University (NDU) new campus in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

Due to Taiwan's geographic characteristics -- being small and surrounded by ocean waters -- Chen said Taiwan will have to be ready to face immediate threats from the enemy because it will have little warning ahead of an attack.

In addition, Taiwan will not have a single, well-defined front line to defend in case of wars, Chen added, urging the NDU, the cradle of the country's high- ranking military officers, to train the three branches of the nation's military forces for joint operations and thereby beef up Taiwan's combat capability.

With Taiwan's recent military reforms and its planned procurement of three big- ticket weaponry systems, Taiwan is determined to defend itself, safeguard peace across Taiwan Strait, and help assure regional safety and stability, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pig farmers sue officials over animal drug issue

TEXT.P: A group of pig farmers, led by a Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker, launched a lawsuit Friday against Department of Health (DOH) Minister Hou Sheng- mao and Bureau of Food Sanitation Director-General Cheng Hui-wen over the DOH's decision to allow the use of a previously banned animal drug.

TSU lawmaker Yin Ling-ying and hog raisers lodged the lawsuit against Hou and Cheng at the Taipei Prosecutors Office on charges of dereliction of duty after the DOH announced Tuesday that it has decided to relax the ban on ractopamine -- a veterinary drug which promotes lean meat in livestock -- by the end of this month.
Ractopamine is banned in Taiwan, but two shipments of imported U. S. pork were found last month to contain the illicit drug, stirring up food safety concerns among local consumers.

Executive Yuan Spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said a day earlier that the ban will be eased in late Aug. and U.S. imports containing minimum levels of ractopamine residue in different organs of pigs and cattle and their meat will be permitted, if no one voices opposition to the plan by Aug. 21.

In view of the government's softened stance on the banned drug, thousands of hog raisers from across the country are slated to demonstrate in front of the DOH Aug. 21 should it fail to repeal the decision.

Yin accused the DOH of failing to detect ractopamine-tainted pork imports and criticized its arbitrary decision to remove the ban as a way to allow questionable U.S. imports to enter Taiwan. Arguing that the DOH has to put the public health concern in the first place, she lashed out at Hou for "hoodwinking" the public by amending the regulations pertaining to animal drug residue to facilitate U. S. imports.
Yin threatened to take pig raisers to the streets Aug. 22 and fully boycott U.S. pork if the DOH ignores their demands.

According to Lee Chen-jung, chairman of the pig-raising association in Taipei County, the government's tailor-made opening to U.S. pork imports will have a profoundly negative impact on local husbandry, consumers, vendors and food processors.
The local industry is gravely concerned that the use of ractopamine will pose serious risks to the public's health, but the government remains obstinate on its decision to ease the ban, Lee said.
In the face of mounting social pressure, Cheng said that he feels at ease and justified in his decision, while Hou's aides said that the DOH chief remains calm and tranquil despite the lawsuit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Second-generation overseas Taiwanese get to know Taiwan

TEXT.P: Almost 300 second- or third-generation overseas Taiwanese concluded Friday an eight-week internship program aimed at helping them understand more about Taiwan.

The "Taiwan Tech Trek 2007, " an annual event entering its third year, was organized by the National Science Council (NSC) and received 271 overseas Taiwanese aged between 18 and 30 from 23 countries, offering them internships at government agencies, non-profit organizations, private companies and special group projects.
After a one-week group orientation during which the members visited several organizations in southern Taiwan, the members spread out to different parts of Taiwan for the internship program.
The summer program is part of the government's efforts to recruit new generations of overseas Taiwanese to raise Taiwan's competitiveness.

Compared to their elders, the younger generation possess better language abilities, professional expertise and international savvy that are advantageous to Taiwan, an NSC staff member said, adding that building a strategic liaison with this generation can attract long-term returnees for the future and ultimately increase international support for Taiwan.

The academic conference was categorized into five groups -- natural sciences, engineering, social sciences, life sciences and the humanities -- with topics such as Taiwan's environmental pollution, public diplomacy strategies and software management.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 female Vietnamese detainees escape from detention center

TEXT.P: Ten female Vietnamese detainees escaped early Friday from the No. 2 detention center run by the Immigration Agency in Yilan County, northeastern Taiwan, agency officials said later that day.
According to the officials, detention center workers found out about the breakout when they took the roll call.

After searching the center, personnel found the runaways had used an oxyacetylene torch to burn through the bars on a window in their second-floor dormitory, from where they jumped out and escaped from the center, which has no high walls or fences, at around 4 a.m.

The detention center authorities suspected that accomplices might have helped the women, who were to be repatriated, to escape. "This seems to have been a well-planned escape, " they said, adding that human trafficking rings might have been working behind the scenes to induce the women to escape.
As of 7 a.m., one of the women had been arrested by a police and Immigration Agency officers.
It was the second such case in Yilan County since the beginning of this month after five male Vietnamese laborers ran away from the county's No. 1 detention center Aug. 1.

The Immigration Agency said in a statement issued later in the day that it will punish negligent officials and immediately further step up security measures and inspections at its detention centers across the country to prevent further breakouts.
The agency admitted that poor equipment and lack of deterrent facilities were the main reasons for the success of the breakout.
As the agency's detention centers are designed to house illegal immigrants temporarily prior to repatriation, they are not walled or enclosed by wire out of humanitarian considerations.

Lawmaker Chen Chin-de of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party suggested that the central government increase budgets to better manage and upgrade facilities at detention centers for illegal immigrants.
In addition, he went on, the government also should step up its pace of repatriation of illegals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seven business groups vow to cut energy consumption

TEXT.P: Seven business groups representing various industries have promised to reduce energy consumption as part of a national effort to improve energy conservation and energy efficiency, a top energy official said Friday.

The seven groups made the pledge Thursday during a symbolic flag presentation ceremony marking the establishment of energy service teams among their organizations to promote energy conservation, according to Bureau of Energy Director-General Yeh Huey-ching.

Yeh said the goal of the campaign is to cut power consumption by 2-3 percent, which would result in savings of the equivalent of approximately 170,000 tons of oil, and thereby prevent the release of 460,000 tons of carbon dioxide emissions.

The effect of the reduction in emissions would be equivalent to planting enough trees to fill 1,200 parks the size of Taipei's Daan Forest Park, Yeh said, adding that if the target is reached, it is expected to save NT$2.1 billion in expenditures.

Yeh said the government has developed various energy conservation promotion projects over the past few years, and this year it has invited many private enterprises to join in its conservation drives in the hope of encouraging them to take the lead in voluntary energy conservation among business organizations.
Under the project, the government will help those business groups train energy conservation experts and set up energy management systems, Yeh added.

The seven groups taking part in the energy conservation drive are TFT-LCD manufacturer Au Optronics. Corp., China Steel Corp., paper and tissue maker Cheng Loong Group., Chang Chun Chemical, food and drink producer Weichun Co., Shinkong Synthetic Fibers Corp. and contract chip maker United Microelectronics Corp., Yeh said.
Most of thouse groups have been winners of various energy conservation competitions launched by the Bureau of Energy since 1988, Yeh noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority supports Taiwan's U.N. bid: survey

TEXT.P: More than 70 percent of respondents to a recent survey have thrown their support behind the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

The survey was conducted by National Chengchi University's Election Study Center under the commission of the MAC. Questionnaires were administered via telephone to randomly chosen adults from Aug. 10-12 and 1,095 valid samples were collected.

Quoting the survey results, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun said 67 percent of the public ascribe Taiwan's difficulties in participating in international organizations and developing diplomacy to oppression by China.

Moreover, 81.5 percent of the respondents said they favor maintaining the status quo in a broader sense, and 67.8 percent said they do not agree with the "one country, two systems" model by which China wants to rule Taiwan.
The survey also shows that 78 percent of those polled do not accept China's claim that Taiwan is part of China and "not qualified to apply for membership of the United Nations."

Liu said Taiwan is an independent sovereignty and that the government is promoting the bid to participate in the international body under the name of Taiwan based on the people's will. He called on the international community to support Taiwan's U.N. bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors to appeal ex-mayor's embezzlement case

TEXT.P: Prosecutors said Friday they will appeal the Taipei District Court's not guilty ruling on a "special allowance fund" embezzlement case involving former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
One of the major reasons cited by prosecutors to back their decision to appeal the case was what they said the judges' criticism of prosecution's investigation into Ma's personal bank accounts.

Noting that judges' should follow the criminal procedural law in handling any judicial case, a spokesman fo the Taipei Prosecutors Office said the judges had offended the division of powers principle enshrined in the procedural law that bans prosecution and judges from infringing upon each other's powers and duties.

"Judges are not in a position to question how prosecutors will exercise their investigation powers," the spokesman said, adding that scrutinizing Ma's personal accounts is necessary in checking the flow of the mayoral allowance funds that were deposited into his account.

Ma, who is now the main opposition Kuomintang's candidate for the 2008 presidential election, was indicted Feb. 13 on suspicion of diverting NT$11.17 million in government funds into his personal account during his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006. The "not guilty" verdict is believed to have removed a dark shadow over Ma's presidential bid.

Another reason cited by prosecutors to justify their appeal was disputes over the truthfulness and validity of the deposition of a key witness in the case -- Wu Li-ju, a Taipei city government cashier.
Claiming that the judges' denial of the validity of Wu's testimony was arbitrary and biased, prosecutors said the verdict was statement taken out of context.

Prosecutors also said the description about the mayoral special allowance fund's nature, function and implication given in the verdict was incoherent, contradictory and incongruant with theoretical and empirical principles.
Prosecutors must formal file their appeal with the Taiwan High Court within 10 days after receiving the verdict.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to set off on Central America diplomatic tour Aug. 21

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will set off on a Central America diplomatic tour Aug. 21 aimed at cementing relations with the Republic of China's allies in the region and the Caribbean, a senior Presidential Office official said Friday.

President Chen will first visit Honduras where he will meet with his counterparts from the country's Central American allies and the Dominican Republic in the Caribbean, said Chen Chi-mai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.
In addition to attending the leadership summit, President Chen will also hold bilateral talks with Honduran President Manuel Zelaya Rosales and top leaders of other participating countries.
Following the leadership summit, President Chen will make state visits to El Salvador and Nicaragua, Chen Chi-mai said.
President Chen will travel via Alaska on his way to Central America and again on his way home later this month. He is scheduled to conclude his tour and return to Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 18, or the sixth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, who through conquest created a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Adm. Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, located in present-day Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War 1, is born.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland, to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration of the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong.
1974: Taiwan baseball teams for the first time win the Little League, Senior League and Big League world titles in the same year.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its policy of apartheid.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action by launching a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the Republic of China leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy in San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: An earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
2000: The Paraguayan embassy in Taipei requests that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs lift an import ban on beef from Paraguay, saying that there have been no cases of foot-and-mouth disease reported among the country's livestock.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing, you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Typhoon Sepat abating, rain continues

TEXT.P: Typhoon Sepat was decreasing in intensity after making landfall in Taiwan Saturday, but heavy rain and strong wind brought about by the typhoon were expected to continue throughout the day, according to forecasters at the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
At 10 a.m., Sepat was centered 40 km south of Taichung, moving northwest at 20-14 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of 155 kph, the forecasters said.

They said the structure of Sepat had been damaged after the eye of the typhoon made landfall over the estuary of the Hsiukuluan river in eastern Hualien County at 5:40 a.m., causing Sepat to decrease in intensity.
However, with the typhoon covering the entire island as of Saturday morning, the rain and wind were expected to continue islandwide, they said.

From midnight until 8 a.m. Saturday, accumulated rainfall had registered 534 mm in Hualien County's Lungchien, 438 mm in Yilan County's Kulu, 305 mm in Taoyuan County's Paling, 288 mm in Taipei County's Fushan, 231 mm in Taitung County's Hsiangyang, 215 mm on Jade Mountain, 213 mm in Nantou County's Tungpu and 208 mm on Orchid Island, according to CWB data.

DOC.TEXT:

The death toll in a massive earthquake that battered Peru's Pacific coast soared toward 500 on Thursday as rescue workers struggled to reach scenes of devastation and stunned victims appealed for medical aid, water and coffins. ]By lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Time to search for 4th generation of S'pore leaders: MM.
It is time to headhunt Singapore's fourth- generation leaders, said Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew on Friday night.
He believes the Prime Minister and his team must talent-spot candidates in their 30s and early 40s before the next general election, which must be called by 2011.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The stock markets' tumble is temporary and will be rebound.
Singapore's Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew is confident that the present nervousness in the stock markets will not derail the long-term growth potential of China, India and the rest of East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Stocks plunge 5% as yen goes through roof
Japanese stocks fell more than 5 percent Friday to a one-year low as the dollar's sharp drop against the yen fueled concerns about earnings outlooks in a market already reeling from the U.S. housing-loan crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan cyclists to join 2007 Paris-Brest-Paris Randonneur
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/18/07 13:15:19 (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan cyclists will take part for the first time in the four-yearly Paris- Brest-Paris Randonneur slated for next week in France, officials of Taiwan's representative office in France said Friday.
The 1200 km-long bicycle tour from Paris to Brest and back is the oldest and most famous cycle rally for amateurs. Participants are required to complete the ride in 90 hours.
This year's event is scheduled to start at 9: 30 p.m. Aug. 20 at Saint-Quentin- en-Yvlines in suburban Paris and end at 5 p.m. Aug. 24 at the same place.

In addition to 2,300 French cyclists, 3,000 foreign cyclists are expected to take part in the randonneur, including three from Taiwan -- Cheng Wen-chang and Juan Yao-chang representing the Taiwan Super Triathlon Association, and independent participant Cho Lo-chun, the officials said.
Taiwan's representative to France Michel Lu will take part in the starting ceremony to boost the morale of the Taiwan participants, they added.

Held for the first time in 1891, the randonneur has since 1931 been organized by Audax Club Parisien, comprising members from 35 countries. Besides those from Taiwan, this year's event will also see first-time participants from Israel and Hungary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vegetable, fruit prices slide in Taipei wholesale markets

TEXT.P: Prices of vegetables and fruit recorded an 11-percent drop Saturday in Taipei's wholesale markets compared with the previous day's level, according to statistics released by the Taipei Typhoon Sepat Disaster Prevention and Control Center.
The drop resulted from an increasing vegetable supply, said a spokesman for the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co. (TAPMC).

According to the disaster control center, the vegetable supply to the Taipei markets increased by more than 200 tons from the previous day and the average price slid to NT$30.98 per kilogram from Friday's NT$34.7.

The average fruit price registered NT$20.7 per kilogram, lower than Friday's NT$22, even though the supply was less. The TAPMC spokesman attributed the drop to poorer fruit quality in comparison with that of the past few days.

Council of Agriculture Vice Minister Lee Chien-chuan said vegetable and fruit supplies to the capital city have been boosted to 1,200 tons per day, meeting demand. He urged consumers to refrain from panic buying in the face of the typhoon threat.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi foundation sets up 12 disaster response centers

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation has set up 12 disaster response centers at its branches around the nation to tackle emergencies caused by Typhoon Sepat, a spokesman for the foundation said Saturday.

The Central Weather Bureau issued a land warning for Typhoon Sepat Thursday and warned the public to be alert to strong wind and heavy rain that could cause landslides or floods. The typhoon was decreasing in intensity after making landfall in Taiwan Saturday, but was expected to continue bringing heavy rain and strong wind throughout the day.
A headquarters for the 12 disaster response centers was set up in Hualien County to receive reports of emergencies from local centers, the Tzu Chi spokesman said.
According to the spokesman, the foundation might also establish community coordination centers in areas seriously affected by the typhoon.
The foundation has also prepared 5,000 emergency kits, sterilized dining utensils, lifesaving equipment, bottled water and vehicles for use in emergencies.

Master Cheng Yen, founder of the foundation, urged the public to be prepared for disaster, while the spokesman called on the public to secure objects that could be blown away by the strong wind, prepare flashlights, water and food, clear drains and avoid going to dangerous areas, such mountain regions or the coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate reiterates opposition to cross-strait common market

TEXT.P: The presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday that he opposes the idea of forming a Taiwan-China common market but supports proposals to open wider the doors for tourist exchanges and chartered flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Frank Hsieh said he opposes the proposal by his election rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), to launch direct air links between Taiwan proper and China. However, he said Taiwan can expand chartered cross-strait flights that operate during holidays and festivals such as Chinese New Year.

He also said he agrees with proposals to allow Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan and to permit Chinese investors to buy real estate in Taiwan. Hsieh made the remarks at a workshop held in Taichung, central Taiwan, by a local industry association.
He said that while pursuing economic development, Taiwan should at the same time make efforts to make the people happy.

He said that Taiwan's economic problems are mostly caused by political disputes and claimed that if he wins the 2008 election, he will first try to settle the conflicts between the ruling and opposition parties before making efforts to seek a majority in the Legislative Yuan, which would help the government carry out its policies.

Talking about his cross-strait policy, Hsieh said he approves of the idea of lifting bans on cross-strait transport, trade and postal links, but opposes the idea of forming a cross-strait common market, claiming that through such a market, cheap agricultural products, substandard goods and cheap labor from China would flow into Taiwan, affecting market and social order.

Speculating that there will be an outflow of investment from China in five years due to increasing appreciation of the Chinese yuan and increasing labor costs there, Hsieh said such an outflow would be a good chance for Taiwan to attract funds from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 76 rivers at high risk of mudflows

TEXT.P: The number of rivers at high risk of mudflows has increased to 76 in the wake of heavy rain triggered by Typhoon Sepat, officials at the Council of Agriculture's Soil and Water Conservation Bureau warned Saturday.
The affected areas include 26 villages in 10 townships located in Taitung, Hualien, Nantou, Chiayi and Taichung counties, where residents have been evacuated to safer places, the officials said.

Another 668 rivers are listed as potentially risky, affecting 68 townships in Taitung, Hualien, Nantou, Chiayi, Yilan, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Taichung counties, they said, adding that residents in these areas had been advised to prepare for evacuation.

According to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , the structure of Typhoon Sepat had been damaged and was decreasing in intensity after the eye of the typhoon made landfall over the estuary of the Hsiukuluan river in eastern Hualien County at 5: 40 a.m.

The eye of Sepat left the island from the mouth of the Choshui river in western Taiwan at 11 a.m., and at 2 p.m., the typhoon was centered 40 km north-northeast of the outlying island group of Penghu, moving northwest at 13 kph toward China, CWB forecasters said.

From midnight until 2 p.m., accumulated rainfall had reached up to 727 mm in Hualien County, 636 mm in Yilan County, 363 mm in Taipei County, 346 in Taoyuan County, 331 mm in Taichung County, 322 in Nantou County, 307 mm in Hsinchu County, 294 in Kaohsiung County, 266 mm in Taitung County, 262 mm in Chiayi County and 250 mm on Orchid Island, CWB data shows.
Meanwhile, tallies from Taiwan Power Company indicate that more than 250,000 households islandwide had experienced blackouts as a result of the typhoon as of 11 a.m. Saturday.
They included 84,065 households in Hualien County, 32,553 in Yilan County, 28,578 in Taitung County, 21,722 in Nantou County and 17,408 in Taoyuan County, Taipower officials said.
While power was restored to 64 percent of the affected households later that morning, power to the other households was not expected to be resumed until midnight, they said.
In the hardest-hit Hualien County, 500 hectares of pomelo orchards were damaged by the typhoon, with financial losses estimated at NT$300 million (US$9.1 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister rejects immigration head's resignation

TEXT.P: Wu Chen-chi, director of the National Immigration Agency under the Ministry of Interior (MOI) , has been asked to stay in his post to improve measures on the security of the country's detention centers, MOI Minister Lee Yi-yang said Saturday.
Wu tendered an oral resignation after 10 Vietnamese women escaped from a detention center in the northeastern county of Yilan a day earlier, the third such mass breakout at the same detention center.
Lee said the agency, which was inaugurated Jan. 2, lacks sufficient manpower and funding to effectively take the control of the detention center.
Following its inauguration, the immigration agency took over the detention center from the National Police Agency, with staff reduced from 160 to 91, Lee went on.
Lee added that he will call a meeting with officials from relevant government agencies to address the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP vice presidential candidate returns from U.S.

TEXT.P: Former Premier Su Tseng-chang, who recently accepted an invitation from ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh to serve as his running mate in the 2008 election, returned to Taiwan Saturday morning from a private trip to the United States.
Su received a warm welcome from Hsieh upon arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, making it the first public meeting between the two since the Hsieh-Su ticket was formed Aug. 15.
Accompanied by election campaign aides, DPP officials and lawmakers, Hsieh offered his appreciation to Su, saying that Su returned home at a time when "Taiwanese people need him the most."
Hsieh said they will not just participate in the election campaign but will also take part in post-typhoon relief efforts and other activities.
Su's return came at the height of Typhoon Sepat, which was ravaging Taiwan with strong wind and heavy rain.

Describing the Hsieh-Su ticket as "unexpected, " Su said he has always hoped that the DPP will unify to win the election since the party's May 6 presidential primary, in which Hsieh won a landslide victory over Su.

The former premier tendered his resignation following his primary defeat and departed for the United States for what he called "a learning trip," which he also said would give Hsieh more room to make a final decision on his running mate.

Su said he decided to accept Hsieh's invitation after receiving many telephone calls and text messages from Hsieh and "many of his good friends, " who expected him to accept "the difficult task" of winning the election.
Su promised that he will do his utmost to help Hsieh and the DPP to victory in the presidential and legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan official meets U.S. counterparts amid China protests
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/18/07 16:52:01 (By Jorge Liu and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Chen Chung-hsin said in Washington Friday that he had exchanged ideas with his U.S. counterparts on climate change issues amid multiple protests from China.

Chen visited several environment and energy officials from the Bush administration in Washington, D.C. after leading a delegation to attend an annual Taiwan-U.S. meeting on environmental protection in Hawaii.
Chen told a press conference held at the National Press Club that almost every U.S. official he met told him they had received a protest from the Chinese embassy in the U.S. capital.
Chen noted that environmental issues are global issues and claimed they have "little to do with politics." He expressed regret over China's complaints.

Describing Chen's visit as "successful, " Stanley Kao, the deputy Taiwanese representative to Washington, also confirmed at the news conference that his office also received calls from State Department officials informing about China's protests.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairman to attend funeral of former Japanese prime minister

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun will attend the funeral of former Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, party sources said Saturday.
Yu is scheduled to leave for Japan Aug. 26 and return to Taiwan Aug. 28.
Miyazawa, whose political career stretched from Japan's defeat in World War II to 2003, died at the age of 87 of natural causes at his home in Tokyo June 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Super-typhoon worsens floods
The Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) and the Philippine National Police (PNP) yesterday mobilized military and police disaster response units after floods worsened in several areas of Northern and Central Luzon triggered by the continuous heavy rains brought by super-typhoon "Egay."
The Philippine Daily InquirerG RP wins $425-M case
THE WORLD Bank has dismissed the claim for compensation over the Naia Terminal 3 project of Germany's Frankfurt Airport Services Worldwide (Fraport), clearing the way for the eventual operation of the mothballed facility, officials said Friday.
The Philippine StarG RP wins NAIA-3 case vs Fraport
Another episode in the legal tug-of-war over the mothballed Ninoy Aquino International Airport Terminal 3 (NAIA-3) ended favorably for the government, with the dismissal by a World Bank-affiliated international court of the $425-million arbitration case filed by Fraport AG, the biggest investor in the airport project.
The Manila TimesG Abu Sayyaf splits up
THE Abu Sayyaf has broken up into smaller groups following the wounding of its leaders in three days of intense fighting in Sulu last week, a senior military official said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Stock markets bounce back after US rate cut counters global jitters
Britains battered stock market investors won a respite yesterday from the past months brutal slump in shares after a surprise move by Americas powerful central bank to calm markets sent the value of the countrys leading bluechip companies soaring upwards.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: U.S. cuts rate, stock markets recovered.
Stock markets in U.S. and Europe recovered Friday following the U.S. Federal Reserves announced to cut the rate at which it lends to commercial banks by 0.5 percent. Italian Finance and Economics Minister Tomasso Padoa-Schioppa warned however that Italy is still vulnerable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five people injured during typhoon devastation

TEXT.P: Five people were injured Saturday in devastation caused by Typhoon Sepat, according to statistics released by the Central Disaster Prevention and Control Center.
Four of the wounded were motorbike riders who crashed in Taipei City, while the other was knocked down by a falling rock in Kaohsiung County, according to the center.

Central Weather Bureau meteorologists forecast that Taiwan will be out of Sepat's storm circle by midnight Saturday. The typhoon had been decreasing in intensity after its structure was damaged when it passed over the central mountain range earlier in the day.
As of noon, the statistics show, 1,785 people had been evacuated from mudslide- threatened areas around the country.

Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang, commander of the disaster control center, said no major human casualties or property damage had so far been reported. He attributed this to local governments, the people and the media's cooperation in carrying out precautions.

Commenting on news reports of skyrocketing vegetable and fruit prices in retail markets, Lee said there was an increased supply to Taipei's wholesale market, and that prices had in fact dropped there. Relevant authorities have been asked to deal with the problem, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to meet DPP presidential, vice presidential candidates

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will meet with ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and vice presidential candidate Su Tseng-chang at the Presidential Office Monday, a source from the Presidential Office said Saturday.
The remarks came after Su returned to Taiwan earlier in the day from a private trip to the United States.
Yeh Chu-lan, who was named by Chen as his chief of staff a day earlier, is also expected to be present at the meeting, the source said.
Yeh, who was previously reported as a possible candidate to team up with Hsieh for the 2008 election, confirmed Thursday that she had accepted Hsieh's invitation to serve as his campaign manager.
Yeh is slated to be sworn in at the Presidential Office one hour before she accompanies Chen to meet with Hsieh and Su, according to the source.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: White House to Offer Iraq Plan of Gradual Cuts
The White House plans to use a report next month assessing progress in Iraq to outline a plan for gradual troop reductions beginning next year that would fall far short of the drawdown demanded by Congressional opponents of the war, according to administration and military officials.
The Wall Street Journal: Fed Offers Banks Loans Amid Crisis
The Federal Reserve took highly unusual steps Friday to open up the supply of cash to the nation's banks and signaled a willingness to cut interest rates if necessary, at a time when some of the safest financial markets are seizing up and threatening the broader economic outlook.
Specifically, the central bank lowered the discount rate, charged on direct Fed loans to banks, to 5.75% from 6.25%, and took steps to encourage banks to borrow from what is known as its discount window, such as lengthening the term of such loans to as long as 30 days from the current one day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sepat not expected to completely leave Taiwan before midnight

TEXT.P: Typhoon Sepat has slowed down since making landfall on Taiwan Saturday and was not expected to completely leave Taiwan before midnight, according to Central Weather Bureau forecasters.

The eye of the typhoon, which passed over the estuary of the Hsiukuluan river in eastern Hualien County at 5: 40 a.m., left the island from the mouth of the Choshui river in western Taiwan at 11 a.m., the forecasters said.
Still covering the entire Taiwan, the typhoon had lost speed to 13 kph over the past several hours, which meant it's effects would continue well into the night, they said.
Rain was increasing in central and southern Taiwan in the afternoon, the forecasters added.
At 4: 15 p.m., the typhoon was centered 50 km north-northeast of the outlying Penghu island group, moving northwest toward China and packing maximum sustained winds of 126 kph, CWB data showed.
With the typhoon continuing to decrease in intensity, it was likely to downgrade to a tropical storm soon, the forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Fed Lowers Bank Rate, Shifts View On Economy
The Federal Reserve cut a key interest rate yesterday, trying to ease a worldwide credit crunch, and said for the first time that it viewed turmoil in financial markets as a major risk to the U.S. economy.
The Washington Times: Fed cuts emergency-loan rate
The Federal Reserve sparked a major rally in world markets yesterday by slashing the interest rate it charges on emergency loans to banks in an effort to avert an increasing threat to economic growth from the credit crisis on Wall Street.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH asks people to clean environment to prevent Dengue fever

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) called on the public to remove standing water from containers and clean their environment after Typhoon Sepat in order to prevent another epidemic of dengue fever, a DOH official said Saturday.

Chou Chih-hau, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control under the DOH, said heavy rain brought by the typhoon might create more breeding areas for mosquitoes and further increase the risk of another outbreak of dengue fever.

Southern Taiwan was hit hard by dengue fever this year, with more than 60 cases of indigenous dengue fever reported since the beginning of summer. The number was much higher than last year's figure, Chou said.

The center previously carried out a large-scale disinfection operation in Tain an City in an effort to eradicate dengue fever-carrying mosquitoes, but they were still found after the second day of the operation, Chou said, adding that this shows the mosquitoes were still breeding.
He asked the public, especially residents of Tainan and Kaohsiung cities, to heed the problem.

Yuan Shao-ying, director-general of the Bureau of Environmental Sanitation and Toxic Substance Control, reminded the public to also clear away mud, which is the preferred breeding site of the biting midge, whose bites cause painful and itchy weals that last for several days.

DOC.HEADLINE: People feel China more hostile toward Taiwan: survey

TEXT.P: A majority of respondents to a recent survey said China has become more hostile toward the Taiwanese government and people than before, according to a senior official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

The survey was conducted by National Chengchi University's Election Study Center under the commission of the MAC. Questionnaires were administered via telephone to randomly chosen adults from Aug. 10-12 and 1,095 valid samples were collected.

Quoting the survey results, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun said 63.8 percent of the respondents think China is hostile toward the Taiwanese government and some 44.1 percent think China is not friendly toward the Taiwanese people.
The survey also shows that 67 percent of those polled ascribe Taiwan's difficulties in participating in international organizations and developing diplomacy to oppression by China.
Liu said China should come up with new thinking and measures to bring reconciliation across the Taiwan Strait instead of blocking Taiwan 's development in the international community.
The survey also shows that 64 percent of the respondents think Taiwan should make more effort to develop diplomatic achievements, even if it increases cross- Taiwan Strait tension.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien sustains NT$260 million-worth of agricultural losses

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses in the eastern county of Hualien has reached NT$260 million (US$7.87 million) since Typhoon Sepat made landfall over the estuary of the county's Hsiukuluan river at 5: 40 a.m. Saturday, according to an assessment by the Hualien County Bureau of Agriculture.

Strong wind and torrential rain destroyed about 2,500 hectares of fruit and vegetable land in the county, representing a zero harvest from a total of 1,340 hectares of cropland, bureau Director Tu Li-hua said after inspecting typhoon- affected areas earlier in the day.

Tu said pomelo growers in Jueisuei and Yuli townships sustained the heaviest losses, with around 1,040 hectares of pomelo orchards damaged, adding that the windfall rate had reached 60 percent in the county.
In addition, Tu added, watermelons, bananas and leafy vegetables were also seriously damaged, noting that the losses have reached the level entitling farmers to financial aid from the government.
Meanwhile, in the southeastern county of Taitung, the production of pomelos was also slashed by nearly 50 percent due to Sepat's devastation, according to the Taitung County Bureau of Agriculture.

Despite the crop damage, Agriculture and Food Agency officials said major vegetable production areas in Taichung, Changhua, Nantou, Yulin and Chiayi counties survived the typhoon better. Thanks to this, they said, vegetable supplies maintained normal levels Saturday.
The agency will instruct farmers' groups to release more than 4,500 tons of frozen stocks to the market based on market needs, the officials said, urging consumers to refrain from panic buying.

DOC.HEADLINE: Don't be conned into working for fraudsters in Malaysia: MOFA

TEXT.P: Diplomatic officials cautioned local people Saturday not to be duped into traveling to Malaysia to work for fraud rings there.

The officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) issued the warning after discovering that several Taiwanese citizens have been arrested by Malaysian police for involvement in fraud cases in that country.
Initial investigations show that those Taiwanese people had traveled to Malaysia to work as "sales people" whose job was to inform others by phone of having won prizes for fraud purposes.
According to MOFA officials, the Taiwanese people made contact with the Malaysian fraud rings simply through manpower recruiting advertisements in local newspapers.

In the past few years, the officials said, a number of Taiwanese citizens were also conned into traveling to South Korea to work for fraud rings there after reading newspaper "talent scout" ads. After arriving in South Korea, they would be asked to cheat others by phone. Many of them have been arrested by South Korean law enforcement authorities and sentenced to prison, the officials added.

Noting that similar criminal operations seem to have been duplicated in Malaysia, the officials said local people should maintain vigilance when they read suspicious "talent scout" ads in the print media.
They said job seekers should carefully verify information given by potential overseas employers in order to avoid breaking the law in the countries they go to.
Meanwhile, the officials went on, MOFA will cooperate with the National Police Agency and relevant foreign police authorities to prevent or thwart similar fraud operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-born Yankees pitcher commended for community service
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/18/07 20:57:46 (By Jaw-pyng Hwang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born New York Yankees pitcher Chien-Ming Wang was commended in a ceremony in Bronx borough in New York City Friday for his participation in community services and public interest activities.
The ceremony was organized by Peace, Unity and Hope Inc., a U.S. public-interest group, at a children's club at Kips Bay near the Yankees Stadium.
Also cited were New York Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman and Adele Smithers, chairman of the Christopher D. Smithers Foundation.

Wang received a citation from Ray Negron, a special aide to Yankees principal owner George Steinbrenner. Negron said Wang has not only emerged as one of the most promising pitchers in the U.S. Major League but has also made great contributions to community services.

According to Negron, Wang has never turned down an invitation to take part in public-interest activities. He often visits hospitals to play with ailing children. Earlier this year, Wang attended the groudbreaking ceremony for the Yankees Stadium station on a new metro railway line.
Nearly 400 children from disadvantaged families also attended Friday's citation ceremony and lunched with Wang and other Yankees baseballers.
Wang said he felt honored to receive the citation, adding that he enjoys playing with children. Children from underprivileged families require more concern and help, he added.

At the ceremony, Wang received a surprise gift -- a color portrait of him -- from James Fiorentino. The noted artist said he spent two days painting the portrait based on Wang's photo. Fiorentino said he was delighted to present the painting to Wang in person. Praising the painting as a masterpiece, Wang said it's an invaluable gift for him.

As part of the Hispanic Heritage Month celebrations, the New York Yankees will join with American Airlines, singer Jose Feliciano and Bronx community leaders in sponsoring a Peace, Unity & Hope Concert Sept. 22 to raise funds for charity groups dedicated to helping children in need.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3D industry alliance launched to boost Taiwan's capacity

TEXT.P: Taiwan research institutions and 3D product manufacturers have forged a new strategic alliance on three-dimensional interaction and display, with the aim of boosting local research and production capacity in related areas, sources at the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) said Saturday.

According to the Hsinchu-based ITRI and another 20-strong member companies, the alliance will focus on technology for 3D interactive imaging and 3D display on liquid crystal display (LCD) - - both of which are regarded as the next promising fields in the digital industry, with an estimated seven-fold expansion in global market value by 2010.

Chan Yi-jen, deputy director of the ITRI's Electronics and Optoelectronics Research Laboratory, explained that 3D interactive imaging technology can be adapted to various products, such as customized 3D photo albums, interactive computer games and even 3D personal medical advisors that can allow doctors run remote diagnosis on patients.

Conventional 3D displays require at least two to three projectors working simultaneously to produce stereo images on large screens, Chan explained, adding that the 3D display technology under research and development can easily create 3D images on LCD displays without additional equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recent storms cause heavy agricultural loss

TEXT.P: Taiwan has incurred tremendous agricultural losses from the recent spate of storms, officials from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday.

Strong southwest air current began to hammer Taiwan Aug. 10, bringing torrential rain to central and southern Taiwan, and Typhoon Sepat came on the heels, rattling the entire country with strong winds and heavy rain.

According to COA tallies, torrential downpours and high winds brought by southwest air current and Typhoon Sepat caused more than NT$830 million (US$25.15 million) in agricultural losses, with the southernmost county of Pingtung and the eastern county of Hualien suffering most devastation.

Pingtung County alone incurred NT$260 million in agricultural losses as floodwaters brought by southwest air current inundated large swaths of farmland, while Hualien County ran up NT$250 million in crop losses, COA officials.
As Typhoon Sepat lashed Hualien with gale-force winds, more than 1,000 hectares of pomelo orchards were decimated, with the windfall rate reaching 60 percent, the officials said.

The neighboring county of Taitung also suffered heavy agricultural losses, with nearly half of its pomelo crop destroyed. County officials said the supply of pomelo, a major fruit for Mid-Autumn Festival, which falls on Sept. 25, could be cut by half.
Meanwhile, the Taipei city government said 14 of its citizens were injured when Typhoon Sepat hammered the city. Most of them sustained only minor injuries, city officials said.

According to the capital city's emergency response and disaster relief center, 848 houses reported power blackout and 302 trees were uprooted by strong winds. Two landslides were reported in hillside areas and 15 vehicles were affected by falling tree branches.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 19, or the seventh day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under U.S. tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch a full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980 and again from 1982 until he was elected U.S. president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years in detention.
1966: An earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a U.S. withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- "glasnost" and "perestroika" -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stresses that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits the Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
1999: The Taiwan Independence Party nominates its chairman, Cheng Pang-chen, as its candidate for the ROC's next presidential election slated for March 2000.
2000: An agreement sending International Cooperation and Development volunteers from the ROC to Nicaragua is passed during a regular meeting of the Executive Yuan.
2001: A 36-hour course on conducting election campaigns launched by the newly- established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Taiwan's 95th political party, begins at the Grand Hotel Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but once you try to figure out a thing, you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranks as world's 22nd largest economy: IMF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy ranked as the 22nd largest in the world in 2006 with a gross domestic product (GDP) totaling US$355.7 billion, according to the latest tallies from the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

According to IMF tallies published in April this year, Taiwan was the world's 20th largest economy in 2004, with a GDP totaling US$322.3 billion, but was surpassed by Turkey in 2005, to fall to 21st place with a GDP of US$346.7 billion.
Taiwan was also surpassed in 2006, this time by Indonesia, dropping back another notch to rank as the world's 22nd largest economy with a GDP of US$355.7 billion, IMF tallies indicated.

However, Taiwan ranked 21st in the world in terms of GDP in 2006 according to tallies from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, which calculated Taiwan's GDP to be US$364.2 billion last year.

The IMF forecast that Taiwan would retain its GDP ranking this year, remaining the world's 22nd largest economy with its GDP dollar estimate -- the value of all final goods and services produced within a nation in a given year -- totaling some US$365.3 billion.

The United States was the world's largest economy in 2006, with a GDP totaling US$13.24 trillion, followed by Japan at US$4.37 trillion, Germany with US$2.89 trillion, and China with a GDP of US$2.63 trillion, according to the IMF.

According to a domestic financial analyst, Taiwan's world GDP ranking could be slightly lower given a weaker New Taiwan dollar after the GDP calculated in Taiwan currency is converted into greenbacks for the GDP dollar estimate.
