DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses in Hualien exceeds NT$300 million

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses to Typhoon Sepat in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, exceeded NT$300 million, the county's bureau of agriculture reported Sunday.

According to the bureau's estimates, Hualien county suffered some NT$310 million in farm and agricultural losses when Typhoon Sepat hit the eastern county Saturday, with townships in its central and southern areas bearing the brunt of the disaster.
Locally grown pomelos were most affected by the typhoon, with 729 hectares, or 63 percent of its production on 1,161 hectares of farmland ruined, bureau officials said.
The effect of the lost pomelo crop on the domestic market remains to be seen, officials said, adding that the top priority now is to help farmers overcome their monetary difficulties.
Hualien produces about one third of Taiwan's pomelos, which is the major seasonal fruit consumed in the annual Mid-autumn Festival, now little more than one month away.
Hualien is also a prime production site for watermelons and bananas, with nearly 50 percent and 64 percent, respectively, of those harvests ravaged.
Sepat, the strongest typhoon to hit Taiwan so far this year, landed on eastern Taiwan Saturday morning and left the island early Sunday of the same day on its way to China.
The Central Weather Bureau warned the public to remain on high alert with ensuing strong torrential rainfall expected for the entire country, in particular central and southern regions.
The bureau has lifted its land warning for the entire Taiwan proper and the offshore islands of Penghu and Matsu Sunday morning. Land warning remains in place for Kinmen Island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't undecided on allowing use of animal drug: spokesman

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wei said Sunday that the government has yet to make a final decision on the use of ractopamine -- an animal drug that promotes the growth of lean meat in livestock -- as several key elements must be thoroughly studied.

Shieh made the remarks to reporters after the China Times reported that ranking Executive Yuan officials are set to make a U-turn on its previous decision to lift the ban on ractopamine by following in Japan's suit and maintaining a ban on its use by local pig farmers while allowing foreign pork imports containing the substance to enter Taiwan.

According to Shieh, the Executive Yuan has not made a final decision on the issue as several factors have to be fully taken into account -- such as the public's health concern, local hog farmers' interests and international norms.

Although the Executive Yuan will do its best to assess the issue and strike a balance among all sides, he acknowledged that it will be extremely difficult for the government to satisfy all parties concerned.
He said that Taiwan will have to respond to the new regulations set to be published in Sept. by the World Trade Organization regarding the use of ractopamine, which is currently banned in Taiwan.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) and the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced last week that they will remove the ban by the end of this month and permit minute levels of ractopamine residue in different organs in pigs and cattle and their meat, spurring fierce oppositions from local pig raisers who threatened to demonstrate in front of the DOH Tuesday if the government fails to repeal the decision by Monday.

Although ractopamine is banned in Taiwan, two shipments of U.S. pork imports containing the unlawful drug were detected last month, provoking grave food safety concerns among local consumers and stirring up strong social criticism that the government has failed to apply the same standard to scrutinize foreign imports.

Local hog raisers said they suspected the government's announcement to lift the ban was a result of U.S. pressure and accused it of turning a blind eye to the public's health and farmers' livelihoods.

In response to the China Times report, Cheng Hui-wen, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said that he is unable to answer the question whether the government is intended to bring in "dual standards" concerning ractopamine as he is not familiar with any "ranking Executive Yuan officials."

Any government decision on changes in this regard must be accepted by local consumers and pig farmers, he said, noting that the levels of ractopamine residue to be permitted by the government are safe and in compliance with international regulations.

According to Cheng, the DOH and the COA share common ground in that they believe the same criteria regarding the use of the animal drug must be applied to foreign and local products and neither of them will move on its own to handle foreign imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins 28 medals at World University Games
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/07 17:33:36 (By Li Chien-chung and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese athletes garnered seven gold, nine sliver and 12 bronze medals, their best ever performance, at the 2007 World University Games which concluded Saturday in Bangkok, Thailand.
The coaches and athletes will earn cash award totaling NT$40.78 million from the government's Guoguang Award program.

Under the program, gold, silver, and bronze medalists will be rewarded with NT$600,000, NT$300,000 and NT$150,000 respectively. Coaches of medal winners will be awarded the same amount as the athletes, while coaches of winning teams will receive 1.5 times the reward money.
As a result, a total of NT$19.5 million will be awarded to athletes, and NT$21.28 million will go to coaches.

This year, Taiwan dispatched 16 sports teams taking part in 14 events, with table tennis star Chuang Chih-yuan the biggest winner, taking a gold, silver and bronze in the men's doubles, men's singles and men' s team play, earning NT$1.05 million, while the women's softball team will share NT$5.1 million for winning a gold in its event.

Other gold medalists include badminton players Chien Yu-chin and Cheng Wen-hsing in the women's doubles; Chen Ming-chuan in the men's golf individual; Chang Yen- shu in the men's table tennis doubles; taekwondo athletes Su Li-wen, Lin An-ni, and Tseng Yi-hsuan in various divisions; and tennis duo Chan Yung-jan (right) and Chuang Chia-jung in the women's doubles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Contract chip makers output to soar to NT$121 billion in Q3

TEXT.P: The output value of Taiwan's contract chip makers in the third quarter is expected to reach NT$121 billion (US$3.66 billion) , a 16.9 percent growth over the previous quarter, thanks to growing market demand, according to an industry report released Sunday.

The contract chip manufacturing industry has experienced an early recovery in Q2, with an output amounting to NT$103.5 billion, having grown 13.2 percent over the previous quarter, according to a survey released by Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA).

The Q3 output is likely to continue on an upward trend following decreases in inventory levels caused by the growing demand for personal computers, mobile phones and other consumer electronic products thanks to hot seasonal sales and outsourcing of orders for nanotech products reported by integrated device manufacturers, the report said.
The TSIA predicted that the Q3 output will surge 5.49 percent over the same period of the previous year.

As for Taiwanese-made IC products, the Q2 output value fell sharply, down 29.4 percent, to NT$64.3 billion from Q1, while the Q3 output is expected to top NT$85 billion, showing a substantial surge of 32.2 percent over the previous quarter due to a boost in DRAM makers' production capacity, advances in manufacturing techniques, and a rebound in product prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan school wins 2nd place in Japan's solar car race

TEXT.P: Students from National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences (NKUAS) won second place in the Dream Cup solar car race in Japan earlier this month, the best ever performance of the NKUAS team in international solar car competitions, a school source said Sunday.

The 18-member NKUAS team competed in the top division of the 16th Japanese solar car race held at Suzuka Circuit in Suzuka City, Mie prefecture Aug. 4-5 and lost to the Japanese team, by eight rounds in endurance trials.

The Suzuka Circuit solar car race attracted 80 teams, mostly from around Japan, to compete in three divisions. The NKUAS team took part in the top division, the only foreign team competing with seven Japanese teams for the Dream Cup.
The Dream Cup, which began in 1992 with an aim to promote eco-friendly automobiles, was jointly sponsored by Yomiuri Shimbun, Suzuka Circuitland Co. and Japan Automobile Federation (JAF).
After the race, NKUAS racers said that the Japanese solar cars were generally very well-built and relatively better in terms of stability than the model that the Taiwan team used.
"There is certainly ample room for us to improve our equipment and techniques," said the NKUAS racers.

Although the NKUAS-developed solar car -- which uses a solar panel on par with U.S. aerospace industrial standards -- is far less efficient than current commercial cars, the NKUAS team has accumulated experience and skills making and using environmentally friendly solar cars, and is seen as a rising star in the field of transportation.
The NKUAS team -- the one and only team of its kind in Taiwan -- has been participating in international solar car races abroad since 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fair Trade Commission to investigate grocery prices

TEXT.P: Officials from the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission (FTC) have decided to investigate soaring grocery prices in the wake of Typhoon Sepat, which swept through Taiwan Saturday causing flash floods and landslides around the island.
FTC officials will begin from Monday looking into whether traders of groceries, particularly leafy vegetables, have hoarded produce or conspired to raise prices.

In the wake of the typhoon, which wreaked havoc on open fields in central, eastern and southern Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains, the prices of leafy vegetables have skyrocketed, with the price of high-altitude Chinese cabbage surging to NT$260 (US$7.8) per piece, and spring onions rising to NT$100 per catty (about 600 grams).

Meanwhile, officials from the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co. forecast that higher grocery prices will probably persist throughout the next half a month as a result of the passing typhoon and in anticipation of the approach of the Zhongyuan Ghost Festival, during which Taiwan people will prepare feasts as offerings for ghost from the nether world.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential candidate unveils forestation plan

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) for the March 22, 2008 presidential election, unveiled Sunday his plantation plan during a visit to Tainan County in southern Taiwan.

On a visit to Wushantou Reservoir -- the largest reservoir in Taiwan -- Ma promised that if elected, he will immediately launch a plantation project on some 50,000-hectare fallow farmland in Tainan and Chiayi counties to help balance the country's carbon emissions in line with global efforts to reduce the greenhouse effect.

Ma also paid laid flower wreaths and bowed to a statue of Hatta Yoichi, a late Japanese engineer who constructed a massive irrigation system in the Tainan and Chiayi areas -- a prime granary for the country -- during the period of Japanese rule of Taiwan.

According to Ma, about 220,000 of Taiwan's 970,000 hectares of farmland are fallow. He voiced his hope that in the future, the government and the private sector would cooperate in massive forestation to help protect natural environments and conserve water resources -- which will be key national development strategies in the coming 30 years.
The forestation project might cost the national coffers up to NT$8 billion, but it would help counterbalance 140 million tons of carbon dioxide emissions, he explained.

Under the terms of the Kyoto Protocol, Taiwan has to slash its carbon dioxide emission by 5.8 percent during the coming 2008-2012 period based on its 1990 level, Ma said, adding that the best way to achieve the aim is to plant trees and forests.
If Taiwan fails to meet the target, the country's foreign trade will be boycotted by the international community -- a development he said will pose serious threat to its sustainable growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu Science Park unaffected by Typhoon Sepat

TEXT.P: Operations at the Hsinchu Science Park in northern Taiwan remained normal despite Typhoon Sepat sweeping across Taiwan over the weekend, a park administration official said Sunday.

Huang De-ruei, director general of the park administration, said there was no damage reported at the science-based industry park, as the winds and rains Sepat brought to the area were not as strong as expected.
High-tech companies stationed in the park reported no disruptions to operations as supplies of water and electricity remained normal, Huang continued.

To prevent flooding and other damages caused by Sepat's strong winds and heavy rains, the park's administration set up a disaster rescue and emergency response center Saturday, comprised of members of the park administration's construction and building office, commercial services division, industrial safety and environmental division, fire station and security guard office, as well as staffers of Taipower Co. and Taiwan Water Supply Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pig farmers poised to demonstrate against easing ban on animal drug

TEXT.P: Local farmers said Sunday that they will demonstrate Tuesday in Taipei anyway, despite a local newspaper report that the government is to retain the ban on local use of an animal drug while allowing foreign imports containing the same substance to enter Taiwan.

Lin Min-chi, chairman of the pig-raising association in Taichung County, central Taiwan, said that nearly 10,000 farmers from across the country are set to demonstrate in front of the Department of Health (DOH) as scheduled because they cannot accept the government's decision, adding that the government was "toying" with the public's health and farmers' interests by planning to ease the ban on the unlawful drug.

Lin questioned how consumers could distinguish good products from bad if the government is to permit ractopamine-tainted foreign imports to enter Taiwan, and warned that easing the ban will pose great risks to consumers' health and deal a heavy blow to local producers.

Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers and its presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, voiced the same day their objections to a government planned removal of its ban on ractopamine -- an animal drug that promotes the growth of lean meat in livestock.
Ma expressed his opposition to the government's plan to relax the ban during a seminar with local pig farms on a visit to Tainan County, southern Taiwan.

The government's softened stance on the banned drug has stirred up fierce opposition from local consumer groups and hog raisers who threatened to demonstrate in front of the DOH Tuesday if it fails to back off from its decision to lift the ban by Monday.

The use of the illicit drug has provoke heated debates in society after two shipments of U.S. pork imports were discovered last month to be ractopamine- tainted, while local farmers are banned from using the substance.

Arguing that the government must apply the same criteria to examinations of local and foreign products to protect the health of Taiwan's people, Ma said that he will back local farmers' opposition to lifting the ban so as to allow tainted foreign imports to enter the country.

Tainan hog farmers attending the seminar complained that U.S. pork imports laced with ractopamine residue are low-end products and lashed out at the government for discriminating against local people by seeking to permit such foreign imports.
"We will never accept such double-dealing from the government," they asserted.
KMT lawmakers also said that they are firmly opposed to easing the ban on ractopamine whatever the reason cited by the government.
Chou Shou-hsun, a KMT legislative caucus whip, said that the government must not undermine local farmers' interests and the public's health under any circumstances.
Commenting on Tuesday's demonstration by hog raisers, Chou said that the KMT will not be involved in the protests to avoid clouding the issue with political implications.

The China Times daily newspaper reported Sunday on its front page that the Executive Yuan is likely to reverse its earlier decision to lift the ban on ractopamine by following Japan's example and maintaining a ban on its use by local pig raisers while allowing pork imports containing the substance to enter the domestic market.
Executive Yuan speaker Shieh Jyh-wei said the same day that the government has not yet made a final decision regarding lifting the ban and the use of the veterinary drug.

Both the DOH and the Council of Agriculture (COA) reiterated their stance Sunday evening that a final decision on whether to lift the ban will be made only once both agencies have fully assessed the viewpoints of all parties concerned.
The reported "double dealing" method to handle local and foreign products is not the final conclusion, the COA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture loses nearly NT$1 billion to 10 days of bad weather

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural sector has lost nearly NT$ 1 billion (US$30.27 million) over the past ten days due to heavy rains brought by a series of storms, according to tallies released by the Council of Agriculture on Sunday.
Beginning Aug. 6, the island was subjected to two tropical storms--Pabuk and Wutip--followed by Typhoon Sepat, each of which drenched the island with torrential rains.

According to the Council of Agriculture, losses since Aug. 10 total some NT$941.34 billion, with Hualien and Pingtung counties bearing the brunt of the damage, losing NT$300 million and NT$260 million respectively, and together accounting for more than half of the country's losses.

Damaged crops made up the bulk of the losses, totalling NT$784.38 million over 13,180 hectares of farmland. Especially hard hit were pomelo and banana orchards, and watermelon, cantaloupe, honey dew and leafy vegetable farms.
Poultry and livestock farmers have seen losses of more than NT$72.94 million, including the deaths of 1,287 pigs, 631,000 chickens, 145,000 ducks and 23,000 geese.
Fish farmers suffered damages costing NT$77.31 million as 128.65 hectares of fishing ponds in Pingtung County, and 3 hectares of fishing ponds in Yunlin County were flooded.
Forestry lost NT$350,000, mostly in the form of seedlings drowned by the rains.
Other losses include damaged farm facilities, as well as damaged fowl and livestock shelters.

However, a council official said there will not be a shortage of vegetables on the market as there are 4,421 tons of vegetables stored in freezers operated by farmers' associations around the island, which will supply 250 tons to 300 tons of stock each day to various markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County sustains farm losses of NT$70 million

TEXT.P: The southern county of Kaohsiung has sustained NT$70.4 million (US$2.13 million) worth of agricultural losses from Typhoon Sepat, according to an assessment released by the county's Bureau of Agriculture Sunday.

Strong winds and torrential rains brought by Sepat Saturday affected about 1,100 hectares of fruit and vegetable crops in the county, essentially wiping out the harvest on 259 hectares of cropland, and causing damage to about one hectare of agricultural facilities.
However the losses have not exceeded the threshold at which farmers will be entitled to register for low-interest loans or other forms of financial aid from the government, according to the report.

Banana growers in Meinung, Chishan, Taliao and Chiaotou townships were most affected by the typhoon, with 466 hectares of banana orchards damaged, and a damage rate of approximately 13 percent, resulting in the equivalent of no harvest from 61 hectares of land. The losses total an estimated NT$18.05 million.

Papaya losses in Chishan and Meinung townships reached NT$5.41 million, with 164 hectares of land affected, and an 11 percent wind fall rate resulting in the equivalent of no harvest from 18 hectares of land.
Bell fruit in Liukuei and Luchu townships sustained losses of up to NT$5.41 million, with 16 hectares of land affected, and a 61 percent damage rate, or no harvest from 10 hectares of land.
In addition, Kangshan and Yenchao townships incurred NT$3.3 million in guava harvest losses, while Chinese dates in Kangshan have seen losses of NT$4.17 million.
Meanwhile, the county's green onions suffered the worst damage of any vegetable crop, with a loss of NT$3.9 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL aircraft explodes in Naha airport, all passengers safe

TEXT.P: A passenger plane of Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) exploded upon landing at Okinawa's Naha international airport around 10: 30 a.m. local time.
All of the 157 passengers aboard were evacuated before the Boeing 737-800 exploded, according to a CAL spokesman.
The CAL flight was in the blast and broke into two pieces from the tail after all the passengers were evacuated. The fire was put out as of 11:10 a.m. local time.
The Boeing 737-800 departed from Taiwan Taoyuan international airport around 8: 45 a.m., carrying four travel groups from around Taiwan to Okinawa for tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in hisotry

TEXT.P: Today is Monday, Aug. 20, or the eighth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1741: Danish explorer Vitus Bering discovers Alaska on a mission sponsored by Russia.

1833: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, is born. The first Pan-American Conference took place (1889) during his administration, which passed the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in 1890.
1860: Raymond Poincare, French statesman and president from 1913 to 1920, is born.

1905: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had been exiled for his involvement in the anti-Ching movement, organizes the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo. The organization, headed by Dr. Sun, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1912: William Booth, British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army in 1878, dies at the age of 83.

1925: Liao Chung-kai, one of a 16-member steering committee that established a national government in July 1925, is assassinated in Canton, five months after the demise of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Peking. Liao was 47.
1928: Both the Wen River and the Mi River in the province of Shantung overflow their banks, drowning 18,000 people and leaving some 30,000 others homeless.
1940: A total of 153 Japanese military aircraft carry out a heavy bombing raid on Chungking, the war-time capital of the Republic of China.
1940: Radar is used for the first time, with the British employing it during World War II.
1940: Leon Trotsky, one of the leaders of the Russian Revolution, is stabbed to death by a Spanish communist with an alpine ax in his home in Coyoacan, near Mexico City. He was 61.

1944: Representatives of China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics meet in Washington, D.C., to discuss the establishment of a world organization after World War II.
1944: Rajiv Gandhi, former Indian prime minister, is born. The son of Indira Gandhi was assassinated on May 21, 1991.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a second invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14, 1945.

1955: Gen. Sun Li-jen, chief military aide to the president, submits a request for disciplinary action against himself as a gesture of self-reproach in regard to a communist espionage case involving Kuo Ting-liang.
1967: A total of 247 people, including Taipei City Councilor Lin Shui-chuan, are arrested for attempting to stage an armed rebellion for Taiwan independence.
1968: Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops begin the invasion of Czechoslovakia in an attempt to crush the "Prague Spring" reforms.
1972: The Republic of China Mei Ho baseball team defeats a U.S. team from California 9-0 to win the Senior League world title.

1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Lugar, chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lugar says that the U.S. government has not changed its basic support of the Republic of China and that he hopes the ROC will open its markets to reduce the ROC-US trade deficit.
1988: A U.N.-mediated cease-fire between Iran and Iraq takes effect, ending nearly eight years of war.
1995: An express train collides with another train in northern India, killing nearly 300 passengers and injuring more than 200 others.
1999: The Central Bank of China announces that Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments surplus amounted to US$5.47 billion, the highest single-quarter total in 12 years.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation arrive in Gambia at the start of his one-week, three-nation African tour which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad.
2001: Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation makes its 300th bone marrow donation, with the recipient a college student in Hangzhou City, in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to sift out, but when you once try to sift out a thing, you must never give it up until you have sifted it out clearly and distinctly."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL aircraft catches fire at Naha airport, all passengers safe

TEXT.P: A passenger jet of Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) caught fire shortly after landing at Okinawa's Naha international airport at 10:26 a.m. local time.

All 157 passengers and eight crew members aboard the Boeing 737-800 were able to escape to safety, a CAL spokesman said, adding that two of the crew members were rushed to hospital to be treated for smoke inhalation.
The plane had just pulled up to the gate to disembark passengers at 10: 27 a.m. local time when the left engine exploded and caught fire, according to the CAL spokesman, Sun Hung-wen.
None of the 157 passengers, including 17 Japanese citizens and 24 foreign nationals, were harmed, Sun said.
The Boeing 737-800 had departed from Taiwan Taoyuan international airport at 8: 23 a.m. Taipei time, carrying four tour groups from around Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier orders quick probe into CAL plane engine blast

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung ordered Monday all relevant authorities to determine as soon as possible the cause of the explosion of the left engine of a Taiwan- based China Airlines passenger jet plane at Naha Airport on the Japanese island of Okinawa earlier the same morning.

Chang said the Cabinet will provide all necessary assistance to deal with the aftermath of the incident and will continue to monitor all related developments, according to Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey.
The plane caught fire soon after landing at Naha Airport at around 10: 30 a.m. local time.

All 157 passengers and eight crew members aboard the Boeing 737-800 were able to escape, a CAL spokesman said, adding that two of the crew members were rushed to hospital to be treated for smoke inhalation.

DOC.HEADLINE: All Boeing 737-800s in Taiwan grounded after CAL plane fire

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) announced Monday that all Boeing 737-800s in Taiwan will be grounded temporarily for safety inspection after a Boeing 737-800 of Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) burst into flames at Okinawa's Naha international airport earlier in the day.

CAA Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng said at a news conference called after the mishap that all 14 Boeing 737-800s currently in service in Taiwan -- including the 12 owned by CAL and two belonging to Mandarin Airlines -- will be grounded temporarily for thorough safety checks.
The CAL Boeing 737-800, flight CI-120, caught fire shortly after landing at Okinawa's Naha international airport at 10: 26 a.m. local time.
The plane had just pulled up to the gate to disembark passengers
at the Naha airport at 10: 27 a.m. local time when its left engine exploded and caught fire, according to CAL spokesman Sun Hung-wen.
All 157 passengers, including 17 Japanese citizens and 24 other foreign nationals, and eight crew members managed to escape before fire engulfed the entire plane.

Chang said that according to preliminary findings, the cause of the engine fire may be related to the plane's fuel supply system. So the Boeing 737-800 safety checks will focus on the planes' fuel supply system, engines, pumps and other related systems, he added.

Meanwhile, according to Chang, a delegation of nine officials from the CAA, the Cabinet-level Aviation Safety Council and CAL, is heading to the southern Japanese island of Okinawa Monday afternoon to join the Japanese aviation experts in the investigation into the cause of the mishap.
The CAL Boeing 737-800 had departed from Taiwan Taoyuan international airport at 8: 23 a.m. Taipei time, carrying four tour groups from around Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Landslides block main route to Alishan Recreation Area

TEXT.P: Landslides caused by heavy rain brought by Typhoon Sepat have blocked Provincial Highway No. 18, the main route to the Alishan Forest Recreation Area, at three locations, and road repair workers were working non-stop trying to get the road open at least partially, local public works officials said Monday.
The officials said that although Typhoon Sepat had already left Taiwan, intermittent downpours in mountainous areas of Chiayi County triggered several landslides that blocked the road.

Workers had removed some fallen rocks to allow single-lane traffic at two locations -- the 39 km point and the 44.5 km point -- but emergency repairs were still continuing to open the blockage at the 82.5 km point.

Meanwhile, three search teams formed by firemen from Chiayi County were still trying to retrieve the body of a villager by combing the banks of a stream that runs through Highway No. 169 in Chiayi County. The man, identified as Fang Ming- li, was washed away by torrents Sunday while trying to cross the stream that had inundated the highway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese drivers can obtain Swiss licenses

TEXT.P: Taiwanese expatriates in Switzerland with a valid Taiwanese license can now obtain a Swiss license without taking any tests, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Monday.

Liu Yi-min, director-general of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, said the government established an agreement with the Swiss government on the reciprocal recognition of driver's licenses in late July after more than two years of consultations between the two sides.

According to Liu, the reciprocal recognition of driver's licenses in the absence of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Switzerland has improved the substantial relations between the two countries.
MOFA officials said the Taiwan-Switzerland agreement is different from another one forged recently between Taiwan and Japan that targets tourists.
Under the Taiwan-Switzerland agreement, Republic of China nationals residing in Switzerland aged 18 or over and who have a Taiwanese license can obtain a Swiss license, the officials said.

The offer is valid for licenses for cars and motorcycles up to 250 cc and before filing their applications with the Swiss authorities, the applicants need to first obtain a French or German translation of their Taiwan-issued licenses from Taiwan's representative office in Switzerland, they said.
Tourists visiting Switzerland are allowed to use international driver's licenses issued by Taiwan, which are valid for use in the European country for up to one year, they said.

Swiss citizens in Taiwan who intend to obtain a Taiwanese license can file their applications with local motor vehicles offices along with a Chinese translation of their driver's license, an alien resident certificate valid for at least one year, passport and health examination report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses accumulate to over NT$1.2 billion

TEXT.P: Taiwan incurred heavy agricultural losses valued at more than NT$1.2 billion (US$36.49 million) as a result of the recent spate of storms, including Typhoon Sepat, according to statistics released Monday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

Since early August, Taiwan has been under the influence of a strong southwesterly air current that had caused heavy downpours in the central and southern regions, while Typhoon Sepat pounded Taiwan with torrential rain and strong wind on Saturday.
According to the COA, 19,083 hectares, or 27 percent of the country's farmland has been damaged, with zero crop harvest for 5,190 hectares.

Hualien County in eastern Taiwan suffered the greatest losses, reaching NT$340 million, followed by Pingtung County in the south, with losses of NT$280 million, Yunlin County in central Taiwan at NT$180 million, and Taitung in southeastern Taiwan at NT$100 million, according to the tallies.
Pomelo orchards were hit the hardest, along with bananas, watermelons, melons and leafy vegetables.
Poultry and livestock raisers suffered losses of over NT$78.54 million, including the deaths of 3,025 pigs, 678,000 chickens, 186,000 ducks and 38,000 geese.
Fish farmers suffered damages worth NT$71.76 million, with 142.65 hectares of fishing ponds flooded.
Forestry lost NT$38.84 million, with 225.45 hectares of woodland and 146.2 hectares of seedlings destroyed by heavy downpours and gales.
Other losses include damaged farming and fishing facilities, such as fowl and livestock shelters, as well as fish breeding ponds.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung visited the worst-hit region of Hualien earlier Monday, accompanied by COA Minister Su Chia-chuan.
At a damaged pomelo orchard, Chang said the government has kicked off efforts to aid farmers with financial subsidies.

Chang made the remarks in a response to Hualien Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan's request for a special agricultural aid program for pomelo growers, who lost a combined 1,000 hectares of orchards, with a 60 percent windfall rate, according to COA officials.
It will take at least three years for the damaged pomelo trees to recover their productivity, Hsieh said, expressing hope that the Executive Yuan will increase its aid to the victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vegetable prices to remain high for three weeks

TEXT.P: High prices for vegetables and fruit in Taipei City due to heavy rain brought by Typhoon Sepat are expected to continue for three weeks, a spokesman for the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co. said Monday.
According to the spokesman, heavy rain and strong wind in central and southern Taiwan damaged farmland and blocked transport from mountain areas, affecting supplies.

Sunday's vegetable supply in Taipei City decreased to 643 tonnes, which is only 43 percent of the figure from Aug. 18, with the wholesale price of vegetables surging to NT$37.5 per kilogram. The wholesale price prior to the typhoon was a little over NT$20 per kilogram, the spokesman said.

Prices of leafy vegetables and melons both increased by 40 percent Sunday. The wholesale price of cabbage, which was affected the most by the typhoon, increased to NT$140 per kilogram, while that of cucumber surged to about NT$120 per kilogram.
The typhoon's impact on vegetable prices will be more obvious this week, and will continue until supplies of leafy vegetables return to normal.
The spokesman suggested that as an alternative, consumers might consider buying root vegetables, which have relatively stable prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market surged Monday due to the U.S. Federal Reserve Board's slashing of the rediscount rates by a half-percentage point, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September rising 543 points to close at 8,428, with 55,861 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 549 points to finish at 8,399, with 379 contracts traded, while December futures increased 489 points to close at 8,421, with 154 contract transactions. March futures surged 479 points to close at 8,430, with 15 contracts traded, while June futures rose 466 points to finish at 8,377, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,885 for September, 7,850 for October, 7,932 for December, 7,951 for March and 7,911 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were all higher.

September TE futures moved up 23.1 points to close at 353.15, with 3,389 contracts traded, while October TE futures rose 19.05 points to finish at 355.5, with 39 contract transactions. December TE futures grew 18.1 points to close at 349.3, with three contracts traded, while March TE futures increased 22.35 points to finish at 346 with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

September TF futures increased 62.8 points to close at 960, with 3,170 contracts traded, while October TF futures moved up 62.8 points to finish at 962.4, with 33 contract transactions. December TF futures moved up 34.4 points to close at 951, with two contracts traded, while March TF futures grew 21.8 points to finish at 948, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan consumers urged to boycott U.S. pork

TEXT.P: The private Consumers' Foundation urged Taiwan consumers Monday to boycott pork imported from the United States, which might contain the banned veterinary drug ractopamine.

At a news conference held over the government's about-face on the policy on the use of ractopamine in pigs and cattle, foundation officials called for Taiwan consumers to reject imported American pork and fast food that might also use ractopamine-contaminated American pork.

You Kai-hsiung, secretary-general of the foundation, criticized the government for having succumbed to U.S. pressure by lifting its ban on ractopamine, which the Council of Agriculture (COA) banned last October after cases were reported abroad concerning the effect of the drug on consumers' cardiac and neural systems.

Citing seven cases related to ractopamine poisoning reported in Hong Kong and the Chinese province of Guangdong between 1997 and 2006, You said more than 100 people in these two areas developed symptoms, including racing heartbeat, dizziness, difficulty breathing, headache, muscle cramp, vomiting, diarrhea and high blood pressure, after consuming pork containing ractopamine. One Chinese patient died 15 days after being rushed to hospital, he added.

Besides, You said, ractopamine -- marketed under the brand name Paylean -- a phenolethanolamine s-adrenoceptor agonist that is used for the improvement of weight gain, carcass leanness and feed efficiency in animals -- could also enter fetuses through the placenta and cause damage if consumed by pregnant women.
Currently, he said, ractopamine is not banned in only 24 countries, including Japan and the United States, and is banned in over 160 countries, including Taiwan, China and the European Union.

A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday that the government did not receive any pressure from the United States to lift its ban on ractopamine ahead of its decision to relax the ban.

MOFA deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei-pi said the Department of Health (DOH) tentatively decided to relax the ban Aug. 14 to permit low levels of ractopamine residue in pigs and cattle after conducting a thorough assessment of the impact of the drug on public health and food safety.
The relaxing of the ban also has nothing to do with President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming transit stop on U.S. soil as alleged by some media outlets, according to Yeh.

According to a proposed revision to the DOH's standards for veterinary drug residues, the maximum allowable level of ractopamine residue in pigs and cattle would be 10 ppb in muscle and fat tissue, 40 ppb in the liver and 90 ppb in the kidneys.
If the proposal meets no objection by Aug. 21, the new standards can be implemented at the end of the month at the earliest, DOH officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: As Democracy Push Falters, Bush Feels Like a 'Dissident'
By the time he arrived in Prague in June for a democracy conference, President Bush was frustrated. He had committed his presidency to working toward the goal of "ending tyranny in our world, " yet the march of freedom seemed stalled. Just as aggravating was the sense that his own government was not committed to his vision.
The Washington Times: Dean strafes Jamaica
Hurricane Dean pummeled Jamaica with gusting winds and torrential rains yesterday, although the island was spared a direct hit from the storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Caution Over Shuttle Shows Shift at NASA
Confronted with the same kind of problem that doomed the space shuttle Columbia, NASA officials, chastened by years of criticism and upheaval in the agency, took a markedly different approach during the current mission of the Endeavour, calling on an array of new tools and procedures to analyze and respond to the problem.
The Wall Street Journal: Credit, Profit Woes May Hit Stocks Even if Fed Acts Fast
Just a month ago, the stock market was up 12% for the year, even as corporate- earnings growth and the economy were slowing. Investors, as they generally do, were looking ahead, in this case to an expected rebound in the second half.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares prices rally

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange skyrocketed Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 425.31 points to close at 8,515.6.
The bourse opened at 8,496.97 and fluctuated between 8,516.75 and 8,397.26 during trading. A total of 4.32 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$127.45 billion (US$3.86 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 6.5 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 5.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 5.5 percent, construction issues at 5.4 percent and machinery and electronics, cement and textile stocks all at 5.2 percent, with plastics and chemicals shares at 5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers more than 1,000 to 105, with 72 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, decreasing NT$0.041 to close at NT$32.890.
A total of US$930 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.88 and fluctuated between NT$32.970 and NT$32.810.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung committee charting development course for city

TEXT.P: An 80-member Kaohsiung committee met Monday in an attempt to chart a future development course for the southern port city.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu chaired the meeting of the committee, whose members represent policy-making government agencies and a wide spectrum of the business and academic communities.

Some of the members come from the Industrial Development Bureau and the Small and Medium Enterprises Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the state-owned China Steel Corp., the Bank of Kaohsiung and leaders from the hotel and tourism industries.

Chen urged the committee members to brainstorm concrete, workable strategies to help revitalize Kaohsiung's economy. She said a new development course is necessary for the city to adapt to a new era and soften the impact of globalization.
Proposals discussed at the meeting included providing incentives to encourage companies to set up production bases in three industrial parks in the areas of software, logistics and aviation.

Some committee members suggested that Kaohsiung's export processing zone should bring in digital industries and invite information and software industries, as well as electronics and telecommunication industries, to set up their headquarters and research and development centers in the zone.

DOC.HEADLINE: Those refusing to face history `bound to be eliminated': president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Monday lambasted opposition members struggling to protect the privileges of the past authoritarian rulers of Taiwan, claiming that those who refuse to face up to history are "bound to be eliminated" by history.

Chen made the remarks while addressing a pictorial exhibition held at the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late opposition movement activist Kuo Yu-hsin. He was referring to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) politicians who have used every possible means to block the Democratic Progressive Party administration's decision to rename the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei as the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall.

Describing Kuo as a forerunner of Taiwan's opposition movement and a founding father of Taiwan's democracy, Chen said it is very meaningful that the exhibition is being held at the renamed memorial hall that was originally built in memory of Chiang -- the dictator who persecuted Kuo and forced him into exile in the United States in the 1970s.

According to Chen, Kuo started pushing for democratic reforms in Taiwan 50 years ago, including organizing an opposition party, promoting direct presidential elections, pressing for the depoliticization of the military and promoting the establishment of a new country.

However, Kuo, who died before the end of martial law in Taiwan 20 years ago, was not able to witness the democratic achievements made by Taiwan over the past seven years, including the termination of the KMT's 50 year-rule of Taiwan in 2000, the enactment of the Referendum Law in 2003 and the first national referendum in 2004, Chen said, adding that in 2008, Taiwan will hold a second national referendum to "deepen the country's democratic development."

Chen noted that during the authoritarian rule by Chiang Kai-shek and his son, Chiang Ching-kuo, Kuo stuck to his ideals despite the KMT's persecution, a move that inspired many younger democratic activists, including Huang Hsin-chieh and Yao Chia-wen.

Chen said a lot of stories about Taiwan's pursuit of democracy remain untold and that the memorial hall will further introduce other figures and incidents crucial to the development of Taiwan's democratic movement, such as Lei Chen, Huang Hsin-chieh, the Formosa Incident, the Chen Wen-cheng Incident and the abolition of Article 100 of the Criminal Code.

These stories will help the people realize that freedom and democracy are not free gifts from heaven or granted by the dictators, Chen said, adding that the democracy and progress of Taiwan were achieved with the sacrifice of life, youth, blood and sweat.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow TimesG Kazakh President Gets His Landslide
President Nursultan Nazarbayev's party won all available seats in Kazakhstan's new parliament in an election that international observers said Sunday was flawed but that still showed the oil-rich country was making progress toward becoming a democracy. [by Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG GPs given ultimatum to open at night and weekends
Family doctors have been warned that unless they agree to open at evenings and on Saturdays, private companies will be contracted to take over their practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua Magistrate orders no repeat of flooding

TEXT.P: Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan has ordered that there be no recurrence of flooding in the central county's Lukang, Fangyuan and Tacheng townships, warning that he will punish his subordinates if more flooding occurs.
Cho made the remarks Sunday during an inspection tour of the heavily flooded areas as a result of torrential rain brought by Typhoon Sepat.
Complaining to Cho that the areas are often flooded by heavy rain, residents said officials visited them several times without solving the problem.
To avoid serious flooding, many of the residents were forced to seek temporary shelter at their relatives' homes and public facilities.
In response, Cho ordered officials of the county's Water Resources Bureau and Public Works Bureau to propose solutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei fruit, vegetable prices up 20%-44% in wake of typhoon

TEXT.P: The wholesale prices of fruit and vegetables in Taipei have risen between 20 percent and 44 percent in the wake of Typhoon Sepat, Fair Trade Commission (FTC) officials said Monday.
The officials attributed the rise to the dual effects of reduced supply because of the typhoon and increased demand boosted by consumer expectations of price hikes.

According to the results of a survey conducted by the FTC at the Taipei Agricultural Product Marketing Co. -- the country's largest wholesale fruit and vegetable market at a consumer destination, 643 metric tons of vegetables were available Sunday, down 55 percent from 1,444 metric tons Saturday, with the average price surging 20 percent from NT$30.9 to NT$37 per kilogram.
The fruit supply was also down 59 percent from 851 metric tons Saturday to 345 metric tons Sunday, with the average price soaring 44 percent from NT$21 to NT$30.2 per kilogram.

Meanwhile, another survey at the wholesale fruit and vegetable market in Hsilo, Yunlin County -- the country's largest at a place of production -- indicates that the vegetable supply was down 86 percent from 631 metric tons Friday to 88 metric tons Sunday, with the average price rising 4.9 percent from NT$28.3 to NT$29.7 per kilogram.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers urged not to buy pirated goods

TEXT.P: The National Policy Agency (NPA) urged consumers Monday not to serve as accomplices of intellectual property rights (IPR) pirates by buying counterfeit products.

An NPA spokesman made the call after police cracked down on many forgery offenses around Taiwan over the past few weeks, seizing a wide range of counterfeit products including sports appliances and clothing carrying protected trademarks such as the "NY" logo of the New York Yankees.
Recently, a large amount of counterfeit new-season Timberland garments and boots appeared in night markets in southern Taiwan, sold at just 10 percent of the genuine article, the NPA spokesman said.
Even with intensive moves to crack down on counterfeiting, police have been unable to root out the crime, the NPA spokesman said, calling for "consumers' self-discipline."

The NPA launched a national anti-pirate operation in early August, in which police were mobilized to crack down on manufacturing, selling and smuggling of counterfeit goods in night markets, shopping centers, factories and warehouses around the country, as well as on the Internet.

During the operation, police cracked 339 cases of IPR violation, arresting 402 suspects and confiscating products valued at over NT$400 million (US$12.12 million) , according to the NPA's report on the mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't seeking consensus on use of animal drug: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Monday that government agencies should forge a consensus on the use of ractopamine -- an animal drug banned in Taiwan but used to promote lean meat in livestock in some countries -- and allay public concerns over its safety.
Chang made the comments in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan during an inspection of local pomelo orchards, where the crop was seriously damaged when Typhoon Sepat swept through the county Saturday.

A local newspaper reported Sunday that the Executive Yuan is likely to allow ractopamine-tainted foreign imports to enter the country while retaining a ban on its use by local hog raisers, prodding Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wei to clarify later the same day that the government has not yet arrived at a final decision on whether to lift the ban on the drug.

Saying that he personally has no set position on this question, Chang said that he has asked government agencies in charge of the issue, the Department of Health and the Council of Agriculture, to consult all parties concerned as soon as possible and build a consensus before coming to a final decision on whether or not to lift the ban.

The use of ractopamine became a social issue after two shipments of U.S. pork imports were detected to contain ractopamine residue last month, spurring anger from local farmers and health concerns from consumers who have vowed to take to the streets against an easing of the ban. The veterinary drug is not banned in the United States.
Meanwhile, pig farmers from across the country are set to demonstrate Tuesday in front of the DOH, the COA and the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC local cultural industry expo, workshop held in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 2007 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Local Cultural Industry Virtual Exposition, known as ALCIVE, and an APEC workshop on e-commerce opened in Taipei City Monday.

The event organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) at the Grand Hotel brought together representatives from APEC member economies including Japan, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, Peru, Mexico, Chile, Papua New Guinea, and Taiwan, as well as the Pacific Islands Forum, an observer in the regional economic organization.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen- shiang introduced the event as a key arena for APEC member-states to promote their local industries with unique cultural characters to the international market and conduct business exchanges with each other.
ALCIVE is a channel for the products previously marketed only in local markets to be sold internationally, Shih said.

Lai Sun-quae, director general of the MOEA Small and Medium Enterprise Administration, said local cultural industries exist in almost every APEC member, noting that assisting local industries in transforming themselves to arrive at sustainable operations, and building their e-commerce system to open the international market is an issue to which Taiwan and other APEC members attach great importance.

DOC.HEADLINE: No publication of permissible drug levels Tuesday: spokesman

TEXT.P: The government will not publish permissible levels of ractopamine residue in the meat and organs of pigs and cattle Tuesday as a national consensus on the issue has yet to be reached, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Monday.

Shieh made the remarks a day before the expiration of a period set by the Department of Health (DOH) for local people to express their opinions or opposition to proposed relaxation of a ban on ractopamine -- a veterinary drug used as a feed addictive to promote growth of lean meat in livestock.

Despite strong opposition from local pig farmers who are banned from using ractopamine, the DOH unveiled Aug. 14 possibly permissible ractopamine residue levels for meat and organs of pigs and cattle and said that the ban on the drug may be lifted if no opposition is expressed by Aug. 21.

Hog raisers from across the country have threatened to demonstrate in front of the DOH, the Council of Agriculture (COA) and the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) if the government fails to repeal the decision.

The use of ractopamine has become a focal point after two shipments of pork imported from the United States were found last month to contain residue of the banned drug, and local farmers accused the government of bowing to U.S. pressure by planning to allow the use of the drug, which is not banned in the United States and some other countries.
According to Shieh, the government will not necessarily legalize the permissible ractopamine residue levels upon the expiration of the deadline, despite the DOH's previous announcement.

Shieh cited food safety and health concerns, local hog raisers' interests, the DOH's and the COA's professional assessments and international regulations as key elements to be considered by the government before it makes a final decision on easing the ban.

Until the government has answered all the public's questions and clarified misconceptions surrounding ractopamine, the ban will not be relaxed, Shieh said, adding that the Executive Yuan will definitely prioritize the public's health when addressing relevant issues.
As hog farmers will also stage protests at the COA Tuesday, COA officials are prepared to meet them to exchange views and opinions, Shieh added.

Shieh said Sunday that the government remained undecided on whether to remove the ban on ractopamine after a local daily newspaper reported earlier that day that the Executive Yuan was likely to make a U-turn in its decision to lift the ban by retaining the ban on local farmers while allowing foreign imports containing ractopamine residue to enter the country -- described by local farmers as discriminatory "double dealing."

Even though Shieh said the government has yet to make a final decision on the issue, local pig-raising associations said that some 10,000 farmers from around the country have vowed to demonstrate as slated Tuesday in front of the DOH, the COA and the AIT against the government's softened stance.

As the deadline for airing different opinions is drawing near, the DOH said Monday that it is impossible for the government to adopt "dual tracks" to regulate ractopamine residue on local and foreign products.

Cheng Hui-wen, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, denied Monday the alleged "dual tracks" and said that the DOH will not move on its own to legalize ractopamine residue levels before the COA has officially announced a lifting of the ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largest ever pole-climbing folk event in Hengchun

TEXT.P: The 2007 Cianggu, a pole-climbing event that has been annually held during Ghost Month in the southern Taiwan township of Hengchun for over a century, will be the largest ever and enjoy the addition of some "international flavor," an official said Monday in a press conference.

The pole-climbing competition, in which competitors of each team have to climb barehanded up an 11-meter column, heavily greased with beef tallow, and snatch the "lucky flag" at the top, will be expanded from four columns to 36 columns, meaning that there will be 36 teams participating, including two teams of foreigners, said Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung.
The event will be held on the night of Aug. 27, the last day of a three-day festival which also includes various cultural events, such as a street dance competition, a parade, and rock concert.

Cianggu is one of the most popular folk Ghost Month events in Taiwan -- the seventh lunar month -- though in its human origins and background have always been well represented, said Tsao, who explained that the festival was held to distribute the offerings worshipers made to ghosts to society's homeless, poor and starving people.
In Taiwan, the annual religious event has put two small towns on the cultural map: Yilan County's Toucheng Township in the north and Hengchun, Pingtung County in the south.

"In the past, there were some foreigners in the competition, mixing in teams with the locals, in the past, but they never competed as a separate team, " Hengchun Mayor Yeh Ming-shun said, adding that a Thai team and a mixed team of Americans, Indonesians and Japanese had registered to compete this year.

The fastest team to climb to the top of the column and snatch the lucky flag from the top platform typically places the flag at the front end of their boat, symbolizing that they will enjoy the kindly protection of ghosts thorough the year, Tsao said.

With Hengchun's rich history, historical sites and cultural heritage, more events have been planned for the future, Tsao said. Pingtung County government is planning to hold an international folk song festival next year in Hengchun, where well-known late folk singer Chen Da lived.

Tsao believes the combination of the folk song festival, Cianggu and the Spring Scream, a rock festival held annually in April, will boost Hengchun's tourism and local business as well as its cultural awareness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-vice premier takes over as President Chen's chief of staff

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan was sworn in as President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff Monday, saying that she will do her utmost in what she described as an "unexpected" role.
Yeh made the remarks at a changeover ceremony presided over by Vice President Annette Lu.
Lauding Yeh as an outstanding female politician in Taiwan, Lu said she admired Yeh's courage in disclosing scandals and combating unlawful practices when Yeh was a lawmaker long ago.

Lu said that Yeh's distinguished political performance led her to many important posts, including minister of transportation and communications, head of the Council for Hakka Affairs, and acting mayor of Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second largest city.

Yeh is the first woman to assume the position of the top presidential aide, which Lu said is another start for her future career success, citing examples of Yeh's predecessors who later served as premier, vice premier, and chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Meanwhile, Lu praised the hard work of Presidential Office Deputy Secretary- General Cho Jung-tai, who had been serving as acting Presidential Office secretary-general since May.

Yeh, for her part, expressed her appreciation to President Chen and Lu, saying she is confident that she will serve the position well with the assistance of Cho and another Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai, two of her long-term friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan investigation team heads to Japan for CAL plane fire

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese investigative team left for the southern Japanese island of Okinawa Monday afternoon to join Japanese aviation experts in investigating the cause of an explosion of a Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) passenger jet plane earlier this month.
The team comprises CAL General-Manager Ringo Chao, officials from the Civil Aeronautics Administration, and the Cabinet-level Aviation Safety Council.

Before departure, Chao apologized to passengers for the accident, and expressed hope of minimumizing the damage from the event. He said CAL will ensure passengers' rights are respected and will provide a further explanation after having a better understanding of the event in Okinawa.
CAL's Boeing 737-800, flight CI-120 caught fire, starting in its left engine, shortly after landing at Okinawa's Naha international airport at 10:26 a.m. Monday.

All 157 passengers onboard, including 17 Japanese citizens and 24 other foreign nationals, were evacuated immediately after landing. Eight crew members managed to escape before fire engulfed the entire plane.
According to information provided by CAL, the exploded aircraft underwent its mandatory annual examination and maintenance in July, and nothing abnormal was found.

The plane also underwent its Routine Event -- a routine maintenance check that follows every 500 hours of flying time Aug. 4. The result appeared to be fine, and the aircraft had no record of a recent heavy landing.

All of CAL's 12 B737-800 aircraft, including the damaged one, are equipped with engines manufactured by the French company CFM International. Two engines on the exploded aircraft were examined as recently as July 6 and July 8, respectively, and the results showed nothing abnormal.

The investigative team left at 4: 25 p.m. on the China Airlines Airbus A333, together with a group of reporters and passengers set to travel to Okinawa. The aircraft will also carry returning passengers who traveled to Okinawa on the plane which exploded and now wish to return to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to enhance competitiveness of Kaohsiung Port

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved a plan Monday to inject NT$20.9 billion (US$633.52 million) over the next four years to improve the competitiveness of Kaohsiung Port.

The CEPD made the decision at regular a meeting of its members held to review the development plans of three ports on the west coast of Taiwan -- Kaohsiung, Anping, and Budai -- and Magong Port on the outlying island of Penghu.

Noting that Taipei Port in Taipei County's Wanli township is near completion, CEPD members said that after the new port becomes operational at the end of 2008, it is expected to cause Kaohsiung to lose 5 percent of its containers business, estimated at 500,000 TEUs (20-foot equivalent units).

Kaohsiung, Taiwan's largest port, was the world's third busiest container port in 1999, but gradually lost its competitive edge and dropped to sixth place in 2005, according to a survey by London-based Container International monthly.

The CEPD members expressed confidence that Kaohsiung harbor's annual container handling will not show negative growth after the CEPD spends NT$20.9 billion between 2007 and 2011 to renovate its wharves and improve its transport links in an attempt to boost its competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chief, lawmakers concerned over easing ban on animal drug

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun urged the government Monday to prioritize local consumers' concerns and hog farmers' interests when handling issues related to ractopamine -- an animal drug banned in Taiwan but used in some countries to promote the growth of lean meat in livestock.

In the face of growing social opposition to possible easing of the ban on the drug, allegedly to facilitate foreign imports, a group of DPP lawmakers urged the government during a news conference held in the Legislative Yuan not to remove the ban.
Two shipments of U.S. pork imports were found last month to contain the illegal substance, spurring public health concern and widespread discussion of the ractopamine issue.

DPP lawmakers from central and southern Taiwan have endorsed a petition calling on the government to retain the ban on both local and foreign products to fully ensure the public's health and protect local hog farmers' livelihoods.

DPP Legislator Wu Ming-min said the local pig-farming industry will crushed if ractopamine-containing foreign imports are allowed to enter the country, adding that Taiwan consumers' health would also be affected in such a case.

Another DPP lawmaker, Chen Hsien-chung, warned the government not to underestimate the impact of a demonstration Tuesday by thousands of hog farmers from across the country if it is set to relax the ban.

Yen Wen-chang, also a DPP lawmaker, said he strongly opposes a reported "dual track" solution -- allowing imports of ractopamine-containing foreign pork to enter Taiwan while banning local hog farmers from using the drug as a feed addictive -- to address the issue.
"Such a practice, if implemented, would be unfair to local farmers and could put consumers' health at great risk," Yen said.

Amid rampant speculation that the government may ease the ban to allow in ractopamine-tainted imports while retaining the ban on local farmers, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Sunday that the government has not yet reached a conclusion concerning the matter, citing considerations for the public's health, farmers' livelihoods and international regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan band praised by U.S. newspaper

TEXT.P: Taiwanese symphonic black metal band Chthonic, which is currently on a performance tour in North America, has earned kudos from the U.S. news media, musical industry sources said Monday.
Among others, the New York Times in its Aug. 18 music review of Ozzfest 2007 praised Chthonic as one of the "best acts" of the international concert event, the sources said.
Chthonic played in Ozzfest 2007 at the invitation of Ozzy Osbourne, the lead singer of the pioneering heavy metal band Black Sabbath.

Chthonic has performed at more than 30 concerts across the country over the past month, playing before hundreds of thousands of concert goers, and been interviewed by more than 70 media outlets, including the Washington Post, Los Angeles Times, and New York Times.

It has been warmly received by audiences since first performing in major cities on U.S. West Coast in early July. The band has also won praise from Randy Blythe, lead singer of the Lamb of God group, which won a Grammy Award nomination last year.

The band titled its American tour "UNlimited Taiwan " to promote Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, and to represent Taiwan's unlimited potential to the international community.
The band will give another 30 performances in cities on the east coast of North America, including New York, Washington, Detroit, Pittsburgh, Boston, Montreal, and Toronto.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors seek detention of 2 suspects in donation case

TEXT.P: Prosecution authorities have sought detention of two suspects in a political contribution case allegedly involving Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate, judicial sources said Monday.

Prosecutors from the Special Investigation Task Force under the Supreme Prosecutors Office applied for detention of Hsu Cheng-chao and Hsiao Ling-hui after questioning them in probes into the case in which Hsieh was accused of having embezzled nearly NT$10 million in political contributions to line his own pocket during his tenure as mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Hsu, president of the Kaohsiung Development Association, and Hsiao, the association's accountant, were suspected of having collected funds from board members of the municipal Bank of Kaohsiung in the name of Hsieh back in 2002 when Hsieh was seeking re-election.
Hsu and Hsiao allegedly had also asked hopefuls for seats on the bank's board of directors to donate NT$1 million each as political contribution to Hsieh.
They were first questioned as witnesses, but prosecutors later listed them as suspects on charges of corruption, forgery and money laundering.
But prosecutors said they have so far not yet found any evidence showing Hsieh's involvement in the case.

Three prosecutors from the Special Investigation Task Force -- Chu Chao-liang, Wu Wen-chung and Lee Hai-lung -- traveled to Kaohsiung Monday morning to interrogate seven witnesses in the case. Except for Hsu and Hsiao, all the five others were released after questioning.
The three prosecutors said they will expand investigations into bank accounts of relevant personnel, but they didn't elaborate.
The Kaohsiung District Court has yet to determine whether the two suspects -- Hsu and Hsiao -- should be taken into custody pending further investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan investigation team heads to Japan for CAL plane fire

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese investigative team left for the southern Japanese island of Okinawa Monday afternoon to join Japanese aviation experts in investigating the cause of an explosion of a Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) passenger jet plane earlier this month.
The team comprises CAL General-Manager Ringo Chao, officials from the Civil Aeronautics Administration, and the Cabinet-level Aviation Safety Council.

Before departure, Chao apologized to passengers for the accident, and expressed hope of minimumizing the damage from the event. He said CAL will ensure passengers' rights are respected and will provide a further explanation after having a better understanding of the event in Okinawa.
CAL's Boeing 737-800, flight CI-120 caught fire, starting in its left engine, shortly after landing at Okinawa's Naha international airport at 10:26 a.m. Monday.

All 157 passengers onboard, including 17 Japanese citizens and 24 other foreign nationals, were evacuated immediately after landing. Eight crew members managed to escape before fire engulfed the entire plane.
According to information provided by CAL, the exploded aircraft underwent its mandatory annual examination and maintenance in July, and nothing abnormal was found.

The plane also underwent its Routine Event -- a routine maintenance check that follows every 500 hours of flying time Aug. 4. The result appeared to be fine, and the aircraft had no record of a recent heavy landing.

All of CAL's 12 B737-800 aircraft, including the damaged one, are equipped with engines manufactured by the French company CFM International. Two engines on the exploded aircraft were examined as recently as July 6 and July 8, respectively, and the results showed nothing abnormal.

The investigative team left at 4: 25 p.m. on the China Airlines Airbus A333, together with a group of reporters and passengers set to travel to Okinawa. The aircraft will also carry returning passengers who traveled to Okinawa on the plane which exploded and now wish to return to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to enhance competitiveness of Kaohsiung Port

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved a plan Monday to inject NT$20.9 billion (US$633.52 million) over the next four years to improve the competitiveness of Kaohsiung Port.

The CEPD made the decision at regular a meeting of its members held to review the development plans of three ports on the west coast of Taiwan -- Kaohsiung, Anping, and Budai -- and Magong Port on the outlying island of Penghu.

Noting that Taipei Port in Taipei County's Wanli township is near completion, CEPD members said that after the new port becomes operational at the end of 2008, it is expected to cause Kaohsiung to lose 5 percent of its containers business, estimated at 500,000 TEUs (20-foot equivalent units).

Kaohsiung, Taiwan's largest port, was the world's third busiest container port in 1999, but gradually lost its competitive edge and dropped to sixth place in 2005, according to a survey by London-based Container International monthly.

The CEPD members expressed confidence that Kaohsiung harbor's annual container handling will not show negative growth after the CEPD spends NT$20.9 billion between 2007 and 2011 to renovate its wharves and improve its transport links in an attempt to boost its competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chief, lawmakers concerned over easing ban on animal drug

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun urged the government Monday to prioritize local consumers' concerns and hog farmers' interests when handling issues related to ractopamine -- an animal drug banned in Taiwan but used in some countries to promote the growth of lean meat in livestock.

In the face of growing social opposition to possible easing of the ban on the drug, allegedly to facilitate foreign imports, a group of DPP lawmakers urged the government during a news conference held in the Legislative Yuan not to remove the ban.
Two shipments of U.S. pork imports were found last month to contain the illegal substance, spurring public health concern and widespread discussion of the ractopamine issue.

DPP lawmakers from central and southern Taiwan have endorsed a petition calling on the government to retain the ban on both local and foreign products to fully ensure the public's health and protect local hog farmers' livelihoods.

DPP Legislator Wu Ming-min said the local pig-farming industry will crushed if ractopamine-containing foreign imports are allowed to enter the country, adding that Taiwan consumers' health would also be affected in such a case.

Another DPP lawmaker, Chen Hsien-chung, warned the government not to underestimate the impact of a demonstration Tuesday by thousands of hog farmers from across the country if it is set to relax the ban.

Yen Wen-chang, also a DPP lawmaker, said he strongly opposes a reported "dual track" solution -- allowing imports of ractopamine-containing foreign pork to enter Taiwan while banning local hog farmers from using the drug as a feed addictive -- to address the issue.
"Such a practice, if implemented, would be unfair to local farmers and could put consumers' health at great risk," Yen said.

Amid rampant speculation that the government may ease the ban to allow in ractopamine-tainted imports while retaining the ban on local farmers, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Sunday that the government has not yet reached a conclusion concerning the matter, citing considerations for the public's health, farmers' livelihoods and international regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan band praised by U.S. newspaper

TEXT.P: Taiwanese symphonic black metal band Chthonic, which is currently on a performance tour in North America, has earned kudos from the U.S. news media, musical industry sources said Monday.
Among others, the New York Times in its Aug. 18 music review of Ozzfest 2007 praised Chthonic as one of the "best acts" of the international concert event, the sources said.
Chthonic played in Ozzfest 2007 at the invitation of Ozzy Osbourne, the lead singer of the pioneering heavy metal band Black Sabbath.

Chthonic has performed at more than 30 concerts across the country over the past month, playing before hundreds of thousands of concert goers, and been interviewed by more than 70 media outlets, including the Washington Post, Los Angeles Times, and New York Times.

It has been warmly received by audiences since first performing in major cities on U.S. West Coast in early July. The band has also won praise from Randy Blythe, lead singer of the Lamb of God group, which won a Grammy Award nomination last year.

The band titled its American tour "UNlimited Taiwan " to promote Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, and to represent Taiwan's unlimited potential to the international community.
The band will give another 30 performances in cities on the east coast of North America, including New York, Washington, Detroit, Pittsburgh, Boston, Montreal, and Toronto.
