DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 21, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal- gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: Republic of China Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: A massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes in Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian Parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of a coup attempt by hardliners.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
1999: Over 96 percent of the Kuomintang's party delegates vote to support Vice President Lien Chan as the party's candidate in the following spring's presidential election.
2000: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui proposes the establishment of an Asian monetary fund to promote economic cooperation in Asia.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his Gambian counterpart Yahya Jammeh sign a joint communique pledging to continue enhancing close cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterates while meeting with visiting Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli that the ROC government will abide by the memorandum of trade and investment signed by the ROC and Paraguay to further cement the established ties between Taipei and Asuncion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."

DOC.HEADLINE: President departs for Central America visit

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian departed Tuesday for a three-nation visit to Central America, during which he will take part in the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the region to be held in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa.
With a brief stopover in the U.S. state of Alaska, Chen is scheduled to arrive in Honduras Aug. 21 for a three-day visit.

The national leaders who are expected to take part in the Taiwan-Central America leadership summit include Belizean Prime Minister Said Musa, Guatemalan President Oscar Berger, Salvadoran President Antonio Saca, Honduran President Manuel Zelaya, Panamanian President Martin Torrijos, Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Morales and Dominican Republic Vice President Rafael Alburquerque.

Also during the president's visit in Honduras, the two countries will sign a memorandum under which Taiwan will provide a US$5 million loan in support of the Central American country's national computerization project, according to Republic of China Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Javier Ching-shan Hou.
On Aug. 24, Chen will head to El Salvador for a three-day visit before traveling on to Nicaragua Aug. 26.
The president is set to conclude his trip Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska. He is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Aug. 29.

Chen's delegation is comprised of a total of 88 members, including Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Liao Pen-yen, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislators Hsieh Hsin-ni and Tang Pi-o, Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce Chairman Theodore M.H. Huang, and Taiwan External Trade Development Council Chairman C.J. Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum plan, U.S. transit stops should not be linked: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Tuesday his resolve to safeguard the Taiwan people's right to hold a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations.

Chen rejected a suggestion that he give up the referendum in exchange for better treatment on his planned transit stops in the United States, saying the two issues should not be linked or traded off against each other.
Chen made the remarks before his departure for a three-nation visit to Central America, which will include brief stopovers in the U.S. state of Alaska en route to and from the region.

Washington has reportedly refused to allow Chen to set foot in the continental United States or stay overnight during the transit stops as a way of expressing its displeasure with Taiwan's plan to push for a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan."

Chen said that although Taiwan and the United States have maintained a longstanding friendship and are strategic partners sharing the common values of freedom and democracy, the two countries do not always see eye to eye on every issue because of their different national interest concerns.

Chen said Taiwan will continue to communicate with the U.S. side to try to sort out their differences on the referendum issue, adding that he does not want the issue to complicate his U.S. transit plan and blur the focus of his Central America visit.
According to Chen, the holding of referendums is a basic human right that not even the head of state is allowed to block or restrict.
As a sovereign country, Taiwan has the right to participate in the international community, he added.

"Taiwan not only must fight for international recognition and respect for the country's sovereign status but also let the world hear the Taiwan people's strong desire to become a full member of the World Health Organization and the United Nations," Chen said.

Pointing out that China's diplomatic suppression of Taiwan has extended even to non-political fields such as sporting events, the president urged the opposition parties to give up what he called their "wishful thinking" that Taiwan could find a way out of the current impasse by accepting the so-called "1992 consensus."

According to Chen, accepting the "1992 consensus" would mean accepting Beijing's "one China" principle and recognizing Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China, and by doing so, Taiwan would "lead itself up another blind alley."

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 36.52 points to close at 8,479.08.
The bourse opened at 8,542.13 and fluctuated between 8,586.73 and 8,424.01 during trading. A total of 4.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$138.83 billion (US$4.22 billion).
Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up 0.5 percent, and cement stocks, plastics and chemicals shares and textile stocks all increasing 0.4 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent, and machinery and electronics shares and construction issues both at 0.6 percent.
Losers numbered more than 1,000 against 457 gainers, with 170 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses rise to NT$1.52 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses resulting from the recent string of storms, and Typhoon Sepat in particular, have risen to NT$1.52 billion, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Council of Agriculture.
That amount includes more than NT$1.24 billion in damage to crops on 23,811 hectares, or 27 percent, of the country's farmland and the complete loss of crops on 6,377 hectares.
The hardest hit crops include pomelos, bananas, watermelons, muskmelons, pineapples, guavas, pears, papayas, custard apples and leafy vegetables.
Livestock and poultry damage comes to NT$92.99 million, due in part to the deaths of 3,537 pigs, 743,000 chickens, 269,000 ducks and 58,000 geese.
Fishery damage amounts to NT$71.76 million, with 142.65 hectares of fish ponds flooded.
Forestry damage stands at NT$40.44 million, affecting 239.45 hectares of woodland, 148.2 hectares of seedlings and 5.73 hectares of plant nurseries.
Damage to agricultural facilities currently amounts to NT$69.29 million.
Meanwhile, vegetable supplies at Taipei Agricultural Product Marketing Co. increased to 1,174 metric tons Tuesday, with the average price dropping from NT$37 per kilogram Monday to NT$30.91.

DOC.HEADLINE: Black boxes of burnt CAL plane recovered
DOC.DATELINE: Okinawa, Japan, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/07 16:47:56 (By Liu Teh-chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Japanese and Taiwanese investigators Tuesday recovered the two black boxes belonging to a Taiwan-based China Airlines aircraft that caught fire upon landing at Naha Airport on the Japanese island of Okinawa a day earlier.

According to members of a rail and air accident inquiry committee under Japan's Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport, a preliminary reading of the flight data recorder has been completed, but no details will be made public until the data is sent back to Tokyo for further analysis.
The cockpit voice recorder, on the other hand, is still being read by experts, the committee members said.

The Boeing 737-800 passenger jet from Taipei caught fire shortly after landing at Naha Airport Monday morning, with all 157 passengers and eight crew members aboard the plane managing to escape before the left engine exploded and sent the fire spreading.
Investigators from the Japanese inquiry committee and China Airlines were looking into the destroyed aircraft Tuesday to try to determine possible causes of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government has no set position on animal drug use: premier

TEXT.P: The government has no set position or any timetable for resolving the controversy over the use of ractopamine -- an animal drug banned in Taiwan but used in some countries to promote the growth of lean meat in livestock, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.

Chang made the remarks while answering reporters' questions on the issue after thousands of pig farmers from across the country demonstrated earlier the same day in front of the Department of Health (DOH) against a possible easing of the ban on the use of the drug.

Asserting that the government is doing its best to properly handle the issue, Chang said he has instructed Vice Premier Chiou I-jen to coordinate the work of relevant government agencies seeking to forge a consensus through extensive consultations with concerned parties.

Although the drug remains banned in Taiwan, the DOH made public Aug. 14 permissible ractopamine residue levels for meat and different organs in pigs and cattle and said that these new guidelines would take effect by the end of this month at the earliest if no opposition were voiced by Aug. 21.
Local hog farmers said that they are firmly opposed to the government lifting the ban on the use of ractopamine under strong foreign pressure.

Many farmers believe that the DOH's announcement of new standards for ractopamine residue levels is a scheme to clear the way for foreign imports after two shipments of pork imported from the United States were found last month to contain the substance.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE to provide funds to schools to set up LOHAS sports centers

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) plans to provide NT$270 million (US$8.18 million) over three years to set up 450 sports centers on campuses around the country in an effort to encourage students to exercise regularly and help them cultivate lifestyles of health and sustainability (LOHAS), an MOE official said Tuesday.

Chien Ming-chung, director of the MOE Department of Physical Education, said as sports facilities have been lacking at all levels of schools nationwide, particularly indoor exercise facilities, with only 18 percent of schools equipped with such facilities, the MOE has decided to launch the program in collaboration with local governments to help solve the problem.

This year, the MOE will provide funds for 50 elementary and junior high schools to set up LOHAS exercise centers, Chien said, adding that any school with more than 12 classes, 300 students and two or three spare rooms is eligible to apply for funding.
The first LOHAS sports centers set up under the program are expected to open in December, he said.
Over the next two years, the program will be expanded to cover senior high schools and vocational high schools, with NT$600,000 in funds to be provided for each facility to be set up, he noted.

He said the main appeal of the program is that it makes the most of spare space on campuses, develops schools' creativity and special characteristics, aims to set up diversified and attractive exercise facilities, and promotes healthy exercise habits.

Under the initial plan, the LOHAS sports centers will be furnished with an array of popular indoor exercise equipment, such as dance machines, trampolines, batting cages and climbing facilities, to spur interest in exercise among young people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung county on alert for dengue fever outbreak

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County officials responsible for health and environmental protection affairs were mobilized Tuesday for an urgent undertaking aimed at preventing an outbreak of dengue fever.

County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsiung ordered officials to reinforce efforts to cleanse mosquito-breeding sites after the southern county reported last week its first indigenous dengue fever case this summer.

The patient, a woman aged over 50, resides in the county's Fengshan City but works in the neighboring city of Kaohsiung, County Director of Health Huang Chih-chung said, noting that Kaohsiung City is one of southern Taiwan's dengue- affected areas, with 52 cases of indigenous dengue fever reported so far since the beginning of the summer.
Tainan City is the area hardest hit by the mosquito-born disease, with 230 cases indigenous dengue fever reported so far this summer. Tainan County has reported 17 cases, according to Huang.

Huang said it is worrisome that there has been no sign of taming the outbreaks in neighboring areas, and that the density of disease-carrying mosquitoes has reached alert-triggering levels in and around the county since repeated storms brought heavy downpours over the past few weeks.

To prevent a major outbreak, the county government has decided that whenever there is a suspicious case reported it will be treated as a confirmed case and the county will activate at once its standard anti-pest procedures, including expanded probes into the disease source.

Dengue fever, a viral illness, is manifested by the sudden onset of fever, severe headache, muscle and joint pains, and skin rash. The classic dengue fever lasts about six to seven days, with a smaller peak of fever at the trailing end of the fever. It can be deadly when the patient is infected by the hemorrhagic dengue fever.

DOC.HEADLINE: All Boeing 737-800s in Taiwan to undergo special inspection

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) ordered Tuesday that all Taiwanese carrier-owned Boeing 737-800 aircraft -- the same model as the one that burned to a hulk at Okinawa's Naha International Airport Monday -- must undergo a special inspection to ensure their safety.

CAA officials said it would take about two days to complete the inspection, which became necessary after a Boeing 737-800 jetliner owned by Taipei-based China Airlines caught fire and exploded after landing at Naha Airport, giving its 157 passengers and eight crew members a close call.
According to the officials, the special inspection will cover more than 20 items, including the fuel system, pumps and airworthiness directives.
Currently there are 14 Boeing 737-800s still in service in Taiwan, including 11 owned by China Airlines and two owned by its subsidiary Mandarin Airlines, a domestic carrier.

The other Boeing 737-800 is Air Force One, which is undergoing regular maintenance. An Air Force Command spokesman said the aircraft will be subjected to a thorough inspection at the request of the CAA.

Initial reports from Japanese ground personnel at Naha Airport showed that a fuel leak from the right engine of China Airlines' flight CI-120 could have caused a fire and led to a series of explosions.
Fortunately, all passengers and crew members escaped in a nick of time, with the last passengers exiting just before flames and explosions engulfed the entire fuselage.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL presents cash gift to passengers aboard exploded airplane
DOC.DATELINE: Okinawa, Japan, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/21/07 17:59:24 (By Liu Teh-tsang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) General-Manager Ringo Chao presented US$100 in red envelopes to each of the passengers aboard the jet plane that caught fire and exploded after landing at Okinawa's Naha international airport in Japan Monday, in an effort to allay their fears.
All 157 of the passengers and eight crew members on board CAL's Boeing 737-800, flight CI-120, managed to escape before fire engulfed the entire aircraft.

Chao arrived in Okinawa with officials from the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the Cabinet-level Aviation Safety Council that same day to help Japanese aviation experts with their investigation into the cause of the fire.

Accompanied by staff members of CAL's branch in Japan, Chao went to three hotels on the southern Japanese island of Okinawa, to present red envelopes to passengers who escaped the ill-fated aircraft. He also offered another US$87 to each passenger to help cover their daily expenditures during their stay in Okinawa.
The investigation by Japanese aviation experts has caused physical fatigue and travel delays for many passengers, but nonetheless they went met Chao in the hotel's lobby at 10 p.m. local time.

Chao apologized to passengers for the accident and said the cash gift is to demonstrate the sincerity and determination of CAL to make available favorable terms of compensation for their luggage losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign diplomats help promote Taiwan pineapple cakes at festival

TEXT.P: Several foreign diplomats stationed in Taiwan as well as a number of foreign baseball players helped promote Taiwan pineapple cakes at a festival named after the snack food held in Taipei Tuesday.

Diplomats from the Mexican Trade Services, Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, and the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office, as well as foreign baseball players from the Taipei-based China Trust Whales attended the ceremony held at Taipei Vocational Training Center under the Taipei city government's Department of Labor.

The activity formed part of the Taipei Pineapple Cake Festival, now in its second year. Boosted by last year's warm response from the public, the Taipei city government has decided to hold a pineapple cake competition Aug. 27-28 to encourage entrepreneurs to present the most creative pineapple cakes.

Felipe Lopez, deputy director of the Mexican Trade Services' documentation and cultural section, who was present at the event, said he tried Taiwan pineapples and mangos after arriving in the country last year to assume his post and found the local fruit to be very tasty. At the event, Lopez enthusiastically learned how to make pineapple cakes.
Jorge Reyes, a section chief of Mexican Trade Services, who has been living in Taiwan for many years, said he always gives pineapple cakes as gifts to visiting friends.

Officials from the Taipei city government said that as pineapple cake sales rose significantly after last year's festival, they will further encourage local cake makers to present flavors that also cater to overseas consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: People urged to refrain from collecting driftwood without permission

TEXT.P: The Hualien Forest District Office (HFDC) warned people not to collect driftwood at the seaside along the coast of Hualien in eastern Taiwan before the local government makes public official permission for its collection.
A HFDC spokesman voiced the warning Tuesday, reiterating that it is against the Criminal Code to collect driftwood without permission, and that violators may be charged with theft.
An avalanche of driftwood has appeared on Haulien's beaches since Typhoon Sepat swept across the island last weekend.

The drift wood is composed for the most part of branches and fallen trees brought down by strong typhoon winds in the Hualien mountains and washed out by rivers in flood, the HFDC spokesman said, noting some of the wood is valuable Taiwan Red Cypress and Taiwan Yellow Cypress logs.
A red or yellow cypress log can sometimes be sold for hundreds of thousands New Taiwan dollars, the spokesman said.
According to HFDC, valuable driftwood will be identified and shipped to a safe place for storage before being publicly offered for sale at the invitation of the Hualien county government.
People will not be allowed to collect other "worthless" driftwood until the local government issues public permission for a month-long period of free collection, HFDC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hornet sting deflates woman's breast implant

TEXT.P: Women with breast implants beware: a single hornet sting might ruin your figure, a plastic surgeon in Miaoli City, Central Taiwan warned Tuesday.

Dr. Tseng Ting-chang said a 31-year-old woman who received breast implants three years ago visited his clinic early this week complaining that one of her breast had deflated after a hornet sting a couple of days before.
The woman said the incident took place while she was riding a scooter in the countryside while wearing low-cut dress.
She took the sting in stride at first, but later was astonished to find a that one of her breasts had shrunk a couple of days later.
Dr. Tseng said he found saline from the woman's breast implant had leaked, apparently due to the hornet sting.
He said the woman had to undergo a surgery to reconstruct her breast.

Noting that the woman is quite skinny and has little fat tissue under her skin, the doctor said it is possible that the hornet's sting could have pierced the saline-filled sack, which is touted as being able to withstand pressures of up to 200 kilograms per square centimeter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military aids displaced villagers in Pingtung County

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will allow some 300 southern Taiwan villagers displaced by Typhoon Sepat last week to be quartered temporarily in disused army barracks in Pingtung County, a senior MND official said Tuesday.

Maj. Gen. Huang Sung, head of the engineering division of the Bureau of Armament and Acquisition, told reporters that officials from the MND and the Pingtung county government had inspected the Ailiao barracks and will make necessary preparations before more than 100 households move into the military housing.

Huang said his division had dispatched 50 soldiers to clean up the 19 buildings in the 3.7-hectare military base and that the Pingtung county government will have water and electricity supplies laid on in three days.
He added that the displaced villagers can live in the army barracks until they have rebuilt their homes, which will take about 18 months with the assistance of the Pingtung county government.
The 300-odd people who lost their homes are from Haocha and Machia villages, which were devastated by mudflows caused by torrential rain brought by Typhoon Sepat.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to invest NT$20 billion in Kaohsiung Port upgrade

TEXT.P: The government will spend NT$20.9 billion (US$633.53 million) improving facilities at Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan to enhance its competitiveness in anticipation of possible impact of the inauguration of Taipei Port's cargo dock late next year, an official said Tuesday.

The official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that the investment in Kaohsiung Port will be used to improve its connecting transportation systems and reconstruct its old wharves between now and 2011, with the aim of bringing further developments to the port.

Kaohsiung Port is expected to lose 5 percent of its export cargo business, which is about 500,000 TEU, after Taipei Port's cargo dock begins operations at the end of 2008, the official said, adding that some of Kaohsiung Port's business of transit cargo might be transferred to Taipei Port due to adjustments in shipping routes.

According to the official, ever-smaller information technology products have affected the volume of cargo handled at Kaohsiung Port, which has registered only single digit growth rate over the past five years. It is hoped that the government's investment will prevent the port from losing more business and ensure its future development.

The official went on that the project was based on the Executive Yuan's requirement that the operations of Taiwan's harbors be thoroughly reviewed every five years as these tend to be affected by changes in both the economy and the depreciation of facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's investment in China up 22.52%

TEXT.P: The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) approved 593 applications for investment in China during the first seven months of this year, amounting to US$4.83 billion, or a year-on-year rise of 22.52 percent, according to tallies released by the commission Tuesday.

The tallies also show that the commission approved a total of 1,233 applications for direct foreign investment in Taiwan during the January-July period, for a total worth of US$7.17 billion, down 13.99 percent from the same period of last year.

However, if Philips Taiwan's sale last year of its Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) shares to its parent -- Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands -- is excluded, then direct foreign investment in Taiwan would have grown 56.14 percent from the year-earlier level, the tallies state.

In addition, 285 outbound investment cases were reported to the commission during the first seven months of this year, worth a combined US$1.96 billion, down 11.76 percent from last year, the tallies indicate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan suffers balance of payments deficit in Q2: CBC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's balance of payments for international transactions registered a rare deficit of US$1.89 billion in the second quarter of this year, the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Tuesday.
Taiwan last registered an international payment deficit in the third quarter of 2004, when US$1.49 billion was reported, a CBC official said.

Noting that the total payment deficit during the first half of this year reached US$1.52 billion, the official attributed the deficit mainly to massive overseas securities investments of US$28.17 billion made by local citizens.

Due to a large interest rate difference between the new Taiwan dollar and the U.S. dollar, Taiwanese people, local investment institutions and insurance companies prefer to invest outside Taiwan, the official explained.
The official added that local citizens invested US$17.21 billion in foreign stocks and bonds during the second quarter of this year, setting the highest- ever single-quarter record.
The country suffered the biggest-ever payment deficit of US$6.88 billion in the second quarter of 1990, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's English proficiency lags behind Asian countries

TEXT.P: Statistics drawn from Britain's IELTS (International English Language Testing System) average scores show that the English proficiency of Taiwanese students lags behind that of most Asian countries, and Taiwanese are encouraged to do more to learn English, the British Council said Tuesday.

The average score of Taiwanese students in the 2006 academic module of IELTS, which has a top score of nine, was 5.62 points, ranking 17th overall and lagging behind Asian countries including Japan, Korea, Vietnam and Thailand, said Iain Mackie, Director of British Council's English Language Services.

Germany ranked first among 20 countries listed, scoring 7.23. Malaysia, the Philippines, Russia and Hong Kong rounded out the top five. Indonesia, Japan, Vietnam, Korea, Pakistan and Thailand ranked 11th to 16th.

"It's a little bit sad to say this but, in my opinion, the overall English proficiency of Taiwan's working class has been going down in recent years. The regression was probably a result of the booming numbers of universities, which means it's much easier to obtain a college degree, " said Monica Chiu, Marketing Director of 104 Job Bank.
The average score of 5.62 actually was not bad. It's enough for Taiwanese students to attend most universities in the U.K., said Mackie.

But Mackie noted that most English teaching programs in Taiwan do not encourage independent thinking, and most teaching materials are irrelevant to the real world. He also said that most programs stress test taking instead of actually using English to communicate.

"According to our statistics, about 45 to 50 out of 100 job offers required basic English proficiency and communication skills, which means anyone who is competent in English will have twice as many job offers, " Chiu said.
"English proficiency is also important for those who want to climb the corporate ladder and win a promotion. Competency has become a basic requirement rather than an advantage, " she noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Large dengue fever cluster infection reported in Tainan: DOH

TEXT.P: Another 89 cases of dengue fever were reported around Taiwan last week, including 44 cases involving residents in a veterans' home in Tainan City's East District, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Tuesday.
Chou Chih-hau, deputy director-general of the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC), said the cluster infection in Tainan was the largest in nearly 10 years.

The first case of the cluster infection was reported Aug. 8, followed by more cases Aug. 13 and 14. Tainan City's Health Bureau and the CDC then started examinations of residents and inspected the environment around the veterans' home, which houses more than 400 veterans in their 70s or 80s.
The CDC discovered that 44 residents were infected with dengue fever and found that drains on the roof and water reservoirs of the facility's air conditioners were the main mosquito breeding areas.

Chou said elderly people infected with dengue fever do not show obvious symptoms of rash and high fever of up to 39 degree Celsius. He reminded nursing houses to heed the situation and clean water storage containers around residences to avoid another cluster infection.

Chou said the North District of Tainan City also reported its second indigenous dengue fever case -- a two-year-old girl who was diagnosed with the disease Aug. 6. She was discharged from the hospital Aug. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: Service sector output accounts for 72.46% of GDP: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's service sector accounted for 72.46 percent of GDP during the first quarter of this year, showing growth of 1.67 percentage points over the 2004 figure, government officials said Tuesday.
According to a report published by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , the figure also represented an increase of 3.53 percentage points over the 2000 figure.

Responding to the report regarding various flagship programs of Taiwan's service sector, officials attributed the growth in output to the efficient implementation of many projects and the government's having amended laws to facilitate foreign investment in the service sector.

For example, officials pointed to an amended law approved earlier this year will allow foreign financial institutions to merge local banking organizations through setting up subsidiaries in Taiwan, which officials said will facilitate both the merger of financial institutions and financial globalization.

On the service sector in telecommunications and media, officials noted that 5.66 million families around Taiwan had access to broadband Internet as of June this year, while nearly 64.85 percent of Taiwanese families have Internet access.

Regarding the design industry, a total of 315 local design products were submitted to major design competitions around the world in the first half of this year, with 39 products winning Germany's iF design awards and 33 gaining red dot design awards, again in Germany, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan man fined NT$50,000 for eating his pet dog

TEXT.P: A man in Tainan City was fined NT$50,000 (US$1,515) Tuesday for killing and eating his pet dog.
The man in his seventies was identified by the surname Su. Neighbors reported to police last week that he had slaughtered his own dog and shared the cooked meat with his family.
Investigators from the Tainan City Animal Health Inspection and Quarantine Institute questioned Su, who admitted that he killed the dog on the grounds that the pet was in heat and "too noisy."
The man, who was described as "remorseful," received the minimum fine of NT$50,000 and was warned not to commit the same offense again.

According to the Animal Protection Law amended in 2003, anyone who kills a dog can be fined from NT$50,000 to NT$250,000 and repeat offenders shall be fined according to the frequency of the violation.

DOC.HEADLINE: More funds earmarked to set up computer centers in remote schools

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will invest an additional NT$80 million (US$2.43 million) in setting up 76 computer centers at elementary and junior high schools in remote areas in an effort to reduce the digital divide between urban and rural areas, an MOE official said Tuesday.

Yang Cheng-hung, director of the MOE's computer center, said the ministry will subsidize junior high and elementary schools located in remote areas to establish "digital opportunity centers" to boost e-learning among students and villagers, mostly aboriginal people.
The MOE has since 2005 set up 61 such centers in schools in remote villages and aims to increase the number to 120 by the end of this year, Yang added.
According to Yang, the centers have borne fruit in many areas.

For example, he went on, several villagers in mountainous areas have learned how to grow coffee and become bed and breakfast operators through the centers, while many others have learned how to promote local specialty products through the Internet.
According to MOE officials, the computer center set up at the Shangfeng Elementary School in Yunlin County in southern Taiwan has become a popular cyber cafe.

Chen Chun-shih, principal of Nan-Jung Junior High School in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, said the establishment of the digital opportunity centers has strengthened exchanges between urban and rural areas, offers a good e-learning environment and has created numerous trade opportunities for villagers living in remote areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL offers blaze flight passengers more compensation

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) decided Tuesday to increase the compensation for passengers aboard the plane that caught fire at a Japanese airport the previous, for "psychological damage," CAL spokesman Sun Hung-wen said Tuesday.

The amount of compensation is being raised from 10,000 Japanese yen (US$87) to 25,000 yen after the company presented US$100 to each the passenger as a "cash gift" when it made a public apology for the accident, according to Sun.
In addition to the compensation, CAL will also reimburse the passengers' expenditure for buying "reasonable" necessities for daily use during their remaining journey in Japan, Sun said.

The Boeing 737-800 passenger jet from Taipei caught fire shortly after landing at Naha Airport Monday morning. All 157 passengers and eight crew members aboard the plane managed to escape before the left engine exploded and gutted the plane.
All the luggage aboard the plane was destroyed in the blaze and CAL announced hours after the accident that it would pay compensation of NT$1,000 per kilogram of luggage to a maximum of NT$20,000.
The passengers included 110 Taiwanese travelers, 23 Japanese citizens and 24 people from other counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH, COA agree to retain ban on animal drug

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) and the Council of Agriculture (COA) agreed Tuesday to retain a ban on ractopamine -- an animal drug to promote the growth of lean meat in livestock that is banned in Taiwan but lawful in some countries -- following protests by local pig farmers in front of the two agencies.

DOH Minister Hou Sheng-mou signed a pledge agreeing to retain the ban on the animal drug and promising that the DOH will not allow ractopamine-tainted foreign imports to enter the county before the law is amended, and that it will not unilaterally ease the ban but rather act in concert with the Council of Agriculture (COA).
Hou inked his name in the pledge after thousands of hog farmers demonstrated in front of the DOH against a possible lifting of the ban by the government.

Some 1,000 pig farmers from across the country later proceeded to the COA, where Vice Minister Hu Fu-hsiung, witnessed by representatives from local hog-raising associations and lawmakers, also made a pledge on behalf of COA Minister Su Jia- chyuan, promising that the COA will maintain the ban on the veterinary drug.
Farmers dropped their plan to protest in front of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan after obtaining assurances from the DOH and the COA.

Pan Lien-chou, chairman of the national pig-farming association, told a news conference at the Legislative Yuan later the same day that all livestock farmers across the country will take to the streets again if the government is found to permit foreign imports with ractopamine residue to enter the local market.

Angry hog farmers from central and southern regions got together in Taipei to protest a possible relaxation of the ban on ractopamine by the government after two shipments of U.S. pork imports were found to contain the substance last month. A limited use of the animal drug is lawful in the United States and Japan, while it is banned in more than 160 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-independence groups urge DPP candidate to elucidate stance

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh should "do the right thing in making himself clear on the position and prospects of the country," a coalition of pro-Taiwan independence groups said Tuesday at a press conference.

The coalition also submitted its own action plan for Taiwan's normalization as a country Tuesday before the DPP Central Executive Committee begins to screen a "normal country" resolution this week. It calls for Hsieh to make his position clear to voters on the resolution.

"A great statesman should follow the example of former Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, who insisted on `doing the right thing, '" said Taiwan Society North Vice President Michelle Wang, who spoke on behalf of the coalition.
What the coalition feels is the "right thing" for Hsieh to do, Wang explained, is to make Taiwan a normal country, a topic Hsieh has been reluctant to elaborate on.

The content of the action plan is little different to the DPP's "normal country" resolution, which includes the basic objectives of changing the country's name, writing a new constitution, establishing a normal country and joining the United Nations, she said, although she claimed it is the "voice of the people."

The DPP election ticket "symbolizes the successful integration of the DPP's internal factions, but we have not seen anything from the DPP that can touch the voters, " claimed Hsu Yung-ming, a research fellow at Academia Sinica and a Taiwan Society North member.

"Supporters are still confused at Hsieh's positioning of the country because he has never made it clear to the public. It's also hard to fathom why the normal country resolution is still an issue without consensus within the DPP, " according to Allen Houng, chairman of the Constitution Reform Alliance.

A responsible political party is supposed to submit its party platform and the blueprint for the country before a major election, said Tsai Ting-kuei, chairman of the Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP). Tsai noted that the coalition does not endorse any candidate in the 2008 presidential election.

"We would like to see `vision, mission and action' from presidential candidates. An election is like an agreement between the candidates and the voters. Any change of position after the election would be a breach of contract, " said William Lo, a pastor of Taiwan's Presbyterian Church.
Once the resolution makes it through the DPP Central Executive Committee, it is scheduled to be presented to the party congress this autumn for final approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City soliciting foreign investment for 3 projects

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government is seeking foreign investment in three massive development projects worth a combined NT$67.4 billion (US$2 billion), Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday.
Hau made the announcement while addressing 35 representatives from foreign companies at an international investment presentation organized by the city government.
Describing Taipei City as "a land of opportunity," Hau encouraged foreign investors to invest more in the city's infrastructure development projects.

Under one development project, a twin tower complex containing stores, offices and hotels, will be constructed near the Taipei Main Station, a city official said, adding that the complex will also be part of an airport subway system in the future.

Another project is to develop a plot of land near the Taipei Municipal Guang Ci Care Home in the city's Hsinyi District into a new complex containing a care center for elderly people, residential buildings, business hotels, a park, an underground parking lot and supermarkets, the official went on.

The remaining project is to develop an area between Fuhsing North Road and Nanjing East Road near China Airlines headquarters into a business complex containing a hotel, a park, a parking lot and other facilities, the official said.
In addition to the briefing, the city government arranged a tour of the planned areas for the foreign representatives, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA to offer subsidies to pomelo farmers in Hualien, Taitung

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Su Jia-chyuan promised Tuesday to offer subsidies to pomelo farmers in the eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien who suffered heavy losses when Typhoon Sepat devastated their orchards.
Su made the announcement while accompanying Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on an inspection tour of the worst-affected areas.
A subsidy of NT$50,000 (US$1,516) per hectare will be paid to farmers who have lost more than 40 percent of their pomelos as a result of the typhoon, a COA official said.

In addition, the COA will provide a subsidy of NT$3 per kilogram for fallen pomelos to the counties' township offices and agricultural associations, which will purchase the fallen fruit for processing, the official said.
Pomelo farmers in the two counties suffered combined losses of NT$160 million, the official estimated.

DOC.HEADLINE: President stays on plane during refueling stop in Alaska

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian stayed on his chartered plane during a refueling stop at Anchorage International Airport in Alaska Tuesday en route to Central America for a three-nation diplomatic tour.

American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Honorary Chairman William Brown and Alaska Deputy Governor Sean Panell went aboard Chen's plane to welcome him, but the president did not disembark throughout the 50-minute refueling stopover.

Lee Nan-yang, director of the Public Affairs Office of the Presidential Office and a member of Chen's entourage, claimed that the president stayed on the plane out of "safety considerations, " saying that personnel movement aboard the plane during refueling "could cause security concerns."
Another reason was that the plane could not stay too long in Alaska as the government of Honduras -- the first leg of Chen's trip, has scheduled a military welcoming ceremony for Chen.

However, lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who are accompanying Chen on the trip claimed that Chen's decision not to disembark was a gesture to protest U.S. government restrictions on his transit stop.

The U.S. government has reportedly rejected Chen's request for layovers in major U.S. cities other than Anchorage or staying overnight during the transit stops as a way of expressing its displeasure with his administration's plan to push for a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.

DPP Legislator Tang Pi-o said seats on Chen's chartered plane all have a sticker attached calling for support for Taiwan's U.N. bid. Tang said she and two other members of Chen's entourage -- DPP Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni and Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey -- also have the stickers attached to their clothes. "I'm convinced that the U.S. representatives have clearly seen our appeal," she added.
Following the brief stopover in Alaska, Chen and his entourage head for Honduras where he will attend the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its Central American diplomatic allies.

The national leaders who are expected to take part in the summit include Belizean Prime Minister Said Musa, Guatemalan President Oscar Berger, Salvadoran President Antonio Saca, Honduran President Manuel Zelaya, Panamanian President Martin Torrijos, Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Morales and Dominican Republic Vice President Rafael Alburquerque.

Also during the president's visit in Honduras, the two countries will sign a memorandum under which Taiwan will provide a US$5 million loan in support of the Central American country's national computerization project.
On Aug. 24, Chen will head to El Salvador for a three-day visit before traveling on to Nicaragua Aug. 26.
The president is set to conclude his trip Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska. He is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 22, 2007

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin delivering speech on "Infrastructure and Investment Opportunity for Urban Waterfront Development of Taipei City" Date and Time: 12:30 p.m., Wednesday, Aug. 22, 2007 Place: Taipei World Trade Center Club, Floor 33rd, No. 333, Keelung Road, Sec. 1, Taipei City Organizers: American Chamber of Commerce Taipei Press Contact: Tel.: 2718-8226 Ext. 511 Tel.2321-0151

3. Event: Award presentation ceremony for the "2007 Doors to Diplomacy" Internet contest Date and Time: 01:30 p.m., Wednesday, Aug. 22, 2007 Place: National Taichung Library, 291-3, Chingwu Road, Taichung City Press Contact: Tel.04-22261105 4. Event: News conference on jobless rate Date and Time: 04:00 p.m., Wednesday, Aug. 22, 2007 Place: Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics Press Contact: Tel.2380-3400 Disclaimer:

DOC.HEADLINE: President regrets U.S. restrictions on his transit stop

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he regrets U.S. restrictions on his transit stop on his way to Central America for a three-nation diplomatic tour, saying that the U.S. treatment was "inconvenient, uncomfortable and indecent."

Stressing that the proposal to hold a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan is backed by a majority of Taiwan people, Chen said the U.S. restriction of his transit stop over this issue is punishment of the people of Taiwan.

Chen was quoted as having made the remarks while meeting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Honorary Chairman William Brown aboard his chartered plane during a refueling stop in Anchorage, Alaska en route to Honduras.

The U.S. government has reportedly rejected Chen's request for layovers in major U.S. cities other than Anchorage or staying overnight during the transit stops as a way of expressing its displeasure with his administration's plan to push for a referendum on the U.N. membership bid under the name of Taiwan.
Brown and Alaska Lieutenant Governor Sean Parnell went aboard Chen's plane to welcome him, but the president did not disembark throughout the refueling stop.

Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai, who is accompanying the president on the trip, said President Chen had decided to stay on his plane as a gesture to protest U.S. government restrictions on his transit stop prior to his departure for the journey.
According to Chen Chi-mai, President Chen held talks with Brown aboard the plane for nearly 90 minutes.
The president was quoted as having told Brown that Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties possess a high degree of consensus on pursuing Taiwan's U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan.

Noting that Taiwan treasures its longstanding friendship with the United States and that transit stop is not the main purpose of his travel, Chen said he personally ate the dirt and endured the insult. Nonetheless, Chen added that the U.S. treatment is not punishment of him, but rather punishment of Taiwan people.

Pointing out that pursuing a U.N. seat under the name of Taiwan neither violates his "four noes" pledge nor change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said the move is actually a way to safeguard Taiwan's democracy and the present peaceful status quo in the Taiwan Strait.
As the holding of referendums is a basic human right, Chen said Taiwan cannot accept any "red line" imposed on its democracy.

On resolving the Taiwan-U.S. dispute over the U.N. referendum issue, Chen suggested that the two sides communicate by phone or the U.S. government send a delegation composed of State Department or Pentagon officials to visit Taiwan for direct dialogue on relevant topics.

For his part, Brown was quoted as having told Chen that the U.S. government has no intention of making him uncomfortable during his transit stop. He also promised to convey Chen's opinions and suggestions to pertinent U.S. authorities.
AIT is a quasi-official U.S. organization authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Following their brief stopover in Anchorage, Chen and his entourage head for Honduras where he will attend the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its Central American diplomatic allies.

Also during his visit in Honduras, the two countries will sign a memorandum under which Taiwan will provide a US$5 million loan in support of the Central American country's national computerization project.
On Aug. 24, Chen will head to El Salvador for a three-day visit before traveling on to Nicaragua Aug. 26.
The president is set to conclude his trip Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska. He is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City soliciting foreign investment for 3 projects

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government is seeking foreign investment in three massive development projects worth a combined NT$67.4 billion (US$2 billion), Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday.
Hau made the announcement while addressing 35 representatives from foreign companies at an international investment presentation organized by the city government.
Describing Taipei City as "a land of opportunity," Hau encouraged foreign investors to invest more in the city's infrastructure development projects.

Under one development project, a twin tower complex containing stores, offices and hotels, will be constructed near the Taipei Main Station, a city official said, adding that the complex will also be part of an airport subway system in the future.

Another project is to develop a plot of land near the Taipei Municipal Guang Ci Care Home in the city's Hsinyi District into a new complex containing a care center for elderly people, residential buildings, business hotels, a park, an underground parking lot and supermarkets, the official went on.

The remaining project is to develop an area between Fuhsing North Road and Nanjing East Road near China Airlines headquarters into a business complex containing a hotel, a park, a parking lot and other facilities, the official said.
In addition to the briefing, the city government arranged a tour of the planned areas for the foreign representatives, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-independence groups urge DPP candidate to elucidate stance

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh should "do the right thing in making himself clear on the position and prospects of the country," a coalition of pro-Taiwan independence groups said Tuesday at a press conference.

The coalition also submitted its own action plan for Taiwan's normalization as a country Tuesday before the DPP Central Executive Committee begins to screen a "normal country" resolution this week. It calls for Hsieh to make his position clear to voters on the resolution.

"A great statesman should follow the example of former Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, who insisted on `doing the right thing, '" said Taiwan Society North Vice President Michelle Wang, who spoke on behalf of the coalition.
What the coalition feels is the "right thing" for Hsieh to do, Wang explained, is to make Taiwan a normal country, a topic Hsieh has been reluctant to elaborate on.

The content of the action plan is little different to the DPP's "normal country" resolution, which includes the basic objectives of changing the country's name, writing a new constitution, establishing a normal country and joining the United Nations, she said, although she claimed it is the "voice of the people."

The DPP election ticket "symbolizes the successful integration of the DPP's internal factions, but we have not seen anything from the DPP that can touch the voters, " claimed Hsu Yung-ming, a research fellow at Academia Sinica and a Taiwan Society North member.

"Supporters are still confused at Hsieh's positioning of the country because he has never made it clear to the public. It's also hard to fathom why the normal country resolution is still an issue without consensus within the DPP, " according to Allen Houng, chairman of the Constitution Reform Alliance.

A responsible political party is supposed to submit its party platform and the blueprint for the country before a major election, said Tsai Ting-kuei, chairman of the Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP). Tsai noted that the coalition does not endorse any candidate in the 2008 presidential election.

"We would like to see `vision, mission and action' from presidential candidates. An election is like an agreement between the candidates and the voters. Any change of position after the election would be a breach of contract, " said William Lo, a pastor of Taiwan's Presbyterian Church.
Once the resolution makes it through the DPP Central Executive Committee, it is scheduled to be presented to the party congress this autumn for final approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday Aug. 22, or the 10th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig, according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a Japanese protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement calling on the people to obey the National government and join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprised of China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Warsaw Pact tanks enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named U.S. secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure had forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese person to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang- kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the party's nomination and to instead run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
1999: A China Airlines passenger plane with 315 on board crash-lands at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during a typhoon, killing two and injuring 211.
2000: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong says that it is still too early to talk about overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification as the government has yet to demonstrate consistency regarding its cross-strait policies.
2000: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore decorades visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Grande Croix in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties.
2001: Republic of China Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, along with a 20-strong delegation, attends the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds though ten efforts, use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."
