DOC.HEADLINE: Diplomat calls for investment in Brazil's biomass energy sector

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Brazil urged the government and private enterprises to invest in Brazil's biomass energy sector, saying the South American country's environmentally-friendly energy technology is "mature."

Chou Shu-yeh made the call at a workshop on global investment and trade opportunities, which was organized and held by the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce and the Foreign Service Institute under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Taipei Tuesday.

In Brazil, Chou said, there are two kinds of fuel for automobiles -- one is pure ethanol and the other is a mixture of 15 percent ethanol and 85 percent petroleum. He added that the Brazilian government is considering raising the percentage of ethanol in the mixed fuel to 25 percent.

Chou Kuo-chin, chief of the economic division under the Taiwan representative office in Brazil, pointed out that Brazil began developing its biomass energy sector two decades ago and that it now possesses advanced bioenergy production technology.
Noting that the United States, Japan and South Korea have been investing in Brazil's bioenergy sector, Chou Chu-yie urged Taiwan to join the trend before it's too late.

DOC.HEADLINE: Whooping cough cases reported in Changhua County

TEXT.P: Several cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, were reported recently in a religious community in Changhua County, a Centers for Disease Control (CDC) official said Wednesday.
A total of three adults and three children were diagnosed with pertussis in the community earlier this month, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao.

The community, affiliated with a local religious association, is comprised of 32 residents, including 14 people from four different families, 12 single volunteer workers and six physically or mentally challenged members who are being sheltered there.
The first two cases -- two infants from different families -- were discovered Aug. 8, Chou said.

After tests on the rest of the residents, a five-year-old boy, three adults were confirmed to have also been infected, he said, adding that the patients are recovering after being treated with antibiotics.

According to Chou, while infants in the country are given four doses of pertussis vaccine, at the age of two months, four months, six months and 18 months, respectively, the infected five-year-old boy had only received the first three doses, while the two infected infants had not received any doses.
According to the CDC, pertussis may start with cold symptoms before developing into episodes of severe coughing, which could lead to vomiting.
However, infants with pertussis may not develop a severe cough and may only have a mild cough and decreased appetite and may have difficulty breathing or turn bluish, CDC officials said.
Chou said that although about 95 percent of children in the country have received pertussis vaccination, sporadic infections are reported every year.

He advised parents to make sure their children receive the vaccination according to schedule and urged caregivers of children to wear masks if any members of the family display symptoms of pertussis, such as coughing or difficulty breathing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Gambling & Entertainment Summit 2007 slated for Aug. 27

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Gambling & Entertainment Summit 2007 is scheduled to be held in Taipei City Aug. 27 with the aim of examining the prospects of Taiwan becoming another gambling mecca after Las Vegas, Macau and Singapore.

Stuart Mann, dean of the William F. Harrah College of Hotel Administration under the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, is scheduled to deliver a keynote speech during the opening session, according to Liao Chao-hung, director of the Taipei- based Asia Management Research Center (AMRC).
The summit, the first of its kind in Taiwan, is being co-sponsored by the Taiwan Office of the State of Nevada, the Chinese Culture University and the AMRC.

Liao said that Macau and Singapore had attracted international funds and applied international casino management systems to develop their gambling and entertainment industries, but the key to maintaining sustainable operations will be whether they are able to cultivate their own high-caliber management talent.
Liao estimated that if casinos are legalized in Taiwan, the new industry will create at least 50,000 jobs.

An official from the Nevada State Taiwan Office said that the four premier casino-hotels in Las Vegas have decided to invest some US$33 billion in Asia to expand their gambling and entertainment operations in this part of the world.

After exploring the Macau and Singapore markets, executives of the Las Vegas hotels will also attend the Taiwan Gambling & Entertainment Summit in Taipei to gain a better understanding of the country's potential in developing a casino gaming industry, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: City government takes over management of Taipei Arena in sudden move

TEXT.P: Over 100 Taipei City officials and police officers entered the Taipei Arena Wednesday in a sudden move by the municipal government to take over management of the city's first multifunctional indoor stadium.

The action was launched by the Taipei City government without any notice being given to the dome-shaped facility's contracted operator, the Eastern Dome Management Company (EDMC), which is a subsidiary of the Eastern Multimedia Group (EMG).
According to the city government, the move was made "to protect the property of the government and citizens."
Yang Hsi-an, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei City government, quoted Mayor Hau Lung-bin as saying that the city government will take charge of the arena's operations for one year.
Yang also stressed that the business operations of stores and the ice rink at the arena will not be affected.
The city government's move, however, triggered a strong protest from EDMC Chairwoman Chiu Pei-lin who questioned the legal basis of the city government's move.

Hau announced Aug. 14 the city government's decision to terminate its nine-year contract with the EMG to manage the Taipei Arena, after public prosecutors indicted EMG Chairman Gary Wang on charges of committing a series of financial crimes, including using collusive bidding to obtain the right to manage the facility.
EMG won the right to manage the Taipei Arena for nine years with a bid of NT$1.58 billion (US$47.78 million) in 2005 when Ma Ying-jeou was Taipei mayor.
Taipei prosecutors have unearthed evidence that Wang and Hsieh Yin-lung, an EDMC deputy manager, engaged in bidding collusion to allow Wang to obtain the concession right.

According to the prosecutors, Wang and Hsieh each formed a new company specifically for the bidding, but Wang later paid Hsieh NT$24.78 million in return for his promise that his bid would not go higher than Wang's -- an act in violation of the Government Procurement Law.

Wang and 31 of his associates were indicted Aug. 13 for their alleged involvement in several embezzlement scandals. Prosecutors are seeking a 28-year prison sentence for Wang, plus a fine of NT$1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen magistrate calls for greater efforts to promote tourism

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng called Wednesday for travel agents and other members of the tourism industry operating on the outlying island of Kinmen to make greater efforts to help Kinmen gain a larger slice of the cross-Taiwan Strait "tourism pie."

Addressing the opening of a tourism training workshop, Lee called for Kinmen- based travel agencies and related tourism operators to upgrade their service quality so they can attract more tourists from mainland China to make sightseeing trips to Kinmen.
A total of 202 people representing travel agencies, hotels, restaurants, shops and bus companies around Kinmen took part in the training workshop sponsored by the Kinmen County Government.

Lee quoted tallies from the Kinmen County Bureau of Tourism as indicating that Kinmen has attracted over 43,000 Chinese tourists since China began allowing residents of Fujian Province to make sightseeing trips to Kinmen in December 2004.

According to the tallies, Lee said, 64 people in four travel groups from Fujian visited Kinmen for tourism in 2004, with the figures increasing to 3,129 people in 170 groups in 2005 and 20,067 people in 1,040 groups in 2006.
So far this year, over 20,000 Fujian tourists in 853 groups have visited Kinmen, he added.

Also addressing the workshop, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Wu Cherng-dean said that there is no reason why Kinmen -- with a cultural history of over 1,600 years, an interesting contemporary history filled with major battles, and an ideal geographical position between the Chinese mainland and Taiwan -- cannot become a major tourism destination.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maximum estate, gift tax rates to be lowered to 40%

TEXT.P: The Cabinet finalized Wednesday a plan to reform the country's estate and gift taxation system that will lower the maximum rates for the two categories of taxes from 50 percent at present to 40 percent.

Also, the exemption for estate tax will be increased from NT$7.79 million (US$236,778) at present to NT$10 million, and the exemption will be applicable to parents who give their properties to their children during their lifetime, according to the plan.

Meanwhile, the minimum taxable amount for the two categories of taxes will be raised significantly from NT$600,000 to NT$5 million, with the number of tax rate classifications simplified from 10 to five -- 6 percent, 13 percent, 21 percent, 30 percent and 40 percent.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the new system may be implemented early next year at the earliest.

In the next step, the Cabinet will further work to integrate the estate tax and gift tax by 2010, adopting a lifetime wealth transfer taxation system and further reducing the maximum tax rate to 20 percent, Chang said, adding that he believes the reforms will help establish a sound taxation system to boost the country's economic development and improve the people's well-being.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical team arrives in Peru to help with post-quake relief

TEXT.P: A medical team from the TaiwanIHA, a government-funded organization which offers international medical aid, has arrived in Peru to provide assistance to victims of the magnitude 8.0 earthquake that struck the South American country Aug. 15.

According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials, the medical team, which arrived in Peru Aug. 18, was the first to reach the hardest-hit town of Pisco, located 240 kilometers southeast of Lima, with Peruvian Minister of Health Carlos Vallejos greeting the team at the airport.

On behalf of the Republic of China government, Taiwan's representative to Peru, Huang Lien-sheng, donated US$100,000 in cash for earthquake relief efforts in the country. Vallejos expressed gratitude for the donation and the concern shown by both the people and the government of Taiwan.
According to the officials, the Aug. 15 earthquake, the biggest to hit Peru in decades, caused more than 500 deaths and injured some 1,600 people.

The Economic and Cultural Office of Taipei in Lima sent a letter to Peruvian President Alan Garcia on Aug. 16 extending Taiwan's regards to the Peruvian people and promising to offer humanitarian aid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close slightly higher

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed slightly higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 14.38 points to close at 8,493.46.
The bourse opened at 8,487.24 and fluctuated between 8,512.45 and 8,432.32 during trading. A total of 4.03 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$110.2 billion (US$3.34 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 3.6 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent, textile stocks at 1.1 percent, cement stocks at 0.8 percent, construction issues at 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares dropping 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 833 to 807, with 233 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. investigators arrive in Okinawa to probe CAL plane fire
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/07 16:14:43 (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A five-member U.S. group, including three aviation officials, arrived in Okinawa Wednesday to help investigate why a Boeing 737-800 of Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) burst into flames minutes after landing at Okinawa's Naha international airport Monday.

The three officials from the National Transportation Safety Board and the Federal Aviation Administration, arrived along with two experts from Boeing Co. and are expected to meet with officials from Japan's Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transportation (MLIT) at Naha Airport to probe the cause of the fire.

The Boeing 737-800 passenger jet from Taipei caught fire shortly after landing at Naha Airport, but all 157 passengers and eight crew members aboard the plane managed to escape before the left engine exploded and engulfed the plane in a fireball.

According to preliminary investigations conducted by MLIT experts, the fire was probably caused by a problem with the fuel pipe in the plane's right wing, which caught fire when it came into contact with the hot engine.
The pipe is inside the plane's "pylon, " a tube that connects the engine with the wing and brings in fuel.
Investigators from the Japanese inquiry committee and CAL have been examining the destroyed aircraft since Tuesday to try to determine the cause of the accident.
The passengers included 110 Taiwanese travelers, 23 Japanese citizens and 24 people from other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September rose 72 points to close at 8,437, with 41,609 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 61 points to finish at 8,431, with 241 contracts traded, while December futures gained 35 points to close at 8,431, with 109 contract transactions. March futures increased 48 points to close at 8,448, with eight contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,365 for August, 8,370 for October, 8,396 for December, 8,400 for March and 8,378 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

September TE futures moved up 2.7 points to close at 354.9, with 3,271 contracts traded, while October TE futures rose 0.5 points to finish at 353.5, with 54 contract transactions. December TE futures gained 0.1 points to close at 352, with one contract traded, while June TE futures increased one point to finish at 351, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March.

September TF futures rose 20.6 points to close at 975.6, with 3,513 contracts traded, while October TF futures moved up 16.2 points to finish at 975.6, with 25 contract transactions. December TF futures gained 15 points to close at 978, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, rising NT$0.018 to close at NT$32.939.
A total of US$1.04 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.900 and hit a high of NT$33.020.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-offered training course receives warm response from allies

TEXT.P: A two-week training course on economic development and human resources sponsored by the government was inaugurated Wednesday, with 27 officials and executives from 22 countries participating.

According to officials of the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the course is open to officials of Taiwan's diplomatic allies or developing countries with friendly ties with Taiwan.

The officials said the course received a warm response from many countries when it was first opened for registration in May. Among the participants are senior officials from Burkina Faso, Poland and the Marshall Islands.

Considering that investment in human resources is a pivotal step for economic development, the ICDF course will focus on the topic in order to share Taiwan's development experience with other developing countries.

Other topics of the seminar will include the global administration of human resources and on-the-job training. In addition, the organizer will arrange in-depth visits around Taiwan for the participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Birth allowance proposed to raise Kaohsiung's birth rate

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung city councilor said Wednesday that she will propose measures in the next city council session in the hope of raising Kaohsiung's decreasing birth rate through granting child-bearing women birth allowances.
Li Chiao-ju of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) told a press conference that Kaohsiung recorded 11,696 births last year, representing a birth rate of 7.73 births per 1,000 population.
She pointed out that the number of births in 2006 dropped 7,375 compared with 19,071 births in 1996, representing a decline of 5.61 births per 1,000 population.

Li said that if the decreasing birth rate is allowed to continue, Kaohsiung will have 800,000 residents who need support 20 years from now, which means each youngster will face enormous pressure of supporting two dependents.
She added that the proposal would grant a NT$30,000 birth allowance to a woman when she has her first baby and NT$40,000 for her second.

DOC.HEADLINE: City government takes over Taipei Arena management

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government's sudden move Wednesday to take over the Taipei Arena's management was to prevent the city-owned stadium's contracted operator from filing a provisional disposition lawsuit in an attempt to "occupy" the Taipei City property, according to a high-ranking city official.

City Deputy Secretary-General Yang Hsi-an made the statement at a press conference at the dome-shaped facility, the capital's first multifunctional indoor stadium, soon after the move that incurred strong protest by the Eastern Dome Management Company (EDMC) , which was formed by the Eastern Multimedia Group (EMG) to manage the Taipei Arena.

In a news release, the city government said it requested that EDMC return the arena management Aug. 17 in accordance with a bilateral contract, as well as the regulations governing contracted management of city properties.
However, not only did EDMC not respect the request, the company, which has not paid any royalties since July, took legal action Monday to confirm its right to manage the dome.
This action revealed EDMC's "attempt to occupy the facility through holding off the city government's move to take it over, " according to the news release.

Yang said the city government has hoped for the takeover to be conducted in a peaceful manner through negotiations and mutual communication since Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced his administration's decision Aug. 14 to terminate its nine- year contract with EDMC.

The decision was made after public prosecutors indicted EMG Chairman Gary Wang on charges of committing a series of financial crimes, including using collusive bidding to obtain the right to manage the arena in violation of the Government Procurement Law, according to the Taipei city government.

The compulsory takeover took effect at 7: 30 a.m. Wednesday, with EDMC employees unable to enter or leave the dome without the city government's permission, Yeh Ching-yuan, director of the city's Law and Regulation Commission, said, reiterating the city government's right to terminate the contract with EDMC since the way the company gained the dome's management right is considered "unjust."
Meanwhile, in response to media inquiries at the Taipei Arena, EDMC General Manager Lin Ker-mo accused the city government of "using its administrative power to deal with a civil contract dispute"
Lin called the morning takeover a "break-in."

Over 100 city officials and policemen entered the Taipei Arena, with most EDMC employees shut outside. EDMC Chairwoman Chiu Pei-lin, accompanied by a lawyer, questioned the legal basis of the move, arguing that the city government has no right to "unilaterally terminate the contract while acting to avoid a lawsuit."

DOC.HEADLINE: President reiterates `no need for Taiwan to declare independence'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated his stance during a recent media interview that Taiwan is already an independent sovereign country and has no need to declare independence, according to the transcript of the interview released Wednesday by the Presidential Office.

In the interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), Chen noted that Taiwan's sovereignty does not fall under the jurisdiction of the People's Republic of China and that there is "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait."

"Taiwan being a sovereign independent country has been the reality for more than half a century and is still the status quo today, " Chen said, rejecting criticism that Taiwan will provoke Beijing and trigger a war across the Taiwan Strait by making such a claim.

Although almost every step taken by Taiwan to further its democracy is considered by China as moves toward "de jure independence, " the country must carry on with its course, whether China likes it or not, Chen said.

He pointed out that China has over the decades refused to acknowledge Taiwan's status as a sovereign independent country and is harboring the motive of annexing Taiwan and turning it into another Hong Kong or Macau by imposing the "one country, two systems" model.
"But this is unacceptable to our people and there is no way we can sit and wait for our enemies to take us over," he said.

Chen said it is important for Taiwan to continue consolidating its democracy "because in democracy lies our most effective `theater missile defense' against China" and making efforts toward establishing Taiwan as a "normal country enjoying the same rights as other countries."
In this sense, he said, Taiwan "has the full right" to participate in the international community and world organizations, including the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations.

Despite the country's failure to become a full member of the WHO under the name of Taiwan this year, it will keep pressing forward with the goal and will also be applying for full membership in the United Nations using a similar format, he said.

"We want to make sure that one day, the voice of our people will be heard in all corners of the world, if not today, then maybe tomorrow, " Chen said. "However long it takes, we will continue striving until we become a normal country that is accepted by international society."

On concerns that Taiwan's efforts to become a "normal country" could provoke a military attack from China, Chen said it is the "collective will" of the Taiwan people that speaks and that Taiwan "will not keep silent just because China doesn't like what it hears."

Citing results of an opinion survey conducted in March this year, the president said that 95 percent of the people support the country's application for WHO membership and that 77 percent support the application for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan.

Asked if he is confident that the United States will defend Taiwan in the event of an attack from China, Chen said he believes the United States will fulfill its obligations as stipulated in the Taiwan Relations Act and come to Taiwan's aid "as long as Taiwan is not the one inciting a military conflict."
However, Chen added that Taiwan cannot rely on others to fight for the country and must work to beef up its defense capabilities, without the intention of engaging in an arms race with China.
"We do not seek to engage in war. But we must be prepared for war if we wish to prevent it and work towards achieving lasting peace, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public encouraged not to use motor vehicles one day per week

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that more energy-saving measures should be carried out, including encouraging people not to use private motor vehicles one day per week.
Chang made the remark after listening to Ministry of Economic Affairs report on the government's energy policy, which includes 10 major energy-saving actions.
Chang said the national energy policy should center on seeking sustainable development, ensuring the safety of energy supplies, protecting the environment and preserving industrial competitiveness.
It is important to strengthen these practices to save energy and develop renewable energy, Chang said.

The energy-saving actions also include buying low-polluting motor vehicles to replace old government-owned automobiles, promoting a "no cold air leak" movement among businesses that use air conditioning, ordering every new government building to meet all requirements for energy saving, pushing schools to use "green energy " and accelerating efforts to develop energy- saving and renewable energy production technologies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Honduras supports Taiwan's U.N. accession
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Honduras, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/22/07 19:09:54 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Honduran President Jose Manuel Zela Rosales vowed Tuesday to support Taiwan's accession to the United Nations, saying that all nations around the world are equal and that Taiwan deserves to be a full U.N. member.
Zela said that Honduras and Taiwan share common values of freedom, democracy and human rights.

The Honduran president made the remarks at a ceremony held at the Palmerola military airport, where he presided over a military salute to welcome the arrival of President Chen Shui-bian for a three-day state visit.

Soon after the red-carpet welcome ceremony, Chen, accompanied by Honduran Vice President Elvin Santos, was driven to the city of Tabacalera, where a Taiwan agricultural mission is located, to inspect the agricultural achievements that Honduran farmers have made with the assistance of the Taiwan mission.
Chen and Santos visited a local farm growing Taiwanese guava and was treated with guava and corn cake by the farm's owner.

Chen met with Zela again in the evening at the Honduran Presidential Palace for mutual talks before signing a joint communique calling for cooperation between the two countries on 11 projects, including the Taiwan Power Company extending assistance to Honduras for the development of a hydraulic power plant, Taiwan helping Honduras develop tourism and Taiwan helping Honduras improve community medical services.

Later in the evening, the two heads of state witnessed the signing of an agreement on mutual exemption of diplomatic and official visas between the two countries. The agreement was inked by Republic of China Foreign Minister James Huang and his Honduran counterpart, Milton Jimenez.

Chen was scheduled to witness the signing of a memorandum Wednesday afternoon under which Taiwan will provide a US$5 million loan in support of the Central American country's national computerization project.
He is also scheduled to be conferred with a citation by Zela Wednesday before delivering a speech and visiting a national museum.

Chen and his entourage arrived in the Honduran capital via the U.S. city of Anchorage, where they made a brief refueling stopover. The president is scheduled to head from Honduras to El Salvador Aug. 24 for another three-day visit before traveling on to Nicaragua Aug. 26. He is set to conclude his Central American trip Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska, arriving in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government promotes fiber broadband building labeling system

TEXT.P: The government has launched a fiber broadband building (FBB) label certification system to promote the new technology in an effort to boost the country's optical fiber communication industry, market sources said Wednesday.

A certificate presentation ceremony was held a day earlier to recognize construction enterprises using the services and encourage more to join, with scores of representatives from 23 construction companies participating.

The ceremony was organized by the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the MOEA Committee of Communications Industry Development, the Institute for Information Industry, the Taiwan Electrical And Electronic Manufacturers Association and the Communications Industry Alliance (CIA).
There are two types of FBB labels -- fiber to the home gold label and fiber to the building silver label, according to CIA Chairman Wen Pu-san, who is in charge of the campaign.

Wen said since the launch of the system in April, system organizers have received 30 applications. He estimated by the end of this year, the number of households using fiber-based broadband services in the country will have increased to 500,000 and by 2010, the number of households using such services will have broken 2.4 million, representing 40 percent of broadband household subscribers.

Citing statistics that show a total of 197 million households worldwide subscribed to broadband services in 2006, IDB Deputy Director-General Shen Jong-chin said the growth of broadband subscribers is relatively slow, as broadband services are mainly based on ADSL technology, which is limited in the transmission of data and is forecast to be unable to meet growing needs of users and service providers in the future.

In contrast, the optical fiber communication industry is highly promising, Shen said, adding that the IDB has commissioned the CIA to organize a series of fiber technology promotional activities, including the FBB label campaign, with the goal of pushing development of the industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Would-be nominee for judiciary chief drops out: legislative speaker

TEXT.P: A would-be nominee for the chief of the Judicial Yuan has asked to have his name withdrawn from consideration, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng confirmed Wednesday.

Wang said that Yang Jen-shou, president of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries, asked him to relay his refusal to be nominated to President Chen Shui-bian after a scholar questioned the constitutionality of Yang's nomination.
Wang said, however, that he had no chance to pass on Yang's request because Chen departed for a Central America trip Tuesday.
The United Daily News said Wednesday Yang decided to withdraw from the nomination to pre-empt any controversy. He could not be reached for comment on the report.
Chen's aides made it known Aug. 17 that the president would name Yang to replace Weng Yueh-sheng as president of the Judicial Yuan, as the latter's term falls due at the end of September.
The nomination would have been submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval after the president returns from his Central America trip later this month, according to Chen's aides.
This news has drawn criticism from Yen Chu-an, a law professor at National Taiwan University, who questioned the constitutionality of the choice of Yang as the judiciary chief.

Noting that Yang served as a grand justice between 2003 and 2006 before he was appointed to his current post, Yen said Yang is not qualified to serve as chief of the Judicial Yuan -- who is an automatic grand justice -- because the Constitution limits grand justices to only one term.

Yen claimed that if Yang is nominated simply because he has terminated his first term as grand justice to serve in another post, it would look like a legal trick to get around the constitutional limitation and would not serve the interests of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO envoy suggests expanding market under WTO framework

TEXT.P: Taiwan should make greater use of the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework to get global market access rather than trying to sign free trade pacts with other countries, which is difficult thanks to political factors, Taiwan Representative to the WTO Lin Yi-fu said Wednesday.

Lin made the remarks while giving a speech at a seminar on investment in the global market organized by the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce and the Foreign Service Institute under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Tariff duties are lower among WTO members, so some of them levy anti-dumping and countervailing duties on imports in order to protect their domestic industries, Lin said.

Because it has the third-highest of cases of anti-dumping duties among WTO members, Taiwan should participate more actively in negotiations with WTO members to prevent their imposition of anti-dumping and countervailing measures against Taiwan products, Lin went on.

In addition, Lin said, Taiwan should slow down its liberalization of agricultural trade to avoid negative impact on Taiwan's economy, as the competitiveness of Taiwan's agriculture sector is relatively weak compared to other WTO members.

Taiwan already has a quite open market in service trade and can further expand its international market in certain areas such as telecommunications, distribution, financial services and professional services through negotiation, he said.
In terms of Taiwan's strong points such as bicycle and hand tool manufacturing, Lin said Taiwan can consider market liberalization or removing tariff duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 charities to raise NT$10 million to help abandoned children

TEXT.P: The Child Welfare League Foundation and 14 other organizations joined forces Wednesday to launch a fund-raising campaign with the goal of raising NT$10 million to help abandoned children in Taiwan.

Wang Yu-min, executive director of the foundation, told a press conference that the money will be used to provide protection and medical services to abandoned children and help them find foster homes.

She urged the public to donate to the campaign generously, noting that the number of abandoned children had increased 40 percent to 509 in 2006 since 2001, while the number of foster families had dropped 35 percent compared with 10 years ago.

The Child Welfare League Foundation is a nonprofit organization founded in 1991. The 14 other organizations taking part in the fund drive include Fubon Financial Holding Co., Carrefour Cultural and Educational Foundation, the 7-Eleven convenience store chain and the DigiTimes online newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jobless rate in first seven months hits seven-year low: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The average unemployment rate in the first seven months of the year hit a new low of 3.88 percent compared with the same period during the last seven years, government officials said Wednesday.

According to officials of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , the unemployment rate in July stood at 4.03 percent, a drop of 0.02 percentage points over the same month of last year.
The number of unemployed registered 433,000 in July, while the average number of jobless persons in the first seven months stood at 415,000.

The number of employed totalled 10.32 million in July, up 59,000 from June, or 187,000 over the same month of last year, while the average number of employed registered 10.25 million in the first seven months, an increase of 203,000 over the same period of last year.

The labor force participation rate in July stood at 58.45 percent, while the average labor force participation rate in the first seven months registered 58.19 percent, the highest during the last decade.

In terms of educational background, the jobless rate for people with senior high or vocational school education was the highest, standing at 4.45 percent, while the unemployment rate for those with university or higher education registered 4.2 percent. The jobless rate for people with junior high or lower education was the lowest, at 3.18 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Customs confiscates undeclared HK$1 million in cash

TEXT.P: The Taipei Customs Office confiscated HK$975,000 (US$124,915) in undeclared cash from a tourist arriving from Macao at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Aug. 20, a customs officer said Wednesday.

According to the officer, customs officials found the money in the tourist's carry-on baggage. The maximum permitted amount of currency that can be brought in undeclared is US$10,000 in foreign currency or NT$60,000 in local currency.

The case marked Taiwan's seventh confiscation of undeclared currency. Among the seven cases, two involved local currency -- one case of NT$13.87 million and the other of NT$10.13 million in undeclared cash.
Five other cases involved with foreign currency, with a total of NT$26.66 million confiscated, the officer added.
The officer warned tourists to declare excess currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Conference on multilateral environmental, trading systems held

TEXT.P: Taiwan, like other World Trade Organization (WTO) members, should understand how to take advantage of appropriate regulations under the WTO framework in the event of trade disputes relating to environmental issues, a Japanese academic said in an international conference held in Taipei Wednesday.

There will always be trade disputes relating to food safety and environmental issues and there is limit to what the dispute settlement procedure can do, Mitsuo Matsushita, a law professor at Japan's Seikei University and a former member of the WTO's Appellate Body, said in the conference titled "Global Governance of Multilateral Environmental and Trading Systems."

There have been over 200 multilateral environmental agreements signed all over the world, including the Kyoto Protocol, aimed at protecting the environment. Some of them use a quota system, such as the International Convention for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna, while others are supposed to resolve the problems within a trading system, such as the Kyoto Protocol and the Basel Convention, Matsushita said.
However, disputes continue to happen, he went on, citing the latest dispute between Brazil and the European Commission over retreaded tires.

Potential conflicts between Kyoto Protocol, Cartagena Protocol (which regulates biosafety) and WTO rules are possible, which is why countries are encouraged to work out different ways to resolve the problems, Matsushita said.

"Global governance is needed to solve disputes such as terrorism and trade issues because we can't do it unilaterally, " Economic Vice Minister Hsieh Fadah said, adding that regional, transnational and international networks are needed to deal with environmental issues.
Any trade restriction implementation has to consider the factors of economical gains, social welfare and environmental impact, Hsieh noted.
The two-day conference was organized by the Chunghua Institution for Economic Research and invited scholars from Japan, South Korea, the U.S. and the WTO to participate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of abandoned children on rise: report

TEXT.P: The number of abandoned children in Taiwan has grown rapidly, jumping by 40 percent over the past six years, according to the latest figures made public Wednesday by the Child Welfare Foundation.
In 2006, 509 children, including 35 newborns, were deserted by their birth parents in Taiwan, up by more than 40 percent over the 2001 figure of 361, according to the results of an investigation.
At the same time, a larger number of families are putting their children up for adoption, while fewer local families are willing to adopt, according to the report.

The number of telephones calls by parents searching for professional consultations to have their children adopted increased by nearly 70 percent during the six-year period, from 366 in 2001 to 619 in 2006, while the number of adopted children dropped by 35 percent in a decade -- from 4,015 in 1996 to 2,626 in 2006.

The report attributed the decreasing number of adopted children to a worsening social environment, the rising cost of rearing children, progressive fertilization techniques and a trend of having fewer children.

In addition, the report pointed out, it is difficult to find foster families in Taiwan for children with congenital illnesses or facial defects and for those born to parents with alcohol or drug addiction.

From 2004 to 2006, as high as 50 percent of children born to drug-addicted parents and nearly 30 percent of children with congenital illnesses were not adopted, it said, adding that some 10 percent of children with darker skin born to migrant workers or foreign spouses were also unwanted.
The foundation has launched a fund-raising campaign urging the public to make monetary donations to help take care of abandoned children, setting its target at NT$10 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranks sixth in BERI investment climate report

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investment environment was ranked sixth among 50 major economies by the U.S.-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) market research firm in its 2007 report.

Taiwan scored 72 points in BERI's second report for the year, with its investment climate ranking behind that of Switzerland, Singapore, the Netherlands, Japan and Norway. Its ranking was third in Asia.
Taiwan was classified in the 1A category -- a country with low risk for investment -- as in previous reports.
BERI evaluates a country's investment climate based on three major indicators -- business risk index, political risk index and currency exchange risk index.
BERI researchers predicted that Taiwan's overall investment climate will improve stably in the next one to five years.

Taiwan's business risk was ranked third in the world, only behind Switzerland and Singapore, and second in Asia, while its currency exchange risk was classified as fifth in the world and third in Asia.

BERI experts predicted that Taiwan's business risk will continue improving due to the approval by its legislature in July of a budget for 10 development projects and growing export demand. These factors will boost Taiwan's economic growth and create more jobs, BERI researchers added.

However, the island's political risk was ranked 15th in the world and third in Asia due largely to the uncertainty caused by its upcoming legislative and presidential elections, according to BERI researchers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Direct China-Songshan flights key for Taipei: mayor

TEXT.P: Upgrading Songshan Airport to an international airport and offering direct flights to places like Shanghai, Hong Kong and Singapore will be key for Taipei City to attract foreign investment, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Wednesday.

Hau reiterated at an American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) lunch that he supports offering direct flights from Songshan Airport to China and other Asian countries, which he claimed will be an important factor to encourage international corporations to set up their headquarters in Taipei while maintaining plants in China.

"However, it will not be possible if the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) keeps the presidency in the 2008 presidential election, " he told around 100 AmCham members in a question and answer session following a 40-minute speech.
Hau talked about his vision and plans for the largest city in Taiwan in his speech titled "Investment Opportunities for Urban Waterfront Development in Taipei City."
To revitalize urban waterfront, Hau said his three goals are to achieve great water quality, waterfront atmosphere and recreation. He also said the Tamsui River will be deodorized by 2011.

The city plans to maximize its information technology leverage in attracting foreign investment with the Taipei Technology Corridor, which will link the Neihu Technology Park, the Nangang Software Park, and the Beitou-Shilin Technology park that is still in the planning stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-money laundering efforts win APG recognition

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made huge progress in its efforts to combat money laundering and has received high ratings from the Asia Pacific Group on Money Laundering (APG) , Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) officials said Wednesday.
Police arrested more than 100 money laundering suspects last year and seized a combined NT$78 billion (US$2.4 billion) , FSC officials said.
The figure was 10 times higher than the NT$6.7 billion seized in the previous year from nearly 30 suspects, the officials went on.
Taiwan, an APG founding member, passed the second round of a review conducted by the APG at the organization's annual meeting held in Perth, Australia, July 23-27, the officials said.
Prior to the annual meeting, the APG had dispatched officials to Taiwan for a two-week inspection tour of the country's bank, security and insurance operators Jan. 28-Feb. 11.

The APG awarded Taiwan ratings on par with the United States, Australia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland in the categories of client screening procedures, internal monitoring, compliance and audit, as well as fighting against underground money remittances or transfers, the officials stated.

Founded in 1997, the Australia-based APG consists of 34 member countries and 18 world organizations and aims to assist its members in complying with international practices in combating money laundering and curbing funding of terrorist activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government holds exhibition on KMT's ill-gotten assets

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday he hopes that an exhibition organized by the Executive Yuan can bring together the public in a campaign aimed at reclaiming the ill-gotten assets obtained by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) during its five decades of authoritarian rule of Taiwan.
The Cabinet kicked off the exhibition earlier in the same day, which features nearly 100 documents, files, newspaper articles from the government, the KMT and the private sector.

The exhibition is part of the Cabinet's efforts to educate the public about the KMT's ill-gotten assets and to realize transitional justice during the country's democratization process, said an official with an Executive Yuan panel that organizes the event.
The exhibition is taking place in the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei and will later be held in Taichung City, Chiayi County, Kaohsiung City, and Yunlin County, the official noted.
The event will run through the end of the year, according to the official.

The exhibition also features the German government's successful experience in asking former East Germany's ruling Communist Party to return ill-gotten assets worth NT$33.75 billion (about US$1 billion) to the national coffers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County Athletic Meet opens

TEXT.P: The 2007 biennial Kaohsiung County Athletic Meet opened Wednesday at Kaohsiung County Stadium, with more than 3,000 athletes from 27 townships in the county taking part.
Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing presided over the opening ceremony, joined by the 27 township heads.
The participants will compete for three days in 18 categories, including track and field events, swimming competitions and various ball games.
Yang said athletes who excel in the competition will represent Kaohsiung County in the 2007 National Athletic Meet to be held in Tainan City in October.

Noting that Kaohsiung County ranked third among all cities and counties in the 2005 National Athletic Meet, capturing 31 gold medals, 15 silvers and 16 bronzes, Yang encouraged the athletes to strive for a better record in the next National Athletic Meet.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT awards international Web site design winners in Taichung

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) spokesman Thomas Hodges awarded four students from Taichung County's Ming-Dao High School Wednesday with first prize in an international Web site design contest called "Doors to Diplomacy."
The ceremony was held at the American Corner of the National Taichung Library in Taichung City.

The contest, sponsored by the U.S. State Department, was aimed at encouraging high school students around the world to create Web pages carrying messages of the importance of international affairs and diplomacy.

Addressing the presentation ceremony, Hodges said the four students' achievement will further improve Taiwan's international profile and that their Web site design will allow the world to aquire a better understanding of Taiwan.

Chang Chia-wei, Hung Ching-ting, Chao Hsu-han and Chen Yen-yu won the first prize -- the platinum award -- among participants from 38 countries, with their project design titled "The Role of Taiwan in World Health -- International Medical Aid."
In addition to a certificate, each of the four students won US$2,000.
Chao expressed hope that the award-winning Web site will let the world know about Taiwan's contributions to medical aid and prompt more Taiwanese people to volunteer for international aid projects.
Five students from Taipei City's Chingshin Middle School also won the contest's silver award.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung city government to set up labor museum

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is slated to establish the country's first labor museum in the southern port city, municipal Labor Bureau officials said Wednesday.

The museum will be constructed at a storehouse area owned by the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. as part of the city government's efforts to promote one of the central government's projects to "activate" idle land and office and factory buildings owned by state-run enterprises around the country, according to the officials.
Since the end of World War II, the officials said, Kaohsiung has been developed into the most important industrial city in southern Taiwan.

Various industries have boomed in the city, including export processing, ship breaking, discarded metal processing, ship building, cement production, fuel refining, steel manufacturing, tourism and consumer electronics, as well as land, marine and air transport, the officials said.

The city government of Kaohsiung-- which is Taiwan's largest industrial city -- proposed building the labor museum with a research center to showcase a large variety of exhibits, including historical documents related to laborers, the officials went on.

Construction of the museum was originally the brainchild of former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who is now ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate for the 2008 presidential election. Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu included the idea as part of her platform in her bid to run in the Kaohsiung mayoral election that took place last December.
The construction budget for the museum, scheduled to open at the end of 2009, totals NT$100 million (US$3.03 million), the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT plans key weekly meeting in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung ordered party officials Wednesday to organize a party meeting in southern Taiwan to explain two key issues concerning the people's livelihoods to local residents.
Wu's remarks were quoted by members of the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) , which held its weekly meeting earlier the same day.

According to the CSC sources, Wu issued the order on a proposal by KMT lawmaker Ho Tsai-feng, also a CSC member, who urged the party to hold the weekly CSC meeting in southern Taiwan to explain the party's efforts in approving the government's NT$80 billion budget for a flood control program and its stance on granting stipends for elderly farmers.

Wu also expressed his hope of inviting Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, also a KMT member, to chair the meeting, tentatively slated to be held within two weeks, at a time when southern regions are recovering from serious flooding caused by Typhoon Sepat, which crossed Taiwan last Saturday, the sources said.

Hou suggested that the party central should hold the CSC meeting in southern Taiwan, claiming that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has been seeking to "pass the buck" for the disaster to the KMT by accusing that the NT$80 billion budget for flood prevention projects was delayed by the KMT at the Legislative Yuan, the sources said.
Hou also suggested inviting Wang to preside over the planned meeting to explain to the public how the KMT screened the budget, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-National Palace Museum curator, 14 others indicted for graft

TEXT.P: Former National Palace Museum Director Shih Shou-chien and 14 others were indicted Wednesday on charges of corruption in connection with the prestigious museum's recently completed renovation and expansion project.
Shih was head of the museum in suburban Taipei in 2004 when a contractor allegedly received a major portion of the renovation and expansion work without fully competing in the bidding process.
Prosecutors suggested in the indictment that Shih be given a 15-year prison term for his alleged role in the profiteering case.

Also indicted was Hsieh Fei-yuan, a museum advisor for whom prosecutors suggested an 18-year sentence. Meanwhile, prosecutors sought a 15-year prison term for Luo Hsing-hua, the architect who won the main part of the expansion contract.
The others indicted include lower-ranking museum officials and subcontractors, prosecutors said.
According to the indictment, the accused allegedly passed favors and possibly got kickbacks for awarding the work to the main contractor.

Prosecutors said the project's bidding process is suspected of having violated the Government Procurement Law by allowing the winning bidder of a NT$2.5 million initial planning contract to secure a follow-up NT$13.3 million design, supervision and service contract.
At issue was the NT$385 million museum renovation project that got underway in July 2004 and was not fully completed until late last year.

Suspecting possible irregularities in the bidding process after repeated cost overruns, the prosecutors launched massive raids on the offices and residences of architect Luo Hsing-hua and other contractors in late May, collecting a large number of files and documents.

A number of former and incumbent museum officials and former Public Construction Commission (PCC) officials have also been arraigned over the case. Among them is Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng, who served as the museum's director from 2000 through 2004. Tu was released after being quizzed by prosecutors earlier this month.

In February this year, the 42-year-old museum, which houses the best of the 1,000-year-old art collection of China's emperors, celebrated the reopening of its full exhibition area after the renovation. The project added a new viewing area for one of the world's largest collection of Chinese artifacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to finalize 'normal country resolution' draft next week

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is set to finalize the draft of a "normal country resolution" next week, a party official said Wednesday.

The official made the remarks shortly after the party's Central Executive Committee (CEC) held its first screening meeting on the draft version of the resolution, which is set to form an important part of the party's platform for the 2008 presidential election.

While most CEC members backed the party central's proposal to issue a "normal country resolution" as part of the party's platform for the 2008 election, the official said, some of them questioned the plausibility of certain parts of the draft resolution.
For instance, Frank Hsieh, the party's 2008 presidential candidate, said at the meeting that superficial and empty slogans can no longer impress people in this democratic era.

"During the previous martial law era, advocacy of freedom and democracy can easily move people. But the time has changed. Nowadays, everybody can publicly air their views and political preferences, including appeals for nation building or Taiwan independence, " Hsieh said, adding that he doesn't think that skin- deep political slogans can sway people into the DPP's fold any more.

In preparation for the coming election, Hsieh said, the DPP needs more soul searching and brainstorming sessions to hammer out policy initiatives that can effectively improve people's livelihoods. "Only by so doing can we win the hearts and minds of the voters, " Hsieh added.

It was decided at Wednesday's meeting that the party's nine-member panel responsible for drafting the "normal country resolution" will meet again Aug. 27 to revise certain provisions or wording, the party official said.
DPP lawmakers and Central Executive Committee members will also be invited to attend the meeting to present their views and opinions, the official said.

"The panel is expected to come up with a new version that incorporates views expressed by party bigwigs at the Aug. 27 meeting, " the official said, adding that the version will then be presented for approval of President Chen Shui-bian and Hsieh.

As Chen will not return from a Central American tour until Aug. 29, the official said, the party's Central Executive Committee will postpone its weekly meeting from Aug. 29 to Aug. 30 to make a final confirmation of the "normal country resolution, " which will then be presented to the party's national congress to be held in September for endorsement.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Secret papers disclose threat posed by killer The Home Secretary believes that Philip Lawrences killer poses a continuing risk to the public, according to papers that the courts tried to prevent being published. Learco Chindamo, now 26, has been rated as the highest level of risk and needs to be barred from parts of the country, the papers say. But the Asylum and Immigration Tribunal rejected the Governments argument in a ruling that makes clear it will be almost impossible to deport a serious criminal from an EU state if they have lived in Britain for more than five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Bush Takes a Step Away From Maliki
When President Bush and Nuri Kamal al- Maliki stood side by side in Jordan last November, the president proclaimed the prime ministeruthe right guy for Iraq.v
By Tuesday, that phrase had all but evaporated from Mr. Bushzs lexicon.
Instead, Mr. Bush acknowledgedua certain level of frustrationvwith the Iraqi government zs failure to unify its warring ethnic factions. His comments at a meeting of North American leaders in Canada came just hours after the top American diplomat in Baghdad, Ambassador Ryan C. Crocker, called political progress in Ir aquextremely disappointingvand warned that United States support for the Maliki government did not come with aublank check.v The Wall Street Journal: Fed Is Hopeful on Steps So Far
Federal Reserve officials are cautiously optimistic that the series of steps they have taken to stabilize markets have started to work.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Turns Up Heat on Maliki
President Bush pointedly declined Tuesday to offer a public endorsement of embattled Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki, expressing his disappointment at the lack of political progress in Iraq and saying that widespread popular frustration could lead Iraqis to replace their government.
The Washington Times: Bush denies planning for a superstate
President Bush and the leaders of Canada and Mexico yesterday ridiculed the notion that their countries are conspiring to create a regional supergovernment similar to the European Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 23, 2007

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Forecast on economic growth rate Date and Time: 05:00 p.m., Thursday, Aug. 23, 2007 Place: Directorate General of Budget Accounting and Statistics office Press Contact: Tel.: 2381-4910
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

In preparation for the coming election, Hsieh said, the DPP needs more soul searching and brainstorming sessions to hammer out policy initiatives that can effectively improve people's livelihoods. "Only by so doing can we win the hearts and minds of the voters, " Hsieh added.

It was decided at Wednesday's meeting that the party's nine-member panel responsible for drafting the "normal country resolution" will meet again Aug. 27 to revise certain provisions or wording, the party official said.
DPP lawmakers and Central Executive Committee members will also be invited to attend the meeting to present their views and opinions, the official said.

"The panel is expected to come up with a new version that incorporates views expressed by party bigwigs at the Aug. 27 meeting, " the official said, adding that the version will then be presented for approval of President Chen Shui-bian and Hsieh.

As Chen will not return from a Central American tour until Aug. 29, the official said, the party's Central Executive Committee will postpone its weekly meeting from Aug. 29 to Aug. 30 to make a final confirmation of the "normal country resolution, " which will then be presented to the party's national congress to be held in September for endorsement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 23, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1305: Sir William Wallace, Scottish patriot who demanded independence for his country, is hung, drawn and quartered in London.
1754: Louis XVI, king of France at the time of the outbreak of the French Revolution, is born.
1818: The first steamship service opens on the Great Lakes in North America.
1821: Mexico gains its independence.
1912: Gene Kelly, American dancer, choreographer, singer, actor and director, is born. He starred in Hollywood musicals, including "Anchors Aweigh," "Singin' in the Rain" and his "Invitation to Dance."
1914: Japan declares war on Germany.
1926: Screen actor Rudoph Valentino, the idol of millions, dies of peritonitis in New York's Polyclinic Hospital. He was 31. The Italian-born American actor was known for his romantic leading roles in silent films such as "The Sheik" and "Blood and Sand."
1927: In one of the most controversial cases in American legal history, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti are sent to the electric chair. In July 1921, a jury found the two Italian political anarchists and immigrants guilty of the murder of a factory paymaster and a guard during a robbery in South Braintree, Massachusetts.
1928: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung and Chu Teh, and their troops flee to Chingkangshan in Kiangsi Province after being outflanked and besieged by government forces from both the provinces of Hunan and Kiangsi.
1933: Gandhi is released from Poona jail after his hunger strike almost kills him.
1939: The USSR and Germany sign the Molotov-Ribbentropp Non-Aggression Pact, a terrible shock to the Western European leaders.
1940: German bombers begin night raids on London.
1945: Soviet troops occupy Manchuria.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a third invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him Aug. 14 to come to Chungking for a conference and the again Aug. 20.
1958: The Battle of the Taiwan Strait begins with Communist China firing 57,000 rounds in 2 hours at the islands of Kinmen. Many defenders are killed, including Gen. Chi Sing-wen, deputy commander of the Kinmen Garrison Command.
1963: Ambassador to the United States Tsiang Ting-fu signs the nuclear test ban treaty on behalf of the Republic of China.
1981: One hundred and ten people die in the crash of a Far Eastern Air Transport plane. The incident represents Taiwan's worst air disaster.
1990: East and West Germany choose October 3 as the date for reunification.
1990: Amenia declares its independence from Moscow.
1992: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with South Korea.
1998: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks his government and names former premier Viktor Chernomyrdin as acting prime minister.
1999: ROC Premier Vincent Siew is awarded an honorary doctorate in public service by Ohio State University.
2000: Eight mountaineers from Taiwan successfully climb to the 3,776-meter peak of Mount Fuji, thus writing a new page in climbing history.
2001: The 12th Taipei Chinese Food Fair, featuring various kinds of Chinese noodles and delicacies, opens with lively performances at the Taipei World Trade Center.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The Emperor Shun might perhaps be considered in the highest sense of the word a pious man. In moral qualities, he was a saint. In dignity of office, he was the ruler of the empire. In wealth, all that the wide world contained belonged to him."

DOC.HEADLINE: Transit arrangements in line with longstanding policy: U.S. official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/23/07 11:58:08 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government has arranged for President Chen Shui-bian's latest transit stops in the United States according to its longstanding policy and practice, a U.S. State Department official said Wednesday.
The official said the United States has always demonstrated the utmost concern for the people of Taiwan, rejecting Chen's criticism that the transit arrangements are humiliating to the Taiwan people.

Reportedly as a way of expressing its displeasure with the Chen administration's push for a referendum on the country's U.N. membership bid under the name of Taiwan, Washington has refused to allow Chen to stop over in major U.S. cities other than Anchorage, Alaska for his latest visit to Central America. Washington also reportedly refused to allow Chen to stay overnight during the transit stops.

During his brief transit stop in Anchorage Tuesday en route to Honduras -- the first leg of his three-nation Central America visit, Chen opted to stay on his chartered plane in what was seen as a gesture of protest against Washington's restrictions regarding his transit stops.

Speaking with American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Honorary Chairman William Brown, who boarded Chen's plane to greet him, the president reportedly described the treatment accorded to him as "inconvenient, uncomfortable and indecent," according to Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai.
Stressing the planned referendum is backed by a majority of the Taiwan people, Chen reportedly told Brown that the U.S.
restrictions concerning his transit stops are tantamount to punishment of the people of Taiwan, according to Chen Chi-mai.

The major purpose of Chen's Central America trip is to take part in the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the region to be held in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa.
The president will also visit El Salvador and Nicaragua before returning to Taiwan Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Democracy should not be subject to any 'red lines': president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan's efforts to deepen its democratic development, including a planned referendum on the country's U.N. bid, should not be subject to any red lines or suppression.
In particular, Taiwan's democracy should not be restricted just because China opposes it, Chen said in the latest issue of his online newsletter.
"Otherwise, we will send the wrong message to the dictators in Beijing that China can have its way with its military might, " Chen said.

Chen was referring to the U.S. objection to Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan" on the grounds that it could increase tensions across the Taiwan Strait -- an issue which has affected the arrangements of the president's plan to stop over in the United States for his latest visit to Central America.

Reportedly as a way of expressing its displeasure with the Chen administration's push for the referendum despite U.S. objections, Washington has refused to allow Chen to stop over in major U.S. cities other than Anchorage, Alaska or stay overnight during the transit stops.

According to Chen, because of the Taiwan-U.S. differences over the referendum plan, he opted to "simplify" the transit arrangements by stopping only briefly at Anchorage International Airport for refueling Tuesday without disembarking the plane.
"This has been an unprecedented experience for me in all of my foreign visits during my terms as president," Chen said.
"But for the sake of protecting Taiwan's national dignity and furthering the country's democracy, the courtesy, comfort and convenience for myself are of little importance," he said.
Taiwan must insist on its quest because "the well-being and future of the Taiwan people cannot be made bargaining chips or terms for any tradeoffs," the president said.

He further said that sticking to the Taiwan-centric consciousness, deepening Taiwan's democracy, and realizing social fairness and justice are courses that the country must take toward becoming a "normal country."

Despite the criticism and doubts over Taiwan's efforts to further its democratic development, the country is not discouraged because as long as it stands on the right side of history and on the side of the majority of the people, it will overcome any obstacles and difficulties, Chen said.
"We are convinced that a more democratic Taiwan will be more helpful to the maintenance of long-lasting peace across the Taiwan Strait," he said.

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange skyrocketed Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 239.38 points to close at 8,732.84.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't urged to crack down on poisonous bibs from China

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged the administration Thursday to crack down on lead-contaminated vinyl baby bibs from China which may pose a health threat to young children in the country.

Chou Mei-li, a TSU publicity chief, said the U.S. toy giant Toys "R" Us removed all store-brand vinyl baby bibs from its store shelves across the United States Aug. 17 after tests confirmed that at least some of the Chinese-made items contained excessive level of lead.

Some 160,000 bibs -- marketed under the Koala Baby, the Especially for Baby and Kidcosmic labels -- were taken off store shelves at Toys "R" Us and Babies "R" Us outlets across America, Chou said, adding that the management of Toys "R" Us Taiwan should at least give a public explanation about similar items that the company has been selling in its Taiwan stores.

Chou also called for the government to take the initiative in looking into baby bibs sold in Toys "R" Us stores and other made-in-China toys and baby products in other stores to see whether they pose a threat to children's health.

DOC.HEADLINE: El Salvador endorses Taiwan's U.N. membership bid
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/23/07 15:43:47 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: El Salvador offered its endorsement Wednesday of a motion supporting Taiwan's U.N. membership that was submitted to the world body last week, bringing to 16 the number of allies endorsing the motion, Taiwan officials posted in New York said.

The motion, which requests that the U.N. General Assembly press the Security Council to deal with Taiwan's membership application according to established procedures, was submitted Aug. 14 to the General Assembly, in the hope that the motion can be included on the agenda of the 62nd regular session of the General Assembly set to open Sept. 18 in New York.
The General Committee is expected to meet Sept. 19 to finalize the agenda of the session.

The other 15 diplomatic allies of Taiwan that have endorsed the motion are Belize, Burkina Faso, Gambia, Honduras, Kiribati, Malawi, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Palau, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Sao Tome and Principe, the Solomon Islands, Swaziland, and Tuvalu.

The Republic of China has tried without success to re-enter the United Nations since 1993. This year marks the first time it has changed tactics by bidding to join the world body under the name of Taiwan.

President Chen Shui-bian sent a membership application letter on behalf of Taiwan to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon July 19, but the letter was returned by Ban based on U.N. Resolution 2758, which U.N. officials said is the basis of the "one China" policy of the United Nations.

On July 31, Chen sent a second letter to Ban urging him to reconsider his decision and one to Wang Guangya, China's permanent representative to the United Nations, who served as rotating president of the Security Council for July. Both letters were also returned.

Taiwan has strongly protested Ban's move, claiming that only the Security Council and the General Assembly have the authority to review and decide on membership applications and that the U.N. Secretariat does not have the power to decide on such matters.
Also, Taiwan argued that Resolution 2758 neither grants China the right to represent Taiwan at the United Nations nor states that Taiwan is either a part of China or the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to help Honduras build hydraulic power plant
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Honduras, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/23/07 17:49:36 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian confirmed Wednesday that Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) will invest some NT$10 billion (US$303 million) to help build a hydraulic power plant in Honduras, which is one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America.

The proposed Patuca-3 Hydroelectric Project -- to be built on the Patuca River, Honduras' longest and most important waterway -- is essential if the ever- increasing demand for electricity in Honduras is to be met, Chen said, adding that Taipower has committed to offering its help to have the project completed.

Chen made the remarks in a speech at the Honduran National Congress. During the visit, the Honduran congressional speaker, Roberto Micheletti Bain, conferred the Medal of Golden Cross on President Chen in recognition of his contribution to cementing bilateral relations between the two countries.
In his speech, Chen said that based on the solid partnership that Taiwan shares with Honduras, Taiwan is obligated to help Honduras reduce poverty and develop infrastructure.

Meanwhile, he called for the Honduran Congress to pass the free trade agreement (FTA) that Honduras has signed with Taiwan to enable the mutually beneficial pact to come into force as soon as possible.

Later in the day, Chen joined Honduran President Jose Manuel Zela Rosales at a middle school where they witnessed the signing of a memorandum under which Taiwan will provide a US$5 million loan in support of a computerization project to be implemented in middle schools and elementary schools across Honduras.
Under the project, 3,000 computer centers will be built in Honduran schools over three years. Over 1 million students are expected to benefit from the project.

Addressing the memorandum-signing ceremony, Chen said he was told that the first such computer center will be named the "Chen Shui-bian Classroom," adding that he really does not deserve this. He said that he will suggest that the Honduran school name the first computer center the "Taiwan classroom, " since the contribution has been made by all the people of Taiwan.

Chen and his entourage arrived in the Honduran capital Tuesday for a three-day state visit. The president is scheduled to head to El Salvador Aug. 24 for another three-day visit before traveling on to Nicaragua Aug. 26.
He is set to conclude his Central American trip Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska, arriving in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mastodon fossils discovered in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Fossil remains of a newborn mastodon were recently discovered in the dry riverbed of Dajia River near Shih-kang village in Taichung County, sources at the Taichung Mountainview Community University reported Thursday.

They also noted that the discovery marks the first time that local archaeologists have found proof that Taiwan was once home to the prehistoric elephant species, which is estimated to have existed from about 28 million years ago to 10,000 years ago.

Mastodon fossils have been unearthed in the past in various areas in the Northern Hemisphere, including in northern China, Europe, and North America. However, they had never been found in Southeast Asia before the recent discovery in Taichung County, which makes the discovery especially remarkable, according to the university.
The fossil teeth discovered have been verified as having belonged to a young calf that lived in the neighboring areas sometime between 1.5 million and 1.8 million years ago.

Archaeologists at the university had previously discovered fossils of mammuthus -- also a species of prehistoric elephant -- in the adjacent areas, proving for the first time that this species existed in central Taiwan between 1.6 million and 2.2 million years ago.
