DOC.HEADLINE: Nangang Exhibition Hall to be inaugurated next spring

TEXT.P: The Taipei World Trade Center Nangang Exhibition Hall will be inaugurated in March 2008, with the first exhibition at the new venue to be the Taipei International Cycle Show, an executive of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Thursday.
Construction of the exhibition hall began in March 2005 and is scheduled to be completed in November this year at a price tag of US$110 million.
The new facility will help solve the problem of insufficient showground at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall in Xinyi district, TAITRA Deputy Secretary-General Yeh Ming-shui said.
Yeh on Wednesday introduced the new exhibition hall and schedule of 2008 Taipei International Trade Shows to representatives from other countries.

The two-storey exhibition hall in Taipei's Nangang district, with 2,465 standard booths and 620 parking spaces, is only 15-minute drive away from the existing Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall, according to Yeh.

Yeh invited foreign enterprises to utilize the venue and said that TAITRA will provide the best showground facilities and transportation for participants in shows at the venue. He said that exhibition booth rental fees will be at a similar level as those of the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall, adding that rental fees will be discounted during the opening period of the new venue.

A variety of exhibitions are scheduled to be held at the venue next year, including Taipei AMPA, Computex Taipei, Foodtech Taipei, Computex Taipei, Taipei Pack, Taitronics Autumn, and Creative Taiwan.

Noting that construction of the Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system's Neihu Line near the new exhibition venue has not yet been completed, Yeh said that the Taipei city government has promised to increase the number of bus routes and stops in the area and that TAITRA will also provide free shuttle bus services from the MRT's Kunyang Station for added convenience for visitors to the new venue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung to celebrate World Car Free Day Sept. 22

TEXT.P: Taichung will celebrate this year's World Car Fee Day Sept. 22 by calling on 2,000 residents to ride bicycles in the city to demonstrate their support for the movement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi said Thursday.
Noting that this will be the sixth consecutive year Taichung will have honored World Car Free Day, Hsiao urged residents in the central Taiwan city to take part to show their care for Mother Earth.

Hsiao said global warming is getting more serious and that everyone has an obligation to protect the environment. He encouraged people to use public transport or ride bicycles to work in order to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

He also said that to add extra fun to the activity, the Taichung city government will invite Liao Wu-hsiung, champion of the 2000 Asia bicycle stunt competition, to demonstrate his bicycle feats in front of the city government building.
World Car Free Day is celebrated by over 100 million people in about 1,500 cities around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: July export orders hit single-month record

TEXT.P: The value of Taiwan's export orders hit a new single-month high of US$29.72 billion in July, up 23.49 percent over the same month of last year, according to tallies released Thursday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Taiwan's industrial production also rose in July, MOEA officials said, pointing out that the industrial production index stood at 157.21 for July, marking an increase of 4.72 percent over that posted in June and an increase of 13 percent year-on-year.

Meanwhile, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported that Taiwan's overall economic growth was recorded as 4.18 percent in the first quarter of this year and that growth for Q2 was preliminarily determined as 5.07 percent.
The economy is estimated to grow 4.47 percent for Q3 and the growth is forecast to top 4.6 percent for Q4, DGBAS officials said.
The officials also said the country's consumer price index is expected to expand by an annual rate of 1.48 percent this year.

Meanwhile, DGBAS officials said the incomes of the top one-fifth of households recorded last year were 6.01 times greater than those of the bottom one-fifth, marking a slight fall from 2005's 6.04 times higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: Evergreen Symphony Orchestra to perform in Norway, Britain
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/23/07 18:51:04 (By Jennifer Huang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based Evergreen Symphony Orchestra (ESO) is scheduled to stage a total of three concerts in Norway and Britain in late August, marking its first ever performance s in Europe, concert sources said Wednesday.

The orchestra is staging the performances at the invitation of the Norway-based marine insurer Assurance foreningen Gard and the Lloyd's List, a London-based newspaper reporting shipping movements, maritime news and other commercial information, the sources said.

According to the sources, two concerts will be held in Norway to celebrate the Gard's 100th founding anniversary. The first concert will be staged Aug. 25 at at an indoor concert hall in Oslo, during which the orchestra will perform several Norwegian folk songs with Norwegian singer Sissel Kyrkjebo.
The repertoire will also include Wagner's "Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg" and Grieg's "Peer Gynt Suites No. 2".

Sissel, who sang on the soundtrack for the movie "Titanic" which sold over 30 million copies, has so far released eight solo albums and has been invited to perform for members of the British and Danish royal families.
The second concert will be held Aug. 26 at a plaza outside the concert hall and will be open to the public.

The concert in Britain will be staged at the Westminster Central Hall in London and will feature Taiwanese folk songs and "The Butterfly Lovers Violin Concerto" by famous violinist Lu Si-qing. Lu is the first Asian to win the gold medal in the International Paganini Competition held in Italy and is highly praised by the Western media.
The Evergreen Symphony Orchestra, which was formed in 2001, has toured Singapore, Tokyo, Shanghai, Beijing and Xiamen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wholesaler arrested for selling counterfeit fashion goods

TEXT.P: A wholesaler in Taipei has been arrested for suspected distribution of counterfeit fashion goods to retailers in southern Taiwan, police sources said Thursday.

Members of a police squad formed to protect intellectual property rights and crack down on commercial piracy found more than 1,000 items of fake brand-name fashion goods during a raid on a storehouse owned by the wholesaler in the Wufenpu shopping area in Taipei City's Songshan district, the sources said.

A large number of boutique clothing, sportswear and handbags carrying various fake brand-name labels, including Nike, Adidas, Puma, Levi's, Chanel and Burberry, were seized in the raid, the sources said.
All those items were believed to have been imported from China, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lead-contaminated Chinese toys not sold in Taiwan Toys 'R' Us

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Toys "R" Us store has not sold any of the lead-contaminated toys that have been pulled from store shelves in the United States, a corporate source claimed Thursday.

Noting that Taiwan Toys "R" Us has a different outsourcing system from those of the U.S.-based Toys "R" Us and Babies "R" Us, a Taiwan Toys "R" Us spokesman said products lines carried in the company's outlets in Taiwan are thus different from those found in stores in the United States.

Meanwhile, responding to a call by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) to the administration Thursday to investigate the possibility of similar lead- contaminated vinyl baby bibs from China that have been removed from Toys "R" Us and Babies "R" Us across America having been displayed and sold in Taiwan Toys "R" Us stores, the spokesman claimed that similar products have been imported by the company and put on shelves only after passing tests and checks by relevant government agencies here.
The baby bibs that have been sold by Taiwan Toys "R" Us have also passed safety checks by the British Intertek Laboratory, the spokesman said.

Chou Mei-li, a TSU publicity chief, said earlier in the day that U.S. toy giant Toys "R" Us removed all store-brand vinyl baby bibs from its shelves across the United States Aug. 17 after tests confirmed that at least some of the Chinese- made items contained excessive levels of lead.

Chou said that some 160,000 bibs -- marketed under the Koala Baby, the Especially for Baby and Kidcosmic labels -- were taken off the shelves across America, adding that the management of Toys "R" Us Taiwan should at least give a public explanation about similar items that the company is continuing to sell in its Taiwan stores.

Chou also called on the government to take the initiative in investigating baby bibs sold in Toys "R" Us stores and other made-in-China toys and baby products in other stores to see whether they pose a threat to children's health.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economic growth for 2007 estimated at 4.58%

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to achieve an economic growth rate of 4.58 percent for 2007, according to statistics released Thursday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The DGBAS originally predicted Taiwan's economic growth for 2007 at 4.3 percent in a February estimate, but marked up the rate to 4.38 percent in May. Three months later, it revised the rate further up to 4.58 percent.

The economic growth rate for the first quarter of 2007 was also adjusted upward from the estimated 4.15 percent in May to 4.18 percent, with the growth rates for the second to fourth quarters estimated at 5.07 percent, 4.47 percent and 4.6 percent, respectively.
The DGBAS also predicted that Taiwan's consumer price index for 2007 will go up by 1.48 percent from 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL chairman offers to resign over plane blaze

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) said Wednesday that he has offered to resign over the recent explosion of a CAL plane at Naha International Airport on the Japanese island of Okinawa.

Philip Wei, who is accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on a visit to the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa, said he told the company's highest supervision authority -- Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei -- immediately after learning of the mishap that he would be prepared to resign to take token responsibility if required.
A CAL Boeing 737-800 caught fire and exploded at the Okinawa airport Monday. All passengers and crew members managed to escape alive before the plane exploded.

Even before learning about the result of the accident, Wei said he had told Tsai that he would be willing to assume full responsibility if the initial investigations show that the blaze resulted from CAL's negligence or fault.

Wei said he originally intended to cancel his travel plan with the president after the fire, but changed his mind and decided to accompany Chen to Central America after learning that there were no casualties.
Wei said he had dispatched the company's general manager to Japan to handle relevant affairs.

Asked whether he was instructed to shoulder the responsibility for the accident, Wei said that "no one asked me to leave." He said he is now waiting for the result of a probe into the explosion, he added.
Meanwhile, in Taipei, Tsai said in response to media inquiries about his stance on Wei's resignation offer that he will not deal with the matter until after Wei's return.

Tsai also serves as chairman of the Taipei-based China Aviation Development Foundation, which is CAL's largest stockholder. Flight CI-120 burst into flames shortly after landing in Naha Monday morning.

The plane had just pulled up to the gate to disembark passengers when its left engine caught fire and exploded. All 157 passengers, including 17 Japanese citizens, 24 other foreign nationals and eight crew members managed to escape before fire engulfed the entire plane. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's aide defends financial loan to ally
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Honduras, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/23/07 20:40:29 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: An official of the Presidential Office has defended Taiwan's US$5 million loan to its diplomatic ally Honduras as "humanitarian aid aimed at helping other developing countries accelerate national development."

Lee Nan-yang, director of the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs, who is accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on a trip to three of the country's allies in Central America, made the remarks after learning that Taiwan's media had criticized the loan as "checkbook diplomacy."

Lee said Honduran President Jose Manuel Zela Rosales has vowed to establish a computer center in an effort to raise the Central American country's education level and that Taiwan wants to provide the loan as humanitarian aid rather than giving the money away.

Citing the results of a survey, Lee said computer usage among the Honduran public is a mere 3.7 percent, adding that only 19 percent of the faculty and staff at primary and junior high schools in Honduras have access to computers and that only 34 percent of the students have used the Internet.
The loan plan is expected to benefit 3,000 schools in Honduras, 1,000 of which will be equipped with Internet access, Lee went on.

In addition, Taiwan hopes to use its advanced technology to help other countries bridge the digital divide, which Lee said is on the the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting agenda this year.

Speaking on a Taiwan Power Co. NT$10 billion (US$303 million) cooperation project with Honduras for the development of a hydraulic power plant, Lee said it is a build-operate-transfer (BOT) investment project and that the Honduran government will need to pay off the loan over 39 years from its electricity revenues.
Lee said the government aims to help its Central American allies utilize hydroelectric power to address their energy problems.
Chen will later visit El Salvador and Nicaragua before returning to Taiwan Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Honduras offers land for Taiwan hi-tech investment
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Honduras, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/23/07 20:48:30 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Honduran President Jose Manuel Zela Rosales invited two Taiwanese high- technology companies Wednesday to build manufacturing plants in Honduras, saying that the two companies would be given plots of land free of charge on which to build.

Zela invited Taiwan-based High Tech Computer Corp. (HTC) -- a maker of mobile phones with touch panels -- and Elitegroup -- a manufacturer of PCs and computer peripherals -- to relocate part of their manufacturing operations to the Central American country.

According to Zela, visiting President Chen Shui-bian challenged him the night before that if he could find two pieces of land for use by two Taiwanese companies, Chen would in turn persuade two companies to invest in Honduras.
Zela said he told Chen he had found two pieces of land and that he hoped HTC and Elitegroup would respond his invitation by starting to think about investing in Honduras.

Zela made the remarks Wednesday after he joined Chen at a middle school where they witnessed the signing of a memorandum under which Taiwan will provide a US$5 million loan in support of a computerization project to be implemented in middle schools and elementary schools across Honduras.
Under the project, 3,000 computer centers will be built in Honduran schools over three years. Over 1 million students are expected to benefit from the project.

Welcoming Zela's offer, Chen Chi-mai, a deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office traveling with President Chen on the three-nation Central American trip, said that if the two Taiwanese companies agree, the administration will also offer incentives to them in accordance with a project designed to encourage increased Taiwanese investment in diplomatic allies in Latin America.

Chen Chi-mai noted that as two-way trade between China and Honduras has increased by leaps and bounds in recent years, Honduras and other Taiwanese allies in the region are hoping that more Taiwanese companies will invest more in Honduras and bring in more funds and technology to rev up bilateral trade and counter pressure from China.

He added that the increasing presence of Chinese influence in Guatemala -- another of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America -- particularly in Guatemalan power plants, is now setting off alarm bells for Taiwan when it comes to the "diplomatic tug of war."

President Chen and his entourage arrived in the Honduran capital Tuesday for a three-day state visit. He is scheduled to head for El Salvador Aug. 24 for another three-day visit before traveling on to Nicaragua Aug. 26.
He is set to conclude his Central American trip Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska, arriving in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Annual gay pride parade slated for Oct. 13

TEXT.P: Taiwan's fifth gay pride parade -- Taiwan Pride 2007 -- to be organized by the gay and transgender communities, is slated to take place Oct. 13 in Taipei City with the aim of urging politicians to make laws regarding equal rights for homosexuals, such as legalization of same-sex marriages, an organizer of the event said Thursday.
Titled "Rainbow Power, " this year's parade will call on gay communities around Taiwan to join the campaign in order to have more people voice the parade's appeal.

The Taiwan Tongzhi Hotline Association president, who goes by the pseudonym Gofyy and who is also the parade's organizer, said last year's parade attracted more than 10,000 people, including members of more than 80 homosexual groups.

Gofyy estimated that Taiwan has at least 1 million homosexuals, which constitute an influential group and a crucial minority for the "single-member constituency, two-vote" electoral system, and so is worth attention from politicians.

Gender/Sexuality Rights Association Taiwan Secretary-General Wang Ping said this year's parade will start from the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, where a group will perform a skit to represent their appeal. The group will then march to Taipei City Hall.

Other groups taking part in preparations for the parade include the Taiwan TG Butterfly Garden, the Tong-Kwang Lighthouse Presbyterian Church, the LesHand Association, the Gin Gin Bookstore, the Gay and Lesbian Teachers' Union and Gay House, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four cases recorded of Chinese people buying Taiwanese real estate

TEXT.P: Only four applications from Chinese citizens for purchasing real estate in Taiwan have been approved since the government began allowing the practice in 2002, according to a news release issued by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Thursday.

The reason so few applications have been approved is that Beijing not only imposes strict measures to control its foreign exchange reserves but has also been reluctant to list Taiwan as a place in which Chinese people can purchase real estate, the news release said.

The MOI drew up regulations governing Chinese people acquiring, creating or transferring property rights on Taiwanese real estate Aug. 8, 2002 after the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) began allowing Chinese people to buy and own real estate in Taiwan under certain conditions.

According to the MOI, no approval will be granted for applications by Chinese people, corporations or groups, or companies funded with Chinese money to buy real estate in Taiwan if such a purchase is deemed to possibly endanger national security or social order.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins medals in Informatics Olympiad

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese team of four local high school students have won two gold medals, one silver and one bronze in the 19th International Informatics Olympiad that ended Wednesday in Croatia.
It is the best result since the country has been participating in the annual event.

Ho Po-chang, a gold medal winner and third-year student at the Affiliated Senior High School of National Taiwan Normal University, said he started to learn how to write computer programs when he joined a club at the school.
Ho said he later became obsessed with breaking computer programs and described writing code as important part of his life.

In his second year, Ho ranked fourth in a national Internet program design contest and won third place in an information contest organized by the Taipei city government. He will become a freshman at the Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering of National Taiwan University (NTU) this year.
The other gold medalist, Huang Shang-en, who is a third-year student at Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School, said he started to learn about computer programs three years ago.
In his third year, Huang won second places in national and Taipei City competitions in the areas of math and information. He will enroll in NTU's Mathematics Department this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Automation exhibition presents Taiwan robots

TEXT.P: Taiwan-made robots with versatile functions on display at the ongoing 2007 Taipei International Industrial Automation Exhibition indicate both a strong R&D capability and a growing competitiveness in local manufacturers, a senior official of Taiwan's Robotics Association said Thursday.

Making examples of several of the robots on display, the association's director- general, Cho Yung-tsai, said a robotic arm developed by a local company has proved helpful with in-vitro fertilization, while a "robot tutor" is designed to facilitate child learning and offer day-care functions and a security robot can protect households from unwelcome intruders.

Cho explained that as the global demand for robots surges, robot functions will surely further expand to cover services such as entertainment, personal protection, medical care, education and training.

As the industry shows signs of fast expansion, this year's Industrial Automation Exhibition taking place Aug. 23-26 at the Taipei World Trade Center -- has introduced a theme area for robots for the first time since its premiere in 2004, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan defends foreign aid projects

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign aid projects should not be criticized because they are conducive to Taiwan's diplomacy and do not account for a high proportion of the general budget of the central government, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said Thursday.

Chen made the remarks in defense of President Chen Shui-bian's promise to have state-owned Taiwan Power Co. help build a hydraulic power plant in Honduras, which is one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, with investment of up to NT$10 billion (US$303 million).

Opposition lawmakers questioned the president's diplomatic strategy of spending such a huge amount of money on foreign aid when Taiwan and Honduras has bilateral trade of only US$43 million per year, which accounts for only 0.01 percent of Taiwan's total trade volume. They described the project as another case of "checkbook diplomacy."
Chen said Taiwan's foreign aid projects do not deserve such "negative wording," stressing that the foreign aid budget is "reasonably used and under control."
He said that although next year's diplomatic budget is NT$31.6 billion (US$956.13 million), up 10.1 percent over 2007's figure, the foreign aid budget remains the same.

Taiwan's foreign aid budget is much less than member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), representing only 0.14 percent of Taiwan's annual gross domestic product (GDP) and 0.12 percent of the government's annual budget.
The average foreign aid budget of OECD members is between 0.25-0.3 percent of their annual government budget, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: January-June regular wage rise hits 7-year high: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Local wage earners' regular average monthly wage stood at NT$36,530 (US$1,105) in the first half of this year, marking a 1.53 percent rise year-on-year, an official of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Thursday.
The growth rate was the highest in seven years, the official said.
The official further noted that June marked the 13th consecutive month that the average increase has surpassed 1 percent, which he described as a strong signal of a rising trend.
Regular wage refers to the base pay, including holiday pay, vacation pay and sick time pay, but excluding overtime pay and irregular bonus pay.
The average wage during the January-June period was NT$48,174, up 1.64 percent from the same period of last year, according to the official.
In addition, the official said the number of new employees during the first six- month period saw an annual increase of 95,000 to register 6.09 million.
The growth is the fourth-highest of the same period over the recent seven years, indicating steady growth in the local labor market, the official went on.

During the first six months of this year, the industrial sector registered a 1.44 percent rise of new employees from last year, while the service sector posted a 1.71 percent increase, the official said.
The manufacturing industry recruited the greatest number of 31,000 new employees during the same period, the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fuel tank of CAL blaze plane pierced by loose bolt: investigators

TEXT.P: A loose bolt from the right wing slat of the Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) Boeing 737-800 that was gutted by fire at Okinawa's Naha International Airport three days ago pierced a fuel tank, causing a leak that triggered a fire and explosion, Taiwan's top official in charge of aviation safety said Thursday.

Yang Hung-chih, executive director of the Cabinet-level Aviation Safety Council, said Japanese investigators had discovered a bolt that came off the wing slat and established the cause of the fuel leak but was still trying to find out why the bolt came off.

Yang said Japan's Aircraft and Railway Accidents Investigation Commission was leading the investigation into the cause of the accident and that he was only giving a technical description of the cause with the consent of the Japanese side.
He noted that Boeing had reported in March last year two accidents in which wing leading edge bolts had come off, one of which also caused a fuel leak.

Although Boeing suggested that all B737-600s, B737-700s, B737-800s and B737-900s should have their wing leading edge slats inspected, the company did not require airlines using these aircraft to replace the nuts and bolts.
He said CAL maintenance personnel had inspected the wing slats of its Boeing 737-800 fleet after receiving the notice from Boeing.
Meanwhile, wire service reports from Tokyo said Japanese investigators had discovered a 2-3-centimeter hole in the fuel tank of the ill-fated aircraft.

Wing slats are movable auxiliary airfoils running along the leading edge of the wings. They can be retracted to help increase the plane's lift during take-off or extended to maximize the plane's drag during landing.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reaffirms belief in international justice
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Honduras, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/23/07 23:22:08 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that despite facing an unfavorable diplomatic reality, he still believes in the existence of justice and righteousness in the international community.
Chen, who is on a three-day state visit to Honduras, made the remarks while giving a series of interviews with international news media.

Responding to questions about a possible domino effect following Costa Rica's switch of diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing in June, Chen said he understands that the diplomatic reality is unfavorable to Taiwan.
Nevertheless, he said he is convinced that shared values in freedom and democracy are the bedrock of Taiwan's relationship with its diplomatic allies.
For all the diplomatic setbacks and challenges, Chen said, he remains confident in international justice and righteousness.

Following the breakup of ROC-Costa Rica diplomatic ties, Chen said all of Taiwan's other Central American diplomatic allies immediately reaffirmed their commitment to maintaining official relations with Taiwan.
Touching on Taiwan's aid to Honduras, Chen said all donations or loans to the Honduran government have been conducted in a transparent manner, with news media invited to witness relevant ceremonies.

In an effort to discount speculation that Taiwan might be engaging in "checkbook diplomacy, " Chen said many of Taiwan's aid projects have been carried out in the form of participating in Honduras' build-operate-transfer investment projects rather than through outright cash donations.

Asked about Taiwan's strategies toward China's fast rise as an economic powerhouse, Chen said his frequent grueling diplomatic tours around the world are aimed at telling the world that Taiwan will not succumb to the Communist Party of China's threat.

Chen and his entourage arrived in the Honduran capital Tuesday for a three-day state visit. He is scheduled to head for El Salvador Aug. 24 for another three- day visit before traveling on to Nicaragua Aug. 26.
He is set to wrap up his Central American visit Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska, arriving in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 25, or the 13th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1718: The city of New Orleans, named in honor of the Duke of Orleans of France, is founded.
1819: Allan Pinkerton, Scottish-born founder of the famous Pinkerton National Detective Agency in the United States, which specialized in railroad theft, is born.
1822: Sir William Herschel, the German-born English astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, dies at the age of 84. He also cataloged more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1825: Uruguay declares independence from Spain.
1867: Michael Faraday, the English chemist and physicist who invented the first electrical cell (battery), dies at the age of 76.
1875: Englishman Matthew Webb makes history by becoming the first person to swim the English Channel. The 27-year-old master mariner covers the 34-km stretch from Dover to Calais in 21 hours 45 minutes.
1900: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the German philosopher whose written works include "Thus Spake Zarathustra," dies at the age of 55. He reasons that Christianity's emphasis on the afterlife makes its believers less able to cope with earthly life.
1912: The Chung-kuo ke-ming tung-meng hui (Society of the Common Cause) is reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) and holds its inauguration meeting in Beijing.
1917: Dr. Sun Yat-sen forms a military government in Canton, southern China.
1919: The first scheduled international air service begins between Paris and London.
1921: Germany and the United States sign a peace treaty ending the state of war between them.
1930: Sean Connery, the Scottish actor who played the leading role as "007" in seven James Bond movies and won an Oscar for best supporting actor in "The Untouchables," is born.
1940: Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are incorporated into the Soviet Union.
1943: Lord Louis Mountbatten is appointed Supreme Allied Commander in Southeast Asia.
1944: Paris is liberated when the local German commander, General von Choltitz, surrenders to the Allies, ending a four-year long ordeal that Paris and her citizens suffered at the hands of the Nazis.
1945: Vietnamese communist leader Ho Chi Minh announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (DRV).
1989: The spacecraft Voyager 2 beams back to earth pictures of Neptune.
1960: The Republic of China Olympic team carries a large sign reading "Under Protest" in the opening procession of the Olympic Games in Rome to protest the International Olympic Committee's ruling compelling ROC athletes to compete under the name of "Taiwan" instead of the "Republic of China."
1961: The second phase of the Yangmingshan Forum opens to study the ROC's educational and cultural issues.
1968: Lesotho Premier Leabua Jonathan arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1986: ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports open in Taipei. Both sides failed to settle disagreements on pricing and advertising for American products during the nine-day talks, and a new round of negotiations was planned.
1991: Byelorussia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1992: Niger's Prime Minister Amadou Cheiffou arrives in the ROC to advance mutual understanding between the two countries.
2001: The opposition People First Party (PFP) unveils the theme of "respect for history, acknowledgment of reality and joint efforts for peace" as the guidelines of its mainland China policy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "For God in giving life to all created things is surely bountiful to them according to their qualities. Hence the tree that is full of life He fosters and sustains, while that which is ready to fall He cuts down and destroys."

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen arrives in El Salvador
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/25/07 14:41:07 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in El Salvador Friday from Honduras to continue his three-nation Central America visit.

Chen received a warm welcome at the San Salvador international airport from the country's president, vice president, president of the Legislative Assembly, and president of the Supreme Court of Justice.
In a grand welcome ceremony, Chen inspected with his Salvadoran counterpart, Antonio Saca, the country's military honor guards, before Saca gave his formal greetings to Chen and his entourage.
Saca said his country shares with Taiwan the same ideas and principles of pursuing democracy, national progress and sustainable development.

He further said that President Chen's visit is an opportunity for El Salvador to reiterate its admiration of Taiwan's achievements in realizing these ideas and its support for Taiwan's ceaseless struggle for its existence in the international community.

Saca noted that during Chen's state visit, the two sides will act to strengthen their dialogue, which will serve efforts to seek better living conditions for their people and will serve as a bridge in enhancing their friendship, understanding and communications.
In his address, Chen mentioned that he last visited El Salvador in May 2001. Since then, Saca has twice visited Taiwan, in 2004 and 2006, he added.

Describing El Salvador as Taiwan's closest and most faithful friend, Chen said that he and Saca share a close friendship and treat each other as brothers. The Salvadoran people are also the closest friends of the Taiwan people, he added.

Chen also expressed his gratitude to Saca for his reassurance at a press conference in Honduras following the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the region Thursday that El Salvador will continue to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan and firmly support Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations.
Chen added that Saca has said that he will attend the U.N. General Assembly to be held in New York next month and will speak in support of Taiwan's bid in person at the general debate session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Solidarity Union sets up Taitung chapter

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) inaugurated its Taitung chapter Saturday, making it the second largest political party in the southeastern county.
The TSU's Taitung chapter has 400 members, including a township administrator and two elected rural township representatives, according to the party.
TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei presided over the inauguration ceremony, during which he presented a party flag to the chapter's first director, Chen Sheng- chung.
Outlining his long-term goals, Chen said he vows to gain seats for the "pan- green camp, " which is led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, in the Taitung County Council.

The TSU, founded in August 2001, is the first political party in Taiwan to include the word "Taiwan" in its name. Dedicated to promoting nationalism, freedom and democracy, as well as clean and efficient government, the party views former President Lee Teng-hui as its spiritual leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chairman to greet President Chen on transit stop in Alaska
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/25/07 16:53:52 (By Jorge Liu and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt will greet President Chen Shui-bian in person when Chen makes a transit stop in Anchorage, Alaska, Aug. 29 en route home from his three-nation Central America visit.
Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States, Stanley Kao, made the remarks at a news conference at Taiwan's representative office in Washington, D.C., Friday.
Burghardt is the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Kao said Burghardt was in Hawaii on official business and so was not able to greet Chen Aug. 21 when the president made a transit stop in Anchorage on his way to Central America to attend the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the region held in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa.

Chen was therefore greeted by William Brown, AIT honorary chairman, Kao said, adding that the U.S. government had informed the representative office about the arrangements prior to Chen's arrival in Anchorage.

The U.S. government has reportedly refused to allow President Chen to stop over in any major U.S. city other than Anchorage, Alaska for his latest visit to Central America or to stay overnight during his transit stops in order to show its displeasure with the Taiwan government's push for a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.

When Brown boarded Chen's plane in Anchorage to greet him on his first stopover, the president described the treatment he had received from the U.S. government as "inconvenient, uncomfortable and indecent, " according to Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai. President Chen did not disembark the plane during the stopover.
The president also said that he hopes the U.S. government will follow established conventions in making arrangements for visiting high-level Taiwan officials.

Asked whether U.S. authorities would accept President Chen's suggestion that the Bush administration send a delegation to Taipei for direct dialogue on the U.N. bid issue, Kao said he believes that the U.S. side has been informed of Chen's proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Relief subsidies to cover damaged farming equipment: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Saturday that the government will provide relief subsidies to farmers who suffered crop losses and damage to equipment in recent storms.
Chang made the remarks at the Yenchao Main Workshop, which is the Taiwan High Speed Rail's maintenance base in the southern County of Kaohsiung Saturday.

The subsidies for damaged equipment was added this year into the government's existing subsidy system which covers crop losses and offers low-interest loans to farmers, Chang said, adding that the new policy will help farmers cover their costs of purchasing equipment and materials such as seeds and fertilizer.

He expressed his gratitude for farmers' efforts and their contribution to the country's economy and assured them that the government will stand by their side to help them overcome their financial difficulties.

Chang also inspected the Taiwan High Speed Rail's operations, during which he stressed that the aim of the high speed railway is to provide the public with comfortable, safe and convenient transportation. He encouraged the operator to continue improving service quality.

He further said that it is inevitable that the high speed rail will have an impact on the business of other transportation operators, and even on the operations of hotels. He called on businesses in the service sector to come up with measures to overcome future challenges.

DOC.HEADLINE: President expresses gratitude for El Salvador's friendship, support
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/25/07 19:31:40 (By Ramon Huang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian expressed his gratitude for El Salvador's longstanding and steadfast friendship and full support for Taiwan's bid to join international organizations in his speech delivered at the Salvadoran Legislative Assembly Friday.
Chen visited the legislative assembly just hours after arriving in the country from Honduras for the second leg of his three-nation Central America visit that will also take him to Nicaragua.

In his first ever speech to the Salvadoran legislature, Chen compared Taiwan's efforts in pursuing freedom and democracy with those of El Salvador, adding the two countries share many similar experiences in this pursuit.

Chen said El Salvador was wracked by 12 years of civil war before the signing of a peace agreement under U.N. mediation Jan. 16, 1992. The country then began efforts to establish a democratic and constitutional government, he noted, adding that he was impressed by the Salvadoran people's diligence which helped the country become a model of democracy for countries around the world in a short period of just 15 years.
He described El Salvador as a "phoenix rising from the ashes."
Speaking about Taiwan, the president said his country is celebrating this year the 20th anniversary of the lifting of martial law.
In 1991, Taiwan began holding legislative elections for all seats in both the Legislative Yuan and the National Assembly, and then in 1996 it held its first direct presidential election, Chen said.

Noting that Taiwan experienced its first transfer of power between political parties in 2000 when he was elected president as the candidate of an opposition party, Chen said he is very proud of this fact.

Chen further said that he has worked to consolidate Taiwan's democracy during his time in office, noting he put forward Taiwan's first Referendum Law in 2003 and oversaw Taiwan's first national referendum in 2004, and that he has also pushed several major constitutional reforms since assuming office.
However, Chen said, despite its world-acclaimed democratic achievements, Taiwan is still not recognized as a "normal country."
Due to China's suppression, Taiwan has been prevented from joining many international organizations such as the United Nations and the World Health Organization, he said.

Nevertheless, Taiwan will never give up its efforts, he stressed, pointing out that recent surveys show that 77 percent of the Taiwan people want to see the country become a member of the United Nations.

Chen said that with this strong support, his government began to push for a referendum on whether Taiwan should apply to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan. He explained that holding such a referendum will give the Taiwan people the opportunity to directly convey their wish to the world body.

In the speech, President Chen also extended his appreciation for Salvadoran Legislative Assembly's passage Aug. 10 of a free trade agreement, which was forged by the governments of the two countries in May.

Chen said he expects that Taiwan's Legislative Yuan will also pass the agreement, which he described as a milestone in Taiwan-Salvadoran trade and economic cooperation, in the near future, adding that he anticipates that the pact will take effect at the beginning of next year.

After the speech, Chen was presented by the assembly president, Ruben Orellana, with a copy of a resolution passed by the legislature to grant Chen with the country's highest honor for a foreign friend in recognition of his contributions to the country through various technical assistance and aid programs.

Others present at the gathering included members of the Legislative Assembly presidium, leaders of legislative caucuses of the country's political parties, assembly members, the president of the Supreme Court of Justice, grand justices, high-ranking executive officials and foreign diplomats stationed in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPA concerned about possible 'domino effect' if Maokong rezoned

TEXT.P: Urban planning officials said Saturday they are concerned about a possible "domino effect" if the Taipei City government's Maokong rezoning plan is approved.

The officials from the Ministry of the Interior's Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) were referring to the city government's urban development plan for a protected area in Wenshan District in suburban Taipei, commonly known as Maokong.

The city government referred the development plan to the CPA for approval in 2006. The plan covers 238 hectares of protected land encompassing slopes and other geological formations as well as many intertwining footpaths. It marks the first time that such a large plot of protected land will be put up for rezoning and development.
Earlier this week, the officials said, the CPA arranged for members of its urban planning commission to inspect the site to be rezoned under the city government's development plan.

"Members of the commission are most concerned about whether approval of the Maokong rezoning plan will cause a 'domino effect, ' with owners of land plots in protected areas in the city's Nangang, Neihu and Beitou districts demanding similar treatment, " a CPA official said, adding that the CPA will ask the city government to furnish it with an assessment report on this question.
Moreover, the official said, the city government should also come up with a report on the main purposes and functions of its Maoking rezoning and urban development plan.

"The CPA's urban planning commission members are also concerned about whether individual land development applicants in the area should be required to produce concrete development projects and financial planning reports for the city government's screening if the rezoning plan is approved," the official said.

Meanwhile, the official said, the city government should also present a report on requiring would-be land developers to share environmental protection obligations and on formulation of a feedback mechanism.
The CPA's urban planning commission will continue screening the plan after the city government produces all relevant reports and data, the official said.

Maokong used to be the largest tea growing area in Taipei. There are many winding footpaths which have been used to transport tea. Now, it's a popular place for tea culture and viewing the night scenery of Taipei City. The recent inauguration of the Maokong Gondola has added yet another tourist attraction to the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG An arrest - but still police meet silence Simmering tension threatened to erupt into violence in Liverpool last night as police confronted bitterness and anger among residents in the community that was home to Rhys Jones. The 11-year-old schoolboys murder has exposed a widening divide between Merseyside Police and those who live in the Croxteth Park area of the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traditional aboriginal medicine center inaugurated in Pingtung

TEXT.P: A cultural and health promotion center of traditional Taiwan aboriginal medicine was inaugurated in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, Saturday as part of local efforts to preserve traditional aboriginal medicine and therapy.

The facility, set up at the Pingtung aboriginal culture hostel, has been promoted by the Pingtung Christian Hospital (PCH) with the support of the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) under the Executive Yuan.

The center will focus on collecting data and artifacts related to traditional aboriginal medicine, as well as conducting scientific research on the medicine's legendary effect of maintaining and improving aboriginal people's health, according to the PCH.

Chi Ming-hsi, chief of the CIP's health welfare department, and PCH President Cho Sung-teh jointly opened the cultural center during a blessing ceremony performed by medicine men and women of the Paiwan tribe -- one of the two major indigenous tribes in southern Taiwan along with the Rukai tribe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Patients with rare disorders enjoy sports competition

TEXT.P: With the help of physical therapists and family members, about 100 patients with rare disorders enjoyed some fun taking part in a sports meet in Taipei Saturday afternoon.

The sports meet, which was organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Rare Disorders (TFRD) as the first ever sporting event in Taiwan for patients with rare disorders, gathered 89 patients of all ages suffering from various disorders.

The participants were divided into four groups and competed in various events, including batting, basketball shooting and soccer ball kicking competitions as well as foot races, during the three-hour meet.

Organizers of the event said that most of the participants have one of three disorders, namely Prader-Willi Syndrome, a complex genetic disorder that typically causes cognitive disabilities and obesity; Anchondroplasia, a genetic disorder that is a common cause of dwarfism; or Tuberous Sclerosis, which causes benign tumors to grow in the brain and on other organs.

One of the participants, named Wu Chih-kang, 26, has been suffering from Wilson's Disease since his junior year at National Cheng Kung University. Wu, a basketball fanatic who said he could dunk a basketball when he was younger, has been recovering well after more than six years of rehabilitation.
Wilson's Disease is one of more than 130 rare disorders which have been found in Taiwan, according to a TFRD news release.

"Most people think that it's better for patients with rare disorders to stay indoors and rest as much as possible. In fact, appropriate exercise is good for them, " said Chien Wen-jen, president of the National Federation of Association of Physical Therapists (NFAPT).

"Without a doubt, patients with rare disorders need professional medical care at all times. However, the physiological and mental development aspect has often been neglected. This event aims to remind the patients and their families of just that, " said TFRD chief executive officer Yang Yung-hsiang.

NFAPT and sporting goods giant adidas Taiwan co-sponsored the event. Singer Tank and local professional basketball players Lee Hsueh-lin, Chang Chi-fung, Chien Chia-hung and Chen Tzu-wei also took part in the charity event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rep office skeptical about reports of U.S. efforts against U.N. bid
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/25/07 21:33:11 (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan official stationed in Washington said Friday he has taken reports about U. S. efforts to persuade Taiwan's diplomatic allies to vote against its U.N. bid at this year's U.N. General Committee session with "grain of salt."

Stanley Kao, the Republic of China's deputy representative to the United States, was referring to an article written by Bonnie Glaser, a senior associate at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

Glaser said in the article that President Chen Shui-bian's push for a referendum on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan could prompt Taiwan-U.S. relations into a dangerous quagmire as the Bush administration may adopt a series of punitive measures, including lobbying Taiwan's diplomatic allies to vote against Taiwan when the U.N. General Committee discusses in September whether to include Taiwan's membership bid into the General Assembly agenda.
Kao said while meeting with Taiwan reporters stationed in the U.S. capital that the ROC representative office took such a report with "pinch of salt."

As to the ROC allies' stance toward the U.N. bid, Kao said 15 allies have signed a letter asking the U.N. General Assembly to address Taiwan's representation issue at its upcoming annual session. Moreover, he said, senior leaders of the countries allies in Central America have voiced support for Taiwan's U.N. bid when they attended a leadership summit in Honduras earlier this week which President Chen also attended.

Kao explained that the U.N. referendum proposal is part of Taiwan's efforts to arouse global heed to its diplomatic plight of being shut out of the United Nations and other major world organizations simply because of China's opposition.

Asked whether the three allies which have not yet endorsed the letter to the U.N. Secretariat regarding Taiwan's membership bid are the targets that the United States are lobbying to vote against the country, Kao said he would not like to speculate. He added that Taiwan's relations with those three countries have been firm and stable. Those countries have traditionally thrown support behind Taiwan's bids for membership in the U.N. and the World Health Organization, he added.

As to reports that China may come up with a proposal asking the U.N. General Assembly to pass a resolution recognizing that Taiwan is part of China, Kao said some U.S. think tanks and news media hae indeed reported on that possibility. Up until now, he said all such reports remain speculative and are subjected to stringent scrutiny.
According to Kao, the representative office in Washington, D.C. is keeping close track on relevant development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Mayor calls for citizens to support Taiwan's U.N. bid

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu called for Kaohsiung citizens Saturday to support the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.
Chen made the request at a garden party held at the Kaohsiung Museum of Fine Arts plaza in an effort to drum up public support for the U.N. bid.
The activities included a variety of music and dance performances, free hot-air balloons rides, and a signature drive in support of the U.N. bid.

Chen said joining the United Nations is not an impossible task for Taiwan, noting that many people in the country had thought that lifting martial law was impossible but that the dream was eventually realized.
It is unreasonable for Taiwan to be excluded from the international organization, Chen said, pointing out that Taiwan is the world's 16th largest trading nation and 17th largest economy.
Twu Shiing-jer, secretary-general of the Taiwan United Nations Alliance, expressed the hope that the Taiwan people will work together to help Taiwan become a member of the United Nations.
The promotion activities will also be held at Tiger City Shopping Center in Taichung City on Sept. 1 and in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei City on Sept. 8, Twu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 worst year in decade in terms of agricultural losses: COA

TEXT.P: The year 2005 marked the worst for Taiwan over the past decade in terms of agricultural losses caused by tropical storms and typhoons, with the losses for that year amounting to NT$20.69 billion (US$627.35 million ) , officials from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said Saturday.
The second worst year during the period was 1996, with agricultural losses amounting to NT$19.8 billion, followed by 1998, when losses totaled NT$ 12.69 billion, the officials said.
Most of the agricultural losses were caused by heavy downpours during the rainy season between May and June and by storms and typhoons that occurred between July and September, the officials said.

As to the most severe typhoons over the past decade in terms of total agricultural losses caused in Taiwan, Typhoon Hepuo, which struck in August 1996, topped the list at NT$18.07 billion, followed by Typhoon Haitang in July 2005, which caused NT$7.74 billion in agricultural losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to offer duty-free sugar import quota for El Salvador
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/07 22:38:18 (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will offer duty-free sugar import quota for El Salvador under a bilateral free trade agreement, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen said in San Salvador Friday.

Chen, who is accompany President Chen Shui-bian on a three-day state visit in El Salvador after attending Taiwan-Central America leadership summit in Honduras, made the remarks after Salvadoran President Antonio Saca promulgated his country's free trade pact with Taiwan earlier that same day.
If Taiwan's legislature ratifies the free trade agreement with El Salvador during its coming legislative session, Chen said, the pact will take effect in Taiwan at the beginning of next year.

Under the agreement, Chen said Taiwan will offer a tariff-free import quota of 35,000 tons for Salvadoran sugar in the first year of the implementation of the pact, and the amount will be raised to 50,000 tons in the second year and further increased to 60,000 in the third year. The maximum annual duty-free quota will be capped at 60,000 tons, he added.

According to Chen, Taiwan's annual sugar demand ranges between 500,000 tons and 600,000 tons. In the past, state-owned Taiwan Sugar Co. (Taisugar) monopolized Taiwan's sugar supply. But the monopoly has long been phased out and sugar trade has been fully liberalized, Chen said, adding that the free trade pact will enhance Salvadoran sugar's competitiveness in Taiwan but will in no way affect Taiwan sugarcane farmers' interests. Taisugar will continue to collect sugarcane from local farmers at set prices, he added.

Meanwhile, Chen said Taiwan will also benefit from the free trade pact by gaining easier access to sell industrial products to El Salvador. Moreover, he said El Salvador is one of the countries that have signed Central America Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA) with the United States. Taiwan companies that invest in El Salvador can ship products to the United States under the CAFTA framework, Chen said.
According to Chen, the government has encouraged Taiwan businesses to invest in El Salvador by offering soft loans. Taiwan has so far invested about US$78 million in El Salvador.

Among others, Taiwan companies are launching two new investment projects in El Salvador, under which two industrial parks will be built in the Central American country. President Chen will attend the groundbreaking ceremony for the Sanli Industrial Park before concluding his visit in El Salvador Saturday.

On Friday, President Chen accepted Salvadoran President Saca's invitation to help promote Salvadoran coffee in the Taiwan market. According to Economics Minister Chen, Taiwan imported US$32 million worth of coffee last year, with only 11 percent from Central American countries. "There is still amply room for the promotion of coffee imports from Central American countries, including El Salvador, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate woo Hakka voters

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh wooed Hakka voters Saturday with promises to promote Hakka language and culture as well as accelerate economic development in Hakka communities if he wins the presidency.

Hsieh made the pledges while attending a rally in front of the Yiming Temple in Hsinpu, a Hakka township in the northern county of Hsinchu, in the company of his running mate Su Tseng-chang and Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu-lan, who concurrently serves as the Hsieh campaign's top strategist.
It marked the first time that the three DPP bigwigs have attended a campaign rally together since the formation of the Hsieh-Su ticket for the 2008 presidential election earlier this month.

Su, a former premier, was Hsieh's closest rival in the DPP's hotly contested presidential primary and he agreed to join Hsieh on the ticket only after many twists and turns. As to Yeh, she was reportedly to be Hsieh's original choice for his running mate, but Hsieh changed his mind later and eventually decided to team up with Su with a view to boost party unity and enhance his chance of victory in the presidential race.

As Yeh is favored by many of her Hakka fellows to join Hsieh on the 2008 ticket, Hsieh deliberately chose the Hsinpu Hakka community as the place for his first campaign rally together with Su and Yeh to stage a tableau of unity and party coherence.

Addressing the rally, Hsieh, who had served as premier and Kaohsiung mayor, said he believes that Yeh can follow his footsteps in becoming a premier one day. "And if I can be elected president, a Hakka woman will also be able to win the presidency in the future," Hsieh said.

Since the DPP won the presidency in 2000, Hsieh said a Hakka television station has been established and Hakka language has been actively promoted. Hsieh said he himself took a Hakka proficiency test during his premiership from 2005 to early 2006.
He promised to boost ethnic harmony and glorify Hakka culture if elected the next president.
Su, who succeeded Hsieh to serve as premier, addressed the rally in fluent Hakka as he once served as magistrate of the southern county of Pingtung which has a large Hakka population.
For her part, Yeh urged her Hakka fellows and friends to support the Hsieh-Su ticket to help the homegrown DPP retain its grip on power next year.
Many Hakka heavyweights residing in Hsinchu County, including former Hsinchu Magistrate Lin Kuang-hua, also attended the rally to lend their support.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 26, or the 14th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1850: Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King" of France who abdicated rather than face a middle-class revolt, dies.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the killed-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The US legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Unions announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, US assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo Hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
2001: Seven Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives write a letter to State Secretary Madeleine Albright, requesting that the State Department "take the necessary steps to end the inappropriate ban on high-level visits between elected Taiwanese officials and U.S. officials, including the democratically-elected president of Taiwan."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."

Japan and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations struck a free-trade agreement Saturday that obliges Tokyo to cut tariffs on 90 percent of ASEAN's imports by value but allows it to stay competitive with China and South Korea, which already have ASEAN FTAs.
