DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan donates 500 police motorcycles to El Salvador
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/26/07 15:37:19 (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shu-bian donated 500 motorcycles to El Salvador Saturday to help improve social order in the Central American ally.
Chen handed a symbolic key to El Salvador's police chief, Rodrigo Avila Avilez, at a ceremony to mark the donation, worth US$1.5 million.
Addressing the ceremony, Chen said Taiwan made the offer in an effort to raise the Salvadoran police force's maneuverability and operational efficiency.
It is hoped that the donation will help facilitate President Antonio Saca's efforts to improve social order and police efficiency in El Salvador, Chen added.
He noted that the motorcycles would go into use immediately.
Later in the day, Chen, who arrived in San Salvador Friday for a three-day state visit, traveled to Panchimalco City accompanied by Casa to visit renowned Salvadoran painter Miguel Angel Ramirez.
El Salvador is the second leg of Chen's three-nation Central American visit.
The group was in Honduras Aug. 21-24 to attend a Taiwan-Central America leadership summit.
Chen is scheduled to travel on to Nicaragua Aug. 26. He is set to wrap up his Central American visit Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska, arriving in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academic workshop on cross-strait economic development to open

TEXT.P: Two think-tanks from Taiwan and China are sponsoring an academic workshop on cross-Taiwan Strait economic development and its transformation that is set to open in Taipei Monday, an academic source said Sunday.

More than 20 research papers are expected to be presented and discussed during the one-day workshop being organized by Taiwan's Chunghua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) and the Beijing-based Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS), a CIER source said.

The CASS delegation, to be led by Li Yang, director of the CASS Institute of Finance and Banking, will include 20 academics and researchers from the Institute of Finance and Banking, Institute of Quantitative and Technical Economics, and Institute of Finance and Trade Economics, as well as other institutes in other areas, the CIER official said.

Through the workshop, Taiwan researchers are expected to gain better understanding of the problems that China faces in the process of economic development and its transformation and to offer suggestions to the Taiwan public and government as references or reminders, the CIER official said.

CASS and CIER have been serving as academic windows in terms of cross-strait economic exchanges and relevant studies by hosting cross-strait academic symposiums alternately over the past several years.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU Taiwan office to publish handbook of tips for investors

TEXT.P: The European Economic and Trade Office in Taiwan (EETOT) is scheduled to publish in September a handbook on investing in the European Union, according to a press release issued by EETOT Sunday.

The handbook is aimed at allowing Taiwan investors to gain a better understanding of the investment climate in the EU as well as trade and investment opportunities in the world's largest economy, according to EETOT officials.

According to the EETOT, Taiwan is the ninth-largest supplier of goods in the world to the EU and the fifth-largest Asian trading partner of the EU, behind China, Japan, South Korea and India, in that order.
The amount that the EU imports from Taiwan equals about 15 percent of what it imports from China, the EETOT officials said.

Noting that there is still an ample room for Taiwan to improve in terms of investment in Europe, EETOT officials said the EU is the world's largest economy and that investing in any of the 27 member countries of the EU is tantamount to a passport to entering an immense market of a total population of 500 million.
EETOT officials added that Taiwan companies have missed many golden opportunities to invest in Europe in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talent scouts visiting Silicon Valley to recruit overseas workers
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/26/07 17:24:49 (By Lilian Lin, Josie Chou and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A talent-hunting delegation from Taiwan began its work in Silicon Valley in California Saturday in pursuit of experienced overseas high tech talent to work in Taiwan, recruiting sources said Saturday.

The delegation of representatives of leading enterprises and several academic and research institutions is holding a series of activities in an attempt to persuade foreign professionals to seek jobs in Taiwan, according to Minister- without-Portfolio Lin Feng-ching, who is heading the delegation.

The main appeal of this year's recruiting program is that the government has passed an amendment law to allow draft-age males to serve in research and development positions as an alternative to mandatory military service beginning in 2008, aiming to encourage more young Taiwan expatriate talent to work in Taiwan without the fear of being made to do military service.

He said regardless of what subjects they major in and no matter whether they studied in Taiwan or overseas, master's degree holders will be able to perform R&D services in government bodies and private enterprises instead of having to join the military.

The Executive Yuan has also come up with programs focused on hunting senior professionals with more than 15 years experience to serve as short-term consultants in Taiwan, Lin said, adding that the fields of basic science, biomedical technology, image display, digital content, information technology, semiconductors, energy technology, environmental and natural conservation, nano and high-end technology all require manpower.
There is also still great demand for engineers, business executives, managers and R&D chiefs.

The government also provides preferential incentives for foreign professionals and experts to work in Taiwan, including simplified tax procedures, relaxed regulations relating to work and residence permits and school places for the children of overseas employees.

Since the launch of the overseas talent-seeking event in 2003, it has managed to recruit 2,850 people, Lin said, adding that this year, 1,370 jobs provided by 42 government agencies and private companies will be available.

The delegation was in Silicon Valley in San Francisco Saturday and will travel to Los Angeles, Houston, Washington, D.C. and Toronto until Sept. 4 to conduct seminars, press conferences and one-on-one interviews with overseas professionals seeking work in Taiwan, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cultural chief to visit U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/26/07 17:26:40 (Michelle Tsai and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Wong Chin-chu, chairwoman of Republic of China Council for Cultral Affairs will make a two-day trip to Washington, D.C. next week and is scheduled to visit the U.S. Library of Congress, the National Museum of Natural History and several museums affiliated with the Smithsonian Institute, a Taiwan official posted in the U.S. capital said Saturday.
Stanley Kao, the Republic of China's deputy representative to the United States, made the announcement while meeting with Taiwan reporters stationed in Washington.
Kao said the representative office will arrange two activities for Wong when she is on her first visit to Washington since assuming her post earlier this year.
In addition to Washington, Wong will also visit other cities in the United States and Canada, Kao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA cautions against burning ghost money, incense

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) cautioned against the burning of environmentally harmful ghost money and incense Sunday, saying that violators could face fines of up to NT$100,000 (US$3,040).

With the approach of the traditional Zhongyuan Ghost Festival, during which Taiwan people prepare feasts and burn ghost money as offerings for "ghosts from the nether world, " EPA officials reiterated to the public that it is illegal to burn ghost money and incense outdoors and said violators will be fined from NT$5,000-100,000.

EPA officials said that when ghost money is burned, hazardous pollutants, including oxysulfide, nitrogen oxide and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, will be released into the atmosphere, causing harm not only to humans but also to the environment.

EPA officials also quoted research results published by the Consumers' Foundation as indicating that burning incense is equally harmful, with the release into the open air of pollutants such as benzene, methyl benzene and ethyl benzene.

So far, authorities in 15 cities and counties around the country, including Taipei City and Taipei County as well Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County, have offered to burn ghost money and incense together for worshippers in closed locations to reduce pollution, EPA officials said.

Noting that the centralized burning service is not aimed at encouraging the public to burn ghost money but to raise their environmental awareness, EPA officials warned the public to stop burning ghost money altogether, because the substances released upon burning are hazardous.

Meanwhile, they said, the counties of Taipei, Taoyuan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung, as well as the Kaohsiung City, have even begun to provide online worship rituals to allow the public to worship gods or appease ghosts in complete cleanliness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan cannot afford to have no allies: president
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/26/07 18:21:14 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that Taiwan "cannot afford to not maintain diplomatic relations with all the countries in the world," adding that having no allies would adversely affect national morale.

Talking to members of Taiwan media outlets traveling with Chen on his three- nation Central American visit since Aug. 21, he made the remarks in response to a reporter's inquiry of whether it could be an option for Taiwan to maintain no formal diplomatic relations with any countries.
According to Chen, if Taiwan maintains no formal ties with any countries, it would immediately become "an international orphan" and national morale would be smashed completely.

He added that the number of countries maintaining formal ties with Taiwan is changeable, but said it would be unacceptable for Taiwan to maintain no formal ties and that such a scenario would be "impossible."

As to the issue of the U.N. recognizing both Taiwan and China, Chen told the reporters that he chatted with William Brown, the honorary chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, during his transit stop in Alaska several days ago and was told that in 1971, when Beijing was given the "China seat" in the United Nations, George H.W. Bush, when he was the U.S. ambassador to the U.N., proposed that Taiwan and China be admitted at the same time.
The then-Kuomintang (KMT) administration, however, rejected the proposal and insisted on leaving the U.N. in the face of Beijing's presentation, Chen quoted Brown as saying.
He added that the KMT made the wrong decision and said the whole country is suffering the consequences.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party administration would choose to accept dual recognition and would not mind if Taiwan's allies also maintained diplomatic relations with China. "Taiwan is much more magnanimous than China," he claimed.
Chen and his 88-member entourage arrived in El Salvador Friday for a three-day state visit, the second leg of Chen's three-nation Central American visit.
The group was in Honduras Aug. 21-24 to attend a Taiwan-Central America leadership summit.
Chen is scheduled to travel on to Nicaragua Aug. 26. He is set to wrap up his visit Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska, arriving in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to hold Taitronics India in Chennai

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first Taitronics India, to be held Sept. 14-16 at the Chennai Trade Center in the southeastern Indian city, has lined up 97 exhibitors, including some of Taiwan's top information and telecommunications technology (ICT) manufacturers, organizers said Sunday.

The exhibitors will man 107 stalls at the exhibition to display state-of-the-art ICT products, as well as machine tools, car accessories, hand tools and components, according to the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , which is organizing the show with the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association.
Taitronics India will coincide with Connect 2007, India's largest ICT conference, which will be held in Chennai Sept. 14-17. Last year's conference attracted between 60,000 and 70,000 participants.

Conspicuous among the exhibitors are Holtek Semiconductor Inc., one of Taiwan's top 10 IC designers, and Wintek Corp., a major producer of liquid crystal displays (LCDs) and liquid crystal modules (LCMs).
Wintek officials said the company will set up a factory in Chennai's Nokia Telecom Special Economic Zone by the end of this year to produce some 9 million LCDs per month.
Several other key LCD makers -- Bolymin Inc., Giantplus Technology Co. and Lee Ming Industrial Co. -- will also display their lastest products at the show.

The organizers of Taitronics India will also host a series of economic and industrial cooperation seminars during the three-day exhibition and arrange for Taiwanese companies to meet with potential partners.

Taiwan's IC industries are interested in forming cooperative relationships with Indian companies because the two sides can complement each other. While Taiwan is a powerhouse for IT hardware manufacturing, India is known for its software and system designs.
Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry set up its first overseas research and development center at Olympia Technology Park in Chennai in May last year.

India ranks 25th among Taiwan's trade partners. Official statistics show that two-way trade between Taiwan and India totaled US$2.71 billion in 2006, with Taiwan enjoying a favorable balance of US$226 million. India accounted for 0.64 percent of Taiwan's external trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teenager rescued 21 days after being kidnapped

TEXT.P: A teenager was rescued from an apartment in Chiayi City Sunday 21 days after he was kidnapped for ransom in Tuku, Yunlin County, police said Sunday.
Four men who were allegedly involved in the kidnapping were arrested at the Chiayi apartment, police in Yunlin said.
The 17-year-old teenager, identified by his surname Wang, was taken while he was on his way to school Aug. 6.
His bicycle was later found by the side of a country road 100 meters from his school.
The teenager's mother, who raised him alone, did not receive a ransom call until Aug. 9 when a stranger called and asked her if her son was missing but hung up before she could answer.
The woman immediately alerted the police, who put a tap on her telephone.
The next day the stranger called again demanding a ransom of NT$2 million (US$60,461) which was reduced to NT$700,000 in subsequent negotiations and was to have been paid on Sunday.

Although the kidnappers used different public phones in different cities around Chiayi and Yunlin counties during the negotiations, the police became suspicious of two cars that regularly appeared near the public phones, both of which were traced to a man named Yen Chih-ling living in Huwei, Yunlin County.
Police began watching Yen's movements and monitoring his phone calls and found he often visited an apartment in Chiayi in the company of three others.
When Yen and his two associates left the apartment Sunday, police entered the lobby of the apartment building and laid an ambush there.

When the three came back, they were arrested and forced to make the man still in the apartment open the door, whereupon the police stormed in and overpowered him. A search of the apartment found the teenager hidden in a cardboard box with his eyes blindfolded and hands tied, but otherwise unharmed.
Two guns were also seized in the apartment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to promote exhibition, convention industry

TEXT.P: Taiwan will hold three international meetings on the development of the international exhibition and convention industry Sept. 26-28 in Taipei to explore business opportunities in the industry, officials at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Sunday.

The first will be an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on opportunities in the convention and exhibition industry slated for Sept. 27-28 at the Taipei International Convention Center, the officials said.
The MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade which will organize the forum is inviting industry leaders from APEC member states to attend the meeting, the official said.

He said that Sandra Chipchase, president of BestCities Global Alliance and chief executive officer of the Melbourne Convention and Visitors Bureau, Shawna McKinley, executive director of the Green Meeting Industry Council and Marcia Lyons, general manager of the Calgary TELUS Convention Center, have agreed to attend.

In addition, the 2007 Conference of the Asian Federation of Exhibition and Convention Associations will open Sept. 26, and the second forum for Asian leaders in the trade of meetings, incentives, conventions and exhibitions will be staged by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council Sept. 26-27, the officials said.
The official estimated the three conferences will draw 120 overseas participants from 24 countries in addition to 600 participants from Taiwan.

As the exhibition and convention industry helps drive the development of the transportation, accommodation, food and tourism industries, the government has been trying to bolster its ability to organize international events in the hope of promoting the international profile and competitiveness of the industry, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan International Children's Folklore Festival becomes history

TEXT.P: The Yilan International Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival -- held annually in July and August since 1996 -- became history after its 2007 event ended Sunday.

The Yilan County government made clear earlier this month that it will no longer hold the festival in 2008 because declining numbers of visitors to the festival in the past few years had caused the county government to suffer NT$50 million (US$ 1.51 million) in losses each year.
Yilan County Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua reiterated Sunday that the county government will replace the festival with a different form of large-scale activity in summer next year.
He said the county government will first conduct an overall review to establish why the Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival was no longer attractive to the public.

Lu urged Yilan County residents to contribute creative ideas to to give new meaning to local culture and tourism and make the county visible to the international community through a new summer activity next year.

He added that the 2008 event will no longer be in the form of a summer water park playground alongside the Dongshan River, and that a new activity is needed to reflect the full picture of the county's spirit, culture and tourism.
"People should just wait and see, " Lu said, giving the assurance that the 2008 activity will be a "new eye opener."

In its heyday, the Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival attracted more than 800,000 visitors each year in 2001, 2002 and 2004. The festival was suspended in 2003 as a result of the spread of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

Turnout decreased significantly in recent years, due to a combination of factors, including dwindling national income, rising inflation, the emergence of similar outdoor water activities elsewhere in Taiwan.

Although organizers tried to add variety by inviting troupes from other countries to perform their folk songs and dances, lack of change in the main program was believed to have caused the festival to lose its appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: President offers to nominate anew members for Control Yuan
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/26/07 22:48:10 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian who arrived here Friday for a three- day visit said Saturday that he might come up with a new list of nominees for members of Taiwan's Control Yuan, if the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan agree to act on it. Talking to Taiwan-based journalists who accompanied him on the visit, the president said he would change his list presented to the legislature on Dec. 20, 2004 to accommodate the opposition's requests for the sake of political harmony in Taiwan.

Chen said he has asked Vice President Annette Lu before he left Taiwan for Central America on Aug. 21 to sound out the opposition's opinion on the issue, adding that the Control Yuan is an indispensable part of Taiwan government and should not be left without members. Chen's list of 29 nominees which has to be approved by the Legislative Yuan had been stonewalled by the opposition in the legislature, mainly the Kuomintang and the People First Party on the ground that it was packed with Chen's political proteges.
The two parties said they won't act on the list, let alone approve it, unless the president withdraws it and submits a new list.

Considering it an affront, Chen refused the request, and asked the Legislative Yuan to act on his list again on April 4, 2005 when a new legislature was in session. His request was ignored and the Control Yuan which is the supreme watchdog of the government had thereby left without members after the terms of its previous members fell due on Jan. 31, 2005.

The political impasse has raised the eyebrows of the country's grand justices who ruled on Aug. 15 this year at the request of lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party that the Legislative Yuan's refusal to carry out its obligation to act on the president's nominations is not allowed by the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 27, or the 15th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1813: France's Napoleon Bonaparte, with a force of 130,000, wins his last great battle at Dresden, Germany, against a superior Austrian, Prussian and Russian allied force of 200,000.
1859: The world's first oil well is drilled by Edwin L. Drake at Titusville, Pennsylvania.
1883: The 1,800 meter Krakatoa on the Indonesian island of Rakata erupts with a fury that is heard in Australia, more than 3,541 km away, and gigantic tidal waves of up to 36 meters devastate the coastal towns of Java and Sumatra, leaving an estimated 36,000 people dead, and making the eruption the most catastrophic volcanic event ever recorded.
1891: Russia and France sign an entente cordiale.
1908: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the office after John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He won the 1964 election but faced increasing criticism over the mounting US involvement in Vietnam, and did not stand for reelection in 1968.
1910: Thomas Alva Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, shows his "talking picture" for the first time at his New Jersey laboratory.
1910: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, the Yugoslavian-born Albanian nun dedicated to the poor and sick, particularly in India, is born. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, in an attempt to impose dictatorial rule after assuming the provisional presidency in Beijing in March, 1912, orders the arrest of eight members of a constitution-drafting committee.
1916: Italy declares war on Germany.
1916: Romania declares war on Austro-Hungary, thus entering World War I.
1928: The Kellogg-Briant Pact, or Pact of Paris, an international agreement to condemn all war as a means of settling dispute, is signed by representatives of 15 nations.
1939: The world's first jet-propelled aircraft, the He-178 developed by German manufacturer Ernst Heinkel, makes its first flight at Marienehe, in northern Germany.
1946: A pilot's ejector seat prototype is successfully demonstrated at Wright Airport in the United States.
1946: France and Laos conclude an agreement establishing a kingdom under French domination.
1952: Israel and West Germany reach agreement in their negotiations on Nazi war crime indemnity. Under the agreement, the West German government will pay 3 billion Reichsmarks in 12 years to compensate Israeli people for their loss of lives and properties caused by the Nazi regime during World War II.
1962: The International Amateur Athletic Federation issues statement revoking its ratification for Indonesia to hold the Fourth Asian Games following the southeast Asian country's rejection of the Republic of China delegation to the games.
1972: The Taipei Little League baseball team wins the world title.
1977: The ROC's Lih Teh Little League baseball team wins the world title. Both Senior League and Big League baseball teams from Taiwan also won the 1977 world titles in earlier competitions.
1979: Lord Louis Mountbatten, former admiral and viceroy of India, is murdered by a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army as he and members of his family enjoy an outing on his 30-ft. fishing boat off Mullaghmore, County Sligo in the Irish Republic. He was 79.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Finance decides to lower the highest tariff rate to 57.5 percent and reduce duty rates on products with high import tariffs but limited import volume.
1987: A 13-year-old Chinese girl who was left to live with a family of pigs returns to normal life after three years of special training.
1991: Moldova declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1995: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign an agreement in Cairo to expand Palestinian autonomy from Gaza to the West Bank.
1999: Actress-singer Bai Guang dies at her home in Kuala Lumpur at the age of 79.
2003: A three-day six-nation meeting on North Korean nuclear weapon program opens in Beijing.
2004: Taekwondo athlete Chen Shi-hsin wins the ROC's first-ever Olympic gold medal in the Athens Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The power of spiritual forces in the Universe -- how active it is everywhere! Invisible to the eye and impalpable to the sense, it is inherent in all things, and nothing can escape its operation."

President Chen arrives in Nicaragua for two-day state visit
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/27/07 12:56:44 (By Ramona Huango and Deborah Kudo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his 88-member entourage arrived in Nicaragua Sunday to a red-carpet welcome ceremony presided over by Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega and his wife at the Managua International Airport.

Soon after the welcome ceremony, Chen and his Nicaraguan counterpart headed to Matagalpa City in northern Nicaragua to attend a ceremony marking the kick-off of a "Zero Hunger" project initiated by Ortega to help low-come families and disadvantaged members of society.
According to Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Samuel Santos, Chen and Ortega are expected to discuss economic cooperation and investment issues during Chen's two-day visit.
Taiwan made a donation of US$30 million to Nicaragua last month to help build a thermal power plant with a capacity of 30 megawatts.

Ortega had said during his presidential campaign last year that he would switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing if elected. But after his victory in the election and after President Chen attended his inauguation in January this year, Ortega changed his mind and vowed that Nicaragua would maintain formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
Recently, however, Ortega expressed the hope that Nicaragua could maintain "good relations with both sides of the Taiwan Strait."
Taiwan and Nicaragua signed a free trade agreement in June last year. Currently, Taiwan-invested textile plants in Nicaragua employ about 30,000 Nicaraguan citizens.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and Nicaragua topped US$46 million in 2005, with textiles, zippers, kitchenware, plastic products and knitwear making up the bulk of Taiwan's exports to Nicaragua, and frozen beef, coffee, scrap metals, timber and cotton fabrics forming the bulk of its imports from the Central American country.

Chen arrived in Nicaragua from El Salvador, where he made a three-day state visit, the second leg of his three-nation Central America trip. He visited Honduras Aug. 21-24 to attend a Taiwan-Central America leadership summit.
The president is scheduled to wrap up his visit Aug. 28 and head home via Alaska, arriving in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. has no plans to buy upmarket apartment in Taoyuan: official

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu has no plans to buy a new luxurious apartment in the northern county of Taoyuan, officials from the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office said Monday.

The officials were responding to an Era cable TV news report Sunday that said that Lu recently visited the construction site of an upmarket residential complex, called "Gallery & Palace by the Riverside, " in Nankan, Taoyuan, and that she might purchase one of the units for NT$90 million (US$2.7 million).

The officials said that Lu made the visit in the company of Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC) officials, who want to encourage overseas Taiwanese to return to Taiwan for permanent settlement.

The OCAC has been encouraging overseas Taiwanese to purchase homes in the country to prepare for their eventual settlement, the official said, adding that the vice president has absolutely no plans to buy a new apartment in Taoyuan, where she already owns one.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU doctoral candidate awarded (ISC)2 scholarship

TEXT.P: A doctoral candidate from the Institute of Information Management, National Taiwan University has been named as a winner of the prestigious scholarship awarded by the International Information Systems Security Certification Consortium (ISC)2 for 2007.

Tsang Po-hao, one of the eight winners of the 2007 (ISC) 2 Information Security Scholarship Program, will be awarded a US$12,500 scholarship in recognition of his outstanding contribution to research in information security.

Tsang, who is the only person in Taiwan to have received the Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) and Systems Security Certified Practitioner (SSCP) credentials, will be presented with the scholarship in a ceremony to be held in Tokyo, Japan in mid-November.

Tsang is the only recipient of the prestigious (ISC) 2 scholarship in Asia to receive the US$12,500 scholarship in two consecutive years. He received the scholarship in a similar ceremony held in Seoul, South Korea in May 2006.
The other seven recipients of the 2007 (ISC) 2 Information Security Scholarship are post-graduate students from Japan, Hong Kong, Australia, the United States, Britain and Italy.

Tsang told the CNA that he is elated to be selected again for the scholarship, which not only recognizes his contribution to research in risk and survivability analysis but also provides valuable financial assistance to allow him to carry on with his research work.
Tsang added that as a member of the (ISC) 2 community, he would spare no effort to advance his research in information security.

Currently conducting advanced research under the supervision of NTU professor Lin Yung-sung, Tsang was also included in the Marquis 10th Anniversary Edition of the Who's Who in Science and Engineering published recently.

The (ISC) 2 scholarship program was launched four years ago to recognize the groundbreaking information security research being conducted at universities worldwide as part of the consortium's commitment to promote the profession through education and research.

"The quality and diversity of this year's recipients reflect the high caliber of individuals around the world who are moving information security forward, " said Ed Zeitler, CISSP, executive director of (ISC) 2. "We are all fortunate to have such outstanding, dedicated people conducting such groundbreaking research for the protection of society. (ISC) 2 is honored to present the 2007 scholarships to these extraordinary students."

The International Information Systems Security Certification Consortium, Inc. ((ISC) 2), is the internationally recognized gold standard for certifying information security professionals. Founded in 1989, (ISC) 2 has certified over 50,000 information security professionals in 129 countries.

Based in Palm Harbor, Florida, (ISC) 2 issues the Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) and Systems Security Certified Practitioner (SSCP) credentials to those meeting necessary competency requirements.
