DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September rose 37 points to close at 8,637, with 29,878 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 40 points to finish at 8,620, with 399 contracts traded, while December futures gained 42 points to close at 8,644, with 16 contract transactions. March futures increased 38 points to close at 8,660, with six contracts traded, while June futures increased 38 points to end at 8,644, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 8,600 for September, 8,580 for October, 8,602 for December, 8,622 for March and 8,606 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

September TE futures moved up 2.5 points to close at 365.5, with 2,132 contracts traded, while October TE futures rose 0.9 points to finish at 364.8, with 35 contract transactions. June TE futures increased 14.7 points to end at 370.3, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures rose 2.6 points to close at 974, with 2,504 contracts traded, while October TF futures moved down one point to finish at 974, with 15 contract transactions. December TF futures gained 3.4 points to close at 990, with 16 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.014 to close at NT$32.994.
A total of US$624 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.960 and fluctuated between NT$32.960 and NT$33.015 during trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung urged to adopt new strategy in attracting investment

TEXT.P: A financial expert suggested Monday that Kaohsiung City encourage certain flagship companies to take the lead in attracting more technology-intensive downstream industries to the city to produce a cluster effect.

Hsieh Chin-ho, executive director of the Taipei-based Wealth publishing group, made the suggestions in a meeting at city hall with Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, who in recent months has invited leaders from all sectors of society to provide suggestions on upgrading the southern port city's industry.

During the meeting, Chen said the local government has spared no efforts in working to streamline its administrative procedures in a drive to build Kaohsiung into an attractive investment environment.

On upgrading industry, Hsieh suggested that Kaohsiung should first "find its own strengths, " adding that the city's climate and geographical position make it an ideal place for developing wind power and solar energy industries.

He further suggested that the government encourage more established companies, such as China Steel Corp., to take the lead in attracting more technology-intensive industries, such as machine tool, stainless steel, and precision machinery manufacturing, to Kaohsiung to create more economic benefits for the city.

The expert further advised the city government to draw up measures to attract Taiwan businesspeople operating in China to return home and invest in the city, like "salmon swimming back home to lay legs."

In response, Chen said the city government has implemented many incentive policies to try to attract investment in the city in several fields, including software technology, biotechnology and air cargo transportation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu Science Park to have new convention center

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science Park in northern Taiwan will soon have its own international convention center, the head of the park administration said Monday.

Huang Teh-jui, director of the science park administration, told a press conference that the convention center and an "Elite Guest House" will be officially inaugurated at the end of this year or early next year.

The new facilities will provide more convenience to the nearly 400 high-tech companies in the park in accommodating foreign visitors and holding international conferences or technical seminars, Huang explained.
He added that a huge lawn in front of the Elite Guest House has enough room for large-scale outdoor activities attended by up to 10,000 people.
Huang also said the Hsinchu Science Park's Creative Industry Center will be inaugurated in September.
The science park administration will now focus on improving the quality of its service to the companies housed in the area, according to Huang.

The Hsinchu Science Park, established in 1980, covers an area of 632 hectares. It is one of three science parks in Taiwan, with the other two being the Central Taiwan Science Park and the Southern Taiwan Science Park.

While the focus of the Hsinchu park is semiconductor-related industries, that of the Central Taiwan Science Park is the aviation, precision machinery and optoelectronics industries, and that of the southern Taiwan park is optoelectronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's sovereignty cannot be compromised in torch relay talks: MAC

TEXT.P: The negotiations in which Taiwan would like to engage again with Beijing on the issue of the 2008 Olympic torch relay route would not just involve "wording" as some media outlets have claimed recently, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.
MAC spokesman Liu Te-hsun said that a main element of such negotiations would be Taiwan's insistence that its sovereignty not be compromised in the torch relay arrangements.

Liu noted that Taiwan's stance is firm on four prerequisites being met before the 2008 Olympic torch relay can pass through Taiwan -- namely, that both sides follow IOC protocol and regulations, that there should be consent by the government of Taiwan, that Taiwan's sovereignty should not be downgraded, and that all relevant activities should be conducive to future interaction between the two sides.
Stressing that Taiwan's position has not changed in this regard, Liu said Taiwan hopes that the two sides can resume negotiations within the existing communication channels as soon as possible.
Liu, however, declined to comment on whether Taiwan will drop its insistence that the Olympic torch enter and exit Taiwan via a country other than China.
An unconfirmed source said Monday that the two sides will settle the thorny issue in negotiations to be completed by the end of August.

Taiwan rejected the torch relay route proposed by Beijing in April that would have included Taiwan as China's first "domestic" stop and would have had the torch arriving in Taiwan from Vietnam and heading on to China-controlled Hong Kong. The arrangement was viewed by Taiwan as an intentional move to downgrade its sovereign status.

MAC officials said earlier this month that Taiwan rejected China's proposal because it violated a formal agreement reached between the two sides in 1989 that ensures that Taiwan has equal sporting status to China by referring to Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei." China has often unilaterally referred to Taiwan as "Taipei, China."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Let the president decide': possible nominee for judiciary chief

TEXT.P: A senior judiciary official who has been tipped to be nominated by President Chen Shui-bian as the next chief of the Judicial Yuan said Monday he won't beg for the post and will respect whatever decision the president makes on the matter.

Yang Jen-shou, chief commissioner of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries, made the remarks after Legislator Chen Chin-teh from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that President Chen should not nominate Yang and that Yang should turn down such a nomination as it would be unconstitutional.

The lawmaker's opinion was echoed by a private judiciary-monitoring group on the grounds that Yang doesn't deserve the job as chief of the judiciary, which would automatically make him head of the Grand Justice Council, since he has shown contempt for the post of grand justice by resigning from it in 2006 to take on his current job.
Yang's remarks represented an about-face on the issue of his possible nomination since a presidential aide revealed it to the press on Aug. 17.
It was reported on Aug. 22 that Yang had asked the president to drop him from consideration, after a law professor at National Taiwan University questioned the constitutionality of such a nomination.

Noting that Yang served as a grand justice between 2003 and 2006 before he was appointed to his current post, the professor said Yang is not eligible to be the chief of the Judicial Yuan -- who automatically serves as a grand justice -- because the Constitution limits grand justices to a single term.

The professor claimed that if Yang were to be nominated based on the reasoning that he ended his term as grand justice early in order to serve in another post, this would look like a "legal trick" to get around the constitutional limitation and would not serve the interests of the nation.
The United Daily News said on Aug. 22 that Yang has asked Legislative Speak Wang Chin-pyng to relay his refusal politely to President Chen to pre-empt any controversy.
Wang confirmed the newspaper's report but said at that time that he had not yet conveyed Yang's message to the president, who had left Taiwan for a nine-day visit to Central America on Aug. 21.
The term of the current Judicial Yuan president, Weng Yueh-sheng, expires at the end of September this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington PostGMany Take Army's 'Quick Ship' Bonus
More than 90 percent of the Army's new recruits since late July have accepted a $20,000 "quick ship" bonus to leave for basic combat training by the end of September, putting thousands of Americans into uniform almost immediately.
The Washington TimesGIraq leaders concur on key drafts
Shi'ite, Sunni Arab and Kurdish political leaders announced yesterday they reached consensus on several key measures seen as vital to fostering national reconciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Home Depot Unit Sees Price Plunge in a Tight Market
Home Depot was forced to drop the sale price of its commercial supply business by nearly $2 billion yesterday, according to people involved in the negotiations, one of the first big buyouts to be renegotiated as a result of the recent tightening of credit and problems in the housing market.
The Wall Street Journal: Home Depot Hit As Credit Crunch Squeezes Deals
The global credit crunch has begun to put a squeeze on the buyout boom, with banks and private-equity firms forcing Home Depot Inc. to sell its struggling wholesale supply unit for much less than what had been agreed to just two months ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record number of Hong Kong, Macao students apply to study in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The number of students from Hong Kong and Macao who have applied to study at universities in Taiwan during the 2007-2008 school year marks a record high, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.

A total of 675 Hong Kong high school graduates and 1,993 Macao students have applied to pursue higher education in Taiwan in the academic year that will begin this autumn, Lo Mu-kun, director of the MAC's Hong Kong and Macao affairs department, told the Central News Agency in an interview.
In the previous school year, 413 Hong Kong students and 1,478 Macao students filed such applications, Lo said.
Lo said that during this summer, the council organized two short tours inviting students from the two areas to Taiwan as part of its efforts to enhance the students' understanding of the island.

A total of 220 young students from Hong Kong and Macao joined the tours which took them to several local universities, a science park in Taipei, and the country's high speed rail station in the northern county of Hsinchu, Lo said.
In addition, the visiting students attended several seminars which helped them gain a better understanding of Taiwan's education policies, Lo noted.
Citing past figures, Lo said that about 90 percent of students who join the tours end up enrolling in universities in Taiwan.

These students decide to study in Taiwan because Hong Kong and Macao are close to Taiwan -- within two hours by plane -- and because they speak Chinese mandarin, Lo said. The students are also attracted by the diverse programs provided by Taiwan universities, he added.

The council also organized another tour targeting Hong Kong and Macao college students in mass media departments, Lo said, adding that these students visited Taiwan's media outlets and related university departments.
The students were also given opportunities to serve as interns at local television stations, according to Lo.
Lo said that the council hopes that through their visit to Taiwan, these future media workers can better understand Taiwan's freedom of speech, democracy, and diverse cultures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Danish paper publishes ROC foreign minister's U.N. bid article
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/07 20:11:55 (By Lin Yu-li and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Danish newspaper has published Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang's letter calling for the Scandinavian country to support its application for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan.
Huang said in his letter published in the Saturday issue of Jyllands-Posten that since 1993, the Republic of China has been unsuccessfully filing applications for U.N. representation.
The country decided to adopt a new strategy this year, applying under the name of Taiwan, on the grounds that up to 77 percent of the people of Taiwan support such a bid, according to Huang.
Huang described Taiwan as a "model democracy of multi-party politics" that needs more support from the international community.
However, Huang wrote, the Chinese government suppresses Taiwan by demanding that officials of other countries condemn Taiwan whenever the Taiwan government displeases Beijing.
Huang pointed out that China has deployed 1,000 missiles on its southeastern coast targeting Taiwan and enacted an anti-secession law in 2005 to legitimize China's use of force against Taiwan.

Huang also wrote that Taiwan's new U.N. bid will "not adversely impact cross- Taiwan Strait relations" because the country is not amending its Constitution to change its national title, a move that would be regarded by China as a step toward formal independence.
Saying that Taiwan will not give up its U.N. membership campaign despite the low probability of success, Huang urged Denmark to back Taiwan's U.N. bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA inks pledge to endorse global efforts to ban landmines

TEXT.P: Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Tzu-pao and Tun Channareth, a "friendship ambassador" of the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL) , signed a pledge Monday to highlight Taiwan's resolve to remove its landmines in line with global efforts.
Speaking prior to the ceremony at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), Yang said that the inking of the statement "helps underscore Taiwan's anti-war, peace-loving determination."

Through collective efforts on the Internet, humanitarian issues like this go far beyond political and economic boundaries, Yang said, hailing the non- governmental ICBL's long-term efforts in promoting the goal around the world.
Citing MOFA statistics, Yang said that as of July 2004, 152 countries had signed the statement.

After years of efforts, the Taipei-based Eden Social Welfare Foundation, which invited Channareth to visit Taiwan, eventually succeeded in pushing the Legislative Yuan to approve a law May 26 last year on controlling landmines. The law requires that all such devices across the country, mainly on the outlying island of Kinmen, must be removed within seven years.

Huang Chuo-sung, executive director of the Eden foundation, said the foundation, which acts as the ICBS's representative in Taiwan, has in recent years donated many wheelchairs and mine-sweeping vehicles to countries where there are large numbers of mines planted in their soil.

According to U.N. statistics, nearly 100 million armed mines are still scattered throughout some 70 countries and areas that pose great threat to people living there. The cost of an overall de-mining operation is estimated at US$33 billion and the operation would take some 1,100 years even if no new mines were laid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urged to destroy all recovered landmines

TEXT.P: Taiwan was urged Monday by anti-landmine activists to completely destroy all of its recovered mines.

Visiting Denise Coghlan, who represents the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL) , said Taiwan has shown its determination to fully comply with the Ottawa Treaty, as its legislature already passed the Statute for Anti- personnel Landmine Control last year and its Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) signed a declaration Monday reassuring the support of the treaty.

However, she went on, the most important thing for Taiwan is to destroy all its stockpiles, which she claimed is something Taiwan has been reluctant to do. She added that Taiwan's government has also not yet declared that it will ban the use of landmines in war.
She encouraged Taiwan to destroy its mine stockpiles since it has committed to the Ottawa Treaty, even though Taiwan was not allowed to officially sign the treaty because it is not a U.N. member.

The Statute for Anti-personnel Landmine Control, which requires the removal of anti-personnel mines from Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Dong Yin within seven years, was enacted in the legislature last year, and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has earmarked NT$4.2 billion to remove minefields.

Approximately 100,000 landmines are still in the ground on Taiwan's outlying islands, said Robert Lin, vice chief executive officer of the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, which has been an ICBL member working on Taiwan's anti- landmine campaign for 10 years.

Coghlan, who is based in Cambodia working on the anti-landmine campaign, has played an important role in pushing for the establishment of the Ottawa Treaty, which was initiated in 1997 and has been signed by 154 countries with the objectives of banning the use of and clearing all landmines, as well as helping landmine victims.
Coghlan said the Taiwan government "is one of the leading governments in compensating landmine victims."
The ICBL delegation is scheduled to visit the MND Tuesday before making an inspection trip to the island of Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits Nicaragua democracy site
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/27/07 21:19:52 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday in Nicaragua that he felt proud to be the first foreign head of state to visit the birthplace of Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega's ruling Sandinista Party.

Chen made the remarks after Ortega took him to attend a ceremony in Matagalpa City, northern Nicaragua, which marked the start of a "Zero Hunger" project initiated by Ortega to help low-income families and disadvantaged members of society.

The US$150 million project is expected to benefit 75,000 families during the next five years. The budget will come from the Nicaraguan government, foreign governments, the United Nations, the World Bank and the World Food Program.

Chen said the visit was part of promises Ortega made during his presidential campaign last year that he would take a foreign president to the city -- which is considered by locals as a "holy democratic site"-- if elected.
Along the way, Chen went on, Ortega responded to many of his supporters who made pleas for help. Ortega was elected president in the belief that only he can bring peace, respect and hope, Chen said.
Noting that he and Ortega have a lot in common, Chen also said he can learn a great deal from his Nicaraguan counterpart.

Chen arrived in Nicaragua from El Salvador, where he made a three-day state visit, the second leg of his diplomatic journey to Taiwan's three Central American allies. He visited Honduras Aug. 21-24 for a leadership meeting with Taiwan's Central America allies and the Dominican Republic.
The president is slated to wrap up his visit Aug. 28 before heading home via Alaska, arriving in Taipei Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Envoy voices concern over alleged China claims on Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/27/07 21:43:41 (By C. H. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to the United States said Sunday that he had voiced deep concern to Washington and Taiwan's diplomatic allies over a reported plan by China to seek international backing at the United Nations for its sovereign claim on Taiwan.

Joseph Wu, Taiwan's top representative to the United States, made the comments during an interview with the Voice of America radio station on questions about Taiwan's efforts to join the United Nations and relevant issues after it was reported that China plans to submit a proposal to the U.N. General Assembly next month to tout member states' support for its claims that "Taiwan forms part of China."

Saying that the alleged move by China is an issue of maximum concern to Taiwan, Wu added that Taiwan must express its grave concern regarding the matter to the United States and Taiwan's diplomatic allies. So far, he said, no concrete action has been seen with regard to China's alleged plan.

According to Wu, President Chen Shui-bian last week told William Brown, honorary chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, that he hoped Washington could "better understand" the purpose behind Taiwan's U.N. bid.

Wu also admitted that Chen's refueling stop in Anchorage, Alaska instead of other U. S. city on his way to Central America for his current diplomatic tour had "something to do" with Taiwan's plan to put the U.N. membership issue to a public referendum alongside the next presidential election slated for March 22, 2008.

Chen and his entourage wore stickers touting Taiwan's U. N. membership on their shirts, while the plane's interior was decorated with the same stickers to underscore Taiwan's desire to join the world body.

Responding to the question of whether Chen's most recent transit was played down by the U.S. side due to Washington's disagreement with Taiwan's referendum plan on its U.N. bid, Wu said that it is unfair to judge overall Taiwan-U.S. relations by just a stopover.

As the United States has to deal with the latest developments in North Korea, the Middle East and Venezuela, a quiet and more low-key situation in the Taiwan Strait would allow Washington to better handle thorny international issues, he explained, pointing out that apart from some political differences, Taiwan and the United States actually share great benefits and enjoy common interests in terms of economic prosperity and regional security.

DOC.HEADLINE: More money to be spent on digital opportunity centers: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Monday a plan to spend an additional NT$200 million (US$6 million) on a government project that began in 2005 to lessen the urban-rural digital divide.

Chang made the announcement at a press conference held by the Ministry of Education (MOE) to report the 2007 results of the project, which is aimed at building information and communications technology (ICT) infrastructure in remote areas to help local people and boost local industrial development.

The report said 61 Digital Opportunity Centers (DOCs) have been set up in 57 remote villages around the country since 2005 with help from the government, local communities, volunteer groups, enterprises and civic organizations.

The additional funds will be used to establish 59 more facilities, Chang said, adding that 18,000 students living in remote areas will benefit from the DOCs, one of whose functions is to offer the students after-school computer programs.

A DOC can promote ICT infrastructure construction in the village in which it is located, and the ultimate goal of the DOC project is to see "every village in Taiwan equipped with broadband, " according to the MOE.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Normal country resolution' draft criticized as electioneering

TEXT.P: The draft of a "normal country resolution" from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was written simply in an attempt to win two major elections in 2008, Kuo Shu-chun, a whip of the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , claimed Monday.

The DPP finalized the draft after months of discussion and in it accuses its rival KMT of possessing a huge amount of ill-gotten party assets, encouraging vote-buying and having used a "party-state" system to destroy democracy.
The draft describes the KMT as one of threats against Taiwan's efforts to be a normal country.

In response to media inquiries, Kuo said that if the KMT's party assets are found to be problematic, the matter should and can be addressed in the judiciary system. "Why bother to put forth the matter in a `normal country resolution? '" she asked, expressing doubts about the motives behind the draft.

Kuo also questioned why the draft does not offer any concrete proposals whatsoever aimed at dealing with disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, while mapping out five strategies the DPP claims will make Taiwan into a normal country

Kuo further asked how Taiwan can become a normal country if the cross-strait disputes, which she claimed as "the center of Taiwan's problems, " are not properly addressed and she criticized the draft as nothing more than a "scheme to swindle votes" in the upcoming legislative and presidential elections.
Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-ming denounced the draft as being formed to "destroy another political party."

DOC.HEADLINE: Canadian man gets five years for smuggling cannabis

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court sentenced a Canadian man to five years in prison Monday for smuggling cannabis into Taiwan via express delivery in April last year.
The court said in its ruling that Robertsen Kory David, 30, accepted US$1,500 from British national Michael Richardson to smuggle the marijuana into Taiwan for him.
David bought two kilograms of cannabis in Canada April 18, 2006 and placed it in a cat food bag. He then asked an international express delivery company to send the goods to his address in Taiwan.
The company's screening unit at Taoyuan International Airport reported the case to aviation police after discovering that the cat food bag contained cannabis.
Plainclothes police officers disguised as delivery workers delivered the package to David's residence and arrested him as soon as he signed the receipt and took possession of the drugs.

David confessed to smuggling the drugs during a police interrogation, as well as during district and high court proceedings. Public prosecutors sought 15 years of imprisonment for him, but the Taipei District Court passed a sentence of 10 years.
The Taiwan High Court ruled that although Davis received US$1,500 as payment for smuggling the cannabis, it could not be construed to mean that he had the intention of selling the drugs.

Describing the two kilograms of cannabis involved in the case as "not a small amount," the court said the offense could not be compared with drug traffickers who smuggle far larger quantities of drugs.

The high court also took note of the fact that David was not a professional criminal and that he was remorseful about what he had done. As a result, the high court decided to reduce his sentence to five years.
Cannabis is listed as a Class B drug in Taiwan. According to the Narcotics Endangerment Prevention Act, anyone trafficking such a drug is liable to face from seven years in prison to life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan to set up monument for Taiwan's first battlefield

TEXT.P: The Tainan city government will establish a monument in memory of Taiwan's first battlefield, with the inauguration set for May next year.
Tainan Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai and Netherlands Trade and Investment Office representative Menno Goedhardt attended a ceremony Monday to pinpoint the location where the monument will be erected.

The 1661 war fought between Dutch colonists and Ming dynasty soldiers led by Cheng Chen-kung (1624-1662) -- better known to the West as Koxinga -- near what is now a space behind a temple in the An-An-Nan district of Tainan. The war ended 38 years of Dutch rule of Taiwan.
There are still tombs in the area for both the Chinese and Dutch soldiers who died in the war.

Speaking at the ceremony, Hsu said that Cheng, who received the title Koxinga, meaning "bearer of the imperial surname," from the last emperor of the Ming dynasty, moved his troops to Taiwan in April 1661 and fought the Dutch in a war that lasted nine months.
The mayor said this was the first major war in Taiwan's history, and that the battlefield in Tainan should be called Taiwan's "first old battlefield."
Goedhardt said he was grateful to see that the tombs of the Dutch soldiers have been well-protected through the centuries, even though they were killed as enemies.

Koxinga is closely linked to the history of Taiwan, and the Tainan city government apparently attaches great importance to his contributions to Taiwan and especially to his close connection to the southern city.

Several temples and facilities were built in An-Ping and Tainan and dedicated to Koxinga and his mother after he expelled the Dutch. People not only worship him as a national hero but regard him highly because of his loyalty to his emperor even after the Ming dynasty collapsed.
Although Koxinga's father, leader of a pirate force, surrendered to Ching dynasty rulers, he continued to lead his father's armies to fight the Ching emperor's overwhelming forces.
After defeating the Dutch, Koxinga devoted himself to making Taiwan into an effective base for anti-Ching sympathizers who planned to restore the Ming dynasty to power.
He died at the age of 38, probably of malaria.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP's `normal country' resolution completed

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) completed Monday the draft of a "normal country" resolution, focusing on Taiwan's need to rectify its official designation and write a new constitution amid constant threats from China.

The draft was unveiled at a news conference after a meeting of the party's nine- member task force dealing with the issue. Members of the task force include Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung and Legislator Trong Chai who serves as the panel's convener. Several DPP legislators and members of the party's Central Executive Committee also invited to attend the meeting.

During the meeting, Lin Yao-wen, a close adie to DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, presented a new version of the draft for discussion together with a party central-drafted edition. As party bigwigs have reached a consensus on the content of the resolution, the draft was completed within slightly more than one hour, party sources said.

The draft resolution will be submitted to the party's Central Executive Committee for approval at its weekly meeting Thursday and will then be put for endorsement by party delegates at a party congress next month, the sources said.
In addition to underscoring Taiwan's national sovereignty independent of China, the draft resolution calls for a referendum to allow the public to have a say on the issue "at the proper time."
Pointing out that it is difficult to use the name Republic of China in the international community, the draft resolution says the country should apply to join world bodies in the name of Taiwan.
The draft also identifies China's hegemony and the remnants of the Kuomintang's (KMT's) 55 years of authoritarian rule as major threats that Taiwan faces in its struggle for normalization.

The resolution points out that Beijing's "one China" principle and its anti- secession law against Taiwan have threatened Taiwan's sovereignty and security and caused abnormalties in Taiwan's foreign relations.

The draft resolution also identifies the KMT's huge ill-gotten party assets and the remnants of its authoritarian "party-state" system as threats to Taiwan's democratic development, as they hinder normal inter-party competition.

Wang Sing-nan, a whip of the DPP's legislative caucus, commented later in the day that the "moderate" resolution will help lure middle-of-the-road voters to the party in the March 22, 2008 presidential election.

According to Wang, the "normal country" resolution is more comprehensive than the party's previous two resolutions known as "Taiwan independence platform" and "Resolution on Taiwan's future" by clearly pointing out the prime perils to Taiwan's efforts to become a normal country.

The resolution was initiated early this year by DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun with the aim of making Taiwan into what he called a "normal country." He deemed such a resolution a key weapon to helping the party increase its chances in the next presidential poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's saber-rattling main source of regional instability: MAC

TEXT.P: China's saber-rattling and military intimidation of Taiwan over its fears of the island's democratic development is the main source of regional instability, a senior Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun made the remarks after the local media quoted Chinese President Hu Jintao as having said recently that the only mission of the People's Liberation Army (PLA) is to fight against Taiwan.

Hu was quoted as having told a closed-door meeting of the Communist Party of China (CPC) earlier this month that if the Democratic Progressive Party administration-proposed referendum on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan receives the support of more than half of Taiwanese voters, the CPC may consider organizing a PLA military exercise to intimidate Taiwan.
Commenting on the report, Liu said the report had not been verified or confirmed but added that the government will closely monitor the situation.

Liu further said Taiwan's peaceful quest for participation in international organizations and activities is aimed at protecting its national secutiry and has nothing to do with the independence vs. unification dispute. Moreover, he said a series of public opinion polls show that joining the United Nations under the name of Taiwan is a common aspiration of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor to head for Brisbane to attend cities summit

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin will depart for Brisbane Wednesday to attend the 2007 Asia Pacific Cities Summit to be held in the Australian city, city government officials said Monday.

Hau will deliver a speech at the meeting on Taipei's waterfront city development planning and vision, the officials said, adding that the mayor will take advantage of the regional event to woo foreign investment in the city's major infrastructure construction projects.

The regional cities summit will center on the theme of "Renewing Asia Pacific Cities" and promotion of city-to-city commercial exchange, investment and economic cooperation, the officials said, adding that 1,000 municipal officials and business executives are expected to attend the meeting.
Following the meeting, Hau will travel to Singapore to study the city-state's major development projects and strategies, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer announces plan to buyout Gateway for US$710 million

TEXT.P: Acer Inc. announced its biggest ever buyout plan Monday, saying it will acquire U.S. computer maker Gateway Inc. for US$710 million.

The deal, scheduled for completion by the end of this year, will push the Taiwanese company to pass China's Lenovo Group as the world's third largest vendor of personal computers, an Acer press statement said.
Acer is offering to buy Gateway for US$1.90 per share, pending regulatory approvals in Taiwan and the United States, the statement said.
The acquisition has been unanimously approved by the boards of directors of both the Irvine, California-based Gateway and Acer and is subject to standard closing conditions, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug.28, 2007

TEXT.P: 2. Event: News conference on whether DPP and KMT presidential candidates can upgrade Taiwan's competitiveness Date and Time: 10:00 a.m., Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2007 Place: Legislative Yuan conference room No. 101 Organizers: Forum on Taiwan Competitiveness Press Contact: Tel.2358-5858 Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Name change not included in DPP 'normal country' resolution

TEXT.P: Certain controversial points, including the change of the country's title from the Republic of China to Taiwan, were not included in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) newly drafted "normal country" resolution, party sources said Monday.
The draft resolution, which is set to form a critical part of the DPP's campaign platform for the 2008 presidential election, instead prioritizes underscoring Taiwan's independent statehood.

It calls for completion of the party's ultimate goal of rectifying the national name and writing a new constitution as early as possible and holding a national referendum at the proper time to underline Taiwan's status as an independent sovereign state.

The resolution further says that since it has become very difficult to use the name Republic of China in the international community, the country should apply to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other international bodies in the name of Taiwan.

The DPP headquarters-drafted version originally suggested that the country's title be changed to Taiwan, the ROC calendar be phased out and replaced with Gregorian calendar, the existing "five branch" government system be replaced with a "three-branch" one and the special municipality be eradicated from the local government hierarchy.

As some DPP bigwigs, including Frank Hsieh, the party's standard bearer in the 2008 presidential election, questioned the plausibility of those proposals, they were all dropped from the final version of the draft resolution adopted Monday, party sources said.
The draft resolution identifies China's hegemony and the remnants of the Kuomintang's (KMT's) 55 years of authoritarian rule as major threats that Taiwan faces in its struggle for normalization.

According to the resolution, Beijing's "one China" principle and its Anti- Secession Law against Taiwan have threatened Taiwan's sovereignty and security and caused abnormalities in Taiwan's foreign relations.

The draft resolution also identifies the KMT's huge ill-gotten party assets and the remnants of its authoritarian "party-state" system as threats to Taiwan's democratic development, as they hinder normal inter-party competition.
It further notes that the obsolescence of the ROC constitutional framework has led to the country's constitutional abnormalities following the rotation of governing parties.

According to the resolution, the previous government's suppression of Taiwanese culture has made local people confused about their national identity and the preferential treatment enjoyed by certain special groups has sabotaged social unity and led to "abnormalities in social justice."

To resolve all these abnormalities, the resolution calls for reinforcement of Taiwan-centric education in school curricula, promotion of transitional justice, elimination of inequalities in resources distribution, acceleration of judicial reform and retrieval of the KMT's ill-gotten party assets.

The draft resolution was unveiled after an hour-long meeting of the party's nine-member task force dealing with the issue. Members of the panel include Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung and Legislator Trong Chai who serves as the panel's convener. Several DPP legislators and members of the party's Central Executive Committee also invited to attend the meeting.

As party bigwigs have reached a consensus on the tone and highlights the content of the resolution through extensive discussions in the past few days, the draft was settled after one hour of discussion, party sources said.

The draft resolution will be submitted to the party's Central Executive Committee for approval at its weekly meeting Thursday and will then be put up for endorsement by party delegates at a party congress next month, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP's 'normal country' resolution completed

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) completed Monday the draft of a "normal country" resolution, focusing on Taiwan's need to rectify its official designation and write a new constitution amid constant threats from China.

The draft was unveiled at a news conference after a meeting of the party's nine- member task force dealing with the issue. Members of the task force include Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung and Legislator Trong Chai who serves as the panel's convener. Several DPP legislators and members of the party's Central Executive Committee also invited to attend the meeting.

During the meeting, Lin Yao-wen, a close adie to DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, presented a new version of the draft for discussion together with a party central-drafted edition. As party bigwigs have reached a consensus on the content of the resolution, the draft was completed within slightly more than one hour, party sources said.

The draft resolution will be submitted to the party's Central Executive Committee for approval at its weekly meeting Thursday and will then be put for endorsement by party delegates at a party congress next month, the sources said.
In addition to underscoring Taiwan's national sovereignty independent of China, the draft resolution calls for a referendum to allow the public to have a say on the issue "at the proper time."
Pointing out that it is difficult to use the name Republic of China in the international community, the draft resolution says the country should apply to join world bodies in the name of Taiwan.
The draft also identifies China's hegemony and the remnants of the Kuomintang's (KMT's) 55 years of authoritarian rule as major threats that Taiwan faces in its struggle for normalization.

The resolution points out that Beijing's "one China" principle and its anti- secession law against Taiwan have threatened Taiwan's sovereignty and security and caused abnormalties in Taiwan's foreign relations.

The draft resolution also identifies the KMT's huge ill-gotten party assets and the remnants of its authoritarian "party-state" system as threats to Taiwan's democratic development, as they hinder normal inter-party competition.

Wang Sing-nan, a whip of the DPP's legislative caucus, commented later in the day that the "moderate" resolution will help lure middle-of-the-road voters to the party in the March 22, 2008 presidential election.

According to Wang, the "normal country" resolution is more comprehensive than the party's previous two resolutions known as "Taiwan independence platform" and "Resolution on Taiwan's future" by clearly pointing out the prime perils to Taiwan's efforts to become a normal country.

The resolution was initiated early this year by DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun with the aim of making Taiwan into what he called a "normal country." He deemed such a resolution a key weapon to helping the party increase its chances in the next presidential poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's saber-rattling main source of regional instability: MAC

TEXT.P: China's saber-rattling and military intimidation of Taiwan over its fears of the island's democratic development is the main source of regional instability, a senior Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun made the remarks after the local media quoted Chinese President Hu Jintao as having said recently that the only mission of the People's Liberation Army (PLA) is to fight against Taiwan.

Hu was quoted as having told a closed-door meeting of the Communist Party of China (CPC) earlier this month that if the Democratic Progressive Party administration-proposed referendum on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan receives the support of more than half of Taiwanese voters, the CPC may consider organizing a PLA military exercise to intimidate Taiwan.
Commenting on the report, Liu said the report had not been verified or confirmed but added that the government will closely monitor the situation.

Liu further said Taiwan's peaceful quest for participation in international organizations and activities is aimed at protecting its national secutiry and has nothing to do with the independence vs. unification dispute. Moreover, he said a series of public opinion polls show that joining the United Nations under the name of Taiwan is a common aspiration of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor to head for Brisbane to attend cities summit

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin will depart for Brisbane Wednesday to attend the 2007 Asia Pacific Cities Summit to be held in the Australian city, city government officials said Monday.

Hau will deliver a speech at the meeting on Taipei's waterfront city development planning and vision, the officials said, adding that the mayor will take advantage of the regional event to woo foreign investment in the city's major infrastructure construction projects.

The regional cities summit will center on the theme of "Renewing Asia Pacific Cities" and promotion of city-to-city commercial exchange, investment and economic cooperation, the officials said, adding that 1,000 municipal officials and business executives are expected to attend the meeting.
Following the meeting, Hau will travel to Singapore to study the city-state's major development projects and strategies, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer announces plan to buyout Gateway for US$710 million

TEXT.P: Acer Inc. announced its biggest ever buyout plan Monday, saying it will acquire U.S. computer maker Gateway Inc. for US$710 million.

The deal, scheduled for completion by the end of this year, will push the Taiwanese company to pass China's Lenovo Group as the world's third largest vendor of personal computers, an Acer press statement said.
Acer is offering to buy Gateway for US$1.90 per share, pending regulatory approvals in Taiwan and the United States, the statement said.
The acquisition has been unanimously approved by the boards of directors of both the Irvine, California-based Gateway and Acer and is subject to standard closing conditions, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 28, or the 16th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn, near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1849: Venice surrenders to the Australians, having been under siege since July 20 after proclaiming independence from Austrian rule.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949 , is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for Psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang (KMT) branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by US Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold a meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues as national unity.
1963: US civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration in favor of furthering the cause of civil rights.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1974: The Republic of China and Thailand conclude a maize trade agreement.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Bolivian Vice Foreign Minister Hernando Garcia Vespa and his wife.
1980: Premier Y.S. Sun leaves for Costa Rica, Panama and the Dominican Republic for official visits.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during an exhibition in front of a crowd of 300,000 at the US Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party, is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang convenes the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's nominees for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt -- sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Aid to Central America allies not 'checkbook diplomacy': MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/28/07 13:33:21 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The aid furnished by Taiwan to its Central American allies is part of bilateral cooperation programs and should not be misrepresented as "checkbook diplomacy, " Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang said in Nicaragua Monday.
Huang made the remarks in response to criticism that President Chen Shui-bian is wasting Taiwan taxpayers' money by making various aid offers during his current three-nation visit to Central America.
Huang said that the president "isn't bringing any checks" during the visit and that it is "unfair" to level such criticism against him.

He pointed out that none of the aid offers made by Chen during his visit are new, noting that they are all part of programs that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has been carrying out for quite some time.

They include a US$5 million loan to Honduras in support of a computerization project, a pledge to help Honduras build a hydroelectric power plant, the donation of 500 motorcycles to the Salvadoran police, and a US$1.1 million project to help Nicaragua end poverty and hunger, Huang noted, adding that the Central American allies were only making use of the opportunity of President Chen's visit to publicize the projects so as to make their citizens aware of how Taiwan is helping their countries.
For example, Huang said, even before Chen's latest visit, Taiwan had already provided US$830,000 in aid to Nicaragua under the project to fight poverty and starvation.

Huang said the project, which was launched before incumbent Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega was inaugurated in January this year, is a "very important one" for Taiwan in terms of maintaining its relations with Ortega's Sandinista National Liberation Front.

According to Huang, in light of the fact that Nicaragua has to import 75,000 metric tons of rice per year to meet domestic demand, Taiwan has helped the Central American country improve its rice output with the goal of increasing yields under the anti-poverty project.
Also, Taiwan has provided guidance to disadvantaged families in Nicaragua to raise and sell hogs for a living, he said.

Meanwhile, on Ortega's suggestion Sunday that Nicaragua and Taiwan replace free trade with "fair trade, " Huang said that what Ortega meant was that trade between the two countries should not only be free but also fair, because trade that is 100 percent free is unfavorable to countries that are economically disadvantaged.

Claiming that Ortega's suggestion does not go against the spirit of the free trade agreement established between the two countries, Huang said a major purpose of Taiwan signing FTAs with its Central American allies is to facilitate the export of products from these allies to Taiwan as a way of consolidating bilateral ties.
Citing the example of Taiwan's import quota on Nicaraguan sugar, Huang said the terms offered by Taiwan are more favorable than those offered by the United States.

On Nicaragua's desire to sell its coffee in Taiwan, Huang said this should not be a problem as coffee consumption in Taiwan is quite high, noting that although Taiwan only has a population of 23 million people, the country's coffee consumption is three-quarters of the total coffee consumption in China, which has a population of 1.3 billion people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September rose 43 points to close at 8,680, with 36,694 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 40 points to finish at 8,660, with 362 contracts traded, while December futures gained 33 points to close at 8,653, with 123 contract transactions. March futures decreased 19 points to close at 8,644, with nine contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,637 for September, 8,620 for October, 8,620 for December, 8,663 for March and 8,638 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

September TE futures moved up 3.3 points to close at 368.8, with 2,342 contracts traded, while October TE futures rose 1.25 points to finish at 365.9, with 20 contract transactions. December TE futures gained 1.1 points to close at 364.7, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures lost seven points to close at 967, with 3,387 contracts traded, while October TF futures moved down nine points to finish at 968.6, with 36 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: No casinos to be allowed before consensus reached: Cabinet official

TEXT.P: The government will not allow casinos to be established before a consensus is reached among the various sectors of society, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-Jun said Tuesday.

Chen reiterated the government's stance on the issue in an interview with the Central News Agency, during which he said that the Cabinet will not put any casino-related bills on a priority list to be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval during its upcoming session.
Chen's remarks came on the opening of a new large casino in Macau which has drawn Taiwanese people's attention to the issue again.
Media reports said earlier that the government had decided to issue three casino operating licenses, which sparked heated discussions.

However, Chen said that none of the 80-plus priority bills that the Cabinet will submit to the legislature for review deal with the casino issue. He added that the priority bills are related to the government budget, public welfare and economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan signs joint communique with Nicaragua on boosting cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/28/07 15:39:43 (By Ramon Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian signed a joint communique with Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega Monday in which both leaders reaffirmed their goal of strengthening the friendship and cooperation between the two countries.

In the communique, Chen and Ortega reiterated the importance of continued investment by Taiwan in Nicaragua's economic development projects to create employment opportunities and enhance the well-being of the Nicaraguan people.
They concurred that the two countries need to promote the signing of a "fair trade" agreement and confirmed the importance of promoting reciprocal cooperation.

Furthermore, they noted that both Taiwan and Nicaragua recognize the high value of democracy to their citizens and the necessity for the people to play an active role in strengthening and deepening democracy in their respective countries.
During the signing ceremony, Chen praised the Nicaraguan government's achievements in improving education and health and working to end poverty and illiteracy.

While expressing his appreciation to the government and people of Nicaragua for the warm reception accorded to him during his visit to the country, Chen invited Ortega and his wife Rosario Murrillo to visit Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Ortega expressed his gratitude to Taiwan for contributing to Nicaragua's social and economic development through the promotion of various economic, financial and technical cooperation programs.
Chen is currently on a visit in Nicaragua, the final leg of his three-nation Central America trip that has taken him to Honduras and El Salvador.
The main purpose of the trip was to take part in the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its Central American allies held Aug. 23 in Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: No halt to sports lottery despite baseball scandal: official

TEXT.P: The government will continue to push for the launch of a sports lottery despite a recent scandal in which several local professional baseball players were questioned on suspicion of taking bribes to rig games, Executive Yuan Secretary- General Chen Chin-Jun said Tuesday.

The sports lottery is slated to be officially launched by April 15 next year at the latest, Chen told the Central News Agency in an interview. The Sports Affairs Council is currently in charge of planning the matter, he said.
Expressing his great disappointment in the latest scandal, Chen said that previous baseball fixing scandals have caused a sharp drop in game attendance to 2,000 people per game.

Chen noted that Taiwan has produced many outstanding baseball players, some of whom are currently working for other countries' baseball teams. Such a scandal will hurt the image of these overseas baseball players and Taiwan's baseball sector, he went on.

At present, there are three bidders for the license to operate the sports lottery, namely Chinatrust Commercial Bank, Taipei Fubon Bank, and the Bank of Kaohsiung, a Ministry of Finance official said.
The winner will be announced Sept. 3, the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close slightly higher

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed slightly higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 9.24 points to close at 8,727.55.
The bourse opened at 8,697.15 and fluctuated between 8,753.39 and 8,672.81 during trading. A total of 3.46 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$111.43 billion (US$3.38 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.6 percent, and construction issues at 0.5 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues and machinery and electronics shares both moving up 0.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to help Nicaragua solve power shortages: president
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/28/07 16:43:05 (By Ramon Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan will help Nicaragua acquire thermal-power generators to resolve power shortages in the Central American country.
According to Chen, Taiwan reached an agreement with Nicaragua on the matter in May because Taiwan is very concerned about this problem facing its diplomatic ally.
Also, Taiwan will study the feasibility of cooperating with Nicaragua on the development of alternative energy such as biomass energy, Chen said.
He was speaking during a news conference jointly hosted by himself and Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega.

On reports that Taiwan has offered to provide US$30 million to Nicaragua for the procurement, ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said the two countries have not discussed the amount because they need to first decide on the model and specifications of the generators to be purchased.
Chen is currently on a visit in Nicaragua, the final leg of his three-nation Central America trip that has taken him to Honduras and El Salvador.
The main purpose of the trip was to take part in the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its Central American allies held Aug. 23 in Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. misinterprets U.N. bid referendum plan: FM
DOC.DATELINE: Managua City, Nicaragua, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/28/07 18:15:10 (By K. H. Wen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang voiced regret Monday that the United States has misinterpreted Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its U.N. bid as a step promoting Taiwan independence or changing the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

Huang made the remarks in Managua City, capital of Nicaragua, where he is accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on a state visit to the Central American country, after Hong Kong-based Phoenix Star TV broadcast earlier the same day an exclusive interview with John Negroponte, U.S. deputy secretary of state, regarding the latest political developments in Taiwan.

"So when we talk about the situation in regard to Taiwan, we talk about Taiwan in the context of a great friendship. But when it comes to this issue of a referendum as to whether or not Taiwan join the United Nations in the name of Taiwan, we do have great concerns, " Negroponte said.

"We oppose the notion of that kind of a referendum because we see that as a step towards the declaration -- towards a declaration of independence of Taiwan, towards an alteration of the status quo," he added.

In response, Huang said he could not figure out why Negroponte made such remarks. Holding a referendum is a purely domestic affair, a core value of democracy and the most democratic and peaceful way for the public to express its opinion, he said, adding that "both Taiwan's ruling and opposition camps are in favor of holding a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. cause."

Stressing that holding such a referendum is only meant to allow the public to directly express its desire for the country to participate in the United Nations, Huang said the move will neither break the "four noes" pledges made by Chen in his 2000 and 2004 inauguration speeches nor contribute to a change in cross-strait status quo.
"We regret the U.S. misinterpretation of our referendum plan, " Huang added.

In the interview with Phoenix Star TV, Negroponte was also asked whether the United States will downgrade its economic or military cooperation with Taiwan if Taiwan continues to push for the referendum.

Negroponte replied: "I wouldn't want to get into that kind of a hypothetical discussion at this particular time. But what I would like to emphasize is that we believe it's important to avoid any kind of provocative steps on the part of Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Junior high music ensemble in Chiayi to perform in Germany

TEXT.P: A traditional Chinese music ensemble from Chiayi County's Hsin Kang Junior High School in central Taiwan will travel to Germany to perform in an international youth cultural exchange program at the invitation of the activity's organizer.

The school band of 13 students, led by its instructors Yen Yung-chun and Lu Chih-tung, will depart Aug. 29 for the 10-day international activity at Oberhavel, a district in northern part of Brandenburg State in Germany.

Chiayi County Deputy Magistrate Huang Kuei-nan presented the group with a flag Monday to boost morale and mark its honor as being the only Asian group invited to participate in the international activity.

According to Huang, the band won the chance to perform again in Oberhavel thanks to its impressive performance at the same activity in 2003. Huang also noted that subsidies of NT$300,000 (US$9,060) from the Ministry of Education and Ministry of Foreign Affairs have made travel to Germany possible.
He spoke of his hope that the students would make use of the chance to join the biennial event to learn from observing different lifestyles and ways of thinking.

The school's principal, Lin Ching-huan, said since the band was established in 1997, it has won national awards in three consecutive years from 2004-2006 and been invited to perform in Germany and Turkey in 2003 and 2004, respectively.

The school's Director of Student Affairs Wu Min-nan said the school band's performance of traditional Chinese music will be a highlight of the event, which features bands playing Western music. The group plans to perform five Taiwanese folk songs at the event, he went on.
The school band will return from Germany Sept. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.008 to close at NT$33.002.
