DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign students praise MOE-sponsored Mandarin learning program

TEXT.P: Foreign students from more than nine countries praised the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) Mandarin learning program and shared what they have learned in Taiwan -- in Mandarin -- in a ceremony Tuesday before returning home.

"These have been the most special years of my life, " said Sascha Heusermann, a German who spoke on behalf of the foreign students in a ceremony marking the conclusion of the summer program. Heusermann spoke in fluent Mandarin after spending two years in Taiwan.

To promote Taiwan's Mandarin education expertise, the MOE started offering scholarships to interested foreign students in 2005. According to MOE statistics, 423 university students from 10 countries arrived in Taiwan this year to participate in the program at various local universities.

Among these, 299 students from nine countries were in Taiwan for the summer programs ranging from 21 to 55 days. The students came from countries such as the U.S., U.K., Germany, Canada, Japan, Slovenia, Russia, Poland, Costa Rica, Austria and Kiribati -- Taiwan's diplomatic ally in the Pacific.

Without the scholarships, it would be impossible for them to come to Taiwan and join the program, and the learning environment in Taiwan has been more than they had hoped for, a number of students said during the ceremony.
"Promoting Mandarin learning is a MOE policy, and to that end, there are 48 Taiwanese Mandarin teachers in Thailand, " said Minister of Education Tu Cheng- sheng.

Tu said he was aware that China has been the most common destination for foreigners wanted to learn Chinese, but "from what I heard from foreign friends, Taiwan is one of the best, if not the best, destinations as it offers professional teachers and teaching programs and an environment friendly to foreigners."
Heusermann, 22, learned more than Mandarin in Taiwan. He also observed why most Taiwanese have difficulties learning a foreign language.

"I think most Taiwanese are afraid of making mistakes. In fact, that was the last thing you have to worry about when learning a new language, " said Heusermann, who planned to stay in Taiwan and major in Business Management in National Taipei University of Technology.

"As happy as I am seeing the progress our foreign friends had during the short period of time, I think it's also time for us to take a look at the efficiency of Taiwan's foreign language education," Tu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign students start Taiwan studies with etiquette lessons

TEXT.P: Ninety-eight students from 20 countries who are preparing to study in Taiwan under the sponsorship of the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) attended a specially designed orientation program Tuesday.

An ICDF spokesman said the organization has arranged a series of language and etiquette lessons as well as a cultural experience camp for the students running from Tuesday until Sept. 6 to help them become more quickly acquainted with Taiwan's culture and lifestyle.

Their studies began with a couple of traditional etiquette lessons at National Taiwan Normal University Tuesday, and in the coming days will include paying a cultural education visit to the Confucius Temple to learn more about Taiwan's culture, according to the spokesman.

He added under the ICDF's guidance, the students will pay courteous visits to their teachers in Taiwan and write letters to their teachers to gain acknowledgement as their disciples, an activity which aims at allowing foreign students to better understand the local tradition of showing respect for teachers.

During the 10-day orientation activities, the ICDF will also hold forums on issues related to successful elements of the development of Taiwan, Taiwan's traditional culture and the etiquette of respecting teachers, with the goal of providing a platform for students to understand local culture and exchange their views.

Additionally, on weekends, the ICDF will also organize scenic tours around the island for those students to allow them to experience Taiwan's beautiful landscape and local characteristics, the spokesman added.

Since 1988, the ICDF has collaborated with 13 universities in Taiwan to offer all-English undergraduate and graduate courses and provide scholarships to attract elite foreign students to study in Taiwan. To date, a total of 250 students from 31 countries have benefited from the program, including several heirs of African tribal chiefs and the children of high-ranking political officials of Taiwan's allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top Tainan health official replaced over dengue spread

TEXT.P: The top health official in Tainan City lost his job Tuesday to take the blame for failing to bring a dengue fever epidemic in the southern city under control.

Tainan Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai decided to sack Su Chun-jen, director of the city government's Bureau of Public Health, and replace him with Hu Shu-chen, an associate professor at National Cheng Kung University.
Su confirmed that he had been notified about the decision, which will become effective Sept. 1.
Su was a neurosurgeon at the city's Chi Mei Medical Center before he became director of the public health bureau eight years ago.

Rumors had been rife in the past week that he could lose his job after multiple dengue fever infections were reported around mid-August involving 44 residents in a veterans' home in Tainan City's East district.
This year's first indigenous dengue fever case appeared in the city's Annan district in June. Since then, the number of confirmed dengue fever cases in Tainan has surpassed 260.
Health experts have warned that the Tainan epidemic could get worse as a result of the recent torrential rain that came in the wake of Typhoon Sepat.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid referendum will not change status-quo: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its U.N. cause is only a way of responding to public opinion and has nothing to do with changing the country's official title or changing the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Tuesday.

Wang made the remarks after U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte said in an exclusive interview, which was aired a day earlier on Hong Kong-based Phoenix Star TV, that the United States opposes Taiwan's holding such a referendum.

"We oppose the notion of that kind of a referendum because we see that as a step towards the declaration -- towards a declaration of independence of Taiwan, towards an alteration of the status quo, " Negroponte said.

Stating that the government understands why the United States is concerned about Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its U.N. bid, Wang expressed the hope that the United States could better understand the situation in Taiwan and said that MOFA will continue seeking to exchange views and step up communication with the United States on the referendum issue.

"Taiwan's U.N. bid referendum plan is not a provocative move and does not target any particular side, " Wang said, arguing that "it is only a method to allow the people to directly vote on the country's participation in the United Nations."

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum artworks to be exhibited in Japan

TEXT.P: A collection of 16 items from the National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei will be exhibited in Japan, marking the second time that the museum's art treasures will be seen in that country since the Japan World Exposition held in Osaka in 1970, a spokesman for the museum said Monday.

The items will be displayed at the exhibition "Shanghai Modern" showcasing Chinese artworks from the 19th and 20th centuries, including nearly 200 collections of brush calligraphy, painting, and seal cuttings.

The exhibition was organized by the Japanese newspaper Yomiuri Shinbun and will be held at the Osaka Municipal Museum of Art from Sept. 4 - Oct. 14, and at the Shoto Museum of Art in Tokyo from Dec. 11 to Jan. 27, the spokesman said.

The 16 NPM items, were shipped Monday under the escort of Liu Fang-ju, section chief of the museum's Department of Painting and Calligraphy. The department's Director-General Wang Yao-ting will attend the exhibition's opening ceremony at the Osaka Municipal Museum of Art Sept. 3.
In addition to artworks from the NPM and museums in Japan, the organizer also borrowed artworks from Taiwan's Chang Foundation Museum, and Taiwanese art collector Shih Yun-wen.
The spokesman said the exhibition will bring further cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to seek right to host 2009 Asia Pacific Cities Summit

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government will seek the right to host the 2009 Asia Pacific Cities Summit, a city official said Tuesday.

Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Cheng Wen-lon said he will bid for the right on behalf of the city government when he attends the 2007 Asia Pacific Cities Summit to be held in the Australian city of Brisbane Aug. 31-Sept. 3.

Cheng will head for Brisbane Wednesday at the head of a 21-member delegation composed of municipal officials in charge of construction, urban development, manpower resources development, cultural, media and information affairs.

Representatives from more than 100 cities in 49 member countries will attend the upcoming Asia Pacific Cities Summit to exchange views on urban renewal and sustainable development, Cheng said, adding that Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu has expressed a strong interest in securing the right to host the 2009 summit in the southern Taiwan port city to enhance the city's international profile.

The delegation will also take advantage of the event to sponsor a presentation introducing Kaohsiung City's general investment climate to attract foreign entrepreneurs willing to launch new businesses in the city, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President not opposed to dual recognition
DOC.DATELINE: Managua City, Nicaragua, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/28/07 21:15:17 (By K.H. Wen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said here Monday that he is not opposed to a dual recognition of Taiwan and China idea raised by Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega.

Chen made the remarks while fielding questions on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations and the diplomatic battle between Taiwan and China at a news conference at the Nicaraguan Presidential Office following a meeting with Ortega.
Chen said he does not oppose the idea and added that it would be a great contribution by Ortega to the world if he succeeds in making China accept the dual recognition model.

For his part, Ortega said he is aware of Taiwan's resolve to hold a referendum on its U.N. bid in March next year and that Nicaragua will respond and adopt measures pending the result of the referendum.
As a diplomatic ally of Taiwan, Nicaragua will not interfere in Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum, which Ortega said is a domestic issue.

Asked whether Nicaragua would cut ties with Taiwan in exchange for setting up diplomatic relations with China, Ortega replied that he made it clear before winning the presidential election that he would maintain ties with Taiwan and that China cannot attach any conditions if it seeks to establish formal links with Nicaragua.

Maintaining diplomatic ties with Taiwan is Nicaragua's current policy, Ortega said and he called for dual recognition to deal with Taiwan and China. Nicaragua will work toward this objective, he added.
Nicaragua is the third leg of Chen's diplomatic tour to three Central American allies that already took him to Honduras and El Salvador. He is slated to return to Taiwan Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Courage, passion, Internet take Frenchman to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Courage, passion for Chinese culture and a simple search on the Internet took Jean-Baptiste Buffeteau from France to Taiwan to learn Chinese not once but twice and he plans to come back for a third time.

Buffeteau, 30, caught a lot of attention in a ceremony organized by the Ministry of Education (MOE) Tuesday to mark the conclusion of an MOE-sponsored summer Chinese learning program. Almost all the other members of the program are university students.
Spending a year in Taiwan was not enough for Buffeteau, a politics major.

He worked in a bank after returning to France and kept thinking about coming back to Taiwan. One day he discovered through the Internet that the Taiwan government offers scholarships to foreigners wanting to study in Taiwan.
Buffeteau quit his bank job enrolled in Fu Jen Catholic University on a one- year program.
He also expressed preference for Taiwan's Chinese learning program and claimed it is better than using the simplified Chinese characters used in China.
Buffeteau, who is scheduled to return to France in early September, plans to come back to Taiwan for a third time to teach French.

DOC.HEADLINE: INER to set up solar energy research center in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: The Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER) under the Executive Yuan's Atomic Energy Council plans to establish a solar energy research center at the Kaohsiung Science Park in southern Taiwan to promote development of solar power generation technology and indsutry, INER Director-General Lin Li-fu said Monday.

Knowing that the Kaohsiung county government has invited enterprises in the solar energy industry to invest in the park, Lin visited Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing that same day to explain the plan and solicit his support in promoting solar power generation technology.

According to Lin, the institute plans to build within three years an 18,000-hectare research center in which the institute can transfer its core technology and form inspection standards that will allow it to build an inspection center for solar energy products in the future.

Lin also suggested that the Kaohsiung county government ask for help from the central government to build a 10 million kilowatt photovoltaic solar power generation system in the county, and to sell generated electricity to Taiwan Power Co. as a means of attracting investment projects and expanding the industry's market.
Lin said photovoltaic solar power generation systems have up to 30 percent efficiency, which is much higher than the 13 percent afforded by conventional electric power generation systems.

Yang asked Kaohsiung Deputy Magistrate Yeh Nan-ming to invite enterprise owners to visit the INER to gain a better understanding of the solar power generation system, and expressed willingness to visit the central government with INER staff to deliver the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to produce 'election booklet' for overseas Taiwanese

TEXT.P: The Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC) will publish a question-and- answer booklet by the end of August to help overseas Taiwanese understand their voting rights in next year's presidential and legislative elections, OCAC Vice Chairman Cheng Tong-hsing said Tuesday.
Cheng told the CNA that many Taiwanese expatriates have recently made inquiries to the commission and its foreign offices concerning their voting rights.
The booklet will feature 22 questions and answers on the election dates and voter eligibility, among other information, Cheng noted.
The information will also be published on the OCAC Web site and copies of the booklet will be made available at the commission's foreign offices and cultural centers, Cheng went on.
Cheng said more than 10,000 Taiwanese expatriates returned home to vote in the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC holds WTO national seminar

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization (WTO) National Seminar opened Tuesday, the first of its kind to be held in Taiwan, according to an official of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervision Commission (FSC) which is organizing the event.

The seminar is part of the commission's efforts to help government officials and those working in the financial sector better comprehend the impact of Taiwan's WTO entry on the country's financial market, the official noted.

The two-day seminar covers a wide range of issues on the topics of financial services trade, the General Agreement on Trade in Services, the Doha Round of WTO multilateral trade talks, and liberalization of the financial service industry.

The FSC has invited two speakers to the seminar, namely Juan Marchetti, a WTO official in charge of financial service sector matters, and Wang Lee-rong, a Taiwanese expert at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research Center, the official said.

The seminar is aimed at informing participants of the latest developments and progress in the WTO's financial service negotiations and at educating Taiwanese financial operators about protecting their rights through international negotiations, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 1,000 TB patients banned from air travel

TEXT.P: Health authorities said Tuesday they had notified some 1,100 tuberculosis patients in Taiwan that they are prohibited from traveling abroad by air.

The Center for Disease Control and Prevention under the Cabinet-level Department of Health disclosed that those placed under air travel restrictions comprise 188 multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis patients and over 900 other active infectious TB patients.
According to Chou Chih-hao, deputy director of the center, there are 399 multi- drug-resistant TB patients in Taiwan, of whom 188 have not yet tested negative for the disease.

He said that the more-than 1,100 TB patients on the restricted list will not be allowed to leave Taiwan by air unless they can present documentary proof issued by their doctors within the past week declaring that they are no longer infectious.

According to center officials, the center originally planned to publicize related measures early next year to go with a ban on air travel for infectious TB patients, but decided to implement the measures from Sept. 1.

They said the measures need to be in place urgently after a southern Taiwan couple -- both multi-drug-resistant TB patients -- traveled to China July 21, causing a public health alarm and prompting health officials on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to track them down.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's daughter loses slander case

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's daughter Chen Hsing-yu lost a slander lawsuit against a political commentator Tuesday.

The Taipei District Court ruled that Hu Chung-hsin, a television commentator, had no intention of defaming Chen Hsing-yu when he disclosed in a series of programs in October 2005 that the president's daughter had opened a bank account in New York to engage in suspected money laundering.

Cheng Hsing-yu, a dentist, stayed in New York Sept. 12-16, 2005, to attend a short course on dental implant techniques. Hu quoted unnamed sources as saying that she was seen in the company of friends opening an account with a New York bank.
Money laundering was suspected as a purpose for the account, apparently because at the time, the president and other members of the first family were dogged by a series of corruption scandals.
The court said in its written statement that two witnesses testified that their Taiwanese friends returning from the United States saw Chen Hsing-yu opening an account.

Although the court asked the Ministry of Justice to verify whether she had opened such an account, the ministry pointed out that it could not request U.S. help for such investigation because opening a bank account is not a criminal act, the statement said.

Another dentist from Taiwan who attended the same course testified that Chen Hsing-yu skipped one afternoon class. The court said it could not be ruled out that she might have used that opportunity to open an account.
Based on these facts, the court decided that Hu could not be found guilty of slander unless it could be ascertained that the opening of the account never happened.

DOC.HEADLINE: China sabotaging cross-strait status quo: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its bid to join the United Nation under the name of Taiwan is a move to protect, rather than alter, the Taiwan Strait status quo, the country's mainland policy charter said in a press release Tuesday.

The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) issued the statement in response to U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte's remarks made in an interview with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Star TV that the U.S. government opposes the notion of Taiwan's planned referendum because it sees that as a step toward "a declaration of independence" and toward "an alteration of the status quo."

Rebutting the U.S. stance, the MAC press statement said Taiwan need not declare independence since it is already an independent sovereign state and that the present cross-strait status quo lies in the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are separate, it added.

As a member of the international community, the statement went on, Taiwan is entitled to join all major international organizations. The U.N. bid referendum plan is aimed at manifesting the common will of the people of Taiwan through a democratic procedure and protesting China's hegemonic political apartheid against Taiwan, the statement added.

Under the guise of its peaceful unification overture, the MAC statement said, China has actually spared no efforts to suppress Taiwan diplomatically and to intimidate Taiwan militarily. Besides saber-rattling and economic threats, China has deployed 1,000 ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan and has enacted its so-called Anti-Secession Law to legalize its use of force against Taiwan.
Against this backdrop, the MAC statement said, China is the true saboteur of the cross-strait status quo and the real troublemaker in terms of regional stability and international peace.

Noting that the U.N. bid referendum is initiated by the private sector, the MAC statement said both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the main opposition Kuomintang have come up with similar proposals and are scheduled to hold mass parades Sept. 15 to drum up support for their referendum proposals, respectively.

The MAC statement urged the U.S. government to support Taiwan's quest for U.N. representation and to respect Taiwan's democratic system, while avoiding being misled by China into sending a wrong signal that could accerbate China's suppression of democratic Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said the U.N. bid referendum is a consensus of ruling and opposition parties and that the move neither violates President Chen Shui-bian's now famous "four noes" pledge nor alters the Taiwan Strait status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan committee approves KMT-initiated referendum bid

TEXT.P: An Executive Yuan screening committee approved Tuesday the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -initiated proposal to hold a national referendum on whether to apply to rejoin the United Nations and join other international organizations in a pragmatic manner.

The referendum proposal was put forth for examination by the KMT's vice presidential candidate, Vincent Siew. The proposal was seen as the party's countermeasure against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-initiated, more radical referendum plan which calls for joining the U.N. under the name of Taiwan.

According to the Referendum Law, the KMT now has to collect signatures of at least 825,359 voters in six months to make its referendum proposal eligible for a nationwide vote to be held by the Central Election Commission.

All of the eight KMT recommended members of the Executive Yuan screening committee voted for the referendum proposal at a meeting held Tuesday afternoon, but two members recommended by the People First Party, the KMT's ally, voted against the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Earthquake shakes Orchid Island

TEXT.P: A magnitude 5.2 earthquake shook Orchid Island, also known as Lanyu, at 9: 15 a.m. Wednesday, but there were no immediate reports of damage, according the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The epicenter of the quake was located 32.5 km southwest of the Lanyu earthquake monitoring station at a depth of 15.7 km, the CWB reported.
The temblor registered an intensity of 3 on Orchid Island, which is located southeast of Taiwan proper, and an intensity of 1 in Kaohsiung City and on the Hengchun Peninsula in Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. official's remarks represent strong message to Taiwan: candidate

TEXT.P: The United States sent a strong message to Taiwan when its deputy secretary of state spelled out that Washington opposes Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on the island's bid to enter the United Nations under the name Taiwan, the opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate said Wednesday.
Ma Ying-jeou was referring to remarks made by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte in an exclusive interview that was aired Monday on Hong Kong- based Phoenix Star TV.

In the interview, Negroponte said that "we oppose the notion of that kind of a referendum because we see it as a step towards a declaration of independence of Taiwan, towards an alteration of the status quo."

Commenting on Negroponte's remarks, Ma said that no ranking U.S. official has publicly criticized Taiwan's policy in such strong terms before, adding that his words represent a strong message to Taiwan.
Ma said he does not think the Democratic Progressive Party administration's rash and abrupt moves regarding Taiwan's U.N. bid will work.
"It is wishful thinking that the United States will take whatever it is given and that it will come to Taiwan's rescue anytime, " he said.

Ma said that the KMT, which governed Taiwan between 1949-2000, will continue to push for a referendum on the issue of the Republic of China on Taiwan bidding to "return" to the United Nations, but with a more pragmatic approach that does not include the issue of what name the country should use in applying for membership in the world body.

In the interview with Phoenix Star TV, Negroponte was also asked whether the United States will downgrade its economic or military cooperation with Taiwan if the island's government continues to push for the referendum.

Negroponte replied: "I wouldn't want to get into that kind of a hypothetical discussion at this particular time. But what I would like to emphasize is that we believe it's important to avoid any kind of provocative steps on the part of Taiwan."

JOSE Maria Sison, founder of the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP), was arrested in The Netherlands after a Dutch court judge issued a warrant for his arrest, according to the Department of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nicaragua supports Taiwan's U.N. bid: President Chen
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/29/07 13:07:51 (By Ramon Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday Nicaragua is supportive of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, despite the absence of any public statement of such a stance by the Central American country.

Speaking during an informal gathering with a group of foreign correspondents in Nicaragua, Chen said Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega has on many occasions expressed his support for Taiwan's U.N. bid and its push to hold a referendum on the issue.

According to Chen, Ortega fully understands that the referendum promoted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on joining the United Nations is different from the one promoted by the opposition Kuomintang on "returning to" the world body.

Chen said that Ortega, as a pro-democracy fighter, is well aware of the Taiwan people's aspiration and pursuit of democracy and that during a private meeting between the two of them, Ortega repeatedly encouraged him to continue pushing for the referendum and insisting on using the name Taiwan to join the United Nations.

On Ortega's remarks that his country hopes to have formal diplomatic relations with both Taiwan and the People's Republic of China, Chen said if Nicaragua were able to achieve the goal, it would be a big step forward.

Reiterating that he does not oppose "dual recognition, " Chen said Ortega would make a great contribution to the world that would make him deserving of a Nobel Peace Prize if he succeeded in the effort.

Chen stressed that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should seek a resolution to their differences based on the principles of sovereignty, democracy, peace and equality, calling on Beijing to accept the reality and status quo that Taiwan is a sovereign country and respect the choice of Taiwan's 23 million people.
According to Chen, goodwill, reconciliation and cooperation are crucial for the achievement of lasting peace.
Chen pointed out that he has extended 30 to 50 olive branches to China over the past seven years but that regrettably, none have received a positive response from Beijing.

Noting that the main purpose of his Central America visit was to take part in the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the region held Aug. 23 in Honduras, Chen said the summit became even more meaningful in the wake of Costa Rica's switching of diplomatic recognition to Beijing in June.

While many are concerned that the severance of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Costa Rica might result in a domino effect among Taiwan's other diplomatic allies in the region, leaders of these Central American countries reaffirmed their support for Taiwan during the summit, according to Chen.

Nicaragua was the final leg of Chen's three-nation trip which also took him to Honduras and El Salvador. He wrapped up the visit later Tuesday and departed for home. He was scheduled to make a short stopover in the U.S. state of Alaska en route back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA reiterates U.S. misinterpreting U.N. bid referendum plan

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reiterated Wednesday that the United States has misinterpreted Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, saying it will continue to communicate with Washington on the issue.

MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh repeated Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang's remarks made Aug. 27 in Nicaragua where he was accompanying President Chen Shui- bian on a state visit, in response to U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte's recent interpretation regarding the plan.
Wang said the MOFA regrets that the U.S. official characterized the referendum plan as "a step towards the declaration of independence of Taiwan."
"Such an interpretation is not right at all, " Wang said, adding that holding such a referendum is a domestic affair.
He reiterated Huang's comments on Taiwan's U.N. membership referendum that organizing such an activity is "a peaceful way for the public to express its opinion."
The move will neither break President Chen Shui-bian's "four noes" pledge nor alter the state quo in the Taiwan Strait, Wang stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan not considering importing Chinese liquor: official

TEXT.P: The government currently has no plans to allow liquor from China to be imported into Taiwan, Executive Yuan Secretary General Chen Chin-jun said Wednesday.

Chen was referring to a United Daily News report, which quoted opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Hui-kuan as saying the day before that the Bureau of Foreign Trade, under pressure from certain officials and alcohol importers, is considering allowing a "small quantity" of Chinese spirits to be imported into Taiwan, probably to the tune of about 4-8 percent of the total amount of alcohol consumed annually in Taiwan.

Chen stressed that three conditions would have to be met before Taiwan would allow Chinese liquor imports -- namely that Taiwan's national security would not be undermined, that relevant industries in Taiwan would not be adversely affected and that the Taiwan people's health would not be compromised.

The secretary-general pointed out that there are hundreds of kinds of liquor in China and that according to reports, up to 80 percent of the liquor produced there is bootleg, which he said could pose a health risk to consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO welcomes application for use of U.N. bid logo

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) will start accepting applications for use its logo bearing the image of a whale in a tank symbolizing Taiwan's desire to join the United Nations, in an effort to better promote the government's U.N. bid, a GIO official said Wednesday.
Firms that have their designs approved by the GIO and pay a royalty fee of NT$10,000 will be authorized to use the GIO-designed logo on all their products for a year, the official said.

A T-shirt with the logo worn by GIO Minister Shieh Jhy-wei for U.N. bid promotion activities has drawn the public's attention, prompting the GIO came up with the idea of letting more people use the logo to facilitate the U.N. campaign.

The whale in a fishtank logo shows a humpback whale that has a similar shape to Taiwan trying to escape from a tank that limits its space and isolates it from outside world. The logo symbolizes Taiwan's exclusion from the United Nations and its desire to break free of restrictions and isolation imposed on it.

The GIO expressed the hope that authorized firms would use part of their profits from products bearing the logo for social welfare so that the logo will not only speak for Taiwan's need to join the United Nations but will also benefit society, the official said, adding that application details can be accessed via the GIO's Web site.

The official said the government's promotion advertisements for the U.N. bid will be seen in New York City's John F. Kennedy International Airport, in public phone booths downtown and on buses around the headquarters of the United Nations from September, in order to let its voice be heard by the United Nations General Assembly that will start its next session Sept. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 84.23 points to close at 8,643.32.
The bourse opened at 8,514.47 and fluctuated between 8,643.32 and 8,514.47 during trading. A total of 4.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$129.09 billion (US$3.91 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares and paper and pulp issues both moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.7 percent, construction issues at 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues and machinery and electronics shares both at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent, and textile stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 462, with 162 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen makes brief transit stop in Anchorage
DOC.DATELINE: Anchorage, Alaska, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/29/07 15:35:15 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in Anchorage, Alaska at 11: 20 a.m. Wednesday, Taipei time, for a transit stop, after concluding a three- nation visit to Central America.
Chen did not disembark the plane, receiving Raymond F. Burghardt, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , on board the aircraft.

According to ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tang Bi-a, who is a member of Chen's entourage, Burghardt invited the president to disembark the airplane, telling Chen that "many people are waiting for you down there."
Tang said the president turned down the invitation and told Burghardt that the United States has made him feel a lot of stress.

The U.S. government had reportedly refused to allow Chen to stopover in any major U.S. cities other than Anchorage or to stay overnight during his transit stops on his Latin American trip as a way of expressing its displeasure with his administration's plan to push for a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.
On his first transit stop in Anchorage on Aug. 21 en route to Honduras, Chen expressed regret with the U.S. restrictions, calling the treatment "inconvenient, uncomfortable and indecent."
His second transit stop in Anchorage lasted less than an hour. The president's plane is scheduled to arrive at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at 9: 45 p.m. Wednesday, Taipei time.

President Chen departed Taiwan Aug. 21 for his Central America visit to attend the sixth leadership summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the region. The summit was held Aug. 23 in Tegucigalpa, the capital city of Honduras.
After a four-day visit in Honduras, Chen headed to El Salvador Aug. 24, from where he traveled to Nicaragua Aug. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: EU asks for more information on tax discounts for churchs.
The EU commission has asked the Italian government to provide more detailed information on tax discounts that the church benefits in Italy in order to have a clearer picture of the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to invite president to Sept. 15 rally for U.N. bid

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will be invited to take part in a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rally slated for Sept. 15 in Kaohsiung to promote the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, a party official said Wednesday.
Others to be invited include Vice President Annette Lu as well as DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his running mate, Su Tseng-chang, according to DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung.
Lin said that the DPP's overseas branches will organize a series of activities promoting the bid next month and that on Sept. 15, they will hold events corresponding to the Kaohsiung rally.
With the Kaohsiung rally expected to draw 500,000 participants, the global turnout will top 1 million, Lin said.

On U.S. opposition to the planned referendum on the U.N.bid, Lin said that Taiwan "stands on the side of justice" and that with disregard for international pressure, the DPP will show the international community that joining the United Nations is the common desire of the Taiwan people.

According to Lin, the recent remarks by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte opposing the referendum have made the DPP cling even firmer to its resolve to promote the referendum and the U.N.bid.
Lin said that while the United States claims to be the world's greatest democratic country, Negroponte's remarks are humiliating not to Taiwan but to America's founding spirit.

Lin said it is very ridiculous that two democracies are now quarreling over the issue of holding a referendum and allowing totalitarian China to benefit from the fight. He urged the United States not to make any compromises to China at the expense of Taiwan.

During an interview on Hong Kong-based Phoenix Star TV Monday, Negroponte said the United States is opposed to the U.N. bid referendum because Washington sees it as a step "towards a declaration of independence of Taiwan" and "towards an alteration of the status quo."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow TimesGCourt Orders Arrest of Oil Tycoon
A Moscow court on Tuesday issued an arrest warrant for billionaire Mikhail Gutseriyev, amid speculation that the former Russneft presiden t had fled the country to avoid what he last month called a politically motivated campaign against him. [by Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. restricts Taiwan democracy by opposing referendum: lawmaker

TEXT.P: The United States is restricting the progress of Taiwan's democratization by opposing the government's plan to hold a referendum on its bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Wednesday.
DPP Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim was referring to remarks made by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte in an interview aired Monday on Hong Kong- based Phoenix Star TV.

In the interview, Negroponte said that the U.S. "opposes the notion of that kind of a referendum because we see it as a step toward a declaration of independence of Taiwan, toward an alteration of the status quo."
Hsiao noted that holding a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. membership bid is a move championing the will of the people.

It is regrettable that the United States, which has long supported Taiwan's democratization, is drawing lines and oppressing the progress of Taiwan's democratization when Taiwan is pushing, via peaceful and democratic means, for U.N. membership aimed at expressing Taiwan's wish to participate in global activities and make contributions to the international community, Hsiao said.
According to Hsiao, Negroponte made the remarks more with the aim of getting the message across to the Chinese leadership than speaking to the people of Taiwan.

Negroponte's "misinterpretation" or "over-interpretation" of Taiwan's U.N. bid referendum plan as "a step toward a declaration of independence of Taiwan" could also be the result of Chinese influence, Hsiao said, adding that based on the fact that Taiwan and the United States are long-standing friends, the DPP will continue to communicate with Washington on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid referendum aimed at expressing popular will: DPP lawmakers

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers defended Wednesday the plan to hold a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, saying that the move is aimed at demonstrating the common will and aspiration of the Taiwan people.

The DPP lawmakers made the remarks after U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte said in a recent interview with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Star TV that "we oppose the notion of that kind of a referendum because we see it as a step towards a declaration of independence of Taiwan, towards an alteration of the status quo."

DPP legislative whip Wang Sing-nan said that it is not fair that the United States opposes Taiwan's planned U.N. bid referendum, adding that the United States should have instead criticized U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon for publicly claiming that Taiwan is part of China.
Wang noted that it is important to use the referendum to demonstrate the will of the Taiwan people and to let the world know Taiwan is an independent, sovereign country.
DPP Legislator William C.T. Lai said that Negroponte's remarks show that the United States does not understand the expectations of the people of Taiwan.
The country's bid to apply for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan is aimed at safeguarding the rights of the Taiwan people, rather than at moving towards Taiwan independence, Lai said.

U.N. membership would ensure that Taiwan would not be annexed by China, Laid claimed, adding that U.N. membership would protect the people of Taiwan and dissolve the threat posed by China to peace and security in the Asia Pacific region.

DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin said that every nation has its own interests and that it is understandable that the United States attaches greater importance to China as it has a much bigger market than Taiwan does.

However, Yeh urged the United States to realize that Taiwan also has its own national interests and that the people of Taiwan want to use the referendum to express their view that Taiwan should be recognized by the international community as an independent, sovereign country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to hold first leadership summit with African allies

TEXT.P: The government will hold the first leadership summit with its African diplomatic allies in Taipei Sept. 9, in which President Chen Shui-bian will share Taiwan's various successful experiences with his African counterparts, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.
The heads of state of Taiwan's five allies in Africa -- Swaziland, Malawi, Gambia, Burkina Faso and Sao Tome and Principe -- will attend the summit, MOFA spokesman David Wang told a press conference.
At the summit, Chen will speak about Taiwan's achievements in digital technology, sustainable development, economic growth, medical care and security issues, Wang said.
He will also sign a joint communique with the visiting African leaders following the summit, Wang went on.

In addition to the summit, the government will organize a forum Sept. 10 to invite the allies' government officials, business people, academics and experts from various fields to exchange ideas with their Taiwanese counterparts, Wang said.
The African leaders will also be invited to attend the 2007 World Wheelchair and Amputee Games to be held Sept. 11, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor leaves for Australia to attend regional cities summit

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin will fly to the Australian city of Brisbane Wednesday night to attend the 2007 Asia Pacific Cities Summit (APCS) slated for Aug. 31-Sept. 3.
Hau will deliver a briefing at the event about Taipei's plans and perspective regarding its development as a waterfront city, according to the Taipei city government.

After concluding his visit to Brisbane, Hau will travel to Singapore to inspect the city-state's Hyflux Water Processing Plant and Biopolis, a research and development center for biomedical sciences. He is scheduled to return home Sept. 7.

The Brisbane APCS, the sixth of its kind, is expected to draw the participation of 1,000 government officials and enterprise leaders in the region, who will take part in discussions surrounding the event's 2007 theme -- renewing Asia- Pacific cities -- according to the summit host, the Brisbane city council.

The biennial APCS was founded in 1996 to foster city partnerships and encourage the sharing of information and ideas between local governments, technical experts and businesses within the Asia-Pacific region.
It will be Hau's first time to attend APCS, city officials said, revealing that the mayor will take part in a mayors forum Sept. 1 and will sign an agreement with other summit participants Sept. 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September dropped 131 points to close at 8,549, with 37,086 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved down 124 points to finish at 8,536, with 349 contracts traded, while December futures lost 115 points to close at 8,538, with 32 contract transactions. March futures decreased 137 points to close at 8,540, with 15 contracts traded, while June futures decreased 182 points to end at 8,499, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,680 for September, 8,660 for October, 8,653 for December, 8,677 for March and 8,681 for June.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

September TE futures moved down 6.7 points to close at 362.1, with 2,744 contracts traded, while October TE futures dropped 3.9 points to finish at 362, with 23 contract transactions. June TE futures decreased 8.85 points to close at 356.95, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.

September TF futures lost 22.4 points to close at 944.6, with 2,258 contracts traded, while October TF futures moved down 23.6 points to finish at 945, with 26 contract transactions. Next June TF futures dropped 70 points to close at 943, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gregorian calendar may be included in DPP's resolution

TEXT.P: A passage stipulating that the Republic of China calendar be phased out and replaced with the Gregorian calendar will probably be included in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) newly drafted "normal country" resolution, party sources said Wednesday.

Wang Tuoh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said that adopting the Gregorian calendar instead of the ROC calendar, or "Minkuo, " is more convenient for the Taiwan people in the face of increasing globalization and would also "allow Taiwan to be uplinked to the world."
Wang appealed to the public not to "over-interpret" the calendar change politically.

The passage was not included in the DPP-drafted version of a "normal country" resolution that is set to form a critical part of the DPP's campaign platform for the 2008 presidential election, but after DPP Legislator Trong-rong Chai consulted Frank Hsieh, the party's candidate, a day earlier, Hsieh reportedly expressed no opposition to the notion that the inclusion will be put for discussion in a DPP Central Executive Committee meeting slated for Thursday.
According to Wang, the inclusion will very likely be passed in Thursday's meeting.
Also commenting on the inclusion, DPP Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung said that following the Gregorian calendar is a world trend and that it is "no big deal" for Taiwan to do so also.

The resolution calls for completion of the party's ultimate goal of changing the nation's official name, writing a new constitution and holding a national referendum to underline Taiwan's status as an independent sovereign state.

The resolution further says that since it has become very difficult to use the name Republic of China in the international community, the country should apply to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other international bodies in the name of Taiwan.

The resolution originally suggested that the country's title be changed to Taiwan, that the ROC calendar be phased out and replaced with the Gregorian calendar, that the existing five branch government system be replaced with a three-branch one and that the special municipality designation be eradicated from the local government hierarchy.
As some DPP bigwigs, including Hsieh, questioned the plausibility of those proposals, they were all dropped from the final version of the draft resolution adopted Monday.

The draft resolution will be submitted to the DPP Central Executive Committee for approval at its weekly meeting Thursday and will then be put up for endorsement by party delegates at a party congress next month, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.058 to close at NT$33.060.
A total of US$606 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.950 and closed at the day's high of NT$33.065.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen, Taipei City tops as retirement destinations: survey

TEXT.P: Although most local retirees see Hualien as a "most desirable place" to live after retirement thanks to its natural scenery, they still rate Kinmen County and Taipei City as the "best place" to live based on practical considerations, according to the results of a poll by a local magazine.

The survey was conducted via telephone by Common Health magazine between June 30 and July 31 among 10,225 people in 25 cities and counties to obtain information on topics related to the best places for the elderly to live in Taiwan. The survey was conducted according to five criteria: public safety, medical resources, convenience, leisure and financial security.

Key findings from the survey reveal that most people were looking forward to living in Hualien after retirement, followed by Nantou and Penghu counties. However, the popular tourist attraction scored low on public safety, leisure and medical resources.

The outlying counties of Kinmen, Penghu and Lienchiang ranked the top three local retirement spots in terms of public safety, while the central city of Taichung placed at the bottom of the list in this respect.

The survey results also found that people are most worried about letting elderly relatives go out by themselves in Taichung City and Kaohsiung County, while the streets of eastern Hualien County, Taipei City and Changhua County are most likely to make elderly people fall and more than 70 percent of drivers in Taipei County do not give way to elderly people trying to cross the street.

The southern city of Chiayi came first in terms of health resources, while the central county of Yunlin and Taipei County scored the lowest in this respect. Residents in Hsinchu, Chiayi and Tainan cities reported the highest level of satisfaction for accessibility of medical care, according to the report.

Taichung County and Hsinchu City rated high on leisure, as the local governments attach great importance to promoting leisure activities for seniors, while Penghu and Kinmen counties scored poorly due to the lack of resources, and Lienchiang County ranked bottom in this respect because the county government has never set up any senior-citizen recreation centers or organizations at all.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to open six offshore areas for wind turbine installation

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is set to open up six sea areas off the coast of Taiwan for wind turbine installations, with an estimated power generation capacity of 300,000 kilowatts in the first stage of its "offshore wind power development guidelines," government sources reported Wednesday.
The project will also boost the output value of related local industries by NT$40 billion (US$1.2 billion), they added.

The official installation registration process for applicants will start Sept. 1, with several local companies, including China Steel, Formosa Heavy Industries Corp. and TECO Electric & Machinery Co., having shown strong interest in bidding, according to the MOEA's Bureau of Energy.

MOEA officials pointed out that the offshore wind farm locations are off the coast between Miaoli and Taichung, off the Changpin Industrial Park in Changhua County, near Wai San Din Alluvion in Yunlin County, off the coast between Chiayi and Tainan, off Yilan County and around the outlying Penghu islands.
Officials noted that qualified companies should complete establishment in three years after the ministry issues operation permits, or their exclusive rights will be canceled.

Meanwhile, in order to boost local technology capabilities in wind power generation and wind turbine manufacturing, they said the ministry also requires multinational corporations allowed to join the development to both license a certain portion of key technology to local manufacturers and cooperate with local companies to build components in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nobel laureate invited to lecture at Cheng Kung University

TEXT.P: Aaron Ciechanover, one of three winners of the 2004 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, will lecture at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) as a visiting chair professor this year, a spokesman for the Tainan-based university said Wednesday.

Cienchanover, born in 1947 in Haifa, Israel, was awarded along with Avram Hershko and Irwin Rose for the discovery of ubiquitin-mediated protein degradation. He helped NCKU last year with the establishment of the Institute of Innovations and Advanced Studies and took part in several academic workshops in Taiwan, according to NCKU.

Starting in the 2007 academic year that will begin in September, the professor will give lectures to graduate students pursuing master's and doctorate degrees while conducting research at NCKU, the spokesman said.
NCKU has also invited two other Nobel laureates to lecture at the southern Taiwan university, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei 101 Mall, Grand Hyatt Taipei have city's cleanest toilets

TEXT.P: The Taipei 101 Mall and the Grand Hyatt Taipei have the cleanest toilets among the city's department stores and restaurants, including hotels, according to the results of an evaluation of public toilets released Wednesday by the Taipei city government's Bureau of Environmental Protection.

Rounding out the top three list in the category of department stores are Idee and Sogo's Fuhsing store, while the Grand Hotel and McDonald's Taipei Zoo outlet rank second- and third-cleanest, respectively, in the restaurant category.
In the recreational category, the toilets at Taipei Zoo were rated the cleanest, followed by those at Yangmingshan National Park and the Postal Museum.
In the transportation category, the cleanest toilets were found at the Muzha station of the city's mass rapid transport network, Sungshan Airport and the underground parking lot at Linsen Park.
In the market category, the toilets at the Taipei Pot Plant Auction were the cleanest, followed by the Shuanglien Market and the Nanmen Market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City rescue team to take part in Japan drill

TEXT.P: Seven members from the Taipei City Urban Search and Rescue Team under the Taipei City Fire Department departed Wednesday to take part in a disaster prevention and rescue drill in Tokyo.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin presented a flag a day earlier to the team to mark its honor of being the first foreign rescue team to be invited by the Tokyo metropolitan government to participate in the exercise. It is also the first time the team has participated in an international disaster prevention and rescue drill.
Tokyo delivered the invitation via the Asian Network of Major Cities 21, a body representing the interests of several of Asia's largest capital cities around common themes of importance.
The team's seven members and a rescue dog named Bailey, the city's best rescue dog that has taken part in several local rescue jobs, will join the Japan drill together.

Set up Sept. 21, 2000 as Taiwan's first international rescue team certified by America's Federal Emergency Management Agency, the team is equipped to be self- sufficient for 72 hours in a disaster area and is able to carry out different functions including directing, searching, rescuing, medical relief, construction and back-up supply.
Its members are all professionals and have participated in many rescue jobs including rescues after earthquakes in Iran and El Salvador.

The joint disaster rescue exercise in Japan will simulate a scenario in which Tokyo is hit by an earthquake and the Taipei team will send out Bailey and use a life detector to help rescue people trapped in collapsed buildings, and work with Tokyo rescue teams on other emergency relief jobs.
Hau expressed hope that the team will make use of the chance to learn from Japanese rescue teams' efficiency, which he saw when Japanese rescuers helped after Taiwan's 921 earthquake of 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mayors to address Asia-Pacific Cities Summit in Brisbane

TEXT.P: Two mayors and a deputy mayor from Taiwan will attend the 2007 Asia-Pacific Cities Summit in Brisbane, Australia, from Aug. 31 to Sept. 3.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair will address the summit on the opening day to present business opportunities in their cities.
Kaohsiung, a sister city of Brisbane, will send Deputy Mayor Cheng Wen-lon to the summit, who will also speak on business opportunities presented by the sisterhood ties.
More than 600 delegates will attend the meeting, including civic and business leaders and decision makers from more than 50 Asia-Pacific cities.
The summit was founded in 1996 as an initiative of the Brisbane city council. It is held biennially, with the host city rotating between Brisbane and bidding cities in the Asia-Pacific region.
The primary goal of the summit is to foster city partnerships and to encourage the sharing of information and ideas between local governments, technical experts and businesses within the region.
According to the Brisbane city council, the theme for this year's summit is "Renewing Asia-Pacific Cities."

The summit will focus on cities as the catalysts for economic growth. It is designed to help businesses in the region establish relationships and create export and investment opportunities. For the first time, the summit will be held in conjunction with the 10th International Riversymposium, a leading international forum on river management.
The delegates will have an opportunity to view the southern hemisphere's largest working marina and shipyard, the Gold Coast City Marina.

DOC.HEADLINE: Buddhist organization INEB to hold 2007 conference in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The International Network of Engaged Buddhists (INEB) , a self-governing organization of Buddhists from more than 20 countries, will hold its 2007 conference in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County from Aug. 31 to Sept. 2.

Nearly 100 delegates from around the world will attend the conference at the Buddhist Hongshi College in Kuanyin township. These delegates are coming from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Burma, India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Australia, the United States and China.

Ven. Chao Hwei, professor of religion with Hsuan Chuang University in Hsinchu, is the chairperson of the INEB organizing committee for the Taiwan conference. She and Sulak Sivaraksa, a co-founder of the INEB, will jointly present a keynote speech on "Kukkha and Its Cause" in the Sept. 1 session.

Yo Hsiang-chou, an associate professor with Fo Guang University in Yilan County and chief coordinator for the conference, will co-present another keynote speech on "Nirvana and Its Path" with Yoshiharu Tomatsu, a research fellow with Japan's Jodo Shu Research Institute.

During the afternoon sessions Sept. 1-2, the delegates will be divided into smaller groups to discuss various topics, including the perpetuation of suffering, Buddhism and consumerism, socially engaged Buddhism and spiritually engaged Buddhism, and dana: social welfare or social transformation.

From Sept. 3 to 6, the delegates will travel around Taiwan to visit major Buddhist establishments, including the Dharma Drum Mountain in Chinshan township of Taipei County, Hsuan Chuang University in Hsinchu, Fo Guang Mountain in Kaohsiung, Tzu Chi Buddhist Hospital in Taipei County's Hsintien township and the Museum of World Religions in Taipei.

The INEB was founded in 1989 by a group of Buddhist thinkers and social activists in Thailand, with its focus on peace, human rights, gender issues, spirituality-based development, diversity tolerance and interfaith dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical Storm Fitow unlikely to hit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Tropical Storm Fitow, this year's ninth named storm in the western Pacific, came into being Wednesday afternoon at a location about 1,500 km northeast of Guam, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said in a forecast.
CWB meteorologists said that Fitow, still 3,000 km from Taiwan, was moving north at 13 kph, and that chances of the storm hitting Taiwan are very slim.
The storm has a 100-km radius, with maximum center winds of 18 meters per second and gusts of up to 25 meters per second.
From Aug. 31, Fitow will likely change direction from north to northwest, and increase its speed slightly from 13 kph to 14 kph, according to meteorologists.
They predict that the tropical storm could head toward Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Late president's commemoration days eliminated

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has eliminated commemoration days marking the dates of late President Chiang Kai-shek's birth and passing, which fall on Oct. 31 and April 5, respectively, MOI Minister Lee Yi-yang announced Wednesday.

The Executive Yuan approved the MOI's proposal to remove from the calendar these two national commemoration days, which Lee said were products of Taiwan's authoritarian era when unjust acts violating democratic values and human rights were committed.

The institution of the two commemoration days arose out of particular societal and historical contexts, but are no longer appropriate for Taiwan given that the current government is pursuing transitional justice for the country, Lee said.

Lee explained that national holidays should have special meanings and be celebrated or commemorated by all of Taiwan's people. Chiang, being a controversial person and a pivotal figure in today's polarized views of the nation's historical development, should not have be celebrated with national commemoration days, Lee went on.

Existing regulations stipulate that the anniversary of Chiang's passing, which falls on April 5, be held on Tomb Sweeping Day, which falls between April 4-6 each year, Lee said, adding that the proximity of the two events wrongly creates an impression of a relationship between the them.

Lee called on all Taiwanese people and political parties to deal with problems stemming from the previous authoritarian regime with wisdom, courage and rationality in order to help further the cause of justice and development of Taiwan's democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Voluntary American English teachers to teach in English Village

TEXT.P: More than 30 Americans will soon begin voluntarily working as English teachers in an English Village in Taoyuan County, which will open in September, a charity foundation in charge of the program announced Wednesday.

A total of 34 voluntary teachers, ranging from four to 60 years-old, will teach at the English Village during the next 12 months. The situational language teaching method will be applied in the village, which has different classrooms, said Morgan Sun, the chief executive officer of the King Car Education Foundation.
The teachers volunteered to come to Taiwan through a Christian organization in the U.S. which has been in close relationship with the foundation.

"It feels good to be able to serve another country by teaching English. I would also like my family to learn about Chinese and Taiwanese cultures to better understand what this world looks like, " said Roy Lyons, who brought his wife and daughters to Taiwan. Lyons also taught English in China during 2002-2005.

"It [teaching] is a lot of hard work, but it feels good to make friends with Taiwanese college students and children, " said Nathan Straub, who arrived in Taiwan seven weeks ago and has been teaching in English summer camps in Hsinchu and Hualien.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental issues focus of Taiwan representatives at APEC summit

TEXT.P: In recognition of the threat posed by global warming and the importance of energy security, Taiwanese business leaders will focus on environmental issues at the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) business summit, the delegation said Wednesday in a press conference.

Even from a purely business point of view, the impact of global warming and energy security can no longer be overlooked and ignored, said Jeffrey Koo, Chairman of Chinatrust Financial Holding Company, who will be leading the Chinese Taipei business delegation to Sydney, Australia for the APEC Business Advisory Council (ABAC) Sept. 6-7.

Koo, Theodore Huang, chairman of Chinese Association of Industry and Commerce, and Henry Kao, Vice Chairman of I-Mei Foods Company will be three top representatives of the Taiwanese delegation, which also includes a number of business leaders invited by the Australian government.

Taipei Financial Center Corp Chairwoman Diana Chen, a delegation member, spoke of the importance of energy in the urban setting: "Taipei 101 is like a vertical city. I believe there are many things we can learn from broad discussions and exchanges at the APEC summit in terms of energy management and energy consumption saving."

Taiwan businesses will help promote "Green APEC Opportunity, " the nation's initiative this year for the APEC meeting. As Taiwan has not been doing particularly well in controlling greenhouse gas emissions, it can contribute to the promotion and development of environmental and energy-saving products, said Huang Chih-peng, Director-General of Bureau of Foreign Trade.

Taiwanese business leaders will also support proposals submitted by Australia, the Asia-Pacific Network on Climate Change/Clean Development and the Global Initiative on Forests and Climate, Huang said, adding that Taiwan will be able to contribute with its advanced solar energy technology.

In terms of the other important aspect of the meeting -- Trade and Investment Liberalization and Facilitation (TILF) -- Taiwan's position is no different than other member economies, which share the long term goal of finding ways and means to establish the Free Trade Area of Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) , said David Hong, Director General of the Chinese Taipei APEC Study Center (CTASC).

The ABAC is one of a series of APEC meetings to be held in Sydney from Sept. 2-9. The meetings include Concluding Senior Officials' Meeting (CSOM), APEC Ministerial Meeting (AMM), ABAC and the APEC economic Leaders' Meeting (AELM) -- the highlight of the annual meeting of 21 member economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's referendum on U.N. bid meant to defend status quo: President

TEXT.P: Instead of altering the political status quo across the Taiwan Strait, the referendum on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations is meant to preserve and defend it, President Chen Shui-bian said here Tuesday.

Chen, who arrived here for a transit stop on his way back to Taiwan after a three-state visit to Central America, was quoted by an aide as making the remarks to Raymond Burghardt, Chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, when the latter greeted Chen at the airport.

Lee nan-yang, chief of the Public Affairs Department of the Presidential Office, quoted Chen as telling Burghardt that he disagreed with U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte, who told a Hong Kong-based TV that Washington considers Chen's proposed referendum as an alteration in the status quo and a step towards a declaration of independence by Taiwan.

Lee quoted Chen as saying that the referendum initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party was favored by 76 percent of Taiwanese people, and opposed by 11 percent; more than 74 percent of Taiwan's people believe Taiwan is an independent sovereign state, while 11 percent who think it is a part of China; and 85 percent of Taiwan's people believe its territory does not include the mainland, while 10 percent think the opposite.

Furthermore, the president told Burghardt that 69 percent of people in Taiwan believe they are Taiwanese not Chinese, that this represents the majority opinion in Taiwan, and Washington should be awake to it rather than attempting to suppress it.

A referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid doesn't mean the country will obtain U.N. membership immediately, but it will help Taiwan's people rally behind the idea and let the world know of Taiwan's determination to enter the United Nations, Chen was quoted as saying.

Since most of Taiwan's people believe that Taiwan is already an independent sovereign state rather than a part of the People's Republic of China, there is no necessary to declare its independence, Chen was quoted in rebutting Negroponte's argument.

Although the referendum calls for the country's U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan it has nothing to do with changing the country's designation, Chen argued, citing the fact that Taiwan has joined different international groups under different names.

Chen noted that Taiwan operates under the name Chinese Taipei at the International Olympic Committee and Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, and the name of the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu in the World Trade Organization.
According to Lee, Burghardt asked Chen what Taiwan's next step would be after the U.N. bid referendum.

The president said the question should be answered by the 23 million people in Taiwan, and Washington is in no position to discourage Taiwan's people from pursuing the democracy America promotes around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese Taipei wins title at Asian Junior Baseball Championship

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei successfully won the title for the second year in a row at the AAA Asian Junior Baseball Championship by defeating South Korea 1: 0 in the central city of Taichung Wednesday.

The Chinese Taipei's winning run was scored at the second inn thanks to Lien Chih-yuan who stroke a second base hit which helped a teammate already on the second base to run home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 30, or the 18th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30 B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives US Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian receives Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcomes his visit aimed at strenthening exchanges between the ROC and Australia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid referendum will not change status quo: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has reiterated that Taiwan's planned referendum on its U.N. membership bid will not change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

The president made the remarks upon his arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport late Wednesday after concluding a nine-day trip to Central America, which included transit stops in the U.S. state of Alaska.

According to Chen, the referendum issue was raised during his meeting with U.S. representatives during the transit stops, and he told them that Taiwan is already a sovereign country and has no need to declare independence.

Chen said with the status quo being that there is "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait," the referendum on whether to use the name Taiwan to join the United Nations will not cause any changes to the situation.
Instead, the referendum will help safeguard the cross-strait status quo and prevent China from changing it unilaterally, he said.

Reiterating that the holding of referendums is a basic human right and a way of deepening Taiwan's democracy, Chen said the right of Taiwan's 23 million people should not be restricted or denied just because of China's opposition and suppression.

The country's efforts to gain membership in international organizations such as the United Nations and World Health Organization under the name Taiwan are aimed at upholding the rights of the people and have nothing to do with changing the country's official name, the president said.

The U.S. government, which does not support membership for Taiwan in international organizations that require statehood, has expressed its opposition to the U.N. bid referendum on the grounds that it would increase tensions in the Taiwan Strait.

In the latest such statement, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte said during an interview on Hong Kong-based Phoenix Star TV Monday that the United States is opposed to the referendum because Washington sees it as a step "towards a declaration of independence of Taiwan" and "towards an alteration of the status quo."
