DOC.HEADLINE: President protests changing of Taiwan's name at Venice Film Festival

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian voiced his protest Thursday against a recent change to the country's designation by the organizers of the 2007 Venice Film Festival under pressure from China, saying that not even cultural events are spared from Beijing's relentless political interference.

Chen addressed the issue in the latest edition of his online newsletter, referring to the use of "Taiwan, China" to replace "Taiwan" as the producing country of four films participating in the festival.

Pointing out that similar situations occurred in the past at the Berlin International Film Festival and the Cannes Film Festival, Chen said the Government Information Office has lodged a protest with the organizers in this latest case in the hope that a correction will be made as soon as possible.

As China is using every possible means to isolate Taiwan and prevent it from upholding its sovereignty, the government has been working very hard to strenghten its relations with the international community, Chen said.
Besides these efforts, the president also pointed to two recent examples of Taiwan shining in the international arena, despite China's "brutal and uncivilized" treatment.

The first example was the excellent performances by the Taipei First Girls' High School marching band at the just-concluded Edinburgh International Festival held in the United Kingdom, with the band members wearing uniforms on which the national flag was displayed, Chen said.

According to the president, the performances gave international audiences the chance to see the beautiful Taiwan and allowed the name Taiwan to spread around the world through coverage of the event by local and international media.

The second example mentioned by the president was the Taiwan team's display of national pride at the 2007 Microsoft Imagine Cup. Although the members of the team, which finished second in the short film category of the competition, were prohibited from carrying the country's flag while receiving their medals, they all wore slippers with the colors of the flag and with the letters "TW" stitched on them to let the world know they are from Taiwan.
He said these examples prove that the country's citizens can help Taiwan stand out on the world stage by using their creativity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices rebound on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rebounded Thursday from a moderate drop a day earlier, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 127.89 points to close at 8,771.21.
The bourse opened at 8,782.35 and fluctuated between 8,825.92 and 8,750.62 during trading. A total of 4.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$156.21 billion (US$4.73 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 5.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 3.3 percent, textile stocks at 2.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 2.1 percent, construction issues at 1.9 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.2 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers more than 1,000 to 437, with 215 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recession hits communication equipment sector

TEXT.P: Taiwan's communication equipment production has recently recorded its first recession since 2002, with the output value for the first half of this year registering a decline of 5.4 percent over the same period of 2006, according to statistics released Thursday by a non-profit research center.

The statistics, compiled by the Industrial Economic and Knowledge Center (IEK) under the Industry Technology Research Institute, show that the communication equipment manufacturing sector's production totalled NT$317.5 billion (US$9.58 billion) for the period.

IEK analyst Wu Yu-ju said the industry enjoyed significant growth in output in 2002 due to fast-growing demand for wireless products. The trend contributed to a steady expansion of the sector over the past five years, she added.

In 2006, it flourished again, thanks to a boom in mobile phone OEM orders, as well as the impact of the Taiwan-based BenQ Group's takeover of the mobile phone department of Germeny-based Siemens, one of the world's leading manufacturers in electrical engineering and electronics, Wu said.

However, the good days failed to last, Wu went on, saying that the output of mobile phone OEM factories fell by 36.1 percent in the first half of this year compared with the same period of 2006 -- from 67.77 million units to 43.16 million units.
The mobile phone sector generated an output value of NT$95.2 billion between January and June, down from NT$159.5 billion for the same period of 2006, according to Wu.

In Contrast, the global positioning system (GPS) production industry posted booming growth in the first six months of the year, with the output registering a rise of 69.7 percent over the same period of 2006 to reach NT$71.8 billion.
The output of personal navigation devices took the lion's share of the total output of the GPS sector at 79 percent, according to the IEK.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI defends move to scrap late president's commemoration days

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang rebutted Thursday opposition criticism of his ministry's move to scrap two commemoration days related to the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
Describing the commemoration days as vestiges of authoritarianism, Lee said they should never have existed in the first place and that their abolishment is long overdue.

Lee announced Wednesday the abolition of the commemoration days marking Chiang's birth and passing, which fall on Oct. 31 and April 5, respectively. The move was immediately criticized by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party as an example of "ideological manipulation."
According to Lee, no democratic countries in the world have a day designated to commemorate an individual unless he is the country's founding father or has made a major contribution to the country.

Noting that "half of the people in Taiwan disapprove of Chiang, " Lee added that the government should not continue coercing the public into honoring him, especially in light of his role in the 228 Incident of 1947 in which thousands of people were massacred by KMT troops while suppressing a rebellion against KMT rule in Taiwan.

Asked whether the Ministry of the Interior has any plans to scrap the commemoration days marking the birth and passing of Republic of China founding father Sun Yat-sen, Lee said the government has no intention of doing this, as those commemoration days are not controversial.

Meanwhile, Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said removing the remaining vestiges of Chiang is part of the country's "disenchantment" process to achieve transitional justice and that in the next step, the Democratic Progressive Party administration will eliminate all traces of the past KMT rule.

Although martial law has long been lifted in Taiwan, many people are still living in the dark authoritarian era, Shieh said, adding that only by removing the "phantom" of Chiang will they "let the sunshine in."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, decreasing NT$0.010 to close at NT$33.050.
A total of US$738 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.030 and fluctuated between NT$33.020 and NT$33.082.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC to make diagnosis of suspected Tainan CJD case

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health is expected to announce early next month whether a suspected case of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) reported in Tainan, southern Taiwan is indeed CJD -- the human derivation of mad cow disease.

According to CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao, CDC specialists met in March to discuss the case -- reported by the National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) Hospital -- and based on limited information, made a preliminarily diagnosis that the patient was not suffering from CJD.

The United Daily News, however, reported Thursday that the same patient, who has developed classic symptoms of CJD over the past 10 months and is now in a vegetative state, could be suffering from a new variant of CJD (nv-CJD), as she had received placenta injections for a long time before checking into the NCKU Hospital for treatment.

The CDC decided to call in its specialists Sept. 8, saying that it had received limited information about the patient's medical history before and would like to re-examine the case after the NCKU hospital provides it with more details of the patient.

So far, the causes of classic CJD infection are unknown and there is no exact cure to it, but classic CJD has always been around. It is very rare, striking about one person per million every year worldwide. Mostly the cases are "sporadic, " meaning they have no known cause. A few have been linked to organ transplants from infected people, or to genetics. Many victims who died from classic CJD did not contract it from contaminated meat. Classic CJD strikes people 50 or older, progresses rapidly and has only physical symptoms.
To date, a total of 175 classic CJD cases have been reported in Taiwan, with about a dozen cases being reported each year, according to Chou.

New variant CJD, however, is a human disease of the central nervous system that was first diagnosed in the United Kingdom in 1995. Scientists have tentatively linked the disease to eating meat products from cattle infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), commonly called mad cow disease.

Except for a few cases in other European nations with BSE, nv-CJD has been found almost exclusively in the United Kingdom. It strikes younger people, often begins with psychiatric symptoms and progresses slowly.

Both diseases are brain-wasting, eventually destroying the victims' motor skills and coordination, and both show a characteristic spongelike appearance in the victims' brains when autopsied. Both are fatal and transmissible spongiform encephalopathy.

CDC officials preliminarily excluded the possibility that the Tainan patient -- whose age is an important factor but was not disclosed -- is an nv CJD patient on the grounds that placenta injections are banned in Taiwan and that there is nothing in the literature to indicate that any CJD cases have been caused by placenta injections.

BAA, the owner of Britains three biggest airports, is planning to cut up to 2,000 jobs, leading airlines to give warning that a lack of staff could result in even poorer service than passengers suffer already,The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: Illegal drug labs moving from China to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Illegal drug laboratories are gradually moving from China to Taiwan, posing a threat to the nation's social order, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Minister Wang Jin-wang said Thursday.
The phenomenon has become more evident as investigation and law enforcement on illegal drug production are getting stricter in China, Wang said.

According to Wang, CGA and the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice discovered a drug factory in Tainan County Aug. 26, and found 800 kg of ketamine worth NT$600 million (US$18.09 million), the biggest single haul of ketamine in Taiwan's history.

The CGA discovered 500 kg of smuggled amphetamine and ketamine last year, about half of which was found hidden under the bottom of cars shipped in containers, and half of which was packaged as health food and discovered at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Wang said.

Wang said the black market for illegal drugs in Taiwan is likely to expand because many violators of laws regarding class A and class B drugs were released after implementation of the commutation statute in July. The police are taking notice as to whether released drug violators will increase demand for drugs and cause price hikes, Wang added.
The CGA, the police and the Investigation Bureau will work harder on clampdowns on drug use and smuggling, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kenting authorities urge locals to help protect land crabs

TEXT.P: The Kenting National Park Administration has invited people, particularly locals, to volunteer to help protect the area's land crabs, whose numbers have continued to decline due to environmental changes.

The park is home to the most species of terrestrial crabs found in Taiwan, with the round-bodied, hairy-legged species, scientifically known as cardisoma hirtipes, being the largest group in the Kenting area located along the coast of Taiwan's southernmost tip.

Cardisoma hirtipes exhibits a seasonal activity pattern governed by the lunar cycle. Its breeding season picks up around the Moon Festival, which falls on the fifth day of the eighth month of the lunar calendar, with mother crabs leaving their terrestrial nests and making a perilous crossing of Highway 26 on their way to the sea to spawn.

Many of the crabs are destroyed by cars on their way to the sea, administration officials said, prompting them to appeal to locals to volunteer to protect the crabs so the animals can reach the sea safely.
The locals have also been asked to serve as tour guides for people wanting to see the crabs, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president inspects Matsu development

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu flew to Matsu, a Taiwan-controlled island close to China's southeastern coast, to inspect development there Thursday.

Lu conducted the one-day visit in the company of several Cabinet officials, including Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hsieh Fa-ta, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun, Council of Agriculture Vice Minister Lee Jen-chyuan and Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Oliver Yu.
Lu was wanting to find out what people there need to improve their livelihoods and was briefed to this end by Chen Hsueh-sheng, magistrate of Lienchiang County, which covers Matsu.

During the briefing, Chen and Matsu Legislator Tsao Erh-chung called for the central government to open the doors wider for the existing direct shipping links between Matsu and Mawei in China's Fujien Province, commonly known as "mini three-links."

Tsao asked the MAC to relax restrictions on political policy to allow an expansion of the links and suggested that the government open its doors for people living on Taiwan proper to travel to China via Kinmen and Matsu. At present, only residents of the two islands and some Taiwan business people operating in China enjoy the right to travel between their homeland and China's Fujian Province.

In response, Lu proposed expanding the "mini three-links" to the "medium three- links," saying that Kinmen and Matsu could be developed "into places like Hong Kong and Macau" as cargo and passenger transshipment areas, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen group to attend 2007 Cross-Strait Travel Fair in Xiamen

TEXT.P: A delegation of more than 70 members from the outlying island of Kinmen will leave for Xiamen in China's Fujian province Sept. 4 via the "mini-three links" to take part in the 2007 Cross-Strait Travel Fair scheduled for Sept. 6-11.

The delegation will be headed by Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yang Chung-chuan. Its members will include officials from the county government's Bureau of Tourism and Bureau of Reconstruction, employees from the Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Co., members of the Kinmen Chamber of Commerce and the Kinmen Association of Travel Agents, and representatives from 18 businesses.
Before arriving in Xiamen, the delegation will first visit Zhangzhou and Longyan -- two Fujian cities -- to hold promotional activities Sept. 4-5 to attract tourists to Kinmen.
In addition to taking part in the Xiamen travel fair, the delegation members will also attend a cross-strait travel forum Sept. 7.

The Cross-Strait Travel Fair is sponsored by China's Cross-Strait Travel Exchange Association, the Fujian Provincial Tourism Bureau and the Xiamen municipal government to promote investment cooperation, bilateral and multilateral economic exchanges and partnerships.
The exhibition is part of the 11th China International Fair for Investment and Trade (CIFIT), held annually in Xiamen Sept. 8-11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan opens new Web site for disclosure of unsafe imports

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has created a new Web site for disclosure of unsafe imports, particularly those from China, Cabinet Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun announced at a news conference Thursday.
The Web site is located at http://www.unsafeimports.nat.gov.tw.

Chen also displayed several unsafe Chinese products, including bedding with unsafe formaldehyde levels, a towel containing benzidine, toothpaste containing diethylene glycol, children's garments made with fluorescent material, and frozen shrimp, all of which failed inspection.
Chen said the products are dangerous and could jeopardize consumers' health.
The Executive Yuan also set up a team Aug. 2 to integrate information on unsafe imports and urge authorities at all levels to notify the public about unsafe products on their own Web sites.

Chen said consumers can also dial "1950" to reach local consumer service centers for further information and can submit complaints on problematic products via the Consumer Protection Commission Web site.
The Executive Yuan will enhance examinations of imported products and learn from other countries' measures in dealing with unsafe imports, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rumor of islet airport constructed for Chen rebutted

TEXT.P: Presidential Office officials rebutted Thursday a media report that construction of an airport on the Taiwan-held islet of Taiping in the Nansha Islands near the South China Sea has resumed and is being rushed so that the facility's inauguration might be overseen by President Chen Shui-bian in December this year.
The officials ridiculed the United Daily Evening News allegation as completely off-base for having misleadingly connected the building of the airport to the president's itinerary.

They confirmed that the Taiping airport is being built with funds appropriated from the Executive Yuan Second Reserve Fund and that the construction must be completed by the end of this year in accordance with the usage of the fund.

According to the evening news report, former Defense Minister Lee Jye stealthily appropriated the funds for the project's budget during his tenure, but the budget was killed later by the Legislative Yuan, thus the construction was suspended.

Recently, the Ministry of National Defense quietly resumed construction and ordered that the construction be fast-tracked so that President Chen could travel to the outlying islet to inaugurate the airport in December, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cancer drug found effective against Alzheimer's disease

TEXT.P: Taiwan researchers have proved during rodent testing that a widely used cancer drug is also effective against Alzheimer's disease, with clinical experiments set to begin in October and a new drug for the brain disease expected to be marketed in three to five years, Academia Sinica sources reported Thursday.

The drug -- granulocyte-colony stimulating factor or G-CSF -- has been used in cancer cases for years to offset the side-effects of chemotherapy, with a boosting effect to human blood cell regeneration through stimulating the release of hematopoietic stem cells from bone marrow.

Biologists at Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's top research institution -- have found that the stem cells released can not only replenish the damaged blood cells but can also refresh the impaired areas in body organs like the heart and brain.

In a research paper published in multiple renowned science journals, Shen Che- kun and Tsai Kuen-jer -- both from Academia Sinica's Institute of Molecular Biology -- state that the cognitive and memory functions of Alzheimer's disease- infected laboratory mice have recovered to near-normal status after being treated with G-CSF, indicating that the stem cells have replaced the dysfunctional neurocytes to overcome the injuries caused by the Alzheimer's.

Shen noted that conventional drug treatments for Alzheimer's mainly focus on maintaining the status of brain function, without the ability to restore them to full performance. While some stem-cell therapies show promising signs in function restoration, they require injections or operations on the damaged areas of the brain.

Unlike other stem-cell therapies, the G-CSF method is non- intrusive, requiring only injections in the abdomen or blood vessels to activate the effect, Shen pointed out, adding that the motivated stem cells will then move to the brain and repair the target area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oil, commodity price hikes cost locals dearly: survey

TEXT.P: Surging oil and commodity prices have incurred a combined estimated extra expenditure of NT$46 billion (US$1.4 billion) per month for local people aged over 18, according to the results of a survey released by a local magazine Thursday.
The Global Views Monthly magazine conducted the telephone survey among 1,012 randomly chosen Taiwanese citizens over the age of 18 Aug. 12-14, with a margin of error of 3.1 percentage points.

High oil prices are blamed as the culprit of the recent inflation, the magazine said in its latest issue. Prices for many consumer items, such as dairy products, flour and other food ingredients among other commodities, have surged recently.

According to the survey results, 81 percent of the respondents said gas and commodity price hikes have adversely affected their lives, while another 38 percent described the impact on their lives as "huge."
In addition, 29 percent of the people polled said they have to spend an extra NT$1,000-NT$3,000 per month to maintain their current living standard amid rising oil and commodity prices.
The survey also found that 46 percent of the respondents are more likely to use buses or the MRT than their own vehicles to cope with the soaring oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taiwan drug seeking FDA permit for human testing

TEXT.P: An innovative drug for diabetic ulcers, developed by a Taiwanese biomedical research institution, is about to be submitted to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for a permit on human testing, academic sources disclosed Thursday.
If approved, they noted, it will mark a milestone in the nation's pharmaceutical research and development.

The drug was developed by the government-funded Development Center for Biotechnology (DCB) and has been transferred to a local pharmaceutical company, Microbio Biotechnology, to continue the R&D process.

All ingredients of the combo drug are extracted from natural herbs, and possess distinct curative effects for diabetic wounds but show none of the side-effects seen previously, making it an improvement on the only drug available on the market, according to the DCB.
Diabetic patients sometime suffer from persisting wounds which may become ulcers capable of disturbing or undermining the immune system if left untreated.

To date, Taiwan's biomedical industry has spent most of its R&D funds on improving existing drugs, and there has been no previous case of developing a wholly new drug -- a fact that makes this new drug even more remarkable, noted researchers on the both side.

If the drug is permitted to undergo human testing, it will be the first time that a Taiwanese-made drug has passed FDA reviews, and only the second time that a combo drug has been approved by the U.S. drug administration, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung Mayor publishes book on wife's car accident

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu has published a book recounting his wife Shao Hsiao- ling's "miraculous" survival after a near-fatal car accident last November.

Shao was critically injured in the accident Nov. 18, 2006, which occurred when the van in which she was traveling was run off the freeway while returning to Taichung from a Kaohsiung mayoral election campaign activity.
Shao lapsed into a coma, lost her spleen and part of her left forearm. She was hospitalized for 92 days before making her first public appearance.
"I cannot explain why Shao survived, but I believe it is a miracle," Hu said Wednesday during the launch ceremony for the book, titled "If you Don't Believe in Miracles, They Won't Happen."
Hu also expressed his appreciation for the public's support in helping him and his wife tide through their ordeal, saying he could see the hope in Taiwan through the support of the public.
The accident also caused him to change his perspective on life, Hu said, noting that he has learned to respect the Taichung City Council members and has decided not to quarrel with them any more.
Hu also said he has no plans to take part in any other election campaigns as he wants to spend more time with his wife.

DOC.HEADLINE: Park patrol teams to be organized for wetland protection

TEXT.P: The Taichung County government will organize patrol teams in October to advise visitors against improper behavior that might jeopardize the environment of Kaomei wetlands in the county's Chingshuei township, a local official said Thursday.
The county's Agriculture Bureau is recruiting volunteers to from the patrol teams, the official said. The volunteers will also help clean up the wetlands in addition to advising the public.

The wetlands have abundant floral and fauna resources, constitute an important natural resource conservation area of western Taiwan, and attract a lot of visitors with its beautiful coastline, sunsets, and rich ecological views, the official said.
The Taichung County government designated the wetlands as a wildlife protection area in 2004 and has prescribed a number of rules for visitors in an effort to protect the wetland's natural resources.
Visitors are prohibited from disturbing, mistreating or hunting wildlife inhabiting the wetlands, and behavior that would damage the environment is not permitted.

However, many visitors have ignored and violated the rules, leaving behind litter, catching crabs, and digging up plants. Some have even driven cars or ridden scooters into the area, the official said.
The official said the volunteer park wardens will work with the county's natural resources protection association to safeguard the area.
The bureau has asked five village heads in the area to recommend environmental conscious residents who might be interested in participating, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor federation organizing rally against rising health premiums

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese Federation of Labor announced Thursday that a mass rally will be staged by workers next month in protest against rising national health insurance premiums and a poor pension program for laborers.

Federation President Chen Chieh said that the July 1 rise in the country's minimum wage was a form of "belated justice, " but denounced the administration for allowing the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) to raise the health insurance premiums, beginning Aug. 1.
In addition, Chen said, a planned labor pension reform will probably reduce the laborers' pension payments to a level lower than that to which retired laborers are now entitled.

These two developments have prompted the federation to organize a mass rally Sept. 18, when some 20,000 workers will march to the Executive Yuan, the Legislative Yuan and the Department of Health to vent their anger and make their position known, Chen added.
Responding to the federation's planned demonstration, BNHI President Chu Tze- min said the laborers have the right to demonstrate, but the BNHI has raised the premiums in accordance with the law.
Chu appealed to the labor federation to reconsider before launching the mass rally, which he said would be costly for society.

Also commenting on the federation's demonstration plan, Council of Labor Affairs Vice Chairwoman Tsao Ai-lan said the federation might have misunderstood the content of the new labor pension program, which she insists will definitely be more beneficial to the working class than the existing one.
Tsao also urged the federation to push the Legislative Yuan to quickly pass an amendment governing the laborers' pension system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Accomplice of former Taipei city councilor gets six-year sentence

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court sentenced an accomplice of a former Taipei city councilor involved in extortion to six years in prison Thursday.

The court also ruled that Hung Cheng-hsiung, owner of a construction company who helped former Taipei city councilor Lo Tsung-sheng extort money from several other construction companies, will be stripped of his citizenship rights for two years after he has finished serving his prison term.
The court said that it will pass sentence on Lo and another accomplice, Cheng Hai-yuan, at a later date.
Lo, a two-term Taipei city councilor who served until December 2006, was charged in June last year with extorting money from four construction companies in the 2002-2004 period.

Although Lo has been released from custody on NT$800,000 bail and is barred him from leaving the country, he has never appeared in court proceedings. He has been placed on the nation's most-wanted list.

Public prosecutors in Taipei are seeking a 17-year sentence for Lo, charged with forcing four construction companies to "donate" some NT$4 million to ensure that he would keep quiet about their unlawful dumping of construction debris.

The victims claimed that Lo and his aides had used their access to files at the Maintenance Office of the city government's Department of Public Works to obtain information about which construction companies were found to have illegally dumped construction wastes.
Lo and his aides would then allegedly demand money from the companies and threaten to blow the whistle on them if they did not cooperate.
According to the four construction companies, Lo would accept the cash and pretend that he "borrowed" the money by writing a check to each of them, but the checks would always bounce.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party stripped Lo of his party membership in July 2006. He sought a third city council term but lost the election in December last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA sends locals to learn agriculture in Germany, Japan

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has selected six locals to visit Germany and Japan to study their agricultural methods for one month with the council's sponsorship, COA Chairman Su Jia-chyuan said Thursday.
Su made the remarks at a press conference prior to the departure of the six, urging them to share what they learn from these two advanced countries with others following their return.

The program is part of the council's campaign, launched last year, to provide training to young people who are interested in Taiwan's agricultural industry, and to encourage more young people to join the industry, Su said.

By the end of July, 150 of 2,040 people who participated in the campaign have become involved, bringing new concepts and business operation models to the country's agricultural sector, according to Su.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to launch GMP certification for cosmetic products in 2008

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is slated to launch Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) guidelines for local cosmetic and skin care products in 2008, a bureau official said Thursday.
The quality assurance proof is part of the bureau's efforts to enhance the competitiveness of the domestic cosmetics industry and to raise the industry's international profile, the official said.

The annual output of Taiwan's cosmetics industry amounts to over NT$30 billion (NT$911 million) , NT$7 billion of which comes from products sold in the Southeast Asia and the Europe, according to the official.
The official noted that an increasing number of large local enterprises have also developed cosmetic products over recent years, which provided a strong boost to the industry.

The local cosmetics industry supports the government's promotion of Cosmetic Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) because the official said the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the European Union will do so after 2008, and China will follow within the next two or three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to step up investment in SMEs: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Thursday activated a government policy to allot NT$10 billion (US$300 million) from the National Development Fund for investment in small- and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) around Taiwan to promote industrial upgrading.
Quoting a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) assessment, Chang said, the new strategy is expected to benefit 1,000 SMEs and to create around 20,000 jobs.

A ceremony was held at the National Taiwan University stadium to mark the launch of the new investment drive. Besides Chang, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen and Council for Economic Planning and Development Minister Ho Mei-yueh also attended the ceremony.

Chang said in his address that there were over 1.24 million small and medium enterprises in Taiwan in 2006, accounting for 97.77 percent of all domestic businesses, and that these enterprises employed more than 7.75 million people, or 76.66 percent of the country's working population.
Sales of small and medium enterprises totalled NT$10 trillion last year, accounting for 29.84 percent of revenue at all enterprises in Taiwan, Chang added.

To assist in the development of such enterprises, Chang said the government set aside a budget of NT$23.6 billion for the program in 2006, an amount more than 50 percent greater than any offered in the past.
This year, Chang went on, the NT$10 billion national fund will be used to help SMEs upgrade their techniques, expand market share, promote innovation, and personnel training.
The funds will be managed by seven professional management companies, and venture capital firms have been invited to join in the SME investment program, the premier added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red-clad anti-graft protesters to gather again Sept. 9

TEXT.P: The red-clad anti-graft protestors who launched a campaign Sept. 9 last year to oust scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian will gather again in front of the Presidential Office, an executive of the campaign said Thursday.

Yao Li-ming, a deputy commander of the campaign told reporters that the protesters will be back on Ketegalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office Sept. 9 to keep the anti-graft movement alive.
He said the anti-graft leaders will not mobilize the masses for a large-scale march in Taipei's streets, but will only hold a candle-light vigil.
Yao said the anti-graft headquarters have obtained permission from Taipei police authorities to hold the vigil.
"We will announce plans during the vigil for further protest actions on the Oct. 10 National Day," he said.
Yao confirmed that Shih Ming-teh, former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party who initiated the anti-graft campaign last year, will attend the vigil.

He also said the campaign headquarters will donate whatever balance is left from last year's donations to under-privileged groups, and that the campaign leaders will try to muster new funds needed for future anti-graft activities.

Shih, who served as DPP chairman between 1994 and 1996 before leaving the party in 2000, launched the anti-graft campaign on Sept. 9 last year with a round-the- clock sit-in in front of the Presidential Office following a street march with an estimated 200,000 people.

After a massive street march by an estimated 750,000 protesters on Sept. 15 failed to bring the desired response from the president, anti-graft campaign leaders targeted the Presidential Office on the Double Ten National Day in an attempt to humiliate Chen and his family, who were dogged by a series of corruption and embezzlement scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Noted Chinese NBA player to visit Taiwan Sept. 7-9

TEXT.P: Yao Ming, the best-known Chinese basketball player, is scheduled to visit Taiwan Sept. 7-9 for sports exchanges and public-interest activities, government sources said Thursday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Yao, who is considered one of the best centers in the U.S. National Basketball Association (NBA) , is welcome to visit Taiwan as a basketball professional to help boost athletic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
It will be Yao's first visit to Taiwan since he became an NBA player in 2002. He previously visited Taiwan in 1997 and 2000 for amateur basketball contests with local players.
Chen said Yao should focus on sports-related or public-interest activities during his stay and refrain from any fund-raising activities.
The Cabinet-level MAC, which charts Taiwan's policies toward China , called a special meeting Thursday to screen Yao's application to visit Taiwan. The application was approved during the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense takes lion's share of government budget for 2008

TEXT.P: Defense spending will take the lion's share of the government's budget for 2008, government officials said Thursday.
The officials made the remarks after the Executive Yuan referred the 2008 draft budget bill to the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day for deliberation and approval.

According to the Executive Yuan-proposed budget, military spending is projected at NT$341.1 billion, up NT$48.1 billion from this year's level. The amount accounts for 20.1 percent of the government's projected expenditure from the coming year, which also constitutes the largest share of the budget pie.

Defense spending takes the second largest budget share for 2007, lagging behind expenditure for culture, education, science and technology. Due to increases in arms procurement funds, military spending will top the spending list next year, the officials said.

According to the draft budget bill, the government's revenues are projected at NT$1.61 trillion, compared to the projected expenditures of NT$1.69 trillion. It will mark the first time in nine years that the government's budget gap will be narrowed below NT$100 billion, the officials added.

By the end of July, 150 of 2,040 people who participated in the campaign have become involved, bringing new concepts and business operation models to the country's agricultural sector, according to Su.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to launch GMP certification for cosmetic products in 2008

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is slated to launch Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) guidelines for local cosmetic and skin care products in 2008, a bureau official said Thursday.
The quality assurance proof is part of the bureau's efforts to enhance the competitiveness of the domestic cosmetics industry and to raise the industry's international profile, the official said.

The annual output of Taiwan's cosmetics industry amounts to over NT$30 billion (NT$911 million) , NT$7 billion of which comes from products sold in the Southeast Asia and the Europe, according to the official.
The official noted that an increasing number of large local enterprises have also developed cosmetic products over recent years, which provided a strong boost to the industry.

The local cosmetics industry supports the government's promotion of Cosmetic Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) because the official said the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the European Union will do so after 2008, and China will follow within the next two or three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to step up investment in SMEs: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Thursday activated a government policy to allot NT$10 billion (US$300 million) from the National Development Fund for investment in small- and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) around Taiwan to promote industrial upgrading.
Quoting a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) assessment, Chang said, the new strategy is expected to benefit 1,000 SMEs and to create around 20,000 jobs.

A ceremony was held at the National Taiwan University stadium to mark the launch of the new investment drive. Besides Chang, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen and Council for Economic Planning and Development Minister Ho Mei-yueh also attended the ceremony.

Chang said in his address that there were over 1.24 million small and medium enterprises in Taiwan in 2006, accounting for 97.77 percent of all domestic businesses, and that these enterprises employed more than 7.75 million people, or 76.66 percent of the country's working population.
Sales of small and medium enterprises totalled NT$10 trillion last year, accounting for 29.84 percent of revenue at all enterprises in Taiwan, Chang added.

To assist in the development of such enterprises, Chang said the government set aside a budget of NT$23.6 billion for the program in 2006, an amount more than 50 percent greater than any offered in the past.
This year, Chang went on, the NT$10 billion national fund will be used to help SMEs upgrade their techniques, expand market share, promote innovation, and personnel training.
The funds will be managed by seven professional management companies, and venture capital firms have been invited to join in the SME investment program, the premier added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Noted Chinese NBA player to visit Taiwan Sept. 7-9

TEXT.P: Yao Ming, the best-known Chinese basketball player, is scheduled to visit Taiwan Sept. 7-9 for sports exchanges and public-interest activities, government sources said Thursday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Yao, who is considered one of the best centers in the U.S. National Basketball Association (NBA) , is welcome to visit Taiwan as a basketball professional to help boost athletic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
It will be Yao's first visit to Taiwan since he became an NBA player in 2002. He previously visited Taiwan in 1997 and 2000 for amateur basketball contests with local players.
Chen said Yao should focus on sports-related or public-interest activities during his stay and refrain from any fund-raising activities.
The Cabinet-level MAC, which charts Taiwan's policies toward China , called a special meeting Thursday to screen Yao's application to visit Taiwan. The application was approved during the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 31, or the 19th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
12AD: Caligula, originally Gaius Caesar, Roman emperor remembered for his murderous reign, is born. He succeeded his adopted father Tiberius. After a severe illness, he displayed the ruthlessness, extravagance and megalomania that led to his assassination.
1422: Henry V, King of England, who reopened the Hundred Years' War, defeating the French at Agincourt in 1415 and capturing all of Normandy by 1419, dies of dysentery in France at the age of 35. His son Henry VI accedes to the throne at the age of nine months.
1907: The Anglo-Russian Convention is signed in St. Petersburg, settling differences between the two over Tibet, Afghanistan and Persia.
1907: Ramon Magsaysay, president of the Philippines from 1953 to 1957, is born.
1939: Adolf Hitler announces the invasion of Poland. Three days later, both Britain and France declared war on Germany, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: The Nationalist government divides the three northeastern provinces in Manchuria into nine provinces.
1957: Malaysia achieves independence from Britain with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first president.
1961: President Chiang Kai-shek tells 70 visiting American reporters that Kinmen and Matsu "are as important as West Berlin."
1962: The former British possessions of Trinidad and Tobago become an independent nation.
1962: The Republic of China recognizes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.
1965: Pakistan and India threaten war over Kashmir.
1968: A strong earthquake rocks northeastern Iran, killing 12,000 people and injuring over 100,000 others.
1974: The first plant to produce high-density polyethylene resins in the Republic of China is dedicated at Toufen in Miaoli County.
1976: Little League, Big League and Senior League teams return to Taipei after winning world titles in the United States.
1980: The ROC Mulan soccer team wins the championship at the first International Women's Soccer Tournament held in the United States.
1989: Buckingham Palace officially confirms that the marriage of Queen Elizabeth II's daughter, Anne, and Captain Mark Phillips is on the rocks.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun advises the Legislative Yuan that ROC relations with mainland China will operate under the concept of "one country, two areas."
1992: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expresses support for the ROC's entry into the GATT during her visit to Taipei.
1993: Beijing makes public a white paper reiterating its position of solving the Taiwan problem by "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," while refusing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
1994: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly preside over a farewell ceremony marking an end to half a century of military presence on German soil by troops of the former Soviet Union.
1994: The IRA declares an unconditional end to its 25-year armed struggle for a united Ireland and its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.
1995: The ruling Kuomintang nominates incumbent President Lee Teng-hui as its presidential candidate.
1997: Britain's Princess Diana and her millionaire companion Dodi Al Fayed are killed in a Paris car crash.
1999: Raymond F. Burghardt, the newly appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
2000: ROC Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen says that the military will continue to try to obtain an early warning system after recent war games revealed Taiwan's limited means to counter mainland Chinese missile attack.
2001: Compaq Computer Inc. and Taiwan's Academia Sinica, the highest academic researrch institute in Taiwan, sign a cooperative memorandum to engage in gene and biotechnology research in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he, in the world, who possesses absolute truth who can get to the bottom of the law of his being. He who can get to the bottom of the law of his being will be able to get to the bottom of the law of being of other men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers, private groups call for demilitarization of islet

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from across the political spectrum and members of several private opinion groups called for the Ministry of National Defense Friday to demilitarize the Taiwan-held outlying islet of Wuchiu located near China's Fujian Province.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Wei-che and opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmakers Ho Min-hao and Lo Chih-ming, along with representatives of two private activist groups and a Wuchiu resident jointly called for the Defense Ministry at a news conference "to return Wuchiu to the civilians."

Wuchiu -- covering an area of 1.2 square kilometers and located between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matzu and about 73 nautical miles away from Taichung, central Taiwan -- is the only Taiwan-held islet still under complete military control, Wo said, adding that its residents, numbering about 50, continue to live under conditions equal to those during the period of martial law.

Lo said that the Defense Ministry has persistently prevented Taiwan residents from heading to Wuchiu for tourism by citing the military restrictions, bad sailing conditions and lack of space for ferry service facilities on the islet.

Lo suggested that Wuchiu -- located about 20 nautical miles away from Fujian Province's Meizhou Island -- be opened to tourists as "another Kueishan Islet" for sightseeing visits without prior approval from the Defense Ministry. Kueishan Islet, located off the eastern county of Yilan, was opened to tourists in 2000.

The news conference was held prior to an unprecedented three-day, two-night sightseeing excursion to Wuchiu organized by the two private groups. Some 100 people from Taiwan proper are expected to take part in the excursion scheduled for Aug. 31-Sept. 2.
Wuchiu, under the administrative jurisdiction of Kinmen, is Taiwan's smallest rural township, with a population of around 350, including 300 military personnel.
There is no regular ferry service between Kinmen and Wuchiu. A former elementary school on the islet has been closed for several years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's U.N. bid unrelated to independence: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reiterated Thursday that Taiwan's bid to gain membership in the United Nations has nothing to do with seeking so-called "de jure independence, " because Taiwan is already a sovereign independent country.

The MOFA dismissed as "misleading" China's claim that U.N. Resolution 2758 of 1971, which replaced the Republic of China on Taiwan with the People's Republic of China as the sole representative of China in the United Nations, recognizes Taiwan as part of China.

The MOFA made the clarification in a written statement, in response to a letter dated Aug. 17 that was written by China's U.N. permanent representative Wang Guangya to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon.

Referring to a request by some of Taiwan's diplomatic allies that Taiwan's U.N. membership application be considered in the upcoming session of the General Assembly, Wang described the move as "a blatant attempt to clamor for and create Taiwan independence."
Wang claimed resolution 2758 "is based on a self-evident fact that China is an integrated country and that Taiwan is a part of China."
According to Wang, the resolution resolved the question of China's representation in the United Nations "once and for all, politically, legally and in terms of procedures."

However, the MOFA argued in the statement that the resolution did not define the relationship between Taiwan and China nor did it empower the People's Republic of China to represent Taiwan in the United Nations.

The MOFA said Taiwan has no intention of challenging the PRC's representation in the United Nations, noting that the ROC has since 1991 no longer claimed to represent the whole of China and that the bid that the country has been promoting since 1993 to participate in the United Nations does not involve the question of "representation of China."

Taiwan, which maintains diplomatic relations with 24 countries around the world, is undoubtedly a sovereign country independent of China and is entitled to the right to become a full member of the world body, the MOFA said.
According to the MOFA, a consensus is lacking among U.N. member states on the relationship between Taiwan and China, and the United Nations should stop claiming that it follows a "one China" policy.

Of all 169 countries maintaining diplomatic relations with China, only fewer than 60 recognize or support the notion of Taiwan as a part of the PRC, while others simply "acknowledge" China's position or do not take a stance at all, the MOFA said.

On Wang's accusation that Taiwan is attempting to change the cross-strait status quo that "both Taiwan and the mainland belong to one and the same China" and working towards "de jure Taiwan independence" by pushing for a referendum on the U.N. bid, the MOFA reiterated that Taiwan is a sovereign independent country known officially as the Republic of China and has no need to declare independence.
The MOFA noted that Taiwan and China have been ruled separately and have been independent of each other since 1949, a situation which remains the status quo to this day.

President Chen Shui-bian sent a membership application letter on behalf of Taiwan to Ban July 19, but the letter was returned based on Resolution 2758. Chen sent a second letter July 31 to the U.N. secretary-general urging him to reconsider his decision, but the letter was also returned.

On Aug. 13, 15 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies submitted a motion to the General Assembly requesting that the Security Council process Taiwan's membership application according to established procedures, in the hope that the motion can be included on the agenda of the 62nd regular session of the General Assembly set to open Sept. 18 in New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to retrieve bad loans from nations severed ties: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will help retrieve bad loans from nations that have severed formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Friday.

The Foreign Ministry will not sit idly by at a time when Taiwan banking institutions or the non-profit International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) are having trouble retrieving loans granted to countries that later severed formal ties with Taiwan, Wang said.

The spokesman was referring to a China Times report Friday that quoted the Legislative Yuan Budget Center as indicating that Taiwan had incurred losses to the tune of NT$3.3 billion (US$100 million) from bad loans to nations that have severed formal diplomatic relations with the country.
Wang said that it is possible to retrieve the bad loans as all the loans were made via Taiwan banks or the ICDF in contracts with clear terms.

Citing the example of Guiana, he said that after it severed diplomatic ties with Taiwan, the ICDF filed lawsuits in the United States against the government of Guiana, and all the money that Taiwan had loaned the South American country was eventually retrieved.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 282 points to finish at 8,954, with 904 contracts traded, while December futures gained 291 points to close at 8,970, with 115 contract transactions. No transactions were recored for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT criticizes defense ministry on island airport construction

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lashed out at the Ministry of National Defense Friday for not having consulted environmental protection authorities prior to resuming construction of an airport on the Taiwan-held Taiping Island in the South China Sea.

Kuo Su-chun, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said that Taiping Island, part of the Nansha Islands, better known as the Spratlys, is an important military outpost of the Republic of China but that it is also home to green turtles -- a protected species -- whose situation is an important barometer of the state of the environment.

Kuo said it is acceptable that the Defense Ministry seeks to build an airport on Taiping based on strategic considerations, but the ministry should not have rushed the process just to complete construction in time for a planned inauguration ceremony to be presided over by President Chen Shui-bian in December as alleged in a report in the local United Daily News the day before.

According to the report, the Defense Ministry -- in defiance of the fact that a relevant budget plan had been killed by the Legislative Yuan -- has stealthily resumed the building of the airport with NT$715 million (US$21.67 million) in funds appropriated from the Executive Yuan Second Reserve Fund and has ordered that the construction be fast-tracked to meet the December deadline.

Also commenting on the report, KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-min, who had served as president of the College of Defense Management at the National Defense University 1997-2001, said it is justifiable for the Defense Ministry to build an airport on the islet located at the southernmost point of the Republic of China's territory for strategic and defense purposes.
However, Shuai called for the Defense Ministry to act in a manner that befits a ministerial-level agency, rather than proceed with the plan in a stealthy manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan issue expected to be raised at Bush-Hu meeting: U.S. official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/31/07 16:31:56 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The issue of Taiwan's push for a referendum on its U.N. bid is expected to be discussed during upcoming talks between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao at next month's meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a White House official said Thursday.

Dennis Wilder, senior director for Asian affairs of the National Security Council, said he can "almost guarantee" that Hu will raise the topic with Bush, noting that he has "almost never been to a meeting with Chinese officials where the subject of Taiwan didn't come up."

"Hu usually wants a recommitment by the United States to three communiques and to our standing one China policy. I'm sure the president will be willing to give him that, " Wilder said during a press briefing on Bush's planned attendance at the informal leadership summit of APEC slated for Sept. 8-9 in Sydney, Australia.
Wilder said the United States is very supportive of Taiwan on many fronts, such as its participation in international organizations, including APEC and the World Health Organization.

However, Wilder said this does not include membership in the United Nations, which requires statehood, because "Taiwan, or the Republic of China, is not at this point a state in the international community."
"The position of the United States government is that the ROC, Republic of China, is an issue undecided, and it has been left undecided, as you know, for many, many years," he said.
Wilder said it is "perplexing" to Washington as to why Taiwan thinks it would be useful to hold a referendum on the U.N. issue.
According to Wilder, Taiwan is not going to be able to join the United Nations under current circumstances, and the move only "adds a degree of tension" to cross-strait relations.

Meanwhile, Wilder urged China to work to lower the tensions across the Taiwan Strait, in light of the large-scale military build-up opposite Taiwan, and reach out to the duly elected leaders in Taiwan.

Over the past few months, U.S. government officials have on many occasions expressed opposition to Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on the U.N. bid on the grounds that it would increase tensions in the Taiwan Strait.

In an interview on Hong Kong-based Phoenix Star TV Monday, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte said the United States is opposed to the referendum because Washington sees it as a step "towards a declaration of independence of Taiwan" and "towards an alteration of the status quo."

DOC.HEADLINE: Gregorian calendar clause added to DPP 'normal country' resolution

TEXT.P: A clause calling for the adoption of the Gregorian calendar in Taiwan and the dropping of the Republic of China's "Minkuo" calendar has been included in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) newly passed "normal country" resolution, party sources said Friday.
The clause was adopted after a last-ditch effort by DPP Legislator Trong Chai who concurrently serves as convener of a nine-member task force authorized to draft the resolution, the sources said.

Chai insisted on incorporating the clause to signify the party's efforts at linking Taiwan to more closely to the international community at a meeting of the DPP Central Executive Committee Thursday, during which the "normal country" resolution was passed.
Except for the addition of the "calendar" clause, the text of the final resolution was same as the draft version completed Monday.
The resolution, which is set to become a critical part of the party's platform for the 2008 presidential election, was finalized after more than three months of extensive discussions.

The resolution states that the country's official name should be rectified and that a new constitution should be written, but it stops short of specifying a timetable or what national title should be adopted.

Instead, the resolution states that as it has become very difficult to use the name Republic of China in the international community, the country should apply to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other international bodies under the name "Taiwan."
The resolution also stresses the need for the nation to hold a referendum at the proper time to underscore Taiwan's independent statehood.
DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said the resolution will be put forth for approval at the party's national congress slated for Sept. 30.
The resolution identifies China's hegemony and the remnants of the Kuomintang's (KMT's) 55 years of authoritarian rule as major threats Taiwan faces in its struggle for normalization.

According to the resolution, Beijing's "one China" principle and its Anti- Secession Law against Taiwan threaten Taiwan's sovereignty and security and have caused "abnormalities" in Taiwan's foreign relations.

The resolution also identifies the KMT's huge amount of "ill-gotten" party assets and the remnants of its authoritarian "party-state" system as threats to Taiwan's democratic development, as they hinder normal inter-party competition.
It further notes that the obsolescence of the ROC constitutional framework has led to the country's "constitutional abnormalities" since the DPP won the presidency in 2000.

According to the resolution, the previous government's suppression of Taiwanese culture has caused confusion among the citizens of the country concerning national identity, and the preferential treatment given to certain special groups has sabotaged social unity and led to "abnormalities in social justice."

To resolve all these abnormalities, the resolution calls for reinforcement of Taiwan-centric education in school curriculums, promotion of transitional justice, elimination of inequalities in resources distribution, acceleration of judicial reform and retrieval of the KMT's "ill-gotten" party assets.

The DPP headquarters-drafted version originally suggested that the country's title be changed to "Taiwan, " the existing "five branch" government system be replaced by a "three-branch" system, and the special municipality designation in the local government hierarchy be scrapped.

As some DPP heavyweights, including Frank Hsieh, the party's candidate in the 2008 presidential election, questioned the feasibility of these proposals being implemented, the proposals were all dropped from the draft resolution adopted Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices soar on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange soared Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 210.95 points to close at 8,982.16.
The bourse opened at 8,807.7 and fluctuated between 8,982.16 and 8,785.7 during trading. A total of 5.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$166.14 billion (US$5.03 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 6.4 percent, followed by textile stocks and banking and financial shares both at 3.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 3.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 3.3 percent, paper and pulp issues at 3 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2 percent, and construction issues at 1.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,224 to 500, with 216 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elections, media hinder transitional justice in Taiwan: academics

TEXT.P: Scholars discussing transitional justice agreed in a seminar Thursday that while transitional justice should have arisen out of a non-partisan campaign, electoral politics and the media have become necessary means of pursuing those ends.

"Transitional justice in Taiwan should have been built on a non-partisan consensus because justice is a universal value. But more often than not, it has became a partisan movement because the related bills failed to pass through the Legislative Yuan, " said Ku Chung-hwa, a professor at National Chengchi University (NCU).

Rather than operating along ideal lines, the movement has become "an electoral mobilization tool, " said Ku in a seminar titled "Complete Justice, Better Democracy" and organized by the pro-independence Taiwan Thinktank.

It is easy to understand why the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has done all it could to block bills and oppose the campaign, because the movement was directed to the KMT, said Hsu Yung-ming, a research fellow at Academia Sinica.
Transitional justice in Taiwan cannot be achieved without a legislative majority, which means the people of Taiwan have to voice their opinion in the elections, Hsu said.

Media bias is another of the major reasons that transitional justice has been so difficult to implement. What Taiwan needs, said Lilian Wang, a journalism professor at NCU, is a public forum and mass media outlets to publicize the truth so that people might understand their "real history."

DOC.HEADLINE: 85% of manufacturing firms upbeat about business prospects: survey

TEXT.P: A majority of 85 percent of Taiwanese manufacturing firms responding to a recent survey are optimistic about business prospects for the second half of the year, a local think tank researcher said Friday.
The survey of Taiwanese firms was conducted by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) in July to explore their views of future business prospects, said Chen Miao, a TIER researcher.

Citing survey results, Chen stated that the number of manufacturing firms optimistic about business prospects in July rose 18.8 percent from June, while firms expressing pessimism about the future decreased 12.5 percent over the same period.

However, the survey also shows a decrease in the number of firms of all types expressing optimism about business prospects in the second half year, sliding to 37.7 percent from 42.8 in June. Firms anticipating that business will remain constant was unchanged at 47 percent, while those which are pessimistic about the second half of the year increased to 15.0 percent from 10.7 percent the month before.

According to Chen, higher prices for raw materials has caused some of the uncertainty, but increasing demands on the export market, and the manufacturing industry's upcoming boom season have offset much of those concerns.
The manufacturing industry's business climate index for July reached 119.24, up 3.18 points over the June figure, setting a new high for the year to date, Chen said.

Meanwhile, the business climate index for the service industry in July stood at 120.06 points, up 1.09 points from the June figure, Chen said, adding that the figure shows firms have confidence in Taiwan's future economic development.

Pointing to specific lines of business in the service sector, Chen said that banks are currently being more conservative due to the impact of the subprime loan crisis, while travel agents are pessimistic about future development owing to a decrease in the number of group tours in the second half year. However, he also noted that other sectors, such as marine transport, are upbeat as they are entering their high seasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14 local golfers to compete in U.S., Japan tournaments

TEXT.P: A group of 14 Taiwanese golfers will depart for the United States and Japan in September to compete in qualification tournaments under the full sponsorship of a local technology company, a spokesman of the company said Friday.

Wintek Corp. launched the sponsorship program three years ago in an effort to help local golfers win prizes in international events and to raise the country's profile on the world stage, the spokesman said.

Two of the Taiwanese golfers will take part in both the U.S. and Japanese qualification tournaments, the spokesman noted. A total of 11 golfers from the Taiwanese group will compete in the Japanese event, while five will take part in the U.S. event, according to the spokesman.

Chen Tze-chung, one of the two golfers who will compete in both events, finished second at the U.S. Open Championship in 1985, the spokesman said, adding that since then, he has won a number of tournaments in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President names new Supreme Court head

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has named Yang Jen-shou, chief commissioner of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries as the new president of the nation's Supreme Court, according to a press released by the Judicial Yuan Thursday.
Yang will succeed Wu Chii-pin, the incumbent Supreme Court president, who will retire Sept. 12.

According to the press statement, the 65-year-old Yang has been a judge at district, high and supreme court levels, and served as president of district courts in Taoyuan, Banciao, Kaohsiung and Taipei.

Yang has also served on the Council of Grand Justices, and worked as Judicial Yuan secretary-general and director-general of the Civil Department and Department of Administrative Litigation and Discipline. His legal career also includes holding positions as the judge and president of both the Taiwan High Court and its Kaohsiung Branch Court.

An independent commission established by Congress to assess Iraq's security forces will recommend remaking the 26,000-member national police force to purge it of corrupt officers and Shiite militants suspected of complicity in sectarian killings, administration and military officials said Thursday.
The Wall Street Journal: S&P President Corbet Is ReplacedFSharma Is Tapped to Lead Ratings Firm as Criticism Of Subprime Role Mounts
McGraw-Hill Cos. replaced the top executive at Standard & Poor's Corp. as criticism of the company's financial-information division mounts for its role in the unfolding subprime-mortgage crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA urged to lodge protest against France over humiliation

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) was urged Friday to lodge a protest against France over an incident in which two Taiwan citizens were stripped, searched and detained for two days simply because they were holding two different kinds of Taiwanese passports.

Kuo Su-chun, a whip of the opposition Kuomintang legislative caucus, said the Foreign Ministry should protest the humiliating treatment endured by the two men, who work at a Taipei County-based high-tech company, at the main Paris airport two weeks ago, and demand an open apology from the French government over the incident.

Kuo was referring to a report in Thursday's edition of the Apple Daily that the two staff members were on their way from Paris to London for business when they were detained by authorities at Charles de Gaulle International Airport on suspicion of being terrorists because they were holding two different Taiwan passports -- one copy bearing the name "Taiwan" on the cover, the other without.

The two men were handed over by British Airways workers to French police at the airport, after which they were stripped to their underpants, searched, and transported to a detention room where they sat for two days and two nights before being released, according to the report.

According to the report, after the two men informed their head office in Taipei County of the incident, company authorities called the MOFA for assistance, only to be asked by MOFA officials why the two men didn't file for help online in "real time?"
Responding to the Apple Daily report, MOFA officials said that no Taiwan passport holder had been detained in foreign countries before for holding new or old copies of Taiwanese passports.

To date, the officials added, neither the British Airways nor the French authorities has given any reasons why the two men were detained and questioned. They only informed Taiwan's representative office in France of the procedures for the victims to file complaints, the officials said, adding that outbound travelers are welcome to contact the ministry for emergency relief or assistance.
