The TimesG Vaccine warning as measles cases triple
Parents are being urged to give their children the measles, mumps and rubella jab before the start of the new school year after an unprecedented surge of measles cases was recorded over the summer holidays.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-Taiwan German lawmaker writes to U.N. chief on Taiwan membership
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/31/07 19:49:54 (By Lin Yu-li and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Wilhelm Josef Sebastian, chairman of the German-Taiwan Friendship Group of the German Bundestag, has written a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, expressing support for Taiwan's application to join the international body.

The group's 61 members are drawn from various German political parties. Sebastian, a member of the Christian Democratic Union, visited Taiwan in February this year at the head of a delegation from the group.
In the letter delivered Aug. 21, Sebastian emphasized that Taiwan is an independent nation with its own people, land, government, and ability to develop diplomatic relations with other countries.
Sebastian said in the letter that Taiwan's lack of support is regrettable for it is a country working hard to strengthen democracy and participate positively in international affairs.

According to Sebastian, it was sad that Taiwan -- a peaceful and democratic country that has contributed to regional peace -- has been crowded out of the international community, while China, which seriously and repeatedly violates human rights, is recognized in international society.

Sebastian said refusing Taiwan's application to join the United Nations runs counter to the organization's principles, and called on Ban to help place Taiwan's application for entry on the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly scheduled for opening in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC is country: KMT presidential candidate

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is certainly a country from the viewpoint of the ROC, Ma Ying-jeou, the presidential candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said Friday.

There are more than 20 members of the international community that recognize the ROC as a country, and it is regarded as a "foreign country" according to the law of the United States, said Ma, who holds a doctorate in law from Harvard University.

Ma made the comment in response to media inquiries on public remarks made a day earlier in Washington, D.C. by Dennis Wilder, senior director for Asian affairs of White House's National Security Council, regarding Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations.
Wilder pointed out that membership in the United Nations requires statehood and said that "Taiwan, or the Republic of China, is not at this point a state in the international community."
"The position of the United States government is that the [status of the] ROC is an issue undecided and has been left undecided... for many years," he said.
Ma said that since the United States severed diplomatic ties with the ROC in 1979, it has held fast to this viewpoint.

Ma said the U.S. is concerned that Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its U.N. bid under the name of Taiwan will result in a unilateral change to the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo, triggering a cross-strait crisis.

However, a KMT proposal to hold a referendum on "the Republic of China's return to the United Nations" will not raise such concerns because the ROC was one of the founders of the international organization, Ma said, predicting that such a "flexible and pragmatic" proposal will not lead to cross-strait tension.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE clarifies report about adjustment of school break duration

TEXT.P: The minister of education has not instructed local schools to shorten breaks between classes from the current 10 minutes to five minutes as reported by a local newspaper, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Friday.

MOE Secretary-General Chuang Kuo-jung was referring to a front-page report carried in the United Daily News that day claiming that Minister of Education Tu Chen-sheng had demanded that local schools cut short class breaks to make time for an exercise promotion program known as the "cheerful life" plan.

The report immediately drew criticism from opposition lawmakers, who claimed that the program is designed at the expense of the needs of schoolgirls, who "by nature" require longer toilet breaks than boys.
In response, Chuang said the newspaper report was false.

"The minister did not ask local elementary or junior high schools to shorten class breaks to five minutes. The minister only suggested that school authorities more flexibly adjust the break between the second and third classes to give students a longer time to exercise," Chuang explained.

Given that many Taiwanese students are in poor physical condition due to a lack of exercise, the MOE is hopeful that school-based physical activities can be extended. Everyday, every student should spend at least 30 minutes stretching and exercising at school, Chuang said, noting this is the reasoning behind the MOE's proposal.
However, every school has the right to work out its own schedule for recommended activities, based on their individual campus environments, he added.
As for the false news report, Chuang said the MOE is considering taking legal action against the media outlet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Toona sinensis extract can increase male fertility: research

TEXT.P: Results of recent research programs at National Cheng Kung University show that extracts from the toona sinensis tree, also known as Chinese mahogany, can improve male fertility.

Chang Sue-joan, professor and chairwoman of the Department of Life sciences of Cheng Kung University, told a seminar Friday that a series of research programs conducted under her leadership between 2003 and 2006 have shown that toona sinensis extracts can minimize the harm caused by oxidative stress to human sperm.
Some of her research results were published in 2005 at the 18th International Congress of Nutrition in Durban, South Africa, and published in the South African Journal of Clinical Nutrition.

Chang said the World Health Organization has provided evidence showing an overall reduction in male fertility during the past few decades. She added that the decreasing quality of semen and declining sperm count is due partly to long- term exposure to oxidative stress.
She said that toona sinensis could be the answer to the issue of deteriorating sperm count.
Tender shoots of the toona sinensis have long been used by Chinese as a traditional leafy vegetable or crushed as a spice to add flavor to bean curd and noodles.
Results of other research in Taiwan have shown that the effects of toona sinensis extract might improve the quality of spermatozoa of mice and increase their sperm motility.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiping Island runway necessary for humanitarian rescue: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) needs to build a runway on the Taiwan- held Taiping Island in the South China Sea to facilitate humanitarian rescues and sustainable management of the territory, MND spokesman Yu Szu-tsu said Friday.

Yu defended the ministry's building of the runway on Taiping Island, part of the Nansha Islands, better known as the Spratlys, saying that while engaging in the construction job, the builders have paid extra attention to the protection of animals and plants living on and surrounding the island.
Yu also denied that building the airport has anything to do with an alleged visit to be paid by President Chen Shui-bian to the island.
He said that so far, the Presidential Office has no plans to arrange such a visit.
The spokesman made the remarks after the Apple Daily reported Friday that the Defense Ministry has turned Taiping Island into a gravel field in preparation for airport construction.

The development poses a threat to green turtles -- a protected species -- which have made Taiping Island their home and whose situation is an important barometer of the state of the environment, the paper claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE takes measures to ease burden on primary, junior high students

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has come up with a four-year plan to provide NT$50 million (US$1.51 million) annually beginning next year for the installation or repair of storage cabinets at junior high and elementary schools, an MOE official said Friday.
Pan Wen-chung, director of the MOE Elementary Education Department, made the remarks a day after an education meeting to discuss relevant topics.
Pan said that to reduce the weight of the books children need to carry to and from school, the MOE has decided to subsidize schools to provide storage for use by students.
In the initial stage, Pan said priority will be given to younger students at elementary schools in every city and county, according to Pan.

In addition to the problem of heavy backpacks, Taiwan's primary and secondary students spend more hours studying at schools compared with their peers in other countries, Pan noted, adding that in coping with this issue, MOE Minister Tu Cheng-sheng has commissioned experts to study the feasibility of implementing various adjustments and reforms to ease the burden on students.
He said experts have been commissioned to develop courses that serve to advance students' physical and mental health and meet the needs and special requirements of various schools.

During the meeting, Tu also encouraged schools to provide versatile curricula and activities for students to facilitate the development of diversified education, with funds to be provided by the MOE to hire teachers, according to Pan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense Ministry defends islet road expansion project

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has defended a construction project to expand the main road on Taiwan-held Taiping Island in the Nansha, or Spratly, islands in the South China Sea, saying that the road is needed for sustainable development and as an emergency runway.

The ministry made the remarks in a press release issued Friday after an evening newspaper said the day before that former Defense Minister Lee Jye secretly allocated funds for the project to construct an airport during his tenure. The construction was later suspended as the budget was killed by the Legislative Yuan.

Recently, the MND began to send troops to the Nansha islands for a planned resumption of the project slated to kick off Sept. 25, so that the construction can be completed before President Chen Shui-bian travels to the outlying islet to inaugurate the airport in December, the report claimed.

However, the ministry said in the press release that it has obtained the needed budget for the road expansion project by law, has won the approval of the Executive Yuan and has notified the Legislative Yuan of the project.

The islet's main road will be expanded to 1,150 meters in length and 30 meters in width, the press release said, adding that the expanded road will be used by people and vehicle at normal times, and by aircraft for emergency landings and takeoffs during humanitarian relief missions.

Meanwhile, the MND said it has taken measures to protect the environment while planning the project, although the Environmental Protection Administration required no environmental impact assessment for the project.

Under the measures, the MND said it will avoid areas of flourishing trees and will transplant trees prior to the construction. The construction area will be located on either side of the main road where there are fewer trees, the ministry said, adding that the construction area will only account for 10 percent of the islet's total land area.
In addition, the MND said the construction troops will have strict orders not to damage primitive trees or sandy areas frequented by sea turtles.

It added that it will use gravel transported from Taiwan proper rather than from the islet itself and that it will transport discarded goods to Taiwan proper instead of leaving them on the islet, according to the press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA urges U.N. to justly deal with Taiwan's membership application

TEXT.P: The United Nations should justly deal with Taiwan's membership application and address Taiwan's right to join the world body, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman said Friday.

The appeal came two days after the U.N. Secretariat distributed documents related to a motion initiated by Taiwan's diplomatic allies regarding the country's latest U.N. bid, to U.N. missions of all member countries.

Taiwan adopted a new strategy this year in its bid for U.N. membership, using the name Taiwan, following its failure in the past 14 years to gain membership under its official national title of the Republic of China.
The Secretariat provides versions of the motion in six languages -- English, simplified Chinese, French, Spanish, Russian and Arabic -- on its official Web site, the MOFA spokesman noted.

It has also distributed letters written by Kiribati and El Salvador to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon in support of Taiwan's U.N. membership motion to U.N. missions of all member countries, the spokesman said.

President Chen Shui-bian's two letters previously sent to Ban to express the country's wish to join the world body were incorporated in an explanatory note attached to the motion filed by Taiwan's allies on its behalf, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu Science Park signs MOU with Baton Rouge

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science Park Administration (HSPA) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the U.S. city of Baton Rouge in the state of Louisiana Friday on cooperation in biotech business.

HSPA Director-General Huang To-juei and Baton Rouge Mayor Melvin L. Holden signed the MOU in a cermony held at the park in the northern county of Hsinchu that regulates exchanges on research information and personnel, technology transfers and business development.

According to Huang, Holden was impressed by the Hsinchu Science Park when he visited Taiwan in 2005 and so welcomed cooperation between the two sides. He said the park's industrial application of innovative manufacturing technologies will be complementary to the city's advanced research in biotechnology.

Baton Rouge is the state capital and has a well-developed biotechnology industry, with many research institutes working in the fields of stem cell, pharmaceutical, biomedical, microbiology, biochip and health food research.
Louisiana is also an important center of America's petrochemical industry. It has the biggest petroleum refinery and accounts for a quarter of all of America's petrochemical products, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Immigration agency to take measures against escapes

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency under the Ministry of the Interior will improve facilities and personnel at detention centers in an effort to prevent detained illegal immigrants from escaping, an agency official said Friday.
The agency decided to replace dilapidated iron fences, update security systems and monitor illegal immigrants' communication records to keep better control of their movements, the official said.

According to the official, the National Police Agency has appointed 120 people in alternative military service to help cover nightshifts at detention centers in order to increase the intensity of patrols.

The immigration agency has also increased the capacity of detention centers in Kaohsiung City and Tainan County in southern Taiwan and plans to set up new centers in Nantou County in central Taiwan and Kaohsiung County, to ease overcrowding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vietnamese cultural festival to be held in Taipei

TEXT.P: A Vietnamese cultural festival will be held in Taipei Sunday, Vietnam's Independence Day, the Taipei city government's Department of Labor announced Friday.

The celebration, which will be held in 228 Memorial Park, is aimed at easing the homesickness of Vietnamese workers in Taipei City and to recognize their contributions to the city, said Department of Labor Commissioner Su Yin-kuei.

One of the most special events in the festival will be a "slow cycling" competition, Su said. The difference of this traditional Vietnamese competition to other cycling competitions is that the last cyclist to arrive at the finishing line is declared the winner.
"The unique event probably appropriately reflects the characteristics of the Vietnamese as they are always laid back and easy-going, " according to Su.
Three dance troupes -- Minh-hai, Datviet and Quoc Vuong -- that consist of Vietnamese workers will also perform.

Nguyen Ba Hai, head of the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei's Division of Labor Administration, encouraged all Vietnamese workers and families with Vietnamese spouses to take part in the event so that children from these families can better understand the culture of their mothers' home country, Nguyen said.

The event is a part of the 2007 Southeast Asian Cultural Activities series organized by the Migrant Workers' Cultural Center (MWCC) , an organization under the city government. In addition to Vietnam, the MWCC also organizes similar cultural events for workers from Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 40% of men in Aug. 17 gay party infected with HIV: health official

TEXT.P: Nearly 40 percent of the 43 homosexual men taken into custody from a gay house party when Typhoon Sepat was pounding Taiwan on the night of Aug. 17 are HIV- positive, a senior health official said Friday.

Chou Chih-hao, deputy director of the Center for Disease Control under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, told reporters that blood tests show 16 of the men to be HIV positive, accounting for 37.2 percent of the group.
Of the 16 HIV carriers, 14 have been placed on the Center for Disease Control's list for monitoring HIV prevention.
According to Chou, 18 of the men have syphilis, while 10 of them -- aged between 21 and 40 -- are infected with syphilis and are also HIV-positive.
Chou quoted statistics as showing that from November 2004 to August this year, police have busted 14 gay house parties where ecstasy and other illicit drugs were used in the orgies.
He said that of the 354 men taken into custody, 126 were found to be infected with HIV.
In one of the parties in November 2004, 60 percent were HIV carriers, Chou said, adding that many of the partygoers had no idea what kind of sexual partners they were dealing with.

DOC.HEADLINE: President nominates grand justice as new Judicial Yuan head

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has nominated Lai Ing-jaw and Hsieh Tsay-chuan, both of whom are grand justices, as the new Judicial Yuan president and vice president, respectively, a Presidential Office spokesman confirmed Friday.

The spokesman made the announcement after Hsiao Tzu-chung, deputy director- general of the First Bureau under the Presidential Office, referred the nomination list to the Legislative Yuan for approval earlier the same day.

The nomination list also includes eight candidates for seats on the Council of Grand Justices -- Yeh Sai-ying, Lin Hsi-yao, Che hi-ming, Tsai Ching-yu, Liu Hsing-yi, Lee Chen-shan, Hsu Chih-hsiung and Yeh Jiunn-rong.
The spokesman said the legislature is expected to review and exercise its power of consent or refusal on the president-proposed nomination list when its new session opens next month.
Lai, 61, has a Ph.D. in law from Harvard University. He served as deputy Taiwan governor, vice premier and a senior adviser to the president before becoming a grand justice in 2003.

Hsieh, 63, graduated from National Taiwan University's Department of Law and has a master's degree in law from Southern Methodist University in Dallas, Texas. He has served as the Taichung District Court president, director of the civil affairs department of the Judicial Yuan and director of the Training Institute for Judges and Prosecutors. He has been a grand justice since 2003.

Among the 15 seats on the Council of Grand Justices for which Chen nominated candidates in 2003, eight of them, including the post of president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, are for four-year terms, while the remainder are for eight-year terms. However, as former Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo resigned and Yang Jen-shou left to serve as head of the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries, there are currently only 13 grand justices.

Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, who concurrently serves as a grand justice, as well as five other grand justices, namely Lin Yung-mo, Wang He- hsiung, Yu Hsueh-ming, Tseng You-tien and Liao Yi-nan, will see their terms expire at the end of September.
This is why the president has to put forward a list of eight grand justice nominees to fill the vacancies.
Other incumbent grand justices, including Lai, Hsu Pi-hu, Peng Feng-chih, Lin Tze-yi, Hsu Tsung-li, Hsieh Tsay-chuan and Hsu Yu-hsiu, will see their terms expire in September 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: No allies could make Taiwan `2nd Hong Kong': president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that if Taiwan were to abandon all of its diplomatic allies for the sake of saving money, it could become another Hong Kong to be annexed by China.
Chen made the remarks in a political talk show broadcast on Sanlih cable TV in response to criticism by some opposition figures of his recent visit to Central America.

During his three-nation Central American tour that took him to Honduras, El Salvador and Nicaragua, Chen promised development aid to the three allies, drawing accusations that he was engaging in checkbook diplomacy. Some critics suggested that Taiwan should drop all of its allies to save money

Describing that suggestion as "narrow-minded, " Chen noted that Taiwan used to be an aid recipient. "Since we have emerged as an economic powerhouse, we should be more magnanimous and forward-looking in extending a helping hand to other countries in need, " he said, adding that if Taiwan were to lose all its allies, it could become a province of China.
On the U.S. concern about Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, Chen said he attaches great importance to the U.S. concern.

Nevertheless, Chen said Taiwan has its own national interests and value that cannot be compromised. It would be an irony to the spirit of the U.S. founding fathers if Taiwan were to be asked to forsake its pursuit of democratic values, he added.

In an interview with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Star TV Monday, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte said the U.S. government opposes Taiwan's U.N. membership referendum plan because it views that kind of referendum as a move toward declaration of independence of Taiwan.

Stressing that Taiwan is already an independent sovereign state, Chen said Taiwan need not declare independence. As referendum is a basic human right, Chen argued that Taiwan should not be required to give up its referendum plan.

"Taiwan's democratic development should not be subject to any unreasonable restriction. We don't want caged democracy. With more than 70 percent of Taiwan people backing the quest for a U.N. seat under the name of Taiwan, I'm not in a position to block the holding of a referendum to have our people's voice heard in the international community and their common aspiration known to the world, " Chen added.
